site_title: Japan travellers hit by second flight delay at Tokyo's Haneda
summary: Japan Airlines Co scrapped 24 flights at Tokyo's Haneda airport on Friday due to a baggage-loading system malfunction, affecting 3,200 people. This is the second time in less than two weeks that JAL has cancelled flights at Haneda. The issue is a recurring problem, as JAL delayed over 100 flights two years ago and ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's biggest carrier, scrapped 146 flights last week due to a similar check-in system issue.

site_title: Update: World's top banks in US govt cross-hairs over dealings with 1MDB
summary: US officials have requested details from Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan Chase & Co on their dealings with 1MDB, amid global investigations into the Malaysian state fund's alleged corruption and money-laundering. The probes, led by the US Department of Justice, also involve Goldman Sachs and other international banks. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has denied wrongdoing, but opposition leaders call for his resignation. The investigations follow a Wall Street Journal report that over $1 billion was deposited into Najib's account, which is believed to have originated from 1MDB.

site_title: Alibaba scraps plan to inject pharmacy business in healthcare affiliate
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has scrapped plans to inject its pharmacy business into a Hong Kong-listed affiliate, Alibaba Health Information Technology Ltd, due to regulatory uncertainties over the deal and China's broader healthcare industry. The decision comes amid China's efforts to overhaul its healthcare market, with new regulations creating a complex business environment. Alibaba will instead invest in its health food, dietary supplements, and nutritional products business, currently operated by its online platform Tmall.

site_title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo asked by US to save records tied to 1MDB
summary: US authorities have requested that major banks JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Deutsche Bank retain and turn over records related to improper transfers from the Malaysian state fund 1MDB. The banks are not targets of the investigation and have not been accused of wrongdoing. Goldman Sachs, which underwrote $6.5 billion in bond deals for 1MDB, is cooperating with the Justice Department's efforts to gather information. Authorities worldwide are trying to piece together evidence to determine if billions of dollars from 1MDB were siphoned into the personal accounts of politically connected individuals, including Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on BOJ survey, weak Wall St lead
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 1, 2016, after a Bank of Japan survey showed declining confidence among Japan's largest manufacturers and following a weak lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.23% to 16,719.56, and the Topix index lost 0.29% to 1,343.24.

site_title: US offers Ukraine US$335m in security aid
summary: The US has offered Ukraine $335 million in additional security aid, following a meeting between US Vice President Joe Biden and Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko in Washington. The aid comes as Ukraine faces an economic and security crisis since Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014. The White House announced the move as Ukraine's parliament sacked its chief prosecutor, amid concerns over corruption. This is part of a larger $1 billion loan guarantee deal signed last year, aimed at helping Ukraine rebuild its economy and surmount the Russia-backed insurgency.

site_title: Private home prices down 0.7% in Q1: URA
summary: Private home prices in Singapore declined 0.7% in Q1, according to flash estimates from the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This follows a 0.5% decline in the fourth quarter of 2015. The decline was mainly attributed to suburban and city fringe areas, with Outside Central Region prices falling 0.9% and Rest of Central Region prices dropping 0.4%.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei sinks to 1-month low after BOJ tankan chills mood
summary: Japanese stocks fell to a 1-month low on Friday after the Bank of Japan's quarterly corporate survey showed business sentiment among large manufacturers at its lowest level in nearly three years. The Nikkei share average dropped 3.6% to 16,164.16, its lowest close since March 1, with the broader Topix index also falling 3.4% to 1,301.40. The decline was attributed to sapped risk appetite and weighed down stocks across the board.

site_title: Indonesia central bank wants end-2016 inflation at 4-4.5%: deputy gov
summary: Indonesia's central bank aims to manage inflation around 4-4.5% by the end of 2016, according to Deputy Governor Mirza Adityaswara. The current inflation rate in March was 4.45%. The bank expects inflation to cool in April after the government cut fuel prices and transportation tariffs. However, price pressures are expected to increase as the harvest season ends and demand rises ahead of the Muslim fasting month in June. The central bank's official target for inflation is 3-5%.

site_title: Obama promises 'candid' exchange with Xi amid maritime disputes
summary: US President Barack Obama has pledged a candid discussion with Chinese President Xi Jinping on maritime disputes in the South China Sea, amid concerns over Beijing's military buildup. The two leaders will discuss human rights, cyber issues, and the disputed waterway, following China's construction of artificial islands. The US has carried out "freedom of navigation" operations in the area, and Washington is seeking to maintain pressure on North Korea to denuclearize, with both countries committed to the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Wang reclaims top spot among Asia's rich as property unit jumps
summary: Wang Jianlin regains top spot as Asia's richest person, surpassing Li Ka-shing with a $1.6 billion increase in his net worth, reaching $31.5 billion. Alibaba's Jack Ma drops to third place with a $1.8 billion loss. Wang's fortune rose after Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co. jumped 18% following a possible privatization. This marks a significant recovery from a $6.6 billion loss in 2016 amid China's slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Wang Jianlin has become the richest person in Asia. Again.

site_title: Brexit risks taking multi-trillion euro trading from London
summary: London's financial centre risks losing trillions of euros in derivatives trading if Britain votes to leave the EU, according to euro zone central bank officials. The European Central Bank wants oversight of the business, citing a desire to avert a disaster like the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse. The City of London, a major employer and tax generator, faces the risk of losing its position as Europe's financial capital. Supporters of a British exit argue that London's demise as a financial centre was proven wrong in the past, but experts warn that the ECB's full powers would be used to exert pressure on continental banks.

site_title: Japan to hold global econ meetings April 7 and 13
summary: Japan's government plans to hold global economic and financial meetings on April 7 and 13, inviting experts such as Nobel Economics laureate Jean Tirole and Organisation for Economic Cooperation head Angel Gurria. This comes ahead of the Group of Seven summit in May. The meetings are part of Japan's preparation for the global economic discussions.

site_title: Aussie climbs as China manufacturing grows first time since June
summary: The Australian dollar rose to a nine-month high after China's manufacturing unexpectedly expanded for the first time since June, boosting Australia's economic growth. The Aussie added 0.4% to 76.89 US cents, its highest level since July 1. This growth is fueled by China's industrial activity, which relies on raw materials from Australia. However, analysts remain cautious, citing a bearish outlook for the Aussie at current levels.

site_title: Moody's fined HK$11m as Hong Kong tribunal sides with SFC
summary: Moody's Investors Service was fined HK$11 million by a Hong Kong tribunal for breaching the Securities and Futures Commission's code of conduct in 2011. The tribunal ruled that Moody's acted as a regulated entity providing credit-rating services, which meant the firm had to abide by the regulator's code. The report in question used a framework of warning signs about weak corporate governance at Chinese companies, leading to a plunge in shares and increased borrowing costs. Moody's disagreed with the notion that the SFC can regulate the content of research publications, and the company has 30 days to challenge the decision.

site_title: Sterling slips, posts worst quarter since 2008
summary: Sterling slumped to its worst quarter since 2008, falling 6.3% against the US dollar, due to concerns over a possible British exit from the European Union. The pound weakened by half a percent against the euro, with markets rattled by the prospect of a Brexit, which could threaten foreign investment flows and the UK's economy. Despite stronger-than-estimated GDP growth, the pound's decline was driven by risk-averse markets and uncertainty about interest rate hikes from the Bank of England.

site_title: Cameron holds crisis talks as UK steel fights for its future
summary: Prime Minister David Cameron held crisis talks to address the potential sale of Tata Steel's UK business, which could lead to 15,000 job losses and threaten Britain's steel industry. The sale of Tata Steel's UK operations, including the Port Talbot steel plant, has raised concerns about the industry's future. The talks aim to salvage the industry and prevent significant job losses.

site_title: Argos owner backs £1.4b Sainsbury's takeover
summary: Sainsbury's has secured a £1.4 billion offer to acquire Home Retail Group, the parent company of Argos, after rival suitor Steinhoff International withdrew. Home Retail shareholders will receive 0.321 new Sainsbury's shares and 55 pence in cash for each share, plus an additional cash payment. The deal was recommended by Home Retail's board and clears Sainsbury's for a clear run to complete the acquisition.

site_title: Asia: Shares led lower by Japan, US dollar still groggy
summary: Asian shares declined, led by Japan, as investors entered the new quarter cautiously. China's manufacturing sector expanded in March for the first time in nine months, with its PMI reaching 50.2, beating forecasts. Despite this, Japan's shares fell. The US dollar remained weak.

site_title: Thai March consumer prices fall for 15th straight month
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer prices fell 0.46% in March for the 15th consecutive month, mainly due to declining oil prices. The core inflation rate remained steady at 0.75%. This decline gives the central bank leeway to cut interest rates to support weak domestic growth.

site_title: US, Canada issue joint alert on 'ransomware' after hospital attacks
summary: The US and Canada issued a joint cyber alert warning against a surge in ransomware attacks, which infect computers with viruses that encrypt data and demand payments for its release. The attacks have affected individuals, businesses, and government agencies, including US hospitals and police departments. The alert advises against paying hackers, as it does not guarantee the encrypted files will be released. Instead, it only ensures the malicious actors receive the victim's money. The consequences of ransomware attacks include loss of sensitive information, disruption of operations, and harm to a victim's reputation.

site_title: Lockheed, Pentagon still working toward F-35 fighter deal
summary: Lockheed Martin and the Pentagon have missed their March target for a $15 billion F-35 fighter jet deal, but sources indicate they are close to completing the contracts by April. Despite the delay, negotiations are not at an impasse, with one source describing the process as "getting down to the nitty gritty." The deal's completion is seen as a significant milestone for the F-35 program.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat launches startup initiative, fintech office
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat launched SG-Innovate, a startup initiative, and a fintech office, which will catalyze innovation and commercialize new technologies. SG-Innovate will be formed as a company under the National Research Foundation, with Steve Leonard as its CEO. The fintech office, co-led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will promote Singapore as a fintech hub and review funding schemes. The initiatives aim to create better jobs and a more vibrant economy.

site_title: Brazil prosecutors charge prominent banker Safra in bribe scheme
summary: Brazilian prosecutors charged Joseph Safra, the world's richest banker, in a bribe scheme involving up to $500 million in corporate tax debts. Safra, majority owner of Banco Safra SA, was not directly involved in negotiations, but his executive, João Inácio Puga, reported to Safra on alleged bribery plans. The charges follow a broader police inquiry into kickbacks by companies, including steelmaker Gerdau SA. Safra's spokesman denied the charges, stating they were unfounded and there was no just cause for the legal proceedings.

site_title: US women soccer champs demand equal wages, conditions
summary: Five US women's soccer players, including Carli Lloyd and Hope Solo, have filed a federal wage discrimination complaint against the US Soccer Federation, claiming they earn 40% less than male players despite generating more income for the federation. The complaint alleges disparities in compensation for friendly matches, sponsor appearances, and travel allowances. The players, representing the entire women's team, are seeking an investigation and equal pay for equal play, citing the federation's commitment to developing women's soccer.

site_title: China March official services PMI rises to 53.8 from Feb's 52.7
summary: China's official services PMI rose to 53.8 in March, up from 52.7 in February, indicating a faster expansion than the previous month. This growth is crucial for China's economy, which has been relying on the services sector for growth and jobs. The sector's momentum in 2016 is being closely watched by analysts, who hope it can maintain its pace. The 53.8 reading is above the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction, suggesting the services industry is continuing to drive China's economic growth.

site_title: BYD plans to secure lithium supply to curb rising battery costs
summary: BYD, China's largest electric car and bus manufacturer, plans to secure lithium supplies to curb rising battery costs amid increasing pressure to lower prices. The company aims to improve battery designs to help reduce costs, with lithium carbonate prices tripling in China last year. BYD may sell up to 150,000 new-energy vehicles this year, while China considers cutting subsidies for electric buses and imposing a price ceiling for qualifying passenger vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.980 points to 1,715.360. The market saw a slight volume of 10.97 million lots worth RM3.85 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 41 to 38.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on Friday, following a regional sell-off and despite recent gains. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.24% and the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.23%. The sell-off was attributed to traders dismissing data on Chinese manufacturing activity.

site_title: Macau gambling revenue slump continues in March with 16.3% drop
summary: Macau's casino revenue declined 16.3% in March, the 22nd consecutive month of a slump, to 18 billion patacas (S$3.1 billion). The decline is attributed to a campaign against conspicuous spending by public officials and economic growth slowdown on the mainland. The VIP sector remains volatile due to government regulations, with high-rollers accounting for just over half of revenue, down from over two-thirds in 2015. Analysts predict a decline of 0-10% in 2016 gaming revenue in Macau.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower, led by banks
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Friday, down 1.64% to close at 4999.400, weighed down by sell-offs in major banks. The Big Four Australian banks fell 2.6% and 2.1% respectively. However, global miners, such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, rose modestly due to firmer copper prices and China's manufacturing activity expansion. The ASX dropped 1.5% for the week, its second negative session in a row.

site_title: European shares touch one-month low, energy shares slip
summary: European shares fell 1.5% on the first day of the quarter, reaching a one-month low, as Zurich Insurance's sharp decline and weaker oil prices pressured energy stocks. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 7.7% in the first quarter. On the positive side, Thyssenkrupp rose 5.4% after Tata Steel planned to take a stake in its European steel unit. Investors will focus on US payrolls jobs data later in the day, which may impact interest rates.

site_title: Pakistani man lights up Twitter with account of Taliban captivity
summary: A Pakistani man, Shahbaz Taseer, who was held captive by the Taliban for nearly five years, has taken to Twitter to share his story of captivity and release. Taseer, the son of a liberal Punjab governor assassinated in 2011, describes the moment of his reunion with his wife as heart-stopping and loving. He has shared humorous and light-hearted moments of his captivity, including his loyalty to Manchester United and his wife's comparisons to a US Marine turned terrorist. The account has resonated with Pakistanis, who have responded warmly to his bravery and resilience.

site_title: US, South Korea, Japan pledge security cooperation amid North Korea threat
summary: US President Barack Obama, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and South Korean President Park Geun-hye recommitted to each other's security amid North Korea threats during a meeting at the National Security Summit in Washington. The leaders agreed to deepen security cooperation and discussed ways to prevent North Korea from upgrading its nuclear capabilities. The commitment comes amid ongoing tensions from North Korea's nuclear program, with the US, Japan, and South Korea reaffirming their alliance.

site_title: South Korea March house prices gain for 31st mth but at slower pace
summary: South Korea's house prices rose for the 31st straight month in March, but at a slower pace. The house transactions price index increased 0.03% from the previous month and 3.81% from a year earlier. This was the slowest monthly growth since August 2013, marking the fourth consecutive month of slower growth.

site_title: Banks lead Europe stocks lower in worst start to year since 2009
summary: European stocks ended their third quarterly drop in four, marking the worst start to a year since the 2009 financial crisis. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 1.1% at close, trimming its monthly gain to 1.1% and putting its quarterly drop at 7.7%. Lenders led the decline, with banks suffering from low interest rates, while commodity producers rebounded. The Stoxx 600 is now trailing US equities by the most since 2003, with analysts slashing profit estimates and economic data missing projections.

site_title: The world may have too much food
summary: The world is experiencing an unprecedented increase in obesity, with 640 million obese adults worldwide in 1975, expected to reach one-fifth of adults by 2025 if current trends continue. The rate has more than doubled for women and tripled for men, with the World Health Organization's goal to halt the increase "virtually impossible" under the current trajectory.

images.alt_text: The past 40 years have seen an unprecedented increase in the number of obese adults worldwide, climbing to about 640 million from 105 million in 1975. If the current trend continues, about one-fifth of adults will be obese by 2025.

site_title: Taiwan: Shares fall, tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.7% to 8,682.61 at 0136 GMT, mirroring declines in other regional markets due to tech heavyweights like TSMC. The electronics subindex lost 0.9% and TSMC shed 1.5%, while foreign investors bought a net T$160 billion worth of Taiwan stocks in March. The Taiwan dollar firmed to T$32.265 per US dollar.

site_title: GE seeks removal of 'too big to fail' label
summary: General Electric (GE) has requested US regulators to remove its designation as a "systemically important financial institution" due to significant divestitures over the last year. GE Capital, its financial firm, has reduced assets by $284 billion, trimmed consumer loans by 95%, and scaled back short-term and securitization funding. The move comes after GE announced plans to sell most of GE Capital and focus on its industrial businesses. The FSOC, an advisory board of regulators, will reevaluate GE's designation and consider rescission.

site_title: Japan-bound plane returns to Hawaii after passenger does yoga in galley
summary: A United Airlines flight from Hawaii to Japan was diverted to Honolulu after a 72-year-old passenger, Hyongtae Pae, refused to sit down during meal service and instead meditated and did yoga in the galley. The passenger grew agitated when his wife tried to persuade him to return to his seat, prompting crew and US Marines to escort him back. Pae was charged with interfering with the crew and faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted. He was released on $25,000 bail and ordered to surrender his passport.

site_title: Budget 2016 hits right priorities, but not seen to have much impact: Yougov poll
summary: A YouGov poll of Singaporeans found that the 2016 Budget addressed the right priorities but may not have had a significant impact. 49% of respondents deemed the Budget "fair", while 57% did not expect it to make a difference in their lives over the next 12 months. The Silver Support and Workfare Income Supplement schemes were seen as high priorities, but the National Outdoor Education Masterplan was viewed as a low priority. Only 20% of respondents believed the Budget would leave them better off, and 40% thought it would have little impact on the country's economy.

site_title: Australia corporate loans surge, defies Asia slump
summary: Australia's corporate loan volumes surged 11.4% to $10.97 billion in the first quarter of 2016, defying the slump in other major Asian markets. This marked a significant increase from the previous year and accounted for 16.2% of regional volume. In contrast, Asia saw a 38.7% decline in volumes to $68 billion.

site_title: JGBs gain as firm BOJ operation results trigger bargain hunting
summary: Japanese government bond prices rose on Friday as investors engaged in bargain-hunting following the Bank of Japan's debt-buying operation. The benchmark 10-year yield decreased 2.5 basis points to minus 0.075%, its lowest level in two weeks. This came after yields spiked to minus 0.030% the previous day, as investors sold JGBs to record profits before the domestic fiscal year ended.

site_title: US dollar nurses quarterly losses as jobs data awaited
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst quarterly loss since 2010, shedding over 4% in the first quarter. The dollar index edged down to 94.565, reaching a five-month low of 94.319. The decline was attributed to lower US yields and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's cautious stance on raising interest rates, which quashed expectations of a rate hike in April. The nonfarm payrolls report, due on Friday, is expected to show 205,000 jobs added, potentially disappointing dollar bulls.

images.alt_text: The dollar licked its wounds on Friday after taking steep quarterly losses against major rivals, as investors awaited the nonfarm payrolls report for the latest reading on US labour conditions and potential clues to the monetary policy outlook.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit one-month lows, NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell 1.6% to their lowest in a month, led by a 2.1% decline in Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The New Zealand market slipped 0.3%, retreating from an all-time high. The drop was attributed to renewed pressure on bank stocks and a decline in The Warehouse Group, Fletcher Building, and Spark NZ. In contrast, global miners such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose 1.0% following China's manufacturing activity expansion.

site_title: California lawmakers approve hiking minimum wage to US$15
summary: California lawmakers approved a plan to raise the state's minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2022, making it the first state to commit to such a large pay hike for the working poor. The measure was approved by both the state Senate and Assembly and now goes to Governor Jerry Brown for his signature. The move aims to ensure that full-time workers and their families do not live in poverty, as stated by Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.39% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 11 points, or 0.39%, to 2,829.90 on Friday, following overnight US market declines. The three major banks, DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC, lost ground due to Moody's Investors Service downgrading their sector outlook to "negative". The decline was driven by 174.1 million shares worth S$134 million traded.

site_title: Silicon Valley must corral its 'unicorns', SEC's White says
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission head Mary Jo White warned Silicon Valley's "unicorns" - non-public startups valued over $1 billion - to ensure their internal controls and investor protections keep pace with growth. She expressed concerns that prestige drives companies to appear more valuable than they are, and urged founders and advisers to consider regulatory expertise and public-company experience. The SEC is also monitoring the secondary market for early startup employees and online marketplace loans, emphasizing the need for adequate disclosures about the platform's lending models and borrower's ability to repay.

site_title: Mobius's successor at Templeton brings China-Brazil expertise
summary: Stephen Dover, 54, has taken over as head of the Templeton Emerging Markets Group, succeeding investment icon Mark Mobius. Dover has extensive experience in China and Brazil, key economies for the group's portfolios. Mobius, who remains chairman, will focus on promoting emerging markets and attracting investors back to the asset class. He aims to "push emerging markets forcefully" to reverse years of declines. Dover will lead the group's day-to-day management, following Mobius' research-intensive style.

site_title: China official manufacturing activity unexpectedly expands in March
summary: China's manufacturing activity unexpectedly expanded in March, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching 50.2, above the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. This marks the first expansion in the sector since December 2015. The news adds to hopes that downward pressure on the world's second-largest economy is easing. Analysts had predicted a contraction, and the expansion suggests that China's economic slowdown may be slowing.

site_title: Uber CEO must face price-fixing lawsuit by passengers
summary: US District Judge Jed Rakoff ruled that Uber CEO Travis Kalanick must face a price-fixing lawsuit accusing him of conspiring with drivers to set surge prices through the Uber app, affecting passengers. The lawsuit claims drivers agreed to charge prices set by the algorithm, even if it meant lower fares. Passengers led by Spencer Meyer of Connecticut filed the lawsuit, alleging Kalanick's actions harmed consumers. The decision allows the lawsuit to proceed, with Kalanick's team expected to appeal the ruling.

site_title: South Korea Feb current account surplus rises to 13-mth high
summary: South Korea's current account surplus in February reached a 13-month high of $11.33 billion, driven by a 2.8% increase in exports to $40.69 billion and a 4.3% rise in imports to $29.99 billion, resulting in a $10.70 billion goods account surplus.

site_title: CDL looks to overseas markets, funds mgt
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based property developer, plans to grow overseas markets and funds management to mitigate the challenging Singapore property market. The company's chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, stated that 2016 will be a difficult year for businesses globally, and CDL aims to navigate through this by diversifying its geographic footprint and products. CDL has already set out its plans to expand into five overseas markets, including the UK, Japan, China, Australia, and the US, and has seen success with its London-listed subsidiary, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels plc.

site_title: Tesla fans line up, camp out to sign up for new Model 3
summary: Tesla fans camped out overnight to sign up for the new, more affordable Model 3, set to be unveiled in Los Angeles on Thursday evening. The vehicle, expected to cost around $35,000, will go into production in late 2017. Pre-orders began at Tesla stores, with fans pitching tents and setting up camping chairs outside to secure a spot. The Model 3 is part of Tesla's efforts to make electric cars more accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: Tata Steel in talks to take stake in Thyssenkrupp's Europe steel unit
summary: India's Tata Steel is in advanced talks to take a stake in Thyssenkrupp's European steel unit, with a joint venture being considered. Several scenarios are being discussed, including Tata Steel holding an option to increase its stake at a later stage. A consolidation in the steel sector is seen as a sensible move, according to Thyssenkrupp. The talks are reportedly at an advanced stage, with government sources in Berlin confirming the discussions.

site_title: PM Lee 'not very optimistic' about getting TPP ratified before Jan 2017
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong remains hopeful the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade pact will be ratified before January 2017, but is "not very optimistic" about this possibility. The US, chief negotiator, is set to change leadership in January, complicating the ratification process. The TPP, which accounts for 40% of global GDP, was formally signed by trade ministers in February. The deal's future is uncertain due to the US presidential election and potential changes in the US leadership.

site_title: Australia seals uranium export deal with Ukraine
summary: Australia has signed a deal to export uranium to Ukraine, aiming to diversify Kiev's energy supply and reduce its reliance on Russia. The agreement, announced by Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop, is the latest in a series of energy deals between the two countries. Ukraine has expressed interest in buying uranium and coal from Australia, the world's third-largest uranium producer. The pact is seen as a significant move to strengthen bilateral ties and promote energy security in the region.

site_title: Asian market can't escape addiction to Mideast crude
summary: Asian countries, including South Korea and India, continue to rely heavily on Middle East crude despite efforts to diversify due to geopolitical risks. Middle East nations, such as Saudi Arabia and Oman, have increased supplies to Asia, while other suppliers face reduced volumes. The region's proximity and lower prices make Middle East crude attractive, with India's state-run refiner Hindustan Petroleum Corp. stating that cargoes from the Persian Gulf are "irresistible" due to shorter shipping times and lower prices.

site_title: Big picture, big winners
summary: The Singapore Business Awards recognized perseverance and long-term vision as key traits among winners. Robert Yap, Businessman of the Year, attributes his success to commitment and a willingness to sustain in the long haul. DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta emphasized the importance of having a "helicopter view" to balance strategic vision and execution. The awards highlight the value of traditional values in today's complex business world, where short-term thinking can be detrimental to success.

site_title: OECD has the right recipe for the global economy
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) emphasizes the global economy's resilience, contradicting the notion of a "new mediocre." The OECD's recipe for the global economy is seen as a positive feature, highlighting the world's capacity for growth and development. This perspective was expressed at the Boao Forum, where a panel discussion rejected the pessimistic undertones of the title "The looming new mediocre." Instead, the focus was on the economy's positive aspects, demonstrating a more optimistic outlook. This stance counters fatalistic views of the global economy.

site_title: Balancing idealism with pragmatism
summary: Shafie Shamsuddin, 45, has been named Outstanding Chief/Senior Executive (Overseas) of the Year at the 2016 Singapore Business Awards. A former management trainee at Carrefour Singapore, Shamsuddin led the toys, sports and luggage department and recalls the excitement of Carrefour's 1997 opening in Singapore. He attributes his success to balancing idealism with pragmatism, being humble and kind, and a genuine love for serving customers.

site_title: Taking Wanda Commercial private may prove premature
summary: Dalian Wanda Group's proposal to take its commercial properties private may be premature, as the unit's sales forecast is expected to decline by a third this year. The company's heavy exposure to mainland China's volatile real estate market and lack of diversification make it a risk. Taking the unit private could also limit access to cash and hinder a potential China listing. Analysts have expressed skepticism about the move, citing the company's poor performance and regulatory hurdles.

site_title: China's Anbang abandons bid to buy Starwood Hotels
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group Co has abandoned its bid to buy Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc, allowing Marriott International Inc to acquire the Sheraton and Westin hotels operator. Anbang cited "various market considerations" as the reason for its withdrawal. This marks an anticlimactic end to a bidding war between Marriott and Anbang, with Marriott seeking to create the world's largest lodging company with about 5,700 hotels.

site_title: Leveraging product development and the S'pore brand
summary: The Singapore government has invested in helping businesses improve productivity and innovation, but notes that technology has a life cycle and costs will always increase. To remain competitive, businesses should leverage long-term trends such as e-commerce and 3D printing, which can provide opportunities for entrepreneurs to test and launch new products quickly. The Singapore brand can also be a key factor in product success, with "Made in Singapore" providing consumer confidence in quality and reliability. Government grants and resources are available to help businesses build their brand and go global.

site_title: Security vulnerabilities found in US visa database
summary: US State Department's Consular Consolidated Database (CCD) has security vulnerabilities that could have allowed hackers to alter visa applications or steal data from over 500 million records. The aging "legacy" computer systems are the cause, despite an internal review months ago. A mitigation plan has fixed visa-related vulnerabilities, but other government sources are skeptical that all issues have been resolved. A defined timeline for fixing the security concerns has not been set.

site_title: China's yuan weakens after S&P downgrade, but offshore squeeze eases
summary: China's yuan weakened on Friday after S&P cut its credit rating to negative, but the offshore market saw a brief squeeze due to liquidity stress easing. The onshore yuan fell 0.24% to 6.4647 per dollar, while the offshore yuan slid 0.1% to 6.471 per dollar. The People's Bank of China maintained the midpoint rate at 6.4585 per dollar. A manufacturing activity survey showed China's growth is easing downward pressure, offsetting concerns.

site_title: North Korea fires another missile
summary: North Korea fired a ballistic missile off its east coast, marking the latest in a series of launches amid elevated military tension on the Korean peninsula. The missile was launched from the eastern city of Sondok and its range and trajectory could not be confirmed. The launch occurred during a two-day nuclear security summit in Washington, where US President Barack Obama discussed the need to enforce UN security measures imposed on North Korea after its nuclear test. Pyongyang's state media labelled the summit a "nonsensical" effort.

images.alt_text: North Korea appeared to have fired another ballistic missile off its east coast on Friday, South Korean officials said, as regional leaders met in Washington to discuss the threat of Pyongyang's nuclear weapons programme.

site_title: Oil posts best quarter since mid-2015 but glut still worries
summary: Oil prices surged 10% in March, the best quarter since mid-2015, but analysts warn the rally could fade as an output freeze plan fails to alleviate a global glut. Despite a drawdown in US crude stocks and a weak dollar, traders remain concerned about oversupply due to resilient US production and high Opec output. Oil futures have overextended gains, with Brent crude rising 50% since the output freeze proposal in mid-February. Analysts now forecast higher prices for 2016, with Brent averaging $40.90 and US crude $39.70.

site_title: World leaders meet to reduce nuclear material stockpiles
summary: World leaders gathered in Washington for the fourth and final Nuclear Security Summit under President Barack Obama, focusing on reducing radioactive stockpiles and protecting inventories from terrorists. The summit comes amid increased urgency due to the Brussels attacks, where militants linked to surveillance footage of a Belgian nuclear facility were identified. The meeting aimed to address the threat of militants acquiring nuclear material, with about 50 world leaders in attendance.

images.alt_text: The United States turned up the heat on North Korea's nuclear program Thursday as world leaders gathered in Washington to reduce radioactive stockpiles and protect remaining inventories from terrorists.

site_title: Xi says China will defend its South China Sea sovereignty
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that China will defend its South China Sea sovereignty, emphasizing the need for peaceful resolution through direct talks. He assured that Beijing respects and safeguards the freedom of navigation and overflight for other countries under international law. This statement was made to US President Barack Obama during a meeting at a nuclear summit in Washington.

site_title: Takata sees worst-case recall scenario costs of 2.7t yen
summary: Takata, the airbag supplier behind the largest recall in the car industry, estimates a comprehensive recall of its airbag inflators would cost around 2.7 trillion yen ($32.5 billion). This estimate exceeds previous projections and poses significant financial risks for the company, with shares plummeting 20% and its market value decreasing to $307 million. The recall, which has caused nine fatalities, is expected to be costly for carmakers, with estimated expenses totaling 607.8 billion yen.

images.alt_text: A source said the worst-case scenario would involve 287.5m airbag inflators. The question is how much the carmakers want to split the costs, an analyst said.

site_title: US agency won't consider Takata impact in recall decisions
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) will not consider Takata Corp's financial viability in its recall decisions, focusing solely on safety. The agency is reviewing three investigations into Takata's air-bag ruptures, which have caused nine fatalities in the US. The recalls of over 19 million vehicles equipped with Takata air bags are ongoing, with over 7.5 million inflators replaced. NHTSA is investigating the root cause of the flaw, with the company given until 2019 to determine the cause or prove the inflators are safe.

site_title: Knight Frank to combine its two property asset management arms
summary: Knight Frank Singapore will combine its two property asset management arms, Knight Frank Estate Management and Knight Frank Asset Management, into Knight Frank Property Asset Management (KFPAM) on April 1, 2016. The new entity will have over 450 staff, a portfolio of 130 strata-titled developments and 6 million square feet of commercial space. KFPAM will operate two major lines of business: strata management and asset management. The company also announced three new executive appointments, including Tan Boon Leong as executive director and head of industrial, and Wendy Low as executive director and head of retail.

site_title: Singapore's MAS easing among threats to best bonds outside Japan
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is expected to ease monetary policies, which could lead to higher yields for bonds. The move could be detrimental to the country's assets as a weaker local dollar diminishes their appeal. The rally in Singapore's debt market, which is challenging Japan, is expected to end due to factors such as a vanishing yield premium, potential US interest rate hikes, and further monetary loosening. This could shift the spotlight to other emerging markets, including Japan.

site_title: Britain implements minimum wage revamp
summary: Britain's minimum wage increases by 7.5% to £7.20 per hour for workers aged 25 and over, with around 1.8 million employees benefiting. The change is seen as largely symbolic, with critics arguing it doesn't address the country's significant income inequality. The new rate is comparable to Germany and France, but below the recommended rate by the Living Wage Foundation, which advocates for a minimum wage of £8.25 per hour. The government aims to lift the rate to £9.00 by 2020, but experts warn it may be unaffordable for many firms.

site_title: BMW drivers are out of excuses as app says when it's time to go
summary: BMW introduces a smartphone app that provides real-time departure alerts, advising drivers on the best time to leave due to traffic. The BMW Connected mobile application taps into various traffic data sources and is part of the company's efforts to shift its focus towards software and services. The app will also include existing remote services such as vehicle location and fuel-level information. The technology aims to take the lead in the automotive industry as digitization transforms it, responding to customer demand for seamless connectivity and competing with technology companies like Apple.

site_title: Whipsawed by the ghosts of our past
summary: The Necessary Stage (TNS) presents "Ghost Writer," a play that explores the intersection of past and present through a fusion of arts. Directed by Alvin Tan, the play follows characters haunted by their past as they try to move forward. Resident playwright Haresh Sharma collaborated with artists from various disciplines to create the story, which delves into the question of how independent our lives can be. The play features a diverse ensemble and innovative multimedia elements, showcasing TNS's signature devised theatre style. "Ghost Writer" will run at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from June 9-12.

images.alt_text: Ghost Writer traces the stories of characters haunted by their past such as a young artist struggling with the rigidity of her classical training; an expatriate escaping from reality and reimagining it through fiction; and a teacher suddenly alone in the fight to preserve her legacy.

site_title: Gold heads for weekly gain as investors awaits US jobs data
summary: Gold prices are expected to rise as investors await US jobs data and Chinese manufacturing data, which may impact the metal's value. Gold has jumped 16% in the first quarter, its largest quarterly surge since 1986, amid concerns over the US economy. The dollar has fallen to a nine-month low, and economists estimate US employers added 205,000 workers in March. A weak payrolls print could provide immediate support for gold, and a private gauge of Chinese factories is expected to remain in contraction territory.

site_title: Seizing new growth opportunities
summary: Business leaders aim to thrive in a rapidly changing world by seeking new markets, customers, or products and services. The Global CEO Outlook Survey by KPMG International found that top executives expect new growth opportunities from urbanization, increased disposable income, and a technology-savvy population. As the world continues to evolve, companies must adapt to create new demand for goods and services, positioning themselves for success in an environment of constant change.

images.alt_text: What is clear is that businesses need an effective compass to navigate new terrains.

site_title: Asia Pacific M&A activity flat in Q1 2016 as outbound deals reach record
summary: Asia-Pacific M&A activity remained flat in Q1 2016, with total deal value at US$293.2 billion, down from US$296.9 billion in Q1 2015. Outbound deals reached a record high of US$123.4 billion, led by Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse, and UBS AG. Despite a slump in inbound transactions, the record outbound deals partially offset the decline.

site_title: More than 20 killed as flyover collapses in Indian city
summary: A 100-metre section of a flyover in Kolkata, India collapsed onto a crowded street, killing at least 22 people and injuring nearly 100. The incident occurred when the flyover was under construction, crushing pedestrians, cars, and vehicles under concrete slabs and metal. Emergency workers are still rescuing those trapped, with the death toll expected to rise. The disaster management minister for West Bengal confirmed the initial death toll, with many more feared injured.

site_title: Mahathir resigns as chairman of Proton
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has resigned as chairman of Proton Holdings, effective March 30, 2016. Mahathir, who founded Proton in 1983, expressed gratitude for his role as creator of the national car company. His resignation will not affect the company or car sales, according to Domestic Trade Minister Hamzah Zainuddin. This move comes after Mahathir stepped down as chancellor of Petronas Technology University and adviser to two development authorities, citing a need to let go of the post to someone else.

site_title: Strong 6.0-magnitude quake hits off Japan coast; no tsunami
summary: A 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck off Japan's southwest coast on April 1, 2016, at a shallow depth of 10 kilometers. Although there was no danger of a tsunami, heavy shaking forced bullet trains to temporarily stop running. No damage or injuries were reported, thanks to Japan's rigid building codes and strict enforcement. This is the latest in a series of powerful earthquakes that Japan, located at the junction of four tectonic plates, frequently experiences.

site_title: United States, China to sign Paris climate accord on Apr 22
summary: The US and China will sign the Paris climate change agreement on April 22 in New York, aiming to bring the accord into force this year. The two countries, the world's largest greenhouse gas emitters, have called on other nations to sign the agreement to meet the 55% emissions threshold. US climate envoy Todd Stern said this will benefit countries vulnerable to climate change. The UN Secretary-General expects 120 or more countries to sign the accord at the ceremony, with US Secretary of State John Kerry and Indian Environment Minister Prakash Javadekar set to attend.

site_title: South Korea March inflation 1%, lower than expected on oil
summary: South Korea's annual inflation rate was lower than expected in March at 1.0% due to low oil prices. This is below the 1.3% rise in February and 0.8% rise in January. Despite this, a sustained rise in services suggests consumption is recovering. Industrial products inflation declined 0.9% due to falling oil prices, while service prices rose 2.3%. The Bank of Korea is likely to focus on economic growth and exchange rates when reviewing policy on April 19, shrugging off the low inflation.

site_title: Huawei's 2015 revenue jumps 37%, strongest in 7 years
summary: Huawei posted its strongest revenue growth since 2008, with a 37% increase to 395 billion yuan (S$82.5 billion) in 2015. The company's net profit rose 32% to 36.9 billion yuan. Huawei's strong smartphone sales and China's adoption of 4G mobile technology contributed to the growth. The company aimed to reach US$70 billion in revenue by 2018, with 10% annual growth.

site_title: Amazon in talks to buy stake in mapping company HERE
summary: Amazon is in talks with a consortium of German carmakers to take a stake in HERE, a high-definition digital mapping company, as part of a broader deal to access cloud computing services. The consortium, which includes BMW, Audi, and Mercedes, aims to develop self-driving cars and needs HERE's accurate, real-time maps. Taking a stake in HERE could make sense strategically for Amazon, which is expanding its logistics services and needs accurate maps to compete.

site_title: As China turns to consumers, Australia confronts end of iron age
summary: Australia is facing a shift in its economy as China transitions from an industrial to a consumer-led growth model, posing challenges to the country's iron ore exports and economy. Despite China's demand for food and energy, the slowdown in iron ore exports will only partly offset the decline, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The nation must find new growth drivers, including non-resources industries, as a housing boom falters and the currency compounds difficulties.

site_title: A steep slide for US dollar after it 'peaks'
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the US dollar has peaked, following its decline by double figures against several currencies since its peak last year. The dollar has fallen 22% against the Russian rouble, 18% against the South African rand, and 14% against the Brazilian real. Analysts attribute this decline to the current slack US economy and uncertainties such as the US presidential election, Brexit, and emerging-market economies. Some predict a minor US interest rate rise in December, while others believe the dollar could slip further downwards if Hillary Clinton becomes president.

site_title: Italy leads eight-nation push for EU to change budget analysis
summary: Italy, along with seven other euro-area nations, has urged the European Commission to change its budget analysis methods to allow countries to spend more in a downturn. The nations, including Spain, Portugal, and Slovakia, argue that the current two-year calculation of the "output gap" leads to discrepancies and confusion. They propose eliminating these differences and considering "substantial doubts" about the budget methodology. The European Commission acknowledged receipt of the letter, which is due to be reviewed before the EU's next budget recommendations in May.

site_title: More than 100 victims tell UN of peacekeeper sex abuse
summary: More than 100 victims of UN peacekeeper sex abuse have come forward, alleging widespread and systematic abuse, including bestiality, by French troops and UN peacekeepers in the Central African Republic. The UN Secretary-General was "shocked" by the allegations, and the UN rights chief called for investigations that "leave no stone unturned." French authorities have vowed to take "exemplary disciplinary action" if the allegations are substantiated, while the US has described the claims as "extremely concerning." The allegations are the most serious to date to hit the UN peace mission in the Central African Republic.

site_title: Japan Aso: some firms cautious but confidence in outlook remains
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that while some companies have become cautious, overall firms remain confident about the economy's prospects. Leading indicators show rising capital expenditure, a positive sign for corporate Japan. However, confidence among big Japanese manufacturers worsened in the three months to March and is expected to fall further, according to a Bank of Japan survey.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Friday that sentiment at some companies has turned cautious recently but on the whole firms remain confident about the economy's prospects.

site_title: Over half of consumption growth in S'pore to come from those over 60: think-tank
summary: Singapore's consumption growth from 2015 to 2030 is expected to come from those over 60 years old, accounting for over half of the growth. This trend is seen in other developed markets, including Western Europe and North-east Asia. McKinsey Global Institute suggests that firms should focus on designing products and services for this age group to tap future growth.

site_title: East side-by-side with West
summary: A joint exhibition by the National Gallery and Centre Pompidou in Singapore showcases 217 works by 22 South-east Asian artists alongside 26 European artists to redefine the concept of Modernist painting. The show, Reframing Modernism, aims to challenge the traditional narrative of Modernism originating in Europe and spreading globally. The display highlights the unique perspectives and adaptations of artists in South-east Asia, demonstrating that modernity and modernist styles were experienced differently across cultures.

site_title: Indonesia's inflation pace steady in March, as expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate remained steady in March at 4.45%, matching analysts' forecasts. Core inflation rate was 3.50%, and consumer prices rose 0.19% on a monthly basis. This aligns with Bank Indonesia's target range of 3-5% for the year. The central bank's benchmark interest rate remains at 6.75%, following three cuts this year.

site_title: What's up? Indonesia's central bank gets chatty with markets
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has launched a WhatsApp chat group to improve market expectations and communication with economists. The group, which includes senior local economists and Bank Central Asia's chief economist, David Sumual, has been instrumental in reducing market volatility in the rupiah and local government bonds. The strategy has been successful, with market participants attributing improved sentiment and moderating inflation to the central bank's new approach to communications and transparency. The chat group provides valuable market feedback, allowing ideas to be channelled to the board anonymously, and has been praised by economists for its flexibility and effectiveness.

site_title: Monetary policy alone can't fix global woes, says FSB's Carney
summary: FSB chairman Mark Carney warned that monetary policy alone cannot solve the global economic challenges in a low nominal-growth environment. He stated that a low-interest rate environment creates challenges for companies, sovereigns, and policymakers. Carney emphasized that a persistent low-growth environment could undo efforts to rebuild a resilient financial system, highlighting the need for structural policies to enhance productivity and reflate economies.

site_title: Musk unveils Tesla's US$35,000 Model 3 in push for mass market
summary: Elon Musk unveiled Tesla's US$35,000 Model 3, a battery-powered sedan with a 215-mile range, at Tesla's design studio in California. The base model has sparked a frenzy, with over 115,000 fans placing orders, and deliveries expected to begin in 2017 for customers who've made US$1,000 reservations. The Model 3 is seen as a key step in Tesla's plan to expand its customer base and reach sustainable profitability, targeting buyers who consider small luxury sedans. The move is also seen as a response to General Motors' upcoming release of its all-electric Chevrolet Bolt at a similar price point.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk revealed Tesla Motors Inc's Model 3, the sedan that the electric-car maker is counting on to expand its customer base and reach sustainable profitability, to cap a day in which more than 115,000 fans placed orders in stores that attracted lines out the door.

site_title: US: Feeble finish to a tempestuous quarter on Wall Street
summary: US stocks ended the first quarter with a weak performance, reversing a 7-week rally that rescued the S&P 500 from its worst start to a year since 2009. Despite a 13% recovery since mid-February, the S&P dipped after three days of gains, ending the quarter 0.8% higher for 2016. A global economy's troubles and oil price fluctuations contributed to the selloff.

site_title: Nazir Razak 'disbursed US$7m cash to BN politicians ahead of 2013 GE'
summary: Malaysian banker Nazir Razak has been implicated in the 1MDB scandal, having made nearly US$7 million in political disbursements ahead of the 2013 general election, at the behest of Prime Minister Najib Razak. The funds were transferred to Razak's personal accounts, with him claiming they were from donations from corporations and individuals. Najib has denied any wrongdoing, while Razak's involvement raises questions about the close ties between politicians and corporate interests in Malaysia.

site_title: German firm TUV SUD opens digital service centre in S'pore
summary: German testing and certification firm TUV SUD launched its Digital Service Centre of Excellence (CoE) in Singapore, investing S$40 million over three years. The centre focuses on emerging technologies like predictive data analytics, industrial cyber security, and smart infrastructure, creating over 50 jobs. It will develop and test innovative services, including a smart homes pilot project, and introduce a PhD programme for software-based verification of complex systems. The centre aims to enhance digital transformation and integrate TUV SUD's competency in functional safety and industrial cyber security.

site_title: Australia home price growth slows further in March
summary: Australia's home prices rose 0.2% in March, the smallest increase in 31 months, with annual growth slowing to 6.4%. This slowdown eases concerns of a borrowing-fueled bubble and may prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to consider lowering interest rates. Growth varied across cities, with Sydney up 1% and Melbourne down 0.6%, but overall, dwelling values are expected to continue rising, albeit at lower rates, according to RP Data.

images.alt_text: Australian home prices rose only marginally in March while annual growth braked to its slowest in 31 months, a cooling that should please policy makers worried about the risk of a borrowing-fuelled bubble.

site_title: Changing business ecosystems in the 4th industrial revolution
summary: The 4th industrial revolution, or Industry 4.0, is transforming the business landscape due to rapid technological advancements and liberalized public policies. Large companies face increasing pressure to adapt, while individuals and small entities are taking advantage of lowered barriers to market entry and commercialization. A new economic landscape is emerging, where a few large, concentrated players provide infrastructure, platforms, and services to many fragmented, niche players. Companies must assess their market position and choose to focus on infrastructure, aggregation, or agent businesses to remain sustainable.

site_title: Glaxo pledges to skip drug patent process in poor nations
summary: GlaxoSmithKline has pledged to skip patent protection for its products in the world's poorest countries, including 50 nations with a combined population of 1 billion. This move aims to make its medicines more widely available in Afghanistan to Haiti. Glaxo will instead pursue partnerships with generic-drug makers to produce low-cost versions of its products in lower middle-income nations. The company also plans to license its cancer treatments through the Medicines Patent Pool, a UN-backed initiative.

site_title: Not quite the right priority
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has introduced priority queue stickers at all MRT stations to encourage elderly, disabled, and pregnant travelers, as well as those with prams, to enter first. The move aims to promote a more gracious society, but critics argue that it underscores Singapore's lack of common decency. The stickers have been met with skepticism, with some questioning whether they are truly effective in changing behavior, and whether they are a necessary measure to instill kindness in a society.

site_title: S&P cuts China credit rating outlook on risk of slower rebalancing
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has cut China's credit rating outlook to negative, citing the nation's economic rebalancing as likely to proceed more slowly than expected. The AA- long-term credit rating now carries a negative outlook, reflecting increasing economic and financial risks to China's creditworthiness. S&P forecasts China's economic expansion will remain at or above 6% a year for the next three years, with the investment rate expected to be "well above" sustainable levels.

site_title: Trump needs to define his foreign policy
summary: Donald Trump's foreign policy needs definition, focusing on the nation's interests rather than cost-effectiveness or negotiation skills. Unlike economic policies, foreign policy is a critical aspect of presidential decision-making, with voters assessing a candidate's ability to make decisions on war and peace. Trump's 'America First' policy should be clarified to address strategic and political interests, not just economic benefits.

site_title: Microsoft aims at computing platforms of future
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the company's presence in future technologies such as AI and augmented reality. He highlighted Microsoft's advancements in HoloLens augmented reality goggles, Cortana virtual assistant, and cloud computing. The company has 270 million Windows 10 users and aims to have the operating system on over a billion devices by 2018. Microsoft also introduced an update for Windows 10, which includes biometric authentication and will be available on the Xbox One game console. The company has begun shipping HoloLens to application developers, staking its place in the emerging augmented reality platform.

site_title: Going Jumbo in China
summary: Jumbo Group, a seafood supplier, is expanding its presence in China despite concerns over the country's economy. The firm, which listed on the Singapore Exchange in January, has opened its third restaurant in Shanghai and plans to open three more outlets within the next two years. CEO's bullishness in China may surprise, given the expected 6.5-7% economic growth rate this year, which is lower than the 6.9% growth rate last year. Jumbo Group's small base is seen as an advantage for growth.

site_title: Pressure cooking
summary: Kilo Under Pressure, an Italian-Japanese eatery, provides a platform for aspiring chefs to serve a three-course dinner for 50-60 people. Founder Javier Perez warns that entering the F&B industry without experience is a high-risk gamble, citing many restaurants closing within a year. Perez emphasizes the need for continuous work and careful management to keep a restaurant successful.

site_title: Abe sets sights higher for Japan's tourism arrivals and spending
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has set a new target of attracting 40 million overseas tourists by 2020, exceeding the original goal of 20 million by last year. This new target aims to boost Japan's major industry and income earner, tourism. The decision comes ahead of Tokyo hosting the 2020 Summer Olympics.

site_title: Chiyoda seals subsea JV with Ezra
summary: Chiyoda Corporation, a Japanese oilfield services contracting group, has completed its 50% acquisition of Ezra Holdings' subsea business unit, Emas AMC, after initially delaying the deal due to market speculation. The acquisition, worth US$150 million in cash and US$30 million in investments, will elevate Chiyoda's international standing in the subsea business. The joint venture, Emas Chiyoda Subsea, now has over US$500 million in order backlog and US$8 billion projects in its bid pipeline, and is expected to acquire additional procurement muscles to compete with Tier 1 subsea contractors.

site_title: A supply chain love affair
summary: YCH Group's CEO Robert Yap took over the logistics empire at 27 after a handshake with his father, who had initially wanted him to pursue IT or banking. Yap became managing director in 1980, running the company his way despite initial reservations. Over 36 years, Yap transformed the business, leading it to success.

site_title: UOB: No letup in investment flows from China into S-E Asia
summary: UOB's yuan deposits in Singapore have doubled over the last year, driven by Chinese corporate clients expanding into South-east Asia. Despite slower growth in China, Chinese companies continue to invest in the region, taking a longer-term view. UOB's head of RMB Solutions, Ben Chan, attributes the growth to the bank's understanding of yuan internationalisation trends and regulations. The bank has set up a specialised RMB Solutions team and has helped nearly 100 Chinese companies invest and expand into South-east Asia, with plans to further support clients' expansion into Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore market cap up 3.1% in March
summary: The Singapore market rose 3.1% in March, driven by improved sentiment and gains in the mining, agriculture, and multi-industry sectors. The Straits Times Index outperformed the rest of the market, while smaller stocks shed 13.4% in value. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were strong performers due to better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. However, analysts warn that the positive momentum is unlikely to be sustained, citing an uncertain economic outlook and potential risks from global events.

site_title: China's big three airlines hit by US$2.5b forex losses
summary: China's three state-owned airlines, Air China, China Eastern, and China Southern, suffered US$2.5 billion in foreign-exchange losses in 2015 due to the devaluation of the yuan. The losses limited the airlines' ability to fully benefit from declining oil prices, despite a 30% decrease in fuel costs. Passenger yields declined 6.7-8.6% across the airlines, and they have since cut dollar debt and issued bonds to mitigate losses. The airlines face challenges juggling growing air travel demand and intense regional competition, with the prospect of further yuan volatility.

site_title: Singapore getting trounced in IPOs
summary: Singapore's stock exchange saw its smallest haul of new share sales in 2015, with listings totaling US$34 million, lagging Thailand and Malaysia. The decline reflects growing competition from rival exchanges in the region, with Indonesia planning an exchange for young technology companies and Thailand highlighting its capital markets. Singapore's decline adds to challenges faced by CEO Loh Boon Chye, who aims to restore confidence in the market. Despite this, analysts say Singapore remains an attractive listing destination due to its pro-business environment and stability.

site_title: Bottling your very own whisky (Amended)
summary: Diageo has launched its John Walker & Sons Signature Blend programme in Singapore, offering a bespoke whisky blending experience starting at S$260,000 for 50 standard 750ml bottles. The programme involves a tasting session with Johnnie Walker master blender Jim Beveridge, and clients can expect a unique blend crafted to their taste preferences. This exclusive offering is part of Diageo's Diageo Reserve portfolio, and clients can also opt for custom bottlings through companies like Quaich Bar and Spirit of Scotland, with prices ranging from S$80 to S$1,000 per bottle.

images.alt_text: The blending trunk which contains whisky samples from Diageo's John Walker & Sons Signature Blend programme.
Master blender Jim Beveridge conducts John Walker & Sons Signature Blend sessions, doing about 10 a year.
Bottle and packaging possibilities for Diageo's John Walker & Sons Signature Blend programme.
A 35-year-old whisky blend aged in an Oloroso Sherry cask, which was carried out in partnership between Spirit of Scotland and Scottish company Kinloch Anderson.

site_title: China hits property policy jam as regional market gap widens
summary: China's regional property market gap is widening, with top-tier cities experiencing rapid price increases, while smaller cities struggle with declining prices. This is complicating government efforts to spread wealth and stimulate economic growth, which hit a 25-year low in 2015. The weakness in the property sector, accounting for 20% of GDP, is a significant drag on China's economy. Experts predict that a property revival could play a crucial role in lifting 50 million people out of poverty by 2020, but regional variations and excesses from the 2005-2014 property frenzy are hindering progress.

site_title: Is legal recourse meaningful in a Starwood-Anbang dispute?
summary: Starwood Hotels & Resorts faces uncertainty in its deal with Anbang Insurance Group due to China's weak rule of law, making US court judgments unreliable for enforcement. To mitigate this risk, Starwood's lawyers are considering arbitration, collateral, or a deposit to secure the deal. However, Anbang's limited US assets make collateral unfeasible, and a deposit may not be sufficient. The deal also involves regulatory risks, including China's approval process and national security concerns, and financing risks due to Anbang's borrowing requirements. The outcome may favor Marriott International's bid, which is seen as a more stable option.

site_title: British current account deficit hits record high
summary: Britain's current account deficit reached a record high of 7.0% of GDP at the end of 2015, driven by a decline in income from British direct investments abroad and an increase in outflows to foreign investors. The economy grew 0.6% in the fourth quarter, beating previous estimates, but consumer confidence remains at its lowest level in over a year due to EU referendum concerns. Finance minister George Osborne attributed the deficit to the risk of economic uncertainty if Britain votes to leave the EU, while sterling has weakened sharply since the start of the year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub shares upgraded to "buy" by OCBC Investment Research after a Q4 FY15 earnings announcement that met expectations, despite a reduced service Ebitda guidance. The research firm believes the market may have been overly bearish on the company's hubbing strategy. Meanwhile, UOB Kay Hian Research weighs in on the crude palm oil market, predicting prices to stay firm, and recommends Bumitama Agri, First Resources, and Golden Agri-Resources. Super Group shares downgraded to "reduce" by CIMB Research due to a share price run-up after a positive earnings report.

site_title: Sarawak to hold elections in test for Najib
summary: Malaysia's Sarawak state will hold elections on April 11, a test of Prime Minister Najib Razak's support. The elections come after the state assembly's dissolution and are seen as a key factor in determining Najib's popularity. The premier is embroiled in a funding scandal, and a strong win in Sarawak is crucial for building momentum for the next general election. Najib is counting on Chief Minister Adenan Satem's popularity to retain support for the Barisan Nasional coalition, which has been in power since 1957.

site_title: SingPost names Heidrick & Struggles for corporate governance review
summary: SingPost has appointed Heidrick & Struggles for a corporate governance review, with a summary expected by July 2016. A special audit into corporate governance issues is nearing completion, with a report to be shared with shareholders in April.

images.alt_text: A special audit into SingPost's corporate governance issues is also in its final stages, and a summary is expected to be available in April 2016.

site_title: India eyes first AIIB-issued loan for solar power projects
summary: India is set to receive a loan from the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) for its solar power projects, with funding expected to be around $500 million. The loan, which has an interest rate of 2-2.5%, aims to support India's ambitious target of expanding its installed solar capacity to 100 gigawatts by 2022. The move is seen as a step towards reducing reliance on dirty fuels and promoting clean energy initiatives, addressing concerns from environmental lobbyists.

site_title: Bits, bytes and banking
summary: DBS Bank's CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizes the importance of innovation for banks, warning that those that ignore it risk becoming obsolete. Gupta credits DBS's technology efforts for transforming the bank's culture, focusing on customer service and adding an entrepreneurial spirit. He notes that DBS has made significant progress in this area, but acknowledges that the bank still has a way to go to meet its goal of raising standards. Gupta's comments come as he was recently named Singapore Business Awards' Outstanding Chief Executive of the Year.

site_title: Biggest quarterly loss in 5.5 years for US$ tracker
summary: The US dollar is experiencing its biggest quarterly decline in 5.5 years due to dovish comments from Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen, which have spurred a rally in stocks and higher-yielding assets. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot index has fallen 4.3% this quarter, with the dollar also declining against 31 major currencies, including commodity-producing nations. Analysts expect the euro to fall 5% to US$1.08 by year-end, as they bet on a less-hawkish Fed.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Local restaurants and shops are gearing up for spring with new menus and events. Chef Matthew Mok at Rabbit Stash has created a seven-course spring menu priced at S$168++ per person, inspired by his ENSOPHI philosophy. Meanwhile, Journey East is hosting its second vintage fair on April 2-3, featuring local vintage players. The Collectors, a site-specific production exploring Chinese puppetry, is also on at Centre 42 from now till April 10. HBO Asia is launching The Game of Thrones Experience: Worlds of Westeros at ION Orchard from April 2-7, while The Projector is screening Oscar-nominated shorts and celebrating the 20th anniversary of Eric Khoo's Mee Pok Man. A musical adaptation of Liao Zhai Rocks is set to premiere at the Drama Centre Theatre from now till April 17.

site_title: Mark Mobius to pass on his responsibilities
summary: Mark Mobius, a renowned emerging-markets investor, will step down as Templeton Emerging Markets Group head, handing over responsibilities to Stephen Dover as chief investment officer. Mobius, 79, will remain chairman, while Dover, with over 20 years of experience, will oversee the group's products in 14 markets. This move comes amid a reversal in emerging markets, with Asia's growth potential signaling optimism for investors.

site_title: Fleshing out a superhero
summary: English actor Charlie Cox, who plays Daredevil in the Netflix series, expresses nervousness about recreating the show's success in Season 2. Cox's prepwork for Season 1 involved researching the comics, training, and mastering an accent. For Season 2, he focused on depicting Daredevil's growth and evolution, particularly his newfound arrogance and swagger after defeating main antagonist Wilson Fisk. Cox praises Netflix's freedom from ratings pressure, stating it allows for creative freedom and relief. Season 2 has received positive reviews so far.

site_title: Supply chain YCH's Robert Yap bags top business award
summary: Robert Yap, executive chairman of YCH Group, won the top Businessman of the Year award at the Singapore Business Awards 2016 for transforming his family business into a regional supply chain provider. Yap credited technology as a key differentiator in the group's growth, and his company is set to open its new flagship headquarters, Supply Chain City, in Jurong by mid-2016. Other winners included DBS Group's CEO Piyush Gupta and Carrefour Indonesia's boss Shafie Shamsuddin, with the Jumbo Group receiving the Enterprise Award.

images.alt_text: From left: Mr Shafie Shamsuddin, Outstanding Chief/Senior Executive (Overseas) of the Year; Mr Piyush Gupta, Outstanding Chief Executive of the Year; Mr Robert Yap, Businessman of the Year; and Mr Ang Kiam Meng, representing Jumbo Group which won The Enterprise Award, at the SBA awards on Thursday.

site_title: Harrowing devolution of schoolboys
summary: SIGHT Lines' staging of Lord of the Flies at the SOTA Studio Theatre features an impressive production design, transporting the audience to a dense and claustrophobic jungle. The set, designed by Wong Chee Wai, is complemented by lighting and sound effects by James Tan and Jing Ng, respectively. The production depicts the devolution of a group of boys stranded on an island, with some regressing into savages over time, echoing William Golding's 1954 English novel. The set's crucial design effectively immerses the audience in the jungle environment.

site_title: BlackRock to cut over 400 jobs soon: sources
summary: BlackRock plans to cut approximately 400 jobs, about 3% of its 13,000 employees, due to market volatility. The layoffs, to be announced in the coming weeks, will not affect key areas of investment and hiring. The company expects to end the year with a higher headcount. This move follows a similar scale of job cuts in 2013 and is attributed to reduced revenue forecast due to market swings, with analysts predicting a 1% growth in the first quarter and decline in the second quarter.

site_title: Suu Kyi to cement power with special 'adviser' role
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's party has made her a special state adviser, cementing her control over Myanmar's first civilian government in decades. The role, akin to a prime minister, will allow her to coordinate intra-ministerial affairs and influence the executive, despite a constitution barring her from the presidency. The position, lasting five years, will secure her access to the legislature and raise questions about her ability to juggle multiple posts. The move is expected to receive little resistance, but could provoke the military that has stood in her way.

site_title: MetLife not 'too big to fail', rules judge
summary: A federal judge in Washington has overturned the "too big to fail" designation for MetLife, the largest US life insurer, ruling that regulators failed to adequately assess the company's vulnerability to extreme financial distress. The decision, made by Judge Rosemary M Collyer, also raises questions about how regulators determine who is too big to fail. The Treasury Department has vowed to defend the designation process, while supporters of Dodd-Frank say the ruling could slow down regulation of systemic threats to the shadow banking system.

site_title: MAS seeking data from 40 banks in money laundering probe: report
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is investigating possible money laundering and other offenses, including those linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), and has requested data from around 40 banks. The probe follows a report that two Australian banks, ANZ and NAB, have been drawn into the investigation, with their accounts suspected to be among those queried.
