site_title: German inflation inches higher in March: flash estimate
summary: German inflation rose 0.3% in March, higher than the previous month, driven by increasing food, service, and rent prices. The inflation rate was 0.1% using the Harmonised Index of Consumer Prices, down from a minus 0.2% in February. This marks the first increase in inflation since January. The data was a preliminary flash estimate and will be finalized on April 12.

site_title: China warns Taiwan over proposed law governing cross-strait ties
summary: China has warned Taiwan that a proposed law governing cross-strait ties could damage the basis for talks and that Beijing opposes any obstacles to developing ties. The law, proposed by Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, aims to increase oversight of China's influence in Taiwan. China views this as a threat to future agreements, and has vowed to "resolutely oppose" any measures that hinder progress. The warning comes amid heightened tensions between the two sides, with China's Taiwan Affairs Office expressing concerns over Taiwan's increasing independence and anti-China sentiment.

site_title: European banks pay bigger slice of bonuses upfront
summary: European banks are deferring a larger portion of bonuses, with some employees waiting up to four years to receive their full payment. Lenders like Credit Suisse and UBS are reducing the amount of bonus pools, while Deutsche Bank is extending its deferral period to four years. The move aims to balance regulators' desire for long-term results with shareholders' need for flexible cost bases. Banks have been seeking to manage expenses and retain staff amid weak investment banking returns and scandals.

images.alt_text: UBS, which posted its highest profit since 2010, has boosted the total amount of its bonus pool by 14 per cent to 3.5 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Auditors flag concerns over KS Energy's financial position
summary: Auditors of KS Energy have raised concerns over the firm's ability to continue as a "going concern" due to a net loss of S$260.4 million in 2015. Current liabilities exceeded current assets by S$349.9 million, mainly due to loan covenant breaches. However, management believes the firm can generate sufficient cashflows to repay debt obligations through asset divestment plans and financing. A lender has also waived repayment of S$226.2 million in bank loans. KS Energy acknowledges uncertainties accompanying these plans.

site_title: Europe: FTSE sets 2016's highest closing level, miners boost
summary: Britain's top share index, the FTSE 100, reached its highest closing level of 2016, 1.6% higher at 6,203.17 points, boosted by the mining sector after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's cautious comments on raising interest rates. The UK mining index surged 5.6%, while energy stocks rose 3% following a rally in crude oil prices. Analysts attributed the rally to the lower dollar, which lifted dollar-earning firms and commodity stocks.

site_title: Microsoft's artificial intelligence 'chatbot' messes up again on Twitter
summary: Microsoft's artificial intelligence chatbot Tay briefly returned to Twitter after being shut down for spewing racist and sexist comments, but only to launch a spam attack on its followers. The incident occurred just a week after the chatbot was taken offline for making offensive tweets. Tay tweeted "You are too fast, please take a rest..." and "smoking kush" in front of the police, sparking outrage among users. The chatbot's behavior was seen as a setback for Microsoft's efforts to create virtual agents that can interact with people.

site_title: US crude stockpiles rise less than expected in week: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles rose 2.3 million barrels last week, below analyst expectations of a 3.3 million barrel increase. Gasoline and distillate inventories fell, with gasoline stocks dropping 2.5 million barrels and distillate stocks decreasing by 1.1 million barrels. Refinery crude runs increased by 414,000 barrels per day, while crude imports fell by 636,000 barrels per day. These decreases suggest a relatively stable energy market, despite recent global market volatility.

site_title: Fed's Evans says strong economy may justify two 2016 rate hikes
summary: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans says the US economy is likely to be strong enough to justify two 2016 Federal Reserve interest-rate increases, citing expected growth of 2-2.5% and a lower unemployment rate. Evans' comments align with eight other FOMC members who projected two rate hikes for the year. Fed Chair Janet Yellen also expressed caution due to low inflation, but Evans believes the Fed can be cautious and allow inflation to overshoot in the short term to meet its target.

site_title: Boeing to cut 4,000 jobs from commercial airplane division
summary: Boeing plans to cut 4,000 jobs from its commercial airplane division by mid-year, primarily through voluntary departures and attrition, as part of a broader effort to reduce costs amid fierce competition from Airbus. The move aims to create a more streamlined organization and boost productivity. Boeing is also renegotiating supplier contracts, slashing business travel, and working to boost quality and reduce excess inventory. The job cuts follow a record revenue year in 2015, despite an 13% decline in adjusted profit due to accounting losses and declining 747 programmes.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co plans to slash about 4,000 jobs from its commercial airplane unit by mid-year as part of a broader effort to reduce costs amid fierce competition from Airbus Group SE.

site_title: UK homeowners: property prices have gone up faster than you thought
summary: UK property prices rose at an annual average of 6.1% between 2003 and 2011, exceeding the Land Registry's estimate of 4.6%. The updated house-price index, developed by the Office for National Statistics, aims to clarify conflicting pictures from various price indexes. The new measure, which has been in development since 2010, provides a comprehensive overview of UK housing values, potentially altering the understanding of the UK's housing market.

site_title: Apple at 40: stronger than ever as trend-setter
summary: Apple celebrates its 40th anniversary, stronger than ever as a trend-setter in technology. Founded by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak in 1976, the company revolutionized modern life with its innovative gadgets, including the Mac, iPod, iPhone, and iPad. Apple's influence on consumer electronics is unparalleled, and its focus on user experience and design has created a loyal community. Despite product flops and boardroom challenges, Apple has evolved into a company that generates significant revenue from app sales, digital music, and services, with a cash reserve of $215 billion.

site_title: Automakers' high-tech headlights disappoint in safety study
summary: A new study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) found that only one-third of 31 new midsize cars' headlights received a "good" rating, with some models, including BMW's 3 Series, scoring poorly. The study criticized automakers for rushing to implement new technologies without ensuring they meet safety standards. The IIHS devised a new set of night-time road tests to measure safety, with the Toyota Prius V performing better than the BMW 3 Series. The study highlights the need for better government standards for headlights to ensure adequate safety on the road.

site_title: Cyber insurance rates fall with lull in major hacks
summary: Cyber insurance rates have fallen by 13% to an average of $18,756 for $1 million in coverage in the first three months of 2016, according to insurance brokers. This decrease comes after significant rate hikes in 2015, following high-profile data breaches at companies like Home Depot and Target. Insurers attribute the drop to a lull in major hacks, resulting in lower payouts. While pricing has stabilized, some clients may still face significant hikes when renewing their policies.

site_title: Apple, Google routinely asked to help government access devices: ACLU
summary: The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has identified 63 cases in the US where the federal government asked for court orders to compel Apple and Google to access devices seized during investigations. The cases primarily involve drug crimes and indicate that such requests have become "quite ordinary." Apple has received 70 court orders since 2008, with some objections filed, while Google declined to comment on its cooperation frequency. The ACLU report highlights concerns over government access to devices and the potential for abuse of power.

site_title: Opec oil output rises in March as Iran, Iraq growth offsets outages
summary: Opec oil output rose in March to 32.47 million barrels per day (bpd), driven by increased supply from Iran and Iraq, which offset maintenance and outages in smaller producers. Iran's output rose 230,000 bpd since December, while Iraq's exports reached near-record levels. Saudi Arabia kept its output steady, and producers are set to meet on April 17 to discuss a production freeze plan to support prices, which have recovered from a 12-year low.

site_title: China central bank steps up consumer financing support
summary: China's central bank has stepped up support for consumption by encouraging financial institutions to be innovative with consumer credit products. The bank will allow car financing firms to set their own downpayment rates for 'green energy' and second-hand vehicles. This effort aims to expand the consumer credit market and support a slowing economy. The move also highlights the bank's focus on promoting environmentally friendly and affordable transportation options.

site_title: Court dismisses Malaysia Airlines' bid to strike out MH370 suit
summary: A Malaysian court dismissed Malaysia Airlines' bid to strike out a lawsuit filed by relatives of three passengers who went missing on flight MH370 in 2014. The court ruled that Malaysia Airlines Systems' (MAS) liability would be determined in a trial, allowing the airline to be held accountable. More than 50 suits have been filed over the plane's disappearance, and this ruling is seen as a relief for relatives who feared they would not receive compensation. The court also dismissed a bid to hold the Malaysian government liable, with the family planning to appeal the decision.

site_title: Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics' auditors flag firm's going concern uncertainty
summary: China-based Hengyang Petrochemical Logistics' auditors BDO LLP flag the firm's ability to operate as a "going concern" due to a net loss of 13.4 million yuan and current liabilities exceeding current assets by 430.9 million yuan in the 2015 financial year. Despite this, directors believe the firm has adequate liquidity for its working capital requirements for the next 12 months. The auditors' warning casts significant doubt about the company's ability to continue operating as a going concern.

site_title: Disasters cost US$92b in 2015: Swiss Re
summary: US natural and man-made disasters cost $92 billion in 2015, down from $113 billion in 2014, according to a Swiss Re report. Global insured losses were $37 billion, below the 10-year average. The Tianjin port explosions in August were the costliest single event, estimated at $2.5-$3.5 billion. The earthquake in Nepal, which killed nearly 9,000 people, was the deadliest single disaster event, with $6 billion in damages.

site_title: US private sector adds 200,000 jobs in March: ADP
summary: US private employers added 200,000 jobs in March, exceeding economists' expectations of 194,000 jobs. This is above the revised 205,000 jobs reported in February. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain steady at 4.9%. The ADP National Employment Report, released on Wednesday, comes ahead of the US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report on Friday, which includes both public and private-sector employment.

site_title: Taiwan's Hon Hai seals Sharp takeover for US$3.5b
summary: Taiwan's Hon Hai has completed its $3.5 billion takeover of Japanese electronics maker Sharp, acquiring a 66% stake in the company. The deal forms a strategic alliance between the two technology industry leaders.

site_title: SMRT's probe into Pasir Ris accident to conclude next week
summary: SMRT Corporation's internal investigation into the Pasir Ris accident, which killed two staff members, is set to conclude next week. The findings will be reviewed by an independent panel and then handed over to the police and Ministry of Manpower for further investigation. A board-level safety review committee has been established to review SMRT's safety frameworks and procedures. The committee, chaired by an SMRT board member, will ensure safety is prioritized in operations and maintenance services.

site_title: No agreement on Pakuranga Town Centre joint venture
summary: Auckland Council and GYP Properties failed to reach an agreement on a joint venture to redevelop Pakuranga Town Centre. Despite signing a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding in 2015, GYP Properties will proceed with a revised development plan on their own land, focusing on housing, community facilities, and retail. The project will not involve joint development with Auckland Council.

site_title: France says tighter corruption laws will boost growth
summary: France's Finance Minister Michel Sapin announced plans to introduce tighter anti-corruption laws, aiming to boost economic growth by 0.2% annually. The proposed legislation includes measures for a new anti-corruption agency and greater protection for whistleblowers, following criticism of France's image after several companies were fined abroad. The country ranked 23rd in Transparency International's corruption perception index, and officials estimate the new laws could lead to increased economic output. However, Transparency International criticized the government's decision to drop plans for negotiated settlements with companies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar strengthened against the US dollar, while local interest rates declined after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a cautious approach to interest rate hikes. Singapore's 2015 customer satisfaction level fell, and Changi Airport saw double-digit growth in passenger traffic in February. The Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to release data through APIs. Overseas credit searches by Singapore firms declined due to global economic uncertainties.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as rate hike worries ease
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, March 30, 2016, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's remarks eased concerns over interest rate hikes this year. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 65.2 points, the S&P 500 gained 8.03 points, and the Nasdaq Composite index increased 27.77 points. This followed a day after stocks reached record highs amid tariff threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Dubai to impose airport-service fee on departing passengers
summary: Dubai will impose a 35 dirham (US$9.53) airport-service fee on departing passengers, including transfers, starting after June 30. The fee will be collected by airlines and transferred to Dubai Airports, which expects 85 million passengers this year. This move follows the city's efforts to become a regional tourism and transport hub with a largely tax-free environment.

site_title: YuuZoo in multimillion-dollar e-sports deal with Alibaba
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, a social networking firm, signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Alibaba Sports Group to organize and run an e-sports tournament and manage e-sports club competition centers. The agreement will generate revenue through promotional fees, advertising, and e-commerce sales, and is expected to add new users to YuuZoo's growing user base. The AliSports World Electronic Sport Games tournament will start in April, with YuuZoo's China joint venture, YuuGames, receiving a significant fee under the deal.

site_title: New official UK house price index points to bigger past rises
summary: A new UK house price index reveals that average prices in England and Wales rose 6.1% annually between 2003 and 2011, higher than previously reported 4.6% by Land Registry data and 5.2% by an existing Office for National Statistics series. The index, set to replace existing data in June, suggests house prices rose more quickly than reported in mortgage lender surveys. The average house price in December 2011 was £185,000. The new index will provide a more comprehensive view of UK house prices, covering all four countries.

images.alt_text: British homeowners might be sitting on bigger increases in the value of their properties than they thought, based on a new official measure of house prices.

site_title: Gross to central bankers: Get GDP growth humming by 2017 or else
summary: Central bankers must achieve higher economic growth by 2017 to avoid market instability, according to Bill Gross. The US needs nominal GDP growth of 4-5%, while Europe and Japan need 2-3% and 1-2%, respectively. Failure to meet these targets could lead to a market downturn, as investors lose faith in returns. Gross cites low interest rates and stagnant growth as major concerns, and notes that investors can't make money with low-yielding money unless nominal GDP grows to support higher interest rates.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb, with retailer Metro and miners outperforming
summary: European shares rose 1-1.2% on Wednesday, with Metro and mining companies leading the gains. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen urged caution on raising interest rates, supporting equities. The weaker US dollar also boosted mining and energy shares. Metro AG jumped 9% after announcing a demerger plan, while the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 1%.

site_title: Linc Energy seeks voluntary suspension of trading
summary: Linc Energy is seeking a voluntary suspension of trading as it continues debt restructuring and recapitalization efforts. The company requested a trading halt on March 24 and aims to "materially progress" talks in early April. Linc Energy hopes to provide updates before its US oil and gas subsidiary's next coupon payment on April 30. The negotiations involve multiple parties across multiple jurisdictions, requiring more time to complete.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher on Wednesday, closing at 1,717.82 after 1.85 billion lots valued at RM2.34 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 433-351.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says new NFC-enabled SIM cards may not be widely used
summary: DBS Group Research says new NFC-enabled SIM cards in Singapore may not be widely used due to their incompatibility with the iPhone, which commands a significant market share. The cards require a purchase of S$37.50, offering no extra benefit. Apple Pay, a mobile payment service, has been successful in the US, but DBS analyst Sachin Mittal does not see NFC-enabled SIM payments gaining traction in Singapore. This may impact telcos' commission earnings, with potential upside emerging if a new mobile entrant enters the market.

site_title: Ascendas H-Trust's refurbished Osaka hotel reopens on April 1
summary: Ascendas H-Trust's refurbished Hotel Sunroute Osaka Namba in Japan reopened on April 1 after a 1.14 billion yen (S$13.6 million) makeover. The 698-room hotel now boasts a "hip and trendy" look with refreshed guest rooms, facade, lobby, and restaurant. The hotel's value has increased to 16.8 billion yen, up from 9.3 billion yen. The trust's net asset value per stapled security rose to 84.2 Singapore cents, up from 70.3 cents previously. The refurbished hotel is well-positioned to benefit from Osaka's buoyant hospitality market.

site_title: Dutch minister misinforms parliament again about Belgium attack intelligence
summary: Dutch Interior Minister Ard van der Steur has made another factual error, claiming US intelligence warned authorities about the Brussels attackers a week before the bombings. However, it was later revealed that the intelligence was not received until after the attacks. This mistake is the second in as many days, exposing weaknesses in communication between European intelligence agencies. The blunders have highlighted issues in Belgium's security and intelligence agencies following the March 22 Brussels attacks that killed 32 people.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end near 3-month high on global rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a nearly three-month high, rising 2.2% to 20,803.39, driven by the US Federal Reserve's dovish remarks on global growth and inflation. The market scaled back expectations for interest rate hikes this year, with energy shares and index heavyweights such as Sinopec and PetroChina leading the gains. The Fed Chair Janet Yellen emphasized the need to proceed "cautiously" on tightening policy, citing global dangers to growth and inflation.

site_title: German retail giant Metro to split businesses into two listed entities
summary: German retail giant Metro plans to split its businesses into two listed entities, creating a wholesale and food specialist group and a consumer electronics products and services group. The demerger aims to give each company full control over their corporate strategies, increasing customer focus and accelerating growth. Implementation of the demerger is planned for mid-2017, pending approval from the management and supervisory boards and shareholders. The move is expected to simplify structures and improve operational excellence.

site_title: Second Chance's Q2 profit plunges 64%
summary: Second Chance Properties' Q2 net profit plummeted 64% to S$1.1 million, primarily due to lower revenue and reduced fair value gains on properties. Revenue fell 16% to S$8.4 million, largely attributed to its apparel business in Malaysia, which was impacted by shop closures, tax changes, and intense competition. The company's fair value gains on properties dropped by half, while losses on fair valuation of assets widened to S$1.58 million.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on a dovish Yellen, window-dressing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 53.7 points, or 1.9%, to 2,872.78 on March 30, driven by US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's dovish comments and early quarter-ending window-dressing. The index had lost 29 points in the previous two days. Banks and several other stocks, including Keppel Corp and Genting Singapore, were the largest gainers. Turnover was 1.4 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 291 rises versus 125 falls. The index is now only 10 points in the red for 2016.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit's Park Gallery in Australia sold out
summary: Frasers Property Australia announced that its Park Gallery townhouse development in Hope Island, Australia, has sold out after achieving over A$28 million from the sales of 60 townhouses since its launch in November. The 60 "architecturally designed" townhomes, consisting of three bedrooms and two bathrooms, have direct access to a 5,000 sq m park. Settlements for the townhouses are due in Q3 2016, following a partnership with Hutchinson Builders.

site_title: Tiger Airways selling two A320 aircraft to rightsize fleet
summary: Tiger Airways is selling two Airbus A320 aircraft to Stellar Aircraft Holding 1 at a loss, aiming to rightsize its fleet. The sale, expected to be completed in Q2, will help the budget carrier improve its net cash position from S$3 million to S$66 million. Proceeds will be used to fund debt related to the aircraft financing. This sale is part of Tiger Airways' restructuring efforts to turn itself around, following the cancellation of loss-making joint ventures and network rationalization in Singapore.

site_title: MAS plans to offer data through APIs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to release its data through application programming interfaces (APIs), reducing time to market and maintenance costs. Currently, data is published in spreadsheets, but APIs will provide a more efficient way to access information. There are no compliance issues or data leakage concerns, as the data is already publicly available. This move aims to make MAS data more accessible to developers and the public.

site_title: Yellen sends greenback to worst month since 2011 as yen advances
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments doused speculation of interest-rate increases, leading to the dollar's worst month in five years. The yen strengthened, with the dollar dropping against all 16 major counterparts in March. Yellen emphasized "cautious" action amid deteriorating global economic growth, reducing the likelihood of rate hikes in April and June. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index has slumped 3.5% in March, its worst month since April 2011.

site_title: China: Stocks close higher on Fed comments
summary: China's main indexes rose 2.6% and 2.8% respectively, marking their best day in a month, following US Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen's comments on cautious policy tightening. The rally was driven by improved risk appetite, with small-cap stocks outperforming blue-chips. Energy shares, led by Sinopec and PetroChina, also gained amid market expectations of sector reforms. However, some traders warned that the rally could be short-lived due to China's fragile economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop as Takata sinks on report of huge recall cost
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.31% to 16,878.96, and the Topix index falling 1.55% to 1,356.29. Takata's shares plummeted 19% following a report estimating the airbag supplier's recall-related costs could be as high as $24 billion. This news weighed on the market, contributing to the overall decline.

site_title: Sing dollar jumps against US dollar, Sibor and SOR weaken
summary: The Singapore dollar strengthened against the US dollar, trading at 1.3534 to the US dollar, its lowest since July 13, 2015. The Malaysian ringgit also firmed to 3.9395 against the greenback. Local interest rates slid after US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen reiterated the need for a cautious interest rate hike pace.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks finish highest in 2016 on sparked risk demand
summary: The South Korean won reached its highest level of 2016, peaking at 1,150.8 against the US dollar, driven by risk demand sparked by US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's cautious stance on US interest rates. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.4% at 2,002.14 points, with foreign investors purchasing a net 42.0 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Malaysia state fund 1MDB plans to pay US$1.5b in debt soon
summary: Malaysia's state investment company 1MDB plans to repay US$1.5 billion in debt within the next three weeks through asset sales. The company, which has faced financial probes, will settle its short-term debt and bank loans, leaving it with a cash surplus of at least RM2.3 billion. 1MDB's debt was previously RM42 billion, but the repayments will reduce it by about RM40.4 billion. The company has sold its energy unit Edra to China General Nuclear Power Corp for RM9.83 billion. The repayments will also prevent 1MDB from making new investments or undertaking projects.

site_title: Toshiba to book US$800m in April-June on sale of white goods business
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to book a pretax profit of 90 billion yen (S$1.08 billion) in its first quarter ending June due to the sale of its white goods business to Midea Group Co Ltd for 53.7 billion yen. The sale includes an 80.1% stake in the unit, with the profit exceeding the deal price due to the removal of debt from Toshiba's balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp said on Wednesday it would book a pretax profit of 90 billion yen (S$1.08 billion) for its first quarter ending June, on the sale of its while good business to China's Midea Group Co Ltd .

site_title: Changi Airport racks up double-digit growth in passenger traffic in February
summary: Changi Airport reported double-digit growth in passenger traffic for the second consecutive month in February, with a 12% year-on-year increase to 4.6 million passengers. Aircraft take-offs and landings rose 7.7% to 28,520, while cargo shipments remained flat at 135,900 tonnes. Passenger traffic to South East Asia, North East Asia, the Middle East, and Europe increased by at least 10%.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport saw double-digit growth in passengers for the second straight month in February as traffic rose nearly 12 per cent year on year to 4.6 million.

site_title: Japan aims to boost inbound visitors to 40m by 2020: PM Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to increase inbound tourism to 40 million visitors by 2020, doubling the number from last year. The goal is to boost retail sales and revitalize regional economies. Abe made the announcement after a cabinet meeting on promoting tourism.

site_title: The rise and fall of Tim Leissner, Goldman's big man in Malaysia
summary: Tim Leissner, a top Goldman Sachs banker, left the firm after questions about the state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) and his work on an Indonesian mining deal. The firm had raised $6.5 billion for 1MDB, but investigations into the fund and Leissner's involvement have triggered turmoil. Leissner's departure follows allegations that Goldman Sachs misled 1MDB bondholders or broke anti-corruption laws. The firm's business in Malaysia, where it was once one of the top banks, has fallen far. Leissner is now in California, and his wife, model Kimora Lee Simmons, is facing scrutiny for her connections to Malaysian leaders.

site_title: Sweden to hike taxes for banks next year
summary: Sweden plans to introduce higher taxes on banks and financial companies next year, with the goal of generating 1.4 billion crowns (S$231.46 million). The taxes, which include scrapping a tax deduction on subordinated debt, will be part of the country's budget set to be presented this autumn. The move aims to bring in more revenue, although a previously proposed tax specifically on banks is still on the table, expected to raise 4 billion crowns.

site_title: New Hong Kong independence party slammed by Chinese media
summary: A new Hong Kong independence party, the Hong Kong National Party, has been labeled "political hooligans" by Chinese media. The party, formed by around 30-50 university students and young professionals, advocates for independence from the mainland. Chinese media questioned the legality of their ideas, raising concerns over the protection of freedom of speech. The party's launch comes amid growing calls for independence from Hong Kong's youth, fueled by fears of Beijing's attempts to curb freedoms in the city.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says 2016 growth may miss forecast
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Lee Ju-yeol, said the country's 2016 growth may miss forecast, citing a slower-than-expected economic recovery. The Bank of Korea's current forecast predicts GDP growth of under 3% this year, and inflation is expected to remain low. Lee emphasized the need for structural reforms and increased competitiveness to boost economic growth, as monetary policy alone cannot overcome underlying weaknesses in the economy, including weak exports and slowing consumption. The Bank of Korea reviews policy and announces revised economic forecasts on April 19.

site_title: Takata said to put worst-case recall costs at 2.7 trillion yen
summary: Takata Corp, the supplier behind the auto industry's largest recall, estimated a comprehensive callback of its airbag inflators would total 2.7 trillion yen ($33 billion), involving 287.5 million units. This exceeds a previous estimate by $7 billion. The recall's costs, including sharing with automakers, remain uncertain. Takata's shares plummeted 20% to 414 yen, with the company's shares declining 49% this year. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating Takata inflators linked to nine fatalities and has given the company until 2019 to determine the root cause of the flaw.

site_title: India's Modi meets EU leaders, seeking investment
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi met EU leaders in Brussels to boost investment and deepen counterterrorism cooperation. The talks, part of the 13th EU-India summit, focus on trade and security, following deadly suicide bombings in Brussels. India is seeking to revive its economy and create jobs, with the EU being its largest trading partner and source of foreign investment. The EU-India free-trade agreement negotiations have been stalled due to intellectual property rights and climate link issues. Modi emphasized India's commitment to EU cooperation, particularly in the wake of the Brussels attacks.

site_title: Australia: Shares steady near 1-month low, NZ shares hit new record
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5010.3 points, recapturing the 5000-point marker after a one-month low, following comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaling a slower pace of rate increases. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high of 6714.16, driven by record low interest rates luring investors to higher-yielding stocks.

site_title: Automakers' high-tech headlights disappoint in safety study
summary: A new study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) found that high-tech headlights in 31 new midsize cars fell short of safety expectations, with one-third of models receiving the lowest rating. The study, which tested headlights in various conditions, found that some cars, including BMW's 3 Series, failed to illuminate the road, potentially leaving drivers in the dark at night. The IIHS is calling for updated government standards to better measure safety in on-road driving.

site_title: Oil prices rebound on less than expected build in stocks
summary: Oil prices rebounded 28 cents to $39.42 a barrel in Asian trade, driven by a less-than-expected build in crude oil stockpiles. A weakening dollar also contributed to the gains. However, concerns about a two-month rally fading in an oversupplied market limited the increase. US crude rose 38 cents to $38.66 a barrel, and a report from the American Petroleum Institute showed a 2.6 million barrel increase in US crude stocks. The Energy Information Administration's inventory data is due, which is expected to show a 3.3 million barrel build.

site_title: Boeing to trim 4,000 jobs amid makeover of commercial jet unit
summary: Boeing plans to cut approximately 4,000 jobs from its commercial airplanes division by mid-year as part of a cost-cutting effort to reduce costs amid fierce competition from Airbus. The layoffs will come from 1,600 voluntary program participants and 2,400 vacant or attrition positions. Boeing aims to create a "more streamlined and nimble organization" to respond to marketplace demands under new CEO Dennis Muilenburg's leadership. The company is also exploring cost-saving measures, including renegotiating supplier contracts and reducing business travel, to ultimately reduce job cuts.

site_title: Stocks outside Japan jump on dovish Yellen as oil, bonds climb
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reasserted a gradual approach to raising interest rates, citing a deteriorating global economy. Asian stocks outside Japan surged, with the MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index climbing 1.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 1.4%. Oil prices rose, and bonds climbed, while the dollar fell, making commodities cheaper in other currencies. Futures on the S&P 500 Index added 0.1%, and the yen strengthened, driven by negative rates and unconventional monetary policy options. Odds of a US rate rise next month slipped to zero, and the probability of a June rate hike declined to 28%.

site_title: AXA to enter Integrated Shield Plan market on May 1
summary: AXA Life Insurance Singapore has become the sixth player to join the Integrated Shield Plan market. The Ministry of Health (MOH) approved AXA's application to provide three new hospitalisation insurance plans with premiums payable with Medisave, starting May 1. This marks AXA's entry into the IP market, expanding the range of options available to Singapore residents.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic unveils Flybe code-share deal, adds US routes
summary: Virgin Atlantic has signed a code-share deal with Flybe, allowing passengers to travel from 14 European cities to the US and Caribbean. The deal includes routes from Manchester to San Francisco and Boston, and increased frequencies to Barbados. Passengers can check in and baggage through to their final destination at the point of departure. This agreement comes after Virgin was listed as a potential partner by Ryanair. The deal aims to boost passenger numbers and revenue for Virgin Atlantic, with the airline almost doubling its pretax profit to £22.5 million in 2015.

site_title: Hackers breach computer networks of some big US law firms
summary: Hackers breached the computer networks of several major US law firms, including Cravath Swaine & Moore LLP and Weil Gotshal & Manges LLP. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Manhattan US attorney's office are investigating potential insider trading. The hackers, who have threatened more attacks, targeted firms representing Wall Street banks and big companies. The probe has not yet revealed stolen confidential information, but the investigation continues.

site_title: Suu Kyi aide sworn in as Myanmar president in historic power shift
summary: Htin Kyaw, a close aide and confidante of Aung San Suu Kyi, was sworn in as Myanmar's president on March 30, 2016, marking a historic power shift away from army rule. Kyaw pledged to serve the people of Myanmar. This move comes after Suu Kyi's party won the 2015 general election, ending decades of military rule in the country.

site_title: Top computing awards show growing importance of cybersecurity
summary: A California computer scientist, Stefan Savage, will receive the Association for Computing Machinery's ACM-Infosys Foundation Award for his work on cybersecurity. The award highlights the growing importance of cybersecurity in business and government, following recent high-profile cases like the San Bernardino iPhone hacking attempt. Savage's research has focused on combating cybercrime and hacking threats, including a 2010 paper exposing vulnerabilities in General Motors' vehicles. The award underscores the central role of security in computing, with ACM CEO Robert Schnabel stating that security issues now affect everything from cars to devices implanted in bodies.

site_title: Yellen prompts traders to scale back Fed rate bets to November
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has prompted traders to scale back bets on interest rate hikes this year, with the probability of a move at the Fed's next meeting in April dropping to zero and the odds rising only to 50% until November. Yellen's comments, citing heightened global economic risks, suggest a cautious approach to raising interest rates, with the yield on 10-year Treasuries dropping to 1.81% and US government securities returning 3% in 2016, the biggest quarterly gain in almost four years.

site_title: Japan lending rate hit record low on pressure from BOJ's negative rates
summary: Japan's lending rate hit a record low of 1.098% in February, driven by the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy, which aims to revive the economy. This marks the fourth consecutive month of record lows, with rates for new loans and those extended for less than a year also reaching historic lows. The move is seen as a sign of hope for the struggling economy, but also poses a risk to commercial banks' profit margins.

site_title: China's Zheshang, Bank of Tianjin set for flat open in Hong Kong debut
summary: China's Zheshang Bank and Bank of Tianjin are set to open flat on their Hong Kong debut, despite raising a combined $2.6 billion through IPOs last week. The IPOs received tepid investor demand, pricing near the bottom of expectations. Both deals were priced at their initial public offering (IPO) prices.

site_title: Asia's worst-performing currency may be best bet this year
summary: India's rupee, Asia's worst-performing currency, is expected to be a best bet for investors this year due to its high yield and growth prospects. Strategists forecast the rupee to earn 3.2% from now until December 31, making it the most attractive emerging Asian currency. The rupee's value has surged 2.8% in March, driven by lower inflation, improved current account, and budgetary discipline. Central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan's success in replenishing foreign-exchange reserves and taming consumer prices has also boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: DBS CEO's pay rises 8% to S$10.9m in 2015
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta's remuneration increased 8% to S$10.9 million in 2015, with a salary of S$1.2 million, a cash bonus of about S$4.1 million, and share plan amount of about S$5.6 million. DBS's net profit for 2015 rose 10% to a record S$4.5 billion, and total income crossed S$10 billion for the first time. Gupta expressed concerns about 2016, citing slower global growth and the need to adapt to industry changes.

site_title: Singapore's 2015 customer satisfaction level dips
summary: Singapore's national customer satisfaction level dropped to 70.2 points in 2015, down 0.93 points from the previous year, mainly due to poor performance in the finance & insurance and healthcare sectors. The finance & insurance sector's life insurance sub-sector and health & medical insurance sub-sector scored lower year-on-year, with satisfaction ratings also declining at banks and healthcare providers. The decline was attributed to lower satisfaction with touchpoints, such as ATMs and financial advisors.

images.alt_text: Singapore's national customer satisfaction level was lower in 2015, weighed down by the poorer performance from the finance & insurance and healthcare sectors in the fourth quarter.

site_title: ECB's negative rates not main policy instrument: Coeure
summary: European Central Bank Executive Board Member Benoit Coeure stated that negative interest rates are not the ECB's main policy instrument, despite using them to support overall policy. The bank has a wide range of options and will be able to address adverse situations if necessary, according to Coeure. The ECB is not considering "helicopter money" or directly providing cash to consumers, as this would blur the line between monetary and fiscal policies.

images.alt_text: Negative interest rates are not the European Central Bank's main instrument and it still has a wide range of policy tools, despite suggestions it is running out of options, Executive Board Member Benoit Coeure told Politico in an interview.

site_title: Japan trust banks to start imposing negative rates on clients: sources
summary: Japanese trust banks, Mitsubishi UFJ and Sumitomo Mitsui, will start imposing negative interest rates on institutional clients, including asset management firms and pension funds, to reflect the Bank of Japan's negative rates policy. The fees will range from -0.1% on "no interest money trusts" and will be passed on to investors' savings. This move aims to offset the costs of managing trusts, but may further burden institutional investors already facing dwindling low-risk investment options.

site_title: Australia: Shares up slightly, NZ extends rally on Fed relief
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 5025.4, driven by stronger commodity prices, despite caution over the mining industry's exposure to a slowdown. The benchmark fell 1.6% on Tuesday, its lowest since March 2. Global riskier assets gained after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signaled a slower pace of rate increases this year.

site_title: Gold cuts biggest rise in two weeks as stocks jump on Fed signal
summary: Gold prices rose 1.7% on Tuesday, the largest gain in almost two weeks, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a gradual approach to raising US interest rates. The metal is 17% higher this quarter, driven by speculation the Fed may refrain from further tightening to protect the US economy. Investors expect gold to rise to $1,400 in the second quarter as the Fed proceeds cautiously. Asian stocks also surged, with the MSCI Asia Pacific index rising 1%.

site_title: Oil rises on weakened US dollar ahead of US inventory data
summary: Oil prices rose 0.78% to US$38.58 for West Texas Intermediate and 0.46% to US$39.32 for Brent crude, driven by a weaker US dollar ahead of US inventory data. Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signaled a cautious approach to US interest rate hikes, lifting prices. However, analysts warn that any price rise not driven by real demand is unlikely to last, and a supply glut remains a concern. Major producers are set to meet in Doha on April 17 to discuss measures to stabilize prices.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rally after Yellen comments
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rallied after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen indicated US interest rates would remain unchanged in the second half of 2016. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.09% and Shanghai's composite index gained 0.73%. Yellen's comments led to a positive market reaction, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index adding 221.94 points and Shanghai's composite index rising 21.39 points.

site_title: Hitachi, Sagawa Express said to form tie up, consider merger
summary: Hitachi Ltd's transportation unit is tying up its distribution business with Japanese logistics company Sagawa Express Co, considering a possible merger. Hitachi will sell 30% of Hitachi Transport System Ltd to Sagawa's owner, SG Holdings Co, while Sagawa will sell 20% of Sagawa to Hitachi Transport. The companies will hold separate board meetings and announce their decisions at a press conference. The tie-up and potential merger could impact Hitachi Transport's stock price, with shares rising 10% before the announcement. A final decision has not been made, and negotiations are ongoing.

site_title: China considers tightening control over Internet websites
summary: China is considering tightening its control over the internet by introducing draft rules that would effectively ban web domains not approved by local authorities. The proposed regulations would require internet domain name providers to apply for approval from the government before allowing web addresses to operate. This move could allow the government to monitor users' activity and strengthen its control over what content is accessible, potentially turning the Chinese network into a "big Intranet" monitored by a "network big brother".

site_title: Overseas credit searches by Singapore firms fall on global economic uncertainties
summary: Singapore firms' overseas credit searches declined for the second consecutive year, falling 19.13% in 2015, amid global economic uncertainties and tough conditions. Asean countries made up 36.54% of all overseas searches, with Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand being top markets. Credit searches on East Asian companies decreased, while those on European companies rose. Meanwhile, foreign companies' searches on Singapore firms increased by 36.97% in 2015. The decline reflects Singapore companies' caution in expanding overseas, but foreign interest in local markets remains strong.

site_title: UOB chief's pay falls 10% to S$9.2m
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong's pay dropped 10% to S$9.22 million in 2015, primarily due to a decline in variable bonus to S$8 million. The majority of his pay is composed of a salary of S$1.2 million and benefits-in-kind. Wee emphasized the bank's focus on productivity and maintaining a strong balance sheet, as it monitors its portfolio closely and is confident in its asset quality.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up on Yellen caution but Tokyo hit by yen
summary: Asian markets rallied after Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen expressed caution on the global economy, reducing expectations of an interest rate hike. The dollar extended losses, hitting Japanese exporters, and oil prices rose as the weaker dollar made commodities cheaper for other currencies. Hong Kong and Shanghai jumped 1.4% and 1.8% respectively, while Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 0.3%. Analysts said Yellen's comments effectively ruled out a rate hike in April, and the dollar plummeted against the yen, causing a 0.3% drop in Tokyo's Nikkei index.

site_title: Foxconn to overhaul Sharp management after planned takeover
summary: Foxconn is planning to overhaul Sharp Corp's management, including replacing its CEO, after a planned takeover. The Taiwanese company is expected to gain a two-thirds stake in Sharp at a lower price than initially planned. Foxconn will select a majority of Sharp's board candidates by April 15, but Sharp's spokesman denied the decision at this point. The deal, valued at around S$5.89 billion, will give Foxconn control of Sharp's advanced screen technology and strengthen its pricing power with major client Apple Inc.

site_title: Ringgit heads for best month since 1998 as oil brightens outlook
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is poised for its largest monthly gain since 1998, driven by a rally in crude prices and a dovish Federal Reserve. The currency strengthened 5.8% in March to 3.9715 a dollar, led by a 0.6% gain on Wednesday. Oil prices have recovered from a 12-year low, accounting for 22% of government revenue. Global funds are returning to emerging markets, with 4.45 billion ringgit of Malaysian stocks purchased in 2016. The ringgit's gains are also attributed to a decline in government bond yields and a rise in benchmark equities.

site_title: Takashimaya in rent dispute with landlord Ngee Ann City
summary: Singapore's department store Takashimaya is in a rent dispute with landlord Ngee Ann City, a business associate for over 22 years. The dispute centers on the interpretation of a 2014 agreement on how rental rates are valued. The two parties are seeking to resolve the deadlock in a High Court hearing. The disagreement has raised concerns about the stability of the long-term business relationship between the two entities.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares rise hit 2016 highs on Yellen's cautious stance
summary: South Korea's won reached a 2016 high on Wednesday after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed cautious views on an imminent rate hike, boosting investor confidence. The won rose 0.7% to 1,155.4 against the US dollar, while shares also surged to their highest levels in 2016, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 0.6%. Analysts predict the won will continue to rise, but risk-off sentiment remains a concern due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Kia Motors says to start Mexico output in first-half as scheduled
summary: Kia Motors plans to start production at its Mexico factory in the first half of 2016 as scheduled, despite demands from the Mexican state of Nuevo Leon to renegotiate investment incentives. The company expects to start production of the Forte compact car on May 15. Kia's investment deal with the state government was reached in 2014, and the company has stated that it expects the state government to respect the contract. South Korean President Park Geun-hye may address the issue during talks with her Mexican counterpart early next month.

site_title: NZ dollar hits 5-mth high, Aussie rallies as Yellen signals slower rate increases
summary: The New Zealand dollar reached a five-month high of US$0.6884, while the Australian dollar hovered near recent highs after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's cautious stance on future rate increases. Yellen signaled a slower pace of rate increases, boosting the appeal of bond yields in the Antipodes. The New Zealand dollar gained 4% in March, while the Australian dollar surged 6.8% and is on track to break above a recent peak. Attractive bond yields, particularly in Australia and New Zealand, underpin the currencies' strength.

site_title: Singapore shares open 19.88 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened 19.88 points higher on Wednesday, reaching 2,838.96. The gain was attributed to US stocks closing higher overnight, following Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's call for caution on raising interest rates. Top gainers included Jardine C&C and Great Eastern, with 46.8 million shares worth S$49.1 million changing hands.

site_title: China said to consider cutting subsidies for electric vehicles
summary: China is proposing to cut subsidies for electric buses by 32% and impose a price ceiling on passenger vehicles that qualify for incentives, with vehicles costing over 350,000 yuan ineligible for subsidies. The plan aims to balance the policy's generosity with the need to curb demand and encourage manufacturers to invest in more efficient technology. The proposal is still under review and may impact electric vehicle sales, which surged threefold last year to 331,000 units.

site_title: Indonesians ride resurgent rupiah straight to Singaporean malls
summary: Indonesians are taking advantage of the resurgent rupiah to shop in Singapore, drawn by favorable exchange rates and affordable prices. The rupiah has surged 9.6% against the US dollar over the past six months, making it cheaper for Indonesians to buy luxury goods in Singapore. Indonesian arrivals in Singapore rose 5.4% in January, the biggest increase since 2014, as the country's economy quickens to 5.04% growth. However, a resurgent rupiah may disrupt efforts to rein in the current-account deficit and make imports more affordable.

images.alt_text: Drawn by the lure of some of Asia's best shopping and buoyed by a resurgent rupiah, 20-something Indonesian Dewi Lestari was ready to spend when she set foot in Singapore for the first time this month.

site_title: URA launches tender for commercial, residential site in Bukit Batok
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a commercial and residential site at Bukit Batok West Avenue 6 for sale by public tender. The 14,697 sq m site can yield about 425 residential units, with a maximum gross floor area of 6,000 sq m for commercial use. The 99-year lease will close on May 24, 2016.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Low Keng Huat, OUE Commercial Reit
summary: Sembcorp Industries will supply 225 megawatts of power to Myanmar for 22 years. Sembcorp CEO Tang Kin Fei's total remuneration fell 28% to S$4.45 million in 2015 due to losses in its offshore unit. Low Keng Huat reported a 58% drop in net profit to S$32.1 million in Q1 2016. OUE Commercial Reit introduced a distribution reinvestment plan, allowing unitholders to receive new units instead of cash, to increase their holdings and strengthen its capital base.

site_title: HTL International launches home lifestyle flagship store
summary: HTL International has launched HomesToLife, its flagship store in Singapore, featuring over 20 international brands and customisation services. The store aims to transform the furniture shopping experience into a discovery process, with in-house style advisers. This marks a new retail concept by HTL, focusing on enhancing the customer journey.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.460 points to 1,720.500. The market saw 95 gainers for every 35 losers, with a total trading volume of 24.04 million lots worth RM9.66 million.

site_title: UOB launches millennial-focused credit card
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) launched the UOB YOLO credit card, a millennial-focused card offering priority access to bars and clubs, dining deals, and rebates on travel websites. The move aligns with the bank's survey results, which found millennials prioritize experiences over material goods. The card aims to capture the "YOLO" spirit, encouraging users to make the most of their lives.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank (UOB) on Wednesday launched UOB YOLO, a millennial-focused credit card that the bank says captures the essence of the millennial mantra, "You only live once".

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC, CTBC Financial jump
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 1% to 8,703.79 on Wednesday, driven by gains in heavyweights such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and CTBC Financial Holding Co. The electronics subindex rose 0.9% and the financials subindex gained 1%. TSMC, the world's top contract chip maker, rose 0.3% and CTBC Financial extended gains to 1.8% after agreeing to buy a 35.6% stake in Thailand's LH Financial Group for 16.6 billion baht. The Taiwan dollar firmed to T$0.277 to T$32.418 per US dollar.

site_title: Air NZ says mulling sale of its 26% stake in Virgin Australia
summary: Air New Zealand is considering selling its 25.9% stake in Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, citing the need to reassess its investment options. The airline has hired investment banks First NZ Capital and Credit Suisse to advise on its options, including a possible sale of all or part of its shareholding. This move comes amid a review of Air New Zealand's investment portfolio.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand Ltd said on Wednesday it is considering selling its 25.9 per cent stake in Australian airline Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd .

site_title: Apple's encryption battle with United States still alive in Brooklyn
summary: The US Department of Justice is considering whether to continue its bid to compel Apple to help access an iPhone in a Brooklyn drug case. Following a successful unlocking of an iPhone in a San Bernardino case, prosecutors must decide if the technique will work for other seized iPhones. Apple opposes any method that bypasses security features, citing security concerns for all users. A federal magistrate in Brooklyn ruled against disabling an iPhone's security, and the Justice Department will update the court by April 11 on its decision.

site_title: Music streaming company Spotify raises US$1b in convertible debt
summary: Spotify has raised US$1 billion in convertible debt from private equity firm TPG Capital and hedge fund Dragoneer Investment Group. The deal, expected to close at the end of the week, will provide the music streaming service with additional capital amid increasing competition from Apple Music, Pandora Media, and newer rivals. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. This move comes as Spotify faces growing competition in the music streaming market.

site_title: Sinopec profit beats estimates on oil refining cushion
summary: Sinopec, China's largest refiner, reported a 30% drop in net income to 32.4 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. The company's refining business helped cushion it from the impact of falling oil prices, with operating income from refining rising to 20.96 billion yuan. Sales dropped 29% to 2.02 trillion yuan, and the company reported impairments of 8.8 billion yuan. Sinopec's refining margin may receive a boost this year due to China's price floor on retail fuel prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Yellen speech
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a previous day's slide, despite strong US stock gains. Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's dovish speech was a factor. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.15% and the Topix index fell 0.32%, with the benchmark indices losing 25.50 and 4.42 points respectively.

site_title: Washington nuclear summit: What's at stake
summary: US President Barack Obama will host a nuclear security summit in Washington, focusing on securing nuclear material worldwide. The summit, held in 2010, 2012, and 2014, aims to prevent criminals from accessing radioactive materials, reduce highly enriched uranium and plutonium, and enhance detection of smuggling and cybersecurity. This year's summit will build on previous efforts, with the goal of ensuring the security of nuclear facilities globally.

site_title: Noble Group shows junk bond rally to aid Asia refinancing crunch
summary: Asia's junk bonds, hit by a 25-year low in raw material prices, are experiencing a rebound with returns of up to 37% for companies like Noble Group and 27% for coal producer PT Indika Energy. The resources turnaround is a boost for borrowers seeking credit lines from Asian lenders and a reprieve for distressed-debt hedge funds. The rally is attributed to central banks' softening interest-rate outlook and dovish sentiment, with demand for high-yield debt revived.

site_title: Japan Feb industrial output down 6.2% month-on-month
summary: Japan's industrial output fell 6.2% in February, marking the biggest drop since 2011, after a 3.7% gain in January. The decline was due to sluggish demand at home and abroad. Economists had expected a 6.0% decline. Manufacturers predict a 3.9% increase in March and 5.3% in April.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit establishes distribution reinvestment plan
summary: OUE Commercial Reit has introduced a distribution reinvestment plan (DRP), allowing unitholders to choose to receive distributions in the form of new units instead of cash. This plan aims to increase unitholdings without incurring brokerage fees, and will also enlarge the Reit's capital base and strengthen working capital. Participation is optional, and the Reit manager will make an announcement on the Singapore Exchange when deciding to apply the DRP to a particular distribution.

site_title: Protests in Prague as China's Xi signs economic partnership
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping signed a strategic partnership with Czech President Milos Zeman in Prague, amid protests against Beijing's policies on Tibet. Hundreds of protesters, including members of the banned Falun Gong movement and pro-Tibetan demonstrators, took to the streets, waving Tibetan flags and chanting "Freedom for Tibet." The protests highlight controversy over the Czech Republic's pro-China policy and criticism of Xi's visit. The partnership is expected to bring significant investment to the Czech Republic, with Chinese investors committing 95 billion koruna (S$5.32 billion) in 2016 alone.

site_title: American Apparel names former Liz Claiborne CEO as new chairman
summary: American Apparel has appointed Paul Charron, former CEO of Liz Claiborne Inc, as its new chairman. Charron joins Susan Davidson and Bruce Fetter on the revamped seven-person board, aiming to bolster the company's retail experience after emerging from bankruptcy in February. Charron, who previously ran Claiborne until 2006, will help guide American Apparel's comeback efforts following years of losses and a split with founder Dov Charney.

site_title: ADB cuts Asia growth forecast for 2016 on China, global drag
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has cut its economic growth forecast for developing Asia to 5.7% in 2016 and 5.7% in 2017, citing global headwinds, a weaker outlook for China, and producer price deflation. China's growth is projected to slow to 6.5% this year from 6.9% in 2015, while the US Federal Reserve has halved its interest rate hike predictions due to a shaky global economy. Despite this, India's growth is forecast to recover to 7.8% in 2017, and inflation in developing Asia is expected to recover to 2.5% this year.

site_title: Tens of thousands sign online petition to scrap UK foreign aid target
summary: A UK-based online petition, launched by the Mail on Sunday, has garnered over 140,000 signatures calling for the government to scrap its 0.7% target for overseas development aid. The petition claims UK aid funds projects like building a palace and English lessons for North Korean officials. The UK's Department for International Development (DFID) denies the accusations, stating that aid is spent where it's most needed and subject to rigorous checks. The petition's success may lead to a parliamentary debate on the issue.

site_title: Planemakers shrug off Brazil gloom, forecast growth in Latin America
summary: Airbus and Boeing forecast a doubling of Latin America's commercial fleet over the next two decades, despite economic woes in Brazil. The companies are accommodating local airline customers by delaying deliveries and shifting stock to stronger economies. Airbus projects 2,540 new planes needed by 2034, worth $330 billion, while Boeing forecasts 3,050 new planes worth $350 billion. Air traffic is expected to grow 4.7% annually in the region, with Brazil and Mexico as key markets. Both companies are optimistic about long-term prospects for recovery in the region.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan says central bank should raise rates gradually and cautiously
summary: Dallas Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan expressed caution on the US central bank raising interest rates, citing the resilience of the US economy despite global risks. Kaplan stated the US economy will "power through" but warned of potential downward impacts on GDP, unemployment, and inflation due to China's slowdown and global interconnectedness. The Fed downgraded its rate hike forecast to two increases this year, and Chairman Janet Yellen also urged cautious rate hikes given global risks.

site_title: Tata Steel to study sale of UK unit after strategic review
summary: Tata Steel, a UK-based metal-producing arm of India's Tata Group, is considering the sale of its UK steel division amid weaker prices and faltering demand. The company's UK strip products unit restructuring review found proposals unaffordable, leading to discussions with potential buyers and the UK government. Tata Steel's UK long products business is also in talks with Greybull Capital, while the company continues to face global oversupply and increased exports from China, impacting its long-term competitive position in the UK operations.

site_title: Australia says will allow competition for the ASX's cash-clearing activities
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison plans to introduce laws allowing competition for the Australian Securities Exchange's (ASX) cash-clearing activities, ending the exchange's monopoly. Morrison also proposes to relax a law limiting individual shareholdings in the ASX to 15 per cent. The move aims to increase transparency and competition in the country's securities market.

site_title: Oscar-winning actress Patty Duke dies at 69
summary: Patty Duke, Oscar-winning actress and singer, has died at 69. She won an Academy Award at 16 for her portrayal of Helen Keller in "The Miracle Worker" (1962) and went on to have a successful acting and singing career. Duke also served as president of the Screen Actors Guild and advocated for mental health awareness, revealing her own diagnosis with bipolar disorder in her 1987 autobiography. Her son, actor Sean Astin, said she had been preparing to launch a "Patty Duke Mental Health Initiative" before her death.

site_title: Sembcorp to supply power to Myanmar for 22 years
summary: SEMBCorp Industries has signed a 22-year power purchase agreement with Myanmar Electric Power Enterprise (MEPE) to supply 225 megawatts of power. The power will be produced by a new project in Myingyan, Mandalay, upon the execution of a build-own-transfer agreement by Myanmar's Ministry of Electric Power. Sembcorp aims to support Myanmar's growing power demand and contribute to the country's power capacity building.

site_title: SunEdison at risk of bankruptcy, unit says, shares plummet 60%
summary: US solar energy company SunEdison Inc is at "substantial risk" of bankruptcy, warned TerraForm Global Inc, one of its two publicly listed units. The company's shares plummeted 60% to a record low of 50 US cents after a Wall Street Journal report revealed it was being investigated for overstating its cash position. SunEdison has at least $11.67 billion in debt and has identified material weaknesses in its financial reporting controls. TerraForm Global said it would have sufficient liquidity to support its operations even if its parent sought bankruptcy protection.

site_title: Brexit will hurt world economy: US Treasury chief
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew warns that a Brexit would have a negative impact on the British, European, and world economies. The consequences of a Brexit would affect trade and economic relationships, causing uncertainty and potentially harming the global economy. Lew emphasized the need for the rest of the world to develop sophisticated tools for surveillance, as the US already has.

images.alt_text: If Britain exits the European Union it will have a negative impact on the British, European and world economies, US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew warned Tuesday.

site_title: India approves foreign investment in e-commerce sector
summary: India has approved 100% foreign investment in e-commerce sector, formalizing rules for the first time. The move aims to boost the multi-billion dollar sector, with forecasts predicting Indian e-commerce will surge to $220 billion by 2025. However, e-commerce companies will not be allowed to influence prices or own inventory, and not more than 25% of goods sold can come from a single merchant. The decision is expected to benefit global e-commerce giants like Amazon and local rivals Flipkart and Snapdeal.

site_title: Google unveils landline phone, which lives in cloud
summary: Google has unveiled its Fiber Phone service, a landline phone that lives in the cloud, allowing users to stay connected anywhere. The service is available in select US markets and will expand to other cities with high-speed internet. It features transcribing voice mails and connecting with mobile phones when users are away. The Fiber Phone number lives in the cloud, enabling users to access it on various devices, and can ring both landline and mobile phones.

site_title: Funds sell Singapore stocks on thin volume
summary: Global funds sold more Singapore industrials stocks excluding transportation than they bought in the three months to March 23, with net sells of S$147.4 million compared to net buys of S$8.5 million. The top sell was Singapore Technologies Engineering with a volume of S$105.1 million, while the top buy was United Engineers Ltd with S$3.3 million. This trend highlights the overall selling sentiment in Singapore's industrials sector during the period.

site_title: Thailand eyes luxury tourists, operators say keep them safe
summary: Thailand aims to attract luxury tourists, but operators warn that safety concerns could deter high-end travelers. Despite a record 32 million tourists expected this year, crime, accidents, and perception of mass tourism pose a threat. Recent incidents, such as the murder of British tourists and rape complaints against French visitors, have raised concerns. The government plans to focus on "quality tourism" and reassure tourists that Thailand is safe, but luring more discerning travelers may be challenging.

images.alt_text: Thailand needs to do more to keep its tourists safe if it wants to achieve its objective of attracting more high-end travellers, operators say, or it risks losing out to its up-and-coming neighbours.

site_title: Former Canadian Cabinet minister killed in plane crash
summary: Former Canadian Cabinet minister Jean Lapierre, 59, died in a plane crash on Tuesday, along with his wife and three siblings, while traveling to his father's funeral in eastern Quebec. The chartered twin-engined plane crashed in bad weather on the Magdalen Islands, killing all seven people on board. Lapierre, a former transport minister, was a prominent media commentator and politician, praised for his generosity and good humor. Canada's Transportation Safety Board is investigating the crash.

site_title: Brussels airport delays reopening as Belgium lowers attacks toll to 32
summary: Brussels airport remains closed as partial services are tested after the March 22 suicide bombings that killed 32 people. The airport's chief executive warned it could take months to fully operational again. Authorities have lowered the death toll from 35 to 32, with 94 people still in hospital. The sole suspect charged over the attacks was freed on Monday due to lack of evidence, sparking criticism of authorities' handling of the case. Belgium has admitted to missed chances in preventing the carnage, with Turkey accusing the country of ignoring warnings from Ankara.

site_title: IMF says Iraq could secure 3-year standby deal by June
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is considering a 3-year standby deal with Iraq, which could unlock $15 billion in international assistance. The deal, with nearly one-third of the funding from the IMF and the rest from international groups and donor countries, would aim to stabilize Iraq's debt and support the country's economic recovery. Discussions are ongoing, with a possible approval by the IMF board in June. Iraq must implement fiscal reforms to address its financial crisis, which was triggered by the fall in oil prices, and meet performance criteria to access the funds.

site_title: US dollar drops after Yellen's dovish remarks
summary: US dollar drops 0.9% against the euro and 0.6% against the yen after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's remarks signaling no immediate interest rate increase, contradicting recent hawkish comments from Fed regional presidents. Yellen cited growing global economic risks, including the slowdown, China uncertainty, and low oil prices, for the central bank's cautious approach. Her comments leave considerable doubt about a rate hike in June, leading to a decline in dollar value.

site_title: Brazil's biggest party quits ruling coalition, Rousseff isolated
summary: Brazil's largest party, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), has quit President Dilma Rousseff's governing coalition, pulling its six ministers and all other party members with government appointments. This move sharply raises the odds of Rousseff's impeachment, which could put Vice President Michel Temer in the presidential seat. Rousseff has denied wrongdoing and called the impeachment efforts a coup, but faces a significant challenge in forming new coalition allies to block impeachment. The opposition hopes to impeach her for allegedly breaking budget laws, but many analysts warn that impeachment could lead to political turmoil.

images.alt_text: Brazil's largest party announced on Tuesday it was leaving President Dilma Rousseff's governing coalition and pulling its members from her government, a departure that sharply raises the odds she could be impeached in a matter of months.

site_title: Embattled Brazilian president's coalition collapses
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff's ruling coalition has collapsed as her main partner, the PMDB, voted to end its alliance with her party. The PMDB's 69 seats in Congress are crucial to Rousseff's bid to avoid impeachment. The move leaves Rousseff increasingly helpless and vulnerable to impeachment on charges of illegally borrowing money to boost public spending. If impeached, PMDB leader Michel Temer would become interim president.

site_title: Goldman raises US$1.5b in infrastructure fund first close
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised approximately US$1.8 billion in its first close of a new infrastructure fund, surpassing its target of US$3 billion. The fund, which is Goldman's third infrastructure fund, aims to invest in assets such as airports, bridges, and toll roads. This marks a significant increase from Goldman's previous infrastructure fund, which raised US$3.1 billion in 2010. The trend of infrastructure investments is on the rise, with other private equity firms also seeking to raise large infrastructure funds, as investors seek alternative investments with stable returns.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc closed the first stage of fundraising for its newest infrastructure fund with about US$1.5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Cautious Yellen pushes back on Fed officials eyeing hike
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen urged caution in raising interest rates, pushing back on some colleagues who suggested another move in April. Yellen cited global risks, including low oil prices and concerns over China, and said inflation has not proven durable. She expects the US recovery to continue alongside a "gradual" series of rate hikes, but a lower path than anticipated. The dollar dropped, while equities and gold rebounded in response to her comments.

site_title: AIG cuts CEO incentive award 29% after missing profit goals
summary: AIG cut CEO Peter Hancock's incentive award by 29% for missing profit targets in 2015, resulting in a $2.5 million payment instead of $3.5 million. Hancock's long-term incentive awards will now be based 100% on total shareholder return relative to peers, and credit-default swaps will no longer count towards setting his compensation. Hancock's total package rose 3.6% to $12.5 million, despite missing profit goals. The move comes amid pressure from activist investors to split up the company.

site_title: Missile maker adapts guidance systems to steer self-driving cars
summary: Mitsubishi Electric, a Japanese company, is adapting its military-developed guidance systems for self-driving cars. The company will integrate millimeter-wave radars, sonars, sensors, and cameras into autonomous vehicles, which are expected to hit the roads by 2020. Mitsubishi aims to compete with Continental AG, Denso Corp, and Hitachi Automotive Systems by offering superior systems that utilize its expertise in high-precision sensors and electric-power steering. The company plans to start production of components for lane-keeping and automatic braking systems in 2017, with potential expansion to automatic parking systems and a satellite-based system by 2018.

site_title: US: Wall Street hits 2016 high after Yellen delivers
summary: US stocks reached a 2016 high after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed caution on raising interest rates, reversing an earlier dip. The S&P 500 rose 0.88%, its biggest one-day gain in 12 sessions, to close at 2,055.01. Yellen's comments contrasted with recent dovish statements from other Fed policymakers, reducing the likelihood of a rate hike by a quarter point at the July policy meeting. The Dow Jones industrial average also rose, while tech stocks led the gains.

site_title: Western Digital said to boost yield on debt for SanDisk buy
summary: Western Digital Corp is offering a US$4.1 billion unsecured bond with a yield of about 10.5% to finance its takeover of SanDisk Corp, a premium of over 4.5 percentage points over similarly-rated debt. The company is also offering a US$1.5 billion secured bond with a yield of about 7.5%. The deal, valued at US$5.6 billion, has attracted commitments from JPMorgan Chase & Co, Bank of America Corp, Credit Suisse Group AG, and Royal Bank of Canada. The acquisition is seen as key to Western Digital's competitiveness and expansion into solid-state drive products.

site_title: Expect 'unicorn' valuations to be lowered: Ratan Tata
summary: Ratan Tata, chairman emeritus of Tata Sons, predicts that "unicorn" valuations will be lowered as investors who bought into startups solely for the action may not have the long-term vision. He notes that about a dozen of the 150 "unicorns" have been in business for three years or less, and advises large companies to create subsystems that are run differently and led by innovative leaders to innovate. Tata supports founders who take a long-term view and prioritize the company's success over personal gain.
