Trading volume was 60.7 million shares worth S$44 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 68 to 33. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, following a 5-day streak of gains.

site_title: 'Missing link' in US$81m cyber heist set to testify Tuesday
summary: A Philippine junket operator, Kim Wong, is set to testify before a Senate committee on Tuesday, potentially shifting the focus of the hearings from the Philippine banking sector to the operations of casino junket providers. Wong, dubbed the 'missing link' in the $81 million cyber heist, has claimed he was a victim of money laundering and will name two foreigners involved. The heist, one of the largest in modern history, involved hackers stealing funds from Bangladesh Bank and channeling it through Philippine casinos.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: HK shares open higher after Easter break, Shanghai down
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.20% on the first trading day after the Easter break, following Wall Street's gains. The Hang Seng Index increased to 20,386.32. In contrast, Shanghai's composite index fell 1.11 points to 2,956.71, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.19% to 1,871.17. The decline in Shanghai was attributed to a marginally lower composite index.

site_title: iPhone security is the casualty in Apple's victory over the FBI
summary: Apple has emerged victorious in its legal battle with the FBI, but at a cost: its reputation as a secure device. The FBI's decision to abandon its effort to force Apple to help break into a terrorist's iPhone 5C comes after six weeks of public sparring. The FBI's claim that it found a way to hack into the device via an anonymous third party has eroded customer faith in the iPhone's security. Apple's refusal to create a backdoor for law enforcement has set a precedent, but the fact that an external party managed to crack the device has shown that Apple devices are not impervious to hackers.

site_title: Broker's take: Pressure on volumes ahead for Hutchison Port Holdings Trust
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) faces pressure on throughput volumes ahead due to restructuring in the shipping industry, including the merger of Cosco and China Shipping and CMA CGM's acquisition of NOL. The brokerage OCBC Investment Research notes that shipping lines are under pressure to cut costs, leading to a drag on HPHT's FY16 and FY17 volumes. Despite its assets being well-positioned for mega-vessel deployment, HPHT's position as a transhipment hub may be threatened by China's proposal for liberalizing cabotage in coastal waters.

site_title: Pentagon's innovation office reaching out to industry for ideas
summary: The Pentagon's Strategic Capabilities Office is reaching out to US industry for ideas on repurposing existing weapons technologies to maintain a competitive edge over Russia and China. The office, which has a nearly $1 billion annual budget, aims to upset assumptions made by adversaries about US military capabilities. It plans to test new projects, including swarming drones, an arsenal plane, and repurposing missiles for use as anti-ship weapons. The goal is to change the calculus of potential foes and regain the element of surprise, with most projects completed within three to four years.

site_title: Yahoo sets April 11 deadline for preliminary bids
summary: Yahoo has set an April 11 deadline for preliminary bids on its web business and Asian assets, which could lead to a deal closure by June or July. The company has asked bidders to provide details on financing, conditions, and key assumptions. This move comes after Yahoo's failed attempt to sell its core internet business to Microsoft in 2016. The deadline is part of Yahoo's efforts to sell its non-core assets and focus on its core business.

site_title: Georgia governor to veto anti-gay bill after business outcry
summary: Georgia Governor Nathan Deal plans to veto a "religious liberty" bill that would have allowed business owners to deny services to same-sex couples, amid opposition from major companies including Walt Disney Co and 21st Century Fox. The bill's veto would prevent potential job losses and a loss of $1.7 billion in film production revenue. Deal cited the First Amendment's protection of religious freedom, stating that the bill was unnecessary and would harm the state's character. The veto decision must be made by May 3.

site_title: US dollar snaps six days of gains as traders weigh Fed's rate path
summary: The US dollar snapped a six-day rally against major peers due to concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate path, following a report that inflation slowed last month. The dollar has slumped 4% since January on speculation of a rate hike, and traders will watch a speech by Fed Chair Janet Yellen and monthly labor data for clues. The economy's resilience may depend on its ability to withstand overseas turbulence, with some experts predicting a lower probability of a rate hike, now at 36%, according to Bloomberg data.

site_title: Japan's NTT Data buys Dell systems unit for US$3.06b
summary: NTT Data Corp, a Japanese IT company, agreed to buy Dell Inc's information-technology services businesses for $3.06 billion, its largest acquisition. The deal expands NTT Data's presence in the US and other foreign markets, helping to counter sluggish economic growth at home. Dell, which is selling some assets to finance its $67 billion takeover of EMC Corp, will retain its US-based Perot Systems division, which Dell acquired in 2009. The acquisition is expected to boost NTT Data's sales and profit.

site_title: French government opposes PSA chairman's pay increase: Les Echos
summary: The French government opposes a proposed 90% pay increase for PSA Peugeot Citroen chairman Carlos Tavares, citing a 30% cut recommended by the French government for minority-stake companies. Tavares' 2015 remuneration reached 5.24 million euros, up from 2.75 million euros in 2014. PSA returned to profitability in 2015 and is set to present a new strategic plan on April 5. The French government's stance is seen as a response to PSA's recent success, including returning to profitability and achieving performance targets ahead of time.

site_title: Wine tech upstart drops smart bottle on a US$300b industry
summary: Wine tech startup Kuvee is launching a smart bottle system that preserves wine freshness for up to 30 days. The US$199 decanter canister holds a wine and is paired with a catalog of 48 wines, allowing users to swap out bottles without oxygen exposure. Kuvee aims to revolutionize the US$300 billion wine industry by changing consumer behavior and saving billions in wasted wine. The system, which also tracks user ratings and provides pairing suggestions, is expected to compete with existing wine preservation systems like Coravin.

site_title: China's milk stockpile leaves New Zealand dairy farmers struggling
summary: New Zealand's dairy farmers are struggling due to China's stockpiling of powdered milk, which has led to a 60% drop in dairy prices over the past two years. This has resulted in a NZ$7 billion loss for farmers, with 85% of farms operating at a loss. The sector's woes pose a risk to the country's economy, with banks exposed to the sector and a growing concern of rural suicides. The government has ruled out bailouts, but banks have indicated they will support farmers.

site_title: NTU, PBOC launch RMB research centre
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) have launched the Centre for RMB Internationalisation Studies (CRIS) to study the demand and use of the renminbi (RMB) in international markets. The centre will train policymakers and finance executives on RMB policies and internationalisation. It will be jointly managed by the PBOC's China Centre for Financial Training and the Nanyang Business School, aiming to promote RMB use globally.

site_title: Japan Feb consumer spending bounces back, outlook uncertain
summary: Japanese consumer spending rose 1.2% in February, the first increase in six months, driven by spending on medical care, cars, and mobile phone data plans. However, wage growth remained low, and the jobless rate rose slightly. The government faces pressure to implement stimulus to boost the economy amid concerns about weak emerging markets. A new round of stimulus spending and delayed sales tax increase in 2017 are expected, with some economists advising the government to prioritize stimulus over tax hikes.

images.alt_text: Japanese consumer spending in February rose for the first time in six months, but slowing wage growth and worries about overseas economies means the government remains under pressure to come up with stimulus to boost the economy.

site_title: Gunman shot and captured at US Capitol complex
summary: A man with a gun entered the US Capitol Visitor Center, prompting police to shoot and wound him after he pointed the weapon at officers. The suspect, a female bystander, and the suspect were taken to the hospital. No police officers were injured, and a recovered weapon was found on the scene. The suspect's vehicle was also discovered on Capitol grounds.

site_title: Clinton warns of possible Trump Supreme Court nominations
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton warned of potential dangers if Donald Trump appoints the next Supreme Court justice, citing the potential to roll back workers' and abortion rights. Clinton accused Republicans, including Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, of obstructionism for denying a hearing to Obama nominee Merrick Garland, who would fill the seat vacated by Antonin Scalia. Clinton urged Grassley to "do his job" and convene a hearing, warning that Trump's nominees would be likely to undermine progressive values.

site_title: UN chief regrets 'misunderstanding' over Western Sahara
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon regrets a "misunderstanding" over his recent remarks on Western Sahara, which referred to the territory as an "occupation." The comments, made during a visit to a refugee camp, outraged Morocco and led to the expulsion of most UN civilian experts and closure of a military liaison office. The UN stated it would not take sides on the issue, emphasizing Ban's spontaneous and personal reaction was not deliberate. Morocco considers Western Sahara an integral part of the country, seeking self-government under its sovereignty.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon's recent remarks about Western Sahara, which outraged Morocco and soured relations, were not deliberate and he regrets the "misunderstanding," his spokesman said Monday.

site_title: Malaysia Building Society becoming Islamic after failed mergers
summary: Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) has decided to transform into an Islamic lender after two failed merger attempts with Islamic banks. The company, which stopped offering conventional loans, aims to grow its Islamic services, with 85% of its outstanding loans already Shariah-compliant. MBSB expects 6-8% credit growth this year and plans to focus on government contracts and affordable housing. The company's share price has fallen 39% over the past year, but its CEO says the transformation is a "right move" to sustain asset growth and maintain low operational costs.

site_title: Japan jobless rate up slightly at 3.3% in February
summary: Japan's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 3.3% in February, slightly higher than the median estimate of 3.2%. The jobs-applicants ratio remained unchanged at 1.28, its highest in 24 years.

site_title: Facebook's Oculus starts shipping Rift virtual reality headset
summary: Oculus, a virtual reality company acquired by Facebook in 2014, began shipping its Rift headsets on March 28, 2016. The headsets, priced at $599, were initially funded through a Kickstarter campaign in 2012 and come with a remote, audio system, and Xbox One wireless controller. Over 30 games are available on the Oculus Store, with plans to add feature-length movies and more content. This shipment marks the culmination of Oculus's vision for virtual reality, which Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg sees as the next major computing platform.

site_title: Asian upstarts eye global aircraft market
summary: Asian countries are developing their own aircraft, targeting the growing demand for short-hops in emerging markets. Indonesia's PT Dirgantara Indonesia is set to roll out its 19-seat N219, while South Korea is studying a 100-seat aircraft, and India is considering a 70-90 seater. These homegrown manufacturers aim to be cost-effective alternatives to established brands, but face challenges in designing and certifying planes, as seen in China and Japan's past experiences.

site_title: Global elderly population exploding: US report
summary: A US study by the Census Bureau reports that the global elderly population is expected to more than double by 2050, reaching 1.6 billion people aged 65 and over. Currently, 8.5% of the world's population, or 600 million, is in this age bracket. The study projects a significant increase in life expectancy, from 68.6 years in 2015 to 76.2 years in 2050, and a tripling of the "oldest old" population, from 126.5 million to 446.6 million, aged 80 and older.

site_title: Turkey summoned German ambassador over satirical report
summary: Turkey's Foreign Ministry summoned Germany's ambassador Martin Erdmann over a satirical broadcast by German television station NDR that mocked Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan. The report comes amid efforts by German Chancellor Angela Merkel to strengthen ties with Turkey to tackle Europe's migrant crisis. Erdogan is known for his sensitivity to criticism, and Turkish prosecutors have opened nearly 2,000 cases against people for insulting him since he became president. The incident highlights tensions between Turkey and Germany.

site_title: Rich states resettle barely one per cent of Syrian refugees: Oxfam
summary: Wealthy countries have resettled only 1.39% of nearly 5 million Syrian refugees, with rich countries pledging fewer than 130,000 spots, according to Oxfam. The charity urges countries to resettle at least 10% of the refugees by the end of the year. Only Canada, Germany, and Norway have pledged more than their fair share, while 20 countries have fallen short. The UN-hosted conference in Geneva aims to ensure global responsibility sharing for the crisis, with Oxfam calling for urgent solutions to offer safe and legal routes to third countries.

site_title: Volkswagen recalls 5,600 US electric vehicles for stalling issue
summary: Volkswagen is recalling nearly 5,600 electric e-Golf cars in the US due to a battery problem that can cause stalling. The issue, related to the high-voltage battery management system, may lead to an emergency shutdown and deactivate the vehicle's electrical drive motor. Dealers will install updated software to address the problem. The recall affects vehicles sold in the US since November 2014 and includes 157 unsold vehicles. This move comes amid criticism and lawsuits following Volkswagen's admission to installing software to allow diesel vehicles to emit excess emissions.

site_title: Oil trades near US$39 amid doubts producer talks will curb glut
summary: Oil prices traded near US$39 a barrel amid speculation that a meeting of crude-producing countries next month won't curb a global supply glut. Futures fell 1.5% after rising 1.7% earlier, as Iran and Libya, two Opec members, haven't pledged to attend production-freeze talks in Doha, Qatar on April 17. This lack of commitment from key producers has led to doubts about the effectiveness of the meeting in easing the global supply surplus.

site_title: Virgin America receives takeover offers
summary: Virgin America Inc has received takeover bids from JetBlue Airways Corp and Alaska Air Group Inc, exploring a potential sale as the US budget airline faces declining revenue. The offers come after Virgin America's steep decline in unit revenue in the past year. Analysts say a deal could make sense for JetBlue, which has room to grow on the US West Coast, and would benefit from Virgin America's corporate accounts. However, buyers would have to assume high aircraft lease costs and potentially hike pilots' wages. A deal is likely to pass an antitrust review, according to experts.

site_title: American Airlines pilot charged with drinking before Detroit flight
summary: American Airlines pilot John Maguire, 50, was charged with drinking before a Detroit-bound flight on Saturday. He was detained in the cockpit and released after two breathalyzer tests showed his blood alcohol content exceeded the legal limit. The incident is under investigation by the FAA, which prohibits pilots from flying with a BAC higher than .04. Maguire's flight was canceled, and passengers were rerouted. He has not been arraigned and could not be reached for comment.

site_title: Powerful winds bring outages, traffic chaos to western Europe
summary: Powerful winds in western Europe caused widespread disruptions, leaving tens of thousands of homes without power in France, particularly in Brittany and Normandy. Gusts reached hurricane force on the Breton island of Belle-Ile, with winds reaching 150 km/h. The outages led to flight cancellations, road and bridge closures. Although the number of outages decreased to around 15,000 by the late afternoon, the strong winds brought chaos to parts of western Europe.

site_title: China must tie territorial ambition to new rules: Singapore
summary: Singapore urges China to match its economic clout with better leadership on security, saying China's contrasting approaches in the economic and security arenas have sparked tensions in the South China Sea. Despite being a major trading partner, China's actions in the maritime sphere have undercut economic goodwill, with China scoring low on trust among citizens in the region. Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen calls for new rules to be established to prevent escalation, saying "China has to decide what these new rules are" and that disputes should be settled peacefully.

site_title: Japan's NTT to buy Dell unit for US$3.06b
summary: NTT, Japan's former telephone monopoly, agreed to buy technology services businesses from Dell for $3.055 billion. The acquisition aims to expand NTT Data's presence in North America and enhance its cloud services and business-process outsourcing. NTT Data will hire 28,000 Dell employees and has not decided on funding options. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and would be NTT Data's largest acquisition, aiming to boost sales outside Japan.

site_title: Marriott faces prospect of losing Starwood after months of work
summary: Marriott International is facing a possible loss of its bid to acquire Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide after a Chinese investment group, Anbang Insurance Group Co, submitted a higher takeover offer of $82.75 per share, valuing the deal at $14 billion. Marriott has been negotiating with Starwood for four months, but Anbang's new offer may prompt Marriott to reconsider its position. The deal would create the world's largest hotel operator with 5,700 properties and 1.1 million rooms, but analysts question whether Marriott can justify paying more than its previous bid of $78 per share.

images.alt_text: Marriott International Inc is facing the prospect that four months of work toward completing a purchase of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc is about to come undone.

site_title: Obama to meet South Korea, Japan leaders on Thursday
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Park Geun-Hye on Thursday at a nuclear security summit in Washington, with North Korea a key topic of discussion. The trilateral meeting aims to address the threat posed by North Korea and advance regional security cooperation. The summit will also focus on nuclear safety concerns, including the potential for Islamic State militants to obtain nuclear material. Obama will also meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping on the same day to discuss common security concerns.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff faces threat of coalition implosion
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff faces a potential collapse of her coalition as the largest party, PMDB, is set to decide whether to quit the government. The party's leader, Michel Temer, indicated that a majority is in favor of breaking with the government, which would weaken Rousseff's position in the impeachment process. Rousseff is struggling to block impeachment, which is based on accusations of manipulating government accounts and obstructing justice in a corruption scandal. The PMDB's decision could lead to other parties following suit, potentially solidifying the two-thirds majority needed to open an impeachment trial in the Senate.

site_title: Pandora says Westergren to return as CEO, replace McAndrews
summary: Pandora Media Inc has appointed co-founder Tim Westergren as its new CEO, replacing Brian McAndrews. Westergren, who previously held the position from 2004 to 2007, will oversee the company's expansion into on-demand streaming and concert promotion. The move comes as Pandora struggles to compete with Spotify and Apple Music, and faces growing shareholder dissatisfaction with management. The company had reported sales of $336.2 million in the fourth quarter, missing analysts' projections, and has been exploring strategic options, including a potential sale.

site_title: US drops legal action against Apple over encrypted iPhone
summary: The US Justice Department dropped its legal action against Apple, successfully accessing data from an encrypted iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino shooters. The court order, obtained last month, required Apple to disable passcode protection. However, officials later stated they could unlock the iPhone without Apple's help. A two-page court filing revealed the government "no longer requires" Apple's assistance.

images.alt_text: The US Justice Department said it successfully accessed data stored on an encrypted iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino shooters and asked a court to withdraw an order compelling Apple to assist, according to a court filing on Monday.

site_title: Sanders second-half comeback plans running into tougher primary calendar
summary: US presidential candidate Bernie Sanders' campaign is experiencing a second-half comeback after winning three western-state Democratic caucuses. Sanders, who routed Hillary Clinton in the caucuses, faces a tough road ahead with big-state primaries dominating his schedule. Despite the challenges, his campaign is billing his victories as the start of a comeback. Sanders' delegate math remains a concern, but his campaign is optimistic about his chances in the nomination.

images.alt_text: After routing Hillary Clinton in three western-state Democratic caucuses, Bernie Sanders still faces daunting delegate math and a road ahead dominated by big-state primaries that have been the weakest link in his campaign.

site_title: Australia an 'embarrassing circus' as Turnbull mulls early poll
summary: Australia is on a "political knife edge" as Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull threatens to call an early election, despite his party's internal bickering and falling popularity. Turnbull has promised policy reforms, but so far, only concrete plans such as taxation reform have gained momentum. His government's economy is struggling, and the risk of shirking reforms to avoid falling behind in opinion polls is high. An early election, potentially as early as July 2, could give Turnbull a mandate to rule, but also carries risks, including a lack of sweeteners in the budget and opposition from conservative coalition members.

site_title: Syrian forces pursue campaign against Islamic State after retaking Palmyra
summary: Syrian government forces, backed by Russian air strikes, have retaken the ancient city of Palmyra from Islamic State militants. The city, a significant cultural and historical site, was previously dynamited by the group. The loss marks a major setback for Islamic State and a strategic victory for President Bashar al-Assad and ally Russia. The Syrian army plans to use Palmyra as a launchpad for operations against Islamic State strongholds in Raqqa and Deir al-Zor. The international community has welcomed the development, with UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon expressing encouragement for the preservation of Palmyra's ancient heritage.

site_title: Elaine Wynn sues for control of her Wynn Resorts stock
summary: Elaine Wynn, ex-wife of Wynn Resorts founder Steve Wynn, sued him to gain control over her nearly 10% stake worth around $900 million in the casino company. She claims Steve Wynn breached a 2010 stockholder agreement by ousting her from the board and alleges he's misusing the agreement to exert control over her life and legacy. Wynn Resorts denies her allegations, calling them "falsehoods and distortions." The lawsuit seeks compensatory and punitive damages, including for Steve Wynn's alleged failure to support Elaine Wynn's reelection to the board.

site_title: China Big 4 banks likely to show flat profits
summary: China's Big Four state-run banks are expected to report flat annual profits due to soaring bad debts and weakening economic expansion. Funds set aside to cover losses are near regulatory limits, posing a significant challenge to the sector. This marks a decade of slowing profitability, with lending to over-supplied industries contributing to the issue. The slowdown in China's GDP growth raises pressure on policymakers, and Chinese banks are struggling with consumer lending. Regulatory measures may be needed to address the sector's challenges.

site_title: Liquidation of short positions, not bulls, behind recent oil rally: data
summary: Crude oil prices have surged 50% since February 11, driven by the liquidation of short positions rather than bullish bets. According to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data, traders have cashed out of bearish wagers at an unprecedented pace, covering the largest short-covering streak in over a decade. Despite bullish news, such as an expected oil output freeze and declining US production, the rally's staying power is questioned, with traders attributing the price increase to fear and uncertainty.

site_title: US: Stocks flat ahead of Yellen, jobs data; Nikkei gains
summary: US stocks remained flat at the start of a heavy week of economic news, with the Dow and S&P 500 advancing 0.1% and the Nasdaq dipping 0.1%. Japan's Nikkei rose 0.8% due to a weaker yen. The March jobs report and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Tuesday are expected to influence interest rate decisions. A US$14 billion cash bid for Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide boosted the stock, while Valeant Pharmaceuticals International fell 7.2% due to an upcoming Senate hearing.

site_title: California reaches deal for US$15 minimum wage
summary: California Governor Jerry Brown reached a deal to gradually raise the state's minimum wage to $15 per hour, with the proposal still needing approval from moderate lawmakers. The plan would increase the wage to $15 by 2022 for large businesses and 2023 for smaller firms. This move follows a trend of states and cities raising their minimum wages, with 14 states and several cities already implementing or planning increases. The proposal is part of a wave of minimum wage increases driven by Democrats ahead of the November elections.

site_title: Currency devaluation fans Egypt property boom
summary: Egypt's currency devaluation has sparked a property boom, with demand for real estate surging as investors seek safe havens against a weaker local currency. The EGX 30 Real Estate Index has risen 22.6% since the central bank devalued the pound by over 10% in March. Developers have reported increased sales, with luxury developer Palm Hills Development selling 108 units at a price of 491 million Egyptian pounds (S$76 million). Authorities have released more plots, easing supply constraints, and the government has paid billions to developers over land contract disputes.

site_title: Spick, span and a sparkling future
summary: Primech Services & Engineering, a Singapore-based building maintenance firm, has emerged as a leading provider of high-quality commercial and residential building maintenance services. Incorporated in 1998, the company attributes its success to prioritizing customers, employees, and stakeholders. With a growing demand for its services, Primech is poised for a sparkling future, reflecting the determination and perseverance of its leaders and staff.

site_title: Bespoke roadmaps for over 20 economic sectors in the works: Heng
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to develop bespoke roadmaps for over 20 economic sectors, accounting for 80% of the economy, to boost productivity and drive innovation. The Industry Transformation Programme (ITP) aims to provide support to firms and industries while driving innovation, with a team of officers from government agencies to serve each sector. The roadmaps will be adjusted as needed and will include initiatives to invest in skills, drive innovation, and promote internationalization.

site_title: Buffett boosts Berkshire's Wells Fargo stake to 10%
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc has increased its ownership stake in Wells Fargo & Co to 10%, a level that may attract increased federal scrutiny. Berkshire owns approximately 506.3 million shares worth about $24.7 billion, mainly through subsidiaries. The ownership stake has risen from 6.5% at the end of 2009 and 9.8% as of December 31, according to Buffett.

site_title: Brazil's Lula calls for end to austerity, return to growth
summary: Brazil's former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva called for an end to austerity measures and a return to pro-growth economic policies, including tax breaks and increased consumer credit, during a news conference. Lula expressed his willingness to serve as an advisor to his successor, President Dilma Rousseff, despite potential legal implications. He claimed that his strategy could lead to a change in the country's mood within a few months.

site_title: Shanmugam highlights four key challenges for Singapore over the next 50 years
summary: Singapore faces four key challenges over the next 50 years, according to Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam. These include balancing financial prudence with higher social spending, addressing a rapidly ageing population, and competing with foreign forces and terrorism. The government must also find ways to adapt to these challenges, which will test its ability to maintain economic growth and social stability.

site_title: Feeding a global expansion
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agribusiness giant, plans to expand in Africa to fuel its growth. Despite a volatile commodity market, Olam reported revenue of nearly S$20 billion for 2015, driven by its overseas operations. The company aims to capitalize on Africa's growing middle class and demand for packaged food, with sales from the continent rising to S$4.13 billion in 2014. Olam has already established a presence in 24 sub-Saharan countries and has acquired several companies, including Nigerian-based Amber Foods, to increase its market share.

site_title: Eletrobras hires Credit Suisse to help sell unit assets: sources
summary: State-controlled power holding company Eletrobras has hired Credit Suisse to advise on the sale of a subsidiary's renewable energy assets, Eletrosul. The assets, including wind farms and an electricity transmission line, are expected to fetch around 2 billion reais (S$744 million). The sale is aimed at raising cash to fund higher-yielding projects and reduce debt. However, the process may be challenging due to Brazil's struggling electricity industry and a glut of ready-for-sale assets in the renewable energy sector. Eletrobras may not complete the divestment this year.

images.alt_text: State-controlled power holding company Centrais Elétricas Brasileiras SA has hired Credit Suisse Group AG to advise on a plan to sell a portion or all of a subsidiary's renewable energy assets, two sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters exclusively.

site_title: An economy needs a price mechanism to work
summary: The global economy is stuck in an impasse, with deficits and debt at an all-time high. Central banks have tried to stimulate the economy with low and negative interest rates, but this has led to a stalemate. To break the cycle, experts recommend that interest rates should be raised to reinstall a price mechanism, informing creditors that lending is profitable and debtors that repayment is necessary. This would encourage the corporate sector to boost real demand and reduce debt, rather than just shifting the burden to other sectors.

site_title: US$ rises for seventh day vs yen on rates outlook
summary: The US dollar rose for a seventh consecutive day against the yen, reaching 113.53 yen, driven by expectations of solid US economic data this week and speculation of potential interest rate hikes. The dollar's advance, 1.9% over the past week, is the longest winning streak since October. Speculators trimmed bets on the dollar's strength against eight major peers, while the yen weakened 0.4% to 126.76 per euro, as gains in Japanese shares and US stock futures reduced demand for safe-haven assets.

site_title: COEs, car taxes set to make up 10.3% of govt inflows in FY2016
summary: Singapore's government inflows are expected to increase by 10.3% in FY2016, primarily due to rising COE premiums and vehicle taxes. COE premiums and vehicle tax are projected to grow from S$7.203 billion to S$8.590 billion, a S$1.387 billion increase. This represents a significant portion of the government's total inflows, with the two taxes accounting for 9.7% of the government's revenue in FY2015.

site_title: Consumer spending rises a mere 0.1%
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in February, a slight decrease from January's 0.5% gain, indicating a cooling in spending and slowing income growth. Inflation retreated, with the core PCE price index increasing 1.7% in the 12 months ending February, below the Fed's 2% target. This suggests the Federal Reserve may take its time in raising interest rates this year despite a tightening labor market.

images.alt_text: Consumer expenditure last month was held back by a 0.7 per cent drop in purchases of goods. Spending on services rose 0.4 per cent while personal income rose 0.2 per cent - after rising 0.5 per cent in January.

site_title: Myanmar picks Vietnam's Viettel for 4th telecom licence
summary: Myanmar has awarded its fourth telecom licence to a consortium led by Vietnamese mobile network operator Viettel, in partnership with a military-run company. This move is seen as part of the country's efforts to further open up its telecoms market, with the licence set to be granted for 15 years. The deal comes ahead of a scheduled handover of power to a civilian administration led by Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, raising concerns about the military's financial interests.

site_title: Money managers cut wagers on copper rally for a second week
summary: Money managers cut their bets on a copper price rally for a second week, reducing their net-long holdings by 4.4% to 23,011 US futures and options. The recovery of the US dollar and concerns over global demand weigh on demand for commodities. Copper prices have dropped about 20% in the past year, with producers yet to expand production despite lower prices. Analysts predict the surplus will last through 2019, and demand growth in China is seen slowing to 2.2% this year.

images.alt_text: More than 4.5 million tonnes of additional mine capacity is planned to come online by 2020, and most producers haven't changed their plans to expand even in the face of lower prices, according to an analysis by Bloomberg Intelligence.

site_title: ISIS attacks: Obama reaction shows US foreign policy shift
summary: US President Barack Obama's reaction to the Brussels terrorist attacks was marked by a shift in foreign policy priorities, focusing on Asia and Latin America over the Middle East. He chose to continue his Latin America trip, attending a baseball game in Havana and a state dinner in Argentina, despite criticism that he should have returned to Washington to address the crisis. Obama believes the US should extract itself from the Middle East and focus on emerging markets, citing the region's declining relevance to the US economy. He also emphasized the need for regional powers to resolve their own conflicts, rather than relying on US military intervention.

site_title: Skymark exits bankruptcy, expects to be profitable for first time in 3 years
summary: Skymark Airlines Inc has exited bankruptcy administration after reducing its fleet, cutting routes, and securing new funding. The carrier forecasts its first operating profit in three years, with 1.5 billion yen (S$18 million) in operating profit and 70 billion yen in sales for the year ending March 31. Skymark aims for an "early relisting" of its shares, backed by private equity firm Integral Corp and ANA Holdings Inc. The airline targets an operating profit of over 7 billion yen and sales exceeding 80 billion yen starting from April 1, 2018.

site_title: SingPost should reveal identity of independent consulting firm
summary: SingPost has yet to reveal the identity of an independent consulting firm it hired for a corporate governance review, despite making the announcement over two months ago. The firm's expertise and experience in corporate governance reviews are also unknown. The review's outcome, along with a special audit, is expected to be discussed at the company's upcoming annual general meeting. Shareholders are urging SingPost to provide updates on the review's progress.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil output seen slumping more than expected
summary: Malaysian palm oil production is expected to slump by 2 million tonnes in the year through September, down from a previously forecast 1.5 million tonne decline, due to the lingering effects of El Nino. This will result in Malaysian output being "well below" 19 million tonnes, while Indonesia's production will total 31 million tonnes. Palm oil prices are forecast to climb to RM3,000 (S$1,000) a tonne, driven by the El Nino's impact on global supply.

site_title: Germany turns to yoga in Euro 2016 bid
summary: Germany's national football team will employ yoga teacher Patrick Broome to help prepare players for Euro 2016. Broome, who has worked with Madonna and Sting, will lead daily 45-minute sessions to improve flexibility, concentration, and performance. The sessions are optional and only three players decline to participate. Germany head coach Joachim Loew believes yoga helps players relax physically and mentally, and has been a key part of the team's training sessions since 2008.

images.alt_text: Head coach Joachim Loew (left) is a fan of the ancient indian discipline, while Germany's forward Mario Goetze is a firm yoga convert.

site_title: China's real estate recovery spurs rally in online portals
summary: Chinese real estate web portals Leju Holdings Ltd and SouFun Holdings Ltd are experiencing a rally, with Leju surging 44% over the past month and SouFun rebounding 25% from its February low. The recovery is driven by government stimulus, easing housing-market regulations, and an increase in the role of privately-owned technology and service businesses. Analysts attribute the turnaround to the robust real estate market rebound in major cities, such as Shenzhen and Shanghai, and the growth of property-related services.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nordic Group's subsidiaries secured S$36.5 million in contracts with repeat customers. Mermaid Maritime won a US$10 million award for subsea cable installation services. Terratech Group plans to raise S$3 million by issuing up to 74 million new shares. In contrast, global markets experienced volatility, with oil rising 2% amid market concerns and US-EU tariffs. Stocks in Europe and the US edged down, and NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: MAS open to fintechs working to help banks stay ahead
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced an open policy towards fintechs, encouraging banks to collaborate with technology firms. The regulator aims to support traditional lenders, allowing fintechs to thrive and providing a hybrid opportunity for financial advisers to tap into technology for more efficient advisory services. MAS is open to fintechs offering financial services directly, such as crowdfunding platforms, and is working to develop application programming interfaces (APIs) to facilitate communication between banks and fintechs.

site_title: South Korea looks set for a record IPO year
summary: South Korea is poised for a record-breaking initial public offering (IPO) year, driven by family-run conglomerates such as Samsung, Doosan, and Lotte. These companies plan to list assets worth at least $10 billion this year, surpassing 2010's total of $8.5 billion. The IPOs will be used to streamline structures, facilitate management succession, or ease debt burdens.

site_title: Japan seen launching 5-10 trillion yen package to boost Abenomics
summary: Japan is expected to announce a 5-10 trillion yen fiscal spending package to boost its economy, which is believed to have slid back into recession in the first quarter. The package, worth 1-2% of GDP, will likely include "targeted helicopter money" to help the working poor. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to maintain the momentum of Abenomics, a policy aimed at stimulating economic growth.

site_title: The changing face of talent management
summary: C-suite executives face four key challenges in talent management: the strategic value of HR, attracting and retaining top talent, developing future leaders, and managing the skills gap. As businesses compete globally, effective human capital management is crucial for innovation and competitiveness. To navigate the changing landscape of HR, businesses must prioritize these themes and develop strategies to address the "war for talent." This shift in focus is essential for success in today's highly competitive and globalizing world.

site_title: Hedge fund invasion of US Treasuries puts traders at risk
summary: Hedge funds are aggressively investing in US Treasuries, with a record $1.27 trillion in holdings over the past year. This surge has raised concerns among bond traders, who may face increased volatility. The trend is part of a broader shift, as foreign central banks and finance ministries have reduced their US Treasury holdings for the first time since 2000, while also crowding into the market.

site_title: Bitcoin woes give challenger Ethereum an opening
summary: Ethereum, a rival virtual currency to Bitcoin, has surged 1,000% in value over the past three months, attracting attention from major corporations like JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft, and IBM. Ethereum's blockchain technology allows for faster and cheaper transactions, and its smart contracts enable the creation of online markets and programmable transactions. While some experts warn of security problems, Ethereum's sophisticated capabilities have made it fascinating to corporate America, with IBM and Microsoft experimenting with its use in various industries.

images.alt_text: The first full public version of the Ethereum software was recently released, and the system could face some of the same technical and legal problems that tarnished Bitcoin.

site_title: Staying a step ahead of fraudsters
summary: Businesses must adopt innovative data combinations to authenticate transactions and combat fraud. Unlike technology giants, global criminal fraud organizations invest heavily in research and development to stay ahead. Companies like Amazon use data to reduce manual review, while small and medium enterprises can use analytics to target growth and prevent fraud. Experian provides tools to help small businesses drive growth through data analysis, and banks can use data from mobile phones, utilities, and social media to predict credit risk in emerging markets.

site_title: Singapore 1000 gets ready for SG100
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 companies, ranked by revenue and profitability, have demonstrated resilience amid challenging economic conditions. The 2016 Singapore 1000 list shows improved combined turnover of S$3 trillion, with a 0.8% increase in turnover growth. Notable sectors contributing to this growth include property, transport/storage, and services. However, manufacturing industry representation has declined, and SMEs face challenges due to a tight labor market and increased levies. Credit rating polarisation has also been observed, with an increase in Investment Grade companies and those in the High Risk band. The government's 2016 Budget proposal highlights the need for new strategies for growth and productivity.

site_title: TMC Life Sciences eyes growth triangle, China
summary: TMC Life Sciences Bhd, a Malaysia-listed healthcare company, plans to expand its facilities in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, focusing on the growth triangle and medical tourism. The company aims to maximize synergies and tap into the growing demand for quality healthcare services. TMC plans to establish a health services education and training school in partnership with a UK institution and will refer patients to its Iskandariah Hospital in Johor, Malaysia. The company also has its sights on the China-India-Australia growth triangle, particularly China, where it expects to capitalize on the demand for quality healthcare services.

images.alt_text: TMC, controlled by Mr Lim, is likely to set up a health services education and training school.

site_title: Navigating corporate governance challenges over a firm's life cycle
summary: Family businesses face corporate governance challenges as they evolve, with internal and external risks. Key issues include family governance, succession planning, and business governance. A 2013 survey found five major causes of conflict: competence, future strategy, communication, remuneration, and succession. Family businesses must address these challenges to survive and thrive. As they grow, they need to establish proper family governance mechanisms, such as family constitutions and family offices, to manage conflicts and ensure continuity. Failure to plan for succession can lead to business demise, while inadequate internal controls and risk management can result in financial losses.

site_title: India looks to bury feud with Italy to achieve bigger ambition
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to attend a European Union summit, seeking to mend ties with Italy after a four-year feud over the arrest of two Italian marines for killing fishermen in 2012. Italy wants the second marine to be released, while India has joined international arbitration. The EU plans to discuss the issue with Modi, which could impact India's bid for membership in the Missile Technology Control Regime. India hopes a thaw in ties will allow it to pursue its global ambitions.

site_title: Sharp, Foxconn pushing to close rescue deal after a month of delays
summary: Sharp Corp and Foxconn Technology Group are pushing to close a rescue deal for the Japanese manufacturer, which has been delayed due to disagreements. Sharp's banks are ready to extend the deadline for most of its 510 billion yen loans and credit lines beyond March 31, giving the company more time to reach a renegotiated deal. Foxconn is seeking to cut the amount it will pay for equity in Sharp to about 389 billion yen, while keeping a payment of 100 billion yen for preferred shares owned by banks.

site_title: Oil prices up slightly in thin holiday trading
summary: Oil prices rose slightly in Easter holiday trading, supported by disruptions to oil supplies in Nigeria and Iraq, as well as plans by major producers to freeze output. Brent crude futures increased 22 US cents to $40.66 per barrel, while US crude's front-month contract rose 42 US cents to $39.88 a barrel. The upcoming Opec meeting in Doha may lead to a production freeze, which could further support prices.

site_title: Tokyo govt to make it easier for car makers to get accident footage
summary: The Tokyo government plans to revise the Law on the Protection of Personal Information to make it easier for car makers to access video footage of traffic accidents, mainly for improving self-driving technologies. The aim is to support technological development, with the goal of putting self-driving vehicles into practical use by the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The revised law will allow accreditation organizations to receive footage with personal information altered to prevent identification, supporting the development of self-driving vehicles.

images.alt_text: The government is planning legislative measures to make it easier to provide, mainly to Japanese car makers, video footage of traffic accidents recorded by event data recorders installed in vehicles and street security cameras.

site_title: Cordlife to address concerns over CEO's abrupt resignation
summary: The board of Cordlife Corp has agreed to hold a dialogue session with shareholders to address concerns over CEO Jeremy Yee's abrupt resignation. Following a meeting with SIAS, the company's chairman and lead independent director will meet with shareholders to discuss the reasons behind Yee's departure and the company's future plans. The board is optimistic about finding a new CEO to lead the company through its next phase, with the goal of meeting sustainable growth levels and fulfilling its potential.

site_title: OCBC's CEO joins rarified S$10m plus pay club
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO, Samuel Tsien, received a S$10.5 million pay for 2015, increasing by 6.1% from the previous year. He joins the exclusive club of CEOs with pay above S$10 million, following peers Piyush Gupta of DBS and Wee Ee Cheong of UOB. Tsien's pay increase came mainly from a higher bonus of S$5.5 million, with a S$2.8 million increase in deferred share awards. OCBC posted a 2% increase in net profit of S$3.9 billion in 2015.

site_title: Equity crowdfunding still a roll of the dice
summary: Singapore is set to introduce equity crowdfunding, allowing accredited investors to buy shares or debt in startups. Regulators will need to balance investor protection and issuer access to capital. The platform, FundedHere, has already launched, with rival Capbridge following suit. The success of equity crowdfunding in Singapore is uncertain, with mixed results seen globally. Critics argue that lower disclosure and offering requirements may limit investor access to management, while proponents see it as a way for early-stage issuers to raise capital at lower costs. The government must strike a balance between protecting investors and giving issuers access to capital.

site_title: Moving SMEs up the productivity and innovation ladder for growth
summary: SPRING Singapore aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) enhance their productivity and innovation through various assistance schemes. The agency offers grants, vouchers, and loans to support businesses in restructuring and seizing new growth opportunities. Two case studies, Heng Long Pte Ltd and Oculus Pte Ltd, demonstrate the effectiveness of SPRING's programs. Heng Long improved business processes and energy efficiency, while Oculus developed new capabilities in manufacturing cosmetic contact lenses, resulting in increased productivity and competitiveness. SPRING's efforts contribute to Singapore's goal of creating a value-creating economy and maintaining its position as a top business destination.

site_title: Helping customers secure mobile information
summary: Singapore-based Blu5 View has developed mobile security solutions tailored to customers' specific needs, akin to Lego pieces. The company, co-founded by Melvern Chia and Paolo Rossini, aims to fill the gap in mobile security for governments and large corporations. Blu5's approach is to create custom-made solutions using modular, customizable, and "hackable" products. The company has seen significant growth, with sales more than doubling to $14.2 million in 2015, and is now seeking sustainable growth, expanding into new markets and sectors, including fintech and the Internet of Things.

site_title: On the fast lane to growth
summary: Edcol Global, an international procurement and trading company, is expanding globally due to the robust automotive industry. Established in 2001, the company sources parts, components, and raw materials for automotive manufacturing facilities in India, UAE, Europe, South Africa, Thailand, Mexico, and the US. Edcol Global director Eddy Kok stated that their sourcing activities are worldwide, with goods going directly to manufacturing plants or being consolidated in Singapore before redistribution. This growth is driven by the increasing demand for automotive products, positioning Edcol Global for continued expansion.

site_title: No bids for US$2.7b Philippine infrastructure project
summary: A US$2.7 billion Philippine infrastructure project to build an expressway and dike received no bids by a Monday deadline, raising concerns about its viability and potential scrapping by a new administration after elections in May. The project, part of President Benigno Aquino's Public-Private Partnership programme, aims to upgrade ageing roads, airports, and schools. The lack of bids casts doubt on the project's future, with some speculating that plans may be changed or scrapped.

site_title: UAE banks agree to suspend action against indebted SMEs
summary: UAE banks agree to suspend legal action against indebted small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for up to three months to prevent defaults that may jeopardize the economy. The initiative, involving lenders and borrowers, aims to give breathing space to SMEs contributing 60% of the UAE's GDP. The move follows a spate of defaults due to commodity price weakness and reduced bank liquidity. Banks will work with lenders to restructure loans, and the central bank has backed the initiative, which is expected to help prevent a surge in defaults.

site_title: China bank regulator cracks down on improper bad debt transactions
summary: China's banking regulator has tightened its scrutiny of distressed asset managers, cracking down on improper bad debt transactions with commercial banks. The regulator has prohibited AMCs from signing private agreements, including implicit repurchase guarantees, which distort transaction structures or change risk-bearing parties. This comes as China's banking sector faces a 10-year high of 1.27 trillion yuan in non-performing loans, with real levels potentially higher. The move aims to address "in-the-closet" credit risks and address "illegal conduct" among asset managers.

site_title: Play on second liners as market drifts
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 17.1 points to 2,830.29 on March 28, 2016, due to a lack of direction after Hong Kong's Easter Monday closure. The decline was cushioned by a rise in Dow futures, which suggested Wall Street would open in the black. The three banks and Singtel contributed to the fall, while supermarket operator Sheng Siong's shares rose on volume of 798,700 shares. Analysts, including DBSV and Shroders, maintained their buy calls on the market, citing potential support from government initiatives and a steady performance for 2016.

site_title: Belgium seeks more information on airport CCTV's 'man in the hat'
summary: Belgium's police issued a new appeal for information about a man caught on CCTV at Brussels airport with two others who are thought to have blown themselves up in the check-in area last Tuesday. The man, dubbed "the man in the hat," is believed by authorities to be Faycal Cheffou, a self-styled freelance journalist. Half a dozen people have been charged in connection with the attacks, which killed 35 people and injured over 300. The European hunt for suspects has revealed links to the Paris attacks last year and foiled a potential attack in France last week.

site_title: Racing away with success
summary: Singapore's fitness company F1 Recreation has experienced a 16-fold increase in revenue over nine years, driven by the growing interest in fitness among Singaporeans. The company, which started with just two people and a 200 sq ft room in 2007, now sees customers every 10 meters along East Coast Park. CEO Tan Tse Yong attributes the growth to the surge in fitness interest, from just two to three orders a week to a significant increase in demand.

site_title: MAS unlikely to flatten slope of Sing $ policy band to zero: Citi
summary: Singapore's central bank, Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is unlikely to flatten the slope of the Singapore dollar's policy band to zero, according to Citi Research. However, macroeconomic conditions worsening since the start of this year may lead to "granular" easing, potentially reducing the slope to 0.25% for signalling purposes. MAS has shifted its 2016 headline inflation forecast downwards, and a fiscal surplus in the budget suggests the economy is not yet in a dire stage, making a sharp drop in GDP growth or a zero slope less likely.

site_title: Frasers adds 8th property to Jakarta portfolio
summary: Frasers Hospitality, the hospitality arm of Frasers Centrepoint Limited, has launched its third serviced residence in Jakarta, Indonesia, with Fraser Place Setiabudi. The 151-unit property is part of the group's plan to capitalize on the trend of shorter but frequent stays by business travelers. With eight properties in Jakarta, the group aims to reach 1,300 units by 2019. The new property features one- and two-bedroom apartments to cater to the demand, and Frasers Hospitality's global portfolio now stands at 140 properties worldwide.

site_title: India seen as next big e-commerce market for global players
summary: India is poised to become a significant e-commerce market for global players, with a growing market size of up to $25 billion annually and a potential for 40% annual growth. The country's unique characteristics, such as its mobile-led and often mobile-only internet usage, and its dispersed physical retail landscape, make it an attractive opportunity for investors. Despite regulatory hurdles, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's pledge to be more open to foreign investment and simplify regulations is expected to boost the industry. Local companies, such as Quikr and Flipkart, are already innovating and adapting to the market, with the potential to capture a significant share of the growing e-commerce landscape.

site_title: Solar energy lights the path for growth
summary: REC Solar, a Norwegian company, has successfully harnessed the potential of solar energy to drive growth. Formed in 1996, the company expanded its production capacity to Singapore in 2008, investing S$2.53 billion. Since then, it has manufactured 15 million solar panels, with 4.5 million produced in Singapore last year. REC aims to become one of the world's top 10 solar module suppliers by 2020, driven by its Singapore plant, now its global headquarters.

site_title: Prudently calibrated, soberly argued and highly inclusive
summary: The 2016 Singapore Budget aims to support businesses, especially SMEs, amidst economic slowdown and restructuring. The government has allocated S$4.5 billion for the Industry Transformation Programme and introduced measures to help SMEs, such as a 50% Corporate Income Tax Rebate and a Working Capital Loan Scheme. The Budget also includes a small positive fiscal impulse of 1% of GDP, with a projected overall surplus of S$3.4 billion. The government has emphasized the need to create wealth and redistribute it sustainably, rather than relying on handouts.

site_title: First Food Hub tenants to have high-tech cold-room facility
summary: Singapore's JTC Food Hub @ Senoko has introduced a high-tech cold-room facility, offering a first-in-Singapore high-pressure processing service. The facility will extend the shelf life of foods by 3-8 times, reducing waste and opening new markets. Three food-processing businesses, Tenderfresh Fried & BBQ Chicken, Deli Asia, and Kemin Industries, will be the first to utilize the technology. The facility is expected to save tenants up to S$200,000 in capital costs. The government aims to maximize land use and gather core functions under one roof to save businesses capital expenditure and manpower needs.

site_title: Countering cyber attacks is big business
summary: Cyber security solutions firm Accel Singapore has experienced exponential growth in profits, with revenue more than doubling and net profit tripling in its financial year ended March 2014. The company, founded in 2012, has established itself as a leading provider of advanced cyber security solutions, offering services such as information protection, advanced security management, and compliance. With a strong track record and solid growth prospects, Accel Singapore is expanding into India and Japan, leveraging its majority investor's presence in these countries.

site_title: Billionaire aims to create China's first chip giant, touts US$30b arsenal
summary: Billionaire Zhao Weiguo, president of Tsinghua Unigroup Ltd, aims to create China's first chip giant with a $30 billion investment plan. Focusing on memory chips, Zhao plans to take on foreign giants like Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and Micron Tech. Despite regulatory hurdles, Zhao is confident in his strategy, citing the potential for $20 billion in sales. The investment plan will be funded by local governments, investors, and private equity, with Zhao emphasizing the importance of self-sustaining market revenue.

site_title: S Korean builder upbeat on US$20b Saudi housing deal
summary: A South Korean construction firm, Daewoo Engineering & Construction, is confident that a US$20 billion housing deal with Saudi Arabia will go ahead despite the impact of oil price slumps. The 10-year project will build 100,000 housing units and related infrastructure near Riyadh, with a memorandum of understanding signed in Seoul. Daewoo's spokesperson cited King Salman's policy priority on the project, making it a reliable and trustworthy undertaking.

site_title: Resale prices of private apartments inches up 0.4% in February
summary: Singapore's resale prices of private apartments rose 0.4% in February, following a 0.2% increase in January, according to the National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index. The increase was driven by prices in central regions, with prices rising 0.5% in February. However, R'ST Research director Ong Kah Seng notes that this could be a "one-off rebound" due to high-end homes still experiencing flat or slight price declines. Resale prices in non-central regions rose 0.3% and small units fell 1.1%.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality opens third serviced residence in Jakarta
summary: Frasers Hospitality, a division of Frasers Centrepoint Limited, has launched Fraser Place Setiabudi, its third serviced residence in Jakarta, Indonesia. The 151-unit property is located in Jakarta's Golden Triangle and is expected to contribute to the company's portfolio growth in the region. With this opening, Frasers Hospitality's Jakarta portfolio will total eight properties with over 1,300 units by 2019, according to CEO Choe Peng Sum.

site_title: China's fourth-largest oil producer said to cut pay, investment
summary: Shaanxi Yanchang Petroleum Group, China's fourth-largest oil producer, is cutting investments and salaries due to the oil price crash. The company will reduce executive pay by 10% and delay paying non-executive salaries for up to six months. It will also cut spending by 20-24 billion yuan (US$3.7 billion) and delay paying bonuses to non-executive employees. The move follows a 60% decline in Brent crude prices over the past two years, forcing companies to slash spending and lay off workers.

site_title: Silicon Valley looks to next big thing
summary: Silicon Valley is shifting its focus towards artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning, driven by the growing need to collect and analyze vast amounts of data. Companies like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are investing heavily in AI capabilities, which could lead to the next big growth spurt in the tech industry. This technology has the potential to revolutionize various sectors, from computer systems to business operations, and could surpass advertising revenue as a major business driver.

images.alt_text: (From left) Jeff Dean, Google's AI-machine learning technology head, Ms Greene and Mr Holzle, who predicts that the business of renting out machines and software will surpass Google advertising.

site_title: Enterprising and innovative Budget 2016
summary: Singapore's Budget 2016 aims to support enterprising and innovative businesses, particularly medium enterprises (FGMEs), amidst a sluggish global economy. The government proposes measures to enhance capabilities, generate revenue, and globalize through the Industry Transformation Programme and a one-stop Business Grants Portal. FGMEs in construction, manufacturing, and logistics can access over S$450 million for robotics projects, while the Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 Plan offers a S$4 billion war chest for industry-research collaboration. The budget also sweetens mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals and extends the Double Tax Deduction for Internationalisation scheme to support FGMEs in expanding into new overseas markets.

site_title: US consumer spending edges up, inflation retreats
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.1% in February, in line with economists' expectations, after a 0.1% gain in January. Overall inflation retreated, with the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index increasing 1.0% in the 12 months through February. The core PCE, the Fed's preferred inflation measure, is running below the 2% target and suggests the Federal Reserve will continue to gradually raise interest rates this year despite a tightening labor market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on consumer spending data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday after data showed consumer spending picked up in February, indicating an economic recovery. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.63 points, or 0.16%, to 17,544.36, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. This marks the latest sign of a strengthening economy, despite ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore must guard against the worst of democracy too
summary: Singapore must address inequalities and engage stakeholders to prevent disillusionment in its democracy, following the rise of "fringe" candidates in the US presidential race. The country's government should focus on economic development, narrowing the income gap, and improving transparency and accountability. A partnership between the public and private sectors can foster social and economic equality, leading to good standing with civic society. By doing so, Singapore can mitigate the risks associated with democracy and ensure a more inclusive and equitable society.

site_title: Local banks chip in to upgrade skills
summary: OCBC Bank is launching the OCBC FutureReady Programme, a S$500,000 initiative to empower junior executives through skills upgrade. The program includes a S$500 cash top-up for permanent non-executive staff, an OCBC FutureReady Catalogue, and a three-day roadshow. Other banks, such as DBS and UOB, are also offering similar support for employee training. The move aims to address the challenges faced by employees in staying current with technological advancements and changing consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: Local banks are chipping in to the skills upgrade impetus the government is pushing the country towards, providing extra money or credit for the training of junior executives.

site_title: Brussels Airlines decamps after terrorist attack wrecks airport
summary: Brussels Airlines has shifted its operations to four alternative airports after a terrorist attack at Brussels Airport, which killed 11 people and injured over 80. The airline has moved flights to Frankfurt, Zurich, Antwerp, and Liege, using buses to transport passengers to flights. Costs associated with the attack are estimated to be in the double-digit million-euro range. Despite the challenges, Brussels Airlines aims to resume flights from the airport once it reopens, with a preliminary investigation indicating that the main building and check-in facilities are structurally stable.

site_title: Uber using profits from other cities to bankroll expansion in China: CEO
summary: Uber is generating over $1 billion in profit annually in its top 30 cities globally, which is partly used to fund its expansion in China. Despite losing over $1 billion in China's ride-hailing market, Uber's investment is deemed sustainable due to its global profits. The company's market share in China has grown from 1% to 30% since 2015, with Uber testing new products such as UberCommute, a carpooling app. Uber's Chinese business has boosted its valuation to over $8 billion, and the company expects to continue investing in the market.

site_title: Canada energy firms buying back debt cheapened by oil rout
summary: Canadian energy companies are buying back debt at low prices amid the worst oil downturn in decades. About 20% of US$108 billion of energy-company bonds trade below 80 cents on the dollar, allowing companies like Encana Corp and Precision Drilling Corp to reduce their leverage and save on interest costs. Companies are using spare cash to repurchase securities trading below par, with Encana offering to buy up to US$250 million of its senior notes and Repsol's Canadian unit offering to purchase its seven longest-dated bonds.

site_title: Cosco-PSA venture to invest in berths for next-gen mega containerships
summary: Cosco-PSA Corporation has agreed to invest in new container berths at the Pasir Panjang Terminal in Singapore, capable of serving next-generation mega containerships. The investment, valued at three new mega berths, will be fully integrated with PSA's infrastructure and supported by automated and intelligent port technologies. The berths are expected to begin operations in 2017 and will enhance port productivity and support the growing business complexity of customers. The investment is seen as a strategic move to solidify Singapore's position as an international maritime center and contribute to China's Maritime Silk Road initiative.

site_title: China mutual funds planning products linked to commodity futures
summary: China's mutual fund industry is planning to develop investment products linked to commodity futures, betting on the government's campaign to streamline the country's resource sector and drive up prices for raw materials. The funds aim to diversify their portfolio beyond stocks and fixed income, with no immediate upturn in sight. Inflows from the industry could boost liquidity in the commodity futures market, increasing Beijing's sway in international markets. Several funds are awaiting regulatory approval for similar steps, including a fund tracking Shanghai copper futures.

site_title: Amara buying Newton Road bungalow for S$18.8 million
summary: Amara Holdings purchased a freehold bungalow at 31 Newton Road in Singapore for S$18.8 million, or S$1,256 per square foot. The site's combined area with the adjacent property, 29 Newton Road, could be redeveloped into an apartment project of 42,417 sq ft. This would be large enough for a project of about 55 units. The purchase comes after Amara posted a 59% drop in net profit to S$14.33 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: Globalisation gets short shrift amid slowing demand
summary: Globalization faces significant challenges as the world economy slows, with monetary stimulus losing effectiveness. Countries are turning to protectionist controls, and support for free trade is waning due to concerns over job destruction and inadequate alternatives. The refugee crisis and terrorist attacks in Europe further exacerbate the negative sentiment. China and other emerging markets are experiencing trade imbalances, while the US is taking a cautious approach to monetary tightening. The flow of information is also being Balkanized, with authoritarian regimes seeking to control online content. Economists argue that a lack of demand and income inequality are key issues, and that deficit spending and infrastructure investments could help alleviate the problems.

site_title: Starwood Hotels receives higher $82.75-a-share offer from Anbang
summary: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc accepted a higher takeover offer from Anbang Insurance Group Co, valued at $82.75 a share, or about $14 billion, surpassing Marriott International Inc's offer of $75.91 a share, or about $12.8 billion. The new offer from Anbang shows the Chinese company won't back down in its bid to build hotel holdings, which would add brands like Sheraton and W, as well as $4 billion worth of real estate.

site_title: Constant innovation with a dose of optimism
summary: Singapore-based Exceltec, a diversified property firm, has experienced steady growth despite economic challenges. The company has expanded into new businesses, including environmental engineering services and green solutions for buildings, driven by its adoption of technology. Exceltec's revenue has more than doubled to S$29.6 million, and its staff strength has doubled to 335. Managing Director Koh Hock Seng attributes the company's success to its ability to seize opportunities during downturns and its focus on innovation and technology. Exceltec is now preparing to expand into the healthcare sector and is exploring opportunities in neighboring countries, but emphasizes the importance of thorough preparation and cultural understanding before expanding overseas.

site_title: Innopac in talks to reduce consideration for failed China CNG investment
summary: Innopac Holdings is negotiating with Rubic Prize to reduce the consideration paid for its failed investment in China's natural gas market. Innopac acquired 81.8% stake in Extera in 2013, which owned CNG refilling stations and distributed natural gas in Shandong. However, these plans did not materialize, and Dezhou Sheng Rong ended its CNG business last year. Innopac will transfer its remaining 18.2% stake in Extera to Rubic and return the consideration shares.

site_title: Pushing for growth in the age of value creation
summary: Singapore's government calls for a rethink on value-adding in diverse industries, highlighting the need for a new cultural approach to unleash creative thinking from all parts of an organisation. This shift towards value creation presents opportunities for growth, particularly in sectors such as financial services, oil and marine industries, and business services, which face challenges like competition, costs, and labour shortages. To succeed, businesses must innovate, focus on growing productivity, and adopt a new strategic direction. This approach is essential for Singapore's economy to thrive in the age of value creation.

site_title: Belgium releases suspect directly linked with attacks
summary: Belgium released a suspect linked to the Brussels airport attacks, Faycal C, due to lack of evidence. He was charged with "terrorist murder" and had been identified as Faycal Cheffou in media reports. The suspect was found with two others in CCTV footage, but fled with an unexploded bomb. Police are seeking witnesses to identify the third man. The release comes as authorities continue to investigate the March 22 attacks that killed 32 people.

site_title: Cheap buyout plans in Singapore? Not so quick, say minority shareholders
summary: Singapore's minority shareholders are increasingly pushing back against buyout plans by demanding higher premiums, as companies' depressed market valuations present opportunities for take-private transactions. Analysts expect a wave of such deals, with DBS Vickers identifying several small and mid-cap companies as potential targets. Minority shareholders are becoming more educated and vocal, with some companies, like Singapore Airlines and OSIM International, having to sweeten their offers to win approval. This trend is part of a growing trend of shareholder activism in Asia, with Hong Kong's minority shareholders also scuppering a large bid by Li Ka-shing.

site_title: Pending sales of US existing homes increase by most in a year
summary: US existing home sales pending contracts increased by 3.5% in February, the largest gain in a year, driven by better employment prospects and low borrowing costs. The median projection of economists was a 1.2% increase. The Midwest led the region with an 11.4% jump in contract signings. Existing home sales rose 5.1% from the previous year, and the pending home sales index reached 109.1, its strongest level since July. Economists see the increase as a positive sign for the spring-selling season, but note that tight inventory remains a challenge.

site_title: Hot property market Shenzhen tightens rules to cool housing market
summary: Shenzhen, a southern Chinese city, has introduced stricter rules to cool its hot property market. First-time buyers and some second-time buyers must now make a 40% downpayment, up from 30%. Non-local buyers must pay three consecutive years of income tax and social security premiums. The city has also banned financial institutions from offering margin lending to home buyers and plans to increase land supply and build more government-funded houses to balance demand and supply. This move is part of the government's efforts to curb the country's property market, which has seen a strong rebound in prices in major cities.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen. The city is now the top property market in the country, with prices up nearly 57 per cent in February from a year earlier.

site_title: A rare commitment to historical design, artwork in China
summary: A Swiss-led team restored a 19th-century village square in Shaxi, China, to its original historical design and artwork. The project, which took years to complete, was praised by UNESCO and aims to be a model for other village renovation efforts in China. The restored square features a centuries-old Buddhist temple, a four-storey theatre, and a marketplace with low-slung wooden facades. The project has encouraged local villagers to develop their own industries and community economy, with some renting out their homes to outsiders and moving elsewhere.

images.alt_text: The square of Sideng Village is now considered by some to be one of the most beautiful in China; villagers in traditional Shaxi clothes watching a performance in the square; gate leading to the old town centre of Shaxi; theatre in village square (above).

site_title: Indonesia's new economic package to focus on medicine, small business
summary: Indonesia's new economic package aims to boost economic activity by easing restrictions on imported raw materials for the pharmaceutical industry and providing more credit opportunities for small export firms. The package, announced by President Joko Widodo's administration, includes measures to simplify import and export procedures at ports.
