The moves are seen as a signal to foreign businesses that the government is trying to improve the business environment. The package is the latest in a series of 10 policy packages announced since September to attract investment and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Chinese automaker BYD's 2015 profit surges to six-year high on green cars
summary: Chinese automaker BYD reported a six-year high in 2015 net profit of 2.8 billion yuan (US$429.74 million), a 551% rise from the previous year, driven by soaring demand for green-energy cars. The surge was fueled by government policies, including subsidies and tax incentives, which more than quadrupled sales of new energy vehicles. BYD's electric and hybrid vehicles, such as its best-selling Qin plug-in hybrid sedan, are seen as a key strategy for China's domestic auto industry to compete with global rivals and curb pollution.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,702.41 after slipping 1.38 points on Monday. The index saw 1.54 billion lots valued at RM1.3 billion traded, with 321 gainers and 447 losers.

site_title: Sinochem, Halcyon Agri, GMG Global in dual takeover transaction
summary: Sinochem International Corp, a China-based conglomerate, is set to acquire Singapore-listed Halcyon Agri, becoming its largest shareholder, in a deal valued at S$450 million. Halcyon Agri will expand its plantation acreage, processing capacity, and distribution network under the partnership. The deal represents a significant consolidation in the rubber industry, following China's previous acquisition of Noble Agri. The proposed tie-up gives Halcyon Agri access to the Chinese market, while Sinochem gains control over a major natural rubber supply chain manager.

site_title: OCBC's Samuel Tsien joins CEO S$10m-plus pay club
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO Samuel Tsien received a S$10.5 million pay package for 2015, increasing by 6.1% from the previous year. He joins the exclusive club of CEOs above S$10 million, alongside DBS's Piyush Gupta and United Overseas Bank's Wee Ee Cheong. The increase in pay came mainly from a higher bonus and deferred share awards. OCBC posted a 2% net profit increase in 2015, but its stock closed down 8 cents to S$8.83 on the same day.

site_title: Terratech to place 74m new shares at 4.05 S cents apiece for strategic investments
summary: Terratech Group plans to issue up to 74 million new shares at 4.05 Singapore cents apiece, raising S$3 million for strategic investments. The shares represent 12.03% of existing and enlarged share capital. About 60% of the proceeds will be used for investments, acquisitions, and joint ventures, while the remainder will be allocated to working capital. UOB Kay Hian is the placement agent for the deal.

site_title: Cosco Pacific and PSA team up on mega terminals in Singapore
summary: Cosco Pacific and PSA Corporation have formed a joint venture, Cosco-PSA Terminal (CPT), to invest in new container berths in Singapore's Pasir Panjang Terminal. The three new mega berths will be operational from 2017, increasing port productivity and supporting the latest automated port technologies. The investment is seen as a strategic move for both partners, demonstrating confidence in Singapore as an international maritime hub. The joint venture is also expected to contribute positively to China's Maritime Silk Road initiative and 'One Belt, One Road' vision.

site_title: Palm oil hits two-year top, spurred by output worries
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures surged to a two-year high, reaching RM2,758 per tonne, due to concerns over a crop-damaging El Nino weather event that may curb yields. Experts forecast prices to reach RM3,000 by mid-year, a 10% increase from current levels. Annual palm output from Malaysia is expected to fall by 2 million tonnes, while Indonesian production is forecast to decline by 1.2 million tonnes. The market's reaction is considered speculative, with traders weighing demand and supply concerns.

site_title: Secura Group enters into MOU to buy cybersecurity provider RedSentry
summary: Secura Group, a Catalist-listed company, has entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to acquire 100% of cybersecurity provider RedSentry and RedSentry Consultancy. The deal aims to expand Secura's cybersecurity offerings and increase its market share in Singapore. The MOU is non-binding and must be followed by a definitive sale and purchase agreement (SPA) within three months, subject to due diligence and approvals.

site_title: Data breach reveals expat details in Thailand
summary: Thousands of foreign nationals living in southern Thailand's provinces had their personal details leaked online due to a data breach during a test for police. The leaked data included names, addresses, professions, and passport numbers of over 2,000 foreigners. The website carrying the data was taken down after going viral, with the developer admitting it was a mistake during testing stages. The incident comes as Thailand's junta-ruled government cracks down on foreign visa overstayers and criminals, sparking mistrust of foreigners.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 17.1 points to 2,830.29, due to a decline in three banks and Singtel, despite a rise in Dow futures suggesting Wall Street would open in the black. The index saw low volume of 2.5 billion units worth S$773.4 million, with Annica Holdings losing S$0.001 on huge volume.

site_title: Belgian Crisis Centre increases bomb blast toll to 34 dead, includng attackers
summary: Belgium's Crisis Centre has revised the death toll from Tuesday's bomb blasts to 34 dead, including the three attackers. The revised toll includes 15 deaths at the airport and 13 at the metro, with 28 identified victims from the airport and metro blasts. The victims include foreign nationals from the US, UK, Italy, China, Netherlands, France, Germany, and Sweden.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime wins US$10m cable lay job
summary: Mermaid Maritime has won a US$10 million cable lay job through its Qatari business unit. The contract involves subsea cable installation and diving services for a global cable manufacturing company. The project will be completed in three months, starting from April 2016. Mermaid Maritime will utilize the DP2 construction barge, Mubarak Supporter, and other specialized vessels and equipment.

site_title: IMF chief to reappoint David Lipton as principal deputy
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde announced her intention to reappoint David Lipton as the Fund's first deputy managing director for a new five-year term starting September 1. Lipton, an American with experience as an economic adviser to President Barack Obama and head of global country risk management at Citigroup, will undergo approval by the IMF's executive board. Lagarde praised Lipton's policy-making acumen, communication and negotiating skills. This reappointment aims to maintain stability and continuity at the IMF.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to establish bespoke industry transformation plans for over 20 sectors, aiming to boost productivity and innovation. Halcyon Agri Corporation will acquire Sinochem's natural rubber business. Robo-advisory services for banks may be introduced in Singapore. Resale home prices rose 0.4% in February, while employees feel pressure from tech adoption. OCBC Bank will give non-executive employees a S$500 top-up for SkillsFuture courses. The Straits Times Index closed lower in low volume, down 17.1 points, amid global market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: More than 20 sectors in Singapore will each get bespoke plans tailored to their specific needs to help them raise productivity, invest in skills, drive innovation and promote internationalisation.

site_title: Government to study how to transform 20 sectors of Singapore's economy: Heng
summary: Singapore's government has established teams to study and transform 20 economic sectors, including logistics and tourism, to make them future-ready. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced this on a visit to a precision engineering company. The initiative aims to enhance the country's competitiveness and resilience in the face of global economic challenges.

site_title: UAE raises April petrol, diesel prices
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) will increase domestic petrol and diesel prices in April, following a global increase in oil prices. Petrol prices will rise to 1.51 dirhams (41 US cents) per litre from 1.36 dirhams, while diesel prices will increase to 1.56 dirhams from 1.40 dirhams. The price adjustment is based on average global prices with added operating costs, as the UAE shifts from a fixed, subsidised fuel pricing system to a monthly adjustment system.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises to 2-week high on weak yen, Sharp soars
summary: Japanese stocks rose to a two-week high on Monday, driven by a weaker yen and expectations of a takeover deal at Sharp Corp. The Nikkei gained 0.8% to 17,134.37, while the broader Topix rose 1.2% to 1,381.85. Investor purchases of stocks before the business year-end also contributed to the market's gain.

site_title: China bank regulator tightens scrutiny over bad debt managers: document
summary: China's banking regulator has tightened scrutiny on distressed asset managers, prohibiting private agreements with commercial banks that could distort transaction structures or change risk-bearing parties of non-performing loans. The China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) has also asked local offices to strengthen inspections and take regulatory measures against "illegal conduct". The move aims to address "in-the-closet" credit risks, where banks conceal real non-performing loan levels by making repurchase agreements privately with asset managers. This comes as China's banking sector faces its greatest challenge since the global financial crisis, with NPLs reaching a 10-year-high of 1.27 trillion yuan.

site_title: Nordic Group units secure S$36.5m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group's subsidiaries, Austin Energy Pte Ltd, Nordic Flow Control Pte Ltd, and Multiheight Scaffolding Pte Ltd (MHS), have secured contracts valued at S$36.5 million with repeat customers. The contracts include a S$0.4 million project in Indonesia and maintenance agreements with oil majors and other customers for a total of S$36.1 million. The agreements are for one to five years, with MHS's contract with an oil major being extended for the first time on a longer tenure basis. Nordic shares rose 0.6 cents to close at 18.6 cents on Monday.

site_title: China Feb services trade deficit narrows to US$16b
summary: China's services trade deficit narrowed to $16 billion in February, down from $20.7 billion in January, according to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The deficit was largely due to a $15.5 billion gap in spending between Chinese and foreign tourists. Meanwhile, China had a $25.9 billion surplus in goods trade in February. This marks the first two months of the year with a narrowing services trade deficit.

site_title: Philippines puts Marcos jewel images online to teach about graft
summary: Philippine authorities have launched an online exhibition of jewelry owned by late dictator Ferdinand Marcos and his family, aiming to educate a new generation about the corruption of the Marcos era. The "Virtual Jewelry Exhibit" features regular postings of recovered valuables, including a diamond tiara, with captions explaining their value and how they could fund public services. The move comes as the Marcos family tries to extend its political comeback in elections in May, with Ferdinand Marcos Jr. running for vice-president and Imelda Marcos seeking re-election to Congress.

site_title: Oil prices rise in thin holiday trading
summary: Oil prices rose in thin Easter holiday trading, adding to recent gains, as optimism grows over a potential production freeze among major producers. Brent crude futures increased 25 cents to $40.69 per barrel, while US crude rose 34 cents to $39.80 per barrel. The price increase follows a 50% rise from multi-year lows in January due to disruptions in Nigeria and Iraq, and plans for a production freeze. Members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries are set to meet on April 17 to discuss the plan, which could support current market sentiment.

images.alt_text: [LONDON] Oil prices firmed in thin Easter holiday trading on Monday, adding to gains in recent weeks as optimism holds that a production freeze among major producers may be implemented.

site_title: Singapore employees feel pressure of tech adoption in workplace: Randstad
summary: Singapore employees are feeling pressured to keep up with technological advancements in the workplace, with 84% of local employees noting the digitization of the workplace has had a "major impact". 89% of employees require additional training to adapt to new digital processes and tools. Despite increased connectivity, respondents feel that technology has distanced relationships between colleagues and external work contacts, with 79% citing a drop in face-to-face interactions. This is higher than the global average of 60%. The high exposure to new digital processes and tools may be the underlying factor for this sentiment.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks reverse earlier gains to close lower
summary: Shanghai stocks closed lower on Monday, reversing earlier gains, as the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.73% to 2,957.82. This was the first time since mid-2015 that profits at China's key industrial companies rose. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.56%. The Hong Kong market was closed for a holiday.

site_title: Japan's ANA suspends flights to Brussels until at least April 10
summary: ANA Holdings, Japan's largest airline, has suspended flights from Tokyo to Brussels until at least April 10 due to the aftermath of suicide bombings at Brussels Airport. The airline will review the situation after April 11 and will not reopen its flights until then. As a result, 39 flights, affecting 4,500 travelers, will be canceled until April 10.

site_title: China's yuan flat, faces downward pressure if US dollar rises sharply
summary: China's yuan remained unchanged against the US dollar by midday on Monday, despite a softer official guidance rate, with the midpoint rate at 6.5232 per US dollar. A central bank advisor warned that the yuan will face downward pressure if the US dollar rises sharply, citing a dominant US dollar-selling mood in morning trade. The onshore yuan stayed flat against the euro and firmed 0.5% against the Japanese yen, while offshore yuan traded 0.18% softer than the onshore spot.

site_title: Resale prices of completed private homes in Singapore up 0.4% in February
summary: Resale prices of completed private homes in Singapore rose 0.4% in February, according to the National University of Singapore's flash estimates. This increase was driven by prices in central regions, with a 0.5% rise in districts 1-4. In contrast, non-central regions saw a 0.3% increase, while prices of small units fell 1.1%. The latest figure follows a 0.2% rise in January.

site_title: China bank profits flat-line as bad debts continue to soar
summary: China's Big Four state-run banks are expected to report flat annual earnings growth, marking a decade of slowing profitability, due to a surge in bad debts and economic expansion weakening. Non-performing loans reached a 10-year high of 1.27 trillion yuan, or 1.67% of all loans outstanding. Analysts estimate net profit growth to range from 1% to 1% for 2015. The sector is tackling its greatest challenge since the global financial crisis, with banks lobbying for a lower minimum loan loss provision ratio to free up funds.

images.alt_text: [BEIJING] China's Big Four state-run banks this week are set to report annual earnings growth that likely flat-lined after around a decade of terrific profitability, as a surge in soured loans continued unabated while economic expansion weakened.

site_title: Najib critics roll out 'Save Malaysia' campaign against him
summary: Malaysian opposition politicians, led by former premier Mahathir Mohamad and ex-deputy prime minister Muhyiddin Yassin, have launched a 'Save Malaysia' campaign to oust Prime Minister Najib Razak amid a funding scandal and corruption allegations. The campaign aims to collect 1 million signatures calling for Najib's resignation, which will be presented to the nation's royals. The move is seen as a challenge to Najib's leadership, with Mahathir stating that two years is too long to wait for the next general elections and that the country needs to recover quickly from the current situation.

site_title: EU privacy court cases loom over EU-US data transfer pact
summary: The European Union's top court is reviewing three cases on the legality of bulk data collection, which could impact a new transatlantic data pact known as the Privacy Shield. The framework, agreed upon in February, aims to protect European data transferred to the US. However, EU data protection authorities are assessing the limits of US surveillance activities, a key issue since Edward Snowden's 2013 leaks. If EU law on bulk data collection becomes more restrictive, US commitments on surveillance practices may fall short, putting the Privacy Shield on shaky ground.

site_title: Indonesia keeps palm oil, cocoa bean export taxes unchanged for April
summary: Indonesia has decided to keep its export taxes for crude palm oil and cocoa beans unchanged for April. The export tax for crude palm oil remains at zero, while the tax for cocoa beans will stay at 10 per cent.

site_title: Brazil debates economic cost of corruption investigation
summary: Brazil's former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva warns that the ongoing Petrobras corruption investigation is paralyzing the country's economy, citing a 2.5 percentage point contraction attributed to the probe. The IMF projects a 3.5% economic shrinkage this year, and corruption allegations have reduced GDP by 3.6 percentage points. Lula's comments have sparked debate among analysts, with some defending the investigation as necessary to combat corruption, while others argue it's causing unemployment and economic damage.

site_title: Pakistanis hunt for militants behind blast that killed at least 65
summary: Pakistani authorities launched a hunt for militants behind a suicide bomb attack in Lahore that killed at least 65 people, mostly women and children. The attack, claimed by the Jamaat-ul-Ahrar faction of the Pakistani Taliban, targeted Christians and was seen as a challenge to the government. The group has a history of attacks, including a 2013 bombing at a church in Peshawar. Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif condemned the blast as a cowardly act, vowing to bring the perpetrators to justice.

site_title: OCBC to give S$500 top-up to non-execs for SkillsFuture credit
summary: OCBC Bank has launched the OCBC FutureReady Programme, a nearly S$500,000 initiative to empower its employees through skills development. The programme includes a S$500 cash top-up for permanent non-executive employees to use for SkillsFuture Credit eligible courses, a customised resource of 120 courses, and a three-day roadshow. The bank aims to help employees stay current with technological advancements and employable in a rapidly changing job market.

site_title: Oil prices rise on lower US rig numbers
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday, recovering from last week's decline, but analysts expect traders to hold off on making big moves ahead of a key producers' meeting next month. The main contracts briefly rose above US$40 earlier this month due to hopes for an output freeze agreement between Russia, Saudi Arabia, and other major producers. However, gains were offset by a report of increased US crude stockpiles and a strengthening US dollar.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall, banks down after central bank rate cut
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.2% to 8,691.39 points, weighed by declines in banks, which dropped 0.4% amid concerns about squeezed earnings after the central bank cut interest rates for the third time. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.709 per US dollar. The central bank aims for gradual economic growth, but the move was met with market concerns.

site_title: UN's Ban condemns 'appalling' Pakistan bombing
summary: UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon condemned the Easter Day suicide bombing in Pakistan that killed at least 65 people and injured hundreds more, calling it an "appalling" act of terrorism. Ban called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice, consistent with human rights obligations. The bombing occurred at Gulshan-i-Iqbal Park in Lahore, Pakistan.

site_title: Robo-advisory support for banks in the works in Singapore
summary: Singapore is set to introduce robo-advisory services that will support existing financial advisers, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) chief fintech officer Sopnendu Mohanty. The services, currently in early stages, will enable financial advisers to tap into technology to improve efficiency and customer service. MAS is open to standalone self-service outfits and sees no regulatory barriers to the development of robo-advisory. The regulator aims to foster a customer-focused environment and accelerate application development, particularly in the area of application programming interfaces (API).

site_title: El Nino seen cutting Malaysia palm oil output by 2m tonnes
summary: Malaysia's palm oil output is expected to decline by 2 million tonnes in the oil year ending September 2016 due to the effects of El Nino, its sharpest decline in at least seven years. This decline could lead to stronger rallies in benchmark palm oil prices, which have risen 5% in the last two weeks. Malaysian production is running 100,000 tonnes less than the same period last year, and a deficit of 350,000 tonnes is expected by the end of March.

site_title: Budget 2016: SIATP says Budget builds on what has worked with fresh measures
summary: The Singapore Institute of Accredited Tax Professionals (SIATP) praises the 2016 Budget, saying it builds on existing measures with fresh initiatives. Key tax takeaways include lowering taxes for SMEs, introducing a new scheme to incentivize employee volunteerism, and doubling support for qualifying mergers and acquisitions. SIATP chairman Gerard Ee commends these measures as contributing to economic transformation and supporting Singapore's goal of reaching SG100.

site_title: Hong Kong, Australia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, Australia, and New Zealand are closed on Monday, March 28, 2016, for the Easter holiday, resuming trading on Tuesday, March 29.

site_title: Industry transformation maps to be set up for over 20 economic sectors in Singapore
summary: Singapore has launched an Industry Transformation Programme with a $4.5 billion budget to map out bespoke plans for over 20 sectors to boost productivity, skills, innovation, and internationalization. The 20-plus sectors, covering 80% of Singapore's GDP, will have teams of government officers to develop growth and transformation roadmaps. The programme aims to integrate existing plans and bring together industry associations and companies to align efforts, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need for a coordinated approach.

images.alt_text: More than 20 sectors in Singapore will each get bespoke plans tailored to their specific needs to help them raise productivity, invest in skills, drive innovation and promote internationalisation.

site_title: Gold drops to one-month low as dollar rallies before US data
summary: Gold prices dropped to a one-month low, falling 0.7% to $1,208.38 an ounce, due to a strong US dollar and decreased demand. The price has lost 3.1% last week, the most since November. A rally in the dollar, which has risen for the longest stretch since January, has hurt gold's appeal as an alternative investment asset. Data on US economic figures this week may further impact gold prices, with economists forecasting a 208,000 jobs gain in Friday's March jobs report.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Shanghai stocks opened higher on Monday, March 28, 2016, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.29% to 2,988.01. The Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.59% to 1,896.36, following improved profits of industrial companies in January-February.

site_title: Seoul: Won pares early losses on dollar-selling, shares flat
summary: South Korea's won recovered from early losses on Monday, closing at 1,166.2 to the dollar, up 0.3% from Friday. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) remained flat at 1,982.54 points. Despite the currency's recovery, shares remained unchanged as investors remained cautious. This marked a break from three consecutive losing sessions for the won.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.070 points to 1,701.720. Volume was 45.52 million lots worth RM13 million, with 80 gainers and 38 losers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat, won edges lower
summary: South Korean stocks remained steady, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 0.1% to 1,985.92 points. The won edged lower, down 0.9% to 1,171.1 per US dollar. Investors remained cautious ahead of economic indicators and speeches from US Federal Reserve officials. Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co rose 0.6%, while Hyundai Motor gained 1%. The market awaits the release of South Korea's exports data and the US jobs report, as well as a speech from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on Tuesday.

site_title: Czechs roll out red carpet for first visit by Chinese president Xi Jinping
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping began a two-day state visit to Prague on March 28, 2016, to promote business ties and strengthen strategic relations with the Czech Republic. The visit, the first by a Chinese president, includes a business forum and the signing of Chinese investments worth $21 billion. The Czech government has welcomed Xi's visit, despite protests from the opposition, who compare it to the treatment of Soviet leaders during the Cold War. Chinese investments in the Czech Republic are led by CEFC China Energy, which has acquired stakes in several Czech companies, including banks, airlines, and media outlets.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping begins a two-day state visit to Prague on Monday (March 28) to promote business ties, crowning efforts by Czech President Milos Zeman to build a strategic relationship with Beijing.

site_title: Oil halts two-day slide after US rig count resumes decline
summary: Oil prices rose for the first time in three sessions after the number of active US oil rigs declined, easing a supply glut. US oil futures advanced 1.1% to $39.88 a barrel, following a 4.8% loss in the previous two sessions. The rig count fell to 372, with over 150 rigs parked since the start of the year. The decline in rigs and rise in oil prices may ease concerns about a global surplus, with oil climbing back from a 12-year low earlier this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks boosted by US GDP revision
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.74% on Monday, boosted by revised US GDP figures, which increased optimism about the US economy. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 17,129.27, while the Topix index gained 0.67%. The positive sentiment was attributed to the upward revision of US GDP, which may indicate a stronger economy.

site_title: Amazon to Flipkart clash in India's nascent e-commerce market
summary: Amazon and Flipkart, India's largest e-commerce players, are vying for dominance in the country's rapidly growing market. India's e-commerce sector is valued at $25 billion and growing at 40% annually, making it an attractive opportunity for global players. Despite concerns over industry valuations, the market's potential is seen as a major draw for investors, with many companies, including Alibaba and Amazon, seeking to tap into the country's large and growing smartphone user base.

site_title: China military to end paid-for services within three years
summary: China's military will end paid-for services within three years as part of a reform and anti-corruption push, according to a circular issued by the Central Military Commission. The move aims to reduce corruption and improve the military's combat capability. Non-core activities such as military-run hospitals and hotels will be ditched, with services fulfilling social security functions allowed under a new "civil-military integration" scheme. The announcement is part of a broader modernization effort, coinciding with China's increasing assertiveness in territorial disputes.

site_title: ETFs/ETPs in Asia-Pacific ex-Japan see US$2.42b net inflows in Feb
summary: ETFs/ETPs in the Asia-Pacific ex-Japan region received US$2.42 billion in net inflows in February 2016, according to ETFGI. Equity ETFs led with US$1.28 billion, followed by fixed income and commodity ETFs. This marks a "record level" of net inflows for the first two months of 2016, with the Asia-Pacific ETF industry boasting 817 ETFs and US$108 billion in assets. The report attributes the inflows to market volatility, with emerging markets gaining 0.31% in February.

site_title: Japan's negative rates a looming headache for central bank
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BOJ) has introduced negative interest rates, causing a volatile government bond market with prices swinging wildly. The BOJ's massive buying has distorted market functions and reduced liquidity, complicating its efforts to end deflation and boost growth. The central bank may struggle to taper its buying or sell its holdings, potentially triggering market fears and a damaging bond sell-off. Analysts warn that the BOJ's policy unpredictability and large balance sheet pose risks to confidence in the yen and the global financial system.

images.alt_text: Driving interest rates below zero, the Bank of Japan has turned a comatose government bond market into an enormous free-for-all, complicating the central bank's own efforts to kick-start growth and end deflation.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'buy' on film producer mm2 Asia
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained a "buy" rating on mm2 Asia, citing its high-margin business model and growth prospects. The company, a producer of films and TV content, is expected to grow at a 59% EPS CAGR from FY15 to FY18, driven by local productions, cinema operations, and expansion into the China market. A 9.05% stake in mm2 is now held by StarHub, which could raise the company's profile. Key risks include lack of long-term financing and potential delays/cost overruns. A target price of S$0.63 is set for FYMar17 EPS.

site_title: Halcyon, Sinochem to merge natural rubber businesses
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation Limited announced a merger with Sinochem International, acquiring its natural rubber business, including a 51% stake in GMG Global Ltd. Sinochem will acquire a 30.07% shareholding in Halcyon Agri for S$0.75 per share and become the majority shareholder. The deal is expected to create the world's largest natural rubber supply chain manager, spanning 153,000 hectares of land and 35 processing facilities across Asia and Africa.

site_title: China's Shenzhen raises property deposit thresholds
summary: China's Shenzhen has raised deposit requirements for some home buyers, aiming to calm the property market. The city has increased the downpayment threshold to 40% for first-time buyers and 30% for other buyers, and banned financial institutions from offering margin lending. Shenzhen also plans to increase land supply and build more government-funded houses to balance demand and supply. This move follows similar measures introduced across China to address concerns of a property bubble and overheating in the country's biggest cities, including Shenzhen's 57% price increase in February.

site_title: Terratech requests trading halt
summary: Terratech Group, a CATALIST-listed company, has requested a trading halt for its shares ahead of an upcoming announcement. The company's shares last traded at S$0.046 on Thursday before the Good Friday weekend. The reason for the halt is not specified.

site_title: Woes descend on Japanese IPOs as stocks tank on first day
summary: Japan's initial public offering (IPO) market is experiencing its worst start to a year on record, with six out of 21 IPOs failing to meet their offer prices. This follows a rout in Japanese equities, which sent the Topix index to its worst start to a year. Investors' ability to free up funds to buy new offerings has been hindered, contributing to the poor performance. The market's struggles are partly due to the tough conditions in the Japanese IPO market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Halcyon Agri, Keppel, property stocks
summary: Halcyon Agri to acquire Sinochem International's natural rubber business for S$0.75 per share. Keppel Fels delivers first two of five jackup rigs to Mexico's Grupo R under a US$820 million contract. The Singapore government is unlikely to relax property cooling measures in Budget 2016 due to a 8.4% fall in private home prices since 2013.

site_title: Dollar on firm footing: awaits data, Fed comments
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen on Monday, rebounding after a series of comments from US Federal Reserve officials suggested more interest rate hikes. The dollar's performance will be closely watched this week, with key data including the Japanese tankan and US non-farm payrolls. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments on Tuesday and New York Fed President William Dudley's comments on Thursday are also expected to impact the dollar. The dollar index touched its highest level since March 16, and the euro inched down 0.1% to $1.1160.

site_title: Hon Hai to hold board meeting March 30; Sharp talks continuing
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, the flagship company of Foxconn Technology Group, will hold a board meeting on March 30 as scheduled. Negotiations to acquire Sharp continue, with Sharp's banks agreeing to push back the deadline for most of the company's 510 billion yen (S$6.17 billion) in loans and credit lines by up to a month. Foxconn is seeking to cut the amount it will pay for Sharp's equity to about 389 billion yen, while still paying about 100 billion yen for preferred shares.

images.alt_text: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, Foxconn Technology Group's flagship company, on Sunday said it will hold a board meeting on March 30 as scheduled and negotiations to acquire troubled Japanese electronics maker Sharp are ongoing.

site_title: China car fever lifting gasoline use seen as root of diesel glut
summary: China's growing demand for gasoline, driven by increasing vehicle sales, is exacerbating a diesel glut in the region. As refineries process more oil to meet gasoline demand, they produce excess diesel, which is being shipped overseas, flooding regional markets and affecting profit margins. China's refining capacity is expected to expand by 16.4% by 2020, with diesel making up 90% of the fuel surplus. This is partly due to the country's drive to fill strategic petroleum reserves, with imports of crude expected to boost refinery capacity and improve product yields.

site_title: Blazing new trails
summary: YCH Group, a logistics company, has been innovating and expanding its supply chain solutions since the 1980s. Key milestones include the launch of its first 3PL warehouse management system (WMS) in 1987, followed by successful implementations of vendor-managed inventory (VMI) and order fulfilment solutions. The company has also introduced various cutting-edge technologies, such as RFID and automation, and has launched solutions like City Supply Chain and TLM. In 2016, YCH opened its state-of-the-art Supply Chain City facility, featuring best-in-class solutions and automation.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's stock market opened lower on Monday, with a 6.79-point decline to 2,875.19. The drop follows a five-week rally, as major US stocks fell slightly due to speculation of two potential Federal Reserve rate hikes this year. Around 406.1 million shares worth S$77 million changed hands, with winners beating losers 69 to 38.

site_title: Cheap buyout plans in Singapore? Not so quick, say minority shareholders
summary: Singapore management plans to take companies private may face hurdles from minority shareholders seeking higher premiums due to depressed market valuations. The city-state's nearly 300 small- and micro-cap companies trade at half the valuations of Asia-Pacific peers. Minority investors, traditionally with little influence, are now demanding better compensation as institutional investors shun smaller companies. This trend of shareholder activism is growing in Asia, with founders facing increased pressure to pay up for taking companies private. Minority investors are pushing for bigger premiums to depressed market valuations.

site_title: Asia: Shares, US dollar firm, eyes on US data, Fed
summary: The US dollar remained firm, and Asian stocks edged higher on Monday, boosted by strong consumer spending in the fourth quarter, which led to an upward revision in US economic growth. The US dollar index rose to its highest in almost two weeks, while US stock futures ticked up 0.2%. Investors are looking to US data, including PCE inflation, and the Federal Reserve's policy, with some Fed officials indicating a potential rate hike as early as next month.

site_title: Sharp, Foxconn push to close rescue deal after a month of delays
summary: Sharp Corp and Foxconn Technology Group are pushing to close a rescue deal for the Japanese manufacturer after a month of delays due to disagreements. Foxconn aims to pay around 389 billion yen for equity, down from the agreed 600 billion yen, and will pay about 100 billion yen for preferred shares. Sharp's banks are ready to push back the deadline for loans beyond March 31, giving the company more time to negotiate a final agreement. A board meeting is scheduled for March 30 to discuss the deal.

site_title: South Korea set for record IPO year as conglomerates prepare to sell family silver
summary: South Korea is poised for a record-breaking year in initial public offerings (IPOs), with conglomerates like Samsung, Doosan, and Lotte planning to sell billions of dollars in assets. The expected total value of this year's IPOs is at least $10 billion, surpassing last year's record of $8.5 billion. The surge in activity is driven by family firms seeking to streamline structures, ease debt burdens, and prepare for management succession. Newcomers like Netmarble Games are also expected to enter the market, with a projected $1.7 billion listing.

site_title: Ban hails removal of IS from Syria's Palmyra
summary: UN chief Ban Ki Moon welcomed the removal of Islamic State from Syria's Palmyra, calling for its protection for future generations. The site, known as the "Pearl of the Desert," boasts ancient temples and monuments that were seized by IS last year and destroyed. Syrian government forces recaptured the city on Sunday, allowing the preservation and protection of this UNESCO world heritage site. Ban urged the international community to protect and preserve the site, considering its cultural significance.

site_title: Chinese firms hiring less, capex hits 5-year low
summary: Chinese companies reported the lowest capital expenditure in at least five years, with only 33% of firms experiencing growth, according to a private survey. Hiring also declined, with just 23% of firms expanding their workforces in the first quarter. Despite this, profits improved as revenue growth steadied. The survey highlights persistent weakness in the economy, which the government is trying to mitigate with policy support. China's official statistics have been questioned by economists, who rely on private surveys like the China Beige Book International report to gauge the economy's health.

site_title: Brussels Airline decamps after terrorist bomb wrecks main hub
summary: Brussels Airlines has shifted its operations to four airports after a terrorist attack on its main hub, Zaventem Airport, in Brussels, killing 11 and injuring over 80. The airline has relocated flights to Frankfurt, Zurich, Antwerp, and Liege, using buses to transport passengers to alternative airports. Costs from the attack are estimated to be in the double-digit million-euro range. Despite the challenges, the airline plans to resume flights from Brussels Airport once it reopens, with a preliminary investigation indicating that the main building and check-in facility are structurally stable.

site_title: Dutch police arrest French national suspected of planning attack
summary: Dutch police arrested a 32-year-old French national suspected of planning a terror attack in France in the name of the Islamic State group. The suspect, wanted by French authorities since December, was detained in Rotterdam on a request from France. Three other men, including two of Algerian background, were also arrested during a raid at two homes in the city. The suspect is expected to be handed over to France "shortly," and the Netherlands remains on heightened alert following recent attacks in Brussels.

site_title: US Democrat Sanders says party leaders may 'rethink' after wins
summary: US Senator Bernie Sanders said he has gained momentum in the Democratic presidential primary, potentially leading party leaders to "rethink" their support for Hillary Clinton. After winning Alaska, Washington, and Hawaii, Sanders cited a narrow delegate lead for Clinton and criticized her reliance on wealthy donors. He also called for a televised debate in New York, where Sanders will compete in the state's primary. Sanders needs to win up to two-thirds of remaining delegates to catch Clinton, who has a commanding lead in super-delegates.

site_title: Japan opens radar station close to disputed East China Sea islands
summary: Japan has activated a new radar station on Yonaguni Island, 93 miles south of disputed Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands in the East China Sea. The move is part of Japan's military build-up strategy to counter China's growing presence in the region. The radar station will enhance Japan's ability to monitor the East China Sea and provide a permanent intelligence gathering post. Japan plans to increase its military presence in the region, with over 10,000 personnel to be deployed in the next five years. China has expressed concern over the move, warning it will irritate Beijing.

site_title: Online property companies soar on China's real estate recovery
summary: Real estate web portals Leju Holdings Ltd and SouFun Holdings Ltd, listed on the US market, have seen significant gains amid China's recovering property market. Leju surged 44% over the past month, while SouFun rebounded 25% from its February low. The recovery is driven by government stimulus, easing housing-market regulations, and government policies supporting privately-owned technology and service businesses. Analysts expect SouFun to outperform Leju, citing its strong brand image, technology, and large user base.

site_title: Canada's finance minister sees balanced budget in about 5 years
summary: Canada's finance minister Bill Morneau predicts the federal budget will be balanced in about 5 years due to higher economic growth spurred by deficit spending. The Liberal government had previously promised to return to surplus by 2019-20 but now projects a C$29.4 billion deficit for 2016-17. Morneau said the growth must reach the top range of forecasts for the budget to be balanced in five years. The budget includes C$3.97 billion in infrastructure spending.

site_title: Kerry says Republican campaign 'an embarrassment'
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry described the Republican presidential campaign as "an embarrassment" that raises questions about the US's reliability abroad. He stated that leaders from other countries are shocked and upset by the campaign's anti-Muslim rhetoric, including calls for bans on Muslim immigrants and surveillance of Muslim neighborhoods. Kerry's comments come amid a surge in anti-Muslim rhetoric from front-runner Donald Trump and his rival Ted Cruz, particularly following the Brussels suicide bombings. This has led to concerns about the US's image and stability in the international community.

site_title: Suicide bomber targeting Christians kills 65, mostly women and children, in Pakistan park
summary: A suicide bomber targeting Christians in a park in Lahore, Pakistan, killed at least 65 people, mostly women and children, on Easter Sunday. The attack, claimed by the Pakistani Taliban faction Jamaat-ul-Ahrar, occurred in the parking area of Gulshan-e-Iqbal Park, a popular site for the local Christian community. Over 300 others were wounded, and officials fear the death toll may climb. The attack sparked widespread condemnation, including from the Vatican and the US government, and led to a three-day mourning period and closure of public parks in the province.

site_title: Brazil's PMDB plans policies for new government if Dilma Rousseff is ousted: report
summary: Brazil's largest party, the PMDB, is planning policies if President Dilma Rousseff is ousted, including welfare cuts and changes to social benefits. The party aims to cut spending and achieve fiscal balance, potentially affecting programs such as a large housing program and college tuition financing. Cuts to the "Bolsa Família" social policy and tax exemptions in industrial sectors are also being considered. The moves aim to reestablish a fiscal equilibrium and keep government accounts healthy, despite opposition and mass protests against Rousseff's leadership.

site_title: Trump questions Nato, Asia nuclear weapons ahead of Washington summit
summary: US presidential front-runner Donald Trump criticized NATO, calling it "obsolete" and saying it should be "trimmed up and reconfigured." He suggested the US could let Japan and South Korea build their own nuclear weapons to counter North Korea and China. Trump also hinted at halting US oil purchases from Arab allies unless they commit ground troops or pay the US to fight Islamic State. His views have been met with criticism from his rival Ted Cruz, who called them "catastrophically foolish" and said they would hand a victory to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

site_title: Belgium conducts more raids in terror aftermath, questions nine
summary: Belgian authorities conducted 13 raids across the country on Sunday, detaining nine people in an effort to prevent further attacks and learn more about the March 22 airport and subway bombings that killed at least 28 victims. Prosecutors released five people, and charges were brought against two suspects, including one believed to be the man seen on security cameras at the Brussels airport at the time of the bombing. Riot police dispersed hundreds of protesters in Brussels, making 10 arrests, amid concerns about potential football fan violence.

site_title: Israel supreme court strikes down landmark gas deal
summary: Israel's Supreme Court struck down a landmark gas deal regulating the exploitation of Mediterranean gas reserves, citing an unacceptable stability clause that would have barred future governments from altering the deal. The ruling, which was suspended for a year, deals a blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's plans for energy independence and regional diplomacy. The Leviathan consortium, which includes US firm Noble Energy, remains upbeat about the possibility of moving forward with the planned development of the reservoir.

site_title: Womenomics has to wait in line as tenure obstructs Abe's goal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to have 30% of supervisory positions held by women by 2020, but his government is 15 years behind schedule. Currently, women fill just 6.2% of junior management jobs, with 20 years of tenure required to move into a supervisory role. The slow promotion of women is attributed to seniority-based decision-making, with good people often stuck in lowly jobs for decades. Abe's "womenomics" campaign aims to draw more women and the elderly into work, but progress is hindered by the country's aging and shrinking labor force, and the lack of immigration.

site_title: 250 business leaders back Brexit campaign
summary: 250 business leaders, including former HSBC CEO Michael Geoghegan and JD Wetherspoon's Tim Martin, have backed the UK's Brexit campaign, citing EU membership as a "job destruction regulatory machine" for smaller businesses. This move counters previous claims that UK businesses overwhelmingly support remaining in the EU. The campaign aims to counter the economic impact of a "Brexit" ahead of the June 23 referendum.

site_title: Q&A with Michael Zink
summary: Citi Singapore country officer Michael Zink shares his investing experiences and advice in a dialogue session at the National University of Singapore. He admits to making mistakes, including being recklessly aggressive in investing and not selling a stock when it became undervalued. Zink advises young investors to be cautious, consider their risk tolerance, and invest in broad indexes rather than focusing on a single country's market. He also emphasizes the importance of making clear-eyed decisions and not being emotional when selling a stock.

site_title: Iran denies US charges of cyber-attack brought against its citizens
summary: Iran has denied US charges of a cyber-attack targeting its citizens, dismissing the accusations as "baseless" and "unfounded". The US indictment accused hackers linked to Iran of targeting financial institutions and a flood-control dam in New York. Iran's foreign ministry spokesman claimed the US was behind a series of cyber-attacks on Iran's nuclear program, putting "millions of innocent people" at risk. The Iranian government and Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps were accused of orchestrating the hacking, but Iran denies any involvement.

site_title: Brussels airport to run tests Tuesday, no date for re-opening
summary: Brussels Airport will run tests on Tuesday to assess repair work after two suicide bomb attacks damaged the departure hall, but a firm date for re-opening is not yet decided. The airport operator will conduct a major test, involving 800 staff, to test the temporary arrangement and infrastructure. The test follows an extensive analysis of the terminal infrastructure and possible scenarios for partial operations. The airport is unlikely to resume full operations in the short-term, with airlines currently operating at regional airports or neighboring countries like the Netherlands and Germany.

images.alt_text: Brussels Airport said it will run tests on Tuesday to see if repair work after two suicide bomb attacks wrecked the departure hall was satisfactory, but it could not give a firm date for resuming services.

site_title: SMU-DHL collaboration yields unconventional solutions in sustainable logistics
summary: Singapore Management University's (SMU) Green Transformation Lab (GTL), in collaboration with DHL, has accelerated sustainable logistics innovation across the Asia-Pacific region. Since its launch in 2013, GTL has worked with over 150 students, resulting in job placements for many. The lab aims to create innovative solutions for sustainable green growth and drive beneficial change in supply chains. DHL invested S$2 million in GTL, providing scholarships and supply chain domain experts. The lab's projects have included a revamped carbon dashboard for DHL, demonstrating the power of interdisciplinary collaboration.

site_title: Belgium attacks toll raised to 31, could rise further
summary: Belgium's death toll from the March 22 airport and metro attacks has risen to 31, with 28 victims formally identified. Three more remain unidentified, awaiting DNA test results. The victims include 15 at the airport and 13 at the Maalbeek metro station, with six Belgian and nine foreign nationals identified. A total of 340 people were injured, with 101 remaining in hospital and 62 in intensive care, including 30 with severe burns.

site_title: Brazilian lawyers push for Rousseff impeachment
summary: Brazilian lawyers are pushing for President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment, citing a constitutional right to defend democracy. The Brazilian bar association plans to file a new request to Congress on Monday, following a congressional committee's consideration of impeachment proceedings over corruption allegations. Rousseff has ruled out stepping down despite mass protests and the crisis. The president condemned "fascist methods" of her opponents, but the bar association sees impeachment as a necessary measure to resolve the crisis democratically.

images.alt_text: The Brazilian bar association piled more pressure on President Dilma Rousseff, saying it will file a new request Monday to Congress for her impeachment, in a political crisis that threatens to topple her government.

site_title: A small, 'insignificant' US dam caught in Iranian hacking case
summary: A small US dam in Rye Brook, New York, was targeted by Iranian hackers as part of a cyberattack on the US financial system, along with 46 major financial institutions. The Bowman Avenue Dam, a 20-foot-tall dam, was chosen due to its computer-operated controls, which were accessible through a cellular modem. The hackers attempted to penetrate the dam in 2013, but were unsuccessful as it was under repair. The incident highlights the vulnerability of infrastructure to cyberattacks, and US authorities are taking steps to address the issue.

site_title: No bottom yet on economy, says Fullerton
summary: Fullerton Fund Management's CEO Manraj Sekhon warns of a difficult economic environment ahead, despite recent market recovery. He foresees a bottoming in the downgrade and earnings cycle but advises caution until stability in earnings forecasts is achieved. The fund house has added Chinese stocks, while reducing India exposure, and expects growth in multi-asset and fixed income segments. Sekhon predicts at least another 24-36 months before a meaningful economic recovery, citing uncertainty and low demand. Despite this, he sees opportunities in Asia, particularly in China, India, and other sectors with low valuations and interest.

site_title: Civilian deaths drop to four-year low after Syria truce: Monitor
summary: A monitoring group reported that civilian deaths in Syria dropped to a four-year low, with 174 civilians killed in areas under the ceasefire since February 27. This represents a significant decrease from the previous month, when over 1,100 civilians were killed. The ceasefire, brokered by the US and Russia, has brought relative calm to parts of the war-ravaged country, but fighting has broken out among rival groups and with jihadist factions, resulting in 122 rebel fighter and 637 government and allied fighter deaths.

images.alt_text: More than 360 civilians were killed during the first month of an unprecedented ceasefire in Syria, the lowest monthly toll for four years, a monitoring group said on Sunday.

site_title: Abe bent on shaping global policy agenda for G-7
summary: Japan is set to host the Group of Seven (G-7) summit in May, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aiming to shape the global policy agenda on issues such as fiscal stimulus, China, and Russia. Japan seeks to restore the G-7's former influence, given China's hosting of the G-20 summit in September. Abe aims to present a strong diplomatic stance, contrasting with US President Barack Obama and European leaders seen as vulnerable. Japan is likely to focus on fiscal expansion, address China's economic issues, and discuss Russia's involvement, while also tackling terrorism and fragile states.

site_title: Over a fifth of SGX Mainboard stocks in MTP danger zone
summary: Over 172 Mainboard-listed firms in Singapore have a six-month volume-weighted average price (VWAP) below the minimum trading price (MTP) rule of S$0.20, as of March 23. This represents around 21.9% of the 556 firms for which VWAP data was available. At least 22 firms have already undergone share consolidation to meet the MTP requirement, but 98 firms had last traded prices lower than their VWAPs, indicating a recent downward trend.

site_title: Facebook stumbles again with 'Safety Check' after Lahore blast
summary: Facebook apologized for sending safety notifications to users in the US and other countries after a suicide bombing in Lahore, Pakistan. The notifications, which asked if the recipient was safe, were intended for those directly affected by the blast. The company acknowledged the error, stating it was "counter to the product's intent" and apologized to those who received the notifications by mistake. Facebook's Safety Check feature was intended to provide support to users in crisis situations, but the glitch highlighted technical issues with the feature.

site_title: SMU team wins NUS-SGX stock-pitch competition
summary: A team of four finance undergraduates from Singapore Management University (SMU) won the NUS-SGX stock-pitch competition, taking home a $1,500 cash prize. The team, Prime Capital, argued that logistics facilities operator Global Logistic Properties (GLP) was a "buy" with a target price of $2.37. Eight teams from four universities were selected based on the quality of their reports, and SMU teams took the top two spots. The competition aimed to give tertiary students a taste of the equities research industry and inspire them to consider the stock market.

site_title: Tinder dating app shedding its sleazy reputation
summary: Tinder, a popular dating app, is shifting its reputation from a platform for casual hookups to a site for meaningful connections. Despite initial criticism, the app has become a top choice for US dating, with many users finding long-term relationships and even spouses. Users, including Shana Andrews, who met her husband on the app, are proudly embracing their Tinder connections, and the company has received wedding invitations and requests to attend ceremonies. The app's ease of use and growing popularity have helped it move beyond its initial reputation.

site_title: Balancing corporate demands and fatherhood
summary: Singapore is extending paternity leave to two weeks, a move seen as a step towards promoting work-life balance and encouraging shared parenting responsibilities. Experts believe this will boost productivity, increase job satisfaction, and attract and retain talented staff. Companies like Shell, NetApp, and Liberty Insurance have already implemented flexible working arrangements and paternity leave policies, citing benefits such as lower staff turnover and increased employee engagement. The government aims to increase the birth rate, which is currently below the replacement level, to support the country's aging population.

site_title: 'Choose an investment as you'd choose your spouse'
summary: Citi Singapore country officer Michael Zink shared personal finance and investment tips with NUS students, emphasizing the importance of marrying well, living within means, and knowing one's risk appetite. He also advised investing in markets with global growth potential, such as index funds, and avoiding emotional decisions. Zink stressed that learning about stock markets, taxes, and insurance requires dedication and time, likening it to learning any other subject.

site_title: Big on innovation and technology
summary: YCH Group, a Singapore-based logistics company, attributes its growth to innovation and technology. Executive Chairman Robert Yap has leveraged technology since the 1980s, introducing automated warehouses and routing analytics to maintain an edge over competitors. The company has developed its own proprietary software and invests 5% of its revenue in IT. Innovations, such as RFID warehouse tracking and automated storage and retrieval systems, have increased efficiency and reduced costs by 40% and 85%, respectively. Yap emphasizes the importance of business leadership and encourages innovation through employee recognition and cross-functional teams.

images.alt_text: Mr Yap notes that fostering innovation in any organisation must start with a commitment from the top. Building and nurturing a culture of innovation is important.

site_title: Tough for Branson's hip Virgin America to compete
summary: Virgin America, backed by Richard Branson, is seeking buyers due to its unprofitable business model. Despite offering upscale amenities, the airline has struggled to compete with low-cost carriers like Spirit Airlines. Virgin's initial focus on affluent millennials in cities led to limited expansion and high pressure to compete on each route. The airline has managed to make money since 2013, but its profitability relies on factors such as debt restructuring and low fuel costs. As fuel prices rise, Virgin's ability to survive and profit is uncertain, leaving its future uncertain for potential buyers.

site_title: Half empty or half full? STI's rebound stirs debate
summary: Singapore stocks have rebounded from year-to-date losses, but analysts remain divided on the market's prospects. Those who were bearish at the start of the year think the recent market rebound is fragile and risks being a bull trap. However, those who were bullish believe the market is undervalued and has a chance to reach 3,200 points by end-2016. Analysts generally agree that investors should get out of offshore and marine stocks and consider defensive yield plays, such as banks and real estate investment trusts. The market's recovery may run out of steam closer to the Fed's next policy meeting in June.

images.alt_text: Sounding a warning, analysts on both sides of the fence say the Singapore market recovery might run out of steam closer to the Fed's next policy meeting in June, as fears of a rate hike resurface. So investors should seize this chance to exit O&M stocks, and selectively pick up defensive yield instruments.

site_title: Gilead ordered to pay Merck US$200m for hepatitis C patents
summary: Gilead Sciences Inc. was ordered to pay Merck & Co $200 million for patent infringement over a hepatitis C drug compound. The verdict comes amid projections that Gilead's sales will flatten this year. The jury rejected Merck's bid for a 10% royalty on $20.7 billion in revenue generated by Gilead's hepatitis C drugs from 2013 to 2015.

site_title: Tesla to unveil electric car for middle-class market
summary: Tesla is set to unveil the Model 3, an electric car aimed at the middle-class market, with a base price of US$35,000, half the price of its flagship Model S. The car, expected to travel up to 300 miles without recharging, will include modern safety systems and be available for pre-order starting March 31. Analysts see the Model 3 as crucial to Tesla's long-term success, but the company faces competition from General Motors' Chevrolet Bolt and challenges from cheap petrol.

site_title: Belgium's vulnerable nuclear plants facing threat of terror attacks
summary: Belgium's nuclear power plants are under threat from potential terror attacks, according to authorities. The country's nuclear facilities, which provide nearly half of its power, have a history of security lapses and breaches. Surveillance footage linked to the Islamic State has been discovered at a nuclear facility, raising concerns that the group is seeking to obtain nuclear or radioactive material. Experts warn that while obtaining highly enriched uranium is difficult, a dirty bomb made from radioactive waste is more conceivable, and shutting down the plants could have severe consequences.

site_title: Looking for value in China's contemporary art market
summary: China's contemporary art market is plagued by systemic flaws and inconsistencies, with critics often receiving bribes for positive reviews. Despite this, top-selling artist Cui Ruzhuo's works fetched over $120 million at public auctions last year, a 69% increase. Connoisseurs fear that the market prioritizes money over artistic quality, threatening the development of the art world. Auction sales for top 100 living artists totalled $565 million, down 45% from 2014, due to a collapse in volume rather than average prices.

images.alt_text: As China's best- selling living artist, Cui can very well afford to proclaim himself on the moral high ground. His works fetched over US$120 million at auctions last year, up 69 per cent, even as the overall market plummeted.

site_title: Driverless delivery robots could hit Washington DC soon
summary: Washington D.C. may soon see a rollout of driverless delivery robots, with the city's Councilwoman Mary Cheh authorizing legislation to enable the technology. Starship Technologies, a company led by Skype co-founders, plans to deploy "smart, friendly robots" to make local deliveries of groceries and small packages, aiming to reduce costs from $1 to $3 per trip. The robots, powered by electricity and equipped with nine cameras, will operate at speeds of up to 16km/h and be restricted from sensitive areas.

images.alt_text: A prototype of the delivery drone developed by Starship Technologies navigating the venue of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain, on Feb 23.

site_title: Tiny fruit fly sours Australia's big agri export ambitions
summary: Australia's efforts to boost its $3 billion fruit and vegetable exports are being hindered by the presence of a tiny fruit fly, which has restricted sales to key markets such as China and Japan. Despite free trade agreements with China, Japan, and South Korea, securing phytosanitary protocol agreements is a major obstacle, with only a few products able to be sold into China. Tasmania, which is free from the fruit fly, has seen significant growth in fruit and vegetable exports, but mainland Australia's exports are being limited.

site_title: Australia shifts towards public transport boost under Turnbull
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government plans to boost funding for public transport infrastructure on the outskirts of major cities, such as Sydney and Melbourne, to attract housing development projects. This move aims to address the issue of housing affordability, as home prices have surged by 70% in Sydney and 50% in Melbourne. The government believes that major transport investments will support housing developments and alleviate congestion. Turnbull's move is a shift away from the previous government's policy of not providing federal funds for urban commuter rail projects, which the opposition Labor party argues would spur new home construction and help first-home buyers.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government wants to boost funding for road and rail public transport infrastructure on the fringes of Australia's major cities to attract housing-development projects.

site_title: Wearable tech takes aim at healthcare costs
summary: US employers are launching wellness programs using wearable technology to encourage healthier lifestyles, aiming to reduce healthcare costs. UnitedHealthcare has introduced the Trio Tracker device, which tracks steps and intensity levels, with incentives such as earning health insurance premiums. A survey found 37% of large employers already use activity trackers, with more planning to adopt the technology. Critics raise concerns about private data collection and potential misuse, while proponents argue financial incentives can motivate healthier behaviors.

site_title: EU mulls easing bank failure rules to align with global standard
summary: The European Union is considering easing bank failure rules to align with a global standard. A discussion paper by the European Commission proposes setting EU loss-absorbency requirements for major banks, potentially lowering the minimum 8% requirement for top banks. The move aims to ensure the biggest banks can be restructured without threatening financial stability. The proposed framework would also consider a "resolvability assessment" and a possible bank-specific surcharge, with the goal of implementing global banking standards, including the total loss-absorbing capacity requirement, by the end of the year.

site_title: Credit-card use earns rewards, but it encourages extra spending too
summary: A study by economists found that using credit cards tends to encourage consumers to spend more than they would with cash, due to the ease of purchasing and the psychological effect of credit card logos. Research by MIT professor Duncan Simester and Purdue University's Richard Feinberg showed that consumers are willing to pay twice as much when using credit cards as they would with cash. To avoid overspending, experts advise exercising discipline with plastic, paying balances in full, and seeking out low-interest cards, especially for those who struggle to pay off debt.

site_title: Odds favour play on STI as end of Q1 nears
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange is expected to end the first quarter on a positive note, with odds favoring a play on the Straits Times Index. A modest push from key components like Singtel and banks could ensure the index completes the quarter in the black. The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates has led to reduced expectations of rate hikes this year, with the first expected in June. However, there is a slim chance of a surprise rate hike in April, and the situation with China's slowdown and oil prices remains uncertain, potentially affecting market sentiment.

site_title: Markets look to 'dovish' Federal Reserve for direction
summary: US stock indexes fell slightly last week, snapping a five-week winning streak, amid concerns that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates as soon as next month. The Fed's dovish March statement boosted energy and commodities stocks, but strong jobs data could cause a spike in the dollar and roll over the market. Oil futures have returned to below $40 a barrel, and a production freeze by Russia and Saudi Arabia may not be enough to diminish the global oil glut. The US economy is expected to see growth in consumer and government spending, but the effects of the commodities crash on the global economy may still be felt.

site_title: Wall Street may decide outcome of US polls
summary: The US stock market may play a significant role in determining the outcome of the 2016 presidential election, potentially deciding between Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton, or another candidate. Historically, the S&P 500 has gained an average 6.1% in the fourth year of the presidential cycle, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average has also performed well in strong election years. This phenomenon, known as the "wealth effect," suggests that a strong market could benefit the incumbent party, while a weak market could hurt its chances.

site_title: Pastor rock vs Buddhist monk blues in Japan
summary: Lutheran pastor Kazuhiro Sekino and a group of Buddhist monks, including Yoshinobu Fujioka, engage in a musical battle in Tokyo, blending Christian rock with Buddhist influences. The event aims to reach a broader audience in a predominantly Buddhist country, where Christianity is underrepresented. The unlikely duo performs secular music, sharing their message of hope and spirituality, and has opened a bar to provide a space for people to discuss their problems and find solace.

site_title: Botched rules dash India's dream of becoming shipping hub
summary: India's shipping ministry has introduced new rules aimed at developing the country into a world-class shipping hub, but experts say the policy is unclear and may hinder growth. The rules, announced on March 7, allow overseas operators to ferry exported and imported goods at certain ports, but limit this to 50% of container volume. This will not benefit 88% of India's total traffic, and ports must meet a 50% growth in cargo transshipment to retain the benefit. Analysts warn that the policy may not boost trade and could further deter foreign shipping lines due to India's infrastructure constraints.

site_title: The Italian invasion
summary: Two Italian restaurants, ilLido at the Cliff and IO Italian Osteria, in Singapore offer similar dining experiences. ilLido, a revival of the original ilLido in Sentosa, shares its menu with Aura and Osteria Art, with some unique dishes like squid ink tonnarelli. IO, a new restaurant in Hillview, boasts an authentic Italian atmosphere and hearty portions, with standout dishes like porchetta and crispy seafood. Despite some hits and misses, both restaurants excel in providing a welcoming and predictable dining experience.

site_title: Nigerian woman a cut above in diamond trade
summary: Thelma West, a 32-year-old Nigerian woman, is a rare gem in the diamond trade, breaking barriers as a woman and African in a male-dominated sector. Raised in a Jewish family, West traveled to Britain at 16 to finish her education and later attended the Hoge Raad Voor Diamant school in Antwerp, where she honed her skills. She started her own business in London, trading diamonds and creating custom-made pieces, including a £2 million necklace. West plans to open a workshop in Nigeria to train girls in jewelry-making and is developing a revolutionary tool for diamond dealers.

site_title: China industrial profits up for January, February
summary: China's industrial profits increased 4.8% in January and February, reaching 780.7 billion yuan, following a 4.7% decline in December 2015. The growth was driven by quicker product sales and a narrowing decline in industrial producer prices, particularly in the oil processing, electrical machinery, and food sectors. This positive trend contrasts with the country's slowing economic growth and producer prices, which fell for the 48th month in a row in February. Chinese leaders have set a growth target of 6.5-7% for 2016.

site_title: Strength of US$ rebound depends on jobs data
summary: The US dollar has rebounded, rising 1.3% last week, after Federal Reserve officials signaled interest rate increases may not be far off. The upcoming March jobs report, expected to show 207,000 non-farm employment gains, will determine the dollar's sustainability. Traders are optimistic, with some speculating the dollar is headed for a turning point. However, the dollar has still lost 2.5% this year, and its future performance will depend on the jobs report and future interest rate decisions.

site_title: Floating production market sees new opportunities
summary: Singapore's floating production market sees new opportunities as international oil companies, such as BP, invite local yards to bid on turnkey delivery of newbuild floating production projects. Keppel Fels and Sembcorp Marine have made the shortlist for a Hess-operated Equus semi-submersible production project and a BP-operated Mad Dog 2 semisub project, respectively. However, low oil prices make project financing challenging, and yards in Singapore must take on additional financial risks. Meanwhile, redeployments of existing FPSOs and semisubs may offer a third opportunity for yards in Singapore, with potential for lower development costs and faster production startup.

site_title: Selling among directors up, buying flat
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

In the Singapore Exchange, buying activity remained flat while selling among directors increased during the holiday-shortened week of March 21-24. 12 companies recorded 25 purchases worth S$1.04 million, while 3 firms made 4 disposals worth S$0.396 million. Notable buys included Datapulse Technology's first buyback since 2008 and Ezion Holdings' CEO buying shares at a higher price than his acquisition cost. Conversely, 11 companies made 27 repurchases worth S$11.62 million, down from the previous week. Other significant trades included Fragrance Group's chairman buying shares and Schroders becoming a substantial shareholder of Venture Corporation.

site_title: Michael Jackson's home still unsold, 10 months on
summary: Michael Jackson's former Neverland Ranch, now known as Sycamore Valley Ranch, remains unsold 10 months after its $100 million listing. The 12,598-square-foot estate in the Santa Ynez Valley is asking nearly 200 times the median home value in Santa Barbara County. Experts attribute the lack of movement to the slow down of the luxury real estate market, with only a few high-end properties selling annually. Location is a major hurdle, as the property is far from the typical luxury markets, and unique features make it difficult to find comparable sales.

site_title: Keppel delivers first pair of Grupo R jackup rigs
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine's rig-building arm, Keppel FELS, has delivered the first two of five jackup rigs ordered by Mexico's Grupo R. The Cantarell I and II rigs, built to the KFELS B Class design, will go on charter with Mexico's national oil company Pemex in the Cantarell oilfield. The delivery was deferred due to Grupo R's request, but Keppel FELS received compensations from the client. The move brings the number of KFELS B Class rigs working off Mexico to 10 units, with two directly owned by Pemex.

images.alt_text: The Cantarell I and II jackup rigs (above) built to the KFELS B Class design will go on charters with Mexico's national oil company Pemex.

site_title: British EU exit campaign backed by 250 business leaders
summary: The Vote Leave campaign for Britain's exit from the EU has been backed by 250 business leaders, including former HSBC CEO Michael Geoghegan and JD Wetherspoon's Tim Martin. This move aims to counter the perception that UK businesses favor staying in the EU. Meanwhile, hedge funds are planning to use exit polls to make profits on the day of the referendum, which could impact sterling's value.

site_title: Philippine crucifixions a big money spinner
summary: In the Philippines, the Good Friday crucifixion re-enactments have become a lucrative event, with corporate sponsors and vendors profiting from the event. The event, which attracts 30,000 spectators, features re-enactments of Jesus' crucifixion and is supported by major brands such as telcos and fast food chains. Local authorities view the event as a cultural activity, but the Catholic Church has criticized the commercialization of the event, with Archbishop Broderick Pabillo stating that it "distracts from the reason for the season of Holy Week."

images.alt_text: The men being nailed to crosses in a Philippine village were seeking salvation, but for corporate sponsors and small-time vendors the Good Friday event was all about quick riches.

site_title: Strong greenback, US reserves, stall 5-week oil rally
summary: The US dollar's strength and soaring US crude stockpiles have stalled a five-week oil rally, with global oil prices falling. The US Department of Energy reported a 9.36 million-barrel surge in commercial reserves, exacerbating the global supply glut. The strong dollar also made US dollar-priced crude more expensive for buyers with weaker currencies, reducing demand. Despite hopes for a potential deal between OPEC and Russia to freeze oil production, oil prices tumbled, with West Texas Intermediate falling to $39.16 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude to $40.12 per barrel.

site_title: Revisiting board risk governance structures
summary: Companies face complex risks, with boards responsible for assessing and managing them.
