This incident highlights Australia's increasing concerns about home-grown extremism and terrorism.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi to post first net loss
summary: Mitsubishi Corp is expected to post its first group net loss of over 100 billion yen (S$1.22 billion) due to impairment losses from commodity projects, including a Chilean copper concession and an Australian liquefied natural gas stake. The company's impairment losses are estimated at 400 billion yen, leading to a downgrade of its annual forecasts. This comes after rival Mitsui & Co predicted its first loss since its establishment in 1947 due to a slide in energy and metal prices. Mitsubishi's impairment losses are attributed to the commodities slump.

site_title: Singapore shares open 11 points lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore's stock market opened 11.13 points lower at 2,870.85, following overnight falls on Wall Street. The decline was driven by 61 losers and 47 gainers. Total trading volume was 49 million shares worth S$61 million. The market is awaiting GDP data, which could impact the rally seen in the past five days.

site_title: Sharp's top-rated analyst: Foxconn delay raises liquidation risk
summary: Sharp Corp faces a 30-40% chance of liquidation due to a delayed Foxconn rescue deal, according to Jefferies Group's Atul Goyal. The Taiwanese company's bid, which includes a 489 billion yen investment for new shares and preferred stock, may be revised to give Foxconn a lower price for Sharp's LCD technology. Sharp's shares have fallen 47% in the past year, and the company's credit rating has been downgraded to CCC by Standard & Poor's. The company's banks are pushing for a bailout agreement before the end of the fiscal year on March 31.

site_title: North Korea claims successful rocket engine test boosts capability
summary: North Korea claimed a successful test of a solid-fuel rocket engine, which could boost its ballistic rocket capabilities. The test, supervised by leader Kim Jong Un, was seen as a step towards developing an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) despite UN sanctions. The country has previously launched long-range rockets using liquid fuel, but solid-fuel rockets offer military advantages. Experts believe the North is likely a decade or more away from building an ICBM capable of threatening the US, with recent bellicose rhetoric and missile tests escalating tensions.

site_title: Apple Pay coming to mobile websites later this year
summary: Apple plans to integrate Apple Pay with its Safari browser, allowing users to make purchases from mobile websites using iPhone and iPad models with fingerprint technology, expected to be ready before this year's holiday shopping season.

site_title: Fed talk spurs dollar gains, energy weighs on stocks
summary: Global equity markets fell, with the US dollar advancing 0.47% against a basket of major currencies, its first weekly gain in four weeks. Hawkish comments from Fed officials raised expectations for more interest rate hikes this year, despite last week's projection of two rate hikes in 2016. The stronger dollar weighed on oil prices, with US crude stockpiles reaching record highs, and gold prices also fell.

site_title: Oil market sinks as US crude inventories surge
summary: US oil prices sank on Wednesday as crude inventories surged 9.36 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) fell $1.66 to $39.79 per barrel and Brent North Sea crude dropped $1.32 to $40.47 per barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported the surge, which may be a precursor to higher oil prices if the dollar stabilizes, according to analyst Jasper Lawler.

site_title: New Zealand awaits flag vote decision
summary: New Zealanders are set to decide on Thursday whether to keep or change their national flag, with a referendum on the issue that has been ongoing for 18 months. The proposed change, which would replace the Union Jack with the silver fern, has been met with strong opposition, with polls indicating that two-thirds of the electorate support the existing flag. The cost of the referendum has been NZ$26 million. The outcome is seen as a test of Prime Minister John Key's legacy, with many questioning the need for change after more than a century.

site_title: Cruz scores Bush endorsement, Clinton blasts Republicans
summary: Jeb Bush endorsed Ted Cruz for president, citing the need to overcome divisiveness and vulgarity in the Republican Party. The move comes as Cruz and Trump deepen their feud, with Trump criticizing Cruz's wife. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton blasted Republicans for "counterproductive" rhetoric, calling for a more comprehensive approach to counter-terrorism and strengthening alliances. The endorsement and Clinton's comments underscore the deep divisions within the Republican Party and highlight the challenges ahead for the party's nomination process.

images.alt_text: Jeb Bush endorsed fellow Republican Ted Cruz for president Wednesday while Democrat Hillary Clinton thrashed her GOP rivals for "counterproductive" rhetoric that alienates global allies.

site_title: Pressure on Brazil's Rousseff may rise as jobless lose benefits
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff faces growing pressure as over 2 million Brazilians are set to lose unemployment benefits by June, threatening her support among working-class supporters. The expiration of benefits could fuel protests against the left-leaning government amid a corruption scandal at state oil company Petrobras and a recession that has driven the unemployment rate to 9%. Economists expect the downturn to linger, with jobless people struggling for months without finding work, and some Congressmen backing impeachment proceedings against Rousseff.

site_title: Amazon says its female workers paid equally as men
summary: Amazon has revealed that female employees earn the same as their male counterparts, according to a recent survey conducted by the company. The disclosure comes after pressure from activist shareholder Arjuna Capital, which had pushed Amazon to prepare a report on gender pay equity. This move follows criticism of US companies, particularly in the technology sector, over pay equality issues. Amazon's decision aims to address the gap and demonstrate its commitment to equality.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc, under pressure from an activist shareholder to disclose its policies on gender pay equality, said on Wednesday its female employees earned as much as their male counterparts, according to a survey it recently conducted.

site_title: Obama urges unity against terror, vows to wipe out IS
summary: US President Barack Obama urged nations to unite against terrorism following deadly attacks in Brussels, which killed 31 people and wounded 270. Obama vowed to wipe out the Islamic State extremist group, calling it a "vicious killer and murderer" that can't be destroyed. He pledged US assistance to investigate the attacks and bring attackers to justice, and vowed to aggressively target IS until it's removed from Syria and Iraq. Obama emphasized the need for global unity against terrorism, stating it's his top priority.

site_title: Rockefeller Family Fund hits Exxon, divests from fossil fuels
summary: The Rockefeller Family Fund has announced its decision to divest from Exxon Mobil Corp, citing the company's alleged misleading statements about climate change risks. The fund, which has a modest $130 million US investment in fossil fuels, will also divest from coal and Canadian oil sands. Exxon responded by stating the fund's decision is not surprising, and accused the Rockefeller Family Fund of providing financial support to publications that produced "inaccurate and deliberately misleading stories" about the company. The move comes amid growing pressure on the oil industry to address climate change concerns.

site_title: American Airlines adds profit sharing to end workers' rift
summary: American Airlines has adopted a profit-sharing program, joining Delta, United, and Southwest Airlines in sharing 5% of pretax income with employees, starting this year. The decision reverses CEO Doug Parker's previous stance on paying higher base rates instead of offering profit sharing, citing a need to improve labor relations and employee engagement. The program's first payout will be in early 2017, and American also announced a 6% pay raise for flight attendants, effective April 1.

images.alt_text: American Airlines Group Inc gave in to pressure from employees and adopted a profit-sharing program, acknowledging the issue was thwarting efforts to improve labour relations and the carrier's performance.

site_title: 'Brexit' risks £500m shock to energy bills, Rudd says
summary: Energy Secretary Amber Rudd warns a UK vote to leave the European Union could lead to a £500m annual increase in energy bills, threatening Britain's energy security. Rudd says working within the EU allows the UK to diversify gas sources and drive down prices, while a "Leave" vote could leave energy costs "rocketing" and make Britain vulnerable to Russian President Vladimir Putin's gas supplies being used as a tool of foreign policy.

site_title: US dollar rises as Fed official talks possible rate hike
summary: The US dollar rose on Wednesday after a Federal Reserve official, James Bullard, suggested the central bank may consider hiking interest rates in April if economic data is strong. Bullard's comments came after the Fed kept rates unchanged last week, signaling a more gradual pace of rate increases. The hawkish tone from Fed officials this week is seen as supporting the dollar, which has been gaining value. The remarks are a contrast to last week's policy statement, which indicated a more cautious approach to monetary policy.

site_title: Aspial's placement portion for second retail bond offering oversubscribed
summary: ASPIAL Corp's second retail bond offering of four-year 5.30% bonds due 2020 received over S$25 million in valid applications, exceeding its placement portion. The bonds are expected to be issued on April 1 and trade on the main board on April 4. CEO Koh Wee Seng attributes the strong reception to the attractiveness of the bond offering and investors' confidence in the company's value propositions and growth potential. Applications for the public offer remain open until March 30.

site_title: China launches charm offensive for first overseas naval base
summary: China has launched a charm offensive to explain its first overseas naval base in Djibouti, portraying it as a contribution to regional security and development. The base, part of China's "one road, one belt" strategy, aims to bolster the Chinese economy and connect it with the rest of the world. China has briefed diplomats on the Djibouti base's resupply purposes for anti-piracy and humanitarian operations, but Indian officials are concerned about the potential military threat. The move has also raised concerns in the US, which has participated in international counter-piracy actions in the Gulf of Aden.

site_title: Most Japanese firms unhappy with central bank's negative rate policy: Reuters poll
summary: Most Japanese companies are unhappy with the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy, citing it as a bad move that will negatively impact business and consumer sentiment. A Reuters poll found that 64% of firms want the government to implement further economic stimulus, while around 50% support a planned increase in the national sales tax. The policy aims to combat Japan's deflation and stimulate growth, but companies are concerned about the country's huge debt burden.

site_title: Chinese national admits hacking US defence firms
summary: A Chinese national, Su Bin, 50, pleaded guilty to charges stemming from hacking US defence firms, including Boeing, between 2008 and 2014. He admitted to conspiring with others to steal sensitive military information and export it to China. Su faces a maximum 5-year prison sentence and a fine of up to $250,000. The guilty plea comes amid growing US concerns about Chinese hacking of American trade secrets, highlighted by President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Amazon hosts exclusive robotics conference in Palm Springs
summary: Amazon hosted an exclusive robotics conference in Palm Springs, bringing together experts in artificial intelligence, robotics, home automation, and space exploration. The event, called Mars, featured robotic arms, seminars on imbuing machines with human values, and a celebrity appearance by film director Ron Howard. Representatives from companies like Rethink Robotics and Toyota Motor attended, along with academics from top universities. The conference aims to advance Amazon's space-exploration ambitions and align with its robotics and AI initiatives.

site_title: Small but painful sacrifices needed to deal with growing terror threat
summary: A coordinated bombing in Brussels on March 22, 2016, killed at least 34 and injured over 250, with the Islamic State claiming responsibility. This incident highlights the growing terror threat, with Singapore Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam warning of a potential attack in Singapore. In response, the government will launch a national movement called SG Secure, including installing CCTV cameras and stricter event checks. While some concerns arise, the government believes the measures are necessary to ensure national security and protect citizens from terrorism.

site_title: US: Stocks fall; travel shares lose after Brussels attacks
summary: US stocks fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 79.98 points (0.45%) to 17,502.59, and the S&P 500 shedding 13.09 (0.64%) to 2,036.71. Petroleum-linked stocks and travel shares fell, including Chevron (2.0%), ConocoPhillips (4.9%), United Airlines (1.2%), and Hilton Worldwide (1.5%). Market analysts attributed the decline to the ongoing impact of the Brussels attacks, which tightened security across Europe and raised concerns about the summer season for sports.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Select Group, a food caterer, is being taken private by a consortium led by Dymon Asia Private Equity, with a 10.5 times earnings offer price. Huan Hsin Holdings, a Chinese electronics manufacturer, faces a shares subscription exercise to raise US$250 million, while Hotel Properties Limited acquired a US$65 million resort in Vietnam. DBS appointed Joyce Tee as its first female head of SME Banking.

site_title: Retiring Zeti hopes for closure on 1MDB with administrative action
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz hopes to achieve closure on the 1MDB scandal through administrative action before her retirement in April. The bank has taken action against the state-owned development fund for breaching financial regulations, with potential penalties and recommendations for enforcement. Zeti emphasized the importance of complying with rules and regulations, regardless of the shareholders, to uphold the integrity of the financial system. The move is seen as a significant step towards resolving the controversy, which has damaged Malaysia's reputation and hurt investor confidence.

site_title: Negative inflation persists, but core inflation inches up
summary: Singapore's core inflation rate inched up, despite a 0.8% decrease in headline inflation in February, driven by increases in most categories except for cheaper cars and housing rentals. This mixed inflation picture raises uncertainty about the shape of April's monetary policy.

site_title: Cruz's win in Utah gives glimmer of hope to establishment Republicans
summary: US Republican front-runner Donald Trump won Arizona, while rival Ted Cruz secured a win in Utah, giving establishment Republicans hope that Trump won't lead the party to ruin in the presidential election. On the Democratic side, Hillary Clinton defeated Bernie Sanders in Arizona, while Sanders won in Utah and Idaho. The Brussels attacks overshadowed the contests, with Clinton criticizing Trump and Cruz's anti-Muslim rhetoric. Trump's win furthered his argument that he'll secure the nomination, while Cruz's victory in Utah boosted his chances, particularly among Mormon voters.

site_title: Mahathir sues Najib, alleging abuse of power
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has filed a lawsuit against Najib Razak, alleging corruption and abuse of power. Mahathir accuses Najib of obstructing investigations into 1MDB, a state fund linked to corruption allegations. Najib denies wrongdoing and has been cleared of any criminal offense. The lawsuit seeks RM2.6 billion in damages from Najib and the government. The case is unlikely to have an immediate impact, as it will take months to be heard.

site_title: Japan's commercial land prices post first rise in 8 years
summary: Japan's commercial land prices rose 0.9% in 2015, marking the first increase in eight years, according to a government survey. The rise was attributed to growing demand for hotel and retail spaces. This marks a reversal from the flat prices in 2014, indicating a boost in property values.

site_title: Koh Brothers eyes more hotel assets and M&A targets
summary: Koh Brothers Group, a Singapore-based construction and real estate company, is expanding its hotel assets and merger and acquisition targets to diversify its business portfolio. With the current softness in the hotel sector, CEO Francis Koh plans to enter the market to capitalize on expected tourist arrivals and yields of 3-4% in the UK. The company aims to increase its revenue from 30% construction, 30% building materials, and 10% leisure and hospitality. Koh Brothers has built a war chest and is scouting for hotel properties, with plans to hold them for long-term capital appreciation.

images.alt_text: It is time to snap up some hotel assets in Singapore in tandem with the increase in the country's airport capacity in anticipation of more tourist arrivals, says Mr Koh.

site_title: Single-serves seen driving US coffee sales
summary: US coffee sales are expected to grow 3-5% in 2016, with single-serve coffee driving the majority of the growth, according to Massimo Zanetti Beverage USA. Single-serve sales are expected to grow by "double digits" this year, despite concerns over the environmental impact of single-serve cups. The company has introduced a 100% compostable version of the pod, and single-serve coffee now represents about 36% of total coffee sales in the US.

site_title: Overseas remittances fuelling boom in Vietnamese property market
summary: Vietnam's property market is experiencing a boom, fueled by record overseas remittances. The country's diaspora, estimated at 5 million, is sending $14 billion in remittances this year, a 15% increase from 2015. The influx of cash is supporting property prices, with prices in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City rising 10% and 21% respectively. Experts attribute the growth to a healthier US economy and Vietnam's improving business prospects, as well as eased real estate laws.

site_title: Two-horse race for 4th telco licence will raise spectrum costs
summary: A two-horse race for Singapore's fourth telecom licence is expected to drive up spectrum costs, potentially stifling competition. Consistel's chairman, Masoud Bassiri, expressed surprise at the swift drop in data plan prices by the three incumbent telcos, stating that lower prices don't necessarily indicate competition. Consistel plans to differentiate itself through quality and service, not just price matching, as it competes for the fourth licence.

site_title: Abdullah Tarmugi, Wong Kan Seng, Grace Fu recall LKY's leadership style
summary: Former Singaporean leaders Abdullah Tarmugi, Wong Kan Seng, and Grace Fu remembered Lee Kuan Yew's leadership style as "proper," emphasizing his sense of integrity, discipline, and vision. They recalled instances where Lee insisted on following proper protocols, such as having his temperature checked during the Sars outbreak, and encouraged MPs to write notes for leave. The leaders praised Lee's legacy, including his role in transforming Singapore into a first-world nation and instilling strong institutions and values.

site_title: Chinese airlines gain from no-hedge policy
summary: Chinese airlines, including Air China, China Southern Airlines, and China Eastern Airlines, are expected to report a 70% surge in net income for 2015 due to a plunge in oil prices. Unlike rivals Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines, Chinese carriers have a no-hedge policy, which helped them trim their biggest expenditure. The carriers' strategy is set to continue in 2016, with analysts predicting further growth amid China's expected rise as the world's biggest travel market.

images.alt_text: China's airlines are reaping the benefits of a policy not to hedge in the oil market, unlike some of their rivals across the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: StanChart to curb US$2b diamond exposure: sources
summary: Standard Chartered is demanding more loan protection from clients in the Indian and Belgian diamond trade, seeking to tighten standards and curb a US$2 billion exposure. The bank is asking clients to obtain payment insurance or provide 100% collateral, with collateral in the form of receivables not acceptable. This move comes as the bank reviews its entire senior management team and aims to restructure or jettison US$100 billion of assets, following a review of every business line and customer relationship.

site_title: Mr Trump goes to Washington
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump visited Washington, DC, on March 21, 2016, as part of a strategy to appear more presidential. He held a news conference at the Old Post Office Pavilion and met with Republican lawmakers, attempting to rally support from the party establishment. Trump aims to demonstrate his qualifications to lead the country, despite opposition from the GOP, who question his qualifications and conservative values. His visit comes ahead of the Republican primaries and the general election, where he will face Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton.

site_title: Investors in Myanmar swot up on share trading
summary: Myanmar's Yangon Stock Exchange (YSX) is set to debut its first listed company on Friday, ahead of a new civilian government taking power. The bourse, which has seen dozens of investors attend weekly classes on share trading, is a step towards economic revitalization. The debut comes as the country opens up after decades of military rule, with Aung San Suu Kyi's government overseeing the transition. This marks a significant milestone in Myanmar's economic development, with investors and business leaders eagerly watching the bourse's progress.

site_title: Slowdown in New York's high-end market worries Israeli bondholders
summary: Israeli bondholders are growing concerned about financing high-end real estate in New York City due to a slowdown in the luxury market. Extell Development Co's bonds have sunk to 86 agorot on the shekel, with yields reaching 9.9% due to investors' skepticism about financing faraway properties with no local knowledge. This comes as Manhattan's luxury development boom slows, with record-setting price tags for apartments and a surge in inventory. Extell's bonds are backed by a pool of diverse properties, but investors are demanding higher yields, and the company's capital structure dictates that RXR Realty's financing takes precedence.

site_title: 2 online shopping sites bag venture funding
summary: Two Singaporean e-commerce platforms, ezbuy and iFashion, have secured venture funding. Ezbuy raised US$20 million to introduce new source markets, global brands, and product choices, while iFashion secured S$1 million to expand its regional team and acquire online fashion startups. The funding aims to boost growth and help the platforms compete in the competitive e-commerce landscape, with ezbuy serving over 600,000 shoppers and iFashion targeting fragmented fashion and lifestyle industries in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Credit Suisse to further cut costs, downsize investment bank
summary: Credit Suisse announced 800 million Swiss francs in additional cost cuts and plans to shrink its investment bank as part of a restructuring plan to revitalise its earnings. The bank aims to achieve 1.7 billion Swiss francs in cost savings this year. This move follows record-low interest rates, low commodity prices, and slower growth in emerging markets.

site_title: New home sales rebound in Feb but signs indicate loss of momentum
summary: US single-family home sales rebounded 2% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 512,000 units, but the gain was concentrated in one region, suggesting a potential loss of momentum in the housing market. Despite this, economists attribute the strong labor market and low mortgage rates to boosting household formation. However, inventory remains low, with 5.6 months to clear the supply of houses on the market, and prices continue to rise, with the median price of a new home increasing 2.6% from last year.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Singapore's continued relevance - that's the big question
summary: The Singapore Budget 2016 aims to address the city-state's relevance in the face of technological disruptions and global supply chain shifts. Despite being consistently ranked as a top destination for business, Singapore's relevance is not guaranteed, with experts citing threats to its logistics and sea hub status. To mitigate this, the government is exploring growth markets, including South-east Asia, where the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) projects an annual growth rate of 5.4% between 2014 and 2018. Singapore firms are advised to focus on infrastructure-related opportunities, such as projects in utilities, urban development, and transport & logistics, in countries like Indonesia, Myanmar, and Vietnam.

site_title: 'Bleeding' from yuan devaluation, China Inc seeks hedging help
summary: China's companies are seeking hedging services due to the yuan's recent devaluation to a five-year low, with financial service provider KVB Kunlun Global Capital Ltd forecasting a 50% increase in foreign-exchange hedging business this year. Companies such as Country Garden Holdings Co and Greenland Hong Kong Holdings Ltd have cut dollar exposure and entered forward contracts to protect themselves against currency risk, while banks like BNP Paribas and Hang Seng Bank have seen a surge in FX hedging business. The yuan's volatility has raised concerns about the impact on companies' profits and the need for better financial management.

site_title: Google's Greene scores on catch up with Amazon's cloud
summary: Google has secured a major victory in its cloud services effort with Home Depot moving some of its data to Google's cloud. The deal marks momentum gained under Diane Greene, a co-founder of VMware who joined Google last November. Greene's leadership has helped Google Cloud Platform gain ground on Amazon's cloud services. This win is significant for Google, which has long been an underdog in the cloud market. The deal highlights Greene's success in attracting new clients and solidifying Google's position in the market.

site_title: Oil industry in uncharted territory, says IEA senior exec
summary: A senior International Energy Administration (IEA) executive, Neil Atkinson, stated that the world is in uncharted territory regarding oil prices. The industry has struggled to grasp the rapid growth of shale oil production in the US and the resilience of oil production despite plummeting oil prices over the past 18 months. This unpredictability poses challenges for the oil industry, making it difficult to forecast future trends and make informed decisions.

site_title: North America farms swop wheat for pulses to meet demand in Asia
summary: North American farmers are shifting from wheat to pulses to meet Asia's growing demand for protein-rich foods. The world's largest exporter of peas and lentils, AGT Food and Ingredients Inc, expects Canadian farmers to plant record acres of the crops this year. This swap is driven by Asia's increasing hunger for lentils, chickpeas, and other legumes, which are in high demand among vegetarians.

site_title: Refinancing to drive Aussie mortgage growth in '16
summary: Australian mortgage growth is expected to drive refinancing in 2016, with 35% of borrowers seeking better deals after interest rate hikes. Home values have risen 70% in Sydney and 50% in Melbourne, allowing borrowers to increase loan sizes. Regulatory pressure has forced banks to tighten lending, resulting in a six-month low of 7.3% mortgage growth in January. Experts expect housing credit growth to moderate back to mid single-digits post-2016 as refinancing momentum stalls.

site_title: America running the risk of self-inflicted economic wound
summary: US presidential candidates disagree on trade policies, but economists argue that the impact of Chinese imports on US jobs is overstated. Between 1999 and 2011, Chinese imports led to the loss of 985,000 manufacturing jobs, but this represents only about 1/5 of the 5.8 million total US manufacturing job losses during the same period. The US has a large trade deficit, but a strong dollar and exports have offset most job losses. Rejection of trade agreements like the TPP could lead to a "self-inflicted economic wound."

site_title: FBI bringing in hackers to access terrorist's locked iPhone
summary: The FBI is seeking a way to access a locked iPhone used by a terrorist who killed 14 people in 2015. The agency has approached an unidentified third party with a possible method to hack into the iPhone without Apple's help. However, the FBI's new tactic may be subject to a rule requiring the government to disclose any vulnerability to Apple, potentially closing the security gap and making law enforcement's job harder. The review process, known as an equities review, has been shrouded in secrecy and raises concerns about the balance between individual and collective security.

site_title: Saudi bourse invites banks to bid for IPO role
summary: Saudi Arabia's Tadawul stock exchange has invited banks to bid for a role advising on an initial public offering (IPO) for state-owned assets scheduled for 2018. Banks have until the end of the month to respond to the request for proposals. This move indicates the government's push to sell state assets, following previous plans announced in December.

site_title: US carmakers may seek changes to federal fuel-economy rules
summary: US carmakers are expected to seek changes to federal fuel-economy rules due to the industry's struggles to meet its 54.5 mpg target by 2025. Despite investing billions in fuel-saving technologies, the industry has stalled in improving fuel efficiency since petrol prices plummeted last year. Carmakers are building a case for adjusting the 2025 standard, citing the time when the target was agreed upon when petrol cost was around $4 a gallon. The Obama administration has pledged to reduce emissions as part of the Paris climate accord, but government officials and car executives are taking a cooperative stance, extolling the gains in fuel economy in recent years.

site_title: Airports tighten security after Brussels attacks
summary: Twin bombings at Brussels Airport and a metro train killed at least 30 people, with the Islamic State group claiming responsibility. In response, several countries, including Australia, South Korea, Japan, Indonesia, Thailand, and India, have tightened airport security measures, including increased checks on passengers and additional patrols. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull blamed Europe's porous borders and lax security for the attacks, while the US has placed major cities on high alert and increased security at New York City airports.

site_title: Brussels attacks bring terror to heart of Europe
summary: Brussels was struck by coordinated terrorist bombings at the airport and metro system, killing at least 34 and injuring 250. The attacks, attributed to the Islamic State, occurred four days after the arrest of Salah Abdeslam, a Belgian linked to the Paris atrocities. Authorities found IS flags, explosive devices, and chemical products, suggesting potential connections between the attacks and Abdeslam's arrest. The Belgian government is on high alert, and the city is locked down, with both the prime minister and foreign minister expressing concerns that their fears have been realized.

site_title: Turnbull eyes greener Australia in move away from Abbott era
summary: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced support for two clean-energy bodies, the Clean Energy Finance Corp and the Australian Renewable Energy Agency, in an effort to boost his government's green credentials ahead of the Australian election. The Liberal-National coalition will keep these bodies intact, while also creating a new $1 billion Clean Energy Innovation Fund. This move aims to counter the opposition's criticism of the government's energy policies.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced support for two clean-energy bodies, seeking to burnish his government's green credentials with an election in Australia potentially just over three months away.

site_title: China's Botox boom a boon for HK firm
summary: China's demand for medical aesthetics treatments, particularly Botox, is driving growth for Hong Kong-based Union Medical Healthcare. The company, which operates Dr Reborn clinics, aims to expand its network on the mainland, fueled by its forecast that the mainland's medical aesthetics market will double to $11.3 billion by 2020. Union Medical raised HK$742.4 million in an initial public offering to fund its expansion plans.

site_title: US dollar up on Fed officials' rate comments
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-week high against a basket of major currencies due to hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve officials and safe-haven demand following the Brussels attacks. The dollar index gained 0.3% to 95.980, while the euro fell to a one-week low of US$1.1180. US Federal Reserve officials, including Philadelphia and Chicago Fed presidents, expressed support for more interest rate hikes, with Philadelphia Fed president Patrick Harker suggesting another hike as early as next month.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rose to a one-week high against a basket of major currencies on Wednesday, boosted by hawkish comments by US Federal Reserve officials and safe-haven demand following Tuesday's attacks in Brussels.

site_title: Welcome to New York, where boozing, gambling and fighting are now legal
summary: New York has become the last state to legalize mixed martial arts (MMA) after the State Assembly passed a bill on Tuesday. The bill, backed by Governor Andrew Cuomo, imposes a 8.5% tax on MMA ticket sales and 3% on broadcast rights. This move comes as the state is also considering legislation to legalize online poker and daily fantasy sports, with potential revenue generated from these activities. Supporters argue that these activities can bring in significant economic benefits, while detractors express concerns about the potential for violence and exploitation.

site_title: Time to explore using 'fiscal space' to stimulate economies
summary: Fiscal space is being considered as a potential tool to stimulate economies, particularly as central banks' monetary easing has shown limited effectiveness. Economists like Joseph Stiglitz and Paul Krugman advocate for fiscal stimulus, while a growing debate on new financing methods is underway. The upcoming G-7 summit may provide a venue for policymakers to discuss fiscal policies and potentially merge monetary and fiscal approaches, blurring the line between state and private capitalism. The goal is to overcome the global economy's growth deficit by mobilizing money and financing public projects, while minimizing the risk of inflation.

site_title: Developers raise Thai mall investment to 54b baht
summary: Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Group has raised its investment in the Icon Siam development to 54 billion baht (S$2.1 billion), expanding its shopping malls and luxury condominiums. Despite a slowing economy, demand remains strong for luxury retail and condominiums. The project, located on the Chao Phraya River, will feature two high-end retail complexes, luxury condominiums, and a museum and entertainment center, set to open in 2017.

site_title: S-Reits set for wave of consolidation: CIT chief
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trust (Reit) market is expected to undergo consolidation as smaller trusts merge to cope with rising regulatory costs. Cambridge Industrial Trust's CEO Philip Levinson says mergers are the most viable option for Reits to thrive amid tightened rules. The move is driven by the need for Reits to develop sufficient scale and stock liquidity to compete globally. More than half of the 35 Reits in Singapore have a market capitalization of less than $1 billion, making them vulnerable to consolidation.

site_title: StanChart opens innovation lab in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart) has opened its Asian innovation lab, eXellerator, in Singapore, with the goal of exploring emerging technologies and data science for sustainable business solutions. The lab, which will employ around 15-20 people, will work closely with the bank's business units and leverage partnerships with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and A*STAR's Institute for Infocomm Research. The move aims to enhance customer experience, reduce costs, and increase innovation in the region, with StanChart seeing Singapore as a potential fintech hub for the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: SIAS expanding purview to alternative investments
summary: The Securities Investors' Association of Singapore (SIAS) is expanding its services to cover alternative investments, aiming to raise S$5 million over five years. The organization will provide research and guidance to investors on unlisted investment products, such as land banking and gold buyback schemes. SIAS will also help investors navigate class action suits against scammers and subsidize legal fees. The move comes after the association was approached by over 360 scam victims, with some losing up to S$450,000.

images.alt_text: Mr Gerald says SIAS will also lobby regulators to allow class action suits in Singapore

site_title: Dozens of nationalities in Brussels carnage
summary: A triple bomb attack in Brussels on Tuesday resulted in dozens of deaths and injuries from various nationalities. The victims included people from Peru, Morocco, North America, and Europe, with around 40 nationalities represented among the dead and wounded. Belgian Foreign Minister Didier Reynders stated that the victims were diverse individuals with different backgrounds, including parents, eurocrats, sportsmen, and missionaries.

site_title: LKY's insights benefited 3 generations of younger ministers: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong remembered his late father, Lee Kuan Yew, on the one-year anniversary of his death, saying he "left nothing to chance" when governing Singapore. The elder statesman kept a close eye on various aspects of the country, from the economy to foreign relations, and accepted that another prime minister would govern differently. Three generations of younger ministers benefited from his insights and experience, and his legacy continues to inspire the current team, with PM Lee citing the example of reducing Central Provident Fund contributions in 1985 as a key lesson in economic management and political leadership.

images.alt_text: "This Cabinet Room was Mr Lee's command tent, where issues were examined and debated, decisions were taken, instructions given, and progress tracked," says PM Lee. "So for nearly half a century . . . we had a level of discussion and decision-making that would have been exceptional in any Cabinet room in the world."

site_title: Four attackers carried out Brussels blast; two identified as brothers, one on the run
summary: Two brothers, Ibrahim El Bakraoui and Khalid El Bakraoui, carried out suicide attacks in Brussels, killing over 30 and injuring 270. Ibrahim El Bakraoui detonated a bomb at Brussels airport, while Khalid El Bakraoui attacked a metro train near the EU headquarters. A third, unidentified bomber was filmed with Ibrahim and remains on the run. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks, which may be linked to the capture of Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam.

images.alt_text: Belgian prosecutors said on Wednesday that two brothers carried out suicide attacks at Brussels airport and on a metro train, with one of them leaving a desperate will in a trash can saying that he did not know what to do any more.

site_title: Priority shift in Japan could alter emphasis of Abenomics
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to delay raising Japan's sales tax from 8% to 10% in April 2017, a move that could shift the focus of Abenomics from monetary policy to fiscal stimulus. Analysts say this change could reduce the Bank of Japan's influence on the economy and yen exchange rate. Several prominent economists, including Paul Krugman and Joseph Stiglitz, have urged Abe to postpone the hike, citing concerns about Japan's deflationary cycle and the need for fiscal policy to reinforce monetary policy.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Easing taxes to create global insurance hub
summary: Singapore aims to be a global insurance hub, surpassing Hong Kong, by 2020. The country has a vision to accept both regional and global risks, driven by liberalized markets, sound regulations, and a simple tax regime. To achieve this, the government is proposing tax reforms to create a competitive environment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore, led by Ravi Menon, has outlined a plan to enhance the insurance ecosystem, focusing on innovation, people, and regulation.

site_title: The 1MDB monster
summary: Former DBS executive Tan Teck Long has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing retiring CEO Helen Wong. MAS and the PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. Chinese banks are struggling due to Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: China's oil refining glut so far spared the overcapacity axe
summary: China's oil refining industry has avoided the "overcapacity axe" despite having excess capacity, unlike coal and steel sectors. Demand for oil remains strong, with crude use increasing 5.6% last year. The country's refining capacity is expected to expand by 16.4% by 2020, outpacing oil product consumption growth. To manage the surplus, the industry may adopt flexible working hours and lower utilization rates, rather than layoffs. China's government is "quite protective" of the refining industry, suggesting it may continue to expand and lead to more product exports.

site_title: HPL buys American Indochina Resorts for US$65m
summary: HPL acquires American Indochina Resorts for US$65 million, including assignment of US$8.5 million loans. The resort, owned by AIRL, has a market value of US$66.5 million as of November 2, 2015. The acquisition will be funded by HPL's internal resources and a joint-venture partner.

site_title: CapitaLand latest to enter co-working space arena
summary: CapitaLand has partnered with Collective Works to transform the 12th floor of its Capital Tower into a co-working space under a 50-50 joint venture. Spanning 22,000 sq ft, the space can accommodate up to 250 companies, with Collective Works managing the facility. The partnership is part of the growing trend of co-working spaces in Singapore, with the market expected to grow as more workers move to small businesses. This marks the latest move by CapitaLand to cater to the demand for flexible office spaces.

site_title: NEA hands out S$1.3m in quieter building grants
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) in Singapore has committed S$1.3 million to 41 projects under its Quieter Construction Fund (QCF), which aims to incentivize companies to adopt quieter construction solutions. The QCF has received 85 applications since its introduction in 2014 and will be extended for another two years. Funding caps will also be increased, with the maximum grant per project site rising to S$200,000 and the maximum funding for quieter construction equipment increasing to S$150,000.

site_title: Fonterra profit soars as global milk price slumps
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy cooperative, reported a 123% rise in interim profit to NZ$409 million, driven by a 8% increase in milk processed to 12.6 billion litres. However, the low global milk prices have hit the bottom line of its 10,000-plus shareholder farmers, who receive less for the product they supply. The company announced a doubling of its interim dividend to 20 US cents per share to ease the squeeze on farmers. Despite the low prices, Fonterra's chief executive Theo Spierings said the long-term perspective is good, with global dairy consumption per capita growing at 3% per year.

site_title: Germanwings crash victims honoured on eve of anniversary
summary: Hundreds of people in Spain and Germany held vigils on the eve of the one-year anniversary of the Germanwings plane crash, which killed all 150 on board. The crash occurred when suicidal co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed the plane into a mountainside. Relatives of the victims, including those from Spain and Germany, attended ceremonies at airports and the crash site in the French Alps. Investigators said Lubitz had hidden his medical history and had been treated for depression and suicidal tendencies. The European Aviation Safety Agency recommended improving security measures, and airlines have since ensured at least two crew members are in the cockpit at all times.

site_title: Oil down over 2% as markets braces for US inventory data
summary: Oil prices fell over 2% on Wednesday as traders awaited US government data on crude inventories, citing a higher-than-expected stock build and a glut in the market. US crude futures dropped 2.5% to $40.45 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 2.2% to $40.87. The American Petroleum Institute reported a 8.8 million-barrel increase in US crude inventories last week, leading traders to expect a record high for the sixth week in a row.

site_title: US investor group urges halt to dual-class structures in IPOs
summary: A US investor group, the Council of Institutional Investors, has adopted a policy urging companies to stop using dual-class structures in initial public offerings (IPOs), which give insiders extra control. The policy aims to ensure equal voting rights among all investors, making management more accountable. The group, which represents top US pension funds, notes that 27 US IPOs in 2015 used dual-class structures, valued at $12.6 billion. The move is a response to a recent trend of companies using such structures in IPOs.

site_title: Axe to fall on 1MDB staff soon
summary: 1MDB, a Malaysian investment holding company, is laying off staff as controversy surrounding it continues. The company, established seven years ago, has completed a RM10 billion cash sale of power assets. Affected staff will receive their termination notices soon, marking the latest move in the company's struggles.

site_title: Brussels Airport to remain closed Thursday amid bomb probe
summary: Brussels Airport will remain closed at least through Thursday amid a terrorism investigation following the twin bombing attacks that killed at least 31 people. The airport operator has no access to the terminal due to the ongoing investigation, making it impossible to assess the damage. Six national rail stations in and around Brussels also remain shut. The main train stations, Nord and Midi, are open.

site_title: Temasek-linked group taking Select private with S$0.525 a share offer
summary: A consortium led by Dymon Asia Private Equity, affiliated with Temasek Holdings, has made a S$0.525 per-share offer to take Catalist-listed food caterer Select Group private. The offer is a 23.5% premium over the last traded price and has been accepted by approximately 53.6% of shareholders. The reasons cited for the offer include low liquidity and listing costs. The deal is expected to give investors more flexibility to manage the business. Goh Gaik Choo, the mother of Ezra Holdings CEO Lionel Lee, is a notable shareholder not part of the accepting shareholders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher, rising 6.39 points to 1,724.75. The index saw 2.42 billion lots traded, with 396 gainers and 473 losers.

site_title: Small-car COE bucks trend of premium dips in latest round
summary: COE premiums in Singapore's latest round ended mixed, with some easing and others remaining unchanged. Small cars (up to 1,600 cc) saw a slight increase to S$45,504, while cars above 1,600 cc, the open category, and goods vehicles/buses all decreased from the previous round. This trend bucks the general decline in premium prices in the industry.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed at the close of Wednesday's round of bidding, with the premiums for cars above 1,600 cc, the open category as well as for goods vehicles and buses all easing from the last round two weeks ago.

site_title: Streaming top earner last year for US music business
summary: US music streaming surpassed CD sales and downloads as the top earner for the US recorded music business, with $2 billion in revenue, led by rising Spotify subscriptions. Streaming accounted for 34.3% of overall revenue, but the industry's overall revenue only grew 0.9% to $7 billion. CD sales and digital downloads declined, while vinyl sales increased by nearly a third, worth $416 million. The Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) criticized technology giants for "value grabs" and called for fair-market rates for music creators.

site_title: Hindu temple wants deposit interest in gold
summary: The Sri Venkateswara Swamy Temple in India, one of the world's richest temples, is requesting to be repaid in gold for longer-term deposits under the country's gold monetisation scheme. The temple, which holds 7 tonnes of gold, wants to be repaid in gold instead of cash for deposits over 3 years. This change aims to make the scheme more attractive to temples that value the metal's religious significance. The move follows India's efforts to reduce gold imports and mobilize the country's vast gold reserves.

site_title: Toyota boosts battery range in new plug-in Prius
summary: Toyota unveiled the Prius Prime, a plug-in hybrid vehicle, at the New York International Auto Show. The Prius Prime boasts a 22-mile all-electric range, twice that of its predecessor, and an estimated 120 miles or above per gallon equivalent. The new version features a "chiseled profile" and improved hybrid system, aiming to shake up Toyota's brand image. The vehicle's electric range surpasses several competitors, but falls short of some plug-in hybrids. Toyota's move comes as automakers face challenges selling electric vehicles amid low gasoline prices in the US.

site_title: Strong demand for new ABN Amro 10-year SGD bond
summary: ABN Amro Bank sold a new 10-year SGD 450 million bond issue, enjoying strong demand and exceeding initial order books of S$850 million. The bonds were priced at 4.75%, lower than the initial price guidance of 4.85%, due to strong demand. The issue was oversubscribed, with orders exceeding S$1.3 billion. This deal is seen as proof that the SGD bond market is open to strong offshore issuers, with DBS Bank and HSBC praising the market's recovery and the deal's successful outcome.

site_title: Vietnam PM approves US$300m R&D investment by Samsung Electronics
summary: Vietnam's prime minister has approved a US$300-million research and development project by Samsung Electronics Vietnam, a 50-year, rent-free operation. This project is part of Samsung's expansion in Vietnam, which also includes a US$2-billion investment in another facility. The move is driven by the country's new free trade pacts and lower wages compared to China, attracting other electronics firms such as LG, Microsoft, and Intel.

site_title: HKEx and SGE team up to develop bullion products, connect markets
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx) and the Shanghai Gold Exchange (SGE) have signed a memorandum of understanding to consider developing precious metals contracts and enhancing market connectivity. This collaboration aims to boost links between markets, particularly as China nears establishing a yuan price fix on gold, giving Asian buyers more power in bullion trade. The move could potentially lead to increased trade and investment in the precious metals market.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank to act against 1MDB for failing to provide documents on overseas funds
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, will take administrative action against 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) for failing to provide documents on its overseas funds. The bank had requested documents to show the funds were earmarked for a restructuring program and to repay foreign debts. 1MDB had missed a deadline, prompting the bank to revoke three of its overseas investment permissions and issue a directive to repatriate $1.8 billion. The bank is preparing recommendations for action, which will be submitted to the Attorney-General's Chambers before its governor's tenure ends in April.

site_title: World Bank approves US$500m loan to curb smog in China
summary: The World Bank has approved a US$500 million loan to China to fund projects reducing air pollution in and around Beijing. The projects focus on renewable energy, pollutant reduction, and electric vehicles. This is part of a broader plan to finance US$1.4 billion over six years. China aims to increase renewable energy to 15% of its energy mix by 2020, down from 12% last year, and public anger has driven the push to cut smog. The loan is aimed at reducing China's reliance on coal and promoting cleaner fossil fuels.

site_title: China to offer billions in new loans to Southeast Asia
summary: China has pledged 10 billion yuan (US$1.54 billion) in preferential loans and a US$10 billion credit line to five Southeast Asian countries along the Mekong River, including Myanmar, Laos, Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. The offer was announced by Premier Li Keqiang during a summit in Sanya, China. The move aims to strengthen economic ties between China and the region. The loans are part of China's efforts to expand its influence in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: China will offer 10 billion yuan (US$1.54 billion) in preferential loans and a US$10 billion credit line to five countries along the Mekong River in Southeast Asia, Premier Li Keqiang said on Wednesday, state news agency Xinhua reported.

site_title: Australia calls China's South China Sea moves "counterproductive"
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has criticized China's military deployments in the South China Sea, calling them "counterproductive" despite the lack of legal claims from Australia. China has added reclamation to islands and reefs in waters claimed by several regional countries, raising tensions with neighbors Vietnam, Malaysia, Brunei, the Philippines, and Taiwan. Turnbull's comments are seen as an unusual rebuke against China, Australia's largest trading partner, ahead of a planned visit to China next month.

site_title: European banking supervisor urges banks to re-think business model
summary: European banking supervisor Daniele Nouy urged banks to re-evaluate their business models due to low interest rates and substantial bad debt exposure. She noted that cost-to-income ratios remain high, but banks have room for manoeuvre. Nouy highlighted the potential benefits of digitalization in improving efficiency and reducing costs. The European banking sector faces significant challenges, but there are opportunities for banks to adjust their models and sustain profitability, according to Nouy.

images.alt_text: [FRANKFURT] Low interest rates and exposure to substantial amounts of bad debt have severely weakened Europe's banks, and should cause them to re-evaluate their business models, the region's banking supervisor said Wednesday.

site_title: Occupation, industry biggest factors in gender pay gap: study
summary: A new study found that occupation and industry are the largest factors contributing to the US gender pay gap, accounting for 95% of the gap, while age, education, and experience only account for 5%. Women are more likely to hold lower-paying jobs in industries such as healthcare and insurance, while men dominate executive positions. The pay gap varies by occupation and industry, with the smallest gap found in jobs like social workers and research assistants. The adjusted pay gap fell to 5.4% in the US and was similar across five countries, highlighting the need for further action to address the issue.

site_title: Opec, Russia oil output freeze deal may be "meaningless": IEA
summary: A deal among Opec and Russia producers to freeze oil output may be "meaningless" as Saudi Arabia is the only country with the ability to increase production, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). The agreement, aimed at stabilizing oil prices, lacks impact due to Libya and Iran's refusal to participate. Despite this, the IEA expects oil prices to recover in 2017 as the supply-demand gap narrows later this year.

site_title: Banks take backseat in quiet session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 1.33 points higher at 2,881.98 in a quiet trading session at the Singapore Exchange, with low volume of 1.3 billion units worth S$977.7 million. Banks and big index components such as Keppel Corporation and Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) were subdued, while shares of property developer Sysma Holdings dropped before rebounding to close unchanged. Analysts expect a minimal impact on earnings from a recent foreign workers' levy by the Malaysian government on the Singapore glovemaking sector.

images.alt_text: Wednesday's trading session at Singapore Exchange (SGX) was one of the quietest in recent weeks, with the Straits Times Index (STI) drifting within a narrow range before ending 1.33 points higher at 2,881.98 in low volume of 1.3 billion units worth S$977.7 million.

site_title: BDO flags going concern uncertainty for China Kangda
summary: AUDITORS BDO LLP has expressed material uncertainty for China Kangda Food Company to continue as a going concern due to a significant shortfall in assets (282 million yuan) compared to liabilities (S$59 million). The company reported a net loss of 28 million yuan in 2015 and faces bank borrowings of 649 million yuan due in 2016. However, China Kangda is actively negotiating with banks and exploring alternative financing sources, and its directors believe the company has sufficient working capital to finance operations in 2016.

site_title: US business borrowing for equipment falls in February: ELFA
summary: US companies borrowed $6.1 billion in new loans, leases, and lines of credit in February, down 2% from the previous year and 7% from 2015. Credit quality showed signs of deterioration, with delinquencies and charge-offs increasing. Credit approvals totaled 79.2% in February, up from 78% in January. The Equipment Leasing and Finance Association's confidence index, which measures the volume of commercial equipment financed, is 51.6 for March, up from 48.3 in February.

images.alt_text: Borrowing by US companies to spend on capital investment declined 2 per cent in February, trade association Equipment Leasing and Finance Association (ELFA) said.

site_title: Deutsche Post to issue bonds, sees boost to earnings, cash flow
summary: Deutsche Post plans to issue two senior bonds, raising up to 1.25 billion euros, with at least 1 billion euros used to fund pension obligations. The company expects the measure to positively impact earnings and cash flow in the coming years. Chief Financial Officer Larry Rosen stated, "We expect the measure to have a positive effect on our earnings and our cash flow." The bonds are set to be priced and placed later on Wednesday.

site_title: Deloitte notes going concern uncertainty for Huan Hsin
summary: Deloitte has expressed concerns over Huan Hsin Holdings' ability to continue as a going concern due to a capital deficiency of S$65 million and a net loss of S$57 million in 2015. The company's financial statements show current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$55.5 million. The auditor's assessment is contingent on the successful completion of a share subscription exercise to raise up to US$250 million, which is necessary to prepare the financial statements on a going concern basis.

site_title: US wealth managers grit teeth and prepare for Labour rule
summary: Wealth managers in the US are preparing for a new Labour rule requiring them to prioritize retirement savers' interests over their own, by cutting fees, using technology to provide advice, and reducing minimum account balances. The rule, expected to be published soon, aims to promote transparency and protect investors from unnecessary financial products. Some firms are job hunting, while others are adjusting account offerings to comply with the new standard, which could lead to increased competition between automated and traditional financial advisers.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.33 points higher at 2,881.98 in a low-volume trading session, with 1.3 billion units traded worth S$977.7 million. The broad market excluding warrants saw 213 rises versus 173 falls, with most trading focused on the 30 index components. Shares of Sysma Holdings and Global Logistic Properties experienced unusual activity, with Sysma Holdings closing unchanged despite a drop and Global Logistic Properties experiencing a sudden jump.

site_title: US: Materials, energy shares weigh on indexes
summary: US stock indexes declined on Wednesday, weighed down by energy and materials stocks amid concerns about a global energy glut and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 35.16 points, or 0.2%, while the S&P 500 slipped back to negative territory for 2016. Investors remained cautious following hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve policymakers and the Brussels attacks. Energy stocks, including Chevron, and materials stocks, like Newmont Mining, led the decline.

images.alt_text: [NEW YORK] US stock indexes were slightly lower on Wednesday morning, dragged down by energy and materials stocks, as investors remained wary of taking on risk in a week marred by the attacks in Brussels and shortened by the Good Friday holiday.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank predicts another year of volatile flows
summary: Malaysia's central bank predicts another year of volatile capital flows due to uncertainty in the global economy. The bank projects a 4-4.5% GDP growth this year, focusing on supporting growth through monetary policy. The ringgit has rebounded recently, but the economy remains clouded by rising costs and weaker consumption. The central bank expects a challenging global financial environment, with periodic selloffs in stocks, bonds, and currency. To address these challenges, the bank emphasizes the need for Malaysia to transition to a higher-income nation, boost productivity, and intensify efforts to drive growth.

site_title: New Myanmar finance chief discovers PhD is fake
summary: Myanmar's incoming finance minister, Kyaw Win, has revealed his PhD is fake after a social media campaign exposed it as part of a global fraudulent degree empire. Win, a 68-year-old career bureaucrat, had been nominated to the cabinet of democracy veteran Aung San Suu Kyi, who will take office at the end of the month. Win attributed his fake degree to a thirst for education and limited opportunities to study abroad, saying he "never stopped studying his whole life".

site_title: PetroChina profit dives 70% in 2015 on low oil prices
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil and gas producer, reported a 70% decline in its full-year 2015 profit to 35.52 billion yuan, due to lower oil prices. This marks a significant drop from the 107.17 billion yuan profit in 2014. The company's upstream and marketing segments were particularly affected by the price slump.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation eased to -0.8% in February, with core inflation rising to 0.5%. The country's headline inflation declined due to steeper drops in accommodation and private road transport costs. Meanwhile, the cost of living and healthcare top financial concerns for Singaporeans, according to AIA. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.33 points higher at 2,881.98 in a low-volume trading session.

site_title: COE premiums mostly down in March's second bidding exercise
summary: COE premiums in Singapore's second March bidding exercise were mixed. Cars up to 1,600 cc saw a slight increase to S$45,504, while those above 1,600 cc (category B) decreased to S$46,502. The open category COE also dropped to S$46,667. Goods vehicle and bus COE eased to S$46,502, while motorcycles saw a small increase to S$6,589.

images.alt_text: Certidicate of Entitlement (COE) premiums in Singapore were mixed at the close of Wednesday's bidding exercise.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down slightly
summary: Hong Kong shares closed slightly lower on Wednesday, falling 0.3% to 20,615.23 points, amid signs of economic warming and uncertainty from deadly bomb attacks in Brussels. The China Enterprises Index also declined 0.3% to 8,873.33. Total trading volume reached 1.2 billion shares. Investors remained cautious, weighing economic warming against ongoing trade tensions and US-EU tariffs.

site_title: Japan govt cuts economic assessment as consumption stumbles
summary: Japan's government lowered its economic assessment for the first time in five months due to weak consumer spending, which has led to speculation about delaying the planned consumption tax increase. The government also plans to spend a $27 billion stimulus package, including increased cash handouts to pensioners. Despite this, economists are concerned about weak global demand and the potential for another economic contraction, which could push Japan back into recession. The Bank of Japan is expected to increase its asset purchases if there are no signs of improvement.

site_title: Germany's Postbank sees lower earnings on split from Deutsche Bank
summary: Germany's Postbank, a retail unit of Deutsche Bank, expects its annual adjusted pretax earnings to fall by at least 100 million euros due to costs related to separation from its parent. The bank plans to sell or list Postbank by the end of next year to comply with new bank rules. Postbank's adjusted pretax earnings rose 9.6% last year to 522 million euros. The bank has expanded its board to prepare for its standalone future, with total assets of 151 billion euros and 5.2 million current accounts.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's retail unit Postbank expects its annual adjusted pretax earnings to fall by at least 100 million euros (S$152.77 million) this year, among other due to costs related to the separation from its parent, Postbank said on Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares propped up by gains at Credit Suisse
summary: European shares rose 0.4-0.6% on Wednesday, stabilizing after a pullback following deadly attacks in Brussels. Credit Suisse climbed 3.2% after announcing additional cost cuts and a restructuring plan. Technology group Hexagon also rose, while William Hill slumped 13% after warning of lower profits. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.4% and the Euro STOXX 50 index advanced 0.6%.

site_title: Indonesia seeks to curb use of tax havens by companies
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, aims to curb companies from using tax havens through a tax amnesty plan. The plan offers tax discounts to individuals and companies declaring concealed wealth, and is expected to allow companies to repatriate money stashed overseas. The government suspects Indonesian firms of setting up "special purpose vehicles" to benefit from tax treaties and low tax rates in countries like the British Virgin Islands and the Cook Islands. The tax amnesty is expected to bring in 100 trillion rupiah of additional income and broaden Indonesia's tax base.

site_title: Football: Big-spending China facing World Cup woe
summary: China's national football team is facing World Cup elimination despite significant spending on players, with a 96th-ranked ranking. China hosts Maldives on Thursday and Qatar on Tuesday, needing to win both games to advance, but faces stiff competition from other teams in the qualifying process. The matches also serve as qualifiers for the 2019 Asian Cup, meaning China will likely need to go through a separate round of games to reach the tournament.

site_title: Industry-wide cost reduction alliance to yield RM2b cash generation: Petronas
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, aims to generate up to RM2 billion in cash from its Coral 2.0 industry-wide cost reduction initiative. The initiative, which involves 25 petroleum arrangement contractors, has already yielded RM2.4 billion in cost savings. Petronas plans to achieve this through various initiatives, including activating idle wells and minimizing unplanned deferments. The company is reviewing other elements of the upstream value chain for further reductions, with the unit per barrel operating cost falling to US$8-US$9. The goal is to ensure the sustainability of the cost structure of the country's oil and gas sector.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas aims to achieve up to RM2 billion (S$684 million) in cash generation this year from its Coral 2.0 (cost reduction alliance 2.0) industry-wide initiative implemented to ensure the sustainability of the cost structure of the country's oil and gas sector, not just through the current downturn, but also in preparation for the next upswing.

site_title: Indonesia fin min says central bank has more room to cut interest rates
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, stated that the country's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has room to lower its benchmark interest rate as long as inflation remains at 4%. The benchmark rate was cut by 25 basis points to 6.75% in the third rate cut of the year. This move aims to support the economy and maintain inflation control.

site_title: AstraZeneca heart drug fails in key stroke trial
summary: AstraZeneca's blood-thinning drug Brilinta failed to show significant benefits in preventing recurrent strokes within 90 days of a patient's stroke, according to a major clinical trial. The trial found Brilinta was not better than aspirin, the current standard of care, in preventing stroke attacks. The disappointing results are a blow to Brilinta's potential as a key driver of future sales and profits for AstraZeneca.

site_title: Indonesia decides against Inpex floating LNG project, wants to stay onshore
summary: Indonesia has decided against a proposed $15 billion floating liquefied natural gas (LNG) project by Inpex and Royal Dutch Shell, opting instead to process gas from the Masela field onshore. President Joko Widodo cited economic benefits and regional development as reasons for the decision. The project's completion date is expected to be pushed back by three years, and the companies involved have declined to comment on the matter. The move is seen as a blow to the energy regulator and investors.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has decided against a proposal by Japanese oil and gas company Inpex Corp and Royal Dutch Shell to build a US$15 billion floating liquefied natural gas project in the country's east, the president said on Wednesday.

site_title: Hermes full-year earnings beat estimates on leather goods, Japan
summary: Hermes International SCA reported full-year earnings that beat analysts' estimates, driven by 19% operating profit growth to 1.54 billion euros. Sales of leather goods and demand in Japan contributed to the earnings. Despite growth, the company kept its 2016 guidance, citing global economic and political risks. Hermes plans to raise prices by 3.5% in Europe and has lowered its sales outlook for a second year. The company's operating margin was 31.8%, higher than estimated.

site_title: China: Stocks close up despite bomb attacks in Brussels
summary: China's stocks rose 0.3-0.4% on Wednesday, rebounding from an earlier slump following bomb attacks in Brussels, to close at 3,236.09 and 3,009.96 points respectively. Regional shares held near 3-1/2-month highs, with investors taking comfort from a brightening global economic picture.

site_title: Thailand holds rate a 7th time as government bets on stimulus
summary: Thailand's Bank of Thailand kept its key interest rate unchanged for a seventh consecutive meeting, citing the upcoming benefits of stimulus measures introduced by the military government. The decision was unanimous among committee members, with 19 of 20 economists surveyed predicting the move. The government has approved additional support for the housing market, aiming to boost consumption in rural areas. Economists believe fiscal policies will be more effective in boosting domestic demand than lower borrowing costs, with the economy expected to improve in the second half of the year.

site_title: Sanders defeats Clinton, Cruz beats Trump in Utah
summary: Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in Utah's Democratic caucuses, gaining a crucial victory in his campaign. Sanders also won Michigan's caucuses on March 8. Ted Cruz won Utah's Republican caucuses, defeating Donald Trump. The Utah results could narrow the delegate gap between Sanders and Clinton, but Clinton still needs to secure 2,383 delegates to win the nomination. Meanwhile, Cruz's Utah win puts him in a stronger position for the Republican nomination.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees March annual inflation at 0.6-1.4%
summary: The Philippine central bank forecasts annual inflation to be within a 0.6-1.4% range in March, the slowest rate in five months, driven by cheaper power rates and a stronger peso. This would be the bottom end of the range, while a 1.4% inflation rate would be a three-month low. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas will closely monitor price trends to maintain price stability and support sustained economic growth.

site_title: StanChart opens Asia innovation lab in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart) has opened its Asian innovation lab, eXellerator, in Singapore. The lab aims to explore emerging technologies and data science for sustainable business solutions, working closely with business units. It builds upon StanChart's existing technology centre in Silicon Valley, SC Studios. The lab is the bank's first dedicated innovation space in the region, focusing on innovation and growth.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close higher due to late buying
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.35% to 3,009.96 due to late buying, staying above the 3,000-point level. The Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.16% to 1,902.53. Volatile trading and investor uncertainty contributed to the late buying, which helped the Shanghai Composite Index close higher.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew left nothing to chance when governing Singapore: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew ensured his successors succeeded through his guidance and mentorship. He continued to attend Cabinet meetings even after stepping down as Prime Minister. His experience and insights benefited three generations of younger ministers, including his son Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: China regulator frowns on Anbang's hotel bids: report
summary: China's insurance regulator has opposed Anbang's multi-billion dollar bids for Starwood Hotels and luxury hotels owned by Blackstone due to rules banning insurers from investing more than 15% of their assets overseas. Anbang offered nearly $13 billion for Starwood and $6.5 billion for 16 luxury hotels, but Marriott International now likely to win the deal after increasing its offer to $13.6 billion. The regulator's disapproving attitude was due to these rules, but no further reasons were provided.

site_title: Prototype headband to track athletes suffering concussion
summary: Researchers in Australia are developing a prototype headband to track athletes suffering concussions in sports like football and rugby. The brainBAND technology records impact on players and transmits data in real-time to medics, coaches, and referees. The headband aims to provide an objective measure for players to come off the field after a head knock, and could also alert medics to trauma sustained from seemingly harmless contacts. The device has been tested with amateur rugby union players and is expected to help prevent long-term problems caused by repeated concussions.

site_title: Julius Baer splits negative rates between bank, clients and advisers
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer has taken a "commercial approach" to negative interest rates, splitting costs between the bank, its customers, and advisers. The bank will charge clients, but also offset their portion of negative rates through services, products, and transactions. Advisers will be able to offset their portion through services within the same client relationship. The bank's finance chief previously stated that negative interest rates may be passed on to customers, but details on specific customers and currencies remain unclear. The franc's appreciation against other currencies is seen as a justification for customers' preference for it.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop as Asian shares falter
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.28% to 17,000.98, following a weak lead from Wall Street and the deadly Brussels bombings. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index of all first-section shares also declined, with the broader Topix index losing 0.42%. The decline in Tokyo shares mirrored the Asian market, which faltered due to global economic concerns and ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Update: Brussels airport suicide bombers were brothers El Bakraoui; another still at large
summary: Two suicide bombers who attacked Brussels airport on Tuesday were brothers Khalid and Brahim El Bakraoui, identified as Brussels residents with a criminal record. Their brother Najim Laachraoui, 25, is still at large, with DNA found in Paris attack sites and ties to Salah Abdeslam. Laachraoui had traveled to Hungary with Abdeslam in September. The brothers' identities were confirmed by a Belgian public broadcaster, citing an unnamed source.

site_title: Bourbon's chairman said to weigh bid to take company private
summary: Bourbon SA Chairman Jacques de Chateauvieux is considering a bid to take the French oil services company private amid declining crude prices. He already owns over 50% of the company through his investment company Jaccar Holdings and may team up with another investor to fund the acquisition. The bid comes after de Chateauvieux raised his stake in Bourbon from 26% in 2014. No final decisions have been made, and the deal depends on market conditions.

site_title: Learning to trade: Myanmar investors swot up for new bourse
