However, water conservation remains crucial, with the public encouraged to be frugal and judicious in their usage to ensure long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: Checks being made on a reverse-osmosis system at the Changi Water Reclamation Plant. The PUB is expanding the use of NEWater and desalination to meet Singapore's growing water needs.

site_title: New India shipping rules half-hearted, send mixed signals: operators
summary: India's new shipping rules, aimed at establishing a world-class shipping hub, have been criticized as half-hearted and confusing. The policy, announced in March, imposes conditions that will hinder the growth of Indian ports, according to shipping operators. The rules allow overseas operators to ferry cargo but limit it to ports that trans-ship at least 50% of container volume. Local operators argue that the policy will not encourage coastal shipping and foreign players, deterring economic growth and increasing costs for Indian vessels.

site_title: China's Gambia gambit a shot across Tsai Ying-wen's bow
summary: China has established diplomatic relations with Gambia, a move seen as a shot across the bow of Taiwanese President Tsai Ying-wen, who has refused to accept the "one China" concept. This is the second time China and Gambia have established ties, with Beijing proposing the re-establishment of relations after two years of no contact. The move is seen as a warning to Taiwan, which has lost several countries to China in recent years due to economic incentives. China's action is part of a broader strategy to promote its influence in Africa and counter Taiwan's growing diplomatic ties.

site_title: ECB, BOJ trying to depress exchange rate: ex-BOE chief
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) and the Bank of Japan (BOJ) are using negative interest rates to weaken their currencies, according to former Bank of England (BOE) governor Mervyn King. The central banks claim their easing policies aim to boost growth and inflation, but King suggests they are pushing down exchange rates to compensate for weaker global growth. The euro has risen 2.7% on a trade-weighted basis this year, and the US dollar's strength is a concern for many countries, including the UK, which is set to vote on EU membership.

site_title: As London landlords wilt, S Africa Reits defy slowdown
summary: South Africa's real estate investment trusts (Reits) have defied a slowdown in the country's economy, with Growthpoint Properties Ltd and Resilient Reit Ltd gaining over 14% in the past three months. In contrast, London landlords are struggling, with Workspace Group Plc and Derwent London Plc experiencing declines of 13% or more. The South African Reits' stability is attributed to annual lease increases of 8%, which protects them from inflation and drives income growth for investors. The country's economic challenges, including a potential recession and inflation, are also driving companies to expand abroad.

site_title: Contractless mobile plans yet to catch on here
summary: SIM-only mobile plans have yet to gain popularity in Singapore, despite being the most flexible option. Local telcos have been hesitant to adopt these plans due to concerns over low customer churn, preferring to focus on subsidies for premium handsets instead. However, Chinese smartphone makers like Xiaomi have disrupted the market with affordable options, leading to a shift towards data-centric, contract-free plans. Telcos such as M1, Singtel, and StarHub have introduced SIM-only plans, offering customers more flexibility and value, but it remains to be seen if they will gain widespread adoption.

site_title: Apple goes small for new iPhone, iPad
summary: Apple has introduced a new, smaller iPhone SE priced at $399 for US customers without a contract subsidy, targeting first-time buyers and customers in emerging markets. The move comes as the company faces a high-profile court battle with the FBI over encryption and data protection. The new iPhone SE will be aimed at customers who prefer compact phones, particularly in countries like China and India. Additionally, Apple has unveiled a new iPad Pro with a 9.7-inch display, starting at $599 for US customers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezra Holdings seeks approval to amend trust deed and issue, citing low oil prices affecting exploration and production. DBS Bank appointed as solicitation agent. Eurosports Global acquires premium sports car rental businesses for S$535,000. Trek 2000 International's two independent directors resign. OSIM International's privatization bid advised by PwC Corporate Finance. Singtel Invests S$710,000 in engineering company HOPE Technik. ISDN Holdings to seek dual primary listing on Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: US house prices climbed 0.5% in January as inventory tight
summary: US house prices rose 0.5% in January, matching the median estimate of 19 economists, as inventory remained tight. This increase brought prices to a 6% gain from a year earlier. The low inventory is driving up prices and limiting home sales, with existing home closings decreasing 7.1% to a 5.08 million annual rate in February. All regions saw price increases, with the South Atlantic region leading with an 8.9% gain.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi nominated to join Cabinet as minister
summary: Myanmar's president-elect nominated Aung San Suu Kyi to join the Cabinet as a minister, despite the constitution banning her from leading the government due to her British citizenship. Suu Kyi will likely guide the government through a proxy president and will run the country through various ministries, including Foreign Affairs, Education, and Electric Power and Energy. This move is seen as a way for her to circumvent the ban and hold significant influence over the government.

site_title: Japan may have to live with legacy of Abe's tactics for a long time
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering fiscal stimulus to boost the economy, which is struggling despite low interest rates. Abe's previous "Abenomics" policies, including monetary easing and structural reform, have been ineffective. He needs to gain "cover" for increased public spending, particularly to address high government debt. Abe's plan involves fiscal stimulus, a tool he can act on quickly, to stimulate growth and increase his chances of winning the upper house parliamentary election in June.

site_title: Australia has scope for monetary, fiscal easing
summary: Australia's economy is improving, with a 3% growth pace in 2015 exceeding forecasts, according to Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens. However, job growth data has been ambiguous, and the government's labor data shows a slowdown. Stevens noted that there is scope for monetary and fiscal easing if a global crisis occurs, citing Australia's sound financial system and unrestricted access to global capital markets. He emphasized that interest rates are already low, and public debt is higher than in many countries, making room for policy easing if needed.

site_title: STI flat after large swings since January
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.04 points lower at 2,880.65 on Tuesday, with S$1.23 billion worth of shares traded. Overseas markets were quiet, and the Dow futures slipped marginally. Property developer OKH Global led the 'actives' list, rebounding 80 cents after a 47% crash on Monday. The STI remains almost unchanged for 2016, after losing 11% at its low.

site_title: Aspial Corp launches S$75m bond offer
summary: Aspial Corp, a Singapore property and jewelry group, launched a S$75 million four-year bond offering with a fixed interest rate of 5.3%. The bonds, which carry an unconditional guarantee from the company, will be issued in two tranches and open for applications on March 23. DBS Bank is the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the offer, and the bonds are expected to be issued on April 1. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate funding and investments.

site_title: SMRT to probe deaths of 2 employees killed in track accident
summary: Two SMRT maintenance employees, Nasrulhudin Najumudin, 26, and Muhammad Asyraf Ahmad Buhari, 24, were killed in a track accident near Pasir Ris MRT station on March 22, 2016. They were part of a group of 15 workers in single file, moving towards an oncoming train, when they were hit. An investigation is underway to determine how the incident occurred, with SMRT reviewing its safety procedures and the authorities promising to strengthen safety protocols to prevent a repeat incident.

site_title: OKH recovers 20% after collapse
summary: OKH Global's shares recovered 20% to 8.5 cents on Tuesday after a 80% plunge on Monday due to the forced sale of pledged shares by private banks. The company's CFO, Francis Lee, stated that OKH is still operating and does not see liquidity issues. The forced sale affected the company's executive chairman, Thomas Bon Ween Foong, whose stake dropped from 62% to 43%. Despite the recent market volatility, OKH expects its Loyang Enterprise and Ace@Buroh projects to contribute positively to full-year performance.

site_title: Intel pioneer Andy Grove dies, aged 79
summary: Intel pioneer Andy Grove, 79, died Tuesday, leaving behind a legacy as the driving force behind Intel's growth and success in the 1980s and 1990s. Grove, a Hungarian immigrant who endured World War II and Parkinson's disease, joined Intel after its founding in 1968 and became a key figure in the development of the personal computer industry. He championed innovation and encouraged employees to adapt to changes, leading Intel to become the world's top chipmaker. Grove's contributions, including the "Intel Inside" logo, helped usher in the personal computer age.

site_title: US chides Aussie central bank for trying to talk currency down
summary: The Australian central bank's efforts to lower the local currency through public statements were criticized by the US Treasury, citing a commitment to a freely floating exchange rate. The US expressed concern over the Reserve Bank of Australia's statements in August, which suggested the currency's depreciation was likely and necessary, contrary to the IMF's guidelines. This led to a surge in the Aussie dollar, and the RBA has since tempered its language on the currency. The US Treasury's actions may have implications for other central bankers who have used similar tactics to lower their currencies.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: How businesses should approach the future
summary: Singapore's economy needs to shift from a value-adding to a value-creating economy, requiring businesses to focus on commercialization and global market expansion. The government should provide targeted and broad-based support schemes to help startups and mature enterprises scale up and disrupt industries. An Internationalisation Academy can teach local enterprises how to understand foreign markets and consumers. The government should also provide more support for entrepreneurs to commercialize their ideas and take their businesses global. This will enable Singapore to compete with bigger players and "punch above its weight" in the global marketplace.

site_title: Deutsche Bank at risk of Moody's rating cut
summary: Deutsche Bank faces a possible Moody's rating cut due to concerns over its ability to complete an overhaul and improve profit. The review comes after the bank changed leadership and recalibrated its strategic plan, with worsening operating conditions increasing execution challenges. Moody's stated that Deutsche Bank's structural cost issues and achievement of its new plan are high execution challenges.

site_title: mm2 Asia to place 44m new shares to StarHub for S$18m
summary: StarHub invests S$18 million to acquire a 9.05% stake in mm2 Asia, a film and TV content producer. The investment is aimed at expanding pay-TV offerings and tapping into mm2's regional presence to market and distribute local content. The deal involves the placement of 44 million new shares at S$0.41 each, a 19% discount to the volume weighted average price. mm2 plans to use the funds to improve cash flow and pursue acquisition opportunities, following a similar stake purchase by StarHub in 2012.

site_title: Credit Suisse unveils targets for Asia-Pacific
summary: Credit Suisse has set ambitious targets for its Asia-Pacific business, investing up to 900 million Swiss francs (S$1.26 billion) over the next three years to expand its entrepreneur client base. The bank aims to become the "trusted entrepreneurs' bank" by providing financing, access to capital markets, and structuring services. Key goals include doubling pre-tax income to 2.1 billion Swiss francs in 2018, growing client assets under management to 250 billion Swiss francs, and increasing the number of relationship managers to 800.

images.alt_text: "Our clear objective is to be the bank that serves and helps entrepreneurs to grow and develop their businesses and generate wealth. . ." - Francesco de Ferrari, Credit Suisse head of private banking Asia Pacific

site_title: Former investor darlings Japan, Europe fall to bottom of the heap
summary: Japan and Europe, once favored by investors, have become the worst-performing developed markets, with the Topix index losing 13% and a regional benchmark gauge losing 6.8% this year. Central banks' negative interest rates have failed to stimulate the markets, and investors are questioning the effectiveness of stimulus. In contrast, emerging markets have seen a 20% rally, and US shares have erased losses for the year. Strategists expect shares to remain stagnant, with some warning that the economic implications of negative interest rates could be severe, particularly in net-saving economies like Japan and Europe.

site_title: Tesco launches new range of own-label food
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, launched 76 new own-label food products, including fresh produce, poultry, and meat, to compete with discounters Aldi and Lidl. The new "farm" brands will match or beat competitor prices, aiming to step up Tesco's fightback against the discounters. The move follows a reported first like-for-like sales growth for four years and a 37% increase in Tesco's shares over the last three months. The launch is part of Chief Executive Dave Lewis's strategy to improve product availability, customer service, and relationships with suppliers.

site_title: PCS to invest US$80m in new naphtha import facilities in S'pore
summary: Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore (PCS) plans to invest US$80 million in new naphtha import facilities in Singapore by the third quarter of 2017. The project will include storage tanks and a liquid berth capable of handling large vessels, aiming to improve naphtha import logistics and optimize feed to crackers. The new facilities are expected to start operations by the fourth quarter of 2017, reducing drop-offs by naphtha tankers to once every 8-10 days and cutting costs. The project is in response to the global trend of moving naphtha in larger vessels.

site_title: Rise of 'anti parties' detrimental to global growth, UBS says
summary: UBS economist Paul Donovan warns that the rise of "anti parties" and "scapegoat economics" poses a risk to global growth. The shift in support for parties opposing specific groups, often fueled by economic dissatisfaction, can lead to trade protectionism, reduced labor mobility, and hindered expansions. Donovan cites examples of countries experiencing higher levels of prejudice, such as Germany and the US, which are less likely to be economically competitive. He advises economists to closely monitor political developments, which will determine the relative trend rates of growth in different economies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.39 points to 1,724.75. The trading volume reached 2.42 billion lots, valued at RM2.88 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 396-473.

site_title: Candidates for Bukit Batok constituency begin campaigning for by-election
summary: Candidates Chee Soon Juan and Murali Pillai have begun campaigning for the Bukit Batok by-election, visiting homes of 27,000 voters in the single-member constituency. The two candidates, 53 and 48 years old, are from the Singapore Democratic Party and People's Action Party, respectively. The by-election is expected to draw attention from voters, with the outcome potentially influencing the country's politics. The campaign is the first major test for the two parties since the last general election in 2020.

site_title: German business morale rebounds more than expected in March
summary: German business morale rebounded in March, rising to 106.7 from 105.7 in February, surpassing expectations of a 106.0 increase. The improvement was driven by better sentiment in manufacturing and wholesaling sectors, while construction saw weaker business sentiment. This marked the end of a three-month decline in business morale.

site_title: 'The whole of Europe has been hit': Hollande
summary: French President Francois Hollande stated that Tuesday's Brussels attacks that killed at least 26 people struck "the whole of Europe." Hollande urged the continent to take action against terrorism, citing France's own experiences with attacks in January and November last year. France will increase its police presence at border crossings and key infrastructure.

site_title: China FX regulator queries fund managers on overseas investment: sources
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator, SAFE, has queried fund managers participating in the Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (QDII) scheme about their overseas investment products and clients' demand, amid concerns over capital outflows. The regulator sent questionnaires to some fund houses, seeking information on expected yuan depreciation and acknowledging the lack of basis for persistent depreciation. This comes as QDII quotas have been in short supply due to domestic investors seeking to reduce exposure to a sliding yuan, and some fund houses have suspended subscriptions for their QDII products.

site_title: Cameron could suffer a 'hangover' even if he wins EU referendum
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has warned that a potential Brexit could lead to a "gamble of the century" and a "hangover" for the country, even if the "out" side wins the EU referendum on June 23. The "in" campaign has taken a page from the "Project Fear" playbook used in the 2014 Scottish independence referendum, which led to a surge in the Scottish Nationalist Party's popularity and a landslide victory in the UK General Election. The SNP's success has transformed its fortunes, and it is now in a strong position to win a majority government in the Scottish elections.

site_title: Brexit means crisis for Europe's junk market
summary: The UK's potential exit from the European Union, or "Brexit," is expected to cause a crisis for Europe's junk bond market, with a vote in June potentially leading to the deepest market slump since the Greek debt crisis. Analysts and investors predict that the UK's departure will roil markets, threatening to split the 28-nation union and hurting high-yield assets, equities, and peripheral countries. A vote in favor of leaving could also harm the UK economy, with Moody's Investors Service warning of potential credit rating downgrades for UK manufacturers, retailers, and universities.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after Brussels attacks, paced by airline shares
summary: US stocks fell after the Brussels bombings, with transportation and bank shares leading declines. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index dropped 0.4% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%. The attacks, which killed at least 26 people, fueled demand for haven assets like Treasuries and gold. Despite a five-week rally, investors remain cautious, with Bank of America reporting $1.4 billion in client-selling of US stocks in the past week. The S&P 500 is on track for its first monthly increase since November.

site_title: Singtel unit increases stake in HOPE Technik
summary: Singtel's subsidiary, Singtel Innov8, invested S$0.71 million in Singapore-based engineering company HOPE Technik, acquiring 130,423 shares at S$5.43 each. This increases Singtel Innov8's stake in HOPE Technik from 18.7% to 21.3%. The investment is part of Singtel Innov8's corporate venture capital efforts.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves law to allow central bank to invest in equity
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a law change allowing the central bank to invest a portion of its $170.9 billion international reserves in equity instruments overseas to diversify risks and enhance competitiveness of Thai financial institutions. The initial investment is expected to be 3-4% of the reserves. The amended law also approved the third phase of a central bank financial sector master plan, which aims to promote financial access, electronic payment services, and regional trade and investments. The plan's implementation will be overseen by the central bank's committees.

site_title: Bang & Olufsen in takeover talks with China's Sparkle Roll
summary: Bang & Olufsen is in talks with China's Sparkle Roll Group Ltd for a potential takeover. The Danish company has struggled to win buyers for its high-end hi-fi systems, and the talks aim to ensure further development and growth. The price needs to be "reasonable" and reflect the significant uncertainty and investments required. Shares in B&O rose 8% following the announcement, while the company has lost 14% of its value so far this year.

site_title: Google, PayPal among tech companies following Obama into Cuba
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to Cuba is being accompanied by executives from tech companies Google, PayPal, Airbnb, Priceline, Stripe, and Xerox, marking a significant shift in the US tech industry's approach to the island. The companies aim to capitalize on the relaxation of US-Cuba relations by offering services such as money transfers, internet access, and business opportunities. PayPal plans to begin offering payments to and from Cubans, while Stripe focuses on entrepreneurs looking to start businesses. The move is seen as a step towards establishing a capitalist culture in Cuba, with the US government lifting restrictions on imports of software and allowing Cuban apps into the US.

site_title: EuroSports Global to expand into premium sports car rental business
summary: EuroSports Global has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Ultimate Drive and Driven By Adrenaline, two companies that provide short-term rental of premium sports cars, for S$535,000. The acquisition aims to expand EuroSports into the premium sports car rental business, which is considered complementary to their existing operations. The deal will be funded through the group's internal resources, with the acquired companies' assets valued at S$82,485 and S$149,811.

site_title: Oil market rattled by deadly Brussels blasts
summary: Deadly blasts in Brussels have rattled the oil market, causing oil prices to see-saw. Brent crude futures rose 5 cents to $41.59 a barrel, while US May crude futures fell 6 cents to $41.46. The attacks prompted a flight towards safe-haven assets like gold, and investors are now waiting for news to catch up with the market. Oil prices had risen earlier following a drop in US inventory levels, but the Brussels blasts have led to risk-off positioning.

site_title: Swiss watch exports fall for eighth month on Hong Kong slip
summary: Swiss watch exports fell 3.3% to 1.65 billion Swiss francs in February, marking the eighth consecutive month of decline. Shipments to Hong Kong, the largest export market, fell 25% for the 13th month, due to a crackdown on bribery and extravagant spending among Chinese government officials. In contrast, shipments to Japan rose 22% and those to the US increased 2.4%, as China's tourism shifts away from Hong Kong. The decline in Hong Kong is attributed to a drop in tourists to Europe following the Paris terrorist attacks.

site_title: PwC appointed independent financial adviser to OSIM privatisation deal
summary: Pricewaterhousecoopers (PwC) has been appointed as the independent financial adviser to advise the board of OSIM International on its bid to privatise the company at S$1.32 a share. The offer will be valid for at least 28 days, and a circular containing the IFA advice and recommendations will be sent to shareholders within 14 days. OSIM, a lifestyle products group, has traded above the offer price since the bid announcement two weeks ago.

site_title: Bangladesh confirms first case of Zika virus
summary: Bangladesh has confirmed its first case of the Zika virus, found in an old blood sample from a 67-year-old man who had not traveled outside the country. The man, living in Chittagong, was well and none of his relatives had tested positive. The Zika outbreak, affecting Latin America and the Caribbean, is linked to microcephaly, a rare birth defect, and has been declared an international health emergency by the World Health Organization.

site_title: Singapore shares close almost unchanged
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore closed 0.04 points lower at 2,880.65 on Tuesday, with S$1.2 billion worth of shares traded. Overseas markets were relatively quiet, with the Dow futures slipping marginally. Property developer OKH Global rebounded to S$0.085 after a 80% drop on Monday, while Keppel Corp remained unchanged at S$6.03. Analysts at OCBC Investment Research maintained a "HOLD" rating for Keppel Corp, citing improved oil prices and increased valuations for its O&M and property segments.

site_title: Japan's commercial land prices in 2015 post first rise in 8 years
summary: Japan's commercial land prices rose 0.9% in 2015, the first increase in 8 years, driven by growing demand for hotel and retail spaces, a weak yen, and the government's push to boost tourism, which reached a record 19 million foreign visitors. Commercial land prices in core cities rose 5.7%, while residential land prices fell 0.2%, marking the 8th consecutive annual decline. Key areas like Tokyo's Ginza district saw record-breaking price increases, with a spot rising to 40.1 million yen per square meter.

site_title: German private sector growth holds steady in March on strong services
summary: Germany's private sector growth remained steady in March, with the Markit composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) holding at 54.1, above the 50 line separating growth from contraction. Services growth accelerated, while manufacturers saw a slowdown due to weak foreign demand. The drop in exports and input prices indicate "huge deflationary pressure" but moderate growth is expected for the first quarter, with 0.3-0.4% growth prospects.

site_title: Deutsche Bank drops as Moody's signals risk of cut amid overhaul
summary: Deutsche Bank's shares declined 1.7% after Moody's Investors Service signaled a possible downgrade of the bank's credit rating due to concerns over its ability to restructure businesses and boost profitability. The bank faces challenges such as record-low interest rates, slumping energy prices, and mounting legal charges. Moody's may cut the bank's senior unsecured debt rating to Baa2 and long-term deposits rating to A1, citing execution challenges in addressing structural cost issues and achieving its strategic plan.

site_title: Soccer: Fifa opens proceedings over 2006 German World Cup bid
summary: Fifa's ethics watchdog has initiated formal proceedings against six individuals, including Franz Beckenbauer, over the 2006 World Cup hosting rights award to Germany. The individuals include former DFB chief Wolfgang Niersbach and others, who may have received undue payments or contracts to gain an advantage. The investigation focuses on possible corruption in the selection process and associated funding. Niersbach resigned from the DFB presidency after failing to explain a 6.7 million euro payment to World Cup organizers.

site_title: UK's Osborne looks set to miss budget target for 2015/16
summary: British finance minister George Osborne is on the verge of missing his target to cut the budget deficit to 72.2 billion pounds in the 2015/16 financial year, with the deficit currently standing at 70.7 billion pounds. To meet the target, borrowing in March would need to fall to its lowest March level since 2004. The government is also dropping plans to cut disability benefits. Meanwhile, inflation held steady at 0.3% in the 12 months to February, with core inflation rising 1.2%.

site_title: BlackRock says there won't be a US recession, cut treasuries
summary: BlackRock's global chief investment strategist, Richard Turnill, predicts the US will avoid a recession and advises investors to pare their Treasury holdings due to an "underweight" position. The company manages $4.6 trillion, citing economic indicators showing a mild slowdown but no recession. US Treasury yields remain unchanged at 1.92% as Treasuries have fallen 0.7% in March, their first losing month this year. Quickening inflation is expected to push Treasuries down, with yields potentially increasing.

site_title: Two Trek 2000 independent directors resign
summary: Two independent directors, Francis Heng and Ng Chong Khim, have resigned from Trek 2000 International. Heng cited personal work commitments, while Ng resigned due to a family member's medical care. The resignations follow a "pre-planned board retirement" by Heng, which Trek 2000 International has accepted.

site_title: SMRT accident: Investigation will focus on how the men were hit by oncoming train
summary: Two SMRT maintenance staff were killed in an accident on Tuesday morning when they were hit by an oncoming train while walking on a designated walkway beside the tracks. The incident is under investigation, focusing on how the men ended up on the track. The walkway was described as a safe passage, and the group of 15 workers were walking in single file in the direction of the oncoming train. The cause of the accident is still unknown, with SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek stating that the investigation will explore how the men got onto the track.

images.alt_text: The two SMRT maintenance staff killed in an accident on Tuesday morning were part of a group of workers on a walkway beside the tracks.

site_title: Gold rises as traders 'unconvinced' about April rate increase
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,248.20 an ounce after disappointing US housing data led investors to question a potential Federal Reserve rate hike in April. The data showed a drop in sales of previously owned US homes, dampening expectations of a rate increase. Despite two Fed officials' comments suggesting additional tightening, market sentiment remains uncertain, with a 10% probability of a rate hike in April. Gold has rallied 18% this year, making it the best-performing major commodity, as the dollar nears a nine-month low.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower as financial shares drag
summary: Hong Kong shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.1% to 20,666.75 points. Financial shares led the decline, mirroring a sell-off in mainland China markets. The China Enterprises Index lost 0.3%. Total trading volume was 1.3 billion shares.

site_title: Update: Explosions hit Brussels airport and metro station, several killed
summary: Explosions at Brussels airport and metro station on March 22, 2016, killed at least 34 people in coordinated attacks. The blasts also injured many and prompted the shutdown of the airport and metro system. Interior Minister Jan Jambon raised Belgium's terror threat to its highest level, indicating a significant threat to national security.

images.alt_text: Explosions tore through the departure hall of Brussels airport and a Brussels metro station close to EU institutions on Tuesday morning.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Explosions occurred at Brussels airport and metro station, killing several people. In other news, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry prepares for increased costs. Malaysia is set to seize assets worth RM3 billion, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow. Asean agreed that the Myanmar election is not a priority, and the UK economy shrank for the second month. Additionally, Singapore's top companies reported high CEO salaries and the country was ranked the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

site_title: One dead, several injured in Belgian airport blasts
summary: Explosions hit the departure hall of Brussels airport on Tuesday morning, killing one person and injuring several others. The cause of the blasts was not immediately clear, with reports suggesting they occurred near the American Airlines desk. All flights at the airport have been suspended, and rail traffic to the airport was also halted. The incident has raised concerns about airport security.

site_title: AXA's new CEO bets on digital for growth
summary: AXA's new CEO, Thomas Buberl, plans to focus on developing the company's digital business to drive growth, rather than large acquisitions. Buberl stated that "digital should be our focus" and prioritizes transforming the business model for a digital future. He will take over as CEO on September 1, succeeding departing boss Henri de Castries. This shift in strategy aims to capitalize on the growing importance of digital in the insurance industry.

site_title: Eurozone businesses end first quarter on a higher note: PMIs
summary: Eurozone businesses ended the first quarter on a higher note, with Markit's flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) jumping to 53.7 from 53.0 in February. The result, above forecasts, suggests the European Central Bank's stimulus is having a positive effect. While inflation remained low at -0.2%, the PMI points to 0.3% GDP growth, and service industry activity increased. However, some activity was driven by cleared orders and employment levels remained weak.

site_title: Iranian oil exports at 2.2m bpd since sanctions lifted
summary: Iran's crude oil exports have reached 2.2 million barrels per day (bpd) since sanctions were lifted two months ago, a significant increase of 900,000 bpd, according to Vice President Eshaq Jahangiri. This marks a notable rebound for Iran's oil industry, with exports rising from 1.3 million bpd in January to the current level. The surge in oil exports is attributed to the lifting of international sanctions, which were imposed on Iran in 2012.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei strikes 1-week high as US dollar gains on Fed rate hike hopes
summary: The Nikkei share average reached a one-week high on Tuesday, rising 1.9% to 17,048.55, driven by a strong US dollar after two Federal Reserve officials expressed support for an interest rate hike. The Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained 1.9% and 1.8% respectively, marking the highest closing levels since March 15.

site_title: Tournament chief Moore resigns over controversial comments
summary: Tournament director Raymond Moore has resigned from the BNP Paribas Open following controversy over comments he made about women's tennis, stating top-level female players are "very, very lucky" to have equal prize money. World number one Serena Williams and tennis legend Martina Navratilova rebuffed his statements, and the ATP men's tour formally denounced them. Tournament owner Larry Ellison announced Moore's resignation, reaffirming the tournament's commitment to equal prize money and championing the sport's efforts towards equality.

site_title: Stevens says Australia coping with commodities, has policy scope
summary: Australia's economy is adjusting well to lower commodity prices, with a sound and credible macroeconomic policy framework, according to Reserve Bank Governor Glenn Stevens. Despite risks and lower interest rates, Stevens believes there is more room to ease monetary and fiscal policy than in many countries. The Australian banking system is resilient, with limited exposure to commodity price falls. Stevens also notes that measures to slow lending to real estate investors in Sydney and Melbourne are helping to moderate house prices.

site_title: China's big oil might do something rare: write down assets
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil and gas producer, and Cnooc, its largest offshore explorer, are expected to write down assets due to a 35% drop in Brent crude prices in 2015. Analysts predict impairments of around $5.86 billion and 18.3 billion yuan, respectively, which could lead to PetroChina's first quarterly loss. Despite the decline, analysts see potential investment opportunities in PetroChina and Cnooc shares, citing lower production costs and profit-making abilities.

site_title: Taiwan's Cathay Financial says set aside T$1.4 billion for derivative loss provisions
summary: Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holdings has set aside T$1.4 billion (S$58.77 million) to cover potential losses from customer defaults on a yuan derivative trading product. The move comes as the company's banking unit, Cathay United Bank, faces losses from defaults on the target redemption forward (TRF) contracts, which pay investors a monthly income if the yuan remains above a trigger price. Analysts estimate combined losses in the Taiwanese banking industry could run to hundreds of millions or billions of US dollars.

site_title: Australia economy improving, but jobs data ambiguous: RBA
summary: Australia's economy is improving, with a 3% growth rate in 2015, but jobs data is ambiguous, with recent data showing a slowdown in jobs growth. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens noted that the economy's financial system is sound and there would be scope for monetary and fiscal easing in the event of another financial crisis. Stevens also mentioned that interest rates at low levels and public debt higher than usual would provide room for policy easing.

site_title: PCS to invest US$80m in new naptha import facilities in Singapore
summary: PCS to invest US$80 million in new naphtha import facilities in Singapore, targeting completion by 3Q 2017 and operations by 4Q 2017. The new facilities, valued at US$80 million, will include storage tanks, a liquid berth, and associated facilities, enabling better efficiencies and optimized feed to crackers. The project aims to strengthen PCS's naphtha import logistics, reduce costs, and support the company's petrochemical operations.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks notch highest closes this year on foreign buying
summary: The South Korean won reached its strongest close of the year at 1,153.6 to the dollar, a 0.9% gain from Monday. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed 0.4% higher at 1,996.81 points, its highest finish since late December. Foreigners were net buyers of shares for a ninth straight day, purchasing 139.3 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: China: Stocks fall, pulled down by finance sector shares
summary: China's stocks fell on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index dropping 0.7% to 3,225.79, and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.6% to 2,999.36. The decline was attributed to a sell-off in finance industry shares, partly due to concerns over speculative capital and rising debt levels in the sector, as well as central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan's comments on the issue. Analysts also pointed to the Monday release of pension reform guidelines, which were seen as vague.

images.alt_text: China stocks closed lower on Tuesday, dragged down by a sell-off of finance industry shares.

site_title: Australia arrests two suspected of Islamic State financing
summary: Australian police arrested two individuals, including a 16-year-old girl, on suspicion of financing the Islamic State militant group. The arrests, part of counter-terrorism operations, aim to disrupt funds flow to foreign fighters. Authorities believe dozens of Australians have traveled to Syria and Iraq to fight with Islamic State, and the arrests are seen as valuable in identifying and arresting potential radicals. The individuals are expected to be charged with financing terrorism and will attend court later.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat, NZ hits another record
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 5,166 points, down 0.3% from Monday, as investors remained cautious amid market resistance. New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high of 6,664.25, up 0.3%, driven by yield-hungry investors shifting funds from bank deposits. The US stock market also edged down, despite reaching fresh records, amid ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: IMF pushes China to disclose more currency data, WSJ reports
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is pushing China to disclose more data on its derivatives holdings, which could shed light on the country's intervention in the yuan's exchange rate. The IMF seeks data on forwards and futures, a step that would align with China's pledge to adhere to IMF disclosure standards. Analysts say the move would help understand China's policy stance in financial markets. China has made progress in disclosing data, but still has less transparency than many other large economies, according to former China specialist David Loevinger.

site_title: China considers Tobin tax to counter capital outflows
summary: China is considering implementing a Tobin tax to curb capital outflows, a move to combat currency speculation. The tax, proposed by central bank vice governor Yi Gang, would target transactions and help stabilize the yuan. Wang Yungui, head of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, confirmed the study of the policy tool but did not provide a timeframe for its implementation. The move aims to counter China's significant capital outflows and stabilize the currency.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall after explosions hit Brussels airport
summary: Explosions at Brussels airport on Tuesday morning killed one person and injured several others. European shares fell, with travel and leisure stocks leading the decline, as the STOXX Europe 600 Travel and Leisure index dropped 2.2%. Shares in companies such as easyJet, Ryanair, and Accor fell 2.4-4.6%. The incident cast a shadow over the market, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: European shares fell in early trading on Tuesday, with travel and leisure stocks leading the market lower after explosions hit the airport in Brussels.

site_title: French business activity jumps to 5-month high on firmer services
summary: French private sector activity expanded in March at the fastest pace in five months, driven by a stronger than expected rebound in services, according to a poll by Markit. The composite monthly purchasing managers index rose to 51.1 from 49.3 in February, beating economists' average expectations. The service sector bounced back to 51.2 after slumping in February, while manufacturing activity pulled back to 49.6. Markit chief economist Chris Williamson said the growth was "disappointingly modest" and urged European Central Bank monetary stimulus to boost business and consumer confidence.

site_title: Disgruntled Indonesian taxi drivers protest ride-hailing apps
summary: Thousands of Indonesian taxi drivers protested ride-hailing apps like Grab and Uber in Jakarta, blocking main thoroughfares and clashing with motorbike riders. The proliferation of cheap taxis using ride-sharing apps has made traditional pick-up and drop-off services unprofitable, threatening the business models of top taxi firms. The government has welcomed competition but the status of ride-hailing operations is unclear, with the Transportation Minister stating companies must be registered and subject to the same rules as regular taxi operators. The protests have brought parts of the city to a standstill.

site_title: Noble Group's Elman has nothing to offer but blood, tears, sweat
summary: Noble Group Ltd founder Richard Elman expressed skepticism about predicting market turning points, likening it to Winston Churchill's wartime phrase. Elman stated that predicting commodity market shifts is only possible with hindsight, and no one can accurately forecast how various factors will interact. He advised those seeking market insights to leave disappointed, as he doesn't possess such knowledge.

site_title: Indonesia economy to improve in the 2nd half: central bank
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo expects the country's economy to improve in the second half of 2016, driven by private sector investment. The government is spending to support growth in the first half, but private sector growth is expected to strengthen in the second half. The rupiah has room for "flexibility" according to the governor. This positive outlook is in contrast to the global economic uncertainty and slow growth forecasted by China.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges up on foreigners' stock demand, stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won edged up against the US dollar on Tuesday, reaching a 3-month high, driven by foreign buying of domestic stocks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) remained flat at 1,990.13 points. Foreign investors purchased a net 50.6 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, supporting the construction and consumer electronics sectors. The dollar's weakness, attributed to foreign investors selling dollars, contributed to the won's increase.

site_title: Foxconn working towards cutting planned investment into Sharp: sources
summary: Foxconn is considering cutting its planned investment into Sharp Corp by around 100 billion yen, down from an initial 489 billion yen. This move aims to factor in future losses and deteriorating earnings. The planned reduction aims to reduce the risk associated with investing in the loss-making Japanese electronics firm.

site_title: Japan's ANA says computer glitch forces domestic flight cancellations
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's largest carrier, canceled over 100 domestic flights due to a computer glitch affecting check-in and reservation systems. The issue occurred on Tuesday morning and affected 15,200 customers. The airline's check-in and reservations software stopped working at 0840 local time, while check-in terminals resumed operation in under five hours. The cause of the system failures remains unknown, with international flights operating normally.

site_title: Japan's lower house approves reflationist Sakurai for BOJ board
summary: Japan's lower house approved Makoto Sakurai, a reflationist and think tank executive, to join the Bank of Japan's policy board, shifting the balance in favor of Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's stimulus push. Sakurai's addition replaces Sayuri Shirai, who voted against the BOJ's negative interest rate decision. The move is seen as securing Kuroda's position and easing pressure on his radical stimulus plans. Sakurai's first policy-setting meeting is set for April 27-28, and he is expected to back Kuroda's decisions, further solidifying the BOJ's reflationary stance.

site_title: China state firms seen boosting green energy investment in Australia
summary: Chinese state-owned companies are expected to boost investment in Australia's renewable energy sector, following a more favorable national leadership and existing deals such as State Power Investment Corp's A$300 million wind farm buyout. Chinese firms are attracted to Australia's rule of law, stable economy, and regulation, and are looking for long-term projects with offtake agreements and local expertise. Other companies, including Shanghai Electric Power Co Ltd and Cecep Wind-power Corp, are also exploring Australian energy assets, with wind farms being a key focus.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars subdued, RBA awaited
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were subdued on Tuesday after recent gains, awaiting Reserve Bank of Australia comments. The Australian dollar eased to US$0.7572, its third session of losses, following a 6% monthly rise. Dealers expect RBA governor Glenn Stevens to talk down the currency, aiming for a lower value. The New Zealand dollar remained steady at US$0.6756. Investors await Stevens' comments, which may impact monetary policy expectations and the currencies' values.

site_title: 2 SMRT staff killed in track accident near Pasir Ris station
summary: Two SMRT maintenance staff were killed in a track accident near Pasir Ris MRT station in Singapore on Tuesday morning. Train services on the East-West Line between Tanah Merah and Pasir Ris stations were suspended for over two hours. The staff were believed to have been hit by an oncoming train.

images.alt_text: SCDF officers on the track near Pasir Ris MRT on March 22.

site_title: US dollar buoyed in Asia by bullish Fed comments
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen and euro on Tuesday after two Federal Reserve officials suggested a potential interest rate hike as soon as next month. The comments countered the dovish stance of Fed Chair Janet Yellen, who cited concerns about the US economy. The dollar rebounded from a near nine-month low, with gains dependent on further comments from other Fed officials. The euro was also firm against emerging market units, while the dollar fell against the South Korean won and Philippine peso.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says it doesn't expect major TV impact from Hon Hai's Sharp deal
summary: Samsung Electronics doesn't expect significant changes to its TV business following Hon Hai's acquisition of Sharp Corp. As the world's No.1 TV maker by market share, Samsung is currently the largest buyer of Sharp's display panels. Samsung's head of TV business, Kim Hyun Suk, stated that while predicting future changes is challenging, he doesn't anticipate any major impact on their business.

site_title: ANZ CEO says bank needs to "tighten" Asia business
summary: ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott stated the bank needs to "tighten" its Asia business, which could result in a smaller presence in the region. ANZ has been scaling down its Asia operations due to economic slowdowns and exited its "emerging corporate" business in several countries. Elliott has shifted focus to areas with faster growth and more attractive returns.

site_title: Hong Kong property crash averted, if stock traders are right
summary: Hong Kong property prices are sliding from all-time highs, but a crash is unlikely, according to analysts. The Hang Seng Properties Index has jumped 18% in two months, outpacing the broader Hong Kong equity market, and has historically been a decent leading indicator of turning points in the housing market. Sales volumes are recovering, and the market is thawing as fears of an exodus from Hong Kong assets fade. Analysts predict home prices will bottom out by year-end and resume annual gains of about 10% through 2019.

site_title: Botched rules trip Modi's dream of shipping hub rivaling Singapore
summary: India's shipping ministry has introduced new rules aimed at making the country a world-class shipping hub, but analysts say they will hinder growth and fail to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi's vision. The rules, announced in March, impose conditions that will limit the growth of Indian ports and favor foreign shipping lines. The policy gives mixed signals, and ports will need to show a 50% increase in cargo transshipment to retain the benefit, making it difficult for them to meet the condition. The move is seen as a step in the right direction, but a piecemeal solution that will not help India compete with regional star Singapore.

site_title: South Korea fin min says recovery sluggish, fiscal conditions challenging
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il Ho, expressed concerns about the country's sluggish recovery, citing declines in production and consumption, and a lack of improvement in exports. The government's welfare and job creation spending is under pressure due to increased uncertainties in the global economy. The unemployment rate reached its highest in six years in February, and analysts predict the Bank of Korea may lower interest rates in April to boost the economy. The government is also preparing to announce measures to boost youth and female employment in April.

images.alt_text: South Korea's recovery has lost momentum from declines in production and consumption while exports show no sign of improving, adding pressure on the government's welfare and job creation spending, finance minister Yoo Il Ho said on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.9 points to 1716.70. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 46, with volume reaching 51.17 million lots worth RM13.42 million.

site_title: Suu Kyi nominated for Myanmar cabinet post: speaker
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate and leader of Myanmar's opposition party, was nominated to join the cabinet in the incoming government. She was named first in a list of ministers read out to lawmakers by the parliament speaker, despite being blocked from the presidency. Suu Kyi has vowed to rule above the next president, Htin Kyaw, and will hold a formal position in the administration. The nomination marks a significant move towards Suu Kyi's integration into the government, following her party's landslide victory in the recent elections.

images.alt_text: Aung San Suu Kyi was nominated to join the cabinet in Myanmar's incoming government on Tuesday, giving the democracy veteran a formal position in the administration, despite being blocked from the presidency.

site_title: Sydney home values have biggest quarterly drop in seven years
summary: Sydney home values experienced the largest quarterly drop in seven years, falling 1.6% in the December quarter due to a regulatory crackdown and increased mortgage rates. This decline follows record prices, with Sydney home values rising 70% since 2007. The total value of Australia's residential dwellings increased A$31.6 billion to A$5.9 trillion. The decline is expected to slow home-price growth across the country's largest cities.

site_title: China's rising sway seen in Korea bonds as holdings top US
summary: China has surpassed the US as the largest foreign holder of South Korean won-denominated bonds, with holdings reaching 17.5 trillion won. Chinese companies have also made record investments in South Korean firms, with a focus on the services sector. This influx of investment is seen as a positive for investor diversification but also raises concerns about capital outflow in cases of economic turmoil in China. South Korea's won has seen significant volatility, with the won outperforming regional peers in March due to concerns about instability in China's economy.

site_title: Bank of China loans over US$50b for Chinese firms' overseas M&A
summary: Bank of China has extended US$56.3 billion in loans to fund 188 overseas acquisition deals by Chinese companies since 2010, as growth slows at home. The deals cover various industries, including electronics, infrastructure, and commerce. The bank aims to provide US$100 billion in loans for China's "One Belt, One Road" strategy, which aims to build new trade links and markets. Chinese companies, backed by state lenders, have been aggressively snapping up assets overseas to drive growth. The purchases are partly driven by slowing growth at home.

site_title: Aspial Corp to guarantee subsidiary's bond offering of up to S$75m
summary: ASPIAL Corp will guarantee a subsidiary's bond offering of up to S$75 million, with the bonds carrying a 5.30% interest rate and set to mature in 2020. The bonds will be issued through electronic applications and placements, with DBS Bank serving as the lead manager and bookrunner. The Singapore Exchange has granted in-principle approval for the listing and quotation of the bonds, subject to certain conditions.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall after weak export orders data
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.6% on Tuesday as weak export orders data and overseas market declines weighed on investor sentiment. Apple's latest iPhone launch failed to boost key tech shares, with suppliers such as Hon Hai Precision Industry and Pegatron down 0.8% and 2.2%, respectively. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co was off 1.3%. The country's export orders in February fell for the 11th month in a row, further cementing expectations of a rate cut at the central bank's next meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Battered OKH Global shares regain some footing
summary: OKH Global shares recovered from a tumultuous trading session, rising 27% to 9.5 Singapore cents, before closing at 8.5 cents, a 19.7% gain from the previous day. The counter was among the most active stocks, with 287 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Australia PM hits out at putdown from predecessor
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull criticized his predecessor Tony Abbott for claiming credit for policies the government is taking ahead of elections. Abbott, ousted last September, said the Turnbull government is running on his record, citing hardline immigration policies and free trade agreements. Turnbull responded, saying Abbott is not right and there is both continuity and change. Employment Minister Michaelia Cash issued a veiled threat to right-wingers considering agitating for Abbott's return, saying her goal is to ensure the re-election of the Turnbull government. Turnbull's support has slipped in recent weeks due to unfulfilled policy changes.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares sidle sideways, telecoms in demand
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares remained steady on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index flat at 5,165.4. Telecoms sector led gains, driven by TPG Telecom's 5% surge in stock price after reporting a 90% jump in first-half net profit. Oil stocks also rose, while outdoor clothing retailer Kathmandu and insurance company Tower saw gains. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.16%, driven by yield-hungry investors shifting funds out of bank deposits.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves 60b baht soft loans for lower-income first-home buyers
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved 60 billion baht (S$2.34 billion) in soft loans for lower-income first-home buyers to stimulate the sluggish economy. The move aims to increase household spending and counter a global slowdown and declining exports. The measure was approved at a cabinet meeting, with Finance Minister Apisak Tantivorawong stating the aim is to boost the economy. The loans will support first-time homebuyers, helping to stimulate demand in the property market.

site_title: 'Brexit' may lead to downgrades and slower economy, Moody's says
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that a UK vote to leave the European Union, known as "Brexit," may lead to downgrades in credit ratings for British manufacturers, retailers, and universities due to potential economic growth slowdown and supply chain disruptions. The report states that the economic costs of leaving the EU outweigh potential benefits, and sectors like automotive and telecommunications may face challenges, while others like utilities may benefit. Moody's joins other rating agencies in warning of the risks of Britain's exit from the EU.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks dip after margin-trading rally
summary: Shanghai stocks fell 0.57% on Tuesday, closing at 3,001.63, after a surge in margin trading support the previous session. The Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.84%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.17%. The decline was attributed to a decrease in investor sentiment following increased support for margin trading.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says no plan to ease property cooling measures
summary: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying stated that there are no plans to ease the city's property cooling measures despite a downturn in the market. This decision comes amid concerns about the economy, with billionaire Li Ka-shing describing it as the worst in 20 years. Standard & Poor's forecasts home prices to fall 10-15% this year. The government's stance on property cooling measures has been unchanged, despite recent land sales pricing below expectations.

site_title: Japan finance minister says no need now for fresh economic stimulus
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the country's economy fundamentals are firm, eliminating the need for fresh economic stimulus measures. Aso emphasized the importance of coordinating with the international community, rather than taking additional fiscal steps. This decision comes amid growing calls for Japan to take a leadership role in boosting domestic demand as the G7 chair.

site_title: China's vice finance minister says no secret US-China exchange rate agreement
summary: China's vice finance minister, Zhu Guangyao, denied speculation of a secret US-China exchange rate agreement, stating there was no such understanding. The comment comes after foreign exchange market speculation following the G20 summit in Shanghai. The US agreed to allow the dollar to depreciate, relieving pressure on other currencies, according to some reports. However, Zhu's statement clarifies there was no such tacit agreement, contradicting earlier market expectations.

images.alt_text: China's vice finance minister, Zhu Guangyao, said on Tuesday there was no secret agreement between the United States and China regarding adjustments to exchange rates.

site_title: China Railway Group plans regional headquarters in Malaysia
summary: China Railway Group plans to invest US$2 billion in building a regional headquarters in Malaysia, with the goal of expanding into Southeast Asia. The company will build an office complex at Bandar Malaysia, a development project in Kuala Lumpur, where it owns a 60% stake. The new headquarters will consolidate China Railway Group's regional businesses and operations, and serve as a base for expansion into other parts of Southeast Asia. This move marks a significant shift in the company's role in Malaysia, from contractor to investor.

site_title: Singapore Feb industrial output seen falling 3.7% y-o-y: poll
summary: Singapore's industrial production in February is expected to have fallen 3.7% year-over-year, marking the 13th consecutive month of decline. This is attributed to weak global demand, with exports rising unexpectedly in February but still facing clouded trade outlook. Analysts predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore may ease monetary policy in April, but most expect it to remain unchanged unless a sharper slowdown in China occurs.

site_title: Gold holds decline as Fed policy makers flag possible April rise
summary: Gold prices declined, falling 1.5% over the past three days, as Federal Reserve officials signaled a possible interest rate increase as soon as April. The dollar's recovery from a near nine-month low has reduced gold's appeal as an alternative asset. Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart and San Francisco Fed chief John Williams expressed concerns over recent economic data, which may justify additional tightening. The Federal Open Market Committee meets on April 26-27, further fueling gold's decline.

site_title: Singapore shares open 4.3 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.3 points to 2,884.99 at 9:01am on Tuesday, with 63 million shares worth S$81 million changing hands. The market followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with 75 counters up and 50 counters down.

site_title: Apple's new iPhone faces challenge measuring up in China, India
summary: Apple's new iPhone SE faces challenges in China and India due to its small 4-inch display, which may not appeal to buyers in these markets. Despite its relatively low price tag of $399, the iPhone SE's price may still be out of reach for many buyers in India, where smartphones with larger screens are more popular. Apple's previous attempt, the iPhone 5C, was also met with disappointment in China. The iPhone SE's features, including the latest processor and fingerprint scanner, may not be enough to overcome these market challenges.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc's new iPhone SE has first-rate features and a relatively low price tag, but its prospects in key markets like China and India may be limited by its diminutive size.

site_title: Next boss at Australia bourse to face global merger upheaval
summary: Australia's ASX Ltd is losing its CEO, Elmer Funke Kupper, amid a police investigation into his former company Tabcorp's activities in Cambodia. The departure comes as the global exchange landscape is undergoing a major consolidation, with the London Stock Exchange Group's acquisition of Deutsche Boerse AG set to create the world's largest exchange operator. ASX's shares rose under Kupper's leadership, but the company's future remains uncertain due to its focus on the energy and mining sectors, which have underperformed globally. A global search for a new CEO is underway.

site_title: Intel former CEO, chairman Andy Grove dies at 79, company says
summary: Intel's former CEO and chairman Andy Grove has died at 79. Grove, a Hungarian immigrant, made significant contributions to the technology industry. He was married for 58 years and had two daughters and eight grandchildren. Intel CEO Brian Krzanich remembered Grove as someone who "made the impossible happen" and inspired generations of leaders.

site_title: Oil trades near US$41 as Opec sees moderate gains amid output drop
summary: Oil traded near US$41 as Opec said prices will rebound to a "moderate" level despite Iran's potential non-participation in output cuts. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' strategy of letting the market rebalance itself appears to be working, with a drop in output outside of Opec and a decline in US drilling activity. American crude stockpiles are forecast to rise, keeping supplies at their highest level since 1930, according to Opec Secretary General Abdalla El-Badri.

site_title: Hulk Hogan gets US$140m in sex-tape case
summary: Hulk Hogan, a 62-year-old wrestling star, was awarded $140 million in a sex-tape case against Gawker, an entertainment website. The jury found that the posting of the secretly recorded video invaded Hogan's privacy and humiliated him. The award is $25 million more than the original $115 million. Hogan's lawyer argued that the video was viewed 7 million times, while Gawker may face bankruptcy and plans to appeal. The case was closely watched by legal experts and celebrities, with defense attorneys citing the First Amendment of the US Constitution as protection for the publication of the sex tape.

site_title: Sharp falls on Foxconn deal as delay raises risks for completion
summary: Sharp Corp fell 5% to 131 yen after a final agreement with Foxconn Technology Group remained elusive, raising risks of deal collapse. The Taiwanese company is seeking to reduce its payment by 10-20% and wants more clarity on Sharp's performance. It has been 26 days since Sharp's board backed the Foxconn bailout, with Foxconn chairman Terry Gou's advisers examining the company's finances. The delay raises concerns that the deal, worth over $7.3 billion, may not be completed.

site_title: Thai central bank seen holding key rate again on Wed: poll
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to keep its one-day repurchase rate steady at 1.50% for a seventh consecutive meeting, letting fiscal policy support the sluggish domestic economy. Analysts predict this move due to weak demand at home and abroad, and the Bank of Thailand governor citing fiscal policy as a more effective tool. The central bank has already lowered its 2016 GDP growth forecast from 3.5% to 3.0% due to increased economic risks.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as US dollar dominates yen with crude above US$41
summary: Asian stocks rallied as the US dollar strengthened against the yen, with Tokyo's Topix index jumping 2.2% and the MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbing 0.7%. The US dollar rose above $41 per barrel of crude oil, supporting the greenback's gains against other currencies. The prospect of a US interest-rate hike as soon as April and a decline in Treasuries also contributed to the market's optimism. However, investor confidence remains fragile due to concerns over China's economic slowdown and the global oil supply glut.

site_title: Nintendo stock jumps as new Miitomo app downloads top one million
summary: Nintendo's shares surged 7.3% to 16,380 yen after downloads of its Miitomo app surpassed 1 million, the first time a Nintendo app has reached this milestone. The app, launched on March 17, has become the top social-networking app in Japan on iOS devices, surpassing Line. Nintendo aims to bring back players to its dedicated hardware by offering popular games like Super Mario Bros. and Donkey Kong on smartphones. The company plans to release five mobile games by March 2017 and make Miitomo available in 15 more countries this month.

images.alt_text: Nintendo Co rose the most in more than a month after downloads of Miitomo, the company's first foray into smartphone apps, surpassed 1 million.

site_title: Ezra seeks noteholder consent to amend trust deed of S$150m notes
summary: Ezra Holdings has launched a consent solicitation exercise to amend its S$150 million notes due 2018. The company aims to provide increased operational and financial flexibility due to soft market conditions. Proposed amendments include establishing an interest service reserve account and permitting the creation of security by the company. The trust deed and note conditions will be modified to allow for these changes, which are expected to be approved by noteholders at a meeting on April 13.

site_title: Europe's junk market faces new crisis if UK votes for 'Brexit'
summary: The UK's potential exit from the European Union in June will lead to a crisis in Europe's junk market, according to analysts. A "Brexit" will cause volatility and a flight to quality, with speculative-grade UK companies and euro debt being hit the hardest. The high-yield market, which has been recovering following the European Central Bank's quantitative easing decision, will be among the biggest losers. Companies are already listing the possibility of the UK's exit as a risk factor to their bonds, and organizations have warned that a decision to leave may harm the UK economy.

site_title: China power giant says money no issue for overseas expansion
summary: China's State Grid Corp, a major power-grid giant, is expanding overseas without financial constraints, according to its chairman Liu Zhenya. The company, which made a $13.3 billion profit last year, can rely on its sovereign-grade rating for low-cost financing. State Grid is seeking international acquisitions as part of China's efforts to overhaul state-owned businesses and allow market forces to play a bigger role in the economy. The company's ambitions are limited by the quality of assets it can find, not the amount of cash it can spend.

site_title: Citing new lead, US govt draws back in battle with Apple
summary: The US Justice Department has requested to postpone a crucial hearing with Apple regarding accessing the iPhone of San Bernardino attacker Syed Farook. New leads were discovered, potentially unlocking the phone without Apple's assistance. Prosecutors claim this method could eliminate the need for Apple's help, which was mandated by the All Writs Act. The hearing was set to take place on Tuesday, and prosecutors now propose a status report by April 5 to test the new method.

site_title: Spain probes coach crash that killed 13 foreign students
summary: Spanish investigators are probing a weekend coach crash that killed 13 foreign students, mostly Italian women, aged 19-25. The vehicle, carrying students from 20 countries, crossed a central reservation and crashed into another car near the town of Freginals, about 150km south of Barcelona. The driver, 62, is in intensive care with chest injuries and faces 13 counts of involuntary manslaughter. Authorities are investigating human error and technical problems as possible causes, with some suggesting the driver may have fallen asleep during the journey.

site_title: Obama, Castro hail 'new day' for US-Cuba relations
summary: US President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro vowed to set aside differences in a "new day" for US-Cuba relations during a joint press conference in Havana. Obama called for an end to the US economic embargo and hinted at releasing Cuban political prisoners, while Castro refused to acknowledge holding prisoners. The historic visit marked a significant shift in relations, with Obama expected to deliver a speech to the Cuban people on Tuesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cordlife, OKH Global
summary: Cordlife shares are expected to react to the sudden resignation of CEO Jeremy Yee, effective March 21. OKH Global shares plummeted 80% on Monday after 119.8 million pledged shares were force-sold by financial institutions. The sudden move may lead to further trading activity.

site_title: South Korea confirms first case of Zika virus
summary: South Korea has confirmed its first case of the Zika virus, a 43-year-old male who traveled to Brazil. The World Health Organization had declared the outbreak a global public health emergency in February, citing a link between Zika and microcephaly, a condition characterized by small heads and developmental problems. Brazil has confirmed over 860 microcephaly cases, with most linked to Zika infections in mothers. The South Korean case brings the total global Zika cases to at least two.

site_title: BBC to bring coding to UK schools with new micro:bit computer
summary: The BBC is distributing the micro:bit computer, a pocket-size device with programmable LED lights and sensors, to 11 and 12-year-old UK students to teach coding and inspire interest in STEM subjects. The device, powered by UK-made chips, can connect to other devices and perform complex tasks, making it suitable for projects related to the Internet of Things. The BBC aims to distribute one million micro:bits to UK schools, with the goal of teaching coding and promoting STEM education. This initiative is part of the BBC's efforts to revive the legacy of its 1980s-era BBC Microcomputer.

site_title: Amazon German warehouse workers start fresh strike in pay row
summary: Amazon warehouse workers in Germany have started a fresh strike over pay, with workers at the Koblenz warehouse walking out until the end of the night shift on March 23. This is the latest in a series of strikes by the Verdi union since May 2013, seeking to increase pay for warehouse workers in line with German collective bargaining agreements. The strikes are the second round this year, following previous action in the run-up to Christmas.

images.alt_text: Workers at an Amazon.com warehouse in Germany are starting a new round of strikes in an attempt to pressure the US online retailer to increase pay.

site_title: Noble to hold AGM on April 14 in Singapore
summary: Noble Group will hold its 2016 annual general meeting (AGM) on April 14 in Singapore, where shareholders will vote on proposals including the re-election of Richard Elman and David Eldon, payment of $770,000 in directors' fees, and the re-appointment of Ernst & Young as auditors. The company is also seeking authority for share buybacks and the issuance of new shares. Meanwhile, a Hong Kong court rejected a bid by Noble for summary judgment against a credit analyst and his firm, who published the Iceberg reports on Noble.

site_title: BP, Statoil to withdraw staff from Algerian plants after attack
summary: BP and Statoil will withdraw staff from two gas plants in Algeria after an attack by Al Qaeda's North Africa branch on the In Salah gas plant on Friday. The attack, which caused no casualties or damage, prompted the companies to take a precautionary measure. BP will temporarily relocate staff from the In Salah Gas and In Amenas JVs over the next two weeks, while Statoil will also withdraw staff from the In Salah and In Amenas plants, as well as its operations centre at Hassi Messaoud. The decision is seen as a response to the heightened security risks in Algeria.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise sharply in opening deals
summary: Tokyo shares rose sharply on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1.27% to 16,937.31, and the Topix index gaining 1.11% to 1,359.99. The gains followed modest gains on Wall Street after a long weekend.

site_title: Sony-backed M3 targeting investments in health-care startups
summary: M3 Inc, a medical web portal backed by Sony, plans to increase investments in healthcare startups globally. The company aims to focus on regenerative medicine, medical devices, and digital healthcare in Japan, Europe, and the US. M3, which has over 3.5 million registered doctors, projects a 25% sales growth to 64.3 billion yen in the current fiscal year. This investment plan is led by Kazuhiro Umeda, the CEO of M3i, a new unit focused on scouting out deals for the company.

site_title: Australia's New Hope sees Asia coal markets bottoming
summary: Australia's New Hope Corp reported a 56% decline in first-half core profit due to lower coal and oil prices. Despite the decline, the company sees signs of stabilization in the Asian thermal coal market, citing growing ship queues at the port of Newcastle as a positive sign. This suggests that demand for Australian coal remains firm, particularly in power stations in Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan. The outlook for Asian seaborne thermal coal markets appears to be stabilizing after a period of weakness driven by Chinese import contraction.

site_title: Valeant CEO Pearson to exit, Ackman to join board
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International announced the departure of CEO Michael Pearson, citing the need for new leadership as the company faces criticism over pricing and accounting practices. Activist investor Bill Ackman, a major shareholder, will join the board. Pearson will stay on until a replacement is appointed. The company also faces government probes over its pricing practices and has been accused of improper accounting by former CFO Howard Schiller, who has denied the allegations. Valeant intends to meet its April 29 deadline to file its annual report and has sought a waiver from lenders.

images.alt_text: Canadian drugmaker Valeant announced Monday it would replace chief executive Michael Pearson (pictured) as the firm weathers criticism over its pricing and accounting practices.

site_title: Communications cut as Congo leader seeks to extend 32-year rule
summary: Communications cut in the Democratic Republic of Congo as President Denis Sassou Nguesso seeks to extend his 32-year rule. The vote counting has been completed, but results have yet to be announced, sparking fears of post-election trouble. The government has shut down telephone and internet links, citing security and national safety concerns. The opposition has compiled its own results, contradicting the government's claims of a smooth process. Tensions remain high, with critics accusing Sassou Nguesso of corruption and nepotism, and the IMF warning of domestic instability without progress in poverty reduction.

site_title: British PM seeks to mend party rift over cuts, EU
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron defended his government amid a rift within the Conservative Party over proposed cuts to state welfare payments for disabled people. Finance Minister George Osborne's planned cuts were scrapped after Welfare Minister Iain Duncan Smith resigned over the issue.
