summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd reached a milestone of selling 3 trillion yuan (S$629 billion) of goods through its online platforms, driven by its focus on rural areas and emerging countries like Russia and Brazil. Despite China's slowing growth, Alibaba aims to sustain its growth by increasing domestic consumption and exploring new markets. The company's vice chairman, Joseph Tsai, emphasized the importance of quality growth and broadening domestic consumption, as the company continues to court foreign brands and invest in emerging sectors like video and cloud computing.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd sold 3 trillion yuan (S$629 billion) of goods through its online shopping websites in the year ending March, as China's largest e-commerce operator moved deeper into the untapped countryside and courted foreign brands.

site_title: North Korea fires short-range projectiles into sea
summary: North Korea fired short-range projectiles into the sea off its east coast on Monday, with projectiles flying 200 km and landing in waters east of the country. This comes after North Korea fired two ballistic missiles on Friday, defying UN and US sanctions for its nuclear and rocket tests. The projectiles' trajectory and impact were not specified, but the incident highlights ongoing tensions between North Korea and South Korea.

site_title: Julius Baer CEO made around 6m Swiss francs in 2015
summary: Julius Baer's CEO, Boris Collardi, received 6.16 million Swiss francs in total compensation for 2015, up from 5.73 million francs in 2014. This figure is based on a Swiss referendum on executive pay curbs. However, based on the company's view, his actual compensation was 5.96 million francs, down from 6.4 million francs.

site_title: India monetary policy panel ready by September, official says
summary: India is set to establish a new monetary policy committee by the end of September, coinciding with the end of central bank governor Raghuram Rajan's term. The six-member committee, proposed by a bill before parliament, will have three members chosen by the central bank and three by the government, with the governor's vote decisive in ties. Economic Affairs secretary Shaktikanta Das aims to have the panel operational in the second quarter of the fiscal year, which starts on April 1. The bill is expected to be voted on by parliament from April 25 to May 13.

site_title: A plea for help: How China asked the Fed for its stock crash play book
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), reached out to the US Federal Reserve in July 2016, seeking its play book for dealing with a stock market crash, specifically referencing the 1987 "Black Monday" crash. The request came after a 8.5% drop in Chinese stocks, prompting the Fed to share publicly available documents detailing its actions in 1987. The Fed provided the PBOC with documents outlining its policy measures, including repurchase agreements and interest rate cuts, which the PBOC used to stabilize its own market.

site_title: Hot stock: OKH Global falls nearly 80%
summary: OKH Global shares plummeted 79% to 7.5 Singapore cents, with 247 million shares changing hands, after a trading halt due to a query from the Singapore Exchange. The company was in talks with Zana Investor on a potential disposal of assets, which is expected to be a disclosable transaction. The counter resumed trading after a halt last Wednesday, following a 33% decline.

site_title: China urges Indonesia to release crew after sea confrontation
summary: China has urged Indonesia to release eight crew members of a Chinese fishing boat detained during a maritime confrontation in the South China Sea. The incident occurred on Saturday when Indonesian vessels tried to detain the boat, which was operating illegally near the Natuna Islands. China's acting charge d'affaires in Jakarta, Sun Weide, claimed the incident occurred in "traditional Chinese fishing grounds." China is demanding the release of the crew, citing the incident as an infringement on its sovereignty.

site_title: Seoul: Won flat as yuan eases; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won closed flat on Monday at 1,163.5 to the dollar, after initial gains were offset by a softer Chinese yuan. South Korean shares were steady, with foreign investors buying a net 140.4 billion won, marking the eighth consecutive positive session. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed 0.1% lower at 1,989.76 points.

site_title: China vows crackdown on fake vaccines amid scandal
summary: China's drug regulator has vowed to crack down on the black market sale of vaccines amid a scandal involving nearly $90 million worth of illegal vaccines. Authorities found that 570 million yuan (S$120 million) worth of vaccines were sold in dozens of provinces, potentially causing severe side effects or death. The scandal highlights China's challenge to regulate its fragmented supply chain. Local police have detained a mother and daughter who bought and sold the vaccines, and authorities will investigate all clues to punish those found guilty.

site_title: Australian foreign minister defends refugee policy on Indonesia trip
summary: Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop defended the country's refugee policy during a trip to Indonesia, where Jakarta has expressed frustration over the treatment of asylum seekers. Bishop said Australia is already doing its share and is looking to other countries in the region to do more. She also emphasized that Australia is committed to resettling thousands of Syrian refugees. Bishop's visit comes amid strained ties between the two countries, but has seen improvements since the change in Australian prime minister in September. Indonesia is not a signatory to the UN refugee convention.

site_title: China punishes film distributor for pumping up box office figures
summary: China's film regulator suspended the distribution license of Beijing Max Screen for allegedly inflating box office figures for Ip Man 3 by millions of dollars. The company admitted to buying 56 million yuan of tickets and fabricating over 7,600 screenings to boost earnings. The punishment casts doubt on China's stellar box office growth in recent years, which has been driven by local hits and a long Lunar New Year holiday. The regulator ordered the company to rectify malpractices within a month and issued warnings to cinemas and electronic ticket-selling groups involved in the fraud.

site_title: South Korea says prepared for another North nuclear test
summary: South Korea is prepared for a potential fifth nuclear test by North Korea, following a series of provocations and threats from leader Kim Jong Un. The country's Unification Ministry stated it believes a nuclear test can happen "right away" and is preparing for all possibilities. This comes after North Korea test-fired two medium-range ballistic missiles and recent satellite images showed activity at its main nuclear test site. South Korea and the US are monitoring the situation closely, with military exercises ongoing on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Emissions-cutting aviation deal must be enforceable: NGOs
summary: A coalition of environmental groups urges the International Civil Aviation Organization to finalize a market-based plan to cap and cut carbon emissions from global aviation at 2020 levels, with enforceable compliance requirements. The deal must also set long-term goals in line with the 2015 Paris agreement, limiting global temperatures to "well below" 2°C above pre-industrial levels. If the plan is not supported by all 190 member countries, the EU may impose its own emissions trading plan, potentially crippling talks. The aviation industry aims to cut carbon emissions by 50% by 2050.

site_title: BP strikes deal for China's biggest carbon permit buyback contract
summary: BP has struck a deal with Shenzhen Energy for the largest carbon permit buyback contract in China's short history, worth 100 million yuan (S$21 million). Under the contract, Shenzhen Energy must repurchase 4 million permits by June, allowing BP to trade them and giving the company access to liquidity. The deal also reflects China's nascent carbon market, which is expected to integrate regional trading schemes into the national market by July 2017, covering 4 billion tonnes of CO2 emissions.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday. No key events or market trends were reported from Tokyo.

site_title: GM's China chief says Chinese car market to grow 3-5% per year till 2020
summary: General Motors' China chief predicts the Chinese car market will grow 3-5% annually until 2020, driven by SUV and luxury segments. The company plans to launch 60 new vehicles in the next five years, including over 10 green energy vehicles. China's vehicle sales are expected to grow 6% this year, rebounding from a slowdown in 2015. Analysts note the market is experiencing unprecedented uncertainty due to a slowing economy.

site_title: UOB-Temasek JV invests US$5m in e-commerce startups from Southeast Asia
summary: A joint venture between United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Temasek has invested US$5 million in e-commerce startups in Southeast Asia through venture debt financing agreements with KFit Holdings in Malaysia and Pomelo Fashion in Thailand. These companies will use the funding to develop their businesses in the region, which is part of a list of 20 companies identified for venture debt funding in the next six months. The venture aims to nurture Asia's entrepreneurs and encourage innovation, supporting the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and driving regional economies.

site_title: Malaysia Feb inflation seen quickening to 4% year on year, highest in over 7 years: Poll
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to have accelerated to 4.0% in February, the highest in over 7 years, driven by rising transport costs and a low base from a year earlier. This would be the highest since December 2008. The central bank's inflation target for this year is 2.5-3.5%, and it expects inflation to peak in the first quarter before moderating.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to have accelerated to over a seven-year high at 4.0 per cent in February as transport costs rose, a Reuters poll showed.

site_title: Indian jewellers calls off strike; gold imports to rise
summary: Indian jewellers have ended a 19-day strike after the government assured them it won't harass them in collecting a 1-per-cent excise duty on gold jewellery. The duty was reintroduced after four years, prompting jewellers to go on strike. The government has agreed to form a committee to address jewellers' concerns, which will submit its report in 60 days. Jewellers will resume operations from tomorrow, and imports are expected to rise as consumers delay purchases due to higher gold prices. Annual imports of up to 1,000 tonnes of gold are expected to increase.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down in line with caution overseas, ahead of data
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.4% to 8,772.11 on Monday, following overseas market weakness ahead of key export data. The electronics subindex and financials subindex declined 0.4% and 1.1%, respectively. The data, due to be released later, is expected to show a 11th consecutive contraction, based on a Reuters poll. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.438 per US dollar.

site_title: AXA CEO Castries to leave group on Sept 1
summary: AXA CEO Henri de Castries will step down on September 1 after nearly 17 years as CEO to implement the company's new strategic plan. Thomas Buberl, 42, will become deputy CEO, taking over as CEO in September. Denis Duverne, 62, will replace Castries as chairman. Castries will work with Buberl and Duverne to ensure a smooth transition, citing the need for a new management team to implement the plan announced in June 2016.

images.alt_text: AXA Chairman and Chief Executive Henri de Castries said on Monday he will step down on Sept 1 after nearly 17 years as CEO to bring in a new management team to implement its new strategic plan.

site_title: Australia: Shares down as oil, metals dip; NZ stocks hit record high
summary: New Zealand shares hit a record high, while Australian shares fell 0.5% due to weaker metals and oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% to 6,633.59, driven by yield-hungry investors seeking higher returns. In Australia, the S&P/ASX 200 index fell 27.42 points, wiping out last Friday's gains, as mining and energy companies were negatively impacted. Investors are shifting funds out of bank deposits into shares in search of higher returns.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip as oil skids; China up
summary: Asian stocks slipped on Monday, following a retreat in oil prices, despite hopes that China may soon cut interest rates again as pressure on the yuan eases. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 0.3% after a three-week gain, while Chinese markets rose. The US Federal Reserve's less hawkish stance on interest rates has encouraged Beijing to pursue its own stimulus measures, with some analysts predicting an interest rate cut in the second quarter. Oil prices also slid, extending Friday's decline, and weighed on sentiment.

site_title: Apple, US govt to face off in court over iPhone privacy
summary: The US government and Apple will face off in court over the unlocking of an iPhone linked to the San Bernardino terror attack. Apple argues that the FBI's request for a "back door" into all iPhones is a "back door" into all iPhones and an overstep of legal bounds. The government claims it's a narrow, targeted order to uncover information on the shooter's phone. The case has implications for digital security, privacy, and the trust infrastructure of the global software ecosystem, with tech companies and security experts warning of a precedent that could lead to companies being forced to hand over customer data and undermine security measures.

site_title: Lippo partners with GrabTaxi to expand e-commerce in Indonesia
summary: Lippo Group, a major Indonesian conglomerate, has partnered with GrabTaxi to expand e-commerce in Indonesia. The partnership, valued at $500 million, will see Grab transport and deliver goods for Lippo's online shopping platform, MatahariMall. The move aims to bolster MatahariMall's services and compete with foreign rivals, such as Rakuten and JD.com, in the country's growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Oil prices fall on higher US rig numbers
summary: Oil prices fell 1.09% to $39.01, as US operational rigs rose for the first time in 12 weeks, sparking fresh oversupply concerns. The increase in US rigs, along with a meeting of Opec exporters in April, has raised uncertainty about a potential deal to ease a global supply glut. Despite recent gains, prices remained below $40, with Brent at $41.04, as analysts see it as a "knee-jerk reaction" to the news.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won edge down, halting recent gains
summary: South Korean stocks and the won edged lower on Monday, halting recent gains, as foreign investors turned sellers after a seven-day buying spree. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.1% to 1,989.48 points. Major shipbuilders declined, with Hyundai Heavy Industries and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering down 4.9% and 2.6%, respectively. In contrast, battery maker Samsung SDI Co Ltd rose 3.1%. The won was quoted at 1,167.2, down 0.4% from Friday's close.

site_title: Singapore shares open nearly 10 points down on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 9.51 points lower at 2,897.29 on Monday, marking a nearly 10-point decline. The trading session saw 82 million shares worth S$136 million being traded, with 81 counters rising and 62 counters falling. This is the first day of the week, which saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China has a US$590b receivables problem as bills go unpaid
summary: China's companies face a $590 billion receivables problem, with outstanding bills taking 83 days to collect, almost twice as long as emerging-market peers. Accounts receivable have swelled by 23% over two years, exceeding Taiwan's annual economic output. Corporate bankruptcies are projected to climb 20% this year, threatening banks, bondholders, and supply chains. Experts warn of a "knock-on effect" through the economy, with some companies forced to choose between extending credit to insolvent customers or cutting off payment lines. Rising debt levels and economic slowdown fuel the problem.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks start week on a high
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks began the week on a positive note, extending gains from the previous week's Federal Reserve interest rate forecast. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17% to 20,707.52, while the Shanghai composite index gained 0.79% to 2,978.46. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.27% to 1,860.61. These gains followed the previous week's momentum, which was driven by the Fed's interest rate forecast.

site_title: Gold declines for third day as dollar stabilizes, hurting demand
summary: Gold prices dropped for a third consecutive day, falling 0.4% to $1,250.99 an ounce, as the dollar stabilized after a slump. The decline follows a 18% rise in gold this year, fueled by speculation about the Federal Reserve's interest-rate outlook. The Fed's revised projections implied only two quarter-point rate increases in 2016, sparking a sell-off in the US currency and gold's subsequent decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.420 points to 1714.360. The market saw 46.46 million lots traded, worth RM17.16 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 144 to 63.

site_title: Consumers can review personal credit data for free from April
summary: Consumers in Singapore can review their personal credit data for free starting April 1, courtesy of Credit Bureau Singapore (CBS). The move aims to empower consumers to monitor their credit files, following an industry initiative by The Association of Banks in Singapore. On average, 11,000 consumers access their credit files monthly, with 85% of 870,766 new credit applicants in 2015 never seeing their files. CBS's free credit report will contain payment history, credit score, and aggregate credit limits, available online or in-person at CBS offices.

images.alt_text: Consumers who have applied for a new credit facility with any of Credit Bureau Singapore's (CBS) member banks or financial institutions can now receive a free copy of their credit report effective April 1.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi to control government as party head: party spokesman
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi will lead the government as party head of the National League for Democracy (NLD), despite not being eligible for the top office due to the country's constitution. Suu Kyi, who led the NLD to a landslide election win, has vowed to defy the constitution and run the country "above the president." The party has not clarified how she will implement this, fueling speculation about possible positions. Suu Kyi's leadership will define the success of Myanmar's transition from military rule.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars off multi-month peaks, RBA speech eyed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined from multi-month highs due to market sentiment shifting away from bullish US dollar bets. The Aussie dollar fell to US$0.7584, down a cent from Friday, while the Kiwi dollar edged down to US$0.6773. The decline is attributed to the Reserve Bank of Australia's potential speech on Tuesday, which may aim to curb the rising currency. The Aussie has gained 6% this month, its largest monthly rise since 2011, and a strong currency poses challenges for the RBA's economy shift.

site_title: NZ consumer confidence down in Q1: survey
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence declined in the first quarter, according to a survey, as households reacted to global economic troubles. The Westpac-McDermott Miller consumer confidence index fell to 109.6 from 110.7. This drop was attributed to deteriorating global economic conditions, which signal tougher times for the export sector.

site_title: Yuan declines after PBOC weakens fixing by most since January
summary: The yuan declined for a second day after China's central bank weakened the daily reference rate by 0.3% to 6.4824, the largest move since January, amid a US dollar gain. The currency fell 0.2% in Hong Kong and 0.13% in Shanghai. Strategists attribute the decline to a correction in Asian currencies after a sharp dollar weakness last week. The People's Bank of China governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, stated the yuan should not be "completely free floating," and capital outflows are expected to be quick, while former Fed chairman Ben Bernanke warned of potential deflation if the market expects a gradual depreciation.

site_title: Bank of Tianjin said to price US$949m IPO near bottom end
summary: Bank of Tianjin Co, a Chinese commercial lender, priced a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) at HK$7.39 per share, raising US$949 million near the bottom end of the marketed range. This is the first Hong Kong IPO to exceed US$300 million this year, as the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index rebounds from a seven-year low. The offering will add to the US$861 million raised from first-time share sales in Hong Kong this year, the slowest start since 2011.

site_title: UK house prices rise in March as regions outpace London
summary: UK house prices rose 1.3% in March, reaching an average of £300,000 (S$591,000) for the first time. This marks a 50% increase over the past decade, outpacing earnings growth. Regional areas saw significant price gains, while London's prices stagnated, with some outer districts increasing. Chancellor George Osborne has pledged to make more land available for homebuilding and introduced a savings product to help first-time buyers. A surge in properties coming to market and diminished buyer appetite have contributed to the price increases.

site_title: China's property bubble is real, if you're offshore: Gadfly editorial
summary: China's property market has seen a significant increase in real estate prices, with Shenzhen experiencing a 74% rise in 12 months. International investors who bought Chinese property-related stocks and bonds a year ago are now seeing returns, but experts warn that the same is not true for offshore investors who are primarily exposed to the nation's biggest cities, where price increases have been the steepest and cooling measures are looming.

site_title: Oil drop weighs on commodity currencies
summary: Crude oil prices fell for a second day, dropping below $40 a barrel, as the dollar strengthened and US rig counts rose for the first time this year. Global equities have gained over $4 trillion in value this month, with the S&P 500 Index returning to levels last seen at the end of 2015. Central bank stimulus efforts have boosted investor sentiment, but experts caution against extrapolating recent returns indefinitely.

site_title: IMF chief says Vietnam's economy is at risk without reforms
summary: IMF Chief Christine Lagarde warns that Vietnam's economy is at risk if it doesn't implement reforms to strengthen its banking system and restructure state businesses. Vietnam's economy is forecast to grow at 6.6% this year, but Lagarde says it needs to address issues such as high public debt, aging population, and lack of exchange-rate flexibility to withstand external shocks. She advises Vietnam to reform state-owned companies, resolve bad debt at banks, and improve corporate governance to ensure sustainable growth and macroeconomic stability.

site_title: Study for European banks says Brexit would harm sector
summary: A study commissioned by European banking lobby AFME warns that Brexit would significantly harm the European banking sector, with banks facing new restrictions on cross-border business and potential loss of "passport" rights. The study suggests that Britain's financial centre and economy could not negotiate favourable new trading terms outside the EU, and that a long period of uncertainty would affect market participants' business planning. The study's findings contradict campaigners who argue that the UK could write its own financial rules outside the EU.

site_title: 'Brexit' could cost UK 950,000 jobs by 2020: CBI study
summary: A CBI study suggests the UK may lose 950,000 jobs and 100 billion pounds in economic output by 2020 if it leaves the European Union. The study, commissioned by the Confederation of British Industry, warns that a vote to leave the bloc would cause a "serious shock" to the UK economy. The CBI director-general, Carolyn Fairbairn, will campaign to keep the UK inside the EU, citing the negative impact on trade and investment.

site_title: Yongnam wins two contracts worth S$49.5m
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured two contracts worth S$49.5 million, a structural steel subcontract for a Singapore hospital complex and a specialist civil engineering subcontract for a Hong Kong MTR tunnel. The contracts, awarded by Penta-Ocean Construction, are expected to positively impact the group's financial performance for 2016.

site_title: New Zealand announces oil exploration tender areas for 2016
summary: New Zealand's government announced tender areas for oil and gas exploration, covering over 525,000 square kilometers. Despite low oil prices, the government is accepting bids for five blocks, including four offshore and one onshore site. The bidding process will open in September and results will be announced in December. Energy Minister Simon Bridges stated that oil and gas is a long-term game and the government remains committed to it.

site_title: Suntec Reit redeems and cancels convertible bond issue due 2018
summary: Suntec Reit has redeemed and cancelled S$275 million of convertible bonds due 2018, leaving S$5 million outstanding, following the exercise of the put option by bondholders. The redemption was funded from internal resources and is not expected to impact cash flow. The conversion price of the bonds was S$2.042, and the closing price of Suntec Reit units on March 18 was S$1.70 per unit.

site_title: Asia: Stocks ease as investors wary after oil drops
summary: Asian stocks eased on Monday, following a retreat in oil prices, as investors became wary about the health of the global economy. The US Federal Reserve's less hawkish stance on interest rates and doubts about sustained inflation fueled concerns. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.2% despite a 16% gain from January's lows. The US dollar also declined, while the Australian dollar consolidated gains after hitting a nine-month high last week. The oil market, which had surged in recent weeks, retreated after a rise in US rig count renewed worries of a supply glut.

site_title: The high stakes of India's dispute with the US over visa fees
summary: India is disputing the US over a spike in visa fees for foreign workers, citing protectionism and violating WTO principles. The fees, set to double to $4,000 per application for H-1B visas and $4,500 for L-1 visas, will significantly impact India's $100 billion services industry, which relies on sending skilled workers to the US. India estimates the fees will add $400 million in annual costs, while US technology companies argue the program brings talented workers and supports the economy. The dispute could lead to stricter visa rules and affect the global tech industry.

site_title: US to offer China's ZTE "temporary relief" on export curbs
summary: The US Department of Commerce is expected to offer China's ZTE Corp "temporary relief" from export curbs imposed for alleged Iran sanctions violations. The restrictions, which made it difficult for ZTE to acquire US components, were imposed earlier this month. ZTE has been in discussions with the Commerce Department and is expected to make binding commitments, which will lead to temporary relief from licensing requirements. This move comes after ZTE's shares were suspended from the Hong Kong stock exchange and the company delayed publishing its annual results.

site_title: YuuZoo pays GEM Global US$80,000, extends funding agreement for second time
summary: YuuZoo Corp has paid GEM Global US$80,000 to extend a funding facility agreement for a second time. The agreement, initially set to expire in May, will now last 210 days, with YuuZoo securing a S$30 million funding facility from GEM Global in September 2015. The company will convene a special general meeting on March 21 to obtain shareholders' approval for the extension.

site_title: Crude oil falls for 2nd day as US oil rig count rises
summary: Crude oil prices fell for the second consecutive day, dropping 1.0% to $39.04 a barrel, as the US oil rig count rose for the first time since December, signaling a stabilizing supply glut. The US energy firms added one oil rig, following a 50% price rally since February. Brent crude fell 12 cents to $41.08 a barrel, with analysts attributing the price decline to concerns over the supply glut. The rally in oil prices had been fueled by OPEC's consideration of a production freeze.

site_title: US dollar on the back foot, sterling unsettled by politics
summary: The US dollar remains on the defensive, extending its losses for a third week following dovish signals from the Federal Reserve. The pound sterling was also affected by British Prime Minister David Cameron's cabinet reshuffle, with the pound falling to US$1.4430 before recovering to US$1.4463. The US dollar index remained steady at 95.063, near a five-month trough. The Fed's decision to cut interest rate hikes and Janet Yellen's comments on inflation suggested the central bank is in no hurry to tighten policy, fueling market concerns.

site_title: SIA, other major shareholders extend A$425m loan to Virgin Australia
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SIA) and three other major shareholders of Virgin Australia Group have extended a 12-month A$425 million loan facility to provide financial flexibility. The loan is subordinated to Virgin Australia's existing debt and is part of a capital structure review to ensure access to capital and improve cash flow generation and profitability. The four shareholders - Air New Zealand, Etihad Airways, SIA, and Virgin Group - provided the loan based on their shareholding proportions.

site_title: Cuba dissidents arrested hours before Obama arrival: AFP
summary: Cuban police arrested dozens of dissidents, including Ladies in White leader Berta Soler, hours before US President Barack Obama's arrival on a three-day visit. The arrests, an almost weekly occurrence, were seen as embarrassing ahead of Obama's landmark visit. The protesters were released, but Soler expressed skepticism about the US president's commitment to human rights. Obama aims to raise the issue of human rights during his visit, which is seen as a significant step towards ending the decades-long Cold War-era standoff between the US and Cuba.

site_title: Tennis: Serena slams Indian Wells boss for 'women riding men's coattails' remark
summary: Tennis world number one Serena Williams publicly criticized Indian Wells tournament director Raymond Moore for his remarks that women's tennis relies on the coattails of men's tennis. Williams stated that the comments were "offensive" and showed a lack of respect for women's achievements. Moore later apologized for his remarks, which also included comments on the physical attractiveness of female players. The incident sparked a swift backlash, with Williams and other players, including Victoria Azarenka and Novak Djokovic, condemning Moore's comments. The WTA Tour also released a statement emphasizing the importance of equality and empowerment in the sport.

images.alt_text: World number one Serena Williams ripped "offensive" remarks by Indian Wells tournament director Raymond Moore, who claimed women's tennis was riding on the coattails of the men's game.

site_title: German economy started 2016 on buoyant footing: finance ministry
summary: Germany's economy started 2016 on a positive note, driven by industrial output growth and domestic demand, despite a weak fourth quarter. The finance ministry reported the economy's industrial sector rose at its fastest rate in over six years in January. Domestic consumption, fueled by record-high employment and rising wages, contributed to growth. However, exports, which have been declining, pose a risk, and the government predicts imports will rise faster than exports throughout 2016, potentially hindering growth.

site_title: Bangladesh gets FBI help on bank heist, cyber expert missing
summary: Bangladesh's central bank was targeted in a massive cyber heist, with hackers attempting to steal $951 million. The US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has offered assistance in the investigation. Cyber crime expert Tanveer Hassan Zoha, who helped identify the hackers, has gone missing after being abducted. Authorities believe six countries were involved in the heist, and a government committee has been formed to probe the breach. The incident has been described as the largest transnational organized crime in Bangladesh's history.

site_title: Turnbull brings forward budget to May 3 as early election looms
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has brought forward the federal budget announcement to May 3, citing militant union activity as a "handbrake on growth." He threatened to call an early election on July 2 if bills to crack down on trade unions are not passed. The move is seen as an attempt to make industrial relations a key election platform, with the construction industry crucial to maintaining jobs and growth. Turnbull is betting he can pressure the main opposition Labor Party with the issue.

images.alt_text: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull brought forward the federal budget announcement by a week to May 3 and threatened to call an early election unless the Senate passes legislation to crack down on trade unions.

site_title: 62% of Brazil lawmakers think president will be impeached: poll
summary: Brazilian lawmakers are nearly evenly split on impeaching President Dilma Rousseff, with 62% of lawmakers in the lower house of Congress believing she will be impeached. A congressional committee is examining accusations of financial manipulation and a corruption scandal surrounding state oil company Petrobras. The impeachment committee is almost evenly split, with 32 supporting impeachment and 31 against. A separate poll found 68% of Brazilians support impeaching Rousseff, up from 60% in February. The outcome of the impeachment trial would determine Rousseff's fate, with a two-thirds vote potentially removing her from office.

site_title: China has a US$590b receivables problem as bills go unpaid
summary: China's companies face a significant receivables problem, with unpaid bills totaling $590 billion, exceeding Taiwan's annual economic output. The average collection time for Chinese firms has increased to 83 days, nearly twice as long as emerging-market peers, due to cash shortages at weak firms. This has led to a 23% rise in accounts receivable over two years, threatening banks, bondholders, and supply chains. Corporate bankruptcies are projected to rise 20% this year, forcing businesses to choose between extending credit or cutting off sales.

site_title: Istanbul on edge after suicide attack blamed on IS
summary: A suicide bombing in Istanbul's Istiklal Caddesi street killed four foreigners, including three Israelis and one Iranian, and injured 19 people. The bomber, identified as Mehmet Ozturk, was linked to the Islamic State group and had been sought by police over alleged links to an IS cell in Turkey. The attack came just six days after a similar bombing in Ankara, and has raised concerns about Turkey's security. The government has defended its response to the attacks, with Interior Minister Efken Ala saying the government is not on Ozturk's wanted list.

site_title: US opens Airbnb in Cuba to global travelers
summary: The US has allowed Airbnb to accept bookings from non-American customers in Cuba, ahead of President Barack Obama's visit to the island. The move, announced hours before Obama's arrival, represents a step to chip away at decades of Cold War-era sanctions. This is part of Obama's effort to transform Cuba's economy and politics, despite the Republican-controlled Congress refusing to lift an embargo. Airbnb had previously only allowed American customers to use the service, but now 4,000 listings are open to global travelers.

site_title: Budget wish list
summary: Business leaders in Singapore have shared their Budget 2016 wishes, focusing on helping local enterprises create value through innovation and navigating assistance schemes. Key requests include a "one-stop shop" for SMEs, grants for overseas investment, tax incentives for international businesses, and support for technological innovation. Many leaders emphasize the need for a balanced approach, prioritizing long-term sustainability and inclusivity. They also stress the importance of addressing labor challenges, improving productivity, and enhancing entrepreneurship culture to drive growth and competitiveness.

site_title: China revives support for margin trading that fueled boom-bust
summary: China's policy makers have relaxed controls on margin trading, allowing securities firms to borrow money and securities for longer periods and at lower interest rates. China Securities Finance Corp will offer loans for 7-182 days, cutting interest rates to as low as 3%. This move could reignite interest in the equity market, particularly if used for market making rather than speculation. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 5.2% last week, and futures on the FTSE China A50 Index rose 0.5%. The goal is to normalize restrictions put in place last year and avoid another margin-driven rally.

site_title: Virgin Australia secures new loan from major partners
summary: Virgin Australia secured a 12-month, A$425 million loan facility from its four major shareholders, Air New Zealand, Etihad Airways, Singapore Airlines, and Virgin Group, as part of a structural review to assess its debt and equity capital mix. The carrier reported a half-year profit in February, citing cost-cutting and increased corporate passengers. Virgin Australia forecasts a return to full-year profitability.

site_title: Donald Trump refuses to condemn violence at his US presidential rallies
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump refused to condemn violence at his rallies, blaming "professional agitators" for provoking supporters. He defended campaign manager Corey Lewandowski, who was seen grabbing a protester, and predicted riots if he wasn't the Republican nominee. The Republican Party is plotting to prevent Trump from becoming the nominee due to his conservative credentials. Trump has encouraged violence at his rallies, saying he'd like to punch a protester, and has predicted anger at the party's convention if someone else wins the nomination.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said that "professional agitators" bore much of the blame for violence at his rallies as video showed a protester being beaten and another apparently being grabbed by Mr Trump's campaign manager.

site_title: 12 dead in Indonesian military chopper crash
summary: A military helicopter crashed in central Indonesia on Sunday, killing 12 people, including 7 passengers and 5 crew members. The Bell 412 helicopter went down in bad weather conditions in Kasiguncu village on Sulawesi island. An investigation has been launched, with the military spokesman attributing the cause to the bad weather. This is the latest in a series of air accidents to hit the Indonesian military, including a Hercules C-130 crash in June that killed 142 people.

site_title: Shoukouwa's raw appeal
summary: Shoukouwa, a new sushi restaurant in Singapore, boasts a link to three Michelin stars via Hong Kong, thanks to its founder's venture with the Emmanuel Stroobant restaurant group. The restaurant offers an omakase-style dinner experience for S$380, featuring high-quality ingredients from daily deliveries from Tsukiji market in Tokyo. The meal includes 13 pieces of sushi, sashimi, and cooked dishes, with some standout items such as the deep-fried crab croquette and silky hot chawanmushi. While the chef's skills are inconsistent, the restaurant's strength lies in its raw ingredients and daily deliveries, making it a promising addition to the Singapore dining scene. Rating: 7.

site_title: Swift to advise banks on security as Bangladesh hack details emerge
summary: Swift plans to issue a written warning to banks on security practices after a cyber attack on Bangladesh's central bank resulted in $81 million stolen. The attack, in early February, was an unprecedented breach of Bangladesh Bank's computer systems. Swift staff will review internal security with banks and provide a summary of recommended security measures to prevent similar attacks. Forensic experts believe the attackers may have targeted other financial institutions and are financially motivated.

site_title: Roger Agnelli, who reshaped miner Vale, dies in plane crash
summary: Brazilian mining executive Roger Agnelli, who led Vale to unprecedented growth during the commodities boom, has died in a plane crash. He was 56 and was on his way to Rio de Janeiro when the single-engine turboprop crashed in a residential neighborhood. Agnelli was president and CEO of Vale from 2001-2011, overseeing $84 billion in investments and acquisitions, and distributing $17 billion in dividends. He was named the world's fourth-best CEO by the Harvard Business Review in 2012, leading Vale to become the world's top iron-ore producer and second-largest miner.

site_title: GameStop attracts large investors as shorts back off
summary: GameStop, one of the most shorted US stocks, has attracted large investors and dissuaded traders betting against it as it fights off a consumer shift toward downloading video games. The company's shares have recovered from a decline from $46 to $25 and now hover around $30. Institutional owners have jumped 21% and short sales have fallen by $100 million, leaving $1.1 billion in bets against the company. Analysts see revenue on track for a fourth straight year of growth, despite concerns about the threat of game studios bypassing GameStop.

site_title: Facebook's CEO meets propaganda czar in China charm drive
summary: Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg met China's propaganda tsar Liu Yunshan in Beijing as part of a charm drive, marking a rare meeting between the two. The meeting suggests warming relations between Facebook and the Chinese government, despite Beijing's increasing censorship and control over the Internet. Liu praised Facebook's technology and management methods, while Zuckerberg expressed optimism about China's emphasis on engineering. The meeting comes after Beijing introduced new rules on online publication, which may curb foreign internet businesses operating in China.

site_title: As China opens bad debt market, private equity firms step in
summary: China has opened its bad debt market, allowing foreign private equity firms to participate. KKR & Co LP, Oaktree Capital Group LP, Clearwater Capital Partners, and Shoreline Capital Management are among the firms staking out plans in the market. The government's measures, including a pilot programme to securitize bad loans, aim to reduce an estimated 4 trillion yuan (S$842 billion) of distressed debt. Foreign firms believe the economy's slowing growth is pressuring Beijing to allow alternative ways to reduce debt, with some firms expecting to pick up distressed assets from sectors like steel, coal, and real estate.

site_title: Lyft drivers, if employees, owed millions more: court documents
summary: A court documents reveal that Lyft drivers in California would have been entitled to an estimated $126 million in expense reimbursements if they were classified as employees instead of contractors. The estimated reimbursement per driver would have been $835, with over 1,500 drivers driving 1,000 hours or more over the four-year period. Lyft has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit with drivers, offering $12.25 million in reimbursement, which is less than 10% of the potential value of the claim.

images.alt_text: Drivers who worked for ride-hailing service Lyft in California during the past four years would have been entitled to an estimated $126 million in expense reimbursements had they been employees rather than contractors, court documents show.

site_title: Cracking the income statement code
summary: A basic understanding of the income statement is crucial for investors to grasp a company's financial health. Yum Brands' income statement reveals the company's revenue from two sources: company sales ($11 billion) and franchise and license fees and income ($2 billion). The net income, or "bottom line," is calculated by subtracting costs from revenue. The operating profit margin is around 15%, which is relatively high compared to rival McDonald's. The analysis of costs, including raw materials, wages, rent, and marketing expenses, helps investors understand the company's efficiency in generating profits.

site_title: Black swans and risk management
summary: A 2010 oil rig explosion, known as the Deepwater Horizon disaster, was described as a "black swan" event, an unprecedented and catastrophic incident. Despite initial rationalization that such an event could have been expected, BP was found "grossly negligent" and ordered to pay $18.7 billion in penalties and claims. This case highlights the importance of risk management and directors' duties, emphasizing the need for robust and well-documented processes to guard against third-party risks, which are often overlooked in traditional risk management plans.

site_title: Japan's apparel industry in hi-tech bid to secure future
summary: Japan's apparel industry is leveraging technology to secure its future, with companies like Shima Seiki and Seiren introducing state-of-the-art manufacturing systems that use digital design, automated machines, and inkjet printers to produce garments with minimal waste and labor costs. The industry has seen a 40% increase in exports over the past 10 years and is now focusing on technique and technology to differentiate itself from cheaper overseas competitors. This shift has enabled Japanese manufacturers to maintain their market share and expand their global presence.

site_title: Canada delays decision on Petronas LNG project
summary: Canada's federal government has delayed a decision on the Petronas LNG project, a $36 billion liquefied natural gas export facility in northern British Columbia. The Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency was granted an extra three months to complete its impact study, which was initially due by March 22. The project, which has faced controversy over its site and environmental impact, will now be decided by the federal cabinet once the agency files its final report.

site_title: Obama arrives in Havana to cement thaw in Cuba relations
summary: US President Barack Obama arrived in Havana on Sunday for a historic visit aimed at normalizing relations with Cuba. The visit, Obama's first to Cuba in 88 years, includes a walking tour of Old Havana, a meeting with Cuban President Raul Castro, and an exhibition baseball game. The trip is seen as a significant step towards easing US policy towards Cuba, despite opposition from some Republicans. Obama's administration has already taken steps to restore relations, including reopening the US embassy and easing restrictions on travel and commerce. The visit is also expected to have implications for US relations with Latin America, with Obama flying to Argentina after the visit.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama arrived Sunday in Havana for a visit that he hopes will help end hostile US policy toward Cuba that he views as futile, lifting one of the biggest impediments to closer US alliances across Latin America.

site_title: Brazil's ex-president Cardoso backs Rousseff impeachment
summary: Brazil's former President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has expressed support for impeaching President Dilma Rousseff, citing the will of the people and the need to address the country's economic and social issues. A recent poll shows 68% of Brazilians support impeaching Rousseff, who faces allegations of manipulating government accounts and is struggling to combat a painful recession and corruption scandal. An impeachment committee has begun proceedings, which could lead to Rousseff's suspension from office or removal from office if approved by the full lower house and Senate.

site_title: Belgium says captured Paris suspect may have planned more attacks
summary: Belgium's foreign minister, Didier Reynders, says captured Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam may have planned more attacks with a weapons cache and network of associates. Abdeslam's first statement to a Belgian magistrate suggested further attacks were planned. Authorities have found 30 people involved in the November 13 attacks that killed 130 people in France. The 26-year-old French national had planned to take part in the stadium attack, backing out, according to his statement. Belgium's prime minister, Charles Michel, says the capture may help disrupt other militant cells, but warns of a "colossal amount of intelligence work" to be done.

site_title: Aiming to be one of the big boys
summary: Singapore-based HOPE Technik is making a name for itself as a leading global engineering firm, with projects including space planes, powered exoskeletons, and emergency vehicles. Founded in 2006 with just $10,000, the company has grown to 100 staff and secured 350 projects from 18 countries, including a deal with Airbus. HOPE Technik is also investing in drones and robotics, aiming to become a major player in the industry, while also promoting engineering education to address the shortage of talent in the field.

site_title: Telecom Italia CEO to step down: sources
summary: Telecom Italia CEO Marco Patuano is stepping down, effective in the next few days, amid tensions with Vivendi over the French media company's increasing stake in the Italian telecom giant. Patuano's departure follows weeks of speculation, with Vivendi seeking to sell its Brazilian business, TIM Participacoes. Flavio Cattaneo, a Telecom Italia board member, is considered a likely successor, while Patuano's severance pay would be approximately 7 million euros.

site_title: Director buying falls; buyback activity picks up
summary: SIA Engineering and SembCorp Marine have seen an increase in buyback activity, with 24 companies reporting 64 repurchases worth S$21.74 million in the previous week. This contrasts with a decline in director buying, with no sales by directors for the seventh straight week. The number of trades was consistent with the previous week's 63 repurchases, while the number of firms and value were up from the previous week.

site_title: Saudi offers US$1.5b to fund Egypt's Sinai projects
summary: Saudi Arabia has offered Egypt $1.5 billion to fund economic projects in the Sinai Peninsula, as part of its efforts to bolster ties with Cairo. The funds will be used for development projects in agriculture and to build 26 residential complexes, including hospitals and schools. The offer comes ahead of Saudi King Salman's official visit to Cairo on April 4. This is part of Saudi Arabia's broader efforts to support Egypt's economic development and combat the Islamic State group's presence in the Sinai Peninsula.

site_title: All eyes on US data out this week
summary: US stocks have seen a positive effect from central bank actions and rising oil prices over the past two weeks, recovering from a 10% loss in January and February. The US Federal Reserve announced keeping interest rates unchanged, and although news of potentially only two rate hikes this year boosted stocks, experts caution that the outlook is not great. Analysts recommend riding the bounce while monitoring daily volumes and sticking to the index, as economies remain anaemic and central banks are under pressure to act.

site_title: SMEs' 2014 R&D expenditure surges 38% to S$800m
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) spent a record S$5.2 billion on research and development (R&D) in 2014, a 38% increase from the previous year, driven by home-grown firms. This surge in R&D expenditure led to the growth in private-sector spending, with SMEs accounting for the year's growth. The increase in R&D spending is attributed to government support, such as the Technology Adoption Programme (TAP), which assisted over 1,000 SMEs with technology adoption.

site_title: British Columbia readies new rules to tackle 'shadow flipping'
summary: British Columbia is introducing new rules to combat "shadow flipping," a practice where real estate agents and purchasers buy a property, then resell the contract to a third party for a higher price. The new rules, set to be implemented in the coming weeks, will require the express consent of the seller and mandate that any profits from assignments be returned to the homeowner. This effort aims to cool down the red-hot housing market, particularly in Vancouver, where median home prices have reached C$3.4 million.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Help to navigate tough climate among top wishes of business leaders
summary: Business leaders in Singapore are urging the government to provide support to help navigate the country's economic terrain, particularly for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). They want the government to set up a "one-stop shop" to assist with grants, tax incentives, and financing. Many also call for incentives to encourage companies to venture abroad and invest in innovation, citing the need to create value in a rapidly changing business landscape. The government's upcoming Budget 2016 is expected to address these concerns, with Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasizing fiscal prudence and long-term sustainability.

site_title: Signs are flashing that dollar plunge has gone too far, too fast
summary: The US dollar has experienced its third consecutive weekly decline, sparking concerns that the currency's weakness may be overdone. The dollar's value has plummeted against major peers, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reaching its lowest point since June. The relative strength index, a measure of momentum, has fallen to 24.7, the lowest level since 2012, suggesting a potential reversal. The dollar's decline has raised questions about the Federal Reserve's ability to raise interest rates amid a slowing global economy.

site_title: Fantasy sports games make a play for legitimacy in US
summary: The US fantasy sports industry has made a significant push for legitimacy, with Virginia becoming the first state to regulate daily fantasy sports. The industry, worth nearly $300 million in revenue last year, has been backed by major players such as the NBA, MLB, and Google Capital. Companies like DraftKings and FanDuel are racing to craft favorable laws in other states before attorneys general shut down their business. The industry faces challenges in convincing lawmakers that daily fantasy sports are games of skill, not luck, and must navigate concerns about addiction, insider trading, and practicality in Internet commerce.

site_title: Trump candidacy stirs alliance angst in Japan
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's comments on Japan's security have sparked concerns in Tokyo about damage to the US-Japan alliance. Trump has criticized Japan as a free-rider on security, stating the US would have to go to war if Japan didn't help, and has also accused Japan of stealing jobs. Japanese policymakers are worried about Trump's chances and are scrambling to find out who advises him on security. The US-Japan alliance is crucial for Japan's security policy, and Trump's comments have emboldened hard-liners in Japan to bolster their military in the face of a rising China.

site_title: China shifts axed miners to jobs in farming, forestry
summary: China is shifting thousands of miners to jobs in farming, forestry, and public services as part of a major restructuring effort to reduce excess industrial capacity. The move aims to keep unemployment rates under check, but may lead to a step down in quality of living and reduced spending power. With up to six million coal and steel jobs at risk, the government has allocated 100 billion yuan for relocating and retraining workers, but critics warn that funds may be spread too thin and that many workers will struggle to adapt to new roles, particularly those nearing retirement age.

site_title: Hidden rebates mask true prices of pharmaceutical drugs in the market
summary: Pharmaceutical companies have long claimed that list prices of drugs are fictional, but a study by SSR Health found that the actual prices, including rebates and discounts, have increased significantly for Gleevec, a cancer drug. Despite the introduction of competitors, the study found that price increases, not discounts, drove the growth of Gleevec's sales. The study estimated that the average net price increase was 15% per year, and that the number of units sold remained relatively flat, indicating that price hikes were the primary driver of revenue growth.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: The Singapore Budget
summary: The Singapore Budget 2016, released on March 20, 2016, aims to promote economic growth and stability. The budget allocated $3.8 billion for the healthcare sector, $2.4 billion for education, and $1.7 billion for transportation. The government also announced plans to increase the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate to 7% from 7% to 9% in 2019. The budget aims to boost economic growth and reduce unemployment, while also addressing pressing issues such as healthcare and education. Overall, the budget is expected to have a positive impact on the Singapore economy.

site_title: 1987: Year of market crashes and MRT rollout
summary: In 1987, Singapore experienced a tumultuous year with market crashes, including Black Monday, where global markets plummeted, wiping out billions of dollars. The Straits Times Index fell 12% on Black Monday, and over $15 billion was lost in market capitalization. Just a week later, the first section of the North South Line MRT began operations, transforming the retail landscape with new businesses dominating MRT stations. The year also saw the Singapore bourse breach the 1,300-mark for the first time and the development of trading curbs to mitigate market crashes.

site_title: Obama's historic Cuba trip ends half a century of conflict
summary: US President Barack Obama arrived in Cuba on Sunday, marking the first visit by a sitting US president in nearly 90 years, to bury the hatchet in a half-century-long Cold War conflict. Obama will meet with Cuban President Raul Castro, attend a baseball game, and give a speech on Tuesday, before leaving on Wednesday. The visit has created excitement among Cubans, who are dreaming of escaping isolation and reinvigorating their economy. However, the lifting of the US economic embargo will require Congressional approval, and some have criticized Obama's decision to deal with Castro's Cuba.

site_title: NY's housing authority cooperating in 'very expansive' federal inquiry
summary: The New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) is cooperating with a federal inquiry led by the US Justice Department, which is reviewing tenant health and safety conditions and investigating whether NYCHA submitted false claims for federal funds. The agency has turned over 400 million records, including repair orders and training manuals, and is cooperating fully with the inquiry. The investigation, led by US Attorney Preet Bharara, aims to determine if NYCHA made false claims for addressing health and safety issues in its public housing projects.

site_title: Built on blind faith in Fed's power, market rally may be short-lived
summary: US stocks may continue their record-breaking rally as the Federal Reserve's dovish stance eases pressure on the market. The Fed's willingness to suspend rate hikes has helped boost the dollar, oil prices, and commodities, benefiting miners and steelmakers. However, some warn that the rally is short-lived, citing blind faith in the Fed's power and the ongoing global economic crisis. The Fed's shift from a hawkish to dovish stance is a rare occurrence, and officials have made it clear they won't change direction without compelling reasons.

site_title: Japan's apparel industry in high-tech bid to secure future
summary: Japan's apparel industry is leveraging high-tech technology to reduce labor costs and secure its future. The WholeGarment system, developed by Shima Seiki, enables digitally-programmed automated machines to manufacture garments instantly, cutting labor costs by 90% and generating no waste. The system has attracted nearly 800 companies, including 400 Japanese brands, which now hold a 60% share of the global knitting machine market. This initiative aims to capitalize on Japan's technical expertise to produce garments that cannot be replicated elsewhere at a lower cost.

site_title: Away from Wall St, DIY quants changing financial markets
summary: A growing number of self-taught "DIY quants" are revolutionizing the financial markets with their open-source software and algorithms, challenging traditional industry giants. These individuals, often with little more than an internet connection, are able to compete with top firms by leveraging the democratization of technology. QTS Capital Management, a two-man startup, has successfully returned 12% last year, outperforming the US stock market and the average for hedge funds globally. The DIY crowd is changing the face of financial markets, raising fundamental questions about the industry's future and the role of human judgment in algorithmic trading.

site_title: Epicentre first S'pore-listed firm to use p2p lending
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a Singapore-listed firm, has become the first company to raise at least S$1 million through peer-to-peer lending platform MoolahSense. The debt, backed by a corporate guarantee, is to be repaid within 12 months at an interest rate of 13.5% per annum. The deal, worth S$500,000 each, has attracted 337 investors in 26 hours, with plans to raise up to S$2 million. This move is expected to expand borrowing options for other listed companies in Singapore, with MoolahSense already receiving enquiries from five other companies.

site_title: Will Cuba steal cruise ships from its neighbours?
summary: Cruise lines are preparing to offer itineraries to Cuba, a long-forbidden port of call, as the US re-establishes diplomatic relations with the island. Executives at major cruise lines, such as Royal Caribbean, MSC Cruises, and Norwegian Cruise Line, say Cuba will not divert traffic from other destinations due to port capacity constraints. Instead, Cuba is expected to create a "halo of interest" around the Caribbean, prompting other destinations to improve their offerings and compete for cruise business. The US has authorized individuals to visit Cuba and US banks to handle financial transactions, making it feasible for cruise lines to offer Cuba-based itineraries.

site_title: Apple aims to bolster its line-up with new iPhone, iPad models
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhone and iPad models on Monday, aiming to boost sales and keep momentum in the fast-evolving mobile device market. The new iPhone SE or 5SE is expected to have a 4-inch display, priced lower than its big-screen counterparts, and is seen as a way to encourage replacement of older models. The event also marks a chance for Apple to restate its stance on the US government's demand to break into an attacker's iPhone, as a federal judge in California is set to hear arguments on the issue.

site_title: Slowing economy, job security top concerns for Singaporeans in pre-Budget feedback exercise
summary: Singaporeans' top concerns in the pre-Budget feedback exercise include the slowing economy and job security, with many recognizing the importance of skills upgrading to stay relevant in a changing economy.

site_title: US: Wall street week ahead, eyes on the US dollar with stocks out of the hole
summary: US stock market investors will be watching the US dollar next week, as a weakening dollar and strengthening stock market trends are expected to continue. The Dow and S&P 500 rallied this week, driven by a 3% drop in the US dollar over the last three weeks. The Fed's policy statement cut interest rate hike projections in half, accelerating the dollar's losses and fueling oil price gains. Analysts expect the dollar to continue weakening, driven by inflation, and believe this trend will benefit stocks.

site_title: Up to US$2b loss for generators as US homes get solar panels
summary: US homes set to install over 1 million solar panels by the end of next month, grid managers plan to cut conventional plant purchases by 1,400 megawatts, affecting generators' revenue. This shift could result in a $2 billion loss for generators, as power prices are already low and environmental regulations are tight. The decision may lead to the retirement of conventional power plants, similar to Germany's experience, where renewable energy has reduced power prices and led to plant closures.

site_title: Iran's leaders offer different visions for nation's economy
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and President Hassan Rouhani offered contrasting visions for the nation's economy, with Khamenei emphasizing self-reliance and Rouhani advocating for cooperation with the world. Khamenei's "resistance economy" concept prioritizes Iran's independence, while Rouhani seeks to engage with the global economy to drive growth. The differing views underscore the divide between the two leaders, who have differing ideas on how to engage with Western powers and the global economy.

site_title: Hong Kong's pro-democracy group Scholarism dissolves
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy group Scholarism has dissolved, nearly a year after its protests against the government sparked the city's biggest challenge to Chinese rule since 1997. Scholarism, led by co-founder Joshua Wong, cited the need to change its approach to inter-crossing political and student movements as the reason for its dissolution. Wong plans to form a new political party in April. The group's decision comes after its protests ended due to a loss of public support. Wong expressed hope to still see supporters on the streets in the future.

site_title: After stellar boom, UK housebuilders face tougher progress
summary: UK housebuilders face challenges after a four-year rally, with shares in companies like Berkeley and Barratt Development down 7-14% in 2016. The British property market has been fueled by foreign buyers, but growth in the construction industry is slowing, and concerns over the "Brexit" referendum could further hit demand. Analysts warn that the sector is now overpriced and vulnerable to volatility, with some predicting a harsher approach to weaker performance.

site_title: Corporate debt too high, warns PBOC chief
summary: China's corporate debt has reached 160% of its GDP, prompting a warning from PBOC governor Zhou Xiaochuan. He calls for developing robust capital markets to reduce leverage and boost equity financing. The country must address the issue, which poses a short-term risk, particularly in sectors like cement and steel. China's leaders aim to balance economic growth with debt reduction, with Premier Li Keqiang stating the need for capital-market reforms to address the issue.

site_title: China says economy improving, capital outflows cooling
summary: China's economy is showing signs of improvement, with recent data indicating steady progress despite downward pressure. Capital outflows have cooled, with net foreign exchange sales by the central bank and commercial banks dropping in February. Commerce Minister Gao Hucheng expects a big rebound in foreign trade in March, while Vice-Premier Zhang Gaoli stated that the government will make pre-emptive policy adjustments to maintain economic growth within a reasonable range. China will also press ahead with "supply-side reforms" to address excess industrial overcapacity.

site_title: China property tycoon Wang Jianlin eyes sporting trophy
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, is expanding his business empire by building a global sports conglomerate, mirroring China's economic and political might. His company, Wanda Group, has become a top-level sponsor of FIFA, and he plans to reach an annual turnover of $10 billion in the sports industry. This move is seen as a strategic shift to promote China's "soft power" abroad, and to capitalize on the country's growing interest in sports.

site_title: ECB bond plans liven up corporate debt market
summary: The European Central Bank's plan to buy corporate bonds has boosted the eurozone economy, with companies rushing to issue new debt and borrowing costs falling. A record-breaking 13.25 billion euros in corporate bonds were issued last week, surpassing the previous record set in 2009. The ECB's plan, set to begin mid-year, aims to stimulate the economy and cut risk by offering reassurance in case of economic uncertainty. Analysts expect the plan to spread to other assets and markets, further lowering borrowing costs for companies.

site_title: Hon Hai seeks to reduce price it pays for Sharp: report
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, the Taiwanese parent company of Foxconn, is seeking to reduce the price it pays for Sharp Corp due to concerns about potential liabilities and future earnings. The company is also renegotiating terms with Sharp's lenders, citing a potential 10-20% reduction in its investment in new equity. Sharp's shares closed at 138 yen in Tokyo, up from 118 yen, as the company prepares to report a net loss of 23.9 billion yen in the final three-month period.

site_title: Four horsemen of January apocalypse unsaddled
summary: Markets have rebounded after a four-week winning streak for the S&P 500, with the US economy, EU, and China all showing signs of improvement. The European Central Bank's (ECB) shift in tactics, including negative interest rates, has helped boost corporate bond markets. The ECB's policy aims to help lenders expand and corporates invest, reducing the influence of investment banks. Despite the recent reversals in bear strategies, the market is now characterized as a "risk-off" move, with short-term risk capital being taken off the table. The US economy is expected to surprise to the upside, and the EU banking crisis appears to be averted.

site_title: Global agencies to work on improving availability of debt data
summary: Global debt data is inadequate, with much of emerging economies' debt not logged in official data. Economists warn of the dangers posed by a global build-up of debt, especially in Asia, and a "debt mountain" could be even bigger due to unreported debt. International agencies, including the IMF and World Bank, agreed to cooperate on improving debt data to analyze and policy-making, focusing on corporate borrowers in emerging economies and domestic debt. Experts estimate up to $3.3 trillion in over-borrowing among corporate and bank balance sheets in emerging markets, posing financial stability risks.

site_title: Grief-stricken Germanwings families plan US suit
summary: Families of the 150 victims of Germanwings Flight 9525, which crashed in the French Alps last year, plan to sue Lufthansa's parent company in the US. The families, who have been seeking compensation for years, argue that the airline's decision to allow co-pilot Andreas Lubitz to fly despite his history of depression and suicidal tendencies was negligent. The families are seeking damages, citing the fact that Lubitz had been prescribed antidepressants and had undergone psychotherapy. A class action lawsuit is expected to be filed in the US, where Lufthansa trains its pilots.

site_title: Starwood signs deal to manage hotels in Cuba
summary: US hospitality chain Starwood has signed deals to manage hotels in Cuba, marking the first American company to run hotels on the island in over half a century. Under the agreements, Starwood will refurbish and manage the Hotel Inglaterra in Old Havana and the Hotel Quinta Avenida in Miramar. The deals signal a return of American companies to the Cuban travel market, with potential for other US hotel chains to follow, including Marriott International. The move comes as the US and Cuba strengthen ties, with increased flights and travel regulations.

images.alt_text: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is set to become the first American hospitality chain to run hotels in Cuba in more than half a century, signalling the return of American companies to the Cuban travel market as the island gears up to receive a surge in visits from the United States.

site_title: Russian passenger jet crashes with 55 people on board: CNN
summary: A Boeing 738 passenger jet, Flydubai Flight 981, crashed while landing at Rostov-on-Don airport in southern Russia, killing all 55 people on board. The incident occurred on March 19, 2016.

site_title: Raw sugar hits over one-year high, arabica coffee ends week up 7%
summary: Raw sugar futures reached a one-year high, closing down 0.1% at 15.97 cents per pound, after a fourth consecutive weekly gain. Arabica coffee rose 7% to a five-month peak at $1.343 per pound, driven by technical strength and currency gyrations. Cocoa futures also advanced amid supply concerns, with ICE May cocoa settling up 0.06% at $3,118 per tonne. The gains were attributed to bullish sentiment and supply worries, particularly in Brazil and West Africa.

site_title: China's central bank chief warns about rising debt
summary: China's central bank Governor Zhou Xiaochuan warned of rising debt levels, citing a high corporate lending ratio of 160% of GDP as a risk to the economy. He called for more robust capital markets and regulation to address excessive leverage in foreign currencies. The warning comes as Chinese leaders struggle to balance economic growth with debt reduction, with Premier Li Keqiang stating that high corporate debt is a challenge that needs to be addressed. The issue is considered a short-term risk by OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria.

site_title: Hackers stalked Bangladesh bank for two weeks before big heist
summary: Hackers targeted Bangladesh's central bank for nearly two weeks before stealing $101 million, using malware to make payments appear genuine. The sophisticated group, believed to be financially motivated and organized, deleted logs and inserted software to re-enter the network. The heist exposed weaknesses in systems, led to the central bank governor's resignation, and sparked a dispute between the central bank and its finance ministry. The investigation, led by cyber security firms FireEye and World Informatix, found 32 compromised assets used for reconnaissance and control of SWIFT servers.

site_title: Rosberg wins Australian Grand Prix
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Australian Grand Prix, his 14th career victory and fourth consecutive win. Ferrari's Fernando Alonso suffered a spectacular crash, severely damaging his McLaren. Rosberg's teammate Lewis Hamilton finished second, eight seconds behind, after recovering from a chaotic start. This victory marks Rosberg's fourth in succession, following his wins in the final three races of last season.

site_title: RHT sees growth drivers in India
summary: Religare Health Trust (RHT) sees growth opportunities in India's nascent healthcare sector, driven by a supply-demand gap for speciality hospitals, rising lifestyle diseases, and emerging medical tourism. The private sector, including RHT, which owns 12 hospitals, is expected to fill this gap. The Indian government's support for private and foreign participation in healthcare, as well as its efforts to tackle the shortage of drugs in rural areas, are seen as positive indicators. RHT plans to add 550 beds in the next two to three years, with a total capacity of 5,500 beds.

site_title: Investigators probe south Russia flydubai crash that killed 62
summary: A flydubai passenger jet crashed in southern Russia on Saturday, killing all 62 people on board. The Boeing 737 exploded into a fireball after missing the runway in bad weather during its second attempt to land. Investigators are probing pilot error, technical fault, or poor weather as causes, with a criminal probe launched. The two black boxes have been transported to Moscow for examination, and authorities are starting to identify human remains using DNA samples. The airport has been closed, but is expected to reopen on Monday.

site_title: What China's leaders can learn from US post-Civil War surge
summary: China's leaders are drawing parallels between their country's economic shift from super-charged growth to a more moderate pace and the US post-Civil War era. Both experienced rapid economic transformation, massive infrastructure projects, and population migration to cities, leading to soaring living standards. China's communist leaders have managed to avoid the sharp peaks and troughs of the US Gilded Age, Roaring Twenties, and Great Depression. However, China's economy remains decades behind the US on many metrics, and policymakers are planning to transition to domestic demand, private entrepreneurship, and consumption to achieve a "moderately prosperous society."

site_title: Developers sanguine about selling out before ABSD deadlines
summary: Singapore developers are confident of selling out their projects before the respective deadlines for additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) remission, without needing to resort to massive price cuts. As of February, 61 unsold units at Mon Jervois, 94 units at Pollen & Bleu, and 173 units at Alex Residences are at risk of incurring a 10% ABSD with interest. Developers like SingLand and City Developments Ltd are prioritizing quick completion of projects to meet ABSD conditions, with some adopting strategies such as setting up subsidiaries or funds to buy unsold units.

site_title: Bangladesh bank heist exposes Philippine dirty money secrets
summary: The Philippines has been exposed as a haven for dirty money, following a cyber-heist that stole $81 million from Bangladesh's foreign reserves. The stolen funds were immediately laundered through the Philippines' RCBC bank, with the thieves targeting the country's lax anti-money laundering laws. RCBC bank manager Maia Deguito is under scrutiny for her role in moving the money, but denies any wrongdoing, while bank president Lorenzo Tan has denied ordering her to do so. The investigation has uncovered a complex web of transactions involving casinos and shady business figures, with some accusing Deguito of being a scapegoat for a larger operation.

site_title: China central bank vice head says Tobin tax still at research stage
summary: China's central bank vice head Yi Gang said the Tobin tax, a currency speculation tax, is still in the research stage. The tax, proposed by James Tobin in 1972, aims to curb speculation in foreign exchange markets.
