Despite a recent easing of capital outflows, analysts believe China still faces a tough job stemming the flows, which have been fueled by concerns about the country's economic slowdown and expectations of higher US interest rates. Yi's comments dampened expectations of an imminent policy step on the Tobin tax.

site_title: Update: 62 killed as flydubai jet crashes in southern Russia
summary: A flydubai Boeing 737 crashed and burst into flames while landing in Rostov-on-Don, Southern Russia, killing all 62 people on board. The plane, carrying 55 passengers and 7 crew members, missed the runway due to bad weather and crashed, scattering debris over a wide area. The cause of the crash is being investigated, with possible pilot error among the factors being examined. A criminal investigation has been launched, and flydubai has expressed condolences to the families of the victims.

site_title: British minister resigns over disability cuts plan
summary: British welfare minister Iain Duncan Smith resigned over planned reductions in welfare payments for people with disabilities, citing them as a "compromise too far." He blamed finance minister George Osborne for the plan, which aims to cut £1.3 billion annually from Personal Independence Payments. The move highlights growing divisions within the Conservative Party ahead of the EU membership referendum. Prime Minister David Cameron's campaign for Britain to stay in the EU faces further challenges as the party's MPs debate the issue.

site_title: Hong Kong student leader to set up political party
summary: Hong Kong student leader Joshua Wong, 19, announced the formation of a new political party to contest legislative elections in September. Wong, a key figure in the 2014 pro-democracy movement, aims to promote "self-determination" for Hong Kong residents. The party's establishment comes amid rising concerns over Beijing's influence and erosion of freedoms. Wong, who cannot stand for election until he is 21, disbands his student activist group Scholarism to pursue the new party, which seeks to push for greater autonomy and potentially even independence from China.

site_title: Hon Hai, banks agree on Sharp credit line to close deal: Yomiuri
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co has reached a basic agreement with Sharp Corp's banks over a 300 billion yen (S$3.7 billion) credit line, potentially clearing a hurdle toward a takeover of the Japanese electronics maker. Under the agreement, Sharp can borrow from main banks if it suffers losses or needs new investments. The banks are also considering waiting for about a month on Sharp's repayment of 510 billion yen in loans if talks with Hon Hai are prolonged. The deal could move forward with the agreement.

site_title: Anti-Trump protesters rally in New York, block Arizona road
summary: Hundreds of anti-Trump protesters in New York and Arizona held rallies and blocked roads, with several people arrested, in an attempt to disrupt the Republican presidential hopeful's campaign. Demonstrators chanted slogans and held up signs criticizing Trump's rhetoric on issues like racism, sexism, and immigration. In Arizona, protesters blocked a major road, but Trump attended his rally despite the disruption. The incidents are part of a growing trend of demonstrations and violence surrounding Trump's campaign, with critics citing his inflammatory rhetoric as a major factor.

site_title: Obama due in Cuba, ending half a century of conflict
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to visit Cuba for a three-day trip, marking the first visit by a sitting US president since 1929. The trip reverses decades of US attempts to isolate the communist island, following the end of the Cold War conflict. Obama will be accompanied by his family, including First Lady Michelle Obama and daughters. The visit aims to bury the hatchet and improve relations between the two nations, ending a half-century-long conflict.

site_title: Indonesia submits bid for seat in ICAO council
summary: Indonesia has submitted its nomination to join the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) council, aiming to gain a voice in international aviation matters. The country has previously failed four times to secure a seat, but former minister Indroyono Soesilo is optimistic about this time due to improved aviation management. Indonesia needs at least 125 votes to secure a seat, with the next election set for September 2016.

site_title: China says economy still under pressure, but recent data shows improvement
summary: China's economy still faces downward pressure, but recent data indicates some improvement in activity, according to Vice Premier Zhang Gaoli. The country's manufacturing output in January and February grew at its weakest pace since 2008. The government will make preemptive policy adjustments to maintain economic growth within a reasonable range, focusing on "supply-side reforms" to cut excess industrial overcapacity. China's growth target for 2016 remains at 6.5-7%, and Finance Minister Lou Jiwei downplays the impact of Moody's recent downgrade of China's government debt outlook to "negative".

site_title: China shifts axed miners to lower-paid jobs in farming, cleaning
summary: China is shifting laid-off coal and steel miners to lower-paid jobs in farming, forestry, and public services amid a major restructuring of the economy. The government has earmarked 100 billion yuan (US$15 billion) for relocation and retraining, but with up to 6 million jobs to be axed, funds may be spread thin. The move risks creating a cohort of middle-aged workers with bleak prospects, as slower economic growth makes it harder to absorb redundant workers, and many are likely to find themselves demoted or earn less.

site_title: Brazil supreme court judge suspends Lula appointment
summary: Brazilian Supreme Court judge Gilmar Mendes suspended ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's appointment as presidential chief of staff, citing a potential act of fraud against the constitution. The decision sent the corruption case against Lula back to judge Sergio Moro, who led the investigation into a multi-billion-dollar corruption scandal at state oil giant Petrobras. The move comes after a leaked phone call between President Dilma Rousseff and Lula, suggesting the appointment was aimed at saving him from arrest. The decision blocks Lula's appointment and raises concerns about the legitimacy of Rousseff's cabinet.

site_title: JPMorgan may add China government bonds to emerging-market index
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is reviewing China's onshore government bond market for inclusion in its emerging-market bond indexes, a move that could bring in billions of dollars of foreign capital and help stabilize the country's flagging currency. The review comes as China seeks to stem the yuan's losses and finance stimulus, with foreign investors having left the country's debt market at a record pace this year. If accepted, China's onshore debt would have a maximum index weight of 10% of JPMorgan's GBI-EM Global Diversified index, tracking $180 billion in assets.

site_title: Execs pay top dollar for audience with China's leaders
summary: China's top executives and academics gather at the China Development Forum in Beijing, a pay-to-play event offering audiences with China's top leadership. CEOs from companies like Facebook and Rio Tinto make "donations" ranging from 1 million yuan (S$211,000) to participate. The event promises exclusive access to China's elite, including top leaders. The invitation-only summit is seen as a lucrative opportunity for those willing to pay the high fee, raising questions about the influence of money in Chinese politics.

site_title: Japan to mull front-loading public works spending: sources
summary: Japan's government is considering front-loading public works spending to support an economy on the brink of recession. Premier Shinzo Abe plans to allocate about 10 trillion yen for public works projects in the 2016/17 year, as part of his efforts to reignite stagnant growth. The government's budget, valued at 96.7 trillion yen, will be approved by parliament by the end of March. Abe will make a decision on additional fiscal stimulus measures by late May, when he hosts the G7 summit.

site_title: Amazon takes nearly 10% stake in Air Transport Services Group
summary: Amazon has acquired a 9.99% stake in Air Transport Services Group (ATSG) for $9.73 per share. The deal allows Amazon to lease 20 Boeing 767 freighter aircraft from ATSG to handle US deliveries. Amazon has the right to buy up to 19.9% of ATSG's stock over five years. The stake was acquired as of March 8, before the publicly announced deal.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc has taken a 9.99 per cent stake in Air Transport Services Group Inc, the company from which it will be leasing freighter aircraft.

site_title: Microsoft apologizes for GDC party with skimpily-clad dancers
summary: Microsoft apologized for hiring dancers dressed as skimpily-clad schoolgirls for its Game Developer Conference (GDC) afterparty in San Francisco, saying it was "absolutely not consistent or aligned to our values." Phil Spencer, head of Xbox, stated the incident was "unequivocally wrong" and will not be tolerated. The move comes amid scrutiny over diversity and compensation equity issues in the tech industry, with Microsoft hosting a "Women in Gaming" luncheon earlier that day. The company will deal with the matter internally.

site_title: Founder of Japan's first US$1b startup travelled round the world
summary: Shintaro Yamada, 38, co-founded Mercari Inc, Japan's first US$1 billion startup, after a six-month, 23-country trip that broadened his mind and fueled his desire to create a platform connecting people worldwide. He teamed up with fellow Waseda University alumni to establish Mercari in 2013, which has since raised 8.4 billion yen from investors and reached a valuation of over US$1 billion. Yamada aims to boost Mercari's presence in the US market, where it has been downloaded 7 million times, and eventually become a global company.

images.alt_text: Mr Yamada wanted to start a company that would let people in different countries connect with each other. He set up Mercari in 2013.

site_title: Argentina secures US$3.5b in new financing from World Bank
summary: Argentina secured US$3.5 billion in new financing from the World Bank over two years to fund water, health, and housing projects, as well as a child welfare program. This financing, in addition to an impending US$2.8 billion disbursement, will help the center-right government of Mauricio Macri rebuild Argentina's low foreign currency reserves. The move is seen as a welcome boost for the government.

site_title: Apple hires corporate security officer amid legal battle with government: sources
summary: Apple has hired George Stathakopoulos, a former Amazon and Microsoft executive, as its new vice president of corporate information security. Stathakopoulos will oversee Apple's digital defenses and protect corporate assets, such as customer data and product designs. The move comes amid a high-profile legal battle with the US government over law enforcement's desire to crack into iPhones. Stathakopoulos reports to Apple's CFO and will work to strengthen the company's security measures against hackers and other malicious threats.

site_title: Business executive sentenced to 5 years in Navy bribery scandal
summary: A Singaporean business executive, Alex Wisidagama, was sentenced to 5 years and 3 months in prison and ordered to pay $35 million in restitution for his role in a US Navy bribery scandal. Wisidagama, who worked for Glenn Defense Marine Asia, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to submit false bills to the Navy. The scandal involved bribing Navy officers with cash, prostitutes, and luxury travel, and resulted in the censure of three retired admirals and multiple Navy officers. His cousin, Leonard Glenn Francis, remains in custody and is cooperating with prosecutors.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde: Negative rates benefit global economy
summary: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde stated that negative interest rates set by central banks in Japan and Europe have supported stronger global economic growth. If these rates hadn't been implemented, the global economy would likely be in a worse state, with lower inflation and growth. Lagarde attributed this to the unorthodox short-term rates, where commercial banks pay central banks to hold their money, which helped stabilize the economy.

site_title: Spotify agreement a 'win' for artists, company: Billboard editor
summary: Spotify has reached an agreement with the National Music Publishers Association, a "win" for songwriters and the music streaming service. The deal will allow independent and major publishers to receive royalties for songs on Spotify where ownership information is unknown. The settlement, worth around $30 million, will benefit both parties, ending lawsuits and disputes. This follows a series of musician-led lawsuits against Spotify, including those by David Lowery and Taylor Swift.

site_title: Oil prices dip at end of strong week
summary: World oil prices closed a strong week slightly lower, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 76 US cents to $39.44 a barrel. The rally was driven by optimism for a production freeze by major producers, but profit taking took hold, leading to a decline. Brent North Sea crude finished at $41.20 a barrel, also dipping from Thursday's settlement. The drop was attributed to market concerns over the outlook and potential tariffs and sanctions.

site_title: US wrestler Hulk Hogan wins US$115m in suit against Gawker
summary: A Florida jury awarded Hulk Hogan $115 million in damages after finding Gawker's publication of a sex tape violated his privacy. The jury awarded $60 million for emotional distress and $55 million for economic damages. Hogan's attorney said the verdict was a victory for those whose privacy was violated. Gawker publisher Nick Denton plans to appeal the verdict, stating the company expects to win the case ultimately.

site_title: US: Stocks rise again on Fed, S&P 500 positive for 2016
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive session, driven by the Federal Reserve's lowered interest rate hike projections. The S&P 500 rose 8.99 points to 2,049.58, lifting it into positive territory for the year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the tech-rich Nasdaq rising 20.66 points. Analysts attributed the rally to global growth concerns and the Fed's decision. Despite some sector gains, stocks remain "essentially flat for the year" according to Wedbush Securities.

site_title: Consumers need help navigating health insurance thicket
summary: Singapore's health insurance market is complex, with many consumers unaware of what their plans cover. A new uniform B1 health insurance plan aims to simplify benefits, with five insurers offering similar coverage at varying premiums. To improve understanding, a dedicated website summarizing policy points in simple English is needed. Additionally, encouraging cash co-payments for Integrated Shield Plan premiums can help consumers build up their Medisave balances, which can earn higher interest rates. Rewards for no-claims could also incentivize healthy lifestyles.

site_title: US dollar edges higher after sharp losses
summary: The US dollar edged higher against major currencies on Friday, reversing two days of losses, following the Federal Reserve's pullback on rate hike expectations. The dollar rose to 1.1270 euros and 111.55 yen, while the British pound remained steady. European Central Bank chief economist Peter Praet hinted at further rate cuts if the economic outlook worsens. Analysts expect the dollar to rebound as central bank policies diverge, with the Fed still likely to raise rates at least twice this year.

site_title: Lufthansa reports near miss with drone over Los Angeles
summary: A Lufthansa Airbus A380 reported a near-miss with a drone while landing at Los Angeles International Airport on Friday. The drone, flying at 5,000 feet, passed within 200 feet of the plane, but no evasive action was taken. The incident occurred 14 miles east of the airport, and the plane landed safely minutes later. The FAA has received 42 reports of drones flying unsafely near LAX since 2014, and has issued a rule requiring drone hobbyists to register their aircraft online.

site_title: Gold declines as equity advances curb demand for haven assets
summary: Gold futures declined for a fifth consecutive session, losing 0.8% as stocks surged, reducing demand for the metal as a haven. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index reached its highest level since January, erasing losses from the worst start to a year. Despite being the best-performing raw material on the Bloomberg Commodity Index, gold's 18% gain this year was trimmed to 17.2% after a second consecutive weekly decline.

site_title: Ong & Ong extends S$100k funding to Nanyang Poly's school of design
summary: Architecture firm Ong & Ong Group has extended S$100,000 in funding support to Nanyang Polytechnic's School of Design over five years. The agreement aims to empower students to bring their design ideas to life by constructing prototypes of their projects. Up to two projects will be chosen annually, with the prototypes fully constructed to help students bring their designs to the market. The firm believes this collaboration will enable good design ideas to positively impact society.

site_title: Memtech eyes car industry for growth
summary: Memtech International, a Singaporean electronics components maker, aims to increase its revenue share from the car industry to 50% by 2017. The company has added Tesla and Faurecia, a car parts producer, as clients, bringing its car industry revenue to 40% currently. This move is part of Memtech's strategy to diversify its business and tap into the growing car industry.

site_title: Morgan the elephant's Somalian saga gets researchers all excited
summary: A rare sighting of a wild elephant has been reported in Somalia, with researchers detecting a small elephant population surviving in the war-torn country. Morgan, a bull elephant, crossed into Somalia from Kenya, likely in search of a mate, and was fitted with a GPS tracking collar. The 209km journey demonstrates exceptional direction and self-preservation skills, allowing him to evade humans. This finding offers a rare glimmer of hope in the fight against elephant poaching, which has led to the decline of elephant populations in Africa.

site_title: ST Engg unit makes cash injection to add to fleet
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm, ST Aerospace Resources, has injected US$5.8 million into Keystone Holdings (Global) to add an Airbus 321 to its aircraft leasing portfolio. This brings its total share capital contribution in Keystone to almost US$19 million. The move reaffirms the group's confidence in the aircraft leasing business, following a similar US$8.1 million injection in December last year for a Boeing 737NG.

site_title: China home prices soar in Feb
summary: China's home prices rose 3.6% in February, the fastest clip in almost two years, driven by demand in big cities. However, this surge poses risks of overheating in some areas, particularly smaller cities with a supply glut, threatening the slowing economy. The divergence in home prices highlights the challenges for policymakers, who must balance stimulus measures with preventing asset bubbles.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by rise in auto stocks
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by a 1.1% gain in the automobile index, with Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot climbing 2.7% and 1% respectively. The euro's decline against the US dollar also contributed to the gains. However, energy stocks fell as crude oil prices dropped. The FTSEurofirst 300 index remains down 7% for the year, despite its first weekly gain in four weeks.

site_title: Research into cold energy from LNG among beneficiaries of S$27m govt grants
summary: Singapore awards S$27 million in research grants to 13 projects, including two that focus on harnessing cold energy from liquefied natural gas (LNG) for seawater desalination. The projects aim to improve energy efficiency and reliability of the electricity and gas systems. The grants are part of the government's efforts to catalyze innovations in the energy sector and make use of the cold energy released during LNG regasification.

site_title: A taste of Sushi Saito in KL
summary: Chef Takashi Saito's maiden sushi restaurant outside Tokyo, Taka by Sushi Saito, is set to open in Kuala Lumpur in April with an estimated average dining cost of RM1,000 per head. The restaurant, located in the six-star St Regis Kuala Lumpur, will feature traditional finishes and rare hinoki wood counter, with ingredients flown in from Japan. With only eight seats, reservations are expected to be difficult to come by, with fans waiting up to 4-6 months for a spot. Saito is confident of robust demand from both local and international sushi enthusiasts, with his partners predicting a strong turnout.

site_title: ETFs, index funds lowering costs of mutual funds
summary: ETFs and index funds are lowering the cost of mutual funds, with the average expense ratio for equity funds dropping to 0.68 percentage points, the lowest since 1996. This trend is driven by the growing popularity of ETFs, which has increased assets in equity index funds by $109 billion in 2015 and reduced assets in actively managed funds by $275 billion. The competition between active and passive investing, as well as ETFs competing with mutual funds, has driven down costs, according to the Investment Company Institute.

site_title: Bullard says Fed's goals largely met, rates should edge up
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard stated that the central bank's inflation and employment goals have been largely met, suggesting it would be "prudent" to edge interest rates higher. Bullard's comments follow the Fed's decision to keep rates steady at its recent meeting. He emphasized the need to normalize policy rates and balance sheet levels, citing concerns about a drop in inflation expectations.

site_title: Big banks need tougher audits: US regulator
summary: US banking regulators should conduct deeper audits of large banks, rather than relying on stress tests, to ensure the financial system's long-term resilience. Vice Chair Thomas Hoenig of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. proposed "full-scope" exams that would involve a team of regulators reviewing a bank's entire balance sheet and management competence. This approach would help uncover potential problems, such as bad mortgages, that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis. Hoenig also suggested that regulators should rotate examiners and develop a more objective perspective to identify potential disasters.

images.alt_text: US banking supvervisors should beef up their oversight of large banks beyond stress tests with deep-dive audits and greater use of outside examiners, a top regulator said Friday.

site_title: Europe's most wanted held in Brussels for Paris attacks
summary: Salah Abdeslam, Europe's most wanted man, was captured in a shootout in Brussels, Belgium, following the November 2015 Paris attacks that killed 130 people. Abdeslam, 26, was wounded and being held in hospital with a leg wound. His elder brother, Brahim, had blown himself up in Paris. Abdeslam's fingerprints and passports were found in a bloody raid, leading to the operation. French President Francois Hollande confirmed France will seek extradition for Abdeslam, who is believed to have planned the Paris attacks. Security concerns remain, with the threat level high, and investigators will seek information on Islamic State plans and structures.

images.alt_text: Europe's most wanted man was captured after a shootout in Brussels in a major coup for authorities investigating November's Islamic State attacks on Paris.

site_title: Spotify reaches deal to improve royalty payments to US publishers
summary: Spotify has reached a settlement with the National Music Publishers' Association to improve royalty payments to US music publishers. The company will add a compensation fund to an existing pool of $16 million to pay for unmatched royalties, totaling $21 million. A database will be built to match streamed songs to their writers more consistently, and individual publishers can choose to participate in the deal or back lawsuits. The agreement aims to address issues with identifying songwriters for obscure or older songs and to provide more accurate payment of royalties.

site_title: Did G-20 meeting lead to a secret Shanghai Accord?
summary: A suspected "Shanghai Accord" may have led to coordinated actions by global policymakers to calm currency markets and stabilize the US dollar. The agreement, similar to the Plaza Accord in 1985, aims to prevent a stronger dollar from negatively impacting the global economy. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank, and the Bank of Japan, have taken steps to stabilize the dollar, which has resulted in a decline in the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index. Analysts, however, are skeptical, citing other reasons for the central banks' actions, such as economic concerns and policy goals.

site_title: Intimate boost
summary: Non-invasive treatments are gaining popularity for under-the-radar body parts, such as the feet and genital areas. Vaginal rejuvenation treatments, like Viveve, are being used to tighten and improve the external appearance of the labia, while also increasing lubrication during intercourse. Areola reconstruction using micro-pigmentation is also becoming more common, particularly for mastectomy patients. Meanwhile, shockwave therapy is being used to treat bunions, reducing inflammation and promoting soft tissue healing. These treatments aim to improve both appearance and function, giving individuals a more confident and youthful look.

site_title: Sending e-mail contributes to climate change
summary: Sending e-mail contributes to climate change by emitting greenhouse gases from running computers, servers, and routers. A single e-mail can add 4 grams of CO2-equivalent to the atmosphere, while 5 dozen e-mails in a day are equivalent to driving an average-size car one kilometer. In France, digital technologies account for over 10% of total electricity use. To reduce carbon footprint, e-mail tips include avoiding unnecessary recipients, slimming attachments, and emptying trash boxes.

site_title: Gold miners still a bargain compared to past peaks
summary: Gold mining companies, such as Barrick Gold and Goldcorp, have seen their shares surge 87% in the past three months, outpacing the gold price rally. Despite this, they remain 19% cheaper than their peak valuation based on gold reserves. The companies' production costs have decreased by a quarter since 2012, and their average all-in sustaining cash cost is now $936.20 per ounce. Analysts believe the rally is driven by central banks' switch to negative interest rates and the Federal Reserve's expected rate hike.

site_title: Ferrari functionality
summary: The Ferrari 488 GTB, unveiled in 2009, has been upgraded with a turbocharged 3.9-litre V8 engine, producing 670 hp and 760 Nm, while maintaining refinement and comfort. The 7-speed dual-clutch transmission and SSC2 system enhance performance, with improved grip and stability. The car offers five driving modes and a dry weight of 1,370 kg, making it both user-friendly and capable of wild performance.

site_title: Australia ups scrutiny on infrastructure sales to foreigners
summary: Australia has introduced new rules requiring a formal review of the sale of critical infrastructure to private foreign investors, effective March 31. The rules apply to assets such as airports, ports, and public transport infrastructure, and will ensure that any potential national security risks can be addressed. The move comes after criticism of a 2015 deal involving a Chinese company, and is part of a broader effort to scrutinize foreign investment in the country. The new rules aim to balance foreign investment with national security concerns.

site_title: PSA Int'l 2015 profit falls as container volume dips
summary: PSA International posted a net profit of S$1.268 billion for FY15, down 9.5% from FY14. Container handling volume declined 8.7% year-on-year due to softening global trade and shipping demand. Revenue fell 6.7% to S$3.573 billion, with 64.1 million TEUs handled, 2% lower than the previous year. Despite a strong balance sheet, the port operator attributed the decline to the global economic landscape and challenges faced by the container shipping industry.

site_title: STI moves into positive territory for 2016
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed in positive territory for 2016, jumping 26.63 points to 2,906.8, driven by large-scale central bank intervention and a Wall Street rally. The index gained 78 points for the week, up 2.8%, and is now 0.8% higher for the year to date. The US Federal Reserve's dovish stance, suggesting only two rate hikes this year, contributed to the market's optimism. Banks and oil-related stocks led the gains, with some second liners experiencing isolated interest.

site_title: High design prefab collectibles
summary: Robbie Antonio's Revolution collection offers pre-crafted, limited-edition homes and pavilions designed by over 30 architects and artists, including Pritzker Prize winners Zaha Hadid and Kengo Kuma. The collection, launched at Design Miami 2015, aims to democratize high-design architecture and make it accessible to a wider audience. Pavilions start at $35,000, while homes range from $100,000 to $300,000. Each design is individually branded by its creator and can be customized to suit clients' needs and budgets.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded OSIM International to "Hold" with a target price of S$1.38. The research notes that the Federal Reserve's independence has been tested but is unlikely to lead to a pivot, maintaining a cautious outlook for the market. The research also highlights the growing importance of dollar asset diversification in Asia, driven by the region's economic growth.

site_title: EU chamber urges China to open markets to reach goals
summary: The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China urged China to open its markets to foreign business and implement overdue reforms to achieve its economic goals. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang aims to maintain 6.5% annual economic growth over the next five years. The EU Chamber emphasized that a genuine market opening based on customer demands, rather than policy planning, is crucial for innovation and success. The chamber also called for stronger protection of intellectual property rights and trade secrets.

site_title: Singapore sets out new anti-terror measures to fight rising threat
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam announced new anti-terror measures to counter the growing threat posed by the Islamic State (Isis) militant group, describing it as a "large powerful monster" with a significant increase in attacks globally. The government plans to boost security measures, including expanding CCTV coverage, installing security cameras in public areas, and introducing new legislation for building owners and event organizers. A new national movement called SG Secure will also be rolled out, aiming to unite Singaporeans and encourage community participation in preventing terrorism.

site_title: Twitter an awkward child as it turns 10
summary: Twitter is turning 10, marking its decade-long journey as a powerful communication tool. Despite becoming a must-have for journalists, activists, and celebrities, the platform struggles to expand beyond its devoted user base, known as "twitterati," to become a mainstream hit. As the company marks its milestone birthday, it faces the challenge of winning new users and achieving profitability.

images.alt_text: FLUTTERING: While Internet lovers might have trouble envisioning life without Twitter, the San Francisco-based company has seen its stock tank, a chief executive leave, and its staff cut in recent times.

site_title: Turning up the heat
summary: Six eateries are launching new concepts and menus amid fierce competition in the cafe business scene. Miss Lok, a hotpot supper joint, offers Malaysian street food and steamboat options, while Mon Bijou, a cafe from Millenium Hotels and Resorts, serves upscale bistro mains. Kraftwich by Swissbake tests new panini-styled sandwiches, Spruce refocuses on lunch and dinner with Italian-inspired dishes, Punch offers unique Asian-fusion options, and The Populus: Coffee & Food Co serves brunch and coffee. These new concepts aim to stand out in the competitive cafe market.

site_title: Spice trader's District 15 bungalow put up for auction
summary: A freehold District 15 bungalow in Singapore's Tanjong Katong area is up for auction as a mortgagee sale. The property, located at 85 Branksome Road, has an indicative price of S$16 million (S$1,213 per square foot) and is owned by Kirpa Ram Sharma, the former managing director of Pars Ram Brothers, a spice and nut trader. The potential buyer may be able to subdivide the plot for redevelopment.

site_title: Chinese developer Greenland's default risk rises
summary: Chinese developer Greenland Holdings Corp's default risk has risen due to widening yield spreads on its US$600 million bonds. The 5.875% 2024 notes now have a 404 basis point yield spread over US Treasuries, indicating a higher risk of default. According to the Bloomberg Default Risk model, there is a 6.89% probability that Greenland will miss debt payments within the next 12 months.

site_title: Cross-border money laundering puts Philippine system at risk
summary: The Philippines' financial system faces a risk due to a US$81 million heist by hackers from the New York Fed account, which was then transferred to a Manila bank and laundered through local entities. The stolen funds were laundered through a casino junket operator and two casino companies. The country's central bank governor, Amando Tetangco, vows to address loopholes in local laws to prevent such cases, and extend the anti-money laundering law to more entities, including casinos and real estate dealers. This is considered the first case of cross-border money laundering in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: NOT ON HIS WATCH: Mr Tetangco has vowed to address loopholes in local laws to prevent a recurrence of cross-border money laundering cases.

site_title: Ascott targets 2,000 units under new Tujia Somerset brand by the end of 2016
summary: Ascott Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of CapitaLand, aims to have 2,000 units under its Tujia Somerset brand by the end of 2016. The new brand, in partnership with Tujia.com International, will cater to middle-class travelers in China. Six serviced residences, operated by Ascott, will be launched under the brand, adding 1,005 units to its portfolio in China. The goal is to achieve 20,000 units in China and 80,000 globally by 2020, with a seamless Offline-to-Online and Online-to-Offline experience.

site_title: A touch of French flair
summary: Chef Joannes Riviere, owner of Siem Reap's Cuisine Wat Damnak, combines French techniques with Cambodian flavors in his cuisine. The restaurant, ranked No 43 in Asia's 50 Best Restaurants, changes its menu on Tuesdays, when chef Riviere and his team prepare new dishes. Riviere, who learned Cambodian recipes from his students and housekeeper, describes his cuisine as "Cambodian with a touch of French sensitivity." He incorporates local ingredients, such as prahok and palm sugar, into his dishes, and his kitchen is mostly helmed by locals.

site_title: EVA investors fret as airline ousts chairman
summary: EVA Airways' chairman, Chang Kuo-wei, was ousted by his three older brothers in a board meeting on March 11, amid a family dispute over control of shipping giant Evergreen Group. The move has raised concerns among investors, who fear the airline may abandon its long-haul expansion plans and record new jet orders. With Chang Kuo-wei taking a "rest" at an undisclosed location, investors are seeking reassurance from the new chairman, Steve Lin, and the Chang family.

site_title: The coal loophole in sanctions on N Korea
summary: China continues to allow coal imports from North Korea, despite UN sanctions, which is crucial to the North Korean economy. The UN resolution bans imports of coal, iron, and iron ore unless for "livelihood purposes," leaving a loophole for China to continue trade. China has barred some North Korean vessels and blacklisted others, but enforcement is inconsistent. Analysts say this loophole is significant, as coal is a major source of hard currency for North Korea, and China's help is essential in enforcing sanctions.

site_title: Yanlord acquires two land parcels in Tianjin
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired two land parcels in Tianjin, China, for approximately 1.97 billion yuan (S$412.3 million). The sites have a total gross floor area of 262,100 square meters and will be developed into high-quality residential apartments, townhouses, and villas. This is Yanlord's fourth project in Tianjin and aims to expand its footprint in the Bohai Rim region, driven by Tianjin's rapid development.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group shares traded at a high of S$0.143 before closing unchanged at S$0.134, with over 190 million shares changing hands. The company attributed the unusual volume to its consideration of restructuring loss-making businesses and preliminary discussions with a Chinese strategic investor. United Engineers Ltd saw its shares jump 13% to S$2.52, their highest in about eight months, after a brief price increase. Meanwhile, SBI Offshore CEO Tan Woo Thian resigned, citing a need to facilitate the group's new business strategies following diversification into renewable energy.

site_title: Star trekking in Japan
summary: A Michelin-starred French restaurant in Osaka may not match its Tokyo counterpart, but both offer unique dining experiences. Sushiyoshi, a two-star restaurant in Osaka, boasts a pure sushi experience, while Koryu, also two-starred, serves a more traditional Japanese meal with a lower price tag. In contrast, Sushiya in Tokyo, without a Michelin star, has gained strong word-of-mouth due to its chef-owner, Takao Ishiyama, who has cut his teeth working for renowned sushi chefs. Despite initial reservations, Sushiya has improved, offering dependable and Michelin-star quality sushi.

site_title: Atlantic City's former airport up for sale on the cheap
summary: Atlantic City is selling its century-old former airport, Bader Field, for a minimum bid of $155 million. The city council approved the sale, citing a need to cut debt service costs and stave off a bond default or bankruptcy. The airport, which has been vacant since 2008, could have fetched up to $1.5 billion from competing casinos, but the city previously passed on a $800 million offer. The sale would reduce the city's debt by $20 million annually and demonstrate that there are no "sacred cows" in Atlantic City.

site_title: Hotel with a cherry blossom view
summary: The Imperial Hotel Osaka offers a unique cherry blossom viewing experience without the crowds, with 4,000-5,000 trees along the Okawa River in front of the hotel. Guests can enjoy the blossoms from the comfort of their rooms or visit nearby Kema Sakuranomiya Park and Osaka Castle. The hotel's old-world charm and international appeal make it an ideal choice for those seeking a sophisticated and culturally immersive experience in Osaka. A shuttle bus connects the hotel to Osaka Station, providing easy access to shopping centers.

site_title: Baring PE Asia offer for Interplex goes unconditional
summary: Baring Private Equity Asia has made its offer for precision engineering firm Interplex Holdings unconditional, with a bid of S$450 million and a price of S$0.82 per share. The fund now controls 65.73% of Interplex, aiming to take the company private if it reaches 75% or more control. The offer is part of a growing trend of delisting bids in recent months, including OSIM and Singapore Airlines' successful privatization of Tiger Airways.

site_title: Beyond coffee and sandwiches
summary: Indie cafes in Singapore have evolved to offer more varied offerings, standing out in the competitive environment. Seven years ago, they were dominated by kopi-o drinkers or Starbucks devotees, but now they serve a range of food options, including waffles with otah otah and full-fledged Italian menus. Successful cafe owners, such as Jane Hia of Kith Cafe, have expanded their brands and menu offerings to remain competitive. Others, like Danny Pang of Spruce, have revamped their approach to serve American classics and Italian cuisine. Despite the saturated market, many cafe owners remain optimistic, with some even exploring overseas markets and diversifying their business models.

site_title: OCBC extends cash withdrawal service to 7-Eleven stores
summary: OCBC Bank has expanded its cash withdrawal service to 7-Eleven stores in Singapore, allowing customers to withdraw up to S$100 per transaction. This move increases the bank's self-service network to over 2,000 locations, including more than 1,200 ATMs. The partnership aims to make banking more convenient for customers on-the-go, following a similar expansion by DBS to supermarkets and other locations.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank has expanded its cash-withdrawal network to 7-Eleven stores, going beyond the traditional banking network in the same way that DBS has recently done.

site_title: Tin output won't keep pace with demand
summary: Tin prices have surged into a bull market due to a global shortage, with demand outpacing output by 13,000 tonnes this year, the largest deficit since 1995. The metal, used in electrical circuits, is in high demand from manufacturers such as food can makers and iPad producers. Supply is expected to remain weak, with major mines in China cutting production, and prices are forecast to reach $18,000 next year, according to Societe Generale. This is a stark contrast to other base metals, which are expected to have surpluses this year.

images.alt_text: SOUGHT AFTER METAL: While economic growth is slowing in China, the biggest consumer, reduced production has sent tin inventories tracked by the LME to a seven-year low this month.

site_title: The 'forgotten' cholesterol
summary: Researchers focus on triglycerides in heart disease, as "good cholesterol" (HDL-C) myth is debunked. Triglycerides, a non-cholesterol fat, are associated with low HDL-C and vice versa. Elevated triglycerides increase the risk of heart disease, inflammation of the pancreas, and plaque formation. However, the triglyceride paradox shows that extremely high triglycerides can protect against heart artery disease. Studies suggest that remnant cholesterol, a component of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins, is a strong causal risk factor for heart artery disease. Reducing triglycerides and remnant cholesterol may help prevent inflammation in the arterial wall and reduce the risk of heart disease.

site_title: EU allows member states to scrap tampon tax
summary: The European Union has given its 28 member states the option to scrap the 5% tax on tampons, following pressure from British Prime Minister David Cameron and feminist MPs. The move aims to address the unfair tax, which has been a point of contention among EU leaders and feminist groups. The change will be implemented through a VAT zero rating for sanitary products, although the exact timeline is unclear.

site_title: Political savvy is a skill - not a game
summary: Leadership experts emphasize that being "politically savvy" is a valuable skill, not a game of scheming or backstabbing. It involves navigating workplace dynamics, building relationships, and maintaining integrity. Rather than trying to avoid office politics, individuals can learn to read people, engage in diplomacy, and win people over by being kind and professional. Effective political savvy also involves being aware of power dynamics, giving credit, and delivering on promises. By reframing workplace politics as a skill to be learned and developed, organizations can benefit from having more credible leaders.

site_title: Merkel dodges Draghi call for clarity with bank union swerve
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi urged EU leaders to set a clear path forward for the monetary union, but Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel avoided committing to discuss banking union, a critical area of disagreement. Merkel's reluctance stems from concerns about underwriting bank deposits and potential backlash from voters. Draghi pushed back against criticism of negative interest rates, emphasizing their positive impact on the economy and banks' medium-term profitability. The EU leaders agreed to discuss progress in completing the Economic and Monetary Union, but omitted the banking union phrase, leaving the issue unresolved.

images.alt_text: DIFFERENT PRIORITIES: Mr Draghi (above) urged EU leaders to set out a clear path forward for the monetary union, while Ms Merkel is wary of the risk of a domestic backlash against underwriting bank deposits in the rest of the bloc.

DIFFERENT PRIORITIES: Mr Draghi urged EU leaders to set out a clear path forward for the monetary union, while Ms Merkel (above) is wary of the risk of a domestic backlash against underwriting bank deposits in the rest of the bloc.

site_title: Bank Indonesia chief calls on Jakarta to address fiscal concerns
summary: Bank Indonesia's Governor Agus Martowardojo has urged the Indonesian government to address fiscal concerns, including revenue and subsidies, to secure an investment-grade rating from Standard & Poor's. The central bank cut interest rates for the third time this year to 6.75% to boost growth, but fiscal concerns are holding back a ratings upgrade. The World Bank expects the government to miss its 2016 revenue target, and the government needs to set up a mechanism to determine retail fuel prices after removing subsidies. An investment-grade rating from S&P could reduce borrowing costs and lower government bond yields.

images.alt_text: MR MARTOWARDOJO: He said that the government has to explain revenue and subsidy concerns.

site_title: On their march to the top
summary: The NBA season is nearing its climax, with the Golden State Warriors leading the way after 61 wins in 67 regular-season games. The Warriors' impressive record, including a 50-game winning streak at home, has them poised to face off against the San Antonio Spurs in the Western Conference playoffs. Meanwhile, in European football, Leicester City is on the verge of pulling off a major upset by winning the Premier League title, with only eight matches left to play. The WWE is also gearing up for its biggest event, Wrestlemania, with the final attendance expected to be close to 100,000 at the AT&T Stadium.

site_title: Referendum may expose fissures across Britain
summary: A Brexit referendum on June 23 may expose regional divisions in Britain, with the north likely to be more eurosceptic due to economic concerns and historical resentment towards London. The north's industrial base and reliance on trade with Europe may be severely impacted if the UK leaves the EU. Regional passions and rivalries, including a north-south divide and east-west fissure, are expected to play a significant role in the outcome.

site_title: France gets closer to slapping extra tax on palm oil used in food
summary: France's National Assembly has approved a new tax on palm oil used in food, starting at 30 euros per tonne in 2017, with a gradual increase to 90 euros by 2020. The tax aims to reduce environmental damage from palm oil plantations, excluding sustainable oils. The move has been opposed by top producers Indonesia and Malaysia, who consider it discriminatory. The French government backs the tax, citing environmental protection, and it still needs to be reviewed in the Upper House.

site_title: Wooing jet-setters on the ground via airport lounges
summary: Airlines such as Singapore Airlines, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, and Qantas are upgrading or expanding airport lounges to attract and retain passengers with a complete travel experience. This move comes as airlines compete in a crowded market where yields are under pressure. By offering comfortable and luxurious amenities, such as showers, quality meals, and spa services, airlines aim to provide a full traveller experience that sets them apart from competitors. Independent lounges, like those run by dnata and Plaza Premium Group, are also emerging as popular options for non-premium passengers willing to pay for access to a quiet spot and quick bite.

site_title: Gibraltar: The Rock that fears a Brexit
summary: Gibraltar, a British overseas territory, is deeply concerned about the potential consequences of Brexit. With over 33,000 inhabitants, the Rock is economically dependent on the EU single market and relies on a daily influx of workers from Spain for trade and labor. Gibraltar's economy has more than tripled in the past decade, driven by online gaming and financial services, and the uncertainty of Brexit is weighing on local businesses. The territory's chief minister, Fabian Picardo, and business leaders emphasize the importance of remaining in the EU to maintain economic stability and access to trade.

site_title: Planned rules on EU banks' bond, derivatives trading under review
summary: The European Commission is reviewing proposed European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) regulations on EU banks' bond and derivatives trading, calling for a "more cautious approach" to ensure accurate market liquidity assessments. The proposed standards were deemed too restrictive, with industry groups arguing they would harm trading and deter market makers. The commission is requesting changes to the regulations, which were set to phase in restrictions over four years, and may lead to stiffer standards in some cases.

site_title: Oil sets new 2016 highs on production freeze, demand bets
summary: Oil prices surged to 2016 highs, reaching US$42.54 for Brent crude and US$41.20 for US crude, driven by expectations of a production freeze by major exporters and stronger seasonal fuel demand in the US. The rally also boosted equity markets, with US energy company shares trading near 3-1/2 month highs. A production freeze by OPEC and non-OPEC producers, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, could result in the first global oil supply deal in 15 years, further fueling price gains.

site_title: Policy vs the cycle: the latest round
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) and Bank of Japan (BOJ) have taken drastic measures to boost risk asset markets, including expanding quantitative easing and negative deposit rates. However, experts warn that this may not be enough to prevent a bear market, as the underlying economic issues remain unaddressed. The ECB's actions may even create a bubble of bad credit, and the Fed's dovish stance on interest rates is seen as a response to the global economic situation, particularly the weakening Chinese currency. Despite this, the dollar is under pressure, and the yen is expected to strengthen.

site_title: Bayer Pharma continues to boost its presence in the Asia-Pacific
summary: Bayer Pharmaceuticals has significantly increased its presence in the Asia-Pacific region, with 2015 regional revenue rising 7% to €4 billion. Clinical trials in the region have more than tripled since 2007, with the number of trials in Singapore expanding nearly fourfold. The company has invested €25 million in local research institutions and partnered with major healthcare centers to focus on diseases such as gastric, liver, and lung cancers. Bayer's pharmaceuticals unit expects sales of €16 billion this year, with over €5 billion expected from recently launched products like Xarelto and Eylea.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: A taste of Budget 2016
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will present the FY16 budget next Thursday, focusing on the business sector amid uncertain macroeconomic landscape. The government is expected to allocate 50-55% of total annual development spending to the healthcare and transportation sectors, with a slight decrease from previous years. The budget deficit is expected to be around S$0.3 billion-S$0.5 billion, with a primary surplus of S$0.7 billion. The government will also continue its efforts to boost productivity, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Economist suggests that governments spend their way out of trouble
summary: International economist Nouriel Roubini advises Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to delay a planned hike in the country's sales tax, citing concerns that it could push the economy back into recession. Roubini favors fiscal spending over monetary policy, suggesting that other economically advanced nations also have "space" to expand spending to boost growth. This advice comes amid a global economic slowdown, with Roubini warning of high debt levels, declining labor supply and capital investment, and rising wealth inequalities.

images.alt_text: Internationally acknowledged economist Nouriel Roubini on Friday joined other experts in urging Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to delay a planned hike in Japan's sales tax, despite the country's government debt burden now being the highest among economically advanced nations.

site_title: Anchor Resources plunges in debut trading
summary: Anchor Resources, a Malaysian gold-miner, made its debut trading on Catalist, closing 41.6% down from its IPO price of 25 cents, at 14.6 cents. The stock fell to 14.4 cents before the close, with over 55 million shares changing hands. The company plans to use half of its IPO's S$4.6 million net proceeds to expand gold-processing capacity. Analysts suggest investors may have been spooked by the company's reported resources of 114,000 ounces of gold, and more geological information is needed for a clearer valuation.

site_title: Ragged battlelines drawn for Brexit
summary: Britain's Brexit referendum has created uncertainty, leading to a fall in the pound and warnings from businesses about the potential negative impact of a "Brexit." Pro-EU views dominate among businesspeople, particularly in larger firms, but opinions are more evenly divided across the country. The main challenge for "In" campaigners is generating enthusiasm for EU membership, which is often seen as expensive, bureaucratic, and unloved. Despite benefits to certain sectors, such as farmers and regions that have received EU funding, it remains to be seen whether these supporters will turn out in force to secure a convincing "In" vote.

site_title: Anbang makes binding Starwood Hotels bid
summary: Anbang Insurance Group Co, led by China, made a binding $13.2 billion takeover bid for Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc, surpassing Marriott International Inc's offer of $68 a share. The bid is $10 a share more, and Starwood's board intends to terminate the Marriott merger agreement. This acquisition would mark the largest-ever US acquisition by a Chinese buyer. Anbang's push into US hotels began with the purchase of Manhattan's Waldorf Astoria for $1.95 billion last year. The deal requires regulatory and shareholder approval.

site_title: Trump could surprise us
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump is defying expectations with a strong showing in the Republican nomination process, despite initial perceptions of him as a divisive figure. Trump's ability to tap into widespread dissatisfaction with establishment politics and his willingness to break rules has drawn comparisons to other unconventional leaders, such as Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Ronald Reagan. Trump's unorthodox style and lack of expectation to adhere to traditional politician's standards may give him an advantage, allowing him to implement an aggressive fiscal policy that could boost the economy.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US eased in March to a five-month low
summary: US consumer confidence eased to a five-month low in March, reaching 90, down from 91.7 in February, amid concerns over rising gasoline prices and lower-income Americans' economic prospects. Despite robust labor market conditions, households at the bottom end of the income scale grew more cautious, while those with higher incomes remained optimistic about pay gains. The median projection for the Bloomberg survey of economists was 92.2.

site_title: Ford CEO's compensation jumped 17 pct to US$17.4m in 2015
summary: Ford CEO Mark Fields' compensation rose 17% to $17.4 million in 2015, driven by the company's record pretax profit of $10.8 billion. Fields' total compensation, including pension and perks, was $18.6 million, down from $18.9 million in 2014. Executive Chairman Bill Ford's compensation was $9.9 million, down 1.6% from 2014, also due to a higher pension award. The 2015 figures marked the first full year under Fields' leadership.

site_title: EU may investigate online content providers over cross-border trade
summary: The European Union may investigate online content providers over cross-border trade after a year-long inquiry found that 68% of digital content providers block consumers in other EU countries, a practice known as geoblocking. This affects 38% of consumer goods retailers, mainly by refusing to deliver abroad or accept foreign payment methods. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager will publish a preliminary report in mid-2016, and a final report is due in 2017. The investigation aims to spur growth in e-commerce and help the bloc catch up with Asia and the US.

site_title: Olympics: China's Xi orders clean Winter Games after corruption scandals
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has ordered a "clean" Winter Olympics in 2022, following corruption scandals involving officials linked to the Games. Despite concerns over issues such as smog and human rights, Xi emphasized the need for strict budget management and supervision to ensure the event is "pure and clean as the snow and ice." Xi has been cracking down on corruption since taking power three years ago, and the Winter Olympics will be his first major test of his efforts.

images.alt_text: China must hold a Winter Olympics that is "clean as the snow" when it hosts the event in 2022, President Xi Jinping said on Friday, after two corruption scandals involving Chinese officials linked to the Games.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter compete for live TV rights: NY Post
summary: Facebook and Twitter are competing to buy rights to stream conventional TV programming. The companies have approached programmers and are in talks with the National Football League for digital rights to Thursday Night Football. However, the delivery method for the shows is unclear. Facebook has met with TV executives, but the details of the potential deal remain unknown. Both companies declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Less is more fun
summary: The Lamborghini Huracán LP 580-2 is a two-wheel-drive version of the Huracán, offering a more entertaining drive. With 580 hp and a 5.2-litre V10 engine, it accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 3.4 seconds and 0-200 km/h in 10.1 seconds. The LP 580-2 has a lower power output and torque compared to its all-wheel-drive counterpart, but its dry weight is 33 kg less, making it more agile. Three driving modes - Strada, Sport, and Corsa - are available, each offering a unique experience, with the LP 580-2 being described as Lamborghini's purest expression of a super sports car.

site_title: Statoil, BP Gas facility in Algeria hit by rocket attack
summary: A rocket attack on a gas facility in Krechba, Algeria, operated by Statoil and BP, occurred on Friday, March 18, 2016. Two homemade mortars were fired from outside the site's perimeter, but no damage was caused and no one was hurt. The facility has been shut down as a safety precaution, and all staff have been accounted for. The attack occurred three years after a deadly assault on the In Amenas gas plant in January 2013.

site_title: Cisco to invest US$100m in India's digital push
summary: Cisco Systems Inc plans to invest over US$100 million in India's digital push, supporting the country's 'Digital India' initiative to connect villages to the internet and create jobs. The investment will be used to launch incubation centers and training programs for entrepreneurs and students. Cisco will also fund early and mid-stage startups with US$40 million of the total investment. The move aims to support India's ambitious plans to move services online and create more tech jobs.

site_title: Upscale jeweller Tiffany expects profit to drop in H1 2016
summary: Tiffany & Co. expects a decline in profit for the first half of 2016 due to a strong dollar hurting tourist spending at its US stores and reducing revenue from other markets. The global economy's weakness and reluctance to offer promotions have also contributed to the expected decline.

site_title: ST Engineering injects US$5.8m into Keystone to acquire aircraft
summary: ST Engineering has injected US$5.8 million into its subsidiary Keystone to acquire an Airbus A321, adding to its aircraft leasing portfolio. This investment brings the total share capital contribution in Keystone to US$18.96 million. The move aims to expand ST Aerospace Resources' fleet.

site_title: Petrobras said to weigh fields sale valued up to US$2 billion
summary: Petrobras is marketing three offshore oil and natural gas fields, valued up to US$2 billion, as part of its plan to sell assets and pay down debt. The fields, Bauna, Golfinho, and Tartaruga, are being sold through Bank of America Corp, with the Brazilian state-run oil producer aiming to raise US$14.4 billion from asset sales this year. The move comes after crude prices tumbled and the company faced management changes due to a corruption scandal.

site_title: Bangladesh IT expert missing after bank heist remarks
summary: A Bangladeshi cyber security expert, Tanvir Hassan Zoha, has gone missing after commenting on the US$81 million heist from the Bangladesh Bank's foreign exchange account. Zoha, 34, had said officials' apathy over security contributed to the theft, and was last seen being taken away by men in plainclothes on Wednesday night. His disappearance has raised concerns over the security of Bangladesh's foreign exchange reserves, valued at over US$27 billion, and has embarrassed the government of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Authorities have denied Zoha was working with them on investigating the case.

site_title: Daimler receives huge order from Uber: Manager Magazin
summary: Uber has placed a large order for at least 100,000 Mercedes S-Class cars from Daimler, with a focus on autonomous driving vehicles. The order is expected to be fulfilled after 2020. Daimler declined to comment on the matter. This deal highlights Uber's interest in autonomous driving technology and its potential impact on the automotive industry.

site_title: Chinese slowdown to hurt Britain via indirect trade and financial links
summary: Britain's economy could be impacted if China's economy slows sharply, potentially slowing British growth by 0.1% due to indirect trade and financial links. China's slowdown could also create uncertainty about the global economic outlook, hurting sentiment and asset prices. However, a slowdown in China's growth could also lead to lower commodity prices, benefiting Britain's economy.

site_title: German court acquits former Porsche CEO in VW takeover case
summary: A German court has acquitted former Porsche CEO Wendelin Wiedeking of alleged market manipulation in the 2008 VW takeover bid. Porsche used derivatives to sidestep share ownership disclosure rules, sparking controversy. The court found no evidence of wrongdoing, clearing Wiedeking of charges. This decision marks a significant outcome in one of the auto industry's most contentious takeover battles during the financial crisis.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and global events. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Ferragamo shares jump in Milan after earnings exceed estimates
summary: Luxury shoemaker Salvatore Ferragamo reported quarterly earnings that beat estimates, with EBITDA increasing 11% to 324 million euros. The company forecast a "positive year" despite a tough industry backdrop and a decline in sales in January and February. Ferragamo attributed the decline to an aggressive refurbishment plan and weak sales in Hong Kong and Macau, as well as subdued trends in the US and Europe. The company's shares rose 3.7% in early trading, with analysts praising the company's ability to deliver superior earnings growth.

site_title: Singapore to step up its strategy to counter terrorism as threat of attack rises: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore is upgrading its counter-terrorism strategy amid the highest threat level ever recorded. The government plans to expand CCTV coverage, implement stringent measures for buildings and major events, and establish dedicated police emergency response teams. These measures aim to enhance the country's preparedness and response to potential attacks. The upgrade is part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen its national security.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher, helped by rising oil prices
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by the Federal Reserve's cautious stance on interest rates and rising oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.71 points, or 0.21%, to 17,518.2, while the S&P 500 gained 3.56 points, or 0.17%, to 2,044.15. The Nasdaq composite added 13.00 points, or 0.27%, to 4,787.98, reaching fresh records.

site_title: China's Suzhou unveils rules to cap home price rises
summary: China's Suzhou city has introduced measures to cool its housing market by capping annual home price gains at 12% and limiting price increases to 6% within six months. This move follows concerns about the country's overheated housing market, which has seen strong sales and price gains in major cities. Suzhou's home prices rose 5.6% in February, making it the second-best performer among 100 major Chinese cities. The move aims to prevent a supply glut and discourage new investment in the market.

site_title: Maersk Drilling CEO ready to buy used rigs in pricing rejig
summary: Maersk Drilling CEO Claus Hemmingsen is considering buying used oil rigs to take advantage of low prices. The company's parent, AP Moeller-Maersk A/S, has $8 billion in cash flow, making it a secure financier for potential purchases. Hemmingsen is looking at ultra-harsh environment jack-up rigs and ultra-deepwater floaters, which are currently hit by low oil prices. The move could shift Maersk Drilling's strategy away from only expanding through new rigs, as the market for used rigs may become more attractive due to the financial clout of the Maersk group.

site_title: HSBC plans to name successor to chairman Douglas Flint next year
summary: HSBC plans to nominate a successor to chairman Douglas Flint next year, with the search process already underway. Flint, 60, will remain in the role as long as necessary to ensure a smooth transition. He joined the bank in 1995 as finance director. The bank has not specified the timeline for the nomination, citing the need to identify and secure the "appropriate candidate."

site_title: Apple prepares to unveil smaller iPhone with narrower ambitions
summary: Apple is set to unveil a smaller, 4-inch iPhone aimed at enticing holdouts to upgrade from older models. The device, which will replace the 5S at the low end of the lineup, boasts a faster processor and may be available in various colors. The move follows Apple's concern that iPhone growth has reached its limits, with quarterly sales expected to decline for the first time in over a decade. The new iPhone's smaller size and lower price could encourage existing customers to upgrade, while also allowing Apple to test new component suppliers ahead of the next-generation flagship phone.

site_title: Lufthansa seeks to lift cargo market gloom with niche services
summary: Lufthansa Cargo is seeking to boost its market share by targeting niche customers and revamping its products, following a 40% drop in adjusted earnings to 73.5 million euros in 2015. The cargo arm cut costs and expects only a slight increase in profits for 2016. Overcapacity in the market, a slowdown in China, and strikes at Lufthansa contributed to the decline. The company aims to adapt to a challenging market environment with new services.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore awarded S$27 million in research grants to 13 projects focusing on gas technology and smart grid innovation. This boost could lead to new momentum in the use of cold energy from liquefied natural gas. Meanwhile, Singapore shares closed higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,906.8, up 0.9% for the day. The US oil futures hit a 2016 high, driven by optimism over an output freeze deal.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher; STI in the black for the year
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed in the black for the first time since 2015, jumping 26.63 points or 0.9% to 2,906.8. The index's gain was driven by the three banks and Singtel, with a total turnover of S$1.2 billion. The US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on interest rates, with a possible two rate hikes this year, was a key factor. For the year, the STI is up 0.8%, after gaining 2.8% for the week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.15 points to close at 1,716.34 on Friday, driven by a 2.03 billion lots traded worth RM2.98 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 538-349. The market's momentum follows a 5-day rally in Singapore, where stocks are expected to be influenced by upcoming GDP data.

site_title: China to build nuclear plant in polluted Hebei province
summary: China plans to build a nuclear reactor in the polluted Hebei province, aiming to reduce smog and promote cleaner energy. The move is part of China's efforts to meet its pledge to peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. The country's nuclear capacity is expected to rise to 120-150 gigawatts by 2030, with new reactors to be built every year. Safety is a priority, and China is investing in new regulations and emergency response capabilities.

site_title: BPM details ECB conditions to approve merger, board to meet by March 22
summary: The European Central Bank has set conditions for the approval of Banca Popolare di Milano's (BPM) planned merger with Banco Popolare, including a strong capital position, asset quality, and a clear governance structure. The ECB also requires the two banks to present a multi-year industrial plan within a month. BPM's board will meet by March 22 to decide on the ECB's requests. Banco Popolare's board will also meet on the same date to consider the conditions.

site_title: Facebook CEO enjoys smoggy Beijing run ahead of forum
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg took a mask-free jog through Beijing's Tiananmen Square ahead of an economic forum, despite thick smog levels that exceeded the World Health Organisation's recommended maximum. The photo, posted on his Facebook account, sparked criticism from Chinese Internet users who are not allowed access to his company's service, which has been banned in China for years. Zuckerberg's apparent deferential treatment of Chinese leaders has also been criticized, with some questioning the wisdom of his excursion.

images.alt_text: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg took a mask-free jog through Beijing's Tiananmen Square Friday, smiling through thick smog as he sought greater access for his company to China, where its service is banned.

site_title: EU lobby says China should open market to meet economic goals
summary: China should open its markets to foreign business and implement overdue reforms to meet its economic goals, a European business lobby said. The European Union Chamber of Commerce in China welcomed China's goals to increase innovation, reform state-owned firms, and develop environmental technology, but emphasized the need for stronger protection of intellectual property rights and greater respect for trade secrets. The chamber stated that market opening should be based on customer demands, not policy planning, and that China's 6.5% growth target, the slowest in a quarter century, could be achieved with genuine market reforms.

site_title: Richemont, parent group of Cartier and Piaget, plans to cut 300 Swiss jobs
summary: Richemont, the parent group of luxury brands Cartier and Piaget, plans to cut 300 Swiss jobs, with around 170 at Cartier and 120 at Piaget and Vacheron Constantin. This move comes after the company confirmed in February it could cut up to 350 Swiss jobs. Richemont did not immediately comment on the news.

site_title: Global watchdog flags slow "too big to fail" bank rule adoption
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) warned that many countries, including Argentina, Australia, Brazil, and China, have not implemented laws allowing regulators to write down bank debts to prevent taxpayer bailouts. The FSB, chaired by Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, said only European Union member states, Switzerland, and the US have implemented the "bail-in tool" to address the "too big to fail" issue, which has contributed to government bailouts during the 2007-09 financial crisis. Countries are given until December to take action.

site_title: Turkish forces disable bomb in vehicle in southeast: sources
summary: Turkish bomb-disposal experts successfully disabled an explosive device found in a vehicle near a government building in the town of Hani, Diyarbakir province, in southeast Turkey. No further details were immediately available.

site_title: Google owner seeking to sell robot developer Boston Dynamics
summary: Alphabet, Google's parent company, is seeking to sell Boston Dynamics, a robotics developer and manufacturer, as part of an effort to refocus robotics efforts under its Google X unit. The company acquired Boston Dynamics in 2013. The move is aimed at boosting Alphabet's robotics efforts. Sources familiar with the plans cite the sale as part of Alphabet's efforts to streamline its business operations.

site_title: South Korea sees stocks, bonds outflows for third month in February
summary: South Korea's stocks and bonds saw significant outflows for the third consecutive month in February, with foreign investors pulling a net 4.2 trillion won from their bond holdings and 194 billion won from shares. The US led the outflow, followed by Luxembourg and Israel. As a result, foreigners held 6.2% of South Korean bonds in February, down from 6.5% in January. The outflows are attributed to global growth uncertainties and investors seeking safe-haven assets in advanced economies.

site_title: Bang & Olufsen enters partnership with LG, could save up to US$30m a year
summary: Bang & Olufsen has entered a strategic technology partnership with LG Electronics to develop and produce high-end televisions, aiming to improve long-term profitability. The partnership has annual savings potential of 150-200 million Danish crowns (US$22.7-30.3 million) over three years, helping the Danish company achieve technological capabilities and scale.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher, gain 2.3 per cent on week
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.8% on Friday, driven by gains in mainland China shares amid easing fears of capital outflows. The Hang Seng index rose 2.3% for the week, its highest gain since January. The China Enterprises Index also gained 1.2%. Total trading volume was 2.2 billion shares.

site_title: Thailand investment applications double in Jan-Feb
summary: Thailand saw a significant increase in investment applications in the first two months of 2016, with a combined value of 32.44 billion baht (US$931.9 million), a 96% rise from the same period last year. Foreign firms alone applied for 12.5 billion baht, a five-fold jump. The government aims to reach a target of 450 billion baht in overall investment applications, driven by new policies targeting industrial clusters and value-added sectors. However, economists remain cautious, expressing concerns that the surge in applications may not translate to actual investments.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch lower led by banks
summary: European shares fell slightly, led by banking stocks, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index down 0.2% at 1,336.86 points. Germany's DAX dropped 0.6%. Banking stocks declined 1%, with Banco Popolare and Banca Popolare di Milano falling over 4% due to ECB conditions for their merger. Insurer Generali fell 2% after missing net profit expectations, despite boosting financial strength. This marks the first negative week for the index in five.

site_title: Oil hits 2016 high on output-freeze hopes
summary: Oil prices reached a 2016 high on Friday, with US crude rising to $40.55 per barrel and Brent crude hitting $41.71 per barrel. The surge is driven by hopes that major producers will agree to freeze output, as well as a softer dollar. If successful, the deal could lead to a 1 million barrel reduction in global stocks by the end of 2016, but some analysts caution that the market's gains may be premature, citing unchanged global fundamentals.

site_title: ECB's Praet says interest rates have not hit lower limit
summary: European Central Bank Executive Board Member Peter Praet stated that interest rates have not reached their lower limit, indicating a potential rate reduction remains in the ECB's arsenal to boost the economy and inflation. Praet emphasized that if negative economic shocks worsen the outlook, a rate cut could be implemented. This statement suggests the ECB is prepared to take further action to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Toshiba conducting stress test for nuclear business this quarter
summary: Toshiba is conducting a stress test on its nuclear business to assess if a 200 billion yen (S$1.6 billion) writedown is needed for its US subsidiary Westinghouse. The company had previously denied such a writedown was necessary, citing profitability. Toshiba forecasts an operating profit of at least 120 billion yen for the year starting in April as it tries to streamline its business and move beyond an accounting scandal. The stress test aims to determine the company's financial health and potential need for a writedown.

images.alt_text: Japan's Toshiba Corp said it is currently conducting a stress test on its nuclear business to assess whether it will require a writedown.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to name Asia regional corporate finance heads
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Oliver Brinkmann as head of corporate finance for North Asia, Sreenivasan Iyer as head of corporate finance for Southeast Asia, and Jason Cox as co-head of equity capital markets for Asia-Pacific.
