The nominees were selected from 41 submissions and were chosen for their contributions to society and fields. They will be appointed by President Tony Tan Keng Yam on March 22 and take their oath at the next Parliament sitting on March 24. The committee chairman, Said Halimah Yacob, expressed confidence that the nominees will add colour to and elevate the quality of debate in Parliament, particularly in addressing economic transformation and social issues.

site_title: Dollar weakens further after Fed's retreat
summary: The US dollar weakened by 1% against major currencies, including the euro, yen, and Swiss franc, following the Federal Reserve's dovish statement on Wednesday. The dollar index fell to its lowest level since October, but rebounded slightly in response to positive economic data. Sterling made the biggest gains against the dollar, rising 1.3% to $1.4445, after the Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged. Market chatter suggested the Bank of Japan may intervene in the yen, but dealers reported no indication of such action.

site_title: US safety agency says automakers to add automatic braking by 2022
summary: US auto safety regulators announced that 20 automakers, including General Motors, Ford, and Toyota, have agreed to make automatic emergency braking standard on nearly all US vehicles by 2022, aiming to prevent thousands of rear-end crashes annually. The voluntary commitment covers 99% of US vehicle sales and will be implemented two years faster than if it were legally required. Rear-end crashes resulted in 1,705 deaths and 547,000 injuries in 2012, with 87% of those linked to driver inattention.

site_title: Cheap ECB cash may not boost corporate borrowing: Heidelberg Cement
summary: HeidelbergCement's finance chief, Lorenz Naeger, says cheap European Central Bank loans may not boost corporate borrowing and investment due to subdued demand in many markets. Naeger believes that ultra-low interest rates alone cannot determine debt ratios and that monetary measures are going into a void. Despite the ECB's efforts to stimulate growth, HeidelbergCement plans to keep capital investment steady at 1.1 billion euros and will not be pushed to borrow more. The company has no plans to change its borrowing plans in response to cheaper funding, citing weak demand as the biggest impediment to growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore imposed penalties on 10 financial advisers for engaging in an anti-competitive agreement to pressure iFAST into withdrawing a 50% commission rebate on life insurance products. Amid economic headwinds, SME optimism dipped to "neutral" for the first time in six years. Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 2.1% in February, beating expectations. The general insurance industry's underwriting profit slipped due to competition and economic slowdown. Noble Group is in talks to raise a US$1.5 billion loan to repay debt.

images.alt_text: The Competition Commission of Singapore has issued an infringement decision against 10 financial advisers who have been found to have infringed the Competition Act

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates steady, says sterling hit by EU vote
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates steady at 0.5% in a unanimous decision, citing uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU referendum and potential impact on growth. Sterling has been hit by the uncertainty, and growth could slow in the near term. The BoE expects 2.2% growth this year and 2.3% next year, more optimistic than the government's forecasts. The central bank reiterated that interest rates are more likely to rise over the next two years, with a gradual increase expected.

site_title: SME sentiment at neutral after 6 years of optimism
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have seen sentiment dip to neutral after six years of optimism, according to a survey by the Singapore Business Federation and DP Information Group. The overall index score fell to 50.0, indicating no growth in the next six months. The transport/storage sector recorded the largest drop, followed by the business-services sector. The manufacturing sector expects contraction, while the retail/F&B sector remains stable. Experts attribute the decline to economic headwinds and global factors, and urge the government to support SMEs in the short term and adopt a pro-business approach in the long term.

site_title: Lufthansa says A320neo engine improving but not there yet
summary: Lufthansa announced that issues with the new A320neo engine are slowly improving but not fully resolved. The German carrier, which took delivery of its first A320neo in January, has not agreed to take additional aircraft into service due to ongoing engine problems. Software issues and issues with the engine's start-up process remain, with 50% of the problems resolved. Despite these issues, Lufthansa is seeing a 20% cost reduction compared to the earlier model and expects to take delivery of 52 new planes this year, including five A320neo jets.

site_title: Goldman's European business cuts pay after IPO activity slows
summary: Goldman Sachs International reported a 6.4% decline in total wage and salary bill to US$2.45 billion, despite a 10% increase in headcount. Average employee pay fell 15% to around US$400,000, driven by underwriting revenue declines of nearly 27% due to market volatility. CEO Lloyd Blankfein signaled further cost cuts to offset low interest rates and stricter regulations, following similar moves by rival Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase.

site_title: Art-felt tribute to Lee Kuan Yew
summary: Artists and a travel company in Singapore are paying tribute to the late Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew on the first anniversary of his passing. Artist Teng Jee Hum created 90 paintings depicting Lee's life and legacy, while graphic artist Sharlene Leong showcased quotes and portraits. Tribe launched a 3.5-hour walking tour exploring Lee's private life and character traits. The tour, which runs until March 23, will donate 100% of proceeds to charity, with 10% going to charity after the month.

images.alt_text: Art collector and self-taught artist Teng Jee Hum's reflections on Mr Lee for the last five years spurred him on to making over 90 paintings which revolve around the Singapore experience and identity (above).
Graphic artist Sharlene Leong combined her love of quotes and Mr Lee's portraiture to stage a solo exhibition called "Remembering LKY" at Palais Renaissance.
Tribe (above) a tour guide company which officially registered earlier this year, focuses on experiential tours and has launched a walking tour to show the personal life of Mr Lee.

site_title: Bad times for watch industry as Basel trade fair opens
summary: The Baselworld watch fair opened in Switzerland, amidst a gloomy atmosphere due to a slumping luxury market and the rising popularity of connected timepieces. Global exports of Swiss watches plummeted 3.3% in 2015, marking their first fall since 2009. Industry leaders acknowledge uncertainty, citing factors such as China's crackdown on corruption, the Russian ruble's volatility, and the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. Despite this, some brands, like TAG Heuer, reported double-digit growth, and experts believe that traditional Swiss watches and connected timepieces can co-exist.

site_title: BOJ asking market players about causes of dollar/yen moves: source
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is inquiring with market participants about the causes of the yen's recent movements against the dollar, without specifically checking interest rates. The central bank is asking "why is it moving?" in an effort to understand the market's dynamics, rather than assessing rates. This move has sparked concerns that the BOJ might intervene to halt further yen gains, which have pushed the dollar down to around 110 yen.

site_title: US current account deficit narrows in fourth quarter
summary: The US current account deficit narrowed to US$125.3 billion in the fourth quarter, down 3.6% from the previous quarter. The improvement is attributed to rising domestic oil production and lower international oil prices, but a strong dollar continues to undercut exports. Goods exports fell 3.4% to US$366.7 billion, and the deficit represented 2.8% of gross domestic product, the largest since 2012.

site_title: Midas gets nod to issue 733 million shares for acquisition of Huicheng Capital
summary: MIDAS Holdings has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to issue up to 733.3 million new shares as part of its proposed acquisition of Huicheng Capital, a China-based aluminium products maker. The shares will be issued at 36 Singapore cents each, valued at up to S$264 million. The company also plans to adopt a share incentive scheme to motivate employees and retain key management. Additionally, Midas has secured contracts worth S$51.8 million to supply train car components to CRRC Changchun Railway Vehicles, expected to positively impact its financial performance.

site_title: Indonesia's loan growth slows to 9.6% y-o-y in Jan
summary: Indonesia's outstanding loans by banks grew 9.6% in January, slowing from 10.5% in December. The Bank Indonesia cut its benchmark interest rate to 6.75% in February, aiming for 12-14% annual loan growth at year-end. The central bank has provided banks with fresh liquidity through reserve requirement ratio reductions, supporting the economy.

site_title: Norway central bank cuts key rate to record low
summary: Norway's central bank cut its key interest rate to a record low 0.5% amid plunging oil prices and a weaker global economy. The rate cut is expected to further hit the oil-based economy, with growth prospects weakening and inflation moderating. The bank predicted the jobless rate will rise to 4.6% and inflation will slow down. Central bank governor Oystein Olsen suggested the rate could be reduced further, possibly into negative territory, if the economy faces new major shocks.

site_title: VW seeks comprehensive deal on emissions with US regulators: source
summary: Volkswagen is seeking a comprehensive deal with US regulators to resolve its emissions cheating scandal. The German carmaker aims to negotiate a solution that includes fixing affected cars and compensation for excessive nitrogen oxide emissions. Talks include a contribution to electric mobility, but a factory for electric cars in the US is not on the table. A federal judge has set a March 24 deadline for VW to agree on a fix, with the US Justice Department seeking up to $46 billion in penalties. VW is also facing mounting legal action and has declined to comment on details of a possible deal.

site_title: Billionaire Li says 'Brexit' would prompt his UK retrenchment
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing stated he would scale back investments from the UK if "Brexit" occurs. He expressed concerns over the possibility of Britain exiting the European Union, citing the potential negative impact on his business. Li's company, CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd, delivered annual profits above analysts' estimates. Li's comments come ahead of the June 23 UK referendum on the EU's future.

site_title: US jobless claims rise modestly in payrolls survey week
summary: US jobless claims rose 7,000 to 265,000 in the week ended March 12, but remained below a level associated with a strengthening labor market. This marks the fifth month at this level, with claims below 300,000 for 54 weeks, the longest stretch since 1973. The four-week moving average of claims edged up to 268,000, suggesting further payrolls gains. The data supports the Federal Reserve's decision to gradually raise interest rates this year, easing fears of a recession.

site_title: Indonesia c.bank sees more room to ease, short-term focus on transmission
summary: Indonesia's central bank cut its key rate for the third time this year, citing room to further ease monetary policy. Executive Director Juda Agung stated the bank's focus is on strengthening the transmission of monetary loosening to the market through adjustments to "term structure" rates. This includes rates for bank deposits and central bank bonds. The move aims to boost economic growth without risking inflation.

site_title: Philippine bankers in Bangladesh heist feared for lives
summary: A Philippine banker, Maia Deguito, transferred $81 million stolen from Bangladesh's central bank into various accounts, fearing for her life, according to a parliamentary investigation. The money was laundered through Philippine casinos, with significant amounts believed to have been laundered through casinos in Manila and the northern province of Cagayan. Authorities have lost track of the money, and no one knows who was behind the heist, with low-level bank officers implicated. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, driven by Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's lowered expectations for US interest rate hikes this year. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.6%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indexes rose 0.7% and 0.9%, respectively. The positive start comes amid ongoing US-EU trade talks and amidst a global rally in stocks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.76 points to close at 1,703.19. Trading volume reached 1.81 billion lots, valued at RM2.31 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers, 490 to 341.

site_title: Ikea's Belgian operations face probe on report of dodged taxes
summary: Ikea's Belgian operations face a probe by the country's tax authorities after a report by the European Union's Green party alleged the furniture retailer avoided paying at least 1 billion euros in taxes in the EU over the past six years. The probe was sparked by the report, which caught the local authorities' attention, and Belgian Finance Minister Johan Van Overtveldt confirmed the investigation. This follows EU action against multinationals, including Apple and Google, over tax rulings deemed unfair subsidies. The probe aims to ensure national fiscal authorities can review multinationals' tax affairs and make necessary adjustments.

site_title: Heineken eyes control of indebted Indian tycoon's brewery
summary: Heineken is set to ask Vijay Mallya, the chairman of India's largest brewer United Breweries, to step down from the board amid India's growing beer market. Heineken, which already holds a 42.4% stake in the company, is betting on the market's rapid growth to surpass the global average. Mallya, who owes creditor banks over $1 billion, has already stepped down from another UB Group company, United Spirits, and has been forced to give up control over United Breweries due to mounting pressure from banks and regulators.

site_title: VW said in talks with US over two funds to pay for pollution
summary: Volkswagen is in talks with US authorities to establish two funds to pay for pollution from its cars, which cheated on diesel-emissions tests. A national remediation fund would promote clean transportation, while a California fund would promote zero-emission vehicles. The deal aims to settle a US Department of Justice civil lawsuit and clear a key obstacle as the German automaker tries to emerge from a scandal affecting 11 million vehicles worldwide. A settlement could total up to $46 billion, adding to VW's existing $10.27 billion set aside for the scandal.

site_title: Oil rallies to $41, near 2016 high, on producer meeting
summary: Oil prices surged to a near 2016 high of $41 a barrel, driven by a plan among major producers to meet in April to discuss output support. OPEC and non-OPEC producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, will discuss freezing production. This could be the first global supply deal in 15 years, increasing market stability. Brent crude has rallied over 50% from its 12-year low in January, reaching a 2016 peak.

site_title: Billionaire Li Ka-Shing's CK Hutchison tops profit estimates
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing's conglomerate CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd reported adjusted net income of HK$31.2 billion for the first year since its reorganisation, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's shares slipped 0.3% to close at HK$98.85 after the announcement. The reorganisation, completed in June, aimed to streamline the empire spanning across industries in over 50 countries, with 51-year-old son Victor set to take over control from 87-year-old Li Ka-shing.

site_title: Swiss central bank leaves interest rates unchanged
summary: Switzerland's central bank, the Swiss National Bank, left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at -1.25% to -0.25% and maintained a 0.75% charge on cash deposits. The decision was made amid a deteriorating global economic outlook and volatile international financial markets. The SNB stated its willingness to intervene in the foreign exchange market to weaken the "significantly overvalued" Swiss franc and ease pressure on the currency.

site_title: 4 MOH and 12 SGH staff disciplined for role in hepatitis C outbreak in hospital
summary: Four senior MOH officials and 12 SGH staff have been disciplined for their roles in the hepatitis C outbreak at the Singapore General Hospital, affecting 25 patients and linked to eight deaths. The outbreak led to actions being taken against those deemed responsible. MOH and SGH issued separate statements revealing the disciplinary actions.

images.alt_text: Four senior officials from the Ministry of Health (MOH) and 12 people holding leadership positions at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) have been disciplined for their role in the hepatitis C outbreak at the hospital that affected 25 patients and were linked to eight deaths.

site_title: China's Tencent Q4 revenue beats estimates on gaming, advertising
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, China's largest social network and online entertainment firm, reported a 45% revenue increase in the fourth quarter, driven by gaming and online advertising. Revenue reached 30.4 billion yuan, exceeding analyst estimates. Net income rose 22% to 7.16 billion yuan, its slowest growth in three quarters.

site_title: Toshiba says agreed to sell white goods ops to China's Midea Group
summary: Toshiba has agreed to sell its majority white goods business to China's Midea Group Co Ltd, aiming to finalize the deal by the end of March. The move follows last year's revelations of overstated profits, with Toshiba's white goods business generating 225 billion yen in sales in 2014. Midea Group is the world's second-largest maker of white goods, according to Euromonitor. The sale is part of Toshiba's efforts to overhaul its operations.

site_title: China offers double-digit growth opportunity to UBS's Zeltner
summary: UBS sees a "double-digit growth opportunity" in China's wealth-management industry despite the country's slowing economy. The Swiss bank's wealth-management president, Juerg Zeltner, attributed this growth to China's rapid expansion, with the country expected to grow at two to three times the global average. UBS plans to double its workforce in China to 1,200 over five years, with the goal of becoming the pre-eminent global wealth manager in the country.

site_title: China Merchants Group joins race to buy Baltic Exchange: sources
summary: State-run conglomerate China Merchants Group has made an informal bid to buy London's Baltic Exchange, a centuries-old hub for the global shipping market. The approach was made by China Merchants Securities, a subsidiary of the group. This move comes as the business heats up, with the group's massive size indicating a strong interest in acquiring the exchange. The bid is the latest in a series of contenders vying for the Baltic Exchange, which has been a cornerstone of the global shipping industry for centuries.

site_title: ECB lowers emergency funding cap for Greek banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered the emergency funding cap for Greek banks by 100 million euros to 71.3 billion euros. The move reflects improving liquidity conditions in Greece's banking sector, thanks to the stabilisation of private sector deposit flows. Greek banks have relied on emergency liquidity assistance since February 2015. The reduced cap makes emergency funding more costly than borrowing from the ECB.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks reach 2016 highs after Fed decision
summary: South Korea's won reached its highest closing level in 2016, closing at 1,173.3 per US dollar, a 1.7% gain. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also closed at 1,987.99 points, up 0.7%. The Fed's decision to halve its outlook for rate hikes this year boosted demand for risky assets, driving up the won and stock prices. This is the won's biggest one-day percentage gain since November 2011.

site_title: China's steelmakers warn slower exports and rising output to pressure market: paper
summary: China's steelmakers are increasing production in response to rising prices, which could exacerbate a supply glut. Steel rebar futures have risen 19% this year, driven by a rally rather than improved fundamentals. The Chinese government aims to cut excess industrial capacity in the coal and steel sectors, but the sector faces potential layoffs, higher environmental costs, and reduced access to loans. Steel exports, the largest share of China's steel production, are expected to fall further due to anti-dumping investigations and waning demand from European countries.

site_title: Greece's jobless rate rises to 24.4 per cent in fourth quarter
summary: Greece's jobless rate surged to 24.4% in the fourth quarter of last year, with 74.3% of the 1.17 million jobless being long-term unemployed. This marks a significant increase from the previous quarter, with the highest unemployment rate recorded in the first quarter of 2014. The debt crisis and austerity measures imposed by the EU/IMF have led to a quarter of Greece's economic output being wiped out, driving record-high joblessness. The economy expanded slightly in the final quarter of 2015 but shrank 0.3% for the year.

site_title: Alzheimer's 'lost' memories may be recoverable: study
summary: Researchers at the RIKEN-MIT Center for Neural Circuit Genetics have discovered that Alzheimer's disease may not destroy specific memories, but rather make them inaccessible. By stimulating specific areas of the brain with blue light, scientists can make mice recall thoughts that were previously unavailable to them. This breakthrough suggests that Alzheimer's patients, especially in their early stages, may retain memories in their brains, offering a possible cure. The study, published in Nature, uses optogenetics to increase the number of "spines" in the mice's brains, allowing them to recall memories previously lost.

site_title: Hamptons luxury home sales soften as Wall Street weakness takes a toll
summary: The luxury home market in the Hamptons, a popular summer destination for Wall Street executives, has seen a decline in sales due to financial market weakness. In 2015, the average price of the top 10 most expensive homes sold was $35.5 million, a 20% decrease from the previous year. This is the second-highest average price ever recorded, up from $15.9 million in 2009. Despite this, the market remains strong, with prices still higher than the pre-financial crisis levels.

site_title: Swiss government sees slow economic recovery in 2016 and 2017
summary: The Swiss government has revised its economic growth forecasts for 2016 and 2017, citing a weaker global economic outlook. Swiss economic growth is now expected to be 1.4% in 2016 and 1.8% in 2017, down from previous forecasts. The government also reduced its inflation forecast for 2016 to -0.6%, with inflation expected to rise to 0.2% in 2017. The revisions come ahead of the Swiss National Bank's quarterly policy assessment.

site_title: Long ringgit bets highest since 2014, Asia FX view improves
summary: Bullish bets on the Malaysian ringgit reached their highest level since August 2014, driven by higher oil prices and expectations of a delayed US interest rate hike. Asian currencies, including the Philippine peso, Thai baht, and South Korean won, also saw improved sentiment. Long positions in these currencies rose to their highest levels since 2014, while bearish bets in the Chinese yuan fell to the lowest level since October 2015. This follows an improvement in US economic data and a recovery in global oil prices.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher after Fed's dovish hints
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 35.96 points to 2,880.17, driven by the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged and the likelihood of only two rate hikes this year due to a weakening economic outlook. The decision sparked a "bad news is good for stocks" sentiment, with markets expecting more stimulus from central banks. The Dow futures gained 60 points during local trading hours. This is the first time since the 1990s that US monetary policy is focused on global growth risks.

site_title: AirAsia India announces new CEO in management shake-up
summary: AirAsia India has appointed Amar Abrol as its new CEO, replacing Mittu Chandilya, as part of a management shake-up. Abrol, a former American Express executive, aims to boost the airline's small market share and turn a profit. He is joined by Ankur Khanna as CFO and Kiran Jain as head of commercial operations. The airline, which has struggled to make money since its launch in 2014, operates six aircraft covering 12 routes in India's competitive air travel market.

site_title: UOB Asset Management (Taiwan) obtains Taiwanese SITE licence
summary: UOB Asset Management (Taiwan) has obtained the Securities Investment Trust Enterprise (SITE) licence in Taiwan, enabling it to offer onshore funds and provide fund management services for domestic investors. This is the first SITE licence to be awarded to a fully foreign-owned fund management company in Taiwan since 2001. The licence allows UOBAM to expand its services, including equity and bond funds, and deepen client relationships in Asia. The move is seen as a positive step for Taiwan's asset management industry, with UOBAM CEO William Wang expressing confidence in the sector's growth potential.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end higher on Fed rate call
summary: The Federal Reserve cut its forecasts for US interest rate hikes, causing Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks to close higher. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 1.21%, while Shanghai's benchmark index jumped 1.20%. The Shenzhen Composite Index surged 3.56%. These gains followed the Fed's decision, which indicated lower interest rate hikes for this year.

site_title: China: Stocks close up more than 1%, led by tech
summary: China's stocks rose over 1% on Thursday, driven by gains in technology shares, which offset weakness in financial stocks. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index both increased, while China's ChiNext growth board rose 5.3%. The rebound reversed consecutive falls in the past two sessions.

site_title: GlaxoSmithKline CEO Witty to bow out in March 2017
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) CEO Andrew Witty announced his retirement in 12 months, citing the need for succession planning. Witty, who has led the company since 2008, has faced criticism over declining sales and profits, as well as a bribery scandal in China. GSK's board will search for an internal or external candidate, with potential internal contenders including Abbas Hussain and Emma Walmsley. Witty's departure comes at a time of uncertainty for the company, prompting speculation about a potential break-up of the group.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish up 1% as miners rally on Fed relief
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Thursday, driven by a slower-than-expected rate hike from the US Federal Reserve. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 49.17 points to 5,168.20, with mining and energy sectors leading the gain, up 2.3% and 2.8% respectively. The US Fed's signal helped boost gold, metals, and oil prices.

site_title: Fed signals send US dollar lower as Europe returns
summary: The US dollar fell to a 3-week low against the yen after the Federal Reserve signaled no interest rate hike by June, undermining expectations of a rate increase. The dollar traded at 111.675 yen, down 2 yen from its previous close, and declined against the Australian dollar and euro. The dollar index hit a 1-month low, trading at 95.424. The decline in the dollar's value was driven by European markets gathering pace, with the dollar losing 0.7% against the euro since its close in New York.

site_title: Indonesian president to decide soon on location of Inpex's LNG plant
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo will soon decide on the location of a $15 billion LNG plant, with Inpex Corp delaying the project's sanctioning by at least two years due to months of uncertainty. The project, jointly developed with Royal Dutch Shell, will not be operational until at least 2026. The government faces pressure to attract long-term energy investments amidst low oil and gas prices. An offshore development plan was submitted last September, but the president's indecisiveness has led to job cuts and investment delays. A decision is expected soon.

site_title: Gold eases after strong rally, Fed eyes fewer rate hikes
summary: Gold prices eased 0.3% to $1,258.25 an ounce after a strong rally of 2.5% in the previous session, following the Federal Reserve's decision to cut the number of planned interest rate hikes. Asian shares gained, and US crude oil futures rose, taking pressure off gold's safe-haven appeal. The Fed's decision reduced expectations for further rate hikes, allowing gold to rise 18% this year, but profit-taking is expected as the upside is capped at $1,280.

site_title: China says it opposes any unilateral sanctions against North Korea
summary: China opposes any unilateral sanctions against North Korea, following the US' imposition of sweeping new curbs in response to North Korea's nuclear and rocket tests. China, North Korea's largest trading partner, had previously believed a blanket trade ban would be ineffective without a stronger commitment from China. China signed on to new UN sanctions against North Korea earlier this month.

images.alt_text: China opposes any unilateral sanctions on North Korea, the Foreign Ministry said, after the United States imposed sweeping new curbs on the isolated country in retaliation for its nuclear and rocket tests.

site_title: Lufthansa restores dividend after 2015 profit jumps
summary: Lufthansa restored dividend payments after a 55% increase in operating profit in 2015, driven by low fuel prices and strong travel demand. The airline reported €1.82 billion in adjusted earnings before interest and tax, in line with forecasts. Lufthansa expects a slight increase in profits and unit cost reductions to combat declining yields. A proposed dividend payment of €0.50 per share was announced, marking a restoration after a three-year hiatus.

site_title: Imagination Technologies plans more cost cuts
summary: Imagination Technologies, a supplier of graphics technology to Apple, plans further cost cuts. The company aims to reduce its cost base by an additional 12.5 million pounds by 2017, on top of the 15 million pounds announced last month. This will be achieved by shedding 200 staff and shutting or selling non-core units. The restructuring efforts follow the company's struggle to ease its reliance on Apple, a trend that has affected its business in recent years.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as stronger yen dents post-Fed risk appetite
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nikkei share average ending 0.2% lower at 16,936.38, as a stronger yen dented investors' risk appetite. The stronger yen offset a rally after the US Federal Reserve signalled fewer interest rate hikes this year. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 0.1% each. The decline was despite a brief intraday rise to a 1.6% gain.

site_title: Trump victory a major global risk: EIU
summary: The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) has ranked a Donald Trump presidency as a major global risk, equivalent to jihadist militancy, with a threat level of 12. The EIU cited Trump's alienation towards China, comments on Islamist extremism, and potential for a trade war as key concerns. A Trump victory could also scupper the Trans-Pacific Partnership and escalate into a trade war with Mexico and China. However, the EIU does not expect Trump to win the election and notes that Congress may block some of his proposals.

site_title: Lanxess Q4 core profit slightly ahead of expectations
summary: Lanxess, the world's largest synthetic-rubber maker, reported slightly better-than-expected fourth-quarter core earnings of 151 million euros, a 1.9% decrease from the previous year. The company attributed the improvement to cost cuts and lower petrochemical raw material prices. Lanxess expects 2016 adjusted EBITDA to be between 880 million and 930 million euros, slightly above the average analyst estimate of 933 million euros. The company also proposed a 20% increase in 2015 dividend to 0.60 euros per share.

site_title: Cambodian PM reshuffles cabinet, but won't name names
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen announced a cabinet reshuffle, citing the need for "more efficient work" and warning that some ministers may be fired. The changes, set to be approved by parliament on April 4, include eight ministries and four provincial governors. Hun Sen has been under pressure from a growing opposition party and has promoted his sons and allies in a bid to consolidate power. The move is seen as a bid to freshen up his government and address concerns about his iron-fisted rule. A new lineup is expected to be approved on April 4.

site_title: Germany closes embassy, consulate in Turkey on attack fears
summary: Germany has closed its embassy and consulate in Turkey due to fears of an imminent attack, following a warning issued to its citizens in Ankara on Tuesday. The German school in Istanbul has also been shut down. This decision comes after the German government increased security measures in response to the threat. The closure is a precautionary measure to ensure the safety of German citizens and personnel in the region.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax to cut 120 journalist jobs from major mastheads
summary: Fairfax Media, Australia's oldest newspaper publisher, is cutting 120 journalist jobs across major mastheads, including The Australian Financial Review, The Age, and Sydney Morning Herald, due to margin pressure in the print industry. The cuts, equivalent to 12-20% of staff, come after Fairfax previously reduced 1,900 jobs in 2012. The move has sparked an unauthorized strike by staff, but the company will continue to publish as usual. The cutbacks highlight the challenges facing traditional media companies in the digital age, with new entrants such as The Guardian and Buzzfeed expanding in the country.

site_title: Singapore's general insurance profit slips on economic slowdown, competition
summary: Singapore's general insurance industry experienced a 17.1% drop in underwriting profit to S$325 million in 2015 due to increased competition and the economic slowdown. Total gross premiums rose 2.6% to S$3.618 billion, with motor insurance accounting for 32% of gross written premiums. The industry faces pressure to maintain underwriting discipline to avoid massive losses, which peaked at S$214.1 million in 2008. Despite the challenges, the General Insurance Association of Singapore (GIA) president noted the industry's "commendable performance" in 2015.

site_title: HSBC sees Australia opportunities as China M&A focus shifts
summary: HSBC sees opportunities in Australia as China shifts its M&A focus from resources to infrastructure, real estate, and agriculture. The bank has hired bankers in project finance and debt capital markets to capitalize on growing Chinese investment in the country. Chinese purchases of Australian assets nearly doubled to A$8 billion in 2015, with HSBC being lead adviser to several major deals. HSBC is well-positioned to benefit from this trend, leveraging its strong relationships in China and Hong Kong.

site_title: Toshiba shares slide almost 10% on report of Westinghouse accounting probe
summary: Toshiba shares dropped nearly 10% after Bloomberg News reported US authorities are investigating the company over accounting related to its Westinghouse nuclear power operations. The investigation, led by the Justice Department and Securities Exchange Commission, is looking into the possibility of fraud. Toshiba has already been investigated in Japan and has previously admitted to overstating profits by 5.8 billion yen. The company's shares have been struggling to recover from a multi-billion dollar accounting scandal.

site_title: Thai gardener behind US$20m Saudi gem heist becomes monk
summary: A Thai gardener, Kriangkrai Techamong, who stole a US$20 million gem heist from a Saudi palace in 1989, has become a monk in a bid to redeem his karma. The heist, known as the "Blue Diamond Affair," soured relations between Thailand and Saudi Arabia and remains unresolved. Thai police returned some of the stolen jewels, but Saudi officials claim most were counterfeits, with the whereabouts of the rare 50-carat blue diamond still unknown. Techamong's conversion to Buddhism aims to make amends for his past actions.

site_title: China says trade declines will ease after March but 2016 will be severe
summary: China's foreign trade is expected to ease after March, with declines expected to gradually ease, according to the Commerce Ministry. February exports and imports fell, with the biggest decline in exports since May 2009. The ministry attributes the weak trade performance to Lunar New Year holidays and expects a worse and more complex trade situation this year compared to 2015. Non-financial foreign direct investment rose 1.8% in February, a sign of a relatively healthy external economy. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Early election looms as Australian PM seeks to reform hostile senate
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is considering dissolving parliament and calling an early election to reform the hostile Senate, which has stalled key government agenda items. The proposed Senate voting reforms aim to limit access to welfare and make higher education and healthcare more expensive. The reforms have support from the opposition Greens Party and business groups, and an election is due by January 2017. Turnbull's government is leading in opinion polls, but his honeymoon period as prime minister may be ending, prompting speculation about an early election.

images.alt_text: Australia's parliament began an acrimonious final sitting day before a May budget on Thursday, with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull considering dissolving both houses of parliament and calling an early election to end a hostile Senate.

site_title: Yellen steers Fed with cautious hand, despite hints of inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen urged caution over interest rate hikes, stating that "caution is appropriate" due to concerns about accelerating inflation. However, a faction of Fed policymakers, led by Governor Lael Brainard, believe US inflation is rising and may require more aggressive rate hikes. The Fed's decision to maintain a gradual pace of rate hikes has been met with skepticism by some economists, who warn that a dovish Fed stance could lead to a loss of credibility if inflation does pick up further.

site_title: Jokowi's call for rates to "fall, fall, fall" raises Indonesia risks
summary: Indonesian President Jokowi's repeated calls for interest rates to "fall, fall, fall" have raised concerns among economists, who warn that the country is becoming more vulnerable to emerging-market selloffs. Analysts predict a 25-basis-point cut in interest rates, which could lead to capital outflows and increased soured credit. The government is also facing budget strains and inflation risks, despite a recent surge in local-currency sovereign debt and a strong rupiah. Experts advise the government to focus on state revenue reform and macro-stability, rather than relying on rate cuts alone.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog imposes penalties on 10 financial advisers
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has imposed penalties totaling S$909,302 on 10 financial advisers for engaging in an anti-competitive agreement to pressure iFAST into withdrawing its 50% commission rebate on competing life insurance products. The CCS found that the agreement prevented the market from becoming more competitive. The financial advisers, representing Cornerstone Planners to Wynnes Financial Advisers, must determine their own responses to competition, rather than collectively pressuring a competitor. The CCS will enforce the law to ensure fair competition in the market.

images.alt_text: The Competition Commission of Singapore has issued an infringement decision against 10 financial advisers who have been found to have infringed the Competition Act

site_title: Chinese hedge fund scramble as regulators clean up
summary: China's hedge fund industry is facing significant disruption due to new stringent rules, which may lead to the shutdown of over half the industry by August. The rules aim to curb a "Wild East" environment of alleged fraud and are part of a broader government crackdown. Domestic and foreign hedge fund managers are scrambling to comply, securing legal advice, hiring staff, and launching new products to save their licenses. The regulator has already threatened to close down around 17,000 "phantom" fund managers. The industry is described as rife with fraud and is under intense scrutiny.

site_title: Asia central banks in spotlight as cheap money fuels debate over race to bottom
summary: Central banks in emerging Asia are facing risks as they struggle to revive slowing growth and maintain financial stability. In response to European and Japanese central banks' unconventional policy moves, including negative interest rates, Asian central banks are reviewing their own policies. Concerns about destabilizing spillovers and a potential "race to the bottom" for rates and currencies are growing, with Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan calling for global coordination to assess the impact of unconventional monetary policies.

site_title: China Mobile 2015 profit falls 0.6%, in line with estimates
summary: China Mobile reported a 0.6% decline in net profit to 108.5 billion yuan in 2015, in line with estimates. Revenue rose 2.6% to 668 billion yuan. The company's 4G expansion efforts contributed to revenue growth, with data services surpassing voice calls and text for the first time. China Mobile's total mobile subscribers reached 826 million, with 300 million on 4G contracts. Despite a 1.8% decline in shares, the company's chairman noted that 4G expansion will be a key focus for 2016.

images.alt_text: China's largest mobile phone carrier China Mobile said on Thursday its net profit slipped 0.6 per cent last year, broadly in line with estimates, as smaller rivals gained ground in the deployment of lucrative fourth-generation (4G) services.

site_title: Australian submarines should be built entirely at home - Germany's TKMS
summary: Germany's ThyssenKrupp AG has endorsed building Australia's new submarine fleet entirely within the country, citing it as the best option. The firm's bid comes ahead of a decision on a $50 billion contract, with Japan and France also vying for the deal. The decision is expected within months, with the contract and resulting jobs being a key issue in the upcoming Australian national election.

site_title: China: Shares jump to two-month high in Hong Kong as oil gains
summary: Chinese stocks rose 1.9% in Hong Kong, reaching a two-month high, after oil jumped and US Federal Reserve officials lowered their interest-rate forecasts. PetroChina and Ping An Insurance Group Co. led gains, while Premier Li Keqiang said the government will use "innovative measures" to keep economic growth on track. The Fed held its benchmark rate target steady, down from four forecast increases in December. China's economic growth is expected to find new drivers if it drops out of its normal range, amid a sluggish global economy.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, oil rally after Fed lowers rate hike forecasts
summary: Asian stocks, oil prices, and emerging market currencies rallied after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rate hike forecasts, citing concerns over global market turmoil and the US economy. The Fed's more accommodative stance boosted US shares, which extended into Asian trade. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul all rose, while the South Korean won, Australian dollar, and Indonesian rupiah surged against the dollar. Oil prices jumped, driven by a weaker dollar and hopes for a potential output freeze among major producers.

site_title: Rio Tinto CEO Walsh to retire, copper and coal chief to lead company
summary: Rio Tinto CEO Sam Walsh will retire on July 1, 2016, and will be succeeded by Jean-Sébastien Jacques, the company's copper and coal division head. Jacques will join the board and become deputy chief executive immediately. This transition is intended to ensure a smooth handover, with Jacques taking on key responsibilities to lead the company.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto said Chief Executive Sam Walsh will retire July 1, 2016, and will be succeeded by the global miner's copper and coal division head Jean-Sébastien Jacques.

site_title: Australia jobless rate dips, even as employment stalls
summary: Australia's jobless rate fell to 5.8% in February, despite employment stagnating, as fewer people searched for work. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) welcomed the drop, citing it as a positive sign for the labor market. The RBA's interest rate stance remains uncertain, with a 50-50 chance of a rate cut by August. The Australian dollar rose to an eight-month high following the data, as investors responded to the RBA's interest rate expectations.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks jump to year's high on dovish Fed stance
summary: The South Korean won surged to a year-high of 1,174.4 per dollar after the US Federal Reserve revised its interest rate hike forecast, reducing the number of expected hikes this year. The local currency rose 1.6% and South Korean shares hit a three-month high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 1.1% to 1,997.12 points. The gains were sustained despite concerns of possible foreign exchange intervention and the ongoing impact of global oil prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares jump on metals, gold, oil, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% by midday, driven by renewed risk appetite after the US Federal Reserve's slower-than-expected interest rate hike, boosting metals, gold, and oil prices. Mining and energy stocks led the way, with BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group up around 3-7.4%. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,181.10.

site_title: Fujifilm questions Toshiba-Canon decision on medical unit deal
summary: Toshiba has granted Canon exclusive negotiation rights for a potential sale of its medical-equipment business, worth more than $6.2 billion, after Fujifilm lost out in a bid. Fujifilm questions the decision, citing a lack of transparency and concerns over the length of time needed to clear antitrust hurdles. Toshiba is under pressure to raise funds amid an accounting scandal and forecasted record losses. The deal's fate is uncertain, with Canon's exclusive negotiation rights set to expire on March 18.

site_title: Yellen revives gold rally as Fed scales back rate outlook
summary: The Federal Reserve signaled it won't raise interest rates as much this year as forecast, reviving gold's rally amid weakening global economic growth. Gold prices surged 2.4% to $1,259.30 an ounce after the Fed's decision, which implies economic growth is weak. Lower rates make gold more competitive against interest-bearing assets, and investors are concerned about the rationality of central bank decisions, especially with the possibility of negative interest rates.

site_title: Denmark tops global 'happy' index, Burundi at bottom
summary: Denmark tops the 2016 World Happiness Report, followed closely by Switzerland, while Syria and Burundi are ranked as the most miserable countries. The report, published by the United Nations, analyzed data from 2005-2015 to find that six factors, including GDP per capita and social support, explain 75% of the variation in happiness across countries. The US ranks 13th, with Germany 16th and France 32nd, while China and India rank 83rd and 118th respectively.

site_title: China steel, iron ore rise as dovish Fed lifts risk-appetite
summary: Chinese iron ore and steel futures rose as the US Federal Reserve signaled fewer interest rate increases this year, boosting risk-appetite globally. Iron ore and steel prices in China climbed, with May rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange up 2.7% to 2,046 yuan a tonne. However, analysts say seasonal demand in China remains slow and spot prices of construction steel products continue to drop. Chinese steel demand is expected to pick up by end-March or early April, but prices may not rise sharply due to weak seasonal demand.

site_title: Oil advances as US output falls amid slowing stockpile growth
summary: Oil prices rose for a second day, advancing 2.4% in New York after US output fell to its lowest level since November 2014 and crude inventories expanded by 1.3 million barrels. Producers are finalizing a plan to discuss freezing output at a meeting in Doha on April 17. Despite a rebound in oil prices this year, analysts say the price needs fundamentals to catch up, and the freeze may have limited impact if it doesn't include Iran. Oil prices rose to $39.38 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate.

site_title: Temasek unit Fullerton appoints head of multi-asset strategies
summary: Fullerton Fund Management Co, a unit of Singapore's Temasek Holdings, has appointed Pranay Gupta as head of multi-asset strategies. The new role aims to offer diversified investment solutions combining different asset classes to cater to clients seeking enhanced returns. Gupta, a seasoned investment professional, joins from Swiss private bank Lombard Odier and ING Investment Management. Established in 2003, Fullerton Fund Management has assets under management of S$13 billion, and the appointment is seen as a move to capitalize on increasing investor demand for multi-asset investing amid market volatility.

site_title: Thailand's TCC said to get 3.2b euro loan for Big C buy
summary: TCC Holding Co, a Thai conglomerate, has secured a 3.2 billion euro (S$4.9 billion) bridge loan to fund its acquisition of a controlling stake in Big C Supercenter Pcl. The loan is provided by nine banks, with some lenders committing up to 500 million euros each. The acquisition price for the remaining shares won't exceed 86.5 billion baht (S$3.4 billion). The deal is part of TCC's larger acquisition of Big C, which was agreed upon last month for 3.1 billion euros. The loan will likely be drawn down by the end of the month.

site_title: Hitachi opens first US train plant to build metrocars in Miami
summary: Hitachi Ltd opened its first US train plant in Miami, marking the start of Metrorail vehicle production for Miami-Dade County. The plant will build 136 cars, replacing the existing fleet, with the first new vehicles set to enter service in late 2017. The facility is expected to create 100 jobs, with production continuing until the first half of 2019. This move follows Hitachi's expansion of its overseas rail operations amid declining domestic demand in Japan.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars extend gains after jobs, GDP and Fed
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged in value after the US Federal Reserve announced it would reduce its interest rate hike expectations to two from four in 2016. The New Zealand dollar rose 1.5 cents to US$0.6746, while the Australian dollar reached an eight-month peak of US$0.7594. Solid domestic data, including a 2.3% annual GDP growth and a surprise drop in Australian unemployment, also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Glencore expects as much as US$1b for Australia coal trains
summary: Glencore, a Swiss-based mining and trading giant, has put its coal trains in Australia, called GRail, up for sale, aiming to fetch up to A$1.5 billion. The sale is part of Glencore's plan to cut debt by around US$8 billion this year. The fleet, which hauls 51 million tonnes of coal annually, is expected to fetch a sale price of above A$1 billion, based on recent Australian infrastructure sales. The sale process is expected to begin in mid-April, with a deal hoped to be closed by September.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees trading boost from year-old digital platform
summary: Credit Suisse has seen a significant boost in trading activity on its digital platform, with the overall value of trades doubling in the past few months. The platform, launched a year ago in Singapore, has been extended to Hong Kong and other markets, with the majority of trades being made in the US market. The app allows clients to track their portfolio risk and simulate past events, enabling them to broaden their investment perspectives and asset allocation. This shift is attributed to clients using the app at convenient times, such as 10am and 10pm Singapore time.

site_title: Frank Sinatra Jr, son of famed actor and singer, dies
summary: Frank Sinatra Jr., son of legendary singer and actor Frank Sinatra, died on March 16, 2016, at 72 due to cardiac arrest while on tour in Daytona, Florida. Sinatra was set to perform his father's songs at the Peabody Auditorium, but the event was canceled after his illness. Sinatra Jr. never felt ashamed of not reaching his father's level of fame, citing the changing music landscape of his time. His sister, Nancy Sinatra, announced his passing on Facebook, saying "Sleep warm, Frankie."

site_title: Japan Feb exports fall 4% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 4% in February from a year earlier, slower than the previous month's decline, but still lower than economists' expectations. The decline followed a 12.9% year-on-year drop in January. Imports fell 14.2% in the year to February. The trade balance came to a surplus of 242.8 billion yen, less than the median estimate. The slowdown in emerging markets is a concern for future export growth.

site_title: Japan exports to China rise in February, boosted by post holiday demand
summary: Japan's exports to China rose 5.1% in February, the first gain in seven months, driven by increased demand for automobiles, metal processing machinery, and engines. This boost contributed to Japan's trade surplus of 242.8 billion yen. However, overall Japanese exports fell 4.0% from the same period last year, while imports declined 14.2% due to lower energy prices. The increase in exports was seen as distorted by the timing of the Lunar New Year holiday, and analysts caution that the trend is weak, with energy prices expected to rise in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Japanese exports to China rose for the first time in seven months in February, the government announced on Thursday, though analysts said the gain was distorted by the timing of the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Noble in advanced talks with banks for unsecured loan, said to be for US$1.5b
summary: Singapore-listed Noble Group is in advanced talks with banks to raise a US$1.5 billion unsecured loan to repay its debt maturing in May, potentially alleviating investor concerns over its financials. The one-year loan, not backed by assets, would be structured as a revolving credit facility and would help the loss-making commodity trader meet most of its debt obligations for this year. Noble has denied accounting claims and has around US$2.1 billion of debt maturing in May.

site_title: PBOC raises yuan fixing after US dollar drops on Fed rate outlook
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, raised the yuan's daily fixing by 0.32% to 6.4961 per US dollar, its largest increase in almost a week, following a drop in the US dollar due to reduced expectations of Federal Reserve interest-rate hikes. The move aims to prevent the currency from strengthening too much, according to experts.

images.alt_text: China's central bank raised the yuan's daily fixing by the most in almost a week after a scaling back of Federal Reserve interest-rate expectations prompted a drop in the greenback.

site_title: SME optimism dips amid economic headwinds
summary: Singapore Business Federation's latest SBF-DP SME Index shows SME optimism dipping to "neutral" after six years of optimism amid economic headwinds, with a score of 50.0. This is the lowest score since the index's inception in 2010. The survey of 3,600 SMEs indicates no expected growth in the next six months.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance as dovish Fed gives boost to risk assets, US dollar under pressure
summary: Asian stocks rose on Thursday, March 17, after the Federal Reserve signaled it won't raise interest rates as quickly as expected this year. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 1.1% as US stocks reached their highest level this year, with the S&P 500 rising 0.6% on Wednesday. The Fed's decision boosted risk assets and put pressure on the US dollar. Energy shares advanced as US oil climbed 5.8% on Wednesday, and commodity producers rallied. The Asian market has gained 13% since its low last month, with the Bank of Japan refraining from expanding monetary policy.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks draw foreign buying as bull market approaches
summary: Taiwan's equities are attracting significant foreign investment, with inflows surpassing other Asian peers and the benchmark Taiex index up 17% from its bear-market low. Investors are optimistic about President-elect Tsai Ing-wen's economic policies, which focus on biotechnology, green technology, and national defense. Foreign asset managers have poured US$2.9 billion into Taiwanese shares in March, the second month of net inflows. The Taiex is trading near its highest level relative to the broader MSCI Asia Pacific Index in about a decade, with traders loading up on options to protect against declines.

site_title: Michigan driver charged with murder files US$10m lawsuit against Uber
summary: Jason Dalton, a Michigan Uber driver charged with murdering six people, has filed a $10 million federal civil rights lawsuit against the company, claiming it ruined his life and discriminates against him due to his mental health. Dalton, 45, wrote in the lawsuit that Uber prioritizes profits over its drivers. The lawsuit, filed in US District Court in Detroit, is a response to the charges against him.

site_title: Air India flight evacuated after false bomb scare: Bangkok airport
summary: Air India Flight 332, carrying 231 passengers from Delhi, was evacuated at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport after a false bomb threat was reported. The flight was ordered to park in an isolated area, and after a search, no suspicious objects were found. The airport called off the emergency operation, and the passengers were allowed to disembark safely. The incident occurred late Wednesday, and authorities later confirmed that there was no threat.

site_title: Saudi Aramco, Shell plan to break up Motiva, divide up assets
summary: Shell and Saudi Aramco announced plans to break up Motiva Enterprises LLC, a US oil refining and marketing joint venture, after nearly two decades. Under the agreement, Saudi Aramco will retain the Motiva name, own the Port Arthur, Texas refinery, and 26 distribution terminals. Shell will assume ownership of the Norco, Louisiana refinery, Convent, Louisiana refinery, nine distribution terminals, and Shell-branded markets in Florida, Louisiana, and the Northeastern region. The deal will see Saudi Aramco use the Shell brand for gasoline and diesel sales in specific US markets.

site_title: Wealth managers get budget boost from UK savings rule changes
summary: UK Finance Minister George Osborne announced budget changes to encourage people to save more, boosting wealth managers. The changes include increasing the Individual Savings Account (ISA) savings allowance to £20,000 per year from April 2017 and introducing a new 'Lifetime ISA' for those under 40, with a government match of up to £32,000 over a lifetime. Shares in wealth managers St James's Place and Hargreaves Lansdown rose following the announcement. However, a former pensions minister expressed caution about the potential impact on pension savings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher as Fed lowers rate hike outlook
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.59% on Thursday, following US Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen's lowered interest rate hike outlook. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 20,580.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The US interest rate decision was seen as a positive signal for the markets, contributing to the gains.

site_title: British budget extends austerity, cuts growth outlook
summary: The UK government has released its annual budget, extending austerity measures and cutting its growth outlook to 2% this year and 2.2% next year, citing global market turbulence and China's economic slowdown. Finance Minister George Osborne warned that a potential Brexit would risk damaging the nation's economic recovery. The budget includes significant tax cuts for businesses and the oil and gas industry, but also includes additional spending cuts of £3.5 billion by 2020.

site_title: China's exporters struggle as yuan swings disrupt business
summary: China's exporters are struggling due to the yuan's volatility, which has made it difficult for companies like Midea Group Co and TCL Corp to manage costs. The currency has swung 4.8% since last year's devaluation, with fluctuations holding near the highest levels since August's shock devaluation. Exports slumped 25% in February, and a gauge of overseas orders contracted for the 17th month in a row. The yuan's volatility has led to capital outflows of an estimated $1 trillion last year, and economists predict a 4.1% drop in the currency by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.690 points to 1696.620. The market saw 160 gainers and 52 losers, with a total volume of 53.9 million lots worth RM27.47 million.

site_title: Virtual reality girds for test in marketplace
summary: Virtual reality technology is poised to enter the mainstream market, with the Oculus Rift headset expected to launch in the US for $599. The device, which uses computer-generated images to create a sense of presence, has the potential to revolutionize industries such as education, healthcare, and social interaction. Analysts predict sales of 12 million headsets by the end of the year, with some experts predicting VR will become a $30 billion market by 2020. However, others believe augmented reality will surpass VR in popularity and impact the smartphone and tablet market.

site_title: Connecticut governor will make US$65.2m of mid-year budget cuts
summary: Connecticut Governor Dannel Malloy announced $65.2 million in mid-year budget cuts due to a potential budget shortfall of up to $900 million. The cuts, effective April 1, include reductions to services for people with developmental disabilities, corrections, education, and other departments. Officials struggle with a weak stock market, which has led to a decrease in capital gains tax receipts. Moody's Investor Service has revised its outlook for the state's debt to negative, citing demographic strain. The state has also canceled pay raises for managers at state agencies.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on dovish Fed outlook
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Thursday as investors reacted positively to the Federal Reserve's decision not to hike interest rates and offering a more dovish economic outlook. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.78% to 17,107.60, while the Topix index rose 0.65% to 1,369.38. The dovish Fed outlook boosted investor sentiment, leading to a higher opening in Tokyo's stock market.

site_title: After Trump pulls out, Fox News cancels Republican debate
summary: Fox News canceled the Republican presidential debate scheduled for next week in Utah after Donald Trump declined to participate, citing that the Republicans "had enough debates." Rival John Kasich also announced he would skip the debate unless Trump changes his mind. Trump criticized Fox News, calling its host Megyn Kelly "crazy" and "unwatchable," and hinted at a "big speech" on the night of the debate. This marks the first time a debate has been canceled by a party.

site_title: Singapore non-oil domestic exports up 2.1% in February
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 2.1% in February, beating market expectations of a 2.6% dip. This rebound follows a 10.1% year-on-year decline in January. Non-electronic exports, which account for the majority of NODX, increased 2.7% in February, reversing a 14.1% drop in the previous month. Shipments to the EU, Hong Kong, and Japan were the top contributors to the expansion.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, up 31.75 points or 1.12% to 2,875.96, driven by banks DBS, OCBC Bank, and UOB. The Federal Reserve cut its US economy outlook and kept interest rates unchanged, citing global slowdown and market turmoil. As of 9:01am, 119.5 million shares worth S$96.2 million had changed hands, with 114 gainers outnumbering 18 losers.

site_title: FedEx profit down due to TNT acquisition costs, court case
summary: FedEx Corp reported a quarterly net income of $507 million, down nearly 20% from last year, due to costs related to its pending TNT acquisition and settling a legal case over FedEx Ground drivers. Despite this, the company's shares rose 5% after it forecast full-year earnings within a range of $10.70 to $10.90 per share. Revenue rose 9% to $12.7 billion, driven by a 30% jump in FedEx Ground unit revenue. The European Commission approved FedEx's $6.56 billion bid for TNT in January, which is expected to move FedEx to second place in Europe.

site_title: LG Display says to invest in new OLED lighting panel plant
summary: LG Display plans to invest in a new OLED lighting panel plant in South Korea, set to begin mass production in the first half of 2017. The investment aims to expand the use of next-generation panel technology beyond TVs and mobile devices. Details on the investment amount are not disclosed. This move is part of the company's efforts to diversify its applications for the panel technology.

images.alt_text: Consumer electronics screen maker LG Display Co Ltd said on Thursday it will build a new production plant that will manufacture organic light-emitting diode panels for its lighting business in South Korea.

site_title: Australia's central bank would prefer a lower Australian dollar
summary: Australia's central bank prefers a lower Australian dollar to boost exports and domestic economies, but notes it's challenging due to other countries seeking weaker currencies. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor Guy Debelle stated that "practically every central bank in the world" wants a depreciating currency. His comments came after the US dollar fell following the Federal Reserve's signal of slower rate hikes this year.

site_title: JPMorgan, Citi shareholders to vote on potential breakup plans: WSJ
summary: Shareholders of JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup Inc will vote on whether the two banks should break up into smaller pieces, a proposal requested by a shareholder. The vote will be included in their proxy filings and held at a shareholder meeting later this year. This move comes as part of the ongoing debate on breaking up large banks in the US, with presidential candidate Bernie Sanders proposing to create a "too-big-to-fail list" and break up financial institutions in his administration. The outcome of the vote is expected to be closely watched by investors and regulators.

site_title: Cyber criminals snap up expired domains to serve malicious ads
summary: Cyber criminals are targeting visitors of popular news and entertainment websites by serving malicious ads on expired domains. The hackers gained ownership of an expired web domain of an advertising company and used it to serve malware to users who clicked on the ads. The affected websites include the New York Times, Newsweek, BBC, and AOL. Security researchers found multiple expired "media"-related domains used by the same cyber criminals, suggesting they may be monitoring for similar domains to exploit. The attacks may have had an impact on ads from third-party companies beyond the control of the affected websites.

site_title: Update: Protests erupt in Brazil after Lula appointed minister
summary: Protests erupted in Brazilian cities after President Dilma Rousseff appointed Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva as chief of staff. The move was seen as an attempt to shield Lula from prosecution on charges of money laundering and fraud. A leaked phone conversation between Lula and Rousseff appeared to show they discussed influencing a corruption investigation. Lula has immunity from prosecution except for the Supreme Court, and Rousseff defended the appointment, saying it was based on Lula's experience and fiscal stability record.

site_title: Apple needs you to upgrade your phone (pretty please): Gadfly editorial
summary: Apple is set to unveil a new iPhone model, potentially called the iPhone SE, at an event on Monday. The device is expected to have the same dimensions as the 2013 iPhone 5S but with updated computer chips and features. The new iPhone will likely replace the 5S, which is still being sold for $450, and may have the same price. The move is seen as a response to Apple's first down year for iPhone sales.

site_title: Japan's Inpex to cut Indonesian workforce by 40%: regulator
summary: Japan's Inpex Corp plans to delay sanctioning its Masela Abadi liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in Indonesia by at least two years due to uncertain government decisions. As a result, the company will reduce its Indonesian workforce by 40%. The project, jointly developed with Royal Dutch Shell, aims to produce 7.5 million tonnes of LNG per year with an estimated price tag of over $14 billion. Inpex will continue with front-end engineering design while adjusting staffing levels in line with the company's workload once a decision is made.

site_title: Day of reckoning imminent for India's troubled lenders
summary: India's troubled lenders face a "day of reckoning" as the Reserve Bank of India completes its audit of all 50 banks by the end of March, forcing them to reveal hidden non-performing loans. Total non-performing loans are expected to reach 18% of total lending, with US$131 billion already disclosed and potentially US$36 billion more. Banks are struggling to recover debt from struggling companies, and the government is planning to invest at least 250 billion rupees in lenders to boost capital ratios. Analysts warn of a higher chance of a banking crisis due to India's lack of a legal system for resolving disputes.

site_title: GLP leases 161,000 sq ft to e-commerce retailer in Greater Tokyo
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) signed a 161,000-square-foot lease with e-commerce retailer Akachan House at GLP Narita in Greater Tokyo. The facility will support same-day distribution for Akachan House's e-commerce operations in Japan. GLP President Yoshiyuki Chosa expressed delight in growing its relationship with the retailer, citing strong domestic consumption and demand for modern logistics facilities. The lease consolidation marks Akachan House's move to consolidate its operations into a single, well-located facility.

site_title: Feeling global slowdown, Fed keeps interest rate unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing a global slowdown and turmoil in world markets. The Fed's outlook for the US economy was less bullish than expected, with forecasted interest rate hikes expected to slow this year. This decision diverges from other central banks, such as the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, which have cut interest rates to combat deflation. The Fed's move reflects the ongoing impact of global economic uncertainty on the US economy.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes at 2016 high as Fed signals fewer rate hikes
summary: The US stock market closed at its highest level of 2016, with the S&P 500 reaching 2,027.22, as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged and signaled fewer rate hikes for the year. The Fed cited moderate economic growth and strong job gains, but noted global economic uncertainty. Stocks rose across sectors, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 74.23 points, and the Nasdaq Composite up 35.30 points.

site_title: Brazil police tapped Rousseff discussing Lula cabinet post
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff and her predecessor Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva discussed Lula's potential cabinet appointment, with Rousseff sending a document confirming his nomination. The conversation, obtained by tapping Lula's phone as part of a corruption investigation, has fueled speculation that Rousseff offered Lula the job to shield him from the probe. The revelation has sparked outrage among opposition lawmakers and critics, and the Supreme Court has ruled that only it can now investigate Lula. The situation is escalating, with hundreds of protesters demanding Rousseff's ouster and her allies jumping ship from the ruling coalition.

site_title: Traders see fewer US rate hikes after Fed forecast
summary: US Federal Reserve officials cut their estimates on the number of interest rate hikes through 2018, with traders now predicting only two quarter-point increases in 2016. The Fed's rate projection implies a more modest increase in the federal funds rate this year, contradicting policymakers' more optimistic outlook on the economy. Traders have pared expectations for a June rate hike and now see a 54% chance of a September rate hike.

site_title: Michelle Obama says has no plans to seek presidency
summary: Michelle Obama has stated she has no plans to run for president, citing the desire to have more impact outside of Washington's polarized politics. She made the remarks at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Texas, after introducing a charity song to support girls' education. Obama, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has distaste for the glare of political life and wants to focus on issues such as fighting obesity. She also wants her daughters to have a normal life after eight years in the White House.

site_title: Britain's surprise tax on sugary drinks delights health campaigners
summary: Britain's government has announced a two-year plan to introduce a sugar levy on soft drinks, expected to raise £500 million annually. The tax, which will apply to drinks with over 5 grams of sugar per 100ml, aims to tackle the growing obesity crisis and reduce consumption of high-calorie products. The move has been welcomed by health campaigners, but criticized by the drinks industry, which claims it will lead to job losses and price increases.

site_title: Trump warns of 'riots' if denied White House nomination
summary: Donald Trump warned that riots could occur if he is denied the Republican presidential nomination. Despite winning several primaries, Trump lost in Ohio, potentially falling short of the delegates needed to secure the nomination. This comes as the US campaign has been marked by controversy and a divided electorate. The outcome of the nomination remains uncertain, with the Republican convention in Cleveland in July. Trump's ability to unite his party remains unclear, raising concerns about the party's unity ahead of the convention.

site_title: Bank of China considering its options in Italy money laundering case
summary: Bank of China is considering options in an Italian money laundering case, where over 4.5 billion euros were allegedly laundered through its Milan branch between 2006 and 2010. The bank denies wrongdoing and is exploring settlement options, including a possible out-of-court deal. The case involves 300 individual defendants and four officials from the bank's Milan branch, accused of failing to report suspicious transactions and concealing funds. A trial is set to begin in Florence, with a judge deciding whether to order a trial or archive the case.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff says central bank chief, finance minister to stay
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff denied reports that her finance minister and central bank chief would leave the government after appointing former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva as a minister. Rousseff stated Lula is committed to fiscal stability and controlling inflation, and Brazil's international reserves will not be used to solve investment issues. She also emphasized that Lula's appointment does not exempt him from investigation, as the highest court would still have the right to try him. Rousseff's move aims to maintain stability in the government amidst Lula's recent appointment.

site_title: EU seeks to tweak Turkey deal to make it legal
summary: The European Union is seeking to tweak a deal with Turkey to halt the flow of migrants into Europe, aiming to make it legally watertight. The deal would involve Turkey taking back migrants and refugees who enter the EU from its shores or territorial waters, in exchange for more money, faster visa-free travel, and accelerated EU membership negotiations. However, a standoff with Cyprus, which has veto power over EU accession talks with Turkey, could scupper the deal, with Cyprus demanding recognition of its statehood and equal treatment of all member states.

site_title: Italy state railways eyeing Greek railway network
summary: Italy's state railways, Ferrovie dello Stato, is considering bidding for Greece's rail network TrainOSE as part of its plans to privatize national rail services to reduce public debt. The deadline for initial bids is March 21, with qualified investors submitting binding bids on April 26. Other shortlisted bidders include Russian Railways, SNCF Participations, and SC Grup Feroviar Roman. This follows Greece's relaunch of the privatization process as part of its international bailout agreement.

site_title: Chipotle mulls more food giveaways as customers slowly return
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill has recovered about one-third of sales lost due to food safety lapses in 2015, and plans to send 21 million free food coupons to US consumers as part of its turnaround strategy. The company has seen redemption rates of 67% for mobile coupons, and executives expect these offers to spur visits and paid transactions. Despite slow recovery in some regions, sales and visits have improved, and paid transactions are 30% lower than last year.

images.alt_text: Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc has recovered about one-third of sales lost to a string of food safety lapses last year, and more free offers may be forthcoming as part of its turnaround strategy, executives said at a conference on Wednesday.
