site_title: US dollar sinks as Fed forecasts slower rate hikes
summary: The US dollar fell after the Federal Reserve forecasted a slower path for future rate hikes and reduced its US growth outlook. The benchmark federal funds rate remained at 0.25-0.5% as expected. The Fed's more dovish tone, citing global slowdown and market turmoil, was a surprise to many. The decision was seen as a response to the ongoing global economic uncertainty, which may impact US economic growth and interest rates.

images.alt_text: The US dollar dived Wednesday after the Federal Reserve forecast a slower path for future rate hikes and cut its growth outlook for the US economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end steady before Fed policy decision
summary: European stocks ended steady before the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index closing up 0.02% at 1,341.8 points. US inflation rose more than expected, bolstering the case for higher interest rates. Energy and auto stocks gained, while the banking sector fell 1.3%. The Fed's policy decision will show how comfortable policymakers are with gradual rate increases.

site_title: Derailing the Donald getting quite remote
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign has defied expectations, winning key primaries in Florida, Illinois, North Carolina, and Missouri, despite violence and turmoil during his rallies. Trump's rivals, including Marco Rubio and John Kasich, had hoped the chaos would slow his momentum, but instead, it rallied support behind him. Trump now holds 200 more pledged delegates than his closest rival, Ted Cruz, and is likely to amass the largest number of delegates by July, when the Republican convention takes place. Despite this, Trump will likely fall short of the 1,237 delegates needed to win the nomination, potentially allowing Cruz to assemble a majority.

site_title: Gold miner Anchor Resources eyes profit by end of year
summary: Singapore-based gold mining group Anchor Resources aims to turn a profit by the end of 2016, despite nine years of full-year net losses. The company's initial public offering was fully subscribed, with 28.8 million shares sold at S$0.25 each, generating S$4.6 million in net proceeds. Anchor Resources plans to expand its gold processing capacity and develop its mines in Malaysia, aiming to produce 600,000 tonnes of gold per annum by 2017. Founder Lim Chiau Woei expects the company to generate a positive cash flow by the end of 2016.

site_title: Nike unwraps new self-tying shoe
summary: Nike unveiled its first self-tying shoe, the HyperAdapt 1.0, which will be sold at the end of 2016. The shoe features adaptive lacing that activates when a foot slips in, and can be loosened or tightened with buttons on the side. This technology is part of a larger innovation effort by Nike, inspired by its previous "power laces" shoe, the Nike Mag, which was inspired by the film Back To The Future, Part II. The shoe will be sold via auction with proceeds going to the Michael J Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

site_title: Four S'poreans arrested under ISA for involvement in armed violence abroad
summary: Four Singapore citizens, Mohammad Razif Yahya, Amiruddin Sawir, Mohamed Mohideen Mohamed Jais, and Wang Yuandongyi, have been dealt with under the Internal Security Act (ISA) for their involvement in armed violence abroad. Razif and Amiruddin were detained for fighting in Yemen's sectarian conflict, while Mohideen was issued a Restriction Order for performing armed sentry duties. Wang Yuandongyi was turned back from traveling to Turkey and Syria to join a Kurdish militia group after being located by authorities. The Ministry of Home Affairs stated that the individuals pose a security threat to Singapore due to their readiness to use violence to pursue their religious cause.

site_title: CPI rise in February keeps Fed on course for rate hikes
summary: The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.3% in February, exceeding expectations, with underlying inflation increasing 2.3% over the past 12 months, the largest gain since May 2012. This increase could keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in June, despite the conclusion of a two-day meeting. Strong demand for machinery and steel led to a manufacturing slowdown easing, while housing starts rebounded in February, reaching a five-month high.

site_title: Germany says to spend 264b euros on roads, railways by 2030
summary: Germany plans to spend 264 billion euros on road, railway, and waterway infrastructure by 2030, the largest investment program on infrastructure in the country's history. Nearly 70% of the budget will be allocated to repairing existing infrastructure, with a focus on modernization over the next 15 years. The move aims to rebalance the country's mainly export-driven economy and boost domestic consumption. This initiative is in response to international pressure to increase spending on infrastructure and reduce its trade surplus.

site_title: MDA to allow shorter terms for pay-TV contracts
summary: The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) has finalized measures to enhance consumer protection for pay-TV content. Key changes include allowing customers to opt for contracts lasting 12 months or less, eliminating early termination charges (ETCs) for exiting contracts within 30 days, and requiring operators to provide a critical information summary (CIS) and written contract copies. The MDA aims to address consumer concerns about unilateral contract changes and equipment charges. Pay-TV operators, including Singtel and StarHub, are reviewing the proposed amendments.

site_title: Loans get scarcer for US developers trying to finish jobs
summary: US developers are facing challenges in securing funding for their projects due to lenders becoming more selective and cautious. Economic uncertainty, including a slowing economy, oil price slump, and strong dollar, is spooking lenders, leading to higher loan costs and increased risk of defaults. Despite this, well-funded buyers are still making record-setting deals for high-quality assets. Property owners are also dealing with overbuilding, declining stock values, and a slowdown in China, making it difficult to keep projects afloat.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's property sector saw a 23% year-on-year drop in new private residential units sold in February, with sales volume in OCR growing 5% and central region falling 41%. Despite recent launches, developers focused on marketing unsold stock, and prices must remain attractive for sales. Meanwhile, Singapore's telco sector is expected to face competition from a potential new player, with some 3-4% of mobile service revenue at risk. Singtel remains a top pick due to its least risk from new competition.

site_title: Strong Q1 euro-bond offerings from Singapore firms
summary: Singapore-based firms raised US$6.6 billion in euro-bond offerings in the first quarter, a 7.7% increase from last year, with euro-denominated bonds hitting US$3.1 billion. The largest issues included Temasek Holdings and United Overseas Bank, which sold euro-denominated bonds at low coupon rates. This surge in euro-bond market activity is driven by low borrowing costs in Europe and strong demand for highly rated debt, while the Singapore-dollar bond market fell 21.6% to S$3.8 billion.

site_title: Property firms tapping bond market to raise funds at attractive rates
summary: Property firms in Singapore are tapping the bond market to raise funds at attractive rates. Ascott Reit issued S$120 million in eight-year bonds with a 4% coupon rate, while City Developments (CDL) raised some S$115 million in five-year bonds at a 2.93% coupon rate. The issuers view this as an opportune time to raise cheaper funds due to the weakened USD/SGD exchange rate.

site_title: Japan gains excuse to delay sales tax hike and boost fiscal spending
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been advised by former World Bank chief economist Joseph Stiglitz to delay a planned consumption tax hike from April 1, 2017, to focus on fiscal stimulus instead. This advice comes as the effectiveness of unconventional monetary policy is being questioned, and Japan is seeking to boost its economy ahead of a critical parliamentary election in June. Stiglitz's advice gives Abe a "cover" to delay the tax hike, while also influencing G-7 nations to prioritize fiscal stimulus to ease the strain on monetary policy.

site_title: Human rights remains China's Achilles heel
summary: China's human rights record remains a significant concern, despite the country's rapid economic growth and increasing global influence. A joint statement by 12 countries, including the US, Japan, and European nations, condemned China's crackdown on civil society, including the disappearance of Hong Kong booksellers and the arrest of human rights lawyers. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights also called for China's release of the detained lawyers. China has accused the US and other countries of interfering in its internal affairs, but critics argue that China's human rights problems are ongoing and serious, and cannot be justified by pointing to other countries' shortcomings.

site_title: Industry execs in US call for fast lane for self-driving cars
summary: Industry executives, including Google, Lyft, and General Motors, are urging lawmakers to create a regulatory framework to facilitate the deployment of self-driving cars. They argue that inconsistent state laws and regulations will hinder innovation, safety, and interstate commerce. The executives emphasize the need for a consistent approach to ensure the safe operation of autonomous vehicles across state boundaries. The Senate panel heard testimony from experts, including Chris Urmson, who heads Google's self-driving car project, and Mary Cummings, who heads the Humans and Autonomy Laboratory at Duke University, highlighting the importance of rigorous testing and evaluation to ensure safety.

site_title: Amid economic headwinds, BNM's Zeti will be a hard act to follow
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), will face a challenge in finding a successor to outgoing Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz, who will retire at the end of April. With the country's economy facing headwinds, including falling oil prices and exports, the new central bank chief will need to provide steady and credible leadership to inspire confidence. The appointment is crucial given the economic challenges, including a looming political crisis and a commodity slump. Zeti's departure leaves a void, and her successor will need to be judged on merit, track record, and integrity.

site_title: Trump, Clinton tighten their grip on nominations
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton tightened their grip on nominations after Tuesday's primaries in five states. Trump won Illinois and North Carolina but lost Ohio to John Kasich, while Clinton won Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina. Trump remains the front-runner with 99% of delegates needed, but a chaotic national convention in Cleveland is possible. Clinton leads Bernie Sanders by a large margin, with 1,561 delegates needed to win. The candidates will head to Arizona and Utah primaries on March 22, with no big-state contests on the Republican side until Wisconsin on April 5.

site_title: Chua Hak Bin another prominent casualty of economic slowdown
summary: Prominent economist Chua Hak Bin, head of Asean economics at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, was let go on March 15 amid a regional banking industry pullback. The move comes as foreign banks in Singapore pare their local operations, with Barclays, Standard Chartered, and the Royal Bank of Scotland also laying off staff. The departure occurs just before Singapore's 2016 Budget unveiling on March 24, and follows a reported 15 senior banker cuts by BoAML in Asia, including three managing directors and 12 directors.

site_title: US$ firmer as investors await Fed signal
summary: The US dollar strengthened against a basket of currencies, rising 0.25% to 96.874, as investors await the Federal Reserve's guidance on interest rate hikes. The dollar index is 0.3% higher against the yen at 113.55, while the euro fell 0.2% to US$1.10855. Market expectations suggest a 50% chance of a quarter-point interest rate hike in June, with the Fed likely to signal a rate hike and four hikes until December, boosting the dollar.

site_title: Economy hotels likely to be worst hit in 2016: HVS poll
summary: A survey by HVS predicts a 10.3% decline in average revenue for Singapore's economy hotel segment in 2016, due to increased supply and competition. This decline is expected to be driven by an 8.3% fall in average daily rates and a 3.0 percentage point drop in occupancy rates.

site_title: Mumbai dance bars to reopen amid worries about more sex crimes
summary: Dance bars in Mumbai and Maharashtra are set to reopen after a 10-year ban, with 150 bars applying for licenses. The decision comes despite concerns from activists that women and girls may be trafficked and abused in these venues. The Supreme Court ordered the state to issue licenses on condition that certain rules are adhered to, but state Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis has expressed opposition to the reopening. The move has raised concerns about human trafficking and exploitation, with activists warning that reopening the bars will legitimize trafficking and abuse.

site_title: Commodity rally threatens to erode US$460b China bonus
summary: China's economy faces challenges as a commodity price rally erodes its US$460 billion annual bonus from cheap imports. Rising iron ore prices, up 21% this year, increase inflationary pressure and limit the central bank's ability to stimulate the economy. The rally also benefits domestic producers but puts pressure on profit margins for industries struggling with slowing growth. The impact on the economy depends on whether steel prices can keep pace with iron ore, with some analysts predicting a slowdown in the country's efforts to cut oversupply.

site_title: Big Japan firms cut wage hikes as Abenomics falters
summary: Japan's major companies are reducing wage hikes for the next fiscal year, citing slowing profit growth, a weakening global outlook, and a strengthening yen. Toyota Motor Corp agreed to a 1,500 yen wage increase, while Nissan Motor Co reduced its hike to 3,000 yen. Panasonic Corp and Hitachi Ltd also agreed to 1,500 yen increases. The trend is seen as a sign that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics efforts to boost the economy are faltering.

site_title: Bumpy ride ahead for insurers Prudential and Aviva
summary: Prudential Singapore and Aviva Singapore face a bumpy ride in the new financial year due to macro and firm-specific factors. Despite reporting 7% and 19% rises in new business profit, respectively, Prudential's new single and regular business premiums dropped, and Aviva's bancassurance tie-up with DBS ended. The insurers must focus on selling more regular premium protection and savings products to drive profits, as Asia's low insurance penetration rate offers untapped opportunities. The challenging outlook is further complicated by tension between agents and management at Prudential and Aviva's need to expand its financial advisory channel.

site_title: Frankfurt, London seal US$30b trading tie-up to counter US threat
summary: Frankfurt-based Deutsche Boerse and London's London Stock Exchange have agreed to a $30 billion merger, creating one of the world's largest exchanges. Despite a potential Brexit vote, the two companies plan to proceed with the merger, with Deutsche Boerse shareholders owning 54.4% and LSE shareholders owning 45.6%. The combined entity will be listed on both exchanges and have equal representation on its board. The merger aims to deliver significant cost and revenue synergies, and is seen as an "industry-defining combination" by the companies.

site_title: US banks create cool technology, and realise it can be sold
summary: US banks, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and JPMorgan Chase, are spinning out or selling technology they've developed in-house to other companies. The technology focuses on data security, mobile applications, and systems integration. While the banks are not yet making significant profits from these efforts, they aim to shift their focus from expenses to revenue streams as regulations limit traditional profit sources. Goldman Sachs has already seen success with its spinoff of Symphony, a messaging system with 75,000 users, and is now working with Synchronoss Technologies to market and sell its mobile data security products.

site_title: Hiap Hoe unit to sell second Melbourne property
summary: Singaporean developer Hiap Hoe has agreed to sell its Melbourne property at 380 Lonsdale Street to Australian developer A&J Brady Pty Ltd for A$60 million (S$61.7 million). The sale, set to be completed by July 31, marks a turnaround for Hiap Hoe's presence in Melbourne after selling its other property at 206 Bourke Street in January for A$116.3 million. Plans for a joint venture to manage the property have also been cancelled.

site_title: 'Sleep box' developer eyes Suvarnabhumi as next target
summary: The Miracle Group, developer of the "sleep box" hotel, is planning to expand its concept to Suvarnabhumi airport. The company is negotiating with Airports of Thailand Plc over the proposal, with the goal of opening a sleep box hotel at the airport this year. The first sleep box hotel is currently operating at Don Mueang airport, offering 25 sleep cabins with room rates starting at 1,000 baht for the first three hours. The Miracle Group sees the sleep box concept as a competitive alternative to Japanese capsule hotels, offering excellent value for passengers waiting for connecting flights.

site_title: Australia, Indonesia renew push for trade deal
summary: Australia and Indonesia plan to resume negotiations for a bilateral trade agreement within 18 months, after a lengthy hiatus due to diplomatic tensions. The talks will focus on areas of common ground, potentially sidestepping contentious issues such as live cattle exports. The agreement aims to boost business links and improve the trade relationship between the two nations, with Indonesia being Australia's 12th-largest trading partner. The move comes after Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's visit to Indonesia last year aimed at smoothing over strained ties.

site_title: Noble's chief operating officer retires
summary: NOBLE Group's chief operating officer, William Cronin, is retiring on March 31, marking the second high-level departure in recent months. Cronin, 53, will remain as a part-time consultant under the title of vice-chairman of Americas. His departure follows that of CFO Robert van der Zalm, who stepped down for a health-related leave. Noble Group has faced scrutiny over its accounting practices since an anonymous research entity accused it of inflating asset prices. The company's share price has recovered partially this year, closing at 41.5 Singapore cents on Wednesday.

site_title: China's monetary policy is 'prudently accommodative'
summary: China's monetary policy is deemed "prudently accommodative" as the country continues to rebalance and consolidate its economy. The current account surplus dropped to 2.7% of GDP, and foreign currency-denominated debt has declined to around a quarter of official foreign reserves. Fiscal policy will be more countercyclical and expansionary, with a budget deficit of 3% of GDP and tax cuts of $95.3 billion. The government is taking measures to reduce excess capacity in manufacturing industries and increase infrastructure investment, including a massive rural power grid upgrade.

site_title: Oracle cloud growth shows promise as company tops estimates
summary: Oracle reports strong profit and revenue growth from its cloud-based businesses, exceeding estimates. The company's sales of key cloud products grew 57% to $583m, driven by a 57-61% increase in sales in the current quarter. Oracle's co-CEO Safra Catz expects the cloud business to continue growing, with gross margins climbing towards the company's target of 80%. The company's stock rose 5.4% in extended trading, and it has gained 6% this year, as it transitions away from traditional software.

site_title: China will hit growth target, avoid hard landing: Li Keqiang
summary: China's Prime Minister Li Keqiang declared the country will meet its growth target this year and avoid mass layoffs, hinting that growth has trumped reform. Despite reform efforts stalling, Li said reform and development aren't contradictory and that China's economy won't have a hard landing. However, analysts argue that the government's focus on mergers and restructuring won't drive productive sector reallocation. The government has set aside 100 billion yuan to relocate laid-off workers, and markets closed higher for the fourth day in a row, with traders expecting more stimulus measures.

site_title: Fooled by false bottom, most US shale firms skip hedging in Q4
summary: US shale oil firms skipped hedging in Q4 due to high costs, despite some producers increasing their hedging positions. The majority of the 28 analysed companies ended the quarter with fewer hedged barrels than when they started, with 16 companies reducing their hedging positions by a total 66 million barrels. Analysts estimate that only 15-20% of 2016 US oil production is hedged, and some cash-strapped drillers may struggle to survive the lower-for-longer price scenario.

site_title: Scientists go rogue by publishing first on Net
summary: Scientists are challenging traditional publishing methods by posting research findings on a publicly accessible website, bioRxiv, before submitting them to scholarly journals. This practice, known as "preprints," aims to speed up the dissemination of scientific results and increase openness in research. Proponents argue that it can help scientists show off their work to prospective employers and benefactors, and that peer review can be conducted after publication. However, journal editors have expressed concerns that preprints can lead to a decline in paper quality and disrupt the traditional journal system.

site_title: Robo-advisers? Nah, says panel
summary: A panel discussion at a Singapore fund management industry gathering expressed skepticism about the ability of robo-advisers to disrupt the asset management and advisory space. Rennie Miller and Sopnendu Mohanty agreed that "robo for advisers" models, where humans manage money with automation, might work. They also noted that hybrid models combining humans and robo-advisers could be successful. The panel members emphasized the importance of the human touch in portfolio management, citing emotional and personal aspects of client needs, and questioned the viability of pure digital models.

site_title: Firms refine travel policies to get more bang for their buck
summary: Corporations in the Asia-Pacific region are tightening their travel policies to stretch their budgets amid a slowing global economy. Firms are slashing their travel budgets by 15-20% in sectors such as banking and finance, while business travel demand from sectors like professional consulting is on the rise. To make the most of their budgets, companies are opting for economy class or budget carriers, with 10-15% of businesses requiring longer flight lengths for business-class tickets. Despite falling fuel prices, airlines are investing in new aircraft and products instead of reducing airfares.

site_title: Vancouver property price hike pushes up country average
summary: Canada's national average home price surpassed the $500,000 mark for the first time in February, driven by Vancouver's soaring real estate market. The average resale price rose 16% to C$503,057, with prices in Vancouver increasing 26% to C$1.1 million. This has raised concerns about lopsided risks in the market, prompting calls for government intervention. Finance Minister Bill Morneau's down-payment requirements may not be enough to address the issue.

site_title: Dublin rents rise above peaks hit a decade ago
summary: Dublin's residential rents rose 0.4% above 2007 highs in the final quarter of 2015, driven by a severe housing shortage. The cost and scarcity of accommodation threaten Ireland's attractiveness to multinational firms, potentially damaging investment and the economy. Despite a surplus of houses after the 2008 crash, a decimated construction industry has failed to meet demand, resulting in rising rents and hampering the mortgage market. The government has introduced rent controls to dampen the market, but the issue persists, affecting workers and the overall economy.

site_title: China clamps down on shadow banking for home downpayments
summary: China's government plans to halt shadow-banking leverage in the housing market, citing risks similar to the US subprime crisis. Total P2P borrowing for home deposits reached 924 million yuan in January, with lenders offering zero-interest loans to cover downpayments. The central bank will bar developers, peer-to-peer networks, and non-banks from offering such loans, and banks will scrutinize mortgage applications. The clampdown aims to stabilize prices in major cities, where online mortgage loans have pushed up prices and fueled speculation.

site_title: Ranhill makes poor debut on Bursa M'sia
summary: Ranhill Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's first IPO listing in 2016, made a poor debut on the Bursa Malaysia stock exchange, opening below its RM1.20 offer price and ending 16% lower at RM1.01. The weak performance was attributed to weak market sentiments and historical baggage, including a non-disclosure breach in 2013. Despite a RM400-500 million IPO, the company was undersubscribed and retail subscribers were returned nearly a third of the subscription price. Analysts expect smaller IPOs to fare better this year.

site_title: Vard to build 4 expedition cruise vessels for Ponant
summary: VARD Holdings has signed a letter of intent to build four luxury expedition cruise vessels for Ponant, a French cruise company. The vessels, valued at approximately 10,000 gross tons, will be delivered between summer 2018 and summer 2019. Each ship can accommodate 180 passengers and a crew of 110, with luxury facilities and environmentally friendly operations. The project aligns with Vard's diversification strategy and realises synergies with majority owner Fincantieri.

site_title: New boss of Russian carmaker Avtovaz enters a lion's den
summary: French executive Nicolas Maure, 55, has taken over as CEO of Avtovaz, Russia's largest carmaker, to turn around the company's declining sales and cut costs. Maure, who previously managed Renault's Romanian business, will focus on weeding out inefficient suppliers and reducing workforce, a task his predecessor Bo Andersson, who was ousted, struggled with. Avtovaz has reported significant losses in recent years, and the company's Russian shareholders have criticized Andersson's job cuts. Maure's appointment aims to modernize the company's operations and improve product quality, with Renault-Nissan and Russian state-owned Rostec backing his move.

site_title: Author alters hit novel in a new edition 20 years later
summary: Karen Hall, author of the 1996 novel "Dark Debts," has released a revised edition 20 years later. Hall had long regretted the book's flaws and made changes, including a new explosive ending, toned-down violence, and character additions. The new edition was published after Hall's former editor, Jonathan Karp, suggested releasing an anniversary edition with Simon & Schuster. Hall had spent 25 years revising the novel, and the new edition marks a fresh start for her writing career.

site_title: First-time US house hunters lose out in busy homebuying season
summary: US first-time homebuyers face significant challenges in the current market, with limited affordable housing options and rising prices outpacing income growth. Despite robust demand, inventory remains scarce, particularly for starter homes, and prices are expected to climb 5% this year, while sales will increase 3%. This is leading to frustration among prospective buyers, who are struggling to afford homes, with starter-home buyers now devoting 38% of their income to housing costs, up from 32% four years ago.

site_title: OKH Global requests trading halt after stock price dives
summary: OKH Global, a Singapore-based investment holding company, halted trading after its stock price plummeted from 52.5 Singapore cents to 35 cents, with 548,000 shares changing hands. The sudden drop occurred amid an Interpol Red Notice issued to CEO Bon Ween Foong, who is wanted by Indonesian authorities on charges of providing false statements for an official document. The company denied involvement in the dispute and reported a net loss of S$2.1 million for the second quarter.

site_title: Consistel puts its name into 4th telco hat
summary: Consistel, a 20-year-old wireless network solutions provider, has announced its intention to challenge MyRepublic for Singapore's fourth telco licence. Consistel aims to raise over S$1 billion through a mix of equity and debt to build a network comparable to existing operators. The company has already built network infrastructure in 800 sites in Singapore and 5,000 sites regionally. Consistel's proposed mobile plans will focus on delivering value through high speed, broad access, and transparent pricing. The bidding process for the New Entrant Spectrum Auction is set to begin in the third quarter of 2016.

site_title: UK budget: infrastructure spending given priority
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne announced a £50 billion infrastructure spending plan to boost the economy, with a focus on transport and Internet connections. The plan includes highway improvements, high-speed trains, and devolution of power to elected mayors. The government aims to encourage corporate spending and employment through Keynesian economics, while also reducing tax rates for large and small companies. To fund the plan, the government plans to close tax loopholes for Internet companies like Amazon and eBay.

images.alt_text: Mr Osborne warned about "a dangerous cocktail of risks" from financial volatility, the slowdown in the economies of China and other nations. He also said Brexit would cause uncertainty and potentially lower growth.

site_title: Economic growth no longer translates into more greenhouse gas: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported that global economic growth did not translate into increased greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector in 2015, for the second consecutive year. Worldwide CO2 emissions stalled at 2014 levels, while the global economy grew by 3.1%. The surge in renewable energy sources, particularly wind, accounted for 90% of new electricity generation, leading to a decoupling of growth and emissions. The findings are seen as a boost to the global fight against climate change, but Greenpeace noted that emissions need to be brought down and more efforts are required to accelerate clean energy deployment.

site_title: Where computers defeat humans, and where they can't
summary: ALPHAGO, an AI system developed by Google's DeepMind, has defeated human Go champion Lee Sedol 4-1 in a tournament, marking a significant milestone in AI's capabilities. Unlike chess, where computers surpassed humans in 1997, Go's complexity and lack of chance or luck make its victory more impressive. This achievement showcases AI's ability to learn and adapt in complex strategy games, raising questions about the future of human-AI interactions and the potential for AI to surpass humans in other domains.

site_title: Valeant investors doubting drugmaker's chief can regain grip
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc, led by CEO Michael Pearson, faced its worst day in history after disappointing financial news and a series of mishaps, including a $600 million typo in a press release and a conference call that left investors baffled. The company's stock price plummeted to $33.51, its lowest ever, as investors lost confidence in its management. Valeant's debt has ballooned to $30 billion, and the company may have to sell non-core assets to pay creditors. The company's top investors, including Pershing Square and Paulson & Co, lost billions of dollars on the stock drop.

site_title: HK luxury land plot prices below expectations
summary: Hong Kong's luxury land plot sale on Wong Ma Kok Road in Stanley fetched HK$2.81 billion, 32% below analyst estimates of HK$4.52 billion and HK$3.8 billion. This is the third government land sale to price below expectations, following a trend of weaker economic growth. The sale comes as Moody's Investors Service downgraded Hong Kong's sovereign credit rating to negative due to mainland China's growing influence and slowing economy. The sale's outcome raises concerns about the health of Hong Kong's expensive property market.

site_title: New painkiller standards in US aim at stemming alarming rise in overdose deaths
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published national guidelines for prescription painkillers, aiming to curb the alarming rise in overdose deaths. The guidelines recommend that doctors first try ibuprofen and aspirin before prescribing opioids, and limit opioid treatment for short-term pain to three days or less. The move is part of a growing backlash against practices that have led to a record 28,647 opioid deaths in 2014. The guidelines are non-binding but could influence medical practice and insurance reimbursement.

site_title: The top may not be too far away for oil prices
summary: Oil prices may reach their peak sooner than expected, with Brent futures recovering to US$41 a barrel, according to the International Energy Agency. Goldman Sachs predicts "green shoots" in the market, but analysts warn that prices may fall again as US production responds to rising prices. The US benchmark may struggle to push past US$50 a barrel this year, with the industry facing losses and a surplus of supply. Analysts predict a temporary rally before prices stabilize, and some forecast prices to return to US$70 in the next year.

images.alt_text: World crude benchmarks may struggle to push past US$50 a barrel this year as any further price recovery only delays the production cuts needed to balance the market, say analysts.

site_title: Obama names Merrick Garland as Supreme Court nominee
summary: President Barack Obama nominated 63-year-old Merrick Garland, a centrist appeals court judge, to fill the vacant Supreme Court seat left by Justice Antonin Scalia's death. The nomination sets the stage for an election-year showdown with Republicans who oppose holding hearings, with some insisting the nomination should be made by the president's successor. Garland, a centrist judge with bipartisan praise, has been a judge since 1997 and previously served in the Justice Department during the Clinton administration. His nomination has the potential to tip the balance from conservative to liberal on the high court.

site_title: Mah Sing says it's time to shop for more land
summary: Malaysia's Mah Sing Group Bhd, the nation's third-largest property developer, is ready to buy more land after holding back in 2015 due to currency and political concerns. The company predicts a rebound in property sales in the second half of 2016 and has a record RM1.4 billion cash pile for land acquisitions. Managing Director Leong Hoy Kum says the market has stabilized and consumer confidence is returning, with shares rising over 7% from a 2013 low. Mah Sing aims to replenish its land bank and sell more "medium range to high-end properties" in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: New York's high-end residential market slows down
summary: New York's high-end residential market has slowed down, with the volume of sales at $5,000 per square foot topping out two years ago. Officials welcome the pause in escalating prices, citing concerns over land prices making it prohibitive to build new rental apartments and small businesses being priced out. Despite a record $100 million sale of a penthouse last year, sales in this price range have been fewer, and developers are adjusting to the market shift. The city's economy remains strong, with diversified job growth, a record number of jobs, and a surge in tourism, but the high-end market slowdown may be a sign of a broader adjustment.

site_title: PlayStation virtual reality gear to launch in October
summary: Sony plans to launch PlayStation VR headgear in October, priced at $399, aiming to make virtual reality mainstream with its gaming console. The headsets are designed for PlayStation 4 consoles and will be accompanied by camera and controller accessories. Over 230 developers are working on games for PlayStation VR, with 50 titles expected to be available by the end of the year. This move is seen as a more affordable option compared to rival headsets that require gaming computers, with Sony's PS4 already selling over 36 million units since its release in 2013.

site_title: US manufacturing output rises in February
summary: US factory output rose 0.2% in February, exceeding economists' expectations, driven by strong demand for machinery and steel. Industrial output overall fell 0.5% due to sagging oil production and utilities output decline. The Fed views the rise in capacity use to 76.7% as a positive sign, suggesting the manufacturing slowdown may be easing.

site_title: Turnbull backs change to Australia's competition laws
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced his support for a change to the country's competition laws, which would reduce the power of big businesses to monopolize markets. The change, known as an "effects test," was recommended by a 2015 economic review. The government also rescinded a planned tax hike on foreign workers in the country. The move aims to promote competition and favor smaller businesses.

site_title: Prudential Singapore's rider up as much as 35%
summary: Prudential Singapore has raised its rider premiums by 5-35% across all age bands, becoming the first Integrated Shield Plan insurer to do so after the implementation of MediShield Life. The increase is due to higher-than-expected claims experience. Prudential's total premiums for its IP and rider plans have risen by 3-14% across different age bands, with the base plan included in the calculation for accurate comparison. The insurer stated that the absolute increase to customers remains the same regardless of the percentage increase.

site_title: Buy the worst markets: Mobius
summary: Templeton Emerging Markets Group executive chairman Mark Mobius advises investors to buy the worst-performing markets, citing the potential for higher returns in bear markets. Mobius notes that emerging markets have been growing faster than developed markets and should account for 30% of a portfolio. He also suggests that state-owned enterprises in Hong Kong have good corporate governance, and predicts oil prices will rise due to falling rig counts and growing demand. Mobius expresses regret over not focusing enough on ownership and control in his investment approach.

images.alt_text: Asked about Chinese companies, Dr Mobius said state-owned enterprises listed in Hong Kong have good corporate governance

site_title: US crude inventories hit another record for 5th straight week: EIA
summary: US crude inventories reached a new record high for the fifth straight week, increasing by 1.3 million barrels to 535.4 million barrels. Gasoline stocks fell by 747,000 barrels and distillate stockpiles fell by 1.1 million barrels. Refinery crude runs rose by 85,000 barrels per day, while US crude imports fell by 355,000 barrels per day. The increase in crude inventories defied expectations of a larger drop.

site_title: Merkel says German economic growth "not bad", but could be better
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Germany's economic growth, at 0.3% per quarter, is "not bad but not exceptionally good either". This growth rate, at 1.7% for 2015, is the strongest in four years. Merkel also expressed concerns about unstable export markets, which she believes could impact the economy.

site_title: Fed meeting: no rate hike expected, but will FOMC turn bullish?
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at a meeting on Wednesday, but may signal more tightening ahead due to signs of strengthening inflation. The Fed's updated policy statement and forecasts for economic growth, unemployment, and inflation will be released, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen explaining the decision in a press conference. Analysts predict one to three rate increases this year, driven by the recent CPI inflation numbers, which are shy of the 2.0% target but show signs of improvement.

site_title: Gain by Dow futures brings market relief
summary: Singapore stocks rose 4.77 points to 2,844.21 on Wednesday, despite a slow trading day, as Dow futures rose 20 points and Europe opened higher. The Straits Times Index had been in the red for most of the day. Wilmar International's shares gained S$0.01, while Macquarie Equities Research predicted a fundamental tailwind for the plantation sector due to rising crude palm oil prices. However, Credit Suisse downgraded Keppel to Underperform, citing a decline in orders, and warned of potential non-performing loans in the offshore and marine sector.

site_title: Economists again cut forecast for Singapore's 2016 GDP growth
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have cut their forecast for the country's 2016 GDP growth to 1.9%, citing a deeper-than-expected manufacturing contraction and slower growth in finance and insurance. The forecast is down from 2.2% a quarter ago, but economists expect better growth in 2017, with a projected 2.5% GDP growth. The trimming of forecasts reflects a more cautious outlook, with economists warning that slow growth may accentuate the risk of misallocation.

site_title: MAS working on initiatives to boost fund industry
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is working on two initiatives to boost the local fund industry: an open-end investment companies (OEIC) framework for mutual funds and an enhanced external fund manager (EFM) programme. The OEIC framework aims to encourage more funds to be legally domiciled in Singapore, while the EFM programme will allow private sector fund managers to manage a portion of Singapore's reserves. The initiatives are expected to create more jobs in the professional services sector and make Singapore an attractive fund domicile location.

site_title: EU seeks to speed up trade defence against cheap Chinese steel
summary: The European Commission plans to speed up trade defense cases against cheap Chinese steel imports, aiming to cut the investigation-to-tariff timeline from nine months to eight months. The proposal includes removing the "lesser duty rule" and updating trade defense measures to better protect the steel sector. EU member states are urged to adopt these proposals, which have been put forward since 2013. The move aims to address the impact of Chinese imports on the steel industry, particularly in Britain where 4,000 jobs were lost in 2015 due to the surge in imports.

site_title: Gate-crashing, cutting in: Anbang's recipe for billions of deals
summary: Anbang Insurance Group Co, led by Chairman Wu Xiaohui, has made several high-stakes deals, including a $12.9 billion offer for Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc, and a $6.5 billion purchase of a luxury-hotel portfolio from Blackstone Group LP. Wu's dealmaking style involves swooping in at the last minute or preempting other bidders, and he often negotiates deals himself, bypassing investment bankers. Analysts say Wu's approach is unconventional, but effective, and his company's assets span multiple countries and industries, with a total value of around $291 billion.

site_title: European travel agents thrive, defying Internet threat
summary: Travel agents in Europe's top three economies continue to thrive despite the rise of the internet. Consumers prefer expert advice and a personal touch when booking holidays, making travel agents a preferred choice. According to a study, 190% tariffs on US goods have not deterred the reliance of a major shoemaker on China, while a major sportswear brand is reviving its running shoe line amid tariff threats. Meanwhile, a hospital operator is exploring expansion in Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: VW dealers in Germany not obliged to take back diesel cars, court rules
summary: A German court ruled that Volkswagen dealers in Germany are not obligated to take back diesel cars with emissions-cheating software, dealing a setback to efforts to rectify the scandal. The ruling, the first of its kind in Germany, found that dealers did not manufacture the faulty vehicles and therefore were not responsible for the emissions-cheating software. The decision may have implications for car dealers worldwide as they face similar lawsuits from owners seeking refunds or replacements.

site_title: 4 Singaporeans arrested under ISA for involvement in armed violence abroad
summary: Four Singaporean citizens, Mohammad Razif Yahya, Amiruddin Sawir, and two unnamed individuals, were arrested under the Internal Security Act (ISA) for involvement in armed violence abroad. They were detained in August 2015 for fighting in the sectarian conflict in Yemen. The arrests were announced by the Ministry of Home Affairs on March 16, 2016. The individuals were dealt with under the ISA, which allows for detention without trial in cases deemed a threat to national security.

site_title: Central banks' "forward guidance" proving a tricky policy tool
summary: Central banks' use of "forward guidance" to influence market expectations is proving tricky, as seen in the European Central Bank's recent mixed message. Forward guidance signals policy intent, but can be confusing and lead to misfires. Central banks like the ECB and Fed are struggling to strike the right balance between providing clarity and avoiding disappointment. This has led to a re-evaluation of the tool, with some, like Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, pulling back from explicit forward guidance. Despite this, forward guidance remains a valid tool, but requires careful communication to avoid policy reversals.

site_title: India to delay quality standards for auto-grade steel imports: sources
summary: India is set to delay the implementation of quality standards for auto-grade steel imports from Japan and South Korea, amid concerns from local carmakers about potential disruption to production. The Bureau of Indian Standards will certify all steel sold in India, but the industry body sought a six-month exemption to complete the documentation process. The delay is expected to be for six months, with the new rules initially set to come into effect on Friday.

site_title: Record breaking AB InBev bond to unlock M&A funding
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) is set to issue a record-breaking corporate bond deal in the European market, attracting 28 billion euros in investor demand. The transaction is expected to unlock billions of euros in M&A funding, following the ECB's newly-announced plans to buy corporate bonds. The deal is expected to be an 11.75 billion euro issue, with investors offered enticing premiums on the jumbo six-part deal. This is the second-largest bond in history for AB InBev, following its US$46 billion January deal.

site_title: UK growth forecasts cut as Osborne lowers corporation tax
summary: Chancellor George Osborne announced the UK economy will grow less quickly than previously forecast, with expected 2% growth this year, 2.2% in 2017, and 2.1% in 2018. Osborne cited global turbulence as the reason for the downgrade and proposed a 4 billion-pound spending cut. He also lowered corporation tax to 17% by 2020 and increased business rates for small companies. The forecasts are predicated on Britain remaining in the European Union, and Osborne made a direct appeal to voters to keep the UK in the EU ahead of the June 23 referendum.

site_title: US housing starts rebound as single-family projects soar
summary: US housing starts rebounded in February, reaching a 5-month high of 1.18 million units, according to the Commerce Department. Single-family starts surged 7.2% to 822,000 units, the highest since November 2007. Economists had forecast a 1.15 million-unit pace. The rebound could boost first-quarter GDP growth estimates, supported by a firming labor market and rising household formation. However, labor and land shortages remain a challenge for builders.

site_title: Noble COO William Cronin to retire on March 31
summary: NOBLE Group's Chief Operating Officer William Cronin will retire on March 31, with a part-time consulting role as vice-chairman of the Americas. Cronin has been with the company since 2012, overseeing the energy segment and North and South American operations. He will remain involved with the company in his new capacity.

site_title: Getting under the hood of LinkedIn
summary: LinkedIn has a significant presence in Singapore, with 1.6 million members, accounting for 44% of the workforce, including foreigners. The platform estimates 80-85% of knowledge workers, or PMETs, are on its platform. This is attributed to LinkedIn's ability to "bring to life" "passive talent", a key differentiator from other recruitment platforms. With 3.8 million users in Singapore, the country can be described as a "LinkedIn Nation", with most professionals having a LinkedIn profile.

site_title: ECB, BOJ will watch US Fed's outlook closely
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi and Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda are closely monitoring the US Federal Reserve's outlook, which may impact their efforts to reflate their economies through monetary easing. The US Fed's announcement on Thursday is expected to influence the value of the euro and yen, with the euro rising 2.1% and the yen jumping 5.8% against the US dollar this year. Both central banks have already implemented record stimulus measures, but their efforts may be hindered unless the US Fed lends support.

site_title: Trendlines loses bid to renew agtech incubator licence
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-based medical and agricultural tech incubator, has lost its bid to renew its agtech incubator licence in Israel. Despite this, the company will continue to invest in agtech through its medtech incubator operations and has requested to expand its medtech incubator's mandate to include agtech investments. The licence was awarded to a competitive bidder, aiming to diversify the Israel Ministry of Economy's partnership profile. Trendlines shares fell 4% after the announcement.

site_title: UK wage growth rises more than expected in Jan, unemployment rate steady
summary: UK wage growth rose 2.1% in January, exceeding expectations, while the unemployment rate remained steady at 5.1% for the third consecutive month. This marks a slight pick-up in earnings after a slowdown in late 2015. Despite this, pay growth remains below pre-crisis levels, and the sluggish wage increase may pose a challenge to the government's budget deficit target.

site_title: Porsche pays higher staff bonus despite VW cost-cutting drive
summary: Porsche has announced it will pay its 20,000 staff in Germany a bonus of up to 8,911 euros each, despite parent company Volkswagen's cost-cutting drive amid the emissions scandal. This decision is seen as a reward for Porsche's workers, who helped achieve a record-breaking 225,121 vehicle sales in 2015. The move contrasts with Volkswagen's core division, where staff will receive a lower bonus due to the company's cost-saving efforts.

site_title: Opec, non-Opec producers to meet on April 17 in Doha
summary: OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers will meet on April 17 in Doha to stabilize falling crude prices. The meeting is a follow-up to January's talks between Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela, who proposed freezing oil output at January levels. The goal is to address the recent decline in oil prices and stabilize the market.

site_title: BMW CEO's strategy puts focus on electric, luxury vehicles
summary: BMW plans to focus on electric and luxury vehicles, aiming to maintain a minimum 10% pretax profit margin through 2020. The company will roll out more electric cars, including the X7 SUV, and add self-driving features faster than rivals. This strategy comes as BMW faces growing threats to its status as the world's biggest luxury vehicle maker, with rivals like Daimler and Tesla Motors gaining ground. The company also plans to expand its high-end models and invest in digital technologies to stay competitive.

site_title: Obama unveils Garland as Supreme Court pick
summary: President Barack Obama has nominated Merrick Garland, a 63-year-old centrist judge, to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by late Justice Antonin Scalia. Garland, a former prosecutor, has more federal judicial experience than any other Supreme Court nominee in history. The nomination is expected to spark a battle with the Republican-controlled Senate, which has vowed to ignore the selection. Garland's appointment could tip the balance from majority conservative to liberal, with Obama making the formal announcement on Wednesday.

site_title: Economic growth no longer translates into more greenhouse gas: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported that global economic growth did not translate into increased greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector in 2015, for the second consecutive year. Despite a 3.1% global economic growth, CO2 emissions from the energy sector remained flat. The surge in renewable energy sources, particularly wind, accounted for 90% of new electricity generation in 2015, decoupling growth and emissions. This marks a significant boost to the global fight against climate change, following the landmark COP21 agreement in Paris.

site_title: Football: Fifa suspect keeps up champagne lifestyle
summary: Disgraced former Fifa vice president Jeffrey Webb, 51, continues a lavish lifestyle while under US house arrest awaiting sentencing for corruption. Despite forfeiting over $6.7 million in assets, Webb has been accused of maintaining an extravagant lifestyle, including hosting an expensive birthday party for his wife at their Georgia mansion. Fifa's lawyers have requested an immediate audit of Webb's funds and assets, citing concerns that he may not have fully disclosed them to the court.

site_title: Hiap Hoe unit to sell Melbourne property to Australian developer
summary: Hiap Hoe's subsidiary Meteorite Property has agreed to sell a Melbourne property to Australian developer A&J Brady Pty Ltd for A$60 million (S$61.8 million). The sale will cancel plans for a joint venture to develop the property into mixed-use towers. The transaction is expected to be completed by July 31, with Brady granted an exclusive due diligence period until April 11.

site_title: Serge Kampf, Cap Gemini founder and ex-chairman, dies at 81
summary: Serge Kampf, founder of Cap Gemini SA, has died at 81. He founded the company in 1967, turning a network of French programmers into a global IT services provider. Kampf saw an opportunity in selling consulting services to corporate executives and built the company into one of the world's largest providers. He stepped down as chairman in 2012 after 45 years leading the company, leaving behind a legacy of understanding the business value of technology through people.

site_title: Australia, Indonesia renew push for trade deal amid warming ties
summary: Australia and Indonesia have agreed to resume negotiations for a bilateral trade agreement within 18 months. The talks, which were stalled due to diplomatic tensions, will resume in May. The agreement aims to boost trade and economic ties between the two countries, with Indonesia being Australia's 12th largest trading partner. Issues such as live cattle exports and asylum policies are expected to be put aside to focus on broader agreements. The move comes after Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull visited Indonesia last year to improve relations.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed ahead of Fed statement
summary: US stocks remained little changed on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy statement, with investors awaiting potential clues on future interest rate hikes. The Labor Department reported a higher-than-expected core consumer price index, bolstering the Fed's case for tightening policy. Despite improving economic data, financial markets remain cautious, pricing in only one 25-basis-point rate hike in 2016. Global markets dipped before the Fed statement, which is expected at 2 pm ET.

site_title: Soccer: Fifa files for compensation in US as victim of corruption
summary: FIFA, the global soccer body, has filed a restitution request with US authorities for tens of millions of dollars in damages due to corruption and vote-selling scandals. The request, made under new president Gianni Infantino, demands return of salaries and compensation for damage to the FIFA brand. The move comes after ex-officials, including Jack Warner and Chuck Blazer, were indicted for graft and racketeering, with some agreeing to pay over $190 million in forfeiture. Infantino vowed to recover the funds, meant for playing fields and kit, not officials' mansions and cars.

site_title: US core consumer prices march higher in February
summary: US core consumer prices rose 0.3% in February, the largest gain since May 2012, with underlying inflation increasing 2.3% in the 12 months through February. This increase could keep the Federal Reserve on track to gradually raise interest rates this year. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index, excluding volatile food and energy components, saw a similar gain in January.

site_title: German women earn one fifth less than men: data
summary: German women earn approximately 21% less than men, a gap wider than the European average of 16.5%. On average, women earn €16.20 per hour before tax, while men earn €20.59 per hour. The gap has narrowed by 1 percentage point from 2014, but remains above the European average. The disparity is more pronounced in the west of the country, with the east showing a smaller shortfall.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.51 points to close at 1,693.43. The trading volume reached 1.43 billion lots, valued at RM1.69 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 380 to 403.

site_title: Japan Display to shut 2 Japan LCD lines, take US$123 million charge
summary: Japan Display Inc plans to shut two liquid-crystal-display production lines in Japan to boost profitability, raising funds for next-generation technologies. The company will book a 14 billion yen (S$170.4 million) impairment loss and consider consolidating its Chinese manufacturing subsidiaries. An early retirement program for Japanese employees aged 45 and over will also be introduced.

site_title: Printer error triggered Bangladesh race to halt cyber heist
summary: A printer error at Bangladesh's central bank triggered the country's swift response to a nearly $1 billion cyber heist. On February 5, a joint director found the printer tray empty, prompting an investigation into Swift financial transactions. The error led to the attempted theft being halted, but not before hackers had accessed and stolen sensitive information. The incident is one of the biggest cyber heists in recent history.

site_title: MDA updates consumer protection measures for pay-TV subscribers
summary: The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) has finalized recommendations to enhance pay-TV consumer protection measures, effective next month. Key updates include the requirement for 12-month or shorter contract terms for all pay-TV packages and bundles, addressing concerns of unilateral contract changes, forced upgrades, and lack of awareness. The MDA aims to provide consumers with more flexibility and transparency in pay-TV contracts.

site_title: Singapore stocks close mixed in lowest daily volume for the year
summary: Singapore's stock market closed mixed on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 4.77 points to 2,844.21, despite a low daily volume of 1.3 billion units worth S$741 million. The market had been sluggish ahead of the US Federal Reserve's Open Markets Committee meeting. The commodities sector saw gains, with Wilmar International's shares rising on rising crude palm oil prices, which reached RM2,611/mt in Kuala Lumpur. The low volume marked the lowest daily haul this year.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse sees 450m euro cost savings in LSE merger
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG has reached a merger agreement with the London Stock Exchange, with estimated annual cost savings of 450 million euros (S$689.24 million). The combined company anticipates significant value creation potential, with total cost savings of 20% of its adjusted operating costs of 2.2 billion euros in 2015. This is in addition to previously planned cost savings by both companies. The merger aims to create a more competitive and efficient exchange operator.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down as China parliament winds down
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down 0.2% on the final day of China's National People's Congress, despite mainland shares rising. The Hang Seng index fell to 20,257.70, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.4% to 8,571.36 points. Analysts attributed the decline to investors taking profits ahead of the Congress' closure.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have revised their 2016 growth forecast to 1.9% from 2.2%, citing economic uncertainties. Meanwhile, MyRepublic, a Singapore telco, has tapped Goldman Sachs and DBS to raise S$250m. Globally, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, and a Malaysian agency is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets.

images.alt_text: Private-sector economists polled by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have again trimmed their growth forecast for this year.

site_title: April oil freeze meeting may go ahead without Iran
summary: Oil producers, including Gulf Opec members, may hold a meeting in April to discuss a deal to freeze output without Iran, despite its absence. A preliminary deal excluding Iran has been reached by Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Venezuela, with Russia also participating. Brent crude has risen to nearly $39 a barrel, up from a 12-year low. The meeting, likely to be held in Doha, aims to discuss and finalize the details of the freeze deal, with Kuwait and the UAE expressing willingness to commit to the freeze if other major producers do.

site_title: China appetite driving dairy capacity expansion
summary: China's growing demand for powdered milk formula is driving major investments in dairy processing capacity. Australia's Murray Goulburn will build a $280 million factory in partnership with Mead Johnson Nutrition and Kalbe Nutritionals in Victoria, producing 45,000 tonnes of powder formula per year. The first stage of the plant is set to be operational in early 2019, catering to China's expanding middle class and online direct distribution market.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end slightly weaker, await Fed's decision
summary: South Korean shares and the won closed slightly weaker on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.3% to 1,974.90 points. The local currency, the won, fell 0.5% to 1,193.3 to the US dollar. Most traders remained cautious, awaiting the Fed's decision on interest rates.

site_title: Mayor of Chinese port city Ningbo probed for corruption
summary: Chinese authorities have launched a graft probe into Mayor Lu Ziyue of Ningbo, a major eastern port city. Lu, 54, is being investigated for "suspected serious disciplinary violations" related to corruption. The probe is part of a sweeping corruption crackdown by the Communist Party. Lu, who has spent his career in Zhejiang province, was deputy secretary of the party's Ningbo branch and mayor. Details about the suspected violations remain unclear, and Lu has not commented. The investigation marks the latest senior official caught up in the anti-corruption efforts.

site_title: ECB has policy options left, but inflation outlook unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) still has policy options, despite its most aggressive easing measures, according to a Reuters poll. The majority of economists (35/44) believe the ECB has not depleted its monetary policy arsenal. Economists suggest further stimulus measures, such as increasing bond purchases and taking interest rates deeper into negative territory, but inflation outlook remains unchanged at just below 2%. Eurozone economic growth is forecast to average 1.5% for 2016, down from 1.6% previously, and inflation is expected to remain tepid at 0.3% this year.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank still has policy options left at its disposal, according to a majority of economists in a Reuters poll, who also said President Mario Draghi has not lost his knack for influencing financial markets.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise, Apple suppliers up
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.7% to 8,669.17 on Wednesday, driven by gains in Apple suppliers Largan Precision and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. following Apple's 2% increase on Tuesday after Morgan Stanley raised its iPhone sales estimate to 56.5 million. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.103 to T$32.815 per US dollar.

site_title: Obama to travel to UK, Saudi Arabia: White House
summary: President Barack Obama will travel to the UK and Saudi Arabia in April, where he will express his support for Britain's EU membership and attend a summit of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Saudi Arabia. His visit comes ahead of the UK's June referendum on EU membership and amid tensions between the US and Saudi Arabia over Middle East policy. Obama will also visit Germany and attend the Hannover Messe trade show. The trip is seen as a diplomatic effort to address concerns over US interference in the UK's EU decision and to repair relations with Saudi Arabia, which has criticized Obama's policies in the region.

site_title: Seoul to continue push to become northeast Asian oil hub, despite delays
summary: South Korea plans to remain an oil hub in northeast Asia despite delays in constructing a terminal in Ulsan, which was initially set to start construction this year. The country has already successfully operated a tank terminal in Yeosu, with 99.7% capacity utilization, and aims to increase oil product exports. The oil hub project, launched in 2014, will boost competition in the oligopolistic oil refining industry in South Korea, with the goal of becoming the world's fourth-largest oil hub by 2020.

site_title: European stocks propped up as shares in oil firms rise
summary: European stocks rose slightly on Wednesday, driven by gains in oil companies such as BP and Total, as oil prices climbed. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index and Euro STOXX 50 index both rose 0.3% by 0805 GMT. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, expected to hold rates steady, did not impact markets. The merger terms of Deutsche Boerse and London Stock Exchange also contributed to the gains. Investors traded cautiously ahead of the Fed's decision, with policymakers' comfort level in proceeding with gradual rate hikes to be revealed.

site_title: Ties will progress no matter who wins US election: China's Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that US-China relations will continue to develop regardless of the outcome of the US presidential election in November. Despite criticisms of China by US candidates, Li emphasized that the underlying trend of China-US relations has been "forward development" over the past several decades. The two countries are in talks on a bilateral investment treaty, with Li expressing hope for reciprocal treatment and mutual benefit. Li also highlighted the importance of cooperation in the Asia Pacific region, despite tensions over issues like human rights and currency policy.

images.alt_text: China-US relations will continue to develop regardless of who wins the US presidential election in November, China's Premier Li Keqiang said on Wednesday, after criticism of Beijing by US candidates.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as investors focus on Fed meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.83% on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 16,974.45, as investors awaited a Federal Reserve meeting. Japan's central bank refrained from additional stimulus, and US-EU trade talks were in focus. The broader Topix index also declined 0.84%. The Fed's meeting is expected to impact global markets, with investors closely monitoring its decisions on interest rates and monetary policy.

site_title: Mah Sing says time to shop for land as Malaysia rebound seen
summary: Mah Sing Group, Malaysia's third-largest property developer, is ready to buy more land as the company predicts a rebound in the property market in the second half of 2016. Following a record 1.4 billion ringgit cash pile, the company's Group Managing Director Leong Hoy Kum sees signs of renewed consumer confidence. Mah Sing aims to reach its 2.3 billion ringgit sales target in 2016 and plans to sell more "medium range to high-end properties" in Kuala Lumpur. The company's shares have risen over 7% since 2013, and Leong believes the market has stabilized after a 2015 slump.

site_title: Carlsberg commits to Russia and improved return on capital
summary: Carlsberg, the world's fourth-largest brewer, has committed to remaining in Russia despite challenges, with new CEO Cees 't Hart outlining a strategy to improve its return on capital. The company aims to consistently improve its return on invested capital (ROIC) through improved earnings and cutting invested capital, but did not provide specific targets. This strategy, called SAIL '22, comes after Carlsberg reported a 2015 ROIC of 8.1%, excluding major writedowns.

site_title: China: Stocks close higher on last day of annual parliament session
summary: China's stocks closed higher on the last day of its annual parliamentary session, with the CSI300 index rising 0.5% to 3,090.03 and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.2% to 2,870.43 points. The move came as the session drew to a close, with no major policy changes or announcements made. The positive performance was attributed to general market sentiment, with investors taking profits and positioning for the upcoming quarter.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher, NZ shares fall for first time in 12 sessions
summary: Australian shares rose 0.15% to 5,119, rebounding from a 1.4% loss the previous day. New Zealand's benchmark fell 0.23% to 6,562.96, marking its first decline in 12 sessions. The decline in NZ shares was attributed to weakness in resources. Despite this, Australian financial stocks supported the market's recovery.

site_title: "Industrie 4.0" slow to catch on among Germany's smaller manufacturers
summary: Germany's small- and medium-sized manufacturers, known as the Mittelstand, are slow to adopt the "Industrie 4.0" technology, which is essential for maintaining the country's industrial preeminence. Despite efforts by policymakers and industry leaders, many companies lack the funds or in-house IT departments to invest in new technologies. The delay risks losing a $653 billion opportunity and could lead to giant software companies rivaling manufacturers. Berlin is providing support, including digital showrooms and cloud computing networks, but at least 40% of companies have made little progress in adopting a strategy for Industrie 4.0.

site_title: MasterCard, IBM to offer big data analytics to smaller merchants
summary: MasterCard and IBM have partnered to offer big data analytics to smaller merchants, providing real-time market insights on revenue, market share, customer demographics, and competitors. The service will be available to merchants who accept MasterCard from mid-2016, with an additional fee applied. This move aims to help smaller businesses better understand their market and consumers, despite the lack of resources to maximize insights.

images.alt_text: Mastercard and IBM on Wednesday said they will partner to offer smaller merchants with big data analytics.

site_title: Australian PM backs tough competition laws opposed by business lobby
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has backed a change to the country's competition laws, which would reduce the power of big businesses to monopolize markets and squeeze out smaller competitors. The "effects test" would prevent firms with substantial market power from engaging in conduct that harms competition. The move is welcomed by small business groups but opposed by the Business Council of Australia, which claims the changes unfairly target large businesses. The government aims to consolidate support ahead of elections this year.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said on Wednesday he would back a controversial change to the country's competition laws that would reduce the power of big businesses to monopolise markets and squeeze out smaller competitors.

site_title: Pound declines a third day before Osborne presents UK budget
summary: The UK pound declined for a third consecutive day before Chancellor George Osborne's budget presentation, dropping 0.3% to US$1.4107. Investors are concerned about the UK's economic risks, particularly the potential exit from the European Union, which may keep interest rates low for longer. The Bank of England is set to announce its policy decision on Thursday, with economists predicting a possible rate cut this year. The UK unemployment rate held steady at 5.1% in January, with earnings growth picking up to 2%.

site_title: Fooled by oil's false bottom, most US shale firms skipped hedging in Q4
summary: US shale firms largely skipped hedging in Q4, despite some producers increasing their hedging positions, according to a Reuters analysis of filings from the largest shale firms. This leaves many with little insurance to ride out a market expected to trade below $40 a barrel. Only a handful of producers, such as Anadarko and Chesapeake Energy, increased hedging, totaling 28 million fewer hedged barrels than at the start of the quarter. The lack of hedging has raised doubts about the sustainability of cash-strapped drillers.

site_title: ECB's Hansson wary on bank's new stimulus measures
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Ardo Hansson expressed concerns over the bank's new stimulus measures, citing potential risks to financial stability. Hansson warned that the measures could fuel asset bubbles and lead to unsuitable risks for conservative market participants. He also suggested that the measures might prevent governments from enacting structural reforms, instead of spurring them. Hansson's comments reflect his dissenting views on the ECB's recently announced stimulus package, which included rate cuts and ultra-cheap loans.

site_title: Palm oil drops with other vegetable oils on slowing demand
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures dropped 0.8% to 2,590 ringgit (S$863.58) per tonne on Wednesday, the steepest decline in two weeks, due to slowing demand and weak export performance. The price was also affected by declining rival vegetable oils, including Dalian soybean oil and Chicago soyoil. Weak export demand, particularly from top buyers China and India, due to economic slowdown, further contributed to the decline.

site_title: China economy will not have a 'hard landing', says Premier Li
summary: China's economy won't experience a "hard landing," Premier Li Keqiang said, despite slowing growth. The government has long-term confidence in the economy, citing reform and opening-up as key factors. China's 13th Five Year Plan aims to grow the world's second-largest economy by at least 6.5% annually from 2016 to 2020, with a focus on reducing poverty. Despite cracks in the economy, including strikes and layoffs, Li worked to dispel fears, saying the government will avoid massive layoffs while making breakthroughs in coal and steel industries.

site_title: Hot stock: OKH Global suspends trading
summary: OKH Global, a Singapore-based investment holding company, suspended trading on Wednesday after its shares dropped to a low of 35.0 Singapore cents, with 548,000 shares changing hands. The company reported a net loss of S$2.1 million for the second quarter, with revenue of S$3.33 million, a significant decline from the same period last year. The trading halt was requested due to trading activity, and the Singapore Exchange issued a query to OKH Global.

site_title: More measures slated to boost Singapore's asset management industry
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is developing a new regulatory framework for open-end investment companies (OEICs) to boost the asset management industry. Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance Indranee Rajah announced the initiative at the 17th annual conference of the Investment Management Association of Singapore, citing the framework as a more efficient structure for fund administration.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is working on initiatives that will boost the asset management industry here.

site_title: New debris found in Reunion 'unlikely' from MH370
summary: Australian authorities leading the search for missing flight MH370 say a second piece of debris found on the Indian Ocean island of La Reunion is "unlikely to be from an aircraft." The debris, measuring 40x20 cm, was discovered by a man who found the first and only officially identified part of the Boeing 777, the "flaperon," last July. The search in the southern Indian Ocean is expected to wrap up around June to July if the aircraft is not found. Authorities are examining two other suspected pieces of debris found in Mozambique to confirm their origin.

site_title: China Premier says confident in Hong Kong government
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang expressed confidence in the Hong Kong government's ability to handle issues, despite ongoing political tensions and unrest. Li made the statement during a news conference, avoiding direct mention of the territory's recent turmoil. The comments come amid massive protests in 2014 and a riot in February. Li's remarks suggest Beijing's stance on granting Hong Kong full democracy remains unchanged, potentially embittering the younger generation of activists.

site_title: China to introduce unified CO2 market standards: expert
summary: China is set to introduce unified national CO2 market standards as part of its nationwide emissions trading scheme, launching next year. The scheme will include over 10,000 major emitters, building on seven pilot exchanges since 2013. Local authorities will have some discretion in deciding which industries participate, with emitters required to buy permits to cover their emissions.
