This move aims to reduce China's carbon footprint and meet its climate goals.

site_title: Hong Kong luxury land plot prices below expectations
summary: A luxury land plot sale in Hong Kong Island fetched less than expected, following previous land sales that also fell below expectations. This is a sign of cracks in the city's expensive property market, which is closely watched by investors. The sale is the latest in a string of government land sales to do so, with two other tenders recently cancelled.

site_title: White House fears Trump damaging US reputation
summary: US President Barack Obama has warned that harsh campaigning in the 2016 presidential race, particularly by Republican frontrunner Donald Trump, is damaging America's image abroad. Obama described Trump's rhetoric as "vulgar and divisive," citing concerns from international leaders about the potential for a Trump presidency, including Mexico and the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. The administration fears Trump's policies, such as building a border wall, could erode the gains made during Obama's presidency and harm US relations with key partners.

site_title: China warns Taiwan trade ties need political stability
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang warned Taiwan that trade ties can only be strengthened if there is political stability, amid concerns over the island's growing pro-independence movement. Li emphasized the importance of the "1992 consensus," which considers Taiwan as part of China, and pledged to introduce policies to boost business cooperation. The warning comes after Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won elections in January, with President Tsai Ing-wen assuming office in May. China considers Taiwan a wayward province to be brought under its control if necessary.

site_title: Yuan set for biggest three-day loss since January on tax concern
summary: The Chinese yuan is poised for its largest three-day loss since January due to concerns over a potential tax on foreign-exchange transactions. The central bank's reported plans for a Tobin tax have drawn criticism from economists, who fear it will spur capital outflows and increase depreciation pressures. The yuan declined 0.12% to 6.5200 a US dollar, taking its three-day retreat to 0.4%, its largest since January 8. The People's Bank of China weakened its reference rate by 0.14% to 6.5172.

site_title: Trendlines' attempt to renew agricultural tech incubator licence in Israel denied
summary: Trendlines Group, a CATALIST-listed incubator, had its agricultural technology (agtech) incubator licence in Israel denied by the Office of the Chief Scientist of the Israel Ministry of Economy. The denial will not impact the group's 2016 earnings, and it plans to continue investing in agtech while making "appropriate adjustments." Despite the setback, Trendlines views its agtech investment activity as "important."

site_title: Thai police charge executives after deadly bank accident
summary: Thai police have charged two executives from Mega Planet Co Ltd, a fire-fighting system supplier, with negligence over an accident at Siam Commercial Bank that killed eight people. The accident occurred on Sunday when contractors triggered an extinguisher, releasing a chemical retardant that may have starved the area of oxygen. Executives Napong Suksanguan and Adisorn Poda face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to 200,000 baht if found guilty. Both men have denied the charges and been released on bail.

site_title: Japan to throw away kitchen scales in overhaul of consumption data
summary: Japan plans to overhaul its household spending survey, which has been criticized for its reliance on outdated methods and biases towards the elderly. The current survey, which relies on respondents weighing groceries on state-provided scales and answering over 20 questions by hand, is set to be replaced by a big-data approach, collecting transactions from credit card firms, travel agencies, and retailers. The move aims to improve the accuracy of consumption data, which has been hurting Japan's gross domestic product, and is expected to be ready by 2019.

site_title: China's ZTE said to appeal US export ban after lobby efforts fail
summary: China's ZTE Corp will appeal US export restrictions imposed due to alleged Iran sanctions violations, following failed lobbying efforts. The US Commerce Department imposed restrictions on US suppliers providing crucial components to ZTE, disrupting its global supply chain. ZTE spent millions on lobbying in the US, seeking to assuage national security concerns, but failed to convince lawmakers. The appeals process may take a year or more, and US officials said discussions with ZTE are ongoing.

site_title: Sony climbs after pricing virtual reality headset below rivals'
summary: Sony's virtual reality headset, the Playstation VR, will be priced at US$399, significantly lower than rival devices such as the HTC Vive (US$799) and Oculus Rift (US$599). The device is expected to appeal to the 36 million PlayStation 4 owners, and Sony plans to release over 50 games for the headset by the end of the year. Analysts see this as a strategic move to capture mainstream market share and encourage users to upgrade to future PlayStation consoles. The headset will go on sale in October.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda denies offering more exemptions from negative rates
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that there is no room to make additional exemptions from the negative interest rate policy, excluding money reserve funds. The BOJ exempted $124.2 billion in short-term funds from negative rates, citing concerns about investment in the stock market. Kuroda also emphasized that the BOJ will not tie its interest rate decisions to European central banks' negative rates.

site_title: Bank of Intl Settlements seen buying South Korea t-bonds this week
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) has reportedly purchased South Korean treasury bonds worth approximately 600 billion won (S$694 million) over the past two days, according to sources. This is not the first time the BIS has bought South Korean bonds, with international institutions seeking stable assets. The move comes after the Reserve Bank of Australia invested 5% of its net foreign currency reserves in Korean won two weeks ago. The BIS has declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: US dollar rises before Fed as Kuroda says minus 0.5% rate possible
summary: The US dollar strengthened against 13 of its 16 major peers before the Federal Reserve meeting, driven by speculation that the Fed will reaffirm its interest rate hike commitment. Deutsche Bank AG suggested Janet Yellen may keep the door open for an April rate increase. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at a possible key rate cut to minus 0.5%, which led to a decline in the yen. Investors expect the Fed's decision to impact the dollar's strength.

site_title: China Premier Li: govt to keep promoting reforms in financial markets
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced the government will continue promoting market-oriented reforms in financial markets, focusing on improving coordination in financial regulation. The financial system needs to support the real economy, and lenders have sufficient provisions to cope with bad loans. Debt-to-equity swaps will be used to lower debt levels. Li emphasized the importance of financial institutions supporting smaller companies.

site_title: China parliament approves five year plan, charity law
summary: China's Communist-controlled legislature approved a five-year economic plan, increasing the country's GDP from 67.7 trillion yuan to 92.7 trillion yuan by 2020, with an average annual growth of 6.5%. The plan also aims to reduce poverty by 2020. Additionally, a charity law was passed, with officials seeking to encourage charitable giving to achieve poverty alleviation targets. The charity law is intended to "recruit help from good Samaritans" in realizing the 2020 goal.

images.alt_text: China's Communist-controlled legislature approved an economic roadmap for the next five years and a charity law among a series of measures Wednesday at the close of its annual meeting.

site_title: Economists temper Singapore growth expectations for 2016 to 1.9%
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have trimmed their growth forecast for 2016 to 1.9% due to a deeper-than-expected contraction in the manufacturing sector. They expect better growth in 2017, with 2.5% growth. The economy is also expected to fare well in construction and accommodation and food services. Unemployment is forecast to remain at 2.1% by year-end, while inflation is expected to be -0.2% in 2016 and 1% in 2017.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks down, Hong Kong up at open
summary: Shanghai stocks declined 0.20% on Wednesday, following a two-day rally, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.12%. Traders await the conclusion of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Shanghai Composite Index fell to 2,858.71, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose to 1,741.87.

site_title: Mexico City curbs cars in first pollution alert since 2002
summary: Mexico City authorities issued its first air pollution alert in 14 years due to high ozone levels, restricting traffic and ordering factories to cut emissions. The alert, effective from Monday to Tuesday, advised people to avoid outdoor sports and kids and seniors to stay indoors. Older cars were ordered off the streets, and factories in the area were ordered to slash emissions by 40%. The alert comes after a surge in ozone concentration, which can cause respiratory and heart ailments, and marks a reversal of years of progress made to improve air quality.

site_title: Kuroda says BOJ has room to cut rates to around -0.5%
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the BOJ has room to cut interest rates to around -0.5%, countering speculation that negative rates would prevent further rate cuts. Kuroda expressed the possibility of cutting rates further, citing "theoretically, there is room to do so," but emphasized that the decision would depend on economic conditions. The comments aimed to alleviate concerns about the BOJ's ability to expand stimulus and maintain a dovish stance.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said there is room to slash interest rates to around minus 0.5 per cent, countering a growing suspicion that public criticism over January's decision to adopt negative rates will prevent him from pursuing with the policy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.100 points to 1692.160. Trading volume was 17.42 million lots worth RM6.63 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 85 to 43. The market's performance was influenced by global factors, including US-EU trade talks and a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Asia: Traders play wait-and-see ahead of Fed decision
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with traders hoping for forward guidance on interest rates. Crude oil prices recovered after a sharp sell-off, while investors played it safe prior to the Fed meeting and chair Janet Yellen's comments. No new measures are expected, but Yellen's comments will be closely watched for clues on policymakers' thinking. Oil prices rose, and markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul increased, while Tokyo ended lower due to the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy.

site_title: Gold trades near two-week low ahead of US Fed policy meeting
summary: Gold prices fell to near a two-week low ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, trading at $1,231.38 an ounce. Investors await the Fed's signals on monetary tightening this year, pricing in a 54% chance of a June rate hike. The metal remains 16% higher this year despite market volatility, and traders expect higher rates to damp its appeal. Fed officials are expected to reduce the number of rate hikes in 2016 and leave the federal funds rate unchanged.

site_title: BHP CEO says 'more bearish' on iron ore as price surge reverses
summary: BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie expressed a more bearish outlook on iron ore prices, citing a decline in demand growth in China and a widening global glut. Prices dropped for a sixth consecutive day, erasing gains from a record spike, after Morgan Stanley lowered its forecast by 14% to US$40 a ton for 2016. The bank attributes prices to a stable trading range until the third quarter, followed by a seasonal pullback. Despite being profitable, BHP acknowledges that excess supply will drive prices lower.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars weighed by weak commodities, yen shines
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined on Wednesday due to weak commodities, particularly iron ore and dairy prices. The New Zealand dollar dropped to a two-week low of US$0.6577, while the Australian dollar fell to US$0.7455. The yen, considered a safe-haven currency, rose against both currencies. The decline in dairy prices and global milk prices put significant financial pressure on New Zealand's dairy farms, but the Reserve Bank of New Zealand remains confident in its banking system. Markets await guidance from the US Federal Reserve on rate hikes.

site_title: UPS makes US$100m investment in CNG vehicles
summary: United Parcel Service Inc announced a $100 million investment to build 12 compressed natural gas fueling stations and add 380 CNG trucks to its fleet. Despite a drop in crude oil prices, UPS is making a long-term commitment to CNG vehicles due to its ownership of all vehicles and fueling infrastructure. The investment aims to reduce the company's dependence on alternative transportation fuels.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.21% to 2,845.49, with 47.7 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 41. The move follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Overnight, US markets ended with minimal movement, awaiting the Federal Reserve's guidance on potential rate hikes this year.

site_title: China studying bad debt equity swap plan, banking regulator says
summary: China is studying a plan to allow commercial lenders to swap non-performing loans with stakes in companies, aiming to reduce NPL ratios and bolster capital reserves. The proposed regulations, which would require cabinet approval, are a response to a decade-high surge in NPLs last year. The move is part of efforts to address China's slowing economy, which has grown at its slowest pace in a quarter of a century. The regulations would bypass the need to revise commercial bank law, which bars lenders from investing in non-financial institutions.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata issues US$500m sukuk for Ncell acquisition
summary: Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's largest mobile operator, has successfully priced a US$500 million 10-year sukuk to fund its proposed acquisition of Nepalese phone carrier Ncell Pvt Ltd. This is the third sukuk issuance under Axiata's US$1.5 billion multi-currency Sukuk issuance programme, set up in 2012. The funds will be used to acquire Ncell, marking Axiata's expansion into the Nepalese market.

site_title: Japan automakers offer smaller 2016 wage hikes
summary: Japan's major automakers, including Toyota, Nissan, and Honda, offered smaller wage hikes for 2016, ranging from 1,100 yen to 3,000 yen. This follows last year's largest increases in years, which slowed wage growth and helped stimulate the economy. The modest hikes are seen as a response to slowing inflation and an uncertain economic outlook. Toyota's 1,500 yen hike is the third consecutive year, but less than half of last year's 4,000 yen increase, which was the largest in over a decade.

site_title: Trump wins big in Florida, knocks Rubio out of race
summary: Donald Trump won the Florida Republican primary, securing 99 delegates and further solidifying his position as the party's front-runner. He lost to John Kasich in Ohio, while Marco Rubio dropped out of the race after the Florida loss. On the Democratic side, Hillary Clinton won Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina, increasing her delegate lead over Bernie Sanders. Trump's momentum and delegate count have given establishment Republicans hope to deny him the nomination, while Clinton's wins have pushed her closer to securing the Democratic nomination.

site_title: Millions vote in make-or-break test for White House hopefuls
summary: Millions of Americans cast ballots in five crucial presidential primaries, with Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton vying for the White House. The primaries, dubbed "Titanic Tuesday," focused on blue-collar issues, immigration, and trade. Trump's divisive rhetoric and promise to revive manufacturing jobs appealed to some Democrats, while his rival, Bernie Sanders, criticized Clinton's support of free trade pacts. The results will determine the shape of the Republican and Democratic nominating races, with Trump seeking to secure the Republican nomination and Clinton aiming to extend her lead over Sanders.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tread water ahead of Fed policy decision
summary: Seoul's stocks and the won remained unchanged ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy decision. Foreign investors purchased KOSPI shares for a fifth consecutive session, but caution ahead of the Fed's decision kept traders in a wait-and-see mode. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index rose 0.1% to 1,972.48 points, while the won fell 0.3% to 1,190.9 to the US dollar. The sub-index for construction stocks fell 2.9%, but Samsung Engineering Co Ltd rose 5.6%. The decision is expected to impact South Korean shares and the won.

site_title: NZ central bank says banks can withstand severe dairy downturn
summary: New Zealand's central bank says the nation's dairy farms are facing significant financial pressure due to low global milk prices. However, the banking system is robust enough to withstand a severe downturn, with banks expected to report losses ranging between 3% and 8% of their dairy exposure. Around 80% of farmers are currently operating below breakeven levels, raising concerns about the financial system. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's stress test provides reassurance that the banking system can handle the pressure, despite the challenges facing the dairy industry.

site_title: Vard signs letter of intent with Ponant
summary: Vard Holdings has signed a letter of intent to construct four luxury expedition cruise vessels for French company Ponant. The vessels, valued at approximately 10,000 gross tons, will feature 92 cabins, a crew of 110, and luxury facilities. Delivery is scheduled for summer 2018 to summer 2019, pending satisfactory financing and contract signing in Q2 2016.

site_title: Sharp falls after report Foxconn may delay deal to get more clarity
summary: Sharp Corp shares fell 9% in Tokyo trading after a report said Taiwan's Foxconn Technology Group may delay its takeover deal due to concerns over Sharp's financial performance. Foxconn, which agreed to pay over 600 billion yen for control of Sharp, requested the company's latest financial results. Sharp forecast an operating profit of 10 billion yen, but analysts estimated a loss of 24 billion yen. Foxconn is negotiating with Sharp's banks to mitigate potential liabilities, and the companies are working to reach a satisfactory agreement.

site_title: Clinton sweeps Sanders in Ohio, Florida, North Carolina
summary: Hillary Clinton secured decisive wins in the Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina Democratic primaries, strengthening her grip on the party's nomination. With a total of 621 delegates at stake, Clinton's victories are expected to leave her with a virtually insurmountable delegate lead. Her campaign is now focusing on the general election, with Clinton explicitly targeting Republican frontrunner Donald Trump, saying the next president must "bring our country together." Clinton's wins will help allay fears among Democrats that she couldn't win in states dominated by white, blue-collar voters.

site_title: As China's consumers tighten belts, retailers cut jobs, offer discounts
summary: China's consumers are tightening their belts, leading retailers to cut jobs, slow expansion plans, and offer discounts. Sales fell 6% at the start of the year, and 1.8% for basic goods, as wealthy households trade down and poorer families cut back on purchases. The slow growth poses a challenge for China's economy, with top 50 retailers and consumer goods makers struggling to adapt. Some firms, like Starbucks and Nike, continue to grow, but many are forced to cut back, focus on smaller cities, and offer discounts to stay afloat.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after BOJ meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a drop in oil prices and the Bank of Japan's decision to abstain from new stimulus. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% to 16,981.36, and the Topix index of all first-section shares fell 0.75% to 1,361.83. Market sentiment remains fragile amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US producers struggle, focus shifts to inventory
summary: US oil prices rose early Wednesday, with WTI crude futures trading at $36.94 per barrel and Brent futures at $39.14 per barrel. The increase came after prices dropped 2% the previous session, driven by concerns over US producers' financial distress and focus on inventory data. Preliminary data showed US crude stockpiles rose 1.5 million barrels, but less than expected. The US Energy Information Administration will issue official figures later in the day, which could impact prices. Oil markets remain oversupplied, with over 1 million barrels of crude pumped daily in excess of demand.

site_title: Singapore telco battle heats up as MyRepublic taps Goldman, DBS to help raise S$250m
summary: Singapore's telecommunications market is heating up as MyRepublic Ltd, a local Internet service provider, seeks to raise S$250 million to support its bid for the new fourth mobile-phone license. Consistel, another regional wireless software provider, plans to invest up to S$1.3 billion. Incumbents Singtel, Starhub, and M1 are defending their market share with new offerings, sparking concerns about rising borrowing costs for potential new entrants. Analysts predict that fundraising for the new entrant will be significantly more costly due to the lack of strong parentage, making it challenging for MyRepublic to compete.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler gains access to cash of its US subsidiary
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has eliminated covenants linked to term loans of its US subsidiary, FCA US LLC, gaining full access to the division's cash. The move follows a buyout in 2014 and is part of restructuring efforts to access the division's cash. FCA US LLC has entered into amendments to its term loans, allowing for the free flow of capital among group members and enabling access to a €2.5 billion syndicated revolving credit facility. This move aims to fund a product overhaul of key brands by 2018 and eliminate net debt by the same time.

site_title: US Republican Marco Rubio ends 2016 White House bid
summary: US Republican Marco Rubio ended his 2016 White House bid after failing to secure victories in primary states, despite support from the party establishment. Rubio projected a loss in his home state of Florida, where he was defeated by Donald Trump. This decision came after poor performances in Michigan and Mississippi, where he received single-digit support in polls. Rubio expressed optimism about America's future despite his loss.

images.alt_text: Marco Rubio ended his campaign on Tuesday for the Republican presidential nomination after failing to translate support from the party's establishment into victories in primary states.

site_title: Instagram says feed will start showing posts in rearranged order
summary: Instagram is introducing a new algorithm-based ordering system to its feed, prioritizing posts that the company thinks users will be most interested in. The move aims to improve the user experience by reducing the average 70% of posts users miss. The feed will still show all posts from users they follow, just in a different order. The change has met resistance from fans, with some calling it the "end of Instagram." The company claims the move is necessary to keep up with the growing number of posts and improve user engagement.

site_title: Suspect killed, 4 police wounded in Brussels raid over Paris attacks
summary: A Kalashnikov-wielding assailant was killed and four police officers were wounded during an anti-terror operation in Brussels linked to the November 13 Paris attacks. The operation took place in the southern Brussels suburb of Forest, where police were searching a property when they came under fire. The suspect, not identified as Salah Abdeslam, was killed in an assault by police. Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel said operations were continuing and that the national security council would meet on Wednesday.

site_title: US economy seen expanding 1.9% in Q1: Atlanta Fed
summary: The US economy is projected to grow 1.9% in the first quarter, according to the Atlanta Federal Reserve's GDP Now forecast model, down from its previous estimate of 2.2%. This slowdown was driven by weaker-than-expected domestic retail sales data, which showed a 0.1% decline in February and a revised 0.4% decline in January. The revised forecast also reduced the expected growth of real consumer spending to 2.7% from 3.3%.

site_title: Amazon Web Services says over 1,000 databases moved to cloud since Jan 1
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) reports that over 1,000 databases have been migrated to its cloud since January 1, citing the availability of its Data Migration Service to all customers. This service allows the migration of databases like Oracle, SQL Server, and PostgreSQL from on-premises data centers to AWS. Companies such as Expedia, Pegasystems, and Thomas Publishing have already utilized AWS' Amazon Aurora and Amazon RDS engines for this purpose.

site_title: John Kerry says to meet President Putin in Russia next week
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow next week to discuss the Syria crisis. The meeting comes after Russia announced a partial withdrawal of its forces from Syria, and the opening of indirect UN-mediated peace talks in Geneva. Kerry sees this as a "window of possibility" to find a negotiated solution to the five-year-old conflict. He acknowledges that the cessation of hostilities has not been perfect, but believes the situation has reached a crucial phase in the process.

site_title: Japan blue chips, in blow to Abenomics, to offer smaller 2016 pay hikes
summary: Japan's leading blue-chip firms, including Toyota, will offer smaller wage hikes this year, underscoring the weakness of "Abenomics" stimulus policy. The pay increases are expected to be below union demands, with some companies raising base pay by 1,500 yen, half of last year's gain. This move is seen as a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to boost economic growth through higher incomes and consumer spending. Analysts predict pay rises will slow to just above 2% at this year's wage negotiations, disappointing expectations of a virtuous growth cycle.

images.alt_text: Japanese blue-chip firms on Wednesday are set to announce wage hikes that undershoot last year's increases, a blow to "Abenomics" stimulus policy at a time fear of a deepening global slowdown and jittery markets are denting business sentiment.

site_title: Weak US data, BOJ outlook push US dollar down vs yen
summary: The US dollar fell sharply against the yen on Tuesday after the Bank of Japan left interest rates unchanged and weak US retail sales data. The yen rose 6.5% since the day after the Bank of Japan's rate cut in January. Investors are seeking safety amid declining oil prices and global equity markets, with the yen seen as a protection against a "risk-off" moment. The US dollar fell 0.6% to 113.12 yen, while sterling also declined 1% against the euro and US dollar.

site_title: Fed seen holding US rates for now, leaving door open for June hike
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are expected to hold short-term interest rates unchanged at their two-day policy meeting, but signal a potential rate hike in June if the job market and inflation continue to improve. The decision comes after recent strong US data and easing of fears over global economic headwinds. Forecasts from Fed officials suggest three or two rate hikes this year, down from four previously envisioned in December.

site_title: Trump, Clinton win in Florida: US networks
summary: US Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton won their respective presidential primaries in Florida, with Trump securing a major win in his home state. Clinton also won the primary in North Carolina. The results leave the Republican primary still uncertain in Ohio, Illinois, and Missouri, with polls now closed. Trump's victory is seen as a setback for Senator Marco Rubio, while Governor John Kasich's performance in Ohio is viewed as a strong contender for the Republican nomination.

images.alt_text: US Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton won the presidential primaries in Florida on Tuesday, US networks projected - big wins for the frontrunners in the 2016 White House race.

site_title: Britain 'not trusted' if it leaves EU: Malta
summary: Malta's Prime Minister Joseph Muscat warns that if Britain votes to leave the EU in June, "acrimony and resentment" would follow, with relations being polite but not intimate. Britain would need to be treated as a friend but not family. Negotiating an exit arrangement would be perceived as a time-consuming distraction, and EU leaders would portray the process as painful and costly.

site_title: Beware the wounded bear that is Russia
summary: Russia's economic woes, fueled by the oil price collapse, will exacerbate nationalistic rhetoric and cross-border tensions. The country's GDP contracted by 3.8% in 2015, with inflation expected to remain high at around 10% this year. As legislative elections approach in September, Putin's grip on power may be threatened, leading to increased suppression of freedom of expression and potentially more aggressive international forays. Russia's military intervention in Syria and its strategic ambitions in the Middle East may escalate international tensions, particularly with Turkey, and have substantial economic and financial consequences.

site_title: Valeant shares plunge 49% on default warning, outlook
summary: Valeant's share price plummeted 49.5% to US$34.86 after the Canadian drugmaker warned it's at risk of debt default and slashed its earnings forecast. The company faces a 60-day deadline to submit its annual 10-K report to the US Securities and Exchange Commission, with bondholders threatening to deliver a notice of default if the deadline isn't met. This warning comes amid ongoing criticism of Valeant's pricing and accounting practices.

site_title: Italian distiller Campari buys French cognac maker for 684m euros
summary: Italian distiller Campari has agreed to buy French cognac maker Grand Marnier Group for 684 million euros, adding to its portfolio of high-end spirits. The deal values Grand Marnier at 8,050 euros per share, a 60% increase from Friday's closing price. The acquisition is Campari's first since 2014 and will add to its profit immediately. The deal also includes a worldwide exclusive distribution agreement for Grand Marnier's spirits, effective in July.

site_title: Europe: Shares led lower by commodity stocks, gloomy BOJ view
summary: European shares retreated on Tuesday, led by a 4.7% decline in the STOXX Europe 600 Basic Resources index, due to a weaker view from the Bank of Japan and concerns about US retail sales data. Copper prices dropped, and shares in mining companies like BHP Billiton and Glencore fell. Meanwhile, French telecoms operator SFR rose 1.4% after reporting a 20% increase in core operating profit. The market awaits the Federal Reserve's policy statement on Wednesday, which may influence interest rate moves and global growth prospects.

site_title: US ethanol glut begins to test limits of storage capacity
summary: The US ethanol market is experiencing a glut, with storage capacity nearing full utilization. Kinder Morgan Inc is rerouting delivery trucks to its Chicago Liquids operation due to an imbalance of stockpile inventories. US ethanol stockpiles rose to a record 23.3 million barrels, and producers like Pacific Ethanol Inc and Valero Energy Corp have reduced production in response. As a result, producers and traders are paying premiums for storage space, with the Chicago area's storage capacity considered nearly full.

site_title: China's Tobin tax proposal riles banks which flag the risk of foreign exodus
summary: China's central bank has proposed a Tobin tax on foreign-exchange transactions to prop up the yuan, but banks and analysts are strongly opposing the move, citing concerns over reduced market liquidity and potential capital outflows. The tax could hinder China's efforts to make the yuan a reserve currency and may lead to a foreign investor exodus. Experts warn that the levy could backfire, hurting market sentiment and increasing investor panic, especially given the country's existing capital controls. The proposal is currently awaiting central government approval, and its implementation is uncertain.

site_title: PlayStation virtual reality gear to launch in October
summary: Sony plans to release PlayStation VR headgear in October at a price of $399, aiming to bring virtual reality to the mainstream. The headsets are designed for PlayStation 4 consoles and will be available for pre-order in the coming months. This move comes after Facebook's Oculus announced its Rift headset, priced at $599, and bundles starting at $1,500. The lower price point of PlayStation VR is seen as a competitive advantage, making it more accessible to consumers.

site_title: Oil extends losses as output freeze hopes fade
summary: World oil prices fell for a second consecutive day, sinking 84 cents to $36.34 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate. Hopes for a production freeze by major crude producers, led by Russia and Saudi Arabia, have faded. Analysts predict prices will remain between $30 and $50 per barrel this year due to oversupply and a slowing Chinese economy. A meeting proposed by Russia and Saudi Arabia has been pushed back to April, and investors await the US weekly report on petroleum inventories on Wednesday, which is expected to show an increase in commercial crude stockpiles.

site_title: 'Buy' call on Zhongmin Baihui despite TWC advice
summary: A Singaporean brokerage, Phillip Capital, issued a "buy" call on Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group despite the Singapore Exchange's "Trade With Caution" (TWC) warning on the stock. The brokerage maintained its target price of S$1.73, citing strong brand equity and a strong cash position. Phillip Capital attributed the TWC warning to a small group of individuals controlling a significant portion of the stock's trading activity, rather than the company itself.

site_title: Keppel Data Centres and NSCC seek strategic collaboration
summary: Keppel Data Centres Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the National Supercomputing Centre (NSCC) to explore collaboration in supercomputing, high-performance computing, and green technology. The partnership aims to integrate Keppel Data Centres' data centres as a supercomputing node, offering clients access to NSCC's high-performance computing resources. This strategic collaboration demonstrates Keppel Data Centres' commitment to enhancing its product offerings.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly down ahead of Fed, pharma shares flop
summary: US stocks finished mostly lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.13% to 17,251.53, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.18% and 0.45% respectively. Pharmaceutical shares declined, with Valeant plummeting 51.5% due to a weak earnings report and potential debt default. Other biotechs and pharma giants like Pfizer and Eli Lilly also fell. The decline was partly attributed to a weak US retail sales report and drop in oil prices, ahead of the Federal Reserve policy statement on Wednesday.

site_title: Harrison Ford to reprise iconic Indiana Jones role
summary: Harrison Ford is set to reprise his iconic role as Indiana Jones in a fifth installment of the series, directed by Steven Spielberg, scheduled for release in 2019. This marks the return of the adventurous archaeologist after a 20-year hiatus. The project is currently in development, with Alan Horn, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, expressing excitement about bringing the legendary hero back to the big screen.

images.alt_text: Harrison Ford will reprise his iconic role as the adventurous archaeologist in a fifth installment of the Indiana Jones series, the Walt Disney Company announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Social unrest a top risk for Asia-Pac aviation
summary: A survey by Willis Towers Watson found social unrest, terrorism threats, and cyber breaches to be top risks for the Asia-Pacific aviation sector. 53% of executives expect digital vulnerability and technological advancements to significantly impact the industry over the next year. The global cyber risk insurance market is expected to balloon to $25 billion by 2025. Competition law scrutiny from mergers and acquisitions was also identified as a significant risk, particularly among airport operators.

site_title: Pound slumps as British poll renews 'Brexit' fears
summary: The pound dropped 1.1% against the dollar after a poll showed 52% of voters in the June Brexit referendum favoring the UK's exit from the European Union. The result raised concerns about the UK's economic future. The poll's findings were published in The Telegraph, and the pound's decline was seen as a reflection of the renewed "Brexit" fears.

images.alt_text: The pound slumped on Tuesday after a newspaper poll showed an edge for voters who want Britain to leave the European Union.

site_title: February retail sales, producer prices dip
summary: US retail sales fell 0.1% in February, less than expected, due to slower automobile purchases and cheaper petrol. January's sales were revised to a 0.4% decline, sparking concerns about consumer spending growth. Producer prices also dropped 0.2% in February, but were unchanged from a year ago, suggesting the downward trend may be nearing its end.

site_title: Washington metro to shut for full day for safety checks
summary: Washington's metro train system will shut down for a full day on Wednesday for emergency inspections after an electrical fire in a tunnel. This is the first system-wide closure for non-weather-related conditions, affecting hundreds of thousands of commuters and tourists. The metro, the second busiest in the US, serves about 700,000 customers daily in Washington, Maryland, and Virginia. The closure is unprecedented and will likely cause mass disruption, with transport chiefs admitting it will trigger "transport misery" for the affected areas.

images.alt_text: Washington's metro train system will shut all day on Wednesday for emergency inspections after an electrical fire in a tunnel, transport chiefs said, in an unprecedented move that threatens to cause mass disruption in the US capital.

site_title: The US Democrats' tax plan: soak the rich
summary: US Democrats' tax plans aim to "soak the rich" by increasing taxes on high-income households. The Tax Policy Center analyzed the proposals of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, finding that both would raise significant revenue over a decade. Clinton's plan would raise $1.1 trillion, with the top 1% paying three-quarters of the increase, while Sanders' plan would raise $15.3 trillion, with a 2.2% surcharge on all taxable income. However, the Center notes that the increased taxes may not lead to significant deficit reduction, as the revenue would be used to finance new spending priorities, potentially harming economic growth.

site_title: More hard pruning on the cards for investment banks: study
summary: A study by Morgan Stanley and Oliver Wyman warns that investment banks in Europe face significant hard pruning to reduce revenues by 10% in 2016, and improve returns. This comes as the industry struggles with falling revenues. The study emphasizes the need for management teams to take action to address the challenges.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff hit by explosive new accusations
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff has been hit by new accusations in the Petrobras corruption scandal. A senator, Delcidio Amaral, accused Education Minister Aloizio Mercadante of sending him a message urging him not to testify, with Mercadante allegedly indicating the message came from Rousseff. Rousseff's office denied the accusations. Meanwhile, former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is reportedly considering a return to government to save his career and protect himself from prosecution. The scandal has weakened Rousseff's government, with impeachment proceedings and mass protests looming.

site_title: US FCC Internet privacy proposal could harm broadband providers: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Services warned that the US FCC's proposed internet privacy rules could harm broadband providers, citing it as "credit-negative." The proposal, led by FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler, aims to restrict providers from collecting user data without consent. However, digital advertisers like Google and Facebook, regulated by the Federal Trade Commission, could continue to collect data without consent, potentially giving them a competitive advantage. The FCC will vote on the proposal on March 31.

images.alt_text: Ratings agency Moody's Investors Services said on Tuesday that a proposal by US communications regulators to impose privacy restrictions on broadband providers like Verizon Communications Inc, AT&T Inc, Comcast Corp and Charter Communications Inc was "credit-negative."

site_title: Lower mobile data prices are here to stay, putting top lines under pressure
summary: Mobile data prices in Singapore have dropped significantly, with top telcos lowering prices by 25-50% in response to MyRepublic's low-cost data plans. The price war is expected to continue until the third quarter of 2016, when bidding for new spectrum will take place, potentially leading to a fourth telco operator. However, MyRepublic may not become a telco if it fails to secure a mobile operator licence, and the lower-priced plans are likely to remain, putting pressure on telcos' revenues.

site_title: Banks most wary of margin erosion from fintechs: poll
summary: Traditional financial institutions are most wary of fintech threats, with two-thirds ranking margin erosion as the top concern, followed by loss of market share. In Singapore, 73% of financial institutions believe they're at risk of losing business to fintechs. Meanwhile, blockchain technology poses a "radically different competitive future" for the industry, but ranks low on respondents' agendas. Financial services firms are uncertain due to IT security, regulatory uncertainty, and differences in business models, with joint partnerships being the most common form of collaboration with fintech companies.

site_title: Singapore LNG importer shortlist down to three
summary: Singapore LNG importer shortlist narrowed to three companies: Pavilion Energy, Sembcorp Industries, and Royal Dutch Shell, after combined Shell and BG bid. The Energy Market Authority will select a LNG aggregator by the end of this year. Being selected could boost Pavilion Energy's cash flow and diversify Sembcorp Industries' power-generation business. The government aims to develop a gas-trading hub, including supporting LNG bunkering and price discovery initiatives.

site_title: AsiaMalls' portfolio holding up in retail downturn
summary: AsiaMalls Management reported a decent performance in 2015, with revenue for four of its six malls in Singapore growing 2.1% and tenant sales improving 1.3% year-on-year. Despite a 2% drop in footfall, the company met its target and attributed the success to suburban malls catering to necessity shopping. AsiaMalls is now focusing on asset enhancements, with Century Square and White Sands set to undergo renovations, and is exploring ways to engage shoppers online and offline.

site_title: Asian art sales kick off in New York after seizure of stolen statues
summary: US special agents seized two stolen Indian statues valued at $150,000 and $300,000 from Christie's auction house in New York, marking the start of the annual week of Asian art sales. The statues, dating back to the 8th and 10th centuries, were obtained through an international investigation with assistance from India and Interpol. The incident raises concerns about the market for stolen cultural heritage, with Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance warning art dealers to avoid selling stolen artifacts. Despite the economic slowdown in China, the Asian art week is expected to generate significant sales, with Christie's and Sotheby's offering rare and valuable pieces.

site_title: America's secular stagnation due to unconventional monetary policies
summary: Warren Buffett disputes Larry Summers' claim of "secular stagnation" in the US economy, citing America's bright future. Economist Robert Gordon's book argues that the economy faces headwinds, including negative demographic trends and technology limitations, but his forecasts are prone to error. Historically, the US population has grown significantly despite initial projections, and Buffett's optimism is based on long-term trends. Despite the immediate economic challenges, Buffett believes America's future will be vindicated in the long run.

site_title: VW whistle-blower's suit accuses carmaker of deleting data
summary: A former Volkswagen employee, Daniel Donovan, has filed a whistle-blower lawsuit in Michigan, alleging that coworkers deleted electronic data after the US government accused the company of cheating on emissions tests. Donovan claims he was fired in December for reporting the company's alleged obstruction of justice. Volkswagen denies the claim of wrongful dismissal, stating that the circumstances surrounding Donovan's departure were unrelated to the emissions issue. The lawsuit could impact Volkswagen's credibility during settlement negotiations with US authorities.

site_title: IP insurers to offer new standard Class B1 plans from May
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has announced that a new standard Integrated Shield Plan (IP) targeting Class B1 wards in public hospitals will be available starting May 1. The plan, offered by five insurers, will have identical benefits as MediShield Life but with varying premiums. The cheapest option is Great Eastern, followed by NTUC Income, while Aviva is the only insurer that does not require underwriting for downgrading. The new plan will have claim limits, co-payment features, and deductibles, and Medisave can be used to pay for premiums.

site_title: Shaken DRB seen seeking RM1.5b state loan
summary: Malaysia's national carmaker Proton is facing financial struggles, with the company bleeding RM2.5 billion since its takeover by DRB-Hicom in 2012. The conglomerate is seeking a RM1.5 billion soft loan from the government to aid new model development, but this request may be challenging due to the Treasury's lack of funds and strained relations between DRB-Hicom's chairman, Mahathir Mohamad, and Prime Minister Najib Razak. Despite efforts to improve Proton's reputation, the company's financial performance remains a concern, with a loss of RM185 million in the third quarter and a significant decline in market share.

site_title: Unsinkable or fuel-efficient, which to go for?
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is set to address the conflicting goals of making ships unsinkable and fuel-efficient, with experts warning that the two objectives are mutually incompatible. The IMO's marine environment protection committee is considering measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, while the International Parcel Tankers Association (IPTA) has expressed reservations about collecting data on fuel consumption, citing external factors that would complicate accurate measurement. The IMO is expected to weigh the challenges of meeting emissions standards, including the potential 0.5% sulphur cap in 2020 and emerging Emission Control Areas.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore oil and gas sector companies reported disappointing Q415 results due to impairments and provisions. Keppel, however, delivered a better performance, while others, such as Sembcorp Marine and Cosco, faced substantial full-year losses. Companies that have adopted cost-cutting measures and diversified beyond the oil and gas markets are better positioned to ride out the downturn. Ascott Residence Trust has entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire a hotel in Manhattan, US, and launched a private placement to raise S$100 million.

site_title: Historic vote hands Myanmar its first civilian president in decades
summary: Myanmar's lawmakers elected Htin Kyaw, 69, as the country's first civilian president in decades, following a historic vote on March 15, 2016. Kyaw, a close aide and friend of Aung San Suu Kyi, was chosen to serve as a proxy for Suu Kyi, who is constitutionally barred from becoming president. This marks a significant milestone for Myanmar, which has transitioned from a junta-run nation to a civilian-led government.

images.alt_text: Mr Htin Kyaw (second from left), Myanmar's newly elected president, and Ms Suu Kyi (centre), NLD party leader, leaving Parliament in Naypyidaw on Tuesday.

site_title: BOJ tempers its negative interest rate plans
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has softened its stance on negative interest rates, bowing to market concerns. The BOJ Policy Board announced that it would "examine risks to economic activity and prices" and take additional easing measures if necessary to meet its 2% inflation target. The board exempted money reserve funds kept at Japanese trust banks from negative rates, and the governor defended the policy, stating it would stimulate corporate and household economic activity. Analysts believe the BOJ may need to reconsider its negative rate policy due to a pessimistic outlook for the economy.

site_title: Siri doesn't have answers to some mental health concerns
summary: A study by the University of California at San Francisco and Stanford University found that conversational agents like Siri come up short when responding to serious mental health concerns, such as rape and domestic violence. The study, which involved over 60% of US adult smartphone owners, found that Siri and other AI assistants trivialized or failed to provide adequate information on these topics. The study highlights the limitations of AI in addressing complex mental health issues, emphasizing the need for more sophisticated and empathetic responses from AI systems.

images.alt_text: Using the Siri function on an Apple Watch Sport smartwatch. The study found that more than 60% of adult smartphone owners in the US use their personal device for health information.

site_title: Illegal tuna fishing costs Pacific US$740m: report
summary: A study by the European Union-funded Forum Fisheries Agency found that illegal tuna fishing in the Pacific reaches a staggering US$740 million annually, with 276,000-338,000 tonnes of Pacific tuna taken illegally each year. The bulk of the black market catch is attributed to trawlers licensed to operate in Pacific waters, which either under-report their catch or transfer it out of sight of monitors. The problem is exacerbated by limited resources and monitoring capabilities in island nations, with some nations relying on a single patrol boat to police vast territories.

images.alt_text: Tuna fish being loaded onto a truck at a harbour in Bali. After two years of research, an EU-funded study has concluded that 276,000-338,000 tonnes of Pacific tuna were taken illegally every year.

site_title: JD.com seen making gains against Alibaba but at high cost
summary: JD.com has been gaining ground against Alibaba in China's online shopping market, with its share increasing to 20% in 2015 from 17% the previous year. However, the company's efforts to diversify and expand its services have led to higher spending, resulting in a 56% reduction in profit forecasts to 34 US cents per share. JD.com's adjusted loss was 48 US cents per share, despite beating forecasts in sales, which increased 57% to 54.6 billion yuan. Analysts warn that the company's growth may be muted due to the macro slowdown in China.

site_title: Bangladesh central bank chief quits over US$81m heist
summary: Bangladesh's central bank governor Atiur Rahman resigned after hackers stole US$81 million from the nation's foreign reserves in a cyber-heist. The heist, which occurred in February 2016, has embarrassed the government. Finance Minister AMA Muhith asked Rahman to resign, which he did on Tuesday. The incident has raised concerns about the country's cybersecurity and financial stability.

site_title: UOB champions artists with autism
summary: UOB has partnered with Pathlight School, Singapore's first autism-focused school, to showcase the works of 16 students with autism, including 16-year-old Ezra Chan, who won the Most Promising Artist of the Year award last year. The exhibition features a range of artworks, priced from S$450, with proceeds going to the artists and the school. This collaboration aims to promote unity and creativity among diverse cultures, and to provide opportunities for artists with unique abilities to share their work with a wider audience.

site_title: Economy bolsters 'leave' EU campaign in Britain
summary: Britain's 'leave' EU campaign gains momentum, according to a Brexit index. The index, which combines economic and non-economic data points, shows a weakening of the pound sterling and British trade with the EU, increasing the risk of a Brexit. The 'remain' camp faces challenges in maintaining economic stability, as anti-EU sentiment grows. Bookies have also seen a decrease in the risk of an EU exit, from 40% in December to 33% in January. The deteriorating economy and rising anti-EU sentiment are expected to continue, making a Brexit more likely.

site_title: Ringgit undervalued by 28%: Mobius
summary: Franklin Templeton's Mark Mobius stated that Malaysia's ringgit is undervalued by 28%, making it an attractive investment destination for South-east Asian economies. The currency lost 18.5% last year but has strengthened 4.0% this year. Mobius cited emerging markets such as Brazil, Vietnam, and Malaysia as favorites, and noted that China remains a significant growth story despite decelerating growth. India is also seen as a growing market with managed foreign reserves.

site_title: A glimmer of hope despite local market's problems
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faces a decline in mainboard initial public offerings (IPOs) due to a cyclical downturn and structural issues, particularly a slowing China. The lack of quality companies and promising investment opportunities hinders entrepreneurs' access to public capital. This trend is a concern, as IPOs are typically a source of pride for companies and their founders.

site_title: Muted outlook for Singapore labour demand, wages, says MOM
summary: Singapore's Labour Market report shows a muted outlook for job demand and wages, with a 1.9% jobless rate and 15,580 workers made redundant, a 20.5% increase from 2014. Job growth is expected to be modest, with labour demand limited due to cyclical weakness in certain sectors and a decline in casual workers. Wages are expected to rise at a moderate pace, but labour productivity continues to fall.

site_title: Divergent China housing markets 'pose issues'
summary: China's top housing official, Chen Zhenggao, warned of a "substantial gap" between the nation's top cities and lower-tier regions, posing challenges to government regulations. Despite a home-buying frenzy in first-tier cities, residential prices in these hubs have surged, while prices in smaller cities continue to drop. The inventory issue remains "serious", mainly in third and fourth-tier areas, with 739 million square meters of unsold homes nationwide, up 15.7% from last year. The government is working to stabilize prices and encourage rural residents to buy homes in urban areas.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Starhill Global Reit secured a three-year tenancy for two of its malls in Kuala Lumpur, with a total annual rent of RM84.4 million (S$28 million), a 6.67% increase from the previous term. The agreements for Starhill Gallery and Lot 10 Property will commence on June 28.

site_title: Google remains business students' top employer pick
summary: Google remains the top dream employer among Singapore university business students, but has slipped to second place among engineering and natural science students. A*Star, a local government board, has overtaken Google as the most attractive employer for engineering and natural science students. This change in popularity poll by Universum highlights the evolving preferences of Singapore university students.

site_title: Caution reigns as market awaits Fed clues
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index dropped 7.62 points to 2,839.44, with trading volume at 1.8 billion units worth S$994 million. Investors are cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's two-day Open Markets Committee meeting, despite expectations of no interest rate hike. Other markets, such as Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and the Shanghai Composite Index, also saw declines, while the Dow futures traded in the red. Analysts predict a potential rate hike in June, with some downgrading their Asean GDP growth forecasts due to weak exports and lower oil prices.

site_title: January retail sales beat expectations with 7.5% rise
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 7.5% in January, beating expectations, driven by car sales and pre-Chinese New Year shopping. Excluding car sales, retail sales still increased 1.4%. Motor vehicle sales spiked 50.9% and other segments like medical goods and toiletries also saw double-digit growth. However, discretionary spending continued to decline, and economists expect a modest growth outlook for the year. The strong performance is attributed to motor vehicle sales, which are expected to remain supportive of retail sales and GDP growth.

site_title: Rusty jets on tarmac show India beer baron's fallen empire
summary: Kingfisher Airlines, once India's second-largest airline, has abandoned its fleet of seven planes on a tarmac in southern India due to debt and regulatory issues. The airline's founder, Vijay Mallya, owes up to $1.36 billion in debt. Aviation analysts say India's complex regulations hinder the growth of the air travel market, which is the world's fastest-growing. The airline's 2012 demise led to regulatory changes, but these changes do not support the market's growth. The abandoned planes are a symbol of Mallya's fallen empire and the challenges faced by the Indian aviation industry.

site_title: Manila office building hits 26-year high on outsourcing boom
summary: Manila is experiencing a 26-year high in office space construction, driven by the outsourcing boom, with approximately 710,000 square meters of new office space expected this year and over 780,000 square meters in 2017. This surge is largely attributed to international corporations outsourcing jobs such as auditing and information technology to countries with cheaper labor costs. The new supply is expected to cap rents and push vacancies higher, with the vacancy rate projected to rise to 5.6% in 2016.

site_title: Tat Hong at 11-mth high
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, Singapore's largest crane operator, saw its shares surge to an 11-month high after the group announced it was considering a potential offer to buy some of its stock. The stock rose 29.6% to close at S$0.635, with trading volume exceeding 12.6 million shares. The company has appointed a financial adviser and is exploring a potential transaction, but emphasizes that discussions are preliminary and no certainty exists. Tat Hong has faced challenges, including a net loss of S$6.7 million in its fiscal third quarter, due to weak demand in key markets.

images.alt_text: Shares of crane rental company Tat Hong Holdings were lifted to their highest in at least 11 months on Tuesday after the group said in the morning that it was considering a potential offer to buy some of its stock.

site_title: Revving up the engine in rough seas
summary: The marine engine industry is expected to experience growth despite current challenges, driven by increasing environmental regulations and global trade. Tighter regulations on emissions and fuel efficiencies will lead to the adoption of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a cleaner fuel option. Industry players believe that LNG will be a major part of the marine engine business in the years to come, particularly for cruise ships and ferries. Global trade will continue to drive demand for marine engines, with Asia expected to be the growth area for the next five to 10 years.

site_title: Four more resign from Colliers office team
summary: Four experienced brokers and one analyst from Colliers International's office services team have resigned for rival firm Knight Frank, leaving the team with eight brokers and one administrative officer. This follows a series of departures by senior executives at Colliers last year. Separately, Redas has appointed Joseph Tan as CEO-designate, effective March 16, who will succeed retiring CEO Lee Suan Hiang on April 30.

site_title: US oil & gas firms find equity lifeline
summary: US oil and gas companies are raising billions of dollars in equity, betting that crude prices have hit a bottom. Since January, over $11 billion has been raised, with midsize companies like Marathon Oil and Pioneer Natural Resources leading the way. Investors, including hedge funds and mutual funds, are taking advantage of the potential comeback, while riskier investors are also getting in on the action. The International Energy Agency has noted signs that oil prices may have bottomed out, citing production freezes and supply outages.

site_title: Book of essays by those who knew Lee Kuan Yew well launched
summary: A new book titled "Up Close With Lee Kuan Yew" has been launched in Singapore, featuring 37 essays written by close colleagues and friends of the late prime minister Lee Kuan Yew. The book delves into Lee's personal side and provides insights into his life and legacy. Contributors include notable figures such as Robert Kuok, Li Ka-Shing, and former president SR Nathan. The book's proceeds will be donated to 20 pre-schools, and it is available for S$29.96 at major bookstores in Singapore, with a digital format to be launched in April.

site_title: Apple busts myth about closing apps to prolong iPhone battery
summary: Apple has debunked the myth that closing unused apps prolongs iPhone battery life. According to Apple senior vice-president Craig Federighi, multitasking apps do not drain battery when not in use, as they are suspended and cease system resource usage. Actively shutting down apps can cause more stress on the phone and contribute to battery usage. To preserve battery life, users can disable Background App Refresh and turn off location services for underused apps. This applies to iPhones, but not all smartphones, such as Samsung Galaxy and Android devices, which may see longer battery life by actively shutting down running apps.

images.alt_text: Apple said last week that running unused apps is not draining your phone battery, dispelling a long-held belief that had battery-conscious iPhone users constantly managing their open apps.

site_title: Alan Chan becomes LTA chairman on April 1
summary: Alan Chan Heng Loon, CEO of Singapore Press Holdings, becomes chairman of the Land Transport Authority (LTA) on April 1, succeeding Michael Lim Choo San. Under Lim's 14-year tenure, LTA launched and updated the Land Transport Master Plan in 2008 and 2013. Chan's appointment marks a significant change in LTA leadership, with Chan's experience in the media industry bringing a new perspective to the role.

site_title: US$ falls against yen after weak US data, BOJ decision
summary: The US dollar fell by over 1% against the yen on Tuesday, following weak US retail sales data and the Bank of Japan's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. The yen strengthened due to investors' search for safety amid oil's tumble and global equity markets' decline. The US dollar was last down 0.95% to 112.72 yen, while sterling fell 1% against the euro and US dollar after a poll showed support for Britain's EU exit.

site_title: DBS dangles bridging loans for SMEs awaiting government grants
summary: DBS Bank has introduced bridging loans for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) waiting on government grants, offering up to S$100,000 with a four-year term and collateral-free. The loans are designed to cover SMEs' expenses before grant reimbursement, providing a cost-effective way to alleviate cash flow strain. Other banks, including UOB and OCBC, offer similar bridging loan facilities. The move aims to support SMEs in the face of economic challenges and encourage innovation.

site_title: Sony pays US$750m for Michael Jackson estate's share of music catalogue
summary: Sony has agreed to pay the Michael Jackson estate $750 million for its share of the Sony/ATV Music Publishing catalogue, ending a closely watched contest in the music industry. The joint venture, which includes more than 1 million copyrights, including 250 songs by The Beatles, will now be solely owned by Sony. The deal, which was announced on Monday, represents the value of the Jackson estate's share of Sony/ATV after debt. The payment includes a lump sum of $733 million, with the remaining amount to be paid in previous commitments.

images.alt_text: Mr Hirai said the deal "further demonstrates Sony's commitment to the entertainment businesses".

site_title: SGX to list China contracts and launch Indian index futures
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is launching contracts on the MSCI China Free Index and Indian sector-specific index futures. The MSCI China Free Index contracts, subject to regulatory approval, will track the index comprising large and mid-cap Chinese companies listed outside mainland China. The Indian index futures, set to debut on March 29, will include the SGX Nifty IT Index Futures, SGX CPSE Index Futures, SGX Nifty Bank Index Futures, and SGX Nifty Midcap 50 Index Futures.

site_title: Audit quality not just auditors' responsibility
summary: The article highlights that audit quality is not solely the responsibility of auditors. Rather, it involves a team effort from management, company directors, and regulators. Management's preparation of accurate accounting records, directors' oversight of financial reporting, and regulators' enforcement of auditing and accounting standards are all crucial in achieving audit quality. The article emphasizes the importance of collaboration and communication among these stakeholders to ensure effective audit quality, citing examples from the Singaporean context, where the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has implemented initiatives to promote audit quality.

site_title: Air Mauritius moves S-E Asia hub to Singapore from KL
summary: Air Mauritius, the national carrier of Mauritius, is shifting its South-east Asian hub from Kuala Lumpur to Singapore, starting with direct flights. The move aims to strengthen ties with Singapore and boost inter-continental exchanges between Asia and Africa. Air Mauritius will serve 18 cities in 10 countries from Singapore, with a focus on promoting Mauritius as a travel destination for Asian travelers. The airline has secured a S$2 million financial contribution from Changi Airport and will explore code-share flights with Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Yuan to fall 3.5% by year-end if China sentiment stays negative
summary: China's foreign debt repayment is expected to continue, potentially reducing downward pressure on the yuan exchange rate. Since the second half of 2015, Chinese companies have repaid approximately $143-330 billion of foreign debt, which accounts for 14.3-33% of total corporate foreign debt. If this trend continues, the yuan could depreciate by 3.5% against the US dollar by year-end. However, if global sentiment towards China improves and capital outflows reverse, the yuan's decline could be mitigated.

site_title: Confidence among US homebuilders holds at nine-month low
summary: US homebuilders' confidence holds at a nine-month low of 58 in March, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo builder sentiment index. Despite steady progress, a shortage of available properties, especially for first-time buyers, limits further improvement. Low-income Americans face challenges due to outpacing wage growth and rising home prices. The housing industry is expected to make slow but steady progress, with labour market growth supporting the industry.

site_title: Obama administration will not open Atlantic coast to drilling
summary: The Obama administration has decided not to open the southeastern Atlantic coast to drilling due to market and environmental concerns, as well as conflicts with competing commercial and military ocean uses. The US Interior Department has withdrawn its plan after an extensive public input process, with no scheduled lease sales offshore in the mid- and south Atlantic. This decision aims to address local opposition and protect the region's ecosystem.

site_title: US business inventories rise as sales remain weak
summary: US business inventories rose 0.1% in January, contradicting economists' expectations of no change. This suggests businesses may take longer to clear warehouse stock, a sign of weak sales. The increase was also a revision from December, which was initially reported as unchanged. The Commerce Department's report is a key component of the US GDP.

site_title: Chinese hackers likely behind US ransomware attacks
summary: Chinese hackers are likely behind recent US ransomware attacks, according to security firms. The attacks, which involved encrypting computer files and demanding payment, showed a high level of sophistication similar to state-sponsored intrusions. Experts believe the hackers may be former government operatives looking to supplement their income or ordinary criminals who have improved their skills and tools. The attacks may also be linked to China's reduced support for economic espionage, with some companies reporting a decline in Chinese hacking since a US-China agreement.

site_title: Daily currency trading volumes bounce to US$5.0 trillion in Feb: CLS
summary: Global currency trading volumes reached US$5 trillion in February, the first time in eight months, according to CLS data. This marks a 3.3% increase from January and a 2.4% rise from the same month last year. The surge in trading was driven by volatility in major currency pairs at the start of 2016.

site_title: OCBC creates wealth management app for the masses
summary: OCBC has launched a mobile app, OneWealth, aiming to make wealth management services more accessible and simple for the masses. The app aggregates investment ideas and prompts users to buy unit trusts, offering customizable news and reports. It also sets mobile price alerts. OCBC's head of e-business said the app is part of the bank's goal to "democratize" wealth management. The app is available for users with a minimum deposit of S$200,000, and a new savings account, 360 account, offers bonus interest rates for customers who invest in unit trusts or structured deposits.

site_title: Singapore and China renew bilateral currency swap arrangement
summary: Singapore and China have renewed their bilateral currency-swap arrangement (BCSA) for a further three years, effective March 7, 2016. This agreement, established in 2010, aims to strengthen regional economic resilience and financial stability. The original arrangement was first renewed in 2013, and this latest renewal solidifies the cooperation between the People's Bank of China (PBOC) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: Valeant lowers 2016 forecast as drugmaker's woes weigh on 2016
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals lowered its 2016 forecast due to increased scrutiny on its business practices, resulting in a decline in market value. The company now expects $11 billion to $11.2 billion in sales and $9.50 to $10.50 in adjusted earnings per share, down from previous estimates. CEO Michael Pearson's medical leave and the company's decision to restate earnings related to Philidor have contributed to the revised forecast. Valeant also delayed reporting fourth-quarter results due to an ongoing investigation into the mail-order pharmacy.

site_title: India solar tender opens market for battery makers such as Tesla
summary: India has launched its first solar tender with a storage component, requiring bidders to include energy storage in 100 megawatts of 750 megawatts of solar capacity in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The pilot program aims to reduce electricity supply fluctuations and enable clean energy transfer between states. Global battery makers, including Tesla, Samsung SDI, and Panasonic, see an opportunity in the project, with Tesla calling it an "exciting market opportunity." However, some industry experts question the feasibility of the project due to high storage costs.

site_title: US hopes easing limits on Cuba will boost reform in Havana: officials
summary: US officials announced new regulatory changes to Cuba, easing travel restrictions and allowing more US dollars in trade transactions. The reforms aim to encourage people-to-people interactions and economic reforms in Havana. The changes also allow Cubans to work legally in the US without defecting, potentially affecting Major League Baseball. These moves come ahead of President Barack Obama's historic visit to Cuba, which could boost US hopes for reforms in Havana.

site_title: Top Glove eyes secondary listing on SGX
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest glove maker, is set to list its shares on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by the third quarter of this year, marking a significant move to expand its investor base and boost trading liquidity. The move, which does not involve issuing new shares, aims to enhance shareholder value and provide a platform for trading its shares on SGX or Bursa Malaysia. Analysts view the decision as a positive step, citing the company's strong fundamentals and healthy balance sheet, which supports a buying spree.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Man in Manila gets US$30m cash from cyber heist
summary: Bangladesh's central bank governor Atiur Rahman resigned amid a massive cyber heist that stole $81 million from the bank's US account. Details emerged that $30 million was delivered in cash to a casino junket operator in Manila, Philippines. The stolen funds were laundered through two casinos, with the Philippines' Rizal Commercial Banking Corp (RCBC) investigating deposits amounting to the stolen sum. Authorities believe it may be impossible to recover the stolen money due to lack of accountability and anti-money laundering laws.

site_title: New private home sales in Feb at 14-month low
summary: Singapore's private home sales in February fell to a 14-month low, with 301 units sold, a 6.8% month-on-month decline and 22.8% year-on-year decline. Weak sentiment amid the Chinese New Year festivities and stock market volatility contributed to the decline. However, market observers expect sales to pick up in March with new launches, including Cairnhill Nine, The Wisteria, and Wandervale. Developers are expected to sell between 500-800 private homes in March, with more launches scheduled for April.

site_title: Richest in US have to try the least in these coastal towns
summary: The wealthiest Americans in the US have had to put in the least effort to accumulate their earnings in coastal towns, particularly in California. The top 5 cities where the richest have to try the least include Atherton, California; Palm Beach, Florida; Montecito, California; Indian River Shores, Florida; and Los Altos Hills, California. These cities boast high average household incomes, with 69% of homes generating passive income, compared to 21% nationally, resulting in an average of $177,773 in effortless earnings per household.

site_title: China consumer day show targets fake online sales, food delivery
summary: China's annual consumer rights day TV show targeted online food delivery app Ele.me, alleging it allowed unlicensed restaurants and used faked images of their outlets. The show, similar to "60 Minutes," failed to snag major international firms, despite naming companies like Apple and Volkswagen in previous episodes. This year's low-key outing was unusual for the show, which typically sparks responses from global corporations. The allegations against Ele.me were part of the show's efforts to crack down on fake online sales and food delivery practices in China.

site_title: Eurostar saw 'sharp drop' in bookings after Paris attacks
summary: Eurostar reported a 'sharp drop' in bookings after the Paris attacks in November 2015, with passenger numbers remaining flat for 2015. The company's sales fell 5% due to sterling strength, and operating profit dropped to £34 million. However, bookings are now picking up, with forward bookings for the summer looking positive. Eurostar plans to boost its e320 train fleet to increase seat capacity and cut fares.

site_title: Oil prices ease over uncertain supply picture
summary: Oil prices fell for a second day, easing concerns about a six-week rally, as Opec stated demand for its crude would be less than expected in 2016 due to resilient supply from rivals. Saudi Arabia and Russia proposed a production freeze to tackle the surplus, but the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated a more significant challenge to reducing excess supply. The decline in oil prices may have fizzled the hopes for a speedy erosion of global crude overhang.

site_title: Alibaba to train a million teenagers in rural China: report
summary: Alibaba plans to train a million teenagers in rural China to start their own online businesses through a partnership with the China Communist Youth League and a 1 billion yuan investment by Ant Financial. The program aims to take e-commerce to China's vast rural areas, supporting college graduates returning to their hometowns to start businesses.

site_title: US further eases Cuba restrictions ahead of Obama visit
summary: The US has further eased travel and trade restrictions with Cuba ahead of President Barack Obama's historic visit to the island. The Treasury Department announced rule changes allowing Americans to travel to Cuba for educational purposes, US banks to provide services, and US businesses to work freely.
