Despite regional currencies being supportive, volatility in Asian equities remains a concern, with HSBC warning that the current calm should not be seen as an opportunity to build cyclical stocks exposure.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Giving the financial services sector a timely tax boost
summary: Singapore's Budget 2016 aims to boost the financial services sector with tax incentives, including reducing corporate tax rates and enhancing the loss carry back system for insurance companies. The government also proposes to expand the tax incentive schemes for fund managers, allowing them to claim tax exemptions on "specified income" derived from "designated investments." Additionally, the government suggests allowing enhanced deductions for losses on loans extended to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and intellectual property (IP) assets to encourage lending and development of Singapore as an IP hub.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed ahead of Fed meeting
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 15.82 points, while the S&P 500 shed 2.55 points. Oil prices fell, causing declines in petroleum-linked shares. However, some stocks, such as Boeing, Nike, and Tesla, rose due to positive news. The Fed meeting is not expected to produce an interest rate hike, but could signal higher rates. Key earnings announcements included Starwood Hotels & Resorts' acquisition by Anbang Insurance Group and GW Pharmaceuticals' positive test results for a phase-3 study of its treatment for epileptic seizures.

site_title: Japan core machinery orders up in January but underlying trend is flat
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 15.0% in January, driven by large steel industry orders, exceeding economists' expectations. However, excluding steel industry orders, machinery orders were likely flat. This volatile data series is unlikely to ease concerns about the economy. Economists warn that risks from overseas economies and potential revisions to capex forecasts may still impact the economy.

site_title: House briefs
summary: Singapore politics: David Ong's seat has been declared vacant after his abrupt resignation due to an alleged extramarital affair. A new Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system, set to launch in 2020, will price only congested roads initially, but can later implement congestion pricing based on distance traveled. Singapore citizenship is not guaranteed for PRs who have completed National Service, despite being a "plus factor" in the evaluation process. Meanwhile, global economic news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariffs, a slowdown in China's GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Smart ways to future-proof your business
summary: Singapore is on its path to becoming the world's first Smart Nation, with emerging technologies like data analytics and artificial intelligence driving business growth. Companies are future-proofing their businesses by embracing innovation, with the goal of preparing for challenges and opportunities ahead. This involves adopting smart IT strategies, leveraging data-driven insights, and staying adaptable in a fast-paced, data-driven world.

site_title: China Vanke brings in Shenzhen Metro as 'white knight' in up to US$9.3b deal
summary: China Vanke Co Ltd signed a deal worth up to $9.3 billion to acquire Shenzhen Metro Group's property projects, mostly atop subway stations in Shenzhen, China. The deal would give Shenzhen Metro around 20% of total Vanke shares and surpass its largest shareholder, Baoneng. Vanke's shares jumped 14% on the news, and analysts expect the deal to be net asset value-accretive for Vanke, leading to further collaboration between the two companies.

site_title: Temasek, GIC among investors in Alibaba's logistics arm
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm, Cainiao, has completed a funding round with investors including Temasek Holdings and GIC Pte Ltd, valuing the unit at an undisclosed amount. This is Cainiao's first funding round since its founding three years ago. Alibaba aims to develop a national logistics network to support e-commerce growth, with a goal of spending 100 billion yuan (S$21.2 billion) over five to eight years. The move is seen as a response to competition from JD.com, a rival e-commerce company in China.

site_title: PBA Group to open non-profit robotics hub
summary: Singapore-based PBA Group plans to open a non-profit robotics hub, the Robotics Automation Centre of Excellence (Race), in June. The hub will house 20-30 robots and four to six full-time employees, offering hands-on learning opportunities for smaller businesses and factories. PBA aims to provide a neutral platform for manufacturers to display their technology and train participants, without promoting specific brands. The hub will be funded with an estimated S$500,000 and will occasionally invite external trainers to educate participants on robotics solutions. PBA hopes the hub will grow the Singapore market for robotics and establish the country as the robotics hub of the region.

site_title: More tax breaks for firms that anchor pioneering activities in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed amendments to the Economic Expansion Incentives Act, offering greater tax incentives to companies that anchor pioneering activities in the country. Firms awarded a pioneer certificate will receive the maximum 15-year tax relief period for each activity, up from the current 15-year period for the company as a whole. The changes aim to encourage companies to undertake high-value-added manufacturing or services activities, creating jobs for Singaporeans and boosting the economy.

site_title: Beware the 'Ides of March': last chance to stop Trump
summary: US presidential front-runner Donald Trump is poised to win the Republican primaries on March 15, which could grant him significant momentum and potentially secure his party's nomination. Trump's wins in Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri, and North Carolina would give him close to half of the 1,237 delegates needed to win the nomination. His opponents, including Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, are struggling to gain traction, and a "contested convention" or "brokered convention" scenario remains unlikely if Trump wins all or most of the races. Trump's populist message has resonated with Republican voters, and his opponents' attempts to attack him have backfired.

site_title: Discrepancies found in Trek 2000 unit's sale transaction documents
summary: Trek 2000 International's subsidiary has found discrepancies in sale transactions, including differences in customer identity, delivery orders, and payment records. External auditors have raised concerns about the source of US$2.65 million in payments. The aggregate value of the transactions is about US$3.2 million. Trek 2000 is seeking a time extension to announce its financial results and advises shareholders to exercise caution. The company's counter ended trading flat on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia signs bank access pacts with Thailand, Philippines
summary: Malaysia's central bank signed agreements with Thailand and the Philippines on market access and operational flexibility for lenders, moving towards an integrated banking market within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). The Asean Economic Community aims to promote trade, capital, and labor flow among 625 million people with a combined economic output of $2.6 trillion. The agreements mark a major step forward in advancing an integrated banking market, with potential future bilateral negotiations on Qualified Asean Banks and trade settlement plans.

site_title: Singer turns her modest act into a stirring breakthrough
summary: Rawan Okasha, a 24-year-old Gaza singer, performed a rare concert in the city, singing patriotic Arabic folk songs and poems. The event, which was approved by Hamas, marked a breakthrough in Gaza's conservative culture, where women are often barred from performing in public. Okasha's performance was met with a mix of reactions, with some praising her bravery and others expressing discomfort with the sight of women singing in public. The singer's family, known as the Okasha 13, has a history of producing musicians, but the women have faced challenges in pursuing their careers due to Hamas' strict rules.

images.alt_text: Ms Okasha follows the Culture Ministry's rules when performing: standing still while singing, dressing modestly and sticking to patriotic music.
Ms Okasha follows the Culture Ministry's rules when performing: standing still while singing, dressing modestly and sticking to patriotic music.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings received a three-month extension from the Singapore Exchange to release its FY2015 financial results due to focusing on asset disposal and shares transfer approvals. The company's shares closed at 0.2 cents, 33% lower than the previous day. Dyna-Mac Holdings' shares rose 1.9 cents to 17.5 cents after unusual trade volume movements. Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Reit completed a S$38 million divestment of its Pandan Loop property, using the proceeds to repay outstanding borrowings.

site_title: App Annie betting on South-east Asia and India
summary: App Annie, a Singapore-based startup, is expanding its operations to capitalize on the growing demand for mobile app data in South-east Asia and India. The company will triple its staffing in Singapore to 25 people this year, as it targets new customers in the region. With a recent US$63 million funding, App Annie aims to measure the users in Asia who are bypassing earlier technologies and capitalize on the expected 24% surge in spending on mobile apps in Asia this year, reaching US$28.3 billion.

site_title: 'Supply-side reform' is buzz phrase at China's annual parliament
summary: China's annual parliament is focusing on "supply-side reform," a term that has been left vague by President Xi Jinping, allowing various interpretations among delegates. The concept, aimed at scaling back government involvement in business, has led to differing views on its meaning, with some seeing it as upgrading state-owned companies, while others believe it's a license for companies to go on an overseas acquisition spree. The lack of clear definition raises concerns of wasteful spending by provincial authorities, echoing past instances of over-investment by local officials.

site_title: Wages in Japan need to rise for Abenomics to work, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Japan's Abenomics needs a "fourth arrow" - an official policy to boost wages - to work effectively. Wages have not been rising at a sufficient rate to combat deflation, with full-time wages increasing by only 0.3% since 1995. The IMF suggests introducing a "comply-or-explain" mechanism for companies to raise wages by at least 2% plus productivity growth, or strengthening tax incentives to encourage wage growth. This is necessary to address the structural causes of deflation, including lifetime employment contracts and non-regular contracts.

images.alt_text: Abenomics needs a "fourth arrow" - an official policy to boost wages - that will work in tandem with other stimulus policies being implemented under the original three arrows, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Monday.

site_title: Starwood Hotels gets rival bid from Anbang consortium
summary: Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc has received a separate, unsolicited takeover proposal from China's Anbang Insurance Group Co, valuing the company at approximately US$12.9 billion. The proposal is for US$76 per share in cash, while Marriott International Inc's offer, which Starwood still supports, values the company at US$72.08 per share. If Starwood accepts Anbang's offer, it would have to pay a US$400 million termination fee to Marriott.

site_title: Property swap is constructive reform
summary: China's state-owned conglomerate Citic is offloading most of its mainland residential property to a government-controlled rival, China Overseas Land & Investment (COLI), in a $6.6 billion deal. Citic will receive a portfolio of commercial property worth almost $1 billion and a 10% stake in COLI in exchange. The deal is seen as a sign of constructive reform, helping Citic streamline its property assets and focus on commercial development. The move is part of a broader effort to overhaul state-owned enterprises, with similar deals underway to consolidate China's state-controlled property sector.

site_title: Keppel Land seeks to cancel remaining shares
summary: Keppel Land, a Singaporean company, plans to cancel all remaining shares held by external shareholders through a selective capital reduction exercise. The S$47.9 million exercise, if approved, will eliminate shares held by 0.73% of shareholders, leaving Keppel Corporation with 99.27% ownership. Keppel Land will offer S$4.24 per share to these shareholders, a 16.2% premium over the last transacted price. The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval, with a required 75% vote.

site_title: Maybank Singapore to grow retail SME business
summary: Maybank Singapore plans to expand its retail SME business, aiming to grow its loan portfolio by 40% to businesses with revenues of up to S$20m. The bank has seen a 50% increase in SME loans since setting up a dedicated unit two years ago. The move comes as 60% of SMEs in Singapore rely on bank loans, and Maybank aims to target this segment through its online capabilities and simplified financing processes.

site_title: Local spice and nut trader folds, owner declared bankrupt
summary: Kirpa Ram Sharma, 60, a prominent Indian businessman and director of Pars Ram Brothers, a spice and nut trading company, has been declared bankrupt. The company, which owed between $130 million and $170 million to 10-17 banks, was placed under provisional liquidation in 2015. Sharma's wife and son were also declared bankrupt as they acted as joint guarantors for the bank loans. The business, which was established in 1937, has collapsed after facing financial difficulties, including problems collecting payments from customers in the Middle East and speculation in foreign exchange markets.

site_title: US$ ticks up against euro; focus on Fed meeting
summary: US dollar rises against euro, stabilizing after last week's market swings, as investors await central bank policy meetings. The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1110 due to rising stock markets, while the dollar eased against yen to 113.70 yen. The Federal Open Market Committee meeting is expected to convey a neutral tone, with a possible acknowledgment of improved US inflation. The Bank of Japan is also expected to maintain its negative interest rate policy, which may impact market expectations.

site_title: Insurance rider premiums on the rise as claims continue to climb
summary: Two Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers, Prudential and Aviva, are raising rider premiums due to increasing claims. Prudential increased premiums by 3-14% and Aviva by 30-60%, while another insurer, AIA, is expected to follow suit. Only Great Eastern and NTUC Income will not raise rider premiums for now. The rise in claims is attributed to rising hospital charges, increasing hospital admissions, and higher medical inflation.

site_title: Yuan bears take a US$562m beating from currency's resilience
summary: China's yuan has strengthened 1.6% since January, defying expectations of further decline, with over $1.2 billion of options that pay out if the currency drops below 6.6 per US dollar expiring worthless since August. The Chinese government has intervened aggressively to prop up the currency, including limiting capital outflows and suspending quotas for outbound investment. Despite some remaining pessimists, experts believe the yuan's resilience is due to China's strong economy, large foreign exchange reserves, and commitment to maintaining a stable currency. The yuan is expected to continue to strengthen, with some predicting a decline of up to 3% to 6.7 per US dollar by year-end.

site_title: Instacart gets Pepsi, Doritos to pay shoppers' delivery fees
summary: Instacart has partnered with major consumer goods makers such as Pepsi, General Mills, and Nestlé to cover delivery fees for shoppers. The companies pay Instacart to advertise on its website and provide discounts, accounting for 15% of the company's revenue. This partnership aims to reduce delivery costs for customers, making online grocery shopping more affordable.

site_title: United Airlines CEO's pay, board role scrutinised
summary: Two activist investors, PAR Capital Management Inc and Altimeter Capital Management LP, have criticized United Airlines' CEO Oscar Munoz's compensation and the airline's board, citing low customer satisfaction scores and sagging stock. They oppose the plan to make Munoz chairman and have proposed six new directors, including former Continental Airlines chief Gordon Bethune. The funds have expressed concerns about Munoz's spending on media and worker outreach, as well as the lack of experienced airline executives on the board. United has defended Munoz's performance and the board, and the two sides are open to a settlement.

site_title: Online harassment must be met head-on: tech summit panel
summary: A panel at the South By Southwest tech summit in Austin emphasized that online harassment and sexism must be addressed head-on to ensure the gaming industry thrives. The discussion came after threats of violence prompted the initial suspension of panels on the subject. Organizers reversed course after facing criticism from online media firms, setting up a full day of discussions on the issue. The panelists noted that online harassment is demeaning to women and cannot be dismissed as an "ugly side" of social media and gaming.

site_title: Juneyao Air aims to double fleet as Disney lands in Shanghai
summary: Juneyao Airlines aims to double its fleet by 2020, driven by expected growth in tourist travel following the opening of Disney's Shanghai park. The privately run Chinese carrier is also considering joining a global alliance. Chairman Wang Junjin sees huge potential for growth, citing China's large population of 1.3 billion people, with only 400 million passenger trips made last year.

site_title: France sends in heavyweights in bid for Aussie submarine deal
summary: France has sent its largest business delegation in nearly two decades to Australia to bid for the A$50 billion contract to build 12 stealth submarines. The French delegation, including top officials from state-controlled naval contractor DCNS, is competing with Japan and Germany for the lucrative deal. The decision is expected within months, ahead of an Australian national election, with the French pushing the subs deal as a way to boost Australia's slowing economy and grow strategic and economic ties with the country.

site_title: Brexit may be just the catalyst needed for real EU reform
summary: The EU faces a potential catalyst for reform following the Brexit referendum, which may lead to a democratic breakthrough. Prime Minister David Cameron's efforts to seek EU reform have failed, but Brexit could be the catalyst for change. The EU's "patrician" elite has been accused of prioritizing special interests over the common good, and Brexit may force them to reform. The outcome of the referendum will determine whether the EU is doomed or if Brexit sparks meaningful reform, potentially leading to a more democratic and responsive union.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as market eyes Fed
summary: US stocks fell early Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 45.30 points (0.26%) at 17,168.01, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. The market is awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy meeting, which is not expected to result in a rate hike but could signal plans for future rate increases. Several stocks moved significantly, including Starwood Hotels & Resorts, The Fresh Market, and GW Pharmaceuticals, which rose due to news of mergers and positive test results.

site_title: The Malaysian Insider ceases operations with immediate effect
summary: Malaysia's The Malaysian Insider, a popular news portal, ceases operations with immediate effect due to significant monthly losses of RM2 million and lack of commercial support. The decision was made despite its status as a top-three news portal in Malaysia, attributed to its courageous reporting. Run-ins with authorities and declining readership, partly due to the Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission's (MCMC) blocking of access to the portal, also contributed to the closure. All 59 staff will receive a severance package.

images.alt_text: "The closure of TMI should serve as a reminder . . . that good journalism cannot be sustained without commercial support," said Mr Ho.

site_title: Bullion back in fashion against paper money
summary: Gold prices have surged due to the widespread adoption of negative interest rates and sharp devaluation of emerging market currencies, making cash and bank deposits less attractive. As a result, investors are turning to gold as a safe-haven asset, with prices reaching an all-time high against several major currencies. Analysts attribute the surge to the changing monetary landscape, which is forcing investors to re-evaluate their risk appetite, and the potential for increased inflation if the velocity of circulation of money picks up.

site_title: Payrolls rose in 30 US states in January, led by Florida
summary: US payrolls rose in 30 states in January, with Florida leading the advance with 32,200 new jobs. Unemployment rates fell in 28 states, with Oregon reporting the largest decline. The labour market remains resilient, with the US economy showing signs of picking up pace. Federal Reserve policymakers have taken note of the progress on employment, with chief economist Scott Brown predicting a solid labour market.

site_title: Bond trading set to surge in 2016: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a "Year of the Bull" for bond markets in 2016, citing a supportive global backdrop and low interest rates. The US Federal Reserve is expected to delay raising interest rates until December, while central banks in Europe and Japan will continue to ease monetary policy. Treasury 10-year yields are forecast to fall to 1.45% by September, approaching a record low. The report also notes that borrowing costs have fallen globally, with average yields on US$23 trillion of bonds reaching a record low of 0.69% in February.

site_title: Stricken US shale producers shift up a gear
summary: US shale producers are intensifying fracking methods to extract more oil, despite low prices. They're pushing techniques like 50-stage frack jobs, 15-foot cluster spacing, and increased proppant use. These advancements could boost initial output by 5-50% per well, with companies like Pioneer Natural Resources and Hess Corp leading the charge. Experts say the techniques' impact may be noticeable only when prices recover, but drillers are preparing for a potential surge in production.

site_title: US inflation survey rebounds in relief for Fed
summary: US inflation expectations rebounded in February, rising to 2.71% one year ahead and 2.62% three years ahead, according to the New York Fed's consumer survey. This marks the first increase in expectations since the survey began in 2013. The firming inflation measures could support Federal Reserve interest rate hikes in the months ahead.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Weak growth in 2015 to dent government revenue
summary: Singapore's government faces a budget deficit of S$6.67 billion in FY15 due to weak economic growth, with GDP growing at 2% in 2015, its slowest growth since the 2009 global financial crisis. The government expects growth to be between 1-3% in FY16. To mitigate the impact, the government has increased top marginal tax rates and will factor in Temasek Holdings' returns into net investment returns. These efforts are expected to help the government achieve a razor-thin surplus or break even in FY16.

site_title: Opec sees lower 2016 demand for its oil, pointing to higher surplus
summary: Opec predicts a lower global demand for its crude oil in 2016, citing higher supply from rivals and increasing excess supply. The organization forecasts an average daily demand of 31.52 million barrels per day, down 90,000 bpd from previous estimates. This would result in a 760,000-bpd excess supply if production remains at February's rate. The decrease in demand and increase in supply may lead to a surplus in the market.

site_title: India's Internet startups come down to earth
summary: India's internet startup space has experienced a significant downturn, with investors shifting focus to sustainable businesses. After a boom in 2015, venture capital and private equity funding has declined, leading to falling deal values. Mergers and acquisitions have become more prevalent as startups restructure and focus on fundamentals. Despite this, the Indian market remains promising, with opportunities in e-commerce, education, travel, and other sectors. Experts predict the market will continue to grow, driven by increasing smartphone adoption and changing consumer needs.

site_title: From budding artist to model student
summary: Vishnucharan Naidu, a former beneficiary of The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, received the Model Student Award from Singapore Polytechnic for his academic and co-curricular excellence. He currently pursues a diploma in Applied Drama and Psychology, which focuses on using drama for social causes. Naidu also owns his own production company, Big Birds Productions, which aims to make arts accessible to all and donates profits to fund the next show. He plans to produce at least three shows a year and teach on the side, aiming to use theatre to reach out to young people who cannot afford arts education.

site_title: A new chapter for Tiger Airways
summary: Tiger Airways, a budget airline, has become a fully owned subsidiary of Singapore Airlines (SIA) after a takeover bid. The acquisition, finalized in March 2016, marks a new chapter for Tiger Airways. SIA had previously held a 56% stake in the airline, but acquired the remaining shares to integrate the two carriers. The move aims to boost connecting traffic between Tiger and SIA's Scoot, with a joint reservation system set to launch in April. The integration also aims to strengthen the SIA group's presence in the market and address competition from Gulf carriers and regional budget airlines.

site_title: EU leaders gear up for landmark migration deal
summary: EU leaders will convene on Thursday for a two-day summit to discuss a landmark migration deal aimed at stabilizing mass migration to the continent. The deal, which includes a €3 billion payment to Turkey and accelerated visa-free travel for its citizens, has been criticized on moral, legal, and practical grounds. Critics argue that Turkey lacks the infrastructure and political will to implement the deal, and that it may lead to increased migration to the EU. Despite these concerns, EU leaders will push forward with the deal, driven by growing pressure to address the migration crisis and maintain the continent's generous asylum system.

site_title: Yahoo CEO hopes to stay in job even if company changes hands
summary: Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer is hopeful of keeping her job if the company changes hands, despite facing pressure from investors and a potential proxy fight. Mayer has pledged to prioritize shareholder interests as Yahoo reviews alternatives for separating its core Internet business from its stake in Alibaba Group. This move comes as Yahoo reviews its options for a potential sale or spin-off.

site_title: EU must stamp out service sector protectionism: auditor
summary: The European Commission must take stronger action to enforce EU service sector rules, auditors said in a report. The EU has failed to open up markets, with member states imposing barriers to foreign competition, and the Commission has not used its power to penalize non-compliant states. Examples of such barriers include technical hurdles and discriminatory practices. The auditors argue that the Commission should use its power to start disciplinary procedures and take states to the EU court, and that it should be more proactive in pursuing legal proceedings.

site_title: Noble seeking renewal of loans without further asset sales: source
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, is seeking over $4 billion in new and refinanced loans without further asset sales, according to a senior source. The company is negotiating with lenders to replace existing facilities, including an oil inventory-backed loan of $2.5-3.25 billion and a revolving credit facility of up to $2.2 billion. Noble has downgraded its ratings to "junk" status but is not required to sell assets as part of the refinancing discussions. The company is instead exploring alternative strategic plans, including equity issuance and partnership with private equity firms, to strengthen its balance sheet.

site_title: Myanmar bourse to get first listing on March 25
summary: Myanmar's Yangon Stock Exchange plans its first listing on March 25, with conglomerate First Myanmar Investment (FMI) set to be the first company to list. FMI, owned by tycoon Surge Pun, has met exchange requirements, while Thilawa SEZ Holdings, a new industrial zone operator, is also expected to list. The exchange, which was launched in December, has faced delays due to governance and capacity issues, with no transactions taking place since its opening. Four other companies are also expected to list, including Myanmar Citizens Bank and First Private Bank.

site_title: Much uncertainty about Vanke's rescue plan
summary: China property developer Vanke has unveiled a plan to sell a stake to Shenzhen's metro operator in exchange for assets worth up to $9.3 billion. The deal aims to fend off a potential hostile bid from Baoneng, which has become Vanke's largest shareholder. Vanke will purchase stakes in property projects near subway stations and issue new shares to the metro operator. The proposal has raised questions about whether Vanke is being rescued by a white knight or swallowing a poison pill, and its impact on shareholders.

site_title: Young tech startups turn to corporate sugar daddies: Gadfly
summary: Young tech startups are turning to corporate sugar daddies to stay afloat due to the increasing pressure to show profitability. Companies like Instacart, GrubHub, DoorDash, Fitbit, and Scoop are partnering with businesses to cover costs, such as grocery delivery fees, commission for items sold, and employee wellness programs. This approach is seen as a way to generate reliable revenue and avoid relying on venture-capital dollars, which have become scarce. By making businesses pay, these startups aim to reduce their financial risk and increase their chances of success.

site_title: US should okay TPP deal before next president takes office
summary: US presidential candidate Bernie Sanders, a strong opponent of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) accord, has scored an upset win in Michigan, beating Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton and Republican front-runner Donald Trump. Sanders, a social-democrat senator from Vermont, shares Trump's opposition to pro-free trade policies, a stance that has been pursued by Democratic and Republican presidents since 1945. The TPP deal, finalized last year, aims to promote free trade among Pacific Rim nations, but Sanders' victory highlights the growing divide within the US over globalization and trade policies.

site_title: ECB's Villeroy says priority to boost financing for real economy
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) latest efforts aim to boost financing for the real economy by providing ultra-cheap loans to banks, with the goal of encouraging lending to households and businesses. ECB governing council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau stated that the priority is financing the real economy, citing the decision to buy corporate bonds as an important step in securing companies' access to financing. This move is part of a broader package to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: China's CNOOC eyes Petrobras' stake in Braskem: paper
summary: China's CNOOC Ltd is interested in purchasing a minority stake in Brazilian petrochemical company Braskem SA from state-run Petroleo Brasileiro SA. This comes as Petrobras seeks to sell assets to finance expansion and pay down its $130 billion debt. Braskem's controlling shareholder Grupo Odebrecht SA may also sell its stake in a joint transaction with Petrobras. The talks are preliminary, and representatives for Petrobras and CNOOC were not immediately available for comment.

site_title: German blue-chip DAX 30 index breaks through 10,000 points
summary: The German DAX 30 index broke through the 10,000-point psychological level for the first time since January 13, rising 2.1% to 10,039.61. This followed the European Central Bank's rate cut and bond-buying last week. Market focus shifts to central bank meetings this week, including the Bank of Japan, Federal Reserve, and Bank of England, with traders seeking fresh stimulus and clues about future rate hikes.

site_title: RBS chairman says Cameron's EU deal could bolster ECB's powers
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland chairman Howard Davies suggests that Britain's EU deal could bolster the European Central Bank's powers, potentially sidelining the UK. The deal allows for deeper eurozone integration, giving the ECB more leeway to adapt EU rules. Davies' remarks echo views that the settlement may shift the financial services center of gravity to the eurozone, undermining Britain's influence. The arrangement erodes the power of the European Banking Authority, further concentrating regulatory power within the ECB.

site_title: Germany to invest 10 bln euros in faster Internet by 2025
summary: Germany plans to invest 10 billion euros by 2025 to improve Internet connections in rural areas, aiming to have broadband coverage across the country by 2018. The goal is to establish a gigabit fibre optic network, which would allow speeds of one gigabit per second, 20 times faster than regular broadband. The government will partly finance the fund through auctioning UMTS mobile phone frequencies and is urging the private sector to play a bigger role. This expansion is seen as crucial to maintain Germany's industrial base competitiveness in the face of US and Asian competitors.

site_title: Goldman revamps electronic stock trading to catch rival
summary: Goldman Sachs is revamping its electronic stock trading technology to improve execution quality and catch up with rival Morgan Stanley. Partner Raj Mahajan, hired in 2015, has brought in dozens of technologists to upgrade the system, which will soon integrate Goldman's proprietary algorithms. The move aims to deliver the best execution quality to clients and win back business from Morgan Stanley, which has been investing heavily in electronic trading. Goldman's investment in the electronic business is notable, as the bank is cutting costs and being selective with its investments.

site_title: Singapore to ban cigarette displays in stores
summary: Singapore's parliament voted to ban the display of cigarettes in stores starting from 2017, joining countries like Australia and the UK in curbing the habit in the nation with one of the world's lowest smoking rates. The ban also includes all forms of cigarette advertising, including online ads, and electronic-cigarettes will not be displayed. The move aims to protect the public from the advertising effects of tobacco, despite Singapore's relatively low smoking rate of 13.3% in 2013. The ban is part of the city-state's efforts to maintain its low smoking rate.

site_title: India delays plans to open up coal sector to private firms
summary: India has delayed plans to open up its coal sector to private firms due to lower-than-expected demand for the fuel. The country aims to increase coal output to 1.5 billion tonnes by 2020, but private companies have not shown enough interest, forcing the government to delay commercialization. State-run Coal India has ramped up production, but debt-heavy power companies are not buying enough, leading to a delay in opening the sector to non-government companies for the first time in over 40 years.

site_title: Keppel Land to start selective capital reduction exercise at S$4.24 per share
summary: Keppel Land will conduct a selective capital reduction exercise, cancelling the remaining shares held by external shareholders at S$4.24 per share. The S$47.9 million exercise aims to reduce the 0.73% of shares held by external shareholders. The move, if approved, will result in Keppel Corporation owning 100% of Keppel Land. The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval, with a special resolution requiring at least 75% of shares voted in favor.

site_title: Ascott Reit acquires New York hotel for US$158m
summary: Ascott Reit acquired the 369-unit Sheraton Tribeca New York Hotel in downtown New York City for US$158 million. The acquisition will be funded by US$100 million from a private placement and US$58 million from debt. Ascott Reit expects an Ebitda of 6.8% and an increase in distribution income by US$6.6 million. This is the Reit's second US acquisition in less than a year, following the purchase of Element New York Times Square West in 2015. The deal is expected to increase distribution per unit to 8.11 Singapore cents.

site_title: India CPI eases more than estimated before Rajan's rate review
summary: India's inflation eased to 5.18% in February, lower than the estimated 5.52%, adding pressure on central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan to lower interest rates. The government's plan to narrow the budget deficit to 3.5% of GDP also supports this move. Rajan is scheduled to review policy on April 5, aiming to keep CPI within 5% by March 2017. The central bank is concerned about meeting India's longer-term inflation targets, which may be challenging due to drought-affected harvests and economic weakness.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.77 points to close at 1,700.31, driven by 419 gainers and 412 losers in trading of 1.5 billion lots valued at RM1.61 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher by 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% to 2,847.06, driven by gains from last Friday's Wall Street rally and European Central Bank stimulus measures. The Straits Times Index climbed 18.2 points, with 229 counters up and 190 down. Total trades were 1.4 billion shares worth S$970 million.

site_title: Indonesia warns of fire risk in haze-prone regions in March-April
summary: Indonesia's state weather agency (BMKG) warns of increased fire risk in western and central regions from March to April due to dry weather conditions. The region experiences haze each dry season, primarily caused by deliberate land clearing for palm oil plantations. A 50% chance of a La Nina weather pattern affecting Indonesia in the fourth quarter may lead to a wetter "dry" season and heavier rainy season, potentially benefiting rice production. The warning comes after a severe haze episode in 2015, which cost the country an estimated $16 billion.

site_title: Blackstone may have set a private equity speed record: Gadfly
summary: Blackstone Group sold US luxury chain Strategic Hotels to Chinese insurance company Anbang Insurance for $6.5 billion, just three months after acquiring it, exceeding the original purchase price of $6.05 billion. This swift sale may indicate Anbang's poor deal-making skills, particularly considering the company had previously spent $1.95 billion on the Waldorf-Astoria hotel. The rapid sale suggests Blackstone's founder, Steven Schwarzman, may not have had to work hard to achieve his payday, potentially undermining Anbang's skills as a dealmaker.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on global strength, mainland rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.2% to 20,435.34 on Monday, driven by gains in mainland shares and a global market rally as oil prices climbed. The China Enterprises Index gained 1.5% to 8,686.27 points, with most sectors rising. China Vanke Co Ltd surged 10% to a two-month high after reporting a 13% increase in 2015 core profit.

site_title: Euro-area industrial production surges most since 2009
summary: Industrial production in the euro area surged 2.1% in January, the strongest monthly performance in over six years, driven by growth in Germany, France, and Italy. This represents a 2.8% annual rise, the largest since 2011. Economists' forecasts for the quarter and next were revised upward, despite inflation remaining below the European Central Bank's goal, as the economy has shown relatively consistent performance in recent quarters.

site_title: China's 'easy' home financing could raise property bubble risk
summary: China's housing market is raising concerns about a property bubble due to easy home financing. Officials vowed to crack down on players lending money for downpayments, which can fuel the market. Frenzied purchases in Shanghai and Shenzhen have led to 17.5% and 51.9% price increases, respectively. The central bank may be more worried about non-bank lending, which often offers quick approval but high interest rates. Defaults on these loans are rare, but a property bubble bursting could lead to financial risks for many borrowers.

site_title: Death toll in Turkish car bomb attack rises to 37
summary: A car bomb attack in Ankara, Turkey's capital, has killed 37 people and injured 71, with 15 in serious condition. The Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) militant group is suspected to be responsible for the attack, which is the second such incident in the city in under a month.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.2% to 6,150.21 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index jumping 1.2% to 9,948.21 points. The Bank of Japan began a two-day meeting, while the Federal Reserve and Bank of England gather this week, with markets watching for potential stimulus or rate hikes. The European Central Bank recently cut rates and boosted bond-buying to stimulate the eurozone economy.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday following a strong start to the week across Asia, as traders looked ahead to more central bank action.

site_title: Edge Media Group to shut down Malaysian Insider from midnight Monday
summary: The Edge Media Group announced the shutdown of The Malaysian Insider news portal from midnight on March 14, 2016, due to commercial reasons. TMI editor Jahabar Sadiq expressed gratitude for the service provided since the portal's launch in 2008.

site_title: Alibaba's logistics arm completes fundraising with Temasek, GIC, Khazanah
summary: Alibaba's logistics arm Cainiao has completed a funding round with investors Temasek, GIC, Khazanah, and Primavera Capital. This is the first funding round since Cainiao's founding three years ago. Alibaba aims to take a lead in China's fragmented package delivery industry, leveraging data from partner delivery businesses to increase efficiency.

site_title: Malaysia, Australia to discuss China moves in disputed South China Sea
summary: Malaysia's Defence Minister Hishammuddin Hussein will meet his Australian counterpart to discuss China's military buildup in the disputed South China Sea, alongside the Philippines and Vietnam. China claims most of the sea's waters, while the US has been conducting "freedom of navigation" operations near islands with reclamation work. The talks aim to address public pressure on China to protect its claims, amid concerns about the region's energy-rich waters and $5 trillion in ship-borne trade.

site_title: China's supply-side slogan means different things to different people
summary: China's annual parliament has adopted the concept of "supply-side reform," a slogan introduced by President Xi Jinping, which analysts interpret as scaling back the government's role in business to allow market forces to flourish. However, the term's exact meaning has been left vague, leading to diverse interpretations, including upgrading noodle shops, manufacturing high-tech products, and approving price controls. The government aims to eliminate industrial overcapacity, reduce state-owned enterprises, and promote market forces, but the lack of clear definition raises concerns about wasteful spending and implementation challenges.

site_title: Tencent invests in Chinese nip-tuck app in US$50m round
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has invested US$50 million in SoYoung Technology, a Chinese app developer of a non-invasive plastic surgery platform, in a bid to tap the growing aesthetic medical services market in China. The app has seen 10 million downloads and aims to enlist 200 clinics and 1,000 plastic surgeons within three years. With the funds, SoYoung plans to develop cloud computing technology to offer loan-financing options for surgery. Tencent will help boost app downloads by targeting users, while regulators may scrutinize the industry's growing popularity.

images.alt_text: SoYoung Technology (Beijing) Co, the developer of the application, has attracted Tencent Holdings Ltd in a financing round of US$50 million, according to a statement from the company on Monday.

site_title: Japan, US, France to team up on Fukushima clean-up
summary: Japan is teaming up with the US and France to develop new technologies to collect melted fuel from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. The project aims to tackle the plant's massive cleanup, which is expected to take up to four decades. The Japanese government will finance the project, worth 3.0 billion yen, and collaborate with US and French experts on equipment, remote-control technology, and radioactive waste management. The goal is to eventually decommission the plant, which is expected to begin in 2021, and make the area habitable again.

site_title: Football: Fifa bans S African officials over match-fixing
summary: FIFA's ethics watchdog banned South African football chief Leslie Sedibe for five years and fined him 20,000 Swiss francs over match-fixing surrounding the national team. Two former referees, Steve Goddard and Adeel Carelse, were also banned for two years. The cases were linked to international friendly matches played in South Africa in 2010. This is the latest in a series of bans and fines related to match-fixing in South Africa, following a 2012 FIFA investigation into the activities of convicted match-fixer Wilson Perumal.

site_title: UBS to open books on Additional Tier 1 US dollar bond
summary: UBS is set to reopen the Additional Tier 1 US dollar bond market, which has been shut since mid-January due to volatility and concerns over banks' ability to pay coupons. The Swiss lender plans to issue a 7% to 7.125% perpetual non-call five-year bond, which will be written down if its Common Equity Tier 1 ratio falls below 7%. This move comes after the European Central Bank's stimulus, which has led to a recovery in riskier assets, including UBS's own Additional Tier 1 debt.

site_title: China steps up war of words with United States over human rights
summary: China responded to US criticism of its human rights record, accusing the US of hypocrisy and racism. Government-backed academics blamed the US for promoting extremist groups, including Islamic State, and for its electoral system being controlled by corporate interests. China denied censoring websites and claimed to have a problem with its own human rights record, but avoided discussing televised confessions of suspects. The US criticism came after the UN criticized China's crackdown on human rights and detentions of lawyers and activists.

site_title: Oil back below US$40 as Iran dashes hopes for quick deal on output
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Monday as Iran dashed hopes for a coordinated production freeze, sending prices back below $40 a barrel. Global benchmark Brent crude futures fell to $39.69, while US crude was down 79 cents at $37.71. Iran's oil minister said the country would only join a production freeze once it reaches 4 million barrels a day, dashing hopes for a quick deal. Analysts also cited concerns about demand fundamentals and the impact of cheap oil on producers and consumers.

site_title: Amtrak says train derails in Kansas
summary: Amtrak's Southwest Chief train derailed in Kansas, about 20 miles west of Dodge City, with 128 passengers and 14 crew members on board. Initial reports indicate no life-threatening injuries, but five cars were derailed, forcing the closure of US Highway 50. Local emergency services were at the scene, and many injured passengers were taken to nearby hospitals. The incident occurred around midnight CDT, following a period of the train shaking at 75 miles per hour.

site_title: Morgan Stanley says bonds set to surge in 2016 Year of the Bull
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a "Year of the Bull" in 2016, citing a supportive global backdrop for bond yields. The firm forecasts Treasury 10-year yields to fall to 1.45% by September, approaching a record low. The Federal Reserve and Bank of England are expected to delay raising interest rates, while central banks in Europe and Japan will continue easing monetary policy. Most major economies are forecast to underperform in 2016 compared to 2015.

site_title: Ageas settles Fortis past for 1.2b euros
summary: Ageas, the insurer left after Fortis' collapse, has agreed to settle 1.2 billion euros in claims related to the Belgian bank's financial troubles. Fortis was bailed out and split into a banking arm and an insurer, with Ageas being left behind. The settlement comes after a series of court cases, with Ageas not admitting any wrongdoing. The agreement settles all outstanding claims, marking a significant conclusion in the aftermath of Fortis' collapse.

site_title: Saudi Feb oil output steady at 10.22m bpd
summary: Saudi Arabia maintained its crude oil production at 10.22 million barrels per day in February, according to an industry source. This steady output follows the same production level in January, when it was reported at 10.23 million bpd. The country's crude supplied to the market in February was approximately 10.4 million bpd.

site_title: Seoul: Won closes at over 2-month high, stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won reached a two-month high, closing at 1,186.1 to the US dollar, a 0.6% gain from the previous day. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.04% to 1,972.27 points. However, South Korean shares were flat due to light trading ahead of major central bank policy meetings. The gains in the won were driven by Wall Street and global oil price increases, sparking investors' demand for riskier assets.

site_title: Thai PM boosts security in Muslim south after attacks
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has ordered the military to increase security in the country's Muslim-majority southern provinces following attacks at the weekend, leaving seven soldiers injured. The attacks, which included a gunfight in a hospital, were blamed on insurgent groups. The southern provinces have been gripped by a bloody insurgency since 2004, resulting in over 6,500 deaths. The move follows a 16% drop in violent incidents in 2015, but local distrust of the Thai state remains high.

site_title: Indonesia detains 14 people allegedly heading to Syria
summary: Indonesia has detained 14 people, including several children, at Jakarta's international airport who allegedly tried to travel to Syria to join extremist groups like the Islamic State (IS). The group, which includes a family of five with three children, was stopped on Sunday before boarding a flight to Bangkok. Hundreds of Indonesians have traveled to join IS and other extremist groups since the group seized territory in Syria and Iraq. The detention highlights concerns about the spread of extremist ideologies in the country, where authorities are considering tougher anti-terror laws.

site_title: Abbott India says to comply with government order on drugs ban
summary: US-pharmaceutical giant Abbott Laboratories' India unit will comply with a government order banning 344 drug combinations, including Abbott's codeine-based cough syrup, due to a lack of therapeutic justification. The ban affects Abbott's Phensedyl cough syrup, which accounts for a third of the Indian cough syrup market and 3% of the company's US$1 billion India revenue. Abbott will comply with all legal requirements, but the company has not commented on potential financial implications.

site_title: Maybank to grow Singapore retail SME loan portfolio by 40% this year
summary: Maybank expects to grow its Singapore retail SME loan portfolio by 40% this year, driven by expanding financing to the region. Since launching its RSME business in Singapore two years ago, the bank has seen loans increase by 50% and deposits rise by 25%. Maybank aims to introduce innovative financing solutions to help business owners manage cash flow, particularly as many Singaporean businesses look to expand overseas in the region. The bank is well-positioned to capitalize on opportunities, being the only bank with a presence in all 10 ASEAN countries.

site_title: Australia's CBH rejects listing proposal; to review structure
summary: Australia's largest wheat exporter, Co-operative Bulk Handling (CBH), has rejected a proposal to buy and list the group, citing concerns over the loss of control by its 4,200 farmer members. The rejection comes after a GrainCorp-backed consortium, Australian Grains Champion (AGC), proposed a deal worth up to A$3 billion. CBH will review its structure and has received expressions of interest from other parties, including those not affiliated with GrainCorp. The decision will be discussed with farmer shareholders by the end of September.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises but markets cautious ahead of BOJ, Fed
summary: Japanese stocks rose 1.7% on Monday, reaching a 1-week high, as investors gained confidence in the European Central Bank's stimulus package and speculated on oil price stabilization. The Nikkei share average ended at 17,233.75 points, with the insurance sector leading gains. However, traders remain cautious ahead of central bank policy announcements in the US and Japan this week. Most market watchers expect no major policy changes from the Bank of Japan, which concludes its policy meeting on Tuesday.

site_title: Blogger Roy Ngerng to pay S$150,000 in damages to PM Lee in instalments: lawyer
summary: Blogger Roy Ngerng has agreed to pay S$150,000 in damages to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in monthly instalments, starting from S$100 per month on April 1. Ngerng's lawyer, Eugene Thuraisingam, announced the agreement after representing Ngerng on a pro bono basis since December 23.

site_title: China expands power distribution reform to more regions
summary: China has expanded a pilot scheme allowing local authorities to control electricity transmission and distribution prices in 12 new provinces and municipalities, bringing the total to 18 regions. The move is part of the country's efforts to boost efficiency through deregulation. The expansion aims to give more control to local authorities, allowing them to set prices based on local market conditions, and promote competition in the electricity sector.

site_title: China: Small-caps lead indexes higher after regulator's assurances
summary: China's stocks rose sharply on Monday, led by small-caps, after regulator Liu Shiyu assured it was premature to consider withdrawing government bailout funds. The CSI300 index gained 1.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.8%. The ChiNext board, which tracks start-ups, led the charge with a 4.7% gain. Liu's comments dispelled fears of a flood of initial public offerings and suggested a relatively long time for China's shift to a registration system.

images.alt_text: China stocks rose sharply on Monday, led by small-caps, with investors encouraged by a regulator's assurance it was premature to consider withdrawing government bailout funds, and comments dispelling fears of a flood of initial public offerings.

site_title: Singapore's economic growth unlikely to hit 3.3% until 2018: ICAEW
summary: Singapore's economic growth is unlikely to reach 3.3% until 2018, according to ICAEW's report. Domestic non-oil exports and manufacturing are expected to remain subdued, with the services sector driving growth. Stronger government investment and household spending will support services, but vulnerability to regional trade weakness and high debt-to-income ratios (150%) may hinder growth potential. The best-performing Asean-6 economies are Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, with strong domestic fundamentals and room for policy support.

site_title: Chemical fire extinguisher leak kills eight in Thai bank
summary: Eight people died and seven were injured in a chemical fire extinguisher leak at the Siam Commercial Bank headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand. The accident occurred late Sunday night when contractors triggered the fire extinguisher system, releasing a suffocating cloud of chemicals that caused oxygen levels to plummet. The victims were killed by the lack of oxygen, with five dying at the scene and three in hospital. The bank has apologized and is cooperating with police.

site_title: Merkel in firing line over refugees after regional vote 'debacle'
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel faced fresh pressure after regional elections in which her Christian Democratic Union suffered defeats, with the right-wing Alternative for Germany party gaining ground. The elections were seen as a referendum on Merkel's liberal refugee policy, which has been criticized by her allies and opponents. Despite the losses, Merkel remains resolute on her stance, refusing to impose a cap on refugee arrivals. The AfD's surge in popularity could strengthen her adversaries' hands, particularly her Bavarian allies, who have long criticized her policy.

site_title: Nomura to raise pay for 3,700 employees at Japan brokerage
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. will increase base pay for approximately 3,700 employees at its Japanese brokerage by an average 2% starting in April, marking the third consecutive year of salary hikes. The move aims to support Japan's economic growth and contribute to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to boost spending and combat deflation. This brings the total pay increase over three years to 6.8%.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings Inc. will raise salaries for staff at its Japanese brokerage for a third year.

site_title: Australia: Shares ride global peers to 10-week high
summary: Australian shares rose to a 10-week high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.4% to 5,185.5, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached new record highs, up 0.8% to 6,566.8. Gains were fueled by the European Central Bank's stimulus package, firmer oil prices, and a rebound from a soft start to 2016. The market's momentum follows gains in Europe and the US, where stocks have hit fresh records, despite ongoing trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.08 points to 1696.20. The market saw 40.5 million lots traded worth RM13.9 million, with 118 gainers outnumbering 37 losers.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 10-week peak, NZ extends record run
summary: Australian shares reached a 10-week peak, rising 0.7% to 5,204, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus package and firmer oil prices. Gains were led by telecoms and financials, with Westpac surging 20% in 12 sessions. New Zealand's benchmark index also hit a fresh all-time peak at 6,567.86, driven by gains in Sky TV and Orion Healthcare Group.

site_title: Oil dips in Asia on profit-taking
summary: Oil prices in Asia dipped on Monday as traders took profits following last week's rally, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate down 19 US cents to US$38.31 and Brent crude down two US cents at US$40.37. Iran's decision not to join a proposed output freeze by crude producers, led by Saudi Arabia, also contributed to the decline. The meeting, set for March 20, now appears increasingly unlikely without Iran's participation, which could further exacerbate the supply glut and send prices lower.

site_title: Gold advances with central bank policies in focus, US dollar drops
summary: Gold prices rebounded 0.5% to US$1,255.03 an ounce after a 1.8% drop on Friday, as investors focused on monetary policy meetings in Japan and the US, which made the US dollar less expensive and boosted demand for bullion. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.9% and the US dollar fell for a fourth day, contributing to the gold price increase.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally resumes before BOJ, Fed reviews
summary: Asia's stock market rally gained momentum before the Bank of Japan's and Federal Reserve's policy reviews this week. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index reached a two-month high, driven by banking shares, while Japan's Topix index rose to a five-week high. The won strengthened to its strongest level of 2016, and gold rebounded from a one-week low. Central banks are expected to dominate market sentiment, with the Fed potentially hiking interest rates this week.

site_title: Australian dollar hits 8-month high as commodity units rise
summary: The Australian dollar reached an 8-month high of 75.94 US cents as commodity-linked currencies rose due to a boost in global equity markets. Investors focused on central bank meetings, including the Bank of Japan's 2-day meeting and the Federal Reserve's meeting, which may provide fresh stimulus. The meetings come after the European Central Bank cut rates and boosted bond-buying to stimulate the eurozone economy. Despite Chinese data showing a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy, the risk rally continued, with other currencies such as the New Zealand and Canadian dollars also gaining.

site_title: Singapore office rents may see prolonged declines, says Daiwa
summary: Singapore office rents may decline by up to 25% by the end of 2018, according to Daiwa Securities Co. Analyst David Lum forecasts a prolonged slump due to slowing demand and a large supply of prime space. This prediction aligns with other analysts, including Jones Lang LaSalle, which expects a 20% drop in prime office rents this year. Daiwa has downgraded office REITs to negative and lowered individual stock ratings, citing deteriorating office sector fundamentals.

site_title: Chinese coal miners strike over wages, layoffs
summary: Thousands of Chinese coal miners in Heilongjiang province have gone on strike over unpaid wages and fears of mass layoffs due to government restructuring plans. The strike, which has turned violent, has resulted in police clashes with protesters. The miners, who work for Longmay Mining Holding Group, demand back pay for months of unpaid wages. The situation highlights the dilemma faced by Chinese authorities, who seek to reform the economy while avoiding unrest and unemployment.

site_title: Seoul: Won up on rise in risk demand; stocks edge up
summary: South Korea's won strengthened 0.6% against the dollar, reaching 1,186.4 per dollar, as investors sought riskier assets amid concerns oil prices have found a bottom. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index rose 0.2% to a 2016 peak, driven by Samsung's 1.5% gain. However, investors remain cautious ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which may impact the won's rally. Foreign investors bought 18.8 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: Vanke agrees to buy Shenzhen Metro stake amid control tussle
summary: China Vanke Co. has agreed to buy a stake in Shenzhen Metro Group Co. for 40 billion yuan to 60 billion yuan as part of a restructuring plan. The acquisition will be funded mainly by selling new shares to Shenzhen Metro and paying cash for a potential shortfall. This move comes as Vanke's management tries to fend off a hostile takeover bid. The deal was announced in a statement to the Shenzhen stock exchange, but a planned press briefing was canceled due to time constraints.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks gain at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.82% in early trade on Monday, following the European Central Bank's stimulus measures. The Hang Seng Index increased 165.66 points to 20,365.26. In Shanghai, the composite index rose 0.76% to 20,831.61, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.49% to 9,503.23. The gains extend last week's rally on global markets.

site_title: China watchdog takes it slow on IPO reform, vows stock help
summary: China's securities regulator chairman, Liu Shiyu, signaled that the government will continue to support the nation's battered stock market, vowing to curb panic and intervene if necessary. Liu defended the regulator's actions following last summer's US$5 trillion selloff, saying it was too early to think about ending the state rescue fund's involvement. A new registration-based system for initial public offerings, which would limit supply and expedite IPOs, is expected to take time to introduce, but Liu acknowledged its importance for the capital market's healthy development.

site_title: Dyna-Mac responds to SGX query on unusual trading activity
summary: DYNA-MAC Holdings responded to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query, stating it is unaware of any information that could explain unusual trade volume movements in its shares. On Monday, the company's shares rose 1.9 Singapore cents to 17.5 cents after 10.47 million shares were transacted. DYNA-MAC announced a net loss for the fourth quarter and full year 2015, mainly due to impairment of long outstanding receivables.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: CITIC to sell property assets to China Overseas Land for US$4.8b
summary: CITIC Ltd is selling its residential property business in mainland China to China Overseas Land & Investment Ltd for 31 billion yuan (S$6.6 billion). The deal includes the transfer of 6.15 billion yuan worth of property portfolios and the issuance of HK$29.7 billion worth of new shares. CITIC will retain a 10% stake in China Overseas Land, focusing on commercial real estate. The deal aims to strengthen CITIC's commercial property business in China and is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

site_title: White House hopefuls hustle for votes as race turns 'toxic'
summary: US presidential hopefuls are intensifying their campaign efforts ahead of "Super Tuesday 2," a crucial election test with multiple primary contests in states including Florida, Ohio, and Illinois. Donald Trump is seeking to build a lead, but his Republican rivals, including Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, are determined to stop him. Trump's campaign has been marred by controversy and violence, including clashes at rallies and attacks on minorities and journalists. Despite this, Trump remains popular among his supporters, who see him as a strong candidate.

site_title: AIA, Prudential decline on China restrictions on insurance sales
summary: AIA Group Ltd and Prudential Plc shares declined in Hong Kong after China tightened restrictions on the use of third-party payment providers for life insurance and investment products. The People's Bank of China will prohibit mainland individuals from using electronic payment services for these purchases, starting March 12. Individuals can still buy insurance policies for personal accidents and medical/transportation coverage, but with a transaction cap of 30,000 yuan. The move aims to slow capital outflows, which reached an estimated $1 trillion last year.

site_title: China completes investment of 5.31t yuan on key projects
summary: China completed investment of 5.3096 trillion yuan (S$1.13 trillion) in 11 key projects by the end of January, according to the National Development and Reform Commission. These projects include information networks, environmental protection, transportation, and clean energy. The commission also approved 15 investment projects worth 34.1 billion yuan in February, further solidifying China's economic investment in key sectors.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rally, EVA Airways down after chairman's removal
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose to their highest level since November, driven by gains on Wall Street and regional bourses, with technology and financial sectors leading the way. The main TAIEX index rose 0.7% to 8,762.50, while the electronics subindex and financials subindex also gained. However, EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, fell nearly 2% after its chairman, Chang Kuo-wei, was removed following an unscheduled board meeting. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.281 to T$32.669 per US dollar.

site_title: Noble seeks major funding breakthrough without asset sales
summary: Noble Group, a trading house, is seeking over $4 billion in new and refinanced loans from lenders without planning further asset sales. The company has downgraded its loans to "junk" status, but a senior source says Noble is not under pressure to sell assets. Noble is instead exploring alternative strategic plans, such as equity issuance or partnerships, to strengthen its balance sheet. The company is moving towards secured borrowing and plans to make more oil available as collateral under its new facility.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.74% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.74% to 2,849.74, with 78.3 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 114 to 27. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China transport minister says ride-hailing subsidies competitively unfair, not sustainable
summary: China's transport minister, Yang Chuantang, stated that ride-hailing companies' subsidies, such as Didi Kuaidi and Uber, are competitively unfair and unsustainable in the long-term. The subsidies, funded by investors, provide discounts and driver wage supplements, but Yang warned that this model cannot be sustained. This comes as the companies spend billions in competition, with Yang emphasizing the need for a more sustainable business model.

site_title: Oil prices stable as market seen bottoming, but oversupply lingers
summary: Oil prices remain stable, trading at US$38.36 per barrel for WTI and US$40.42 per barrel for Brent, as global oversupply and slowing economic growth weigh on markets. Despite Morgan Stanley's prediction that oil prices have likely bottomed out, experts warn that oversupply and production will prevent sharp rises. The International Energy Agency also notes that oil prices have likely bottomed out due to output cuts, but others predict a modest price recovery.

site_title: Hu An Cable gets three-month extension to release FY2015 results
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings has been granted a three-month extension by Singapore Exchange to release its FY2015 financial results due to its focus on asset disposal and share transfer approvals. The company is trying to gather resources for audit preparation following production cessation and uncertainty about its future. It advised shareholders to exercise caution and will announce material updates on a timely basis.

site_title: Zheshang Bank launches US$1.75b Hong Kong IPO, taps Alipay as cornerstone
summary: Zheshang Bank Co Ltd, a commercial lender in China's Zhejiang province, launched a US$1.75 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, with Alipay as a cornerstone investor. The IPO secured US$963 million in commitments from cornerstone investors, offering 3.3 billion shares at an indicative range of HK$3.92 to HK$4.12 each. The shares represent 19% of Zheshang Bank's enlarged share capital, marking the first significant new listing in Hong Kong in 2016.

site_title: Cameron announces plan to help UK savers and younger workers
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron announces a 'Help to Save' program to assist lower earners and younger workers. The program offers a 50% bonus on savings up to £600 (S$1185) for those setting aside £50/month for 2 years. Additionally, those aged 21-24 earning the minimum wage will receive a 450-pound annual pay rise. The measures aim to support hardworking people and teenagers, staving off criticism of the Conservative party favoring wealthier voters.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks continue global rally in opening deals
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.28% on Monday, extending a global rally, despite signs of China's economic slowdown. The Nikkei 225 index reached 17,155.52, while the Topix index gained 1.20%. Investors await the Bank of Japan policy meeting for trading cues.

site_title: Online lender draws QED, Blackstone in 119m pounds fundraising
summary: Future Finance Loan Corp, an online lender to students, has raised 119 million pounds from firms including QED Investors and Blackstone Group LP to expand its business and fund new loans. The fundraising includes 100 million pounds for loans and 19 million pounds for equity. The company has drawn over 37,000 applications since its launch in 2014 and has loaned out 25 million pounds. The injection will enable more students to access higher education and invest in their future careers, according to CEO Brian Norton.

site_title: Australian dollar dragged down with copper by China Data; NZ stocks climb
summary: Australian and New Zealand dollars fell due to weaker-than-expected Chinese economic data, which showed factory output and retail sales slowing. Copper futures dropped 0.3% and crude oil retreated, while global equities rebounded. The Aussie dollar retreated from an eight-month high and the kiwi snapped a two-day climb. Risk appetite increased as investors considered the European Central Bank's stimulus package and US crude oil's surge.

site_title: RBS said to cut 550 jobs as in-person advice moves to web, phone
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland plans to cut approximately 550 jobs as it scales back in-person investment and insurance advice, directing some clients to an online platform. The shift affects clients with less than £250,000 to invest, eliminating 220 workers. The move is part of CEO Ross McEwan's efforts to cut expenses and focus on consumer lending. The bank is also overhauling its protection business, eliminating 200 jobs and shifting services to phone advice. The changes aim to increase efficiency and cater to cost-sensitive investors using automated services.

site_title: Pound's swings complicate life for small UK firms before EU vote
summary: The UK's decision to hold a referendum on its EU membership has created uncertainty for small and medium-sized firms, particularly those that rely on imports and have limited hedging strategies. The pound's sharp swings against the US dollar, largely due to concerns of a "Brexit," have resulted in a six percent increase in the cost of dollars for Universal Tyres, a medium-sized firm. Economists warn that a Brexit could cause sterling to lose about a fifth of its value, forcing many firms to rethink their businesses.

site_title: Philippines' San Miguel, Australia's Telstra end venture talks
summary: Philippines' San Miguel Corp and Australia's Telstra Corp Ltd have abandoned joint venture talks due to unresolved issues. San Miguel President Ramon Ang stated that continuing the talks would be best for all parties. Despite this, San Miguel's wireless unit will proceed with its launch, and the conglomerate remains open to exploring other joint venture opportunities for its telco business.

site_title: Al-Qaeda claims deadly attack at Ivory Coast beach resort
summary: Heavily-armed men attacked an Ivory Coast resort, killing 16 people, including 14 civilians and 2 special forces troops. The attack, claimed by an Al-Qaeda affiliate, occurred at Grand-Bassam's beach resorts. A witness reported hearing one of the assailants shout "Allahu Akbar." The incident raises concerns about a growing jihadist threat in West Africa.

site_title: India said to need an extra US$3.7b in risk to deficit goal
summary: India's government plans to ask lawmakers for an additional $5 billion to cover a proposed $15 billion salary hike for 9.9 million workers and pensioners, which is 70% of the planned increase. The hike is crucial to the budget's credibility, but exceeding the deficit goal of 3.5% of GDP will be challenging. Without extra funds, Prime Minister Narendra Modi risks failing to meet his goal and may need to cut spending or generate more revenue.

site_title: App Annie bets on Southeast Asia, India to capture phone surge
summary: App Annie, a Singapore-based startup, plans to capture the growing mobile market in Southeast Asia and India with its data on apps, usage, and revenue. The company has received a $63 million funding and will triple its staffing in Singapore to target new customers. With Asia's mobile spending expected to surge 24% to $28.3 billion this year, App Annie aims to capitalize on the region's booming smartphone adoption, with China expected to overtake the US as the largest single app market.

site_title: New Zealand's services index rises in February
summary: New Zealand's services sector expanded in February, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) rising 1.5 points to 56.9. All five sub-indices increased, helping offset a decline in the manufacturing sector's performance. The rebound in the employment index, which moved into contraction territory, is seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Japan Jan core machinery orders rise 15% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 15% in January, exceeding economists' expectations and suggesting rising business investment could support economic growth. This increase, a sign of capital spending in the coming months, contrasts with a 3.6% decline seen by analysts. Core orders, excluding ships and electricity, rose 8.4% from the previous year. The data indicates a positive trend for Japan's economy, potentially supporting growth.

site_title: Trek 2000 lists documentation deficiencies in relation to application for time extension
summary: Trek 2000 International has listed documentation deficiencies in relation to sale transactions with a customer, which may impact its financial results for the year ended Dec 31, 2015. External auditors found discrepancies in customer identity, delivery orders, and bank transfer notices, totaling approximately US$3.2 million. The company is seeking a time extension to announce its financial results and advises shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares. Further announcements will be made as material developments emerge, with a review of accounting records and sales documentation underway.

site_title: British banks slam UK Treasury's bank levy plan
summary: UK banks criticize the Treasury's plan to limit the bank levy to domestic businesses only, warning that international operations could still be subject to taxation. The British Bankers' Association says this structure contradicts Chancellor George Osborne's aim to make the levy no longer catch worldwide balance sheets. The BBA calls for a reduction in the levy over a shorter period and a phase-out of the additional 8% charge on profits.
