The system, designed by a father-daughter team, has caught the attention of infrastructure builders and could be a solution to electric cars' limited range. TEV plans to build its first trial road by next year, with estimated costs of $1.2-$1.8 million per mile, significantly lower than traditional highway construction. The project's potential to keep driverless electric cars on the road around the clock has sparked interest among infrastructure companies and experts.

site_title: Suu Kyi's former schoolmate nominated as president
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's former schoolmate, Htin Kyaw, has been nominated as a presidential candidate in Myanmar's Parliament, marking the first time a leader from the civilian sector will hold the role in decades. The National League for Democracy (NLD) holds a majority in Parliament, and Suu Kyi will remain in control of the government despite her initial reluctance to hold the title of president. Htin Kyaw, 69, is a trusted adviser and education foundation founder, and his nomination solidifies Suu Kyi's control of the nascent democratic government.

site_title: China consumer inflation jumps to 2.3% in Feb
summary: China's consumer inflation rose to 2.3% in February, the highest in nearly two years, driven by a surge in food prices during the Chinese New Year holiday. Pork prices jumped 25.4% and vegetables rose 30.6% year-on-year. The producer price index fell 4.9%, meeting expectations, but the prolonged decline bodes ill for industrial growth. Analysts expect a "mild" inflation rate in coming months, and the central bank is likely to inject more liquidity to support the economy, which is struggling with a slowdown.

site_title: Five years on, Japan still having Fukushima nightmare
summary: Five years after the devastating Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan, the country is still grappling with the aftermath, with no clear end in sight. The meltdown of highly radioactive fuel in reactors has set the scene for a decades-long sub-plot, with ongoing radioactive seepage and storage of polluted water posing significant environmental and health risks. Japan's nuclear power plants are aging, and despite opposition, the government plans to restart reactors, citing the need to promote Japan's nuclear technology and construction capabilities. The long-term decommissioning process is expected to take 30 to 40 years.

images.alt_text: The Abe government has been eager to promote Japan's nuclear technology and construction capabilities to overseas buyers and abandoning nuclear now might not be seen as a gesture of confidence in its own abilities in this regard.

site_title: RM80b estimated to be raised via primary market this year
summary: Malaysia's capital market is estimated to raise RM80 billion through the primary market this year, with RM75 billion coming from bonds and RM5 billion from initial public offerings (IPOs). This is based on the Securities Commission's engagements with investment bankers and is lower than last year's total of RM90 billion.

site_title: And ArtScience Museum said: "Let there be light!"
summary: The ArtScience Museum in Singapore has unveiled its first permanent exhibition, "Future World," featuring interactive digital artworks by Japanese collective teamLab. The 1,500 sq metre immersive digital playground combines art and technology, with virtual cities, animated oceans, and interactive installations that change colors and react to visitors. The exhibition includes 178,000 LED lights in the "Crystal Universe" room and a room-size installation filled with flowers and insects that react to the time of year. The museum's executive director says the exhibition aims to showcase innovation from the union of science and art.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Give greater priority to social safety nets: academics, economist
summary: Singapore's government is expected to prioritize social safety nets in the upcoming Budget, as the country navigates an uncertain economic period. Economists and academics recommend improving the social support system to help Singaporeans during job losses or reduced income. The government has introduced various social measures, including the SkillsFuture Credit and Pioneer Generation Package, but experts suggest consolidation and fine-tuning these programs to ensure efficiency and effectiveness.

site_title: IMF again warns on financial market stability
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has issued a warning on financial market stability, citing a "disappointing and fragile recovery" in the world economy. Senior IMF official Jose Vinals stated that recent heightened volatility may signal deeper concerns in markets, and that policymakers need to take urgent action to strengthen growth and manage vulnerabilities. The IMF's baseline outlook suggests modest growth in advanced economies and rising growth in emerging markets, but also warns of risks to global stability, including falling commodity prices and concerns about banks in advanced countries.

images.alt_text: Mr Vinals says "India is projected to continue growing at a robust pace ... (making India) the fastest growing large economy in the world".

site_title: British stage invasion
summary: British stage invasion brings three classic works to the stage: William Golding's Lord of the Flies, Noel Coward's The Vortex, and William Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet. The productions run from March 25 to April 3, showcasing the enduring appeal of these literary masterpieces.

site_title: Beware the unintended consequences of bans
summary: The Singapore government's pragmatic approach to policymaking has led to the implementation of paternalistic policies, which some argue are illiberal and coercive. Bans on public drinking, shisha, and other activities have been introduced, but critics argue that these measures infringe on individual rights and freedoms. The bans are costly to enforce and can erode trust in public institutions. Economists argue that bans are a form of lazy thinking, as they do not encourage policymakers to think creatively about how to address problems. Instead, bans can shift risks to other areas, such as the black market, and lead to a less tolerant society.

site_title: Heartbreaking look at the struggles of artists
summary: The play "MANIFESTO" by playwright Haresh Sharma and directors Alvin Tan and Kok Heng Leun explores the struggles of artists in Singapore over the past 70 years, from being labelled Communists and Marxists to facing accusations of arrogance and self-indulgence. The play spans nearly a century, featuring seven actors playing two dozen roles, and delves into existential inquiries about the role of the artist in society and the state. The play is a personal and emotional portrayal of the hardships endured by artists, shedding light on the complexities of being an artist in Singapore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) priced its US$500 million subordinated notes due 2026 at 99.574% of principal, with a 3.5% interest rate. The notes are callable in 2021 and expected to be rated A2 by Moody's and A+ by Fitch. OCBC priced A$300 million senior floating rate notes due 2020 at 1.2% per annum. CITIC Envirotech secured a 198 million yuan (S$42 million) project to upgrade an industrial wastewater treatment plant in China.

site_title: Low rent reversions ahead for industrial Reits: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse expects industrial Reits to see low single-digit rental growth due to weak leasing transactions and widening vacancy rates. Vacancy rates across warehouses, factories, and business parks are already at 8.6%, 12.8%, and 15.9% respectively, adding to demand weakness. The analysts note that while oversupply is a concern, the incoming supply pipeline has mitigating factors, including single-user assets dominating the supply. Despite this, Credit Suisse maintains an "outperform" rating on Mapletree Industrial Trust, trimming its target price to S$1.72.

site_title: China's shadow-banking boom poses risks
summary: China's shadow banking sector has grown to $3.2 trillion, with 57% increase last year, posing significant risks to the financial system. Wealth management products, typically backed by corporate debt and derivatives, are propping up troubled borrowers, particularly in the property and heavy industry sectors. The boom's vulnerability to sudden loss of confidence could lead to liquidity crunches for mid-size banks, which hold 40% of outstanding wealth management products. The industry's expansion is unlikely to remain in the shadows, given the risks.

site_title: Head of Volkswagen's US unit steps down
summary: Volkswagen's US head Michael Horn is stepping down after the company's emissions scandal. Horn, who was the public face in the early days of the scandal, had repeatedly apologized and testified before Congress. His departure is the latest in a string of executive changes at the company, which has yet to come up with a recall plan to fix the problem. Investigators are trying to determine who was responsible for the fraud, with 17 suspects now under investigation. Horn's departure may signal more modest ambitions in the US market.

site_title: No Asia Square sale to ARA on expiry of exclusive talks
summary: BlackRock's exclusive negotiation period for the sale of Asia Square Tower 1 to ARA Asset Management has ended without a deal, despite initial talks. ARA had expressed interest in 100% of the property but reduced its offer to 66%. BlackRock is still in discussions with ARA and may also consider other parties, including CapitaLand, which has no plans to bid. The initial price tag was S$4 billion, but market talk suggests a lower price range of S$2,700-2,800 per square foot may have been discussed.

images.alt_text: The initial price tag for Asia Square Tower 1 last year was S$4 billion or about S$3,200 psf on NLA of 1.2 million sq ft of offices and 40,000 sq ft of retail space.

site_title: An uncommon lens into life in rural China
summary: China's renowned dramatist Cao Yu's play "Savage Land" was staged at the Esplanade Theatre in Beijing, showcasing his unique blend of influences from Ibsen, Shakespeare, and O'Neill. The play revolves around an ex-convict's quest for revenge in rural China, exploring themes of social hierarchy, politics, and the subjugation of women. The production features beautifully detailed set design and excellent performances, offering an uncommon lens into life in rural China and cementing Cao's legacy as a playwright.

site_title: Why Britain needs self government
summary: Britain leaving the EU would give the country more influence and control over its borders, spending, and taxes. An independent UK could represent itself in global bodies, such as the World Trade Organization, and set its own taxes and spending priorities. The "leave" campaign believes this would lead to fair immigration, increased economic growth, and better representation of British interests abroad.

site_title: M1 and StarHub push out new data offerings
summary: M1 and StarHub launched new data offerings in Singapore, one day after MyRepublic and Singtel unveiled theirs, sparking a price war in the mobile data sector. M1 introduced two new SIM-only plans and an upsize data feature, while StarHub launched a three GB data upsize option for its postpaid customers. The move is seen as an attempt by the telcos to defend their customer bases and revenue from the potential entry of a fourth telco, MyRepublic. Analysts predict a price war could lead to lower prices and increased competition, but also risk network coverage and customer experience.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: PAP Seniors Group issues Budget wish list
summary: The PAP Seniors Group, led by Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob, has submitted a budget wish list to the Finance Ministry, focusing on three key areas: ElderShield Scheme, caregiver support, and the intermediate and long-term care (ILTC) sector. The group recommends making ElderShield compulsory, removing age and pre-existing illness limits, and indexing payouts to inflation. They also suggest incentives for caregivers and measures to strengthen the ILTC sector, including job redesign, training, and better pay.

site_title: Keeping watch over old traditions
summary: Claude Bernard, a Swiss watch-maker, has partnered with local artisans through its Artisans programme, including letterpress studio The Gentlemen's Press. The collaboration aims to support traditional values and hand-crafted products. Michelle Yu, owner of The Gentlemen's Press, notes the precision and dedication required in both watch-making and letterpress printing, emphasizing the importance of quality materials. The partnership seeks to spread awareness for independent watch-makers and create a more defined brand image.

images.alt_text: Michelle Yu, owner of boutique studio The Gentlemen's Press, demonstrating the art of letterpress at a workshop conducted by independent Swiss watch-maker Claude Bernard, whose Open Heart Automatic watch is featured here.

Michelle Yu, owner of boutique studio The Gentlemen's Press, demonstrating the art of letterpress at a workshop conducted by independent Swiss watch-maker Claude Bernard, whose Open Heart Automatic watch (above) is featured here.

site_title: Singapore pushes for private investments in infrastructure
summary: Singapore aims to make infrastructure a mainstream asset class, separate from traditional debt and equity investments, to boost growth amid global market volatility. The country's government is pushing for private sector involvement, with senior Minister Indranee Rajah stating that efforts from multilateral development banks are not enough. Currently, only 3% of global assets under management are allocated to infrastructure investment, with infrastructure debt underweighted. The government seeks to develop infrastructure assets to match long-term liabilities of institutional investors like pension funds and insurance companies.

site_title: 'Brexit' nerves already cost this London tech startup £100,000
summary: A London-based tech startup, Sup, is facing uncertainty due to the Brexit vote, with an investor backing out of a £100,000 funding deal. Tech startups are concerned about losing advantages such as unencumbered movement of money, workers, and goods. Experts warn that a Brexit could hinder access to top talent, restrict hiring of non-EU nationals, and limit the ease of selling products across a larger market. The outcome of the vote could also impact fundraising, particularly for young companies, and may force some startups to consider alternative locations, such as Estonia.

images.alt_text: Rich Pleeth, the co-founder of friend-finding app Sup has found that a German firm that was interested in investing in his company, became nervous and backed out when polls showed the result could be close when Britain calls a referendum on membership in the European Union in June.

site_title: Insurer Aviva Singapore's VNB up 19% at S$216m
summary: Aviva Singapore reported a 19% increase in value of new business (VNB) to S$216 million in 2015, driven by higher sales of protection products through the financial advisory (FA) channel. The insurer's bancassurance tie-up with DBS ended in 2015, but the local lender contributed £28 million (S$55 million) to VNB. Aviva's group operating profit rose 20% to £2.67 billion, driven by contributions from the UK and Asia, and the company plans to focus on digital solutions and improving the group insurance segment.

site_title: Bittersweet departure inspires album
summary: Death Cab For Cutie, an indie band, has become a trio after Chris Walla's departure in 2014. The group's new album, Kintsugi, was released with the help of outside producer Rich Costey. Despite Walla's absence, the band expressed a desire to continue making music with him in the future. The album's title refers to the Japanese art of repairing broken pottery, symbolizing the band's continued existence without a founding member. The album was well-received, with the band expressing their commitment to creating music that reflects their current creative impulses.

site_title: Singtel completes shore landing of new undersea cable
summary: Singtel has completed the landing of the 20,000 km South-east Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 5 (SEA-ME-WE 5) undersea cable at Tuas, Singapore, ahead of its expected completion by the end of the year. The cable has a design capacity of 24 terabits per second, meeting the quadrupling of bandwidth demand between Europe and Asia from 2016 to 2021. It is expected to boost the digital economy and provide a sevenfold capacity increase along the corridor connecting South-east Asia, the Middle East, and Western Europe.

site_title: HK booksellers' disappearance a confidence-shaking event
summary: Five Hong Kong booksellers disappeared and were later found in China, sparking outrage over China's human rights record and accusations of abduction. China denies wrongdoing, but the case has shaken confidence in the "one country, two systems" promise. Britain has charged China with breaching the Sino-British agreement, while other countries, including the US and EU, have condemned China's actions. The booksellers' assertions of voluntary return have been met with skepticism, and China's tactics have undermined Hong Kong's efforts to sign extradition agreements with other jurisdictions.

site_title: Modi under fire after Kingfisher founder leaves India
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faced criticism after Vijay Mallya, founder of Kingfisher Airlines, left the country despite owing over $1 billion to creditors. A group of 17 banks filed a petition to bar Mallya from leaving India, but he departed on March 2. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said banks will take action to recover money, while Mallya claimed he was not an absconder and had been a non-resident for 28 years. The move has raised concerns about the government's ability to tackle rising bad loans in the financial system.

site_title: Carrefour maintains plan for property unit's IPO
summary: Carrefour, France's largest retailer, maintains its plan for an initial public offering (IPO) of its shopping mall property unit, Carmila. The company reported higher full-year profit, with recurring operating income rising 2.4% to 2.45 billion euros. Carmila, which controls over 180 sites near Carrefour hypermarkets in France, Italy, and Spain, may be worth 4.5 billion euros. The IPO is seen as a way for investors to realize their investment, with analysts predicting a potential value of 4.5 billion euros.

site_title: UOB KayHian joins S'pore diamond exchange as its first broker
summary: UOB Kay Hian has joined the Singapore Diamond Investment Exchange (SDiX) as its first broker, enabling clients to trade in diamonds as a financial asset class. The exchange, launched in July 2015, aims to provide transparency and price discovery for the diamond trade. Trading in single stones or baskets of small diamonds will be available, with stones graded by the Gemological Institute of America. The partnership creates opportunities for clients to participate in the $22 billion polished diamond market, with prices expected to rise amid a shortage of supply.

site_title: A big bounce may await rubber investors
summary: A 75-year-old British businessman, Algy Cluff, invested in rubber companies in Malaya in 1961, purchasing shares at a significant discount. This investment, facilitated by Charles Letts, a Scotsman fluent in multiple languages, is seen as a potential precursor to the current rubber market boom. The article does not provide further details on the current market situation or its implications.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Firms must be self-reliant for business growth: CEOs
summary: A pre-Budget poll found that nearly 70% of Singapore CEOs believe businesses should focus on self-reliance for growth, rather than relying on government help. The poll's findings come as the government prepares to release its 2016 budget.

site_title: Developers get early look at Google's new Android software
summary: Google has released an early preview of its new Android software, allowing developers to test the "N release" before the official May developers conference. The preview includes features such as split-screen modes and picture-in-picture functionality. Android is also working on Project Svelte to reduce memory requirements, enabling the software to run on a broader range of devices. The preview is available for testing on select devices, including Nexus and Pixel models, with a final product expected to be released later this year.

site_title: More liquid alternative funds being offered to Asian investors
summary: Liquid alternative funds, which employ hedge fund strategies, have seen a 25% increase in assets under management in Asia to $47 billion in the first 11 months of 2015. These funds, designed for individual investors, use strategies such as short-selling and relative value to profit from market fluctuations. With falling minimum investment requirements, they are becoming increasingly accessible to high net worth and retail investors. While offering a safer alternative to traditional hedge funds, liquid alternatives' limited investment scopes and correlated strategies carry new risks, making it challenging to achieve uncorrelated returns in today's market.

site_title: Ezra, Emas statements send privatisation talk into overdrive
summary: Ezra Holdings and its subsea subsidiary Emas Offshore issued statements indicating they are in talks on "possible transactions", fueling privatisation rumours. The statements led to a 20% surge in Ezra's stock price and a 5% gain in Emas Offshore's shares. Analysts speculate Emas may be considering delisting, which could follow OSIM International's recent privatisation offer. However, concerns remain about the timing and feasibility of privatisation, with oil prices still volatile and banks uncertain about their support.

site_title: Childlike tale with a timely message
summary: The March theatre season in Singapore begins with three plays addressing timely issues. Xenophobia, a growing concern in the city-state, is tackled in the latest production, "Red Demon," a Mandarin play written by Noda Hideki in 1997. The play was translated into English by Roger Pulvers in 2003 and into Mandarin by Nine Years Theatre. The production aims to raise awareness about the issue, which has become a problem in Singapore's diverse and crowded society. The play is part of a trend of Singaporean theatre addressing contemporary issues.

site_title: Amazon leasing 20 Boeing 767s to expand air delivery network
summary: Amazon is leasing 20 Boeing 767 freighters from Air Transport Services Group Inc to expand its air delivery network, aiming to make deliveries faster and more efficient. The deal is part of Amazon's long-term goal to build its own logistics network, reducing its dependence on United Parcel Service Inc and FedEx Corp. Amazon will hold the leases for five to seven years and has the right to buy up to 19.9% of Air Transport Services common shares over five years. The move is seen as a significant step towards Amazon's goal of having its own delivery fleet in the future.

site_title: JTC Furniture Hub @ Sungei Kadut to be completed end-2018
summary: Singapore's first high-rise and multi-tenanted furniture development, JTC Furniture Hub @ Sungei Kadut, is expected to be completed by the end of 2018. The eight-storey hub will feature 63 modular units, ranging from 500 to 1,000 square meters, allowing businesses to combine units to form larger floor plates. The hub will also include a 10,000 sq m Furniture and Furnishings Experience Centre, supporting the industry's ecosystem and fostering collaboration among local companies. The development aims to enhance the industry's competitiveness and position Singapore's furniture sector for long-term opportunities.

site_title: Square's earnings show it can grow beyond just mobile payments
summary: Square Inc., a mobile payments company, reported its first earnings as a public company, beating analysts' estimates with a 49% increase in fourth-quarter sales to $374 million. The company expects to become profitable this year due to larger customers signing up for its add-on services. Square's shares rose 4.8% and 34% since its initial public offering. The company processed $10.2 billion in payments for over 2 million merchants, with larger merchants accounting for 39% of transactions. Square forecasts 2016 adjusted revenue of $600-620 million, topping analysts' projections by 15-20%.

site_title: ST Index slips in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.31 points down at 2,809.12 on Thursday, despite subdued trading volume of 2.4 billion units worth S$988 million. This was the first day since February 19 that turnover was less than S$1 billion. Overseas markets, including the Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite, fell slightly, and US Dow futures dropped 20 points. The lack of direction from overseas markets contributed to the STI's decline.

site_title: Top ballet dancers make S'pore date
summary: Top ballet dancers from around the world, including Yonah Acosta and Daniil Simkin, are set to perform in "The Superstars of Ballet" in Singapore. The show features 12 internationally acclaimed principal dancers performing highlights from iconic ballet classics such as Le Corsaire and Don Quixote. The dancers will engage in friendly competition as they showcase their skills, with many having to fit the performance into their busy schedules. The event promises to be a treat for classical ballet fans in Singapore.

site_title: Central Pattana to invest 46b baht over three years
summary: Central Pattana, Thailand's largest shopping mall developer, plans to invest 46 billion baht (S$1.8 billion) over three years to boost average revenue growth to 15% per year. The company aims to spend 15-16 billion baht in 2016, focusing on developing new projects, renovating shopping centers, and launching condominium projects. With 1.58 million square meters of net leasable areas, Central Pattana achieved a 94% average occupancy rate in 2015, and plans to open a new shopping mall, renovate four centers, and launch three condominium projects in 2016.

site_title: Euro falls; stock, bond prices soar as Draghi pulls out the stops
summary: The euro plummeted after European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi announced a surprise 20 billion euro (S$30.5 billion) boost to its quantitative easing program, expanding it to 80 billion euros a month. This move, exceeding expectations of 70 billion euros, led to soaring stock and bond prices. The ECB also cut interest rates and expanded its asset-buying program to investment-grade corporate bonds, aiming to boost European economies amid migrant crisis, Brexit fears, and slowing Chinese economy.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, HSBC fight Fed's too-big-to-fail plans
summary: Foreign banks HSBC and Deutsche Bank are opposing the Federal Reserve's plans to implement "too-big-to-fail" rules, arguing they are burdensome and unfair to US units of the world's largest lenders. The proposed rules would require US units of foreign banks to have an extra layer of debt available to be wiped out in a crisis, which would be sold to the parent companies rather than third-party investors. The banks claim similar-sized domestic US lenders are not subject to the same requirements.

site_title: IEV soars, prompting query
summary: IEV Holdings' shares surged 78% to S$0.114, nearing its 52-week high, after an unusual trading day with over 166 million shares changing hands. The unusual volume prompted a Singapore Exchange query. IEV Holdings recently unveiled the inauguration of a biomass plant in Vietnam, which it expects to have a positive impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. The company's surge came as other oil and gas counters lost ground.

site_title: Nasdaq to buy ISE from Deutsche Boerse
summary: Nasdaq Inc has agreed to buy International Securities Exchange (ISE) from Deutsche Boerse AG for $1.1 billion. The deal would give Nasdaq 40% of the US options market, further solidifying its lead as the No. 1 US options exchange operator. The acquisition would also allow Nasdaq to expand its stake in the Options Clearing Corporation to 40%, and strip out $40 million from the two businesses. The deal is part of Deutsche Boerse's plan to merge with the London Stock Exchange Group to create a European trading powerhouse.

site_title: Euro dives as ECB unveils raft of easing measures
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) unveiled measures to stimulate growth and inflation in the eurozone, causing the euro to dive against the dollar. The ECB cut its main refinancing rate to zero, lowered its deposit rate to -0.4%, and expanded its bond-buying program to include corporate debt. The euro sank to a one-week low of US$1.0863 per dollar and fell against several other currencies. The measures were seen as a surprise, with expectations of a more significant boost to the economy.

site_title: Uncharted waters of negative interest rates create new uncertainties, risks
summary: Global central banks have implemented negative interest rates to stimulate growth and reduce debt burdens, but the effectiveness of these measures remains uncertain. Despite modestly negative policy rates, banks have been reluctant to pass on the rates to retail deposits, and mortgage rates have not increased. This could undermine the rationale of negative interest rates, posing risks to banks' business models. The phenomenon also affects sovereign bonds, with an estimated $7 trillion in negative-yielding bonds, and individual investors, who may be hesitant to take on risk due to a murky economic outlook.

site_title: US auto safety agency seeking details of Google self-driving crash
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is seeking more details about a recent crash involving a Google self-driving car in California. The incident occurred on February 14, when the Google vehicle struck a municipal bus, with Google acknowledging "some responsibility" for the crash. NHTSA chief Mark Rosekind expressed interest in a "more detailed exploration of what exactly happened" after speaking with Google officials.

site_title: Oil prices ease off multi-month highs
summary: Oil prices eased on Thursday, following multi-month highs, as refineries enter seasonal maintenance and a global glut weighs. Brent crude futures fell to $40.75 per barrel, down 32 cents from their last close, while US crude declined 1 cent to $38.28 per barrel. Analysts warn that larger gains would be unwarranted due to the upcoming refinery maintenance and global supply.

site_title: Gross-out humour, R-rated jokes rule the day
summary: Sacha Baron Cohen stars as Nobby Butcher, a dim-witted football hooligan, in his new film The Brothers Grimsby. Nobby's life is disrupted when he reunites with his estranged brother Sebastian, a posh secret agent, after 28 years. The brothers become embroiled in a plot to exterminate a chunk of the world's population, leading to a series of humorous and cringe-worthy moments. The film, directed by Louis Leterrier and written by Baron Cohen and others, features gross-out humor and R-rated jokes, but may not appeal to all audiences.

images.alt_text: The Brothers Grimsby, starring Mark Strong (right) and Sacha Baron Cohen, dwells on gutter-level subject matter

site_title: Good times for consumers ahead as MyRepublic rattles the incumbents
summary: MyRepublic, a new telco hopeful, unveiled its proposed mobile plans, offering data-only plans at a third the price of the Big Three telcos. The incumbents, M1, Singtel, and StarHub, responded cautiously, with Singtel introducing a new feature to expand its data-centric plans. MyRepublic defended its pricing strategy, citing a more cost-effective and future-proof network type. The move has sparked a price war, with consumers showing interest, as over 37,000 have registered support for MyRepublic. The New Entrant Spectrum Auction is set for Q3 2016, and MyRepublic aims to meet the pre-qualification criteria and raise US$250 million for its mobility bid.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Dairy Farm International (DFI) has been investing in IT, procurement, and supply chain, expected to yield results by FY17. DFI is expected to drive average unit volume growth via building products and brands. Analysts have set a target price of US$7.03 for DFI. In contrast, Keppel's five jackup rigs under construction have been delayed, pushing delivery dates from 2018 to 2020, with a potential -6% impact on Keppel's FY17-18 earnings per share. UOB Kay Hian has maintained an "overweight" view on Singapore banks, with OCBC and DBS as top picks.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US stays within narrow range for 11th week
summary: Consumer confidence in the US remained stable for the 11th week, with the Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index at 43.8, little changed from the prior week. The workforce is growing at its fastest pace in over a decade, with a 4.9% unemployment rate matching an eight-year low. However, sluggish wage growth and signs of inflation may be limiting optimism, according to the report. Confidence in the economy crept up to a five-week high, but dropped a seven-week low among full-time workers.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after ECB cuts rates
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday after the European Central Bank cut key interest rates and increased its asset-buying program to boost the eurozone economy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.18%, the S&P 500 gained 0.15%, and the Nasdaq composite added 0.27%. The rate cut and asset-buying program were seen as a positive move for the global economy.

site_title: 2025 masterplan to enable Singapore to be global city of design
summary: Singapore aims to become a global city of design by 2025, according to the Design Masterplan Committee's report, "Design 2025 - Singapore by Design." The masterplan includes 15 recommendations to boost innovation, entrepreneurship, and design thinking, with initiatives such as a Design Promotion Unit and a Business Centre at the National Design Centre. The government plans to implement these recommendations, including increasing design thinking among public servants and fostering design appreciation through community outreach and trade fairs. The goal is to drive Singapore's economy forward as a thriving innovation-driven city.

site_title: City buzz
summary:

The Singapore Cult & Underground Film Festival showcases indie films like "Housebound" and "Raiders!", while experimental composer Steve Reich performs with the London Sinfonietta. The Singapore Cocktail Week offers over 60 events, including bar tours and workshops. A preview screening of the film "Noma: My Perfect Storm" takes place before the FoodCine.ma festival. Various other events and festivals are also happening in Singapore.

site_title: ECB could pay banks to borrow from it under new scheme
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may introduce a new loan program to boost credit growth, offering banks four-year loans at a discounted rate for lending to households and companies. ECB President Mario Draghi announced the targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO II) at a discounted rate, potentially as low as the deposit facility rate. This move aims to encourage banks to lend more, thereby stimulating economic growth.

site_title: New soloists for SDT Don Quixote
summary: The Singapore Dance Theatre (SDT) is set to debut its new soloists in its second staging of the ballet Don Quixote. The production, which features a range of soloists and principal dancers, will showcase the company's growth and improvement since its 2014 premiere. New soloists include Chua Bi Ru/Li Jie, Etienne Ferrère/Nazer Salgado, Akira Nakahama/Alison Carroll, and others, while lead roles will be reprised by Rosa Park/Chihiro Uchida and Chen Peng/Kenya Nakamura. The ballet, originally choreographed by Marius Petipa, will be performed by SDT until the end of the year.

site_title: ECB couldn't "tolerate" London grip on euro trading post-Brexit: France's Noyer
summary: European authorities, led by the European Central Bank, cannot tolerate London remaining the primary euro trading hub post-Brexit, according to former Bank of France Governor Christian Noyer. The eurozone aims to regain control over trading, with London currently handling $640 billion in euro-dollar trades daily, more than twice the eurozone's total. This move would shift control away from the UK and strengthen the eurozone's economic influence.

site_title: Yahoo adds directors as company struggles with turnaround
summary: Yahoo! Inc added two independent directors, Catherine Friedman and Eric Brandt, to its board amid a turnaround effort, replacing Charles Schwab and Max Levchin. The move aims to boost confidence among shareholders amid a struggling company. CEO Marissa Mayer faces a potential proxy battle from activist shareholders, who have urged the company to overhaul its management and board. The shares fell less than 1% to $33.19 following the announcement, down 22% in the past year.

site_title: Trump calls global currency devaluations 'dangerous' for US
summary: Donald Trump criticized global currency devaluations, calling them "dangerous" for the US economy and costing American jobs. He defended his calls for a tougher US stance on trade and suggested charging a tax on foreign-made products sold in the US. Trump also vowed to stop corporate inversions, saying they cost the US twice as much as estimated, with a potential loss of $5 trillion. He claimed Republicans and Democrats agree on halting inversions but lack leadership to make a deal.

site_title: BSI Singapore banker involved in 1MDB investigation leaves firm
summary: BSI Bank Singapore executive Yak Yew Chee, involved in the 1MDB investigation, has left the bank. His accounts were frozen in September, and he was questioned as part of Singapore's 1MDB inquiry. Yak was a relationship manager for 1MDB Global Investments Ltd and was paid a monthly salary of around $59,000. The bank confirmed his departure, citing his retirement. The move comes amid ongoing investigations into 1MDB and allegations of financial irregularities, with both Najib and 1MDB denying any wrongdoing.

site_title: European stocks rally after ECB unveils more stimulus
summary: European stocks surged 2.5% to their highest level since January 13, driven by the European Central Bank's surprise decision to cut its main refinancing rate to zero and increase its asset purchase program. The move aims to boost growth and inflation in the region. Banking and insurance sectors led the gains, with stocks like UniCredit and Aviva rising 11% and 5% respectively. The euro weakened, making European exports more affordable overseas, and stocks benefiting from the weaker currency.

site_title: Three gems
summary: A wine enthusiast recently shared a dinner experience with three exceptional wines: Roederer's Cristal 2005 champagne, Chateau Lafite Rothschild 1989, and Grands-Echezeaux 1990. The wines were a complete dinner in themselves, showcasing their unique characteristics and complexities. The Cristal's fresh and refined palate was a perfect introduction, while the Lafite Rothschild's delicacy and complexity required time to appreciate, and the Grands-Echezeaux's broad-shouldered and full-bodied nature provided a striking contrast. The experience underscored the importance of the vine, terroir, and skilled winemaking in producing sublime wines.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.3 points down in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.31 points to 2,809.12, its first day below S$1 billion in turnover since February 19. Trading volume was 2.4 billion units worth S$988 million, significantly lower than usual. The index struggled to stay positive, influenced by overseas markets, which saw the Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite fall slightly, and Dow futures drop 20 points. Analysts believe Singapore's residential market may not feel pain until 2017, with cooling measures possibly lifted then.

site_title: Sysma's profit drops close to 69% for H1 FY16
summary: Sysma Holdings reported a 69% drop in net profit to S$499,000 for the first half of FY16, despite a 18% year-over-year rise in revenue to S$68 million. Higher costs, including a 20% increase in cost of sales, contributed to the decline. The company's construction business remains stable, while its property development business has made progress in selling its projects, with all development projects substantially sold. Sysma will focus on marketing strategies to improve sales for its remaining projects.

site_title: Lifebrandz's Q2 net loss narrows to S$366,000
summary: Lifebrandz reported a narrowed Q2 net loss of S$366,000, down from S$929,000 in the same quarter last year. Revenue fell 20% to S$303,000 due to lower food & beverage sales at Mulligan's, impacted by tourist slowdown and economic conditions. Expenses dropped 14% to S$606,000. Loss per share decreased to 0.01 Singapore cent, and no dividend was declared. The company remains cautious about its outlook and will explore business opportunities, including fundraising, to transform its business profile.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate 3-year bond deal upsized on strong demand
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings sold S$125 million three-year bonds at 4.9% to meet refinancing needs, with the issue being upsized from S$75 million due to strong demand. This follows Courts Asia's S$75 million three-year bond deal, also upsized from S$50 million. The bonds will be used to redeem legacy debt maturing in July. The strong demand suggests an improvement in investor sentiment, with attractive pricing being a possible factor.

site_title: ECB cuts rates, expands asset-buying programme to boost economy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates to zero from 0.05% to boost the eurozone economy, also expanding its quantitative easing program to 80 billion euros a month. The moves reflect concerns over falling inflation expectations and low price growth. The euro fell 1% against the dollar following the announcement, which was seen as a surprise by financial markets. ECB President Mario Draghi's news conference will provide further insight into the bank's strategy.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank cut interest rates on Thursday to boost the eurozone economy, surprising financial markets by dropping its main refinancing rate to zero from 0.05 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher on Thursday, closing at 1,690.91 after 1.72 billion lots worth RM1.81 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 441 to 355. The index added 4.56 points to its previous close.

site_title: Finnish MPs to debate euro exit after 'Fixit' petition
summary: Finnish parliament is required to debate a possible referendum on leaving the European single currency euro after a citizen's initiative signed by over 50,000 Finns. The move, dubbed "Fixit," is seen as unlikely in financially stable Finland, but parliament must hold a debate on the matter. A date for the debate has not been set.

site_title: German holiday bookings to Turkey start to recover: minister
summary: German holiday bookings for summer in Turkey have started to recover, with a 40% year-on-year decline in summer bookings reported by the German travel association. The decline was largely due to a suicide bombing in Istanbul in January that killed 10 Germans. Tourism Minister Mahir Unal stated that bookings are expected to bounce back by April and May, with fuel subsidies for tour operators continuing beyond their initial horizon. The Turkish government has unveiled a plan to support the tourism sector, including a US$88 million grant and debt restructuring facility.

site_title: US jobless claims fall to lowest level since October
summary: The US labor market showed sustained strength with initial jobless claims falling to 259,000, the lowest level since October, according to the Labor Department. This marks the longest run below the 300,000 threshold since the early 1970s. The four-week moving average of claims also fell to 267,500, indicating a healthy labor market. The strong job market and low unemployment rate of 4.9% have alleviated recession fears, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 242,000 jobs in February.

site_title: Irish economy grew by 7.8% in 2015, best in EU again
summary: Ireland's economy grew by 7.8% in 2015, the fastest growth in the EU for the second consecutive year. This was driven by a strong retail sector, low unemployment, and a weak euro boosting exports. The economy expanded by 2.7% on a quarterly basis in the final quarter of 2015, exceeding expectations. Despite a forecasted 4.3% growth in 2016, the country's robust GDP growth may not be translating to increased consumer spending, and a prolonged political stalemate may impact the country's economic momentum.

site_title: ECB slashes inflation forecasts, sees lower growth
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered its 2016 inflation forecast to 0.1% and 2017 forecast to 1.3%, predicting price growth will remain below its target until at least 2018. The bank also adjusted its GDP growth projections, showing the eurozone economy slightly outperformed expectations last year. Despite this, the ECB's inflation forecasts indicate that the target of nearly 2% will be undershot for at least three more years. The bank's decisions were made as it struggles with cheap energy affecting the price of goods and services.

site_title: German trade surplus contracts as exports fall
summary: Germany's trade surplus contracted slightly in January due to a 0.5% decline in exports to 98.2 billion euros. Imports rose 1.2% to 79.4 billion euros, resulting in a trade surplus of 18.8 billion euros, down from 20.3 billion euros in December. Exports to the European Union expanded by 1.0% year-on-year, while exports to countries outside Europe fell by 5.0%. The contraction marks a slight slowdown in Germany's robust economy amidst global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Greek unemployment drops to 24 per cent in December
summary: Greece's unemployment rate dropped to 24% in December, the lowest since May 2012, with 1.14 million people out of work. Although the rate remains more than double the euro zone's average, the economy expanded slightly in the last quarter of 2015. The jobless rate has decreased from record highs but still lingers above pre-crisis levels.

site_title: OCBC issues A$300m debt
summary: OCBC has issued A$300 million senior floating rate notes due 2020, priced at the three-month bank bill swap reference rate plus 1.2% per annum. The notes are expected to be rated Aa1 by Moody's, AA- by Standard & Poor's, and AA- by Fitch. They will be used for general corporate purposes and are listed on the Singapore Exchange on March 18, 2016.

site_title: Oil price could fall by US$10 if output freeze fails: DNB Markets
summary: Oil prices could drop by US$10 per barrel if OPEC and non-OPEC countries fail to agree on an output freeze, according to Norwegian brokerage DNB Markets. North Sea crude is currently trading at around US$40 per barrel, a 50% increase from a 12-year-low. A meeting between OPEC and non-OPEC countries is scheduled for March 20 to discuss a potential output freeze. DNB Markets analyst Torbjoern Kjus predicted this meeting could mark a bottom for oil prices, but a failure to agree could lead to a US$10 drop.

site_title: ECB to unveil fresh stimulus to lift sagging economy, inflation
summary: The European Central Bank is set to unveil its second economic stimulus package in three months, aiming to boost inflation and lift the sagging eurozone economy. The ECB is expected to cut its deposit rate deeper into negative territory, adjust its asset-buying scheme, and consider measures to prop up banking margins. Analysts predict a modest package of measures, including a rate cut and increased asset purchases, to combat ultra-low inflation and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Citic Envirotech wins 198m-yuan project to upgrade wastewater treatment plant
summary: CITIC Envirotech (CEL) has secured a 198 million yuan (S$42 million) project to upgrade a wastewater treatment plant in China's Hebei Province. The plant serves textile and dye companies, which produce over 70% of China's print and dye supplies. The project will be completed by December this year and will lead to an upward revision in water tariff for the plant. CEL will be funded by proceeds from its US$175 million senior perpetual securities issuance programme. The company expects more opportunities for upgrading projects in China due to its expertise in membrane bioreactor technology.

site_title: Emirates sees higher profits but cites lower oil industry demand
summary: Emirates airline expects "significantly higher" annual profits for 2015/16, despite lower oil industry demand, according to President Tim Clark. The airline is considering downgrading A380 services to Houston due to decreased demand from the oil industry, its largest corporate customer. Emirates remains interested in an upgraded A380neo, a project put on hold by Airbus, and questions Boeing's wide-body decisions.

site_title: Opec cuts unlikely before US, Russia, Iraq reduce output: FGE
summary: Opec is unlikely to cut oil production until US, Russia, and Iraq reduce output, according to energy consultant Fereidun Fesharaki. Oil prices have risen 50% from 12-year lows due to Saudi Arabia's pledge to freeze supply if others cooperate. The US is expected to cut production by at least 500,000 barrels per day, while Russia may see a decline of 200,000 barrels per day. Iraq has little incentive to cut, and Iran's oil release is timed to avoid a market battle with Saudi Arabia. Oil inventories are expected to be 50% lower by end-2016.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: M1 introduced new and upsized mobile data plans in Singapore, joining a price war in the mobile data space, as MyRepublic and Singtel unveiled theirs. Senior Minister Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of private sector participation in infrastructure development. UOB priced its US$500 million subordinated notes issue. ANZ exited its SME business in five Asian countries, cutting around 100 jobs. SIA and Tourism Malaysia signed a two-year partnership to boost tourist flow into Malaysia. Singapore shares closed 1.3 points down in low volume trading.

site_title: Axe to fall on hundreds more in Singapore oil & gas sector
summary: Hundreds of jobs are at risk in Singapore's oil and gas sector as industry contractors scale down or exit the country. Companies such as BW Offshore, Modec, and CB&I are retrenching, following Keppel and Sembcorp's decision to cut nearly 10,000 global jobs. This move is part of a broader industry downturn, with the liquidation of Dolphin Geophysical Pte Ltd already resulting in 160-170 job losses.

site_title: StarHub also launches new data upsize option
summary: StarHub, Singapore's last Big Three telco, has introduced a new data upsize option for mobile postpaid customers, offering 3GB data for S$3 per month. This move follows similar launches by M1 and MyRepublic, and comes despite Singtel group CEO Chua Sock Koong's warning that a price war would harm the industry and customer experience. The new option is available for customers who sign up or renew their StarHub 4G plans, with the usual monthly rate of S$6 applying from April 1.

site_title: IMF official warns global growth forecasts could be lowered
summary: IMF official Jose Vinals warned that global growth forecasts may be lowered further, citing the need for policymakers to strengthen their economies. The Fund previously revised down its 2016 and 2017 forecasts by 0.2 percentage points in January. Vinals predicted a possible downward revision by the spring meetings next month, amid concerns over global economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close slightly lower on mainland weakness
summary: Hong Kong shares closed slightly lower on Thursday, despite initial gains, due to mainland weakness. The Hang Seng index fell 0.1% to 19,984.42, and the China Enterprises Index lost 0.3% to 8,420.14 points. The decline followed a morning surge driven by hopes of European Central Bank stimulus for the struggling European economy.

site_title: ANZ exits SME business in five Asian countries, cuts around 100 jobs
summary: ANZ has exited its emerging corporate (SME) business in five Asian countries, including Singapore, Vietnam, Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Taiwan, cutting around 100 jobs. This move follows a trend among Australian banks to improve shareholder returns and profits amid slowing revenue growth and stricter regulatory capital rules.

site_title: Datapulse Technology sinks into the red in Q2 FY16
summary: Datapulse Technology reported a net loss of S$580,000 in Q2 FY16, with revenue dropping 21.5% to S$4.78 million due to weak demand for media storage products and services. Net profit for the six-month period doubled to S$3.29 million. The company attributed the decline to a weak Singapore manufacturing sector and ongoing slowdown in China. Despite this, Datapulse plans to boost revenue by expanding customer base and delivering value-added services, while maintaining operating costs through efficiency enhancements.

site_title: Opera becomes first big browser maker with built-in ad-blocker
summary: Opera introduces a new browser version with built-in ad-blocking features, promising faster page-loading times and a less intrusive web browsing experience. This move aims to increase user privacy and security while addressing growing demand for ad-blockers. Despite relying on advertising for revenue, Opera believes ad-blocking will become less relevant when advertising becomes more engaging and less disruptive. The feature will be initially available to developers and early adopters, with plans for future release in mainstream browsers.

site_title: Goldman hired daughter of Najib ally amid 1MDB pitch, WSJ says
summary: Goldman Sachs hired Tan Sri Azmin Shamsudin's daughter, Tan Teck Long, as a banker around the time it was pitching to Malaysia's 1MDB fund, according to the Wall Street Journal. The hiring is being investigated by US authorities as part of a broader probe into Goldman's actions related to 1MDB and former Goldman chairman Tim Leissner. Leissner left Goldman last month amid the investigation into the fund and potential money laundering. The firm is among several banks under investigation over their hiring practices.

site_title: European shares steady before ECB, but DAX underperforms
summary: European shares remained steady on Thursday before the European Central Bank's meeting, where it is expected to unveil more stimulus measures. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index was flat, while Germany's DAX fell 0.4%. The ECB's move aims to combat ultra-low inflation, which is driven by low energy costs and rising wages and prices.

site_title: French industrial output up 1.3% in January
summary: French industrial production rose 1.3% in January, beating expectations and reaching its highest reading since December 2011. Manufacturing output increased by 0.8%. The data follows revisions to seasonal adjustments and weights, as well as the baseline year.

site_title: Stephen Hawking joins 150 top scientists call for Britain to stay in EU
summary: Stephen Hawking has joined over 150 top scientists, including three Nobel laureates, in a letter to The Times urging Britain to stay in the European Union. They argue that leaving the EU would be "a disaster for UK science and universities" due to the loss of funding and talent. The scientists point to Switzerland's struggles to attract young talent after restricting free movement of workers, and note that EU membership allows Britain to attract and fund the best researchers. The letter comes ahead of the June referendum on Britain's EU membership.

site_title: At least five killed, several hurt in shooting near Pittsburgh
summary: At least five people were killed and several injured in a shooting near Pittsburgh on Wednesday. Two gunmen ambushed a backyard party, firing from an alley onto the partygoers, before fleeing. Four women and one man were shot and killed, with three others wounded. The attack in Wilkinsburg, Pennsylvania, is the latest in a series of mass shootings that have raised gun control concerns ahead of the US presidential elections.

site_title: EU to keep strong trade defences even with China shift: official
summary: The European Union plans to maintain strong trade defenses even if it grants China market economy status, according to EU Trade Minister Cecilia Malmstrom. The EU is considering making changes to China's status conditional on China reducing its steel exports to Europe. Malmstrom stated that China needs to behave responsibly and address its excess steel production capacity, regardless of its market economy status. The EU's decision is expected by December, but Malmstrom emphasized the need to maintain trade defense instruments towards China.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi's ally gears up to rule Myanmar, but Suu Kyi still at the wheel
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's ally, Htin Kyaw, has been nominated by her National League for Democracy to be Myanmar's next president, despite the army-drafted constitution banning her from the role. Suu Kyi will serve "above" her appointee, who is seen as having sufficient pedigree in Myanmar's struggle against junta rule. Htin Kyaw, a 69-year-old university teacher and long-time Suu Kyi associate, is expected to be elected by Myanmar's two houses of Parliament in the coming days, with Suu Kyi's party dominating both chambers.

site_title: How a hacker's typo helped stop a billion dollar bank heist
summary: A spelling mistake in an online bank transfer instruction helped prevent a nearly $1 billion heist involving the Bangladesh central bank and the New York Fed. Unknown hackers breached Bangladesh Bank's systems and stole about $80 million, one of the largest known bank thefts in history. The mistake occurred when hackers were trying to transfer funds to a Philippine bank, but instead, the instruction was sent to a different account, blocking the transfer. The typo prevented the hackers from accessing the full $1 billion.

site_title: Shell CEO van Beurden's remuneration fell in 2015
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden's remuneration fell 8% in 2015 to 5.135 million euros, down from 24.198 million euros in the previous year, mainly due to a decrease in his pension. In contrast, BP CEO Bob Dudley's remuneration rose 20% to US$19.6 million, despite the firm delivering one of the lowest profits in its history. The decline in Shell's CEO remuneration was largely attributed to the decrease in his pension, which had been positively affected in 2014 by his promotion to CEO.

site_title: In crowded Cairo, ride-hailing apps such as Uber and Careem leave cabbies fuming
summary: Taxi drivers in Cairo are protesting against ride-hailing apps Uber and Careem, which have gained popularity in the city, leading to a decline in their business. The apps offer a convenient and affordable alternative to traditional taxis, but drivers claim they are being unfairly undercut by the companies. Many drivers have taken to social media to share their frustrations, with some reporting instances of drivers smoking in cars and refusing to turn on air conditioners during hot summer days. The Egyptian government has formed a ministerial panel to investigate the status of the ride-hailing services.

site_title: Aviva posts forecast-beating 2015 operating profit of US$3.8b
summary: Aviva, a British insurer, posted a 20% rise in 2015 operating profit to £2.7 billion, beating forecasts. The company's integration with acquired rival Friends Life is ahead of schedule, with £225 million in synergies expected in 2016. Aviva's combined operating ratio strengthened to 94.6%, and its solvency capital ratio is 180%, exceeding the 100% threshold. The company will pay a final dividend of 14.05p per share, up 15% from 2014.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB initiates coverage on Valuetronics; sees gross margin, EPS upside
summary: CIMB Securities has initiated coverage on Valuetronics Holdings, a Hong Kong-based electronics manufacturing services provider, with a target price of S$0.56. The brokerage house expects the company's gross margin to improve to 15.2% in FY16 and EPS growth of 12-16% per annum. Valuetronics' exit from the mass-market LED segment is seen as a positive move, and the company's expansion into the automotive sector and shift in sales mix are expected to boost margins. The company has a track record of paying dividends, making it an attractive dividend play.

site_title: Shanghai authorities said to discuss ways to cool property market
summary: Shanghai authorities discussed measures to cool the city's surging property market, following a 18% year-over-year increase in residential home prices in January. Possible measures include tightening mortgage policies for second-home buyers, increasing scrutiny of down-payment loans, and restricting pre-sales licenses for high-end apartments. The city's real estate market has been deemed "irrational" and should be more tightly controlled with regulation, according to a senior official. The goal is to prevent potential financial risks and maintain a balanced market.

site_title: Philippine exports at lowest in 3 years, govt spending to support economy
summary: The Philippine economy experienced its lowest exports in three years in January, with shipments falling to $4.19 billion, down from $4.36 billion in the same period last year. Non-electronics exports declined, while electronics shipments rose 5% due to a 7.7% increase in exports to Japan. Despite this, the Philippine economy is expected to support growth due to government investment in infrastructure and a surge in campaign spending ahead of the election. The government aims for a 6.8-7.8% growth rate this year, faster than the IMF's forecast of 6.0%.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on data showing inflation rate rose in Feb
summary: China's stocks fell 2% on Thursday, led by banking and energy shares, as inflation data showed a faster-than-forecast rise. The CSI300 index fell 1.9% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 2.0% due to concerns about limited room for monetary easing. However, companies making consumer products saw gains. The inflation report, which accelerated at its fastest pace since July 2014, suggests the recent rally in China's stocks may be running out of steam.

site_title: China Feb vehicle sales down 0.9% y-o-y
summary: China's vehicle sales declined 0.9% in February to 1.6 million units, compared to a 7.7% year-on-year growth in January and a 15.4% rise in December. For the first two months of 2016, sales grew 4.4% compared to the same period last year. This follows January's forecast of a 6% growth in vehicle sales for the year.

site_title: Twitter doles out stock, cash bonus to retain talent
summary: Twitter is offering restricted stock and cash bonuses to employees to prevent staff departure amid stagnant growth and falling stock. The bonuses range from $50,000 to $200,000 and vary depending on when employees started working. This move comes after four top executives left the company in January, marking the biggest leadership changes since Jack Dorsey returned as CEO last year. Dorsey has also pledged to give a third of his stock to the employee equity pool to attract and retain talent.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower, NZ shares hit record after rate cut
summary: Australian shares fell 0.14% to 5,150.1, while New Zealand shares hit a record high of 6,513.62 after the central bank cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 2.25%. The move made dividend-paying stocks more attractive. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index ended up 51 points at 6,508.28, while the S&P/ASX 200 index declined 7 points.

site_title: Amid "serious" situation, China eyes soil pollution law in 2017
summary: China is working to pass its first soil pollution law by 2017, amid a "serious" situation with widespread contamination affecting food and water safety, and sustainable development. The law aims to address the lack of dedicated legislation, with 10 drafts already reviewed. The legislation will allow the state to decide who is responsible for contaminated land and create financing mechanisms for clean-up costs. The law's provisions may include dedicated funds and subsidy facilities, but details remain unclear.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps three-day losing streak on improved risk appetite
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the first time in four days on Thursday, driven by improved risk appetite and a stronger oil market. The Nikkei share average increased 1.3% to 16,852.35, with exporters benefiting from a weaker yen. Medical electronics company Hoya Corp gained 1.9% after a Deutsche Bank upgrade, while the Topix index rose 1.5% to 1,352.17. However, the Topix subindex for electric and gas fell 3.1% due to a Japanese court's halt of nuclear reactor operations, which weighed on the index.

site_title: IMF official says Indian banks' balance sheet clean-up a priority
summary: IMF official Jose Vinals advises India to prioritize cleaning up its banks' balance sheets and addressing corporate debt overhang to strengthen growth prospects. He warns of potential capital outflows and a further downward revision of global growth estimates. The IMF had previously forecast India's economic growth rate to reach 7.5% in the 2016/17 fiscal year, aided by declining oil prices.

site_title: M1 joins telco price war with new, upsized mobile data plans
summary: M1 Singapore introduced new mobile data plans, mySIM+ 15 and mySIM+ 20, with data options of 1GB and 4GB respectively, at S$15 and S$20 a month. The plans offer additional features like 100 minutes of calls and 600 SMS/MMS. M1 also launched an upsize data feature for S$5.90 a month, allowing customers to boost their data bundles by up to 12GB. This move is seen as a price war in the mobile data space, with MyRepublic and Singtel also unveiling new plans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks resume uptrend at open, Shanghai dips
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.30% to 20,055.42, following a rally in New York and European markets. Shanghai, however, edged down 0.52% to 2,847.57 for a second consecutive day due to lingering concerns over the Chinese economy.

site_title: Clinton sure no indictment coming from email scandal
summary: Hillary Clinton expressed confidence that she will not face an indictment over her use of a private email account while secretary of state. She acknowledged making a mistake by using a homebrew email server but insisted that her predecessors did the same. Clinton also spoke out against Republican frontrunner Donald Trump, calling his rhetoric "demagoguery" and "trafficking in prejudice and paranoia." Despite a shock loss to Bernie Sanders in Michigan, Clinton remained optimistic, saying it was a marathon and her campaign was inclusive. She vowed to continue the campaign.

site_title: Samsung Elec says preorders for Galaxy S7 phones stronger than expected
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd reported stronger-than-expected preorders for its Galaxy S7 smartphones, set to launch this week in South Korea and other markets. President Koh Dong Jin did not disclose sales targets, but said the S7s aim to revive sales in China, where the company lags competitors. Analysts predict weaker sales in the first year compared to last year's Galaxy S6s, but incremental upgrades may help.

site_title: Indonesia launches warehouse-sharing scheme to cut logistics costs
summary: Indonesia launched a warehouse-sharing scheme to reduce logistics costs, aiming to improve competitiveness and competitiveness with neighboring countries. The scheme, inaugurated by President Joko Widodo, allows companies to store goods in shared warehouses for up to three years, receiving tax incentives. The goal is to reduce logistics costs by 2.5 times those in Singapore, currently ranking 53 in the World Bank's logistics performance index. The government plans to establish 50 new logistics centers within the next two to three years, aiming to become a regional logistics hub.

site_title: Clinton, Sanders engage in fiery debate clashes
summary: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed in a fiery debate on immigration, six days before the Florida primary. Both candidates support comprehensive immigration reform and pathways to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. They were pressed on whether they would deport undocumented children, with both saying no. The debate comes after Sanders' surprise win in Michigan, and the candidates are now vying for Florida's crucial primary vote.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed forcefully on the debate stage on Wednesday, with the Democratic presidential rivals opening lines of attack on immigration in the aftermath of Sanders' stunning upset in Michigan.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at highest in 2016, won jumps
summary: South Korean stocks closed at their highest level in 2016, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 0.84% to 1,969.33. The won jumped 1% to 1,203.5 per dollar, driven by stabilizing oil prices and hopes of sustained policy easing. The gains were attributed to a combination of factors, including a hesitant stance from the South Korean central bank towards a further rate cut and increases in risk assets globally.

site_title: Five more limestone stacks found near Twelve Apostles in Melbourne
summary: Researchers at the University of Melbourne discovered five more limestone stacks, dubbed the "Drowned Apostles," 6 km offshore from the Great Ocean Road in Victoria, Australia. The stacks, estimated to be 60,000 years old, were preserved due to the rapid sea level rise during a glacial period. This find is unusual as sea stacks typically erode and collapse as the sea level rises. The discovery could make the Twelve Apostles a bigger draw for tourists.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries IEV as its shares soar
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried IEV Holdings after its shares surged 51% to 9.7 Singapore cents, with over 98,000 shares traded. The stock's price rose sharply within the first hour of trading, with a trading volume higher than usual. IEV Holdings denied any undisclosed information that could explain the unusual activity, stating it's aware of no new information. The sudden spike in share price has raised questions about the company's financials and potential reasons behind the surge.

site_title: South Korea central bank holds rates for 9th month, as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held interest rates steady for the 9th consecutive month at 1.50% as expected. The decision was made in line with market forecasts and aims to monitor global economic trends. The decision was also influenced by analysts' expectations, with 22 of 33 predicting no change. Governor Lee Ju-yeol is set to hold a news conference later in the day.

site_title: Suu Kyi's close friend and ally nominated for Myanmar president
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi's party nominated her close friend and ally U Htin Kyaw to be Myanmar's next president, despite the army-scripted constitution barring her from top office. Suu Kyi vowed to rule "above" the president, fulfilling her historic election mandate. The selection comes after months of speculation and follows the election of the National League for Democracy in November, which gave the party a comfortable parliamentary majority. A military nominee will also be put forward, with lawmakers from the lower and upper houses electing a candidate each.

site_title: Honda to compensate US dealers for losses over air bag recalls
summary: Honda Motor Co will compensate US dealers for losses due to the massive air bag recall linked to potentially faulty Takata Corp inflators. The company will provide reimbursement for depreciation costs and floor-planning expenses resulting from the temporary suspension of sales. The plan will take effect in late March, although the claim process has not been finalized. Honda ordered a stop-sale on 1.7 million vehicles from model years 2007-2015 in January.

site_title: North Korea says to liquidate South assets in joint projects
summary: North Korea announced it will liquidate all assets left behind by South Korean firms involved in two joint projects, the Mount Kumgang tourism resort and the Kaesong joint industrial complex. The Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of Korea made the statement, further escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula. This move is seen as a significant escalation of tensions between the two countries, which have been strained since the projects' shutdown. The liquidation of assets is expected to have significant economic implications for South Korea.

site_title: Fukushima mistakes linger as Japan marks 5th anniversary
summary: Japan marks the 5th anniversary of the Fukushima nuclear accident, which claimed 18,500 lives and set off the worst atomic crisis in a generation. Critics say Tokyo's push to restart nuclear reactors is proof that lessons from the tragedy have not been learned, citing complacency and strong ties between politicians, bureaucrats, and the nuclear industry. Only four of the dozens of shuttered reactors have been switched on under stricter safety rules, with two recently ordered to be shut down due to safety concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.280 points to 1684.690. The market saw 32.4 million lots traded worth RM10.3 million, with 83 gainers outnumbering 43 losers.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands protest over French jobs reform
summary: Hundreds of thousands of French students and workers protested against labor reforms aimed at boosting hiring, with young people expressing concerns that the measures would make their future uncertain. The reforms, proposed by Prime Minister Manuel Valls, would give employers more flexibility in hiring and firing, and reduce overtime pay for work beyond 35 hours. The protests, which drew an estimated 224,000 people nationwide, have put pressure on President Francois Hollande's government, which faces a re-election bid next year.

site_title: Oil prices dip after rally but supply worries persist
summary: Oil prices dipped on Thursday, falling 5 cents to $38.24 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 14 cents to $40.93 for Brent, after a strong rally on Wednesday. Despite a decline in US gasoline stockpiles and a rise in commercial crude stockpiles, supply concerns persist due to the long-running supply glut. Analysts remain cautious, citing the need for a sustained price increase, with a key meeting of major crude producers on March 20 potentially providing insight into price development.

site_title: Halliburton suspending annual salary hikes to avoid more layoffs
summary: Halliburton Co has suspended annual salary hikes and eliminated management bonuses to reduce costs amid the worst crude market downturn in decades. The company, which has already laid off over a quarter of its global workforce, aims to preserve jobs through further cost-cutting measures. Halliburton has also kept in place the base salary cuts for executives and senior managers implemented last year.

site_title: CAG support for cargo partners seeking pharma certification
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) is supporting six cargo partners in obtaining the International Air Transport Association's (Iata) CEIV Pharma certification, a global standard for pharmaceutical cargo handling. The certified companies include SIA Cargo, dnata Singapore, Global Airfreight International, Expeditors Singapore, CEVA Logistics Singapore, and Schenker Singapore. This certification aims to enhance their pharmaceutical cargo handling capabilities in Singapore, improving the country's position as a major pharmaceutical hub. The certification process is expected to boost the country's pharmaceutical logistics industry.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as ECB meeting comes into focus
summary: Asian markets rallied ahead of the European Central Bank meeting, with Japan's Nikkei index up 1%, Hong Kong gaining 0.5%, and Sydney adding 0.1%. Shanghai stocks retreated despite a strong Chinese inflation reading, as analysts attribute the decline to severe weather. The ECB is expected to deliver another stimulus package, with a potential interest rate cut and increased bond-buying. This move is seen as a positive for risk assets, with the US dollar plunging after a surprise interest rate cut in New Zealand.

site_title: SIA, Tourism Malaysia ink deal to boost tourist flow into Malaysia
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Tourism Malaysia have signed a two-year marketing collaboration to boost tourist arrivals in Malaysia through SIA's and SilkAir's services from Singapore. The partnership, effective April 1, 2016, will promote tourist traffic to Malaysia's key destinations, including Borneo, Langkawi, Penang, and the East Coast. The move aims to provide convenient access to Malaysia's unique tourist attractions. SIA currently operates 111 flights per week to five destinations in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore to make infrastructure assets mainstream for institutions: Indranee
summary: Singapore aims to mainstream infrastructure assets as a standalone asset class to attract institutional investors. Senior Minister of State for Finance and Law Indranee Rajah emphasized the need for private sector participation and government reforms to facilitate infrastructure development. Currently, global governments fund 60-65% of infrastructure investment, but this will become unsustainable as populations mature. Only 3% of global assets under management are allocated to infrastructure investment, making it an underweighted asset class. Singapore seeks to change this by developing infrastructure assets for institutional investors.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State for Finance and Law Indranee Rajah on Thursday stressed the importance of private sector's participation in the infrastructure sector, and said Singapore, as a regional infrastructure hub, is working to mainstream infrastructure assets for institutional investors by developing it as a standalone asset class.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up with oil, NZ boosted by rate cut
summary: Australian shares rose 2 points to 5,159.5, driven by higher oil prices and a 1.6% gain in the energy sector. New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut its cash rate to 2.25%, citing a worrying fall in inflation expectations. Global markets remained cautious ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, while yield stocks such as Spark and Fisher and Paykel Healthcare benefited from the rate cut.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, UOB, Hyflux
summary: SembCorp Marine raised its stake in Gravifloat AS to a controlling interest, expanding into offshore gas processing units.
