United Overseas Bank priced $500 million subordinated notes due 2026. Hyflux shares surged 12% after winning a letter of intent for an integrated water and power project in Egypt.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.62% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.62% higher on Thursday, closing at 2,827.97. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 36.26 points to 17,000.36, and S&P 500 gained 10 points to 1,989.26. Crude oil prices strengthened, with Brent rising to $41.07 a barrel and US crude to $38.29 a barrel. Top gainers included ComfortDelGro, Singapore Telecommunications, and DBS, with 111 gainers outnumbering 22 losers.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC jumps ahead of sales data
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.5% on Thursday, led by TSMC's 0.3% gain ahead of its sales data release. The TAIEX index reached 8,673.02, while the electronics and financials subindexes also increased. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.935 per US dollar. The gains came after a rate cut by New Zealand, which kept investors optimistic for European Central Bank stimulus later in the day.

site_title: Iran told to pay US$10.5b to Sept 11 kin, insurers
summary: A US judge ordered Iran to pay over $10.5 billion in damages to families of 9/11 victims and insurers. The ruling includes $7.5 billion in damages for the victims' families and estates, $3 billion to insurers, and $2 million in punitive damages per estate. Iran was found liable for aiding 9/11 hijackers and failing to defend claims against the attacks. The plaintiffs may attempt to collect part of the judgments using a law that permits parties to tap frozen terrorist assets.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises as central bank holds rates; stocks firmer
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.3% to 1,212.4 against the dollar, following the Bank of Korea's decision to keep interest rates unchanged for a ninth straight month. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also edged up 0.4% to 1,961.32 points. The decision was in line with expectations, despite some analysts expecting a rate cut. Traders await Governor Lee Ju-yeol's news conference.

site_title: Alibaba Group said to start marketing US$4b financing
summary: Alibaba Group plans to syndicate a loan of up to $4 billion, hiring eight banks as mandated lead arrangers. The loan, which includes a $3 billion five-year loan, will pay 110 basis points more than the London interbank offered rate. The proceeds will be used to finance merger and acquisition investments. The loan is part of Alibaba's efforts to secure funding for its expansion plans.

site_title: 'King of Wall Street' trader John Gutfreund dies at 86
summary: John Gutfreund, a former CEO of Salomon Brothers and nicknamed the "King of Wall Street" in 1985, has died at 86 due to complications from pneumonia. He played a significant role in revolutionizing bond trading and creating mortgage-backed securities. Gutfreund's contributions to the financial industry were instrumental in shaping the market, earning him the prestigious title.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wall St gains, oil rise
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.01% on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a big jump in oil prices, despite global growth concerns. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index reached 16,811.00, while the Topix index gained 0.95%. The opening deals came despite lingering worries about global growth, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Fifa agent confession threatens to drag down others
summary: A former Fifa match agent, Miguel Trujillo, pleaded guilty in a New York federal court to four counts of money laundering, wire fraud, and a falsified tax return. Trujillo confessed to paying bribes to football officials in Central America and the Caribbean, potentially challenging the not-guilty pleas of CONCACAF officials and others indicted. He claimed Media World and Traffic Sports USA paid hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes to officials to secure World Cup marketing rights. This revelation could further drag down the Fifa scandal, which has already implicated senior members and associated figures.

site_title: China's 770m middle-class aspirants boon to consumption
summary: China's 770 million working population is the largest in the world, but only 15.8 million, or less than 2%, earn enough to pay income tax. Creating at least 10 million urban jobs could boost the middle class, but most Chinese still earn less than Americans, with an average annual wage of $56,360. Chinese consumers spend $7 a day, with food and clothing making up nearly half of their spending. The country's middle class is also spending more on health, with sales of vitamins and dietary supplements expected to reach $5.3 billion by 2017.

site_title: China Feb year on year inflation quickens to 2.3%, fastest pace since July 2014
summary: China's consumer inflation rose to 2.3% year-on-year in February, the fastest pace since July 2014, beating market expectations of 1.9%. Producer prices remained deflationary, falling 4.9%. The data suggests China's economy is showing signs of recovery, with policymakers under pressure to address concerns about slowing growth.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, HSBC fight Fed's 'unfair' too-big-to-fail plans
summary: Foreign banks, including HSBC and Deutsche Bank, are opposing the Federal Reserve's plans to implement "too-big-to-fail" rules, citing them as burdensome and unfair. The rules would require US units of foreign banks to issue debt that can be wiped out in a crisis, on top of existing securities. The banks argue that similar-sized domestic US lenders aren't subject to the same requirements, and the rules would create competitive disparities and unfair treatment. The Fed is implementing rules to ensure the world's 30 biggest lenders can be wound down and recapitalized without taxpayer bailouts.

site_title: Nasdaq buys Deutsche Boerse's options market for US$1.1b
summary: Nasdaq Inc agreed to buy the International Securities Exchange for US$1.1 billion, expanding its US options business. This move comes as Deutsche Boerse AG considers a merger with London Stock Exchange Group Plc. The deal will strengthen Nasdaq's position in the US options market, but does not address the potential merger between Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange.

site_title: How global investors turn negative Japan yields into big returns
summary: Overseas investors are capitalizing on Japan's record-low negative yields, buying large quantities of Japanese government bonds despite a weakening economy. The discount offered by the Bank of Japan's interest rate policy has led to a 2.3% return equivalent for five-year JGBs, despite a yield of minus 0.16%. Foreign demand has continued to increase, with the 12th-straight month of net purchases of medium-term JGBs in January, and a more than doubling of foreign buying in February. This divergence in monetary policy has significant implications for Japan's currency markets and fragile economic recovery.

site_title: Taiwan must "redouble" efforts to meet growth forecast: central bank chief
summary: Taiwan's central bank governor Perng Fai-nan urged the government to "redouble" its efforts to meet the reduced economic growth forecast of 1.47% for 2016, citing contracting exports in neighboring countries, including South Korea and China. The government had previously slashed its growth outlook from 2.32% and projected a year-on-year contraction for January-March. Taiwan's exports, which drive its trade-dependent economy, are expected to contract for the second straight year.

site_title: UOB prices its US$500m notes issue
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has priced its US$500 million subordinated notes due 2026 at 99.574% of their principal amount, bearing an interest rate of 3.5% per annum. The notes are callable in 2021 and expected to be rated A2 by Moody's and A+ by Fitch Ratings. The first call date and maturity dates are September 16, 2021, and September 16, 2026, respectively. The issue date is expected to be March 16, 2016, with joint lead managers including UOB and Citigroup Global Markets Singapore.

site_title: Names of 22,000 IS members leaked to news channel
summary: A disillusioned former IS member has handed over 22,000 documents containing the names, addresses, and family contacts of jihadis who joined the Islamic State group. The documents, obtained by Sky News, reveal information on 51 countries and include previously unknown fighters in northern Europe, the US, Canada, and North Africa and the Middle East. The records are expected to be an invaluable resource for analysts, shedding light on who joined the group and potentially helping authorities track down those involved in terrorist activities.

site_title: Bank of America hiring bankers for new middle-market push: sources
summary: Bank of America is hiring a new team of investment bankers specializing in middle-market companies with $50 million to $2 billion in revenue, four years after abandoning a similar business. The hiring comes as the bank reduces staff and tries to grow in areas where it can gain market share. Vice-Chairman Mark Stephanz will lead the effort, which will focus on mergers, acquisitions, and managing money for executives. The move aims to increase business and revenue, following a record $5 trillion in M&A deals in 2015.

site_title: Singapore, Japan to jointly promote Asia-Pacific air traffic management transformation
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and Japan's Civil Aviation Bureau (JCAB) have signed a memorandum of cooperation to jointly promote air traffic management transformation in the Asia-Pacific region. The agreement aims to facilitate information sharing, knowledge exchange, and collaboration in ATM modernisation efforts. This partnership marks CAAS's first with an air navigation services provider from the Asia-Pacific region and supports Singapore's vision to develop as a Centre of Excellence for Air Traffic Management. The collaboration will contribute to the development of next-generation ATM systems for Singapore and the region.

site_title: UK surveyors see slower house price rises after tax hike
summary: UK property prices continued their rapid growth in February, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' house price balance rising to +50. However, increases are expected to slow down due to a 3% surcharge on purchases taking effect in April. The index for price increases over the next three months dropped to +21, and sales are rising at the joint-fastest rate in almost two years. Surveyors predict prices will rise by a quarter over the next five years, citing a lack of housebuilding since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Argentina reaches deals with more holdout creditors
summary: Argentina reached deals with more holdout creditors, settling with hedge fund GMO, French bank BNP Paribas, and individual investors for $190 million, bringing the total to $6.5 billion. This brings Argentina closer to resolving its 15-year litigation over defaulted bonds, which total $9 billion. The settlements are contingent on the Argentine Congress cancelling laws preventing repayment of the holdouts, with the new government offering $6.5 billion to resolve claims.

site_title: Citi creates new group focused on serving fund clients
summary: Citi creates a new Global Asset Management Group to serve private equity firms, hedge funds, and sovereign wealth funds, as well as pension funds and family offices. The group, led by vice chairman Zubaid Ahmad and global head Brad Coleman, aims to enhance investment banking coverage for these clients. The team will review client prioritization and structure resources to execute more deals for these asset managers. The group will work closely with the Financial Institutions Group and the markets business to provide better service.

images.alt_text: Senior investment bankers Zubaid Ahmad and Brad Coleman will be leading a new group at Citigroup Inc focused on better serving clients that are private equity firms, hedge funds and sovereign wealth funds, according to a memo seen by Reuters on Wednesday.

site_title: Amazon to lease 20 Boeing 767s to expand network
summary: Amazon has leased 20 Boeing 767 freighters from Air Transport Services Group Inc. to expand its air delivery network, aiming to lessen its dependence on United Parcel Service and FedEx. The deal also gives Amazon the right to buy up to 19.9% of Air Transport Services' common shares over five years. This move is part of Amazon's strategy to build a global delivery network, as proposed in a 2013 report, and will provide air cargo capacity for one and two-day delivery for customers.

site_title: North Korea fires two short-range missiles into sea
summary: North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast into the sea, approximately 500km from the South Korean coast, according to Yonhap news agency. The missiles were launched from the city of Wonsan, where similar launches have occurred frequently. The South Korean military's Office of the Joint Chiefs of Staff could not immediately be reached for comment.

images.alt_text: North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast into the sea early on Thursday, flying approximately 500km, South Korea's Yonhap news agency reported quoting the South's military.

site_title: ECB set to loosen policy to lift sagging economy, inflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to unveil its second stimulus package in three months to combat sagging economy and low inflation. The ECB is expected to cut its deposit rate deeper into negative territory and adjust its asset-buying scheme, aiming to boost prices and inflation. Analysts predict modest measures, including a rate cut and increased asset purchases, as the bank faces concerns about the efficacy and limits of monetary policy.

site_title: Euro lower ahead of ECB; NZ dollar sinks 2% on rate cut
summary: The euro was slightly lower against the US dollar ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, expected to ease monetary policy further. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar plummeted 2.0% after the central bank cut interest rates to counter lower inflation. Analysts predict a 10-15 basis point cut in the ECB's benchmark rate and an increase in quantitative easing. The ECB faces challenges in responding to weak inflation and growth without fueling concerns about running out of monetary policy ammunition.

images.alt_text: The euro was slightly lower against the US dollar but up on the yen Wednesday ahead of a European Central Bank meeting expected to further ease monetary policy.

site_title: Changi now offers early check-in option for majority of passengers
summary: Changi Airport has introduced an early check-in option for 48 airlines, allowing passengers to check-in at least 12 hours before their scheduled flight departure, with some airlines offering 24-hour check-in. The service, available at 23 airlines' common counters and 25 individual airline counters, is expected to boost the airport's efficiency and improve the travel experience for passengers. Over 80% of departing passengers can now check-in at least four hours before their flight, and the airport aims to raise awareness of the service to reach more passengers.

site_title: State prosecutors charge former Brazilian President Lula in money laundering probe
summary: Brazilian state prosecutors have charged former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in a money laundering investigation, following an undeclared beachfront apartment in Guaruja owned by his family. The charges are part of a parallel investigation to a two-year-old federal graft probe that detained Lula for questioning on Friday. The specific charges against Lula were not disclosed. This move comes after Lula was detained for questioning on federal graft allegations.

site_title: Volkswagen US chief steps down amid emission scandal
summary: Volkswagen announced that US chief Michael Horn is stepping down amid an emissions-cheating scandal. Horn, who joined the company in 1990, became CEO of Volkswagen Group of America in 2014. His departure is effective immediately by mutual agreement with the company. The move comes as Volkswagen faces numerous investigations into the scandal, with CEO Herbert Diess thanking Horn for his work for the brand.

site_title: US: Big jump in oil prices lifts stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 36.26 points (0.21%) to 17,000.36, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index climbing 10.00 (0.51%) and 25.55 (0.55%), respectively. The benchmark US crude oil price reached its highest level in over three months after a decline in gasoline stocks. Technology shares and oil-linked shares also rose, with Facebook, Alphabet, and Chevron gaining 1.3%, 1.4%, and 4.6%, respectively.

site_title: Susan Lim loses appeal against legal assessor fees
summary: Surgeon Susan Lim has lost an appeal against paying S$235,200 in fees to a legal assessor, Senior Counsel Vinodh Coomaraswamy, for work done in a disciplinary inquiry against her. The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's earlier decision, with Lim facing a bigger bill of S$1.1 million submitted by the Singapore Medical Council for expenses from two disciplinary hearings.

site_title: Hyflux shares surge on news of Egypt project
summary: Hyflux shares surged 11.5% to S$0.63 after winning a letter of intent for an integrated water and power project in Egypt's Ain Sokha Economic Zone. The project, valued at US$500 million, includes a 150,000 cubic meter desalination plant and a 457 MW power plant. Construction is expected to commence after contract terms are finalized, with a 25-year operation and maintenance contract to be awarded to Hyflux. The project marks Hyflux's entry into the Egyptian market and is expected to have a material financial impact on the company by December 2016.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as M&A prospects lift Telecom Italia, Mediaset
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by gains in Telecom Italia and Mediaset on potential mergers with French rivals. The FTSEurofirst 300 index remains down 7% since 2016, but investors are optimistic about the ECB's possible monetary stimulus measures on Thursday. Telecom Italia rose 5.7% after comments from Italian and French leaders, while Mediaset rose 6.8% after reports of a potential sale to Vivendi. The ECB is expected to cut its deposit rate and adjust its asset purchase program.

site_title: Google sides with Facebook in data dominance probe
summary: Google has sided with Facebook in a data dominance probe, disagreeing with the head of France's competition authority who wants to address data privacy and antitrust issues separately. Google's Fabien Curto Millet said protecting data privacy is part of good competition, but it shouldn't be elevated to a different status. The French competition authority is analyzing Facebook's possible market dominance and has opened a sector inquiry into the digital platforms industry. Meanwhile, Germany's Federal Cartel Office is examining whether Facebook abused its power by forcing customers to agree to terms allowing the use of their data.

site_title: Facebook snaps up face-swapping app creator Masquerade
summary: Facebook has acquired Masquerade Technologies Inc, the creator of the popular face-swapping app MSQRD, as part of its efforts to build its video services. The deal, which was announced on Facebook's website, does not disclose financial details. Masquerade's founders will join Facebook, and the app will continue as a standalone product. This acquisition is part of Facebook's broader strategy to innovate in video, but it is unlikely to significantly draw away Snapchat users, according to analyst James Cakmak.

site_title: Oil prices rally on big fall in US gasoline stockpiles
summary: Oil prices surged on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) rising 4.9% to $37.99 a barrel, the highest level in over three months. The US Department of Energy reported a 3.9 million-barrel increase in crude stockpiles, but a 4.5 million-barrel drop in gasoline inventories, a three-fold reduction from estimates. Analysts attribute the gasoline drawdown to a bigger-than-anticipated decrease, which boosted demand expectations.

site_title: HDB rents more resilient than those for apartments, condos
summary: Rentals of both HDB flats and private apartments/condos in Singapore fell in February 2016, with HDB flat rents showing greater resilience compared to non-landed private homes. SRX Property's flash estimates show a 3.7% year-on-year drop in HDB flat rents, while non-landed private home rents declined 5%. Experts attribute HDB flats' stability to their lower prices and stronger demand from budget-conscious tenants.

site_title: Abe suggests higher chance that sales tax increase will be delayed
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe hinted that the sales tax hike scheduled for April might be delayed due to the current economic headwinds, particularly the impact of overseas economic downturns. This is the second time Abe has delayed the tax increase, with the first delay being in 2014. Abe stated that a second delay would only be considered if Japan faced a shock similar to the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse.

site_title: Norwegian sovereign wealth fund suffers worst returns since 2011
summary: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global, the world's largest sovereign wealth fund, reported its worst year since 2011 with a 2.7% return in 2015. The fund's equity portfolio delivered its weakest performance in half a decade, with stocks gaining 3.8%, bonds rising 0.3%, and real estate investments growing 10%. The fund's holdings gained 334 billion kroner (S$54 billion) last year, but CEO Yngve Slyngstad attributed the decline to volatility in the markets, including negative interest rates and falling oil prices.

site_title: Imports spike raises concerns of China trade invoice manipulation
summary: China's reported imports from Hong Kong have surged 89% in February, raising concerns that trade invoices are being manipulated to facilitate capital flight. This phenomenon, known as "phantom goods," allows companies to disguise money flows as payment for goods, evading China's capital controls. The spike in imports follows similar patterns in recent months, with economists estimating that the practice has distorted China's official trade data by billions of dollars, with total outflows estimated at over $1 trillion in 2015. Authorities are cracking down on illicit channels, including phantom goods, to curb capital outflows.

site_title: Trump sends rivals packing in Michigan, Mississippi and Hawaii
summary: Donald Trump won the Michigan and Mississippi Republican primaries and the Hawaii caucuses, regaining momentum in his presidential campaign. Senator Bernie Sanders scored an upset win in the Michigan Democratic primary, while Hillary Clinton won the Mississippi primary and maintained her delegate lead. Ted Cruz won the Idaho Republican primary, and Marco Rubio's campaign is in question after a poor performance. Trump's victories suggest he can appeal to working-class white voters and may have a strong showing in the general election.

site_title: New Zealand cuts benchmark rate to record low
summary: New Zealand's central bank slashed its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 2.25% amid a struggling dairy industry and deteriorating global outlook. The rate cut, the fifth since June last year, aims to boost economic growth and counteract low inflation expectations. Analysts predict further rate cuts, with some forecasting a potential rate of 1.75% by September 2017. The move follows a slump in global milk prices and a deterioration in the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Developers get early look at new Android software
summary: Google has released an early preview of its next Android version, dubbed "N", to developers, allowing for a wider range of devices to support the software. The preview includes features such as split-screen modes and picture-in-picture mode. The goal is to incorporate developer feedback and have the final product ready for device makers by mid-year. This departure from the traditional developers conference release marks a shift towards earlier collaboration with developers.

site_title: Flipkart's markdown heralds 'market detox'
summary: Flipkart's valuation has been slashed by a Morgan Stanley fund from $15 billion to $11 billion, marking a significant downturn in the Indian startup funding market. This move comes after a two-year funding boom, where Indian startups like Flipkart and Snapdeal vied for capital to compete with Amazon in the rapidly growing e-commerce market. Experts predict a "market detox" as investors become more cautious, with only the strongest startups expected to survive and raise funds at realistic levels.

site_title: MAS urges life insurers to stem consumer ire by raising service quality
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has urged life insurers to improve service quality to meet consumers' expectations, citing that nearly half of complaints received last year were related to service standards. MAS Assistant Managing Director Chua Kim Leng emphasized the need for insurers to be fair, proactive, and prompt in dealing with consumers, and to adopt a code of practice that promotes transparency and disclosure. He also highlighted the importance of effective governance and risk culture, particularly in light of the increasing disruption in the insurance sector due to technology.

site_title: Cathay Pacific looks to cut fuel costs with new A350 planes
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways, Asia's largest international airline, will receive 12 new Airbus A350 aircraft this year to trim fuel costs and modernize its fleet. The A350 is 25% more efficient than comparable planes, helping the airline reduce expenses amid increased competition. This move follows a 25% increase in Cathay's 2015 profit, driven by declining crude oil costs and cheaper fares. The new planes are expected to help the airline cut costs and increase productivity.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd, Asia's largest international airline by passengers, will soon start using Airbus Group SE's most fuel-efficient plane as it tries to trim costs in the face of mounting competition.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Budget expected to prime firms, workers for future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2016 is expected to focus on medium-term economic growth, with efforts to help businesses and workers upgrade skills. The government will tweak initiatives aimed at boosting productivity, including the SkillsFuture framework, and channel funds to support the Committee on the Future Economy. However, economists do not anticipate a "flood of goodies" and instead expect a more measured approach, with some pain relief for companies amid a moribund growth outlook. The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) Scheme and foreign worker levy will also be subject to tweaks and possible refinements.

site_title: German court rules Facebook 'like' button may break law
summary: A German court ruled that Facebook's "like" buttons on commercial websites may break German law if users are not warned that their personal data is being shared. The ruling applies to the Fashion ID website, which must now inform users that "liking" the site grants permission for the company to log their IP address. The retailer will face a fine of 250,000 euros for every breach of the order. The ruling highlights concerns over data protection in Germany, where web users are protected by strong privacy rules.

images.alt_text: Facebook 'like' buttons on commercial websites break German law if users are not warned that their personal data is being shared, a court ruled on Wednesday.

site_title: The French style mogul who hates fashion
summary: French fashion designer Agnes b. made a surprising statement, saying "I don't like fashion." Despite spending 40 years at the top of the fashion industry, she expressed her dislike for the fashion world.

site_title: Brexit could damage achievements UK takes for granted
summary: Germany strongly opposes Brexit, considering it a historic mistake that could damage the EU's reputation and industrial interests. The country's industrialists, bankers, and politicians are concerned about the potential consequences of Britain's departure. The article suggests that Brexit could lead to a rift in European relations, making it challenging for the EU to maintain its cohesion.

site_title: Hiring outlook for Q2 dimmest since 2009
summary: Singapore's corporate hiring plans for Q2 are expected to be the lowest since the 2009 recession, according to ManpowerGroup's latest net employment outlook. The survey found 76% of employers plan to freeze headcount, a 8% increase from Q1, while only 4% plan to reduce staff. The dimming hiring outlook is attributed to a sluggish economic environment, high operational costs, and business nerves over China's slowdown.

site_title: PropNex proposes new way to tweak ABSD
summary: PropNex Realty has proposed a tiered approach to tweaking Singapore's additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) to address market concerns. The proposal includes scrapping ABSD for Singaporeans buying second homes and reducing it to 5% for third purchases. Foreigners buying homes under S$3 million would maintain a 15% ABSD, while those buying above S$3 million would have a tiered system of 5% for first-time purchases and 10% for second-time purchases. The proposal also aims to loosen loan-to-value and mortgage servicing ratio limits for second and subsequent properties.

site_title: Libra Group eyes a piece of Malaysia's land and sky
summary: Libra Group, a Singapore-based M&E firm, is expanding into Malaysia's property, tourism, and aviation sectors. The company aims to establish itself in Kuala Lumpur's property sector and venture into Malaysia's tourism industry. Libra also plans to acquire Labuan-registered Neptune Aviation, leasing four second-hand Boeing 737s. The move is seen as a strategic move to tap larger regional markets and increase revenue, despite potential risks.

site_title: Rig-building backlogs come under the spotlight (Amended)
summary: Singapore's rig-building order books, led by Keppel Offshore & Marine and Sembcorp Marine, are facing scrutiny following the deferral of delivery of five jack-up rigs by Transocean. The rigs, originally scheduled for delivery from 2016, will now be delivered in stages from early 2020. Keppel Corp has stated it will be compensated by Transocean for the agreed deferment. Moody's has downgraded Transocean's credit rating, citing reduced demand, heightened bad debt concerns, and a growing supply glut. Analysts disagree on the outlook for the offshore drilling sector, with some seeing deferrals as a lesser evil than cancellations, while others predict a prolonged oversupplied situation.

site_title: FDA deal allows Amarin to promote drug for off-label use
summary: The FDA has agreed to allow Amarin to promote its only product, Vascepa, for a broader range of patients, despite the agency not initially approving this use. The deal settles a legal case between the agency and Amarin, which sued for the right to promote its drug. The settlement allows Amarin to submit proposed marketing materials to the FDA, which can object if deemed untrue or misleading. This decision may encourage other companies to seek similar arrangements, potentially changing the way drugs are marketed.

site_title: Hang on to the cap after popping the bubbly
summary: Champagne cap collecting has evolved into a passion and art form, with some caps selling for up to 1,000 euros each. Rare caps, such as those made by limited-edition brands or featuring unique artwork, can fetch high prices. The hobby has a dedicated community, with a fair held every two years, and a market value guide, le Lambert, that estimates the worth of 30,000 out of 45,000 champagne caps. Collectors, known as "placomusophiles," are willing to pay top dollar for rare caps, with some selling for up to 10,000 euros each.

site_title: COE premiums up across the board; Cat C sees largest jump
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rose across the board in the latest bidding exercise, with Category C goods vehicles and buses seeing the largest increase of S$3,889 to S$48,890. Category A car premiums rose by S$2,000 to S$45,000, while Category B car premiums increased by S$634 to S$47,604. The increase is attributed to post-Chinese New Year demand as companies return to business, with the Land Transport Authority receiving 7,864 bids for COEs. The overall increase is described as "manageable" and unlikely to lead to huge corrections in the near term.

site_title: M1's remote monitoring solution launched for those looking after the elderly
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications operator, has launched a remote monitoring solution for elderly individuals living independently. The M1 Smart Activity Monitoring Service allows caregivers to track the senior's activity in real-time through a desktop computer or internet browser, with customizable alerts for potential issues. The service includes activity and door sensors, data analytics tools, and integration with M1's VSafe service for location tracking. The subscription-based service is available for S$14.66 per month and includes installation fees and customer support. The goal is to support seniors' desire to live independently while ensuring their safety and well-being.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Tax tweaks that help SMEs expand abroad
summary: Singapore is set to increase the Market Readiness Assistance grant for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) looking to expand abroad. The government plans to double the grant cap and liberalize unilateral tax credits to encourage businesses to venture overseas. These tax tweaks aim to alleviate concerns over tax compliance and support Singaporean companies in their international growth strategies.

site_title: Time for innovative international policy cooperation
summary: Major central banks' efforts to stimulate economic growth through negative interest rates have been deemed "futile" by economists, with some calling for a shift to "purer" fiscal policy, including direct monetary financing of public spending and "helicopter drops" to boost middle- and lower-income consumers. In response, a coordinated policy package that includes simultaneous increases in interest rates and fiscal expansion could boost global growth, improve capital allocation, and reduce the risk of speculative bubbles. Policymakers must work together to implement such a package, which would require innovative international cooperation.

site_title: New subpoena gives US investigators broad scope in probe against VW
summary: US investigators have issued a new subpoena to Volkswagen (VW) over its emissions cheating, seeking information on tax perks given to customers of VW's diesel cars under laws governing bank fraud. The probe, led by 20 investigators, aims to examine those who were aware of the wrongdoing and took no action, as well as those responsible for the illegal programming. The German investigation has expanded to 17 suspects, while French prosecutors have opened a formal fraud investigation, finding VW's cheating to be "intentional."

site_title: China housing frenzy spurs fund managers to favour property bonds
summary: China's housing market frenzy is driving fund managers to favor property bonds, with yields reaching 2% for yuan-denominated notes, the highest since 2015. Despite warnings of "panic" buying and concerns over market overheating, fund managers believe the government will continue to support the industry, citing improving balance sheets, falling borrowing costs, and increasing sale prices. The government's monetary stimulus and loosening of property curbs have fueled buying mania, with developers selling 79.39 billion yuan of bonds in the first two months of this year.

site_title: Was Slimane's show a swan song?
summary: Fashion designer Hedi Slimane's recent Saint Laurent collection may be his final show for the label, but its nostalgic and immersive quality has sparked debate about the value of revisiting the past in fashion. The collection, held in a restored 1980s-era YSL couture maison, featured sleek, retro-inspired designs with little innovation or forward-thinking. Meanwhile, other designers like Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski at Hermès and Julie de Libran at Sonia Rykiel struggled to find a balance between honoring their brands' histories and creating modern, forward-looking designs.

site_title: Tokyo should jettison nuclear option once and for all
summary: Tokyo is urged to abandon its nuclear power option, nearly five years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami led to a nuclear meltdown in Japan, killing 16,000 people and injuring tens of thousands. The traumatic event has largely faded with time, but its impact remains, with rebuilding efforts underway. The author argues that Japan should prioritize non-nuclear energy sources, citing the risks and consequences of nuclear power. The call comes as the world continues to grapple with the aftermath of the disaster and the ongoing challenges of nuclear energy.

site_title: Making sense of the Trump phenomenon
summary: A Donald Trump presidency is being discussed as a possibility, and some have questioned whether his policies would lead to the end of globalization. Trump's "trumpery" could imply the interruption of global economic integration, potentially disrupting markets and economies worldwide. His unconventional approach to politics and economics raises concerns about the future of global trade and economic policy-making.

site_title: 'Financial market dislocations' risk growing: IIF report
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns of growing "financial market dislocations" due to divergent central bank monetary policies, particularly between the US Federal Reserve and other major central banks. Volatility has increased, and signs of dislocations in financing markets are emerging. Analysts share concerns, citing factors such as regulatory changes, quantitative easing, and reduced risk appetite of financial institutions. If persistent, these market abnormalities could reduce pricing efficiency, distort risk signals, and potentially lead to unexpected outcomes detrimental to financial stability and economic wellbeing.

site_title: Investor group nominates Bethune to United board
summary: An investor group, including Altimeter Capital Management LP and PAR Capital Management Inc, has nominated Gordon Bethune to the United Airlines board, with Bethune's former role as CEO of Continental Airlines. The move comes as CEO Oscar Munoz returns from medical leave and the airline faces financial struggles and criticism of its board's decision-making. The proxy fight could impact investors, who have expressed concerns over United's stock performance and lack of succession planning.

site_title: Women on boards: Study finds forced quotas not effective
summary: A global study of 1,071 companies found that forcing companies to increase female representation on boards does not lead to a significant increase in women in other executive positions. Despite this, quotas are bringing balance to the boardroom in some countries, and voluntary targets have been successful. The study suggests alternative methods to boost female representation, including enshrining gender diversity requirements in corporate governance codes and setting term limits for directors. Quotas are not a cure-all, but they are a necessary step towards achieving gender equality in the workplace.

images.alt_text: A study has found that forcing companies to put more women on boards has not helped to redress the gender imbalance.

site_title: China plans to centralise commercial paper market
summary: China plans to centralize its commercial paper market, aiming to build a unified national bill market, according to central bank vice-governor Pan Gongsheng. The move aims to cut trading costs and risks through an electronic system. China's commercial paper market is highly fragmented, with poor liquidity and limited trading participation. This follows reports of a potential 3.8 billion yuan loss for Agricultural Bank of China due to a bills of exchange scam. The central bank has been pushing for a national commercial paper exchange for years, but a firm implementation timeline remains unclear.

site_title: Tiger to launch direct flights to Wuxi in April
summary: Budget carrier Tiger Airways will launch direct flights to Wuxi, China in April, becoming the only airline to fly non-stop from Singapore. The flights will offer greater connectivity and convenience to customers, with promotional prices starting from S$178 for a round-trip. This move is part of Tiger's expansion in China, with 10 destinations including Wuxi, Suzhou, and other major cities. The airline is being delisted from the Singapore Exchange to align with parent company Singapore Airlines, aiming to improve its growth prospects.

site_title: 'Detachables' the hot new thing in cooling tablet market
summary: The global tablet market is expected to decline 5.9% in 2016 to 195 million units, while detachables are gaining as PC replacements. Detachable tablet sales are projected to jump 73% this year, driven by Windows-based devices such as Microsoft Surface. By 2020, detachable tablet sales are expected to reach 63.8 million, with Windows-based devices commanding over 74% of the market. This shift is seen as a significant impact of Windows-based devices on the tablet market.

site_title: Ho Bee's recurring income strategy reaping dividends
summary: Ho Bee Land's financial results show a surge in rental income, reaching a fresh high of S$129.93 million in FY2015, driven by its strategy of building a portfolio of investment properties to generate recurring income. The group has diversified its portfolio with acquisitions in London, including a 276,792 sq ft office building, and has seen its occupancy rates and rental income grow. Ho Bee is now exploring options to divest its London properties, potentially selling or leasing them to capitalize on their value, and is considering asset enhancement works to increase their value.

site_title: Judge rules that bankrupt Sabine can reject midstream contracts
summary: US Bankruptcy Judge Shelley Chapman has ruled that bankrupt Sabine Oil & Gas Corp can reject contracts with two midstream companies, HPIP Gonzales Holdings LLC and Nordheim Eagle Ford Gathering LLC, which gather, treat, and transport oil and natural gas. The ruling could save the bankruptcy estate up to $115 million. The companies objected, citing unique agreements that gave them rights to the land. The judge indicated that a commercial resolution may be possible, but did not decide the underlying dispute.

site_title: Cathay Pacific profit up 90% on tumbling oil prices
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a 90% increase in net profit last year due to tumbling oil prices, which reduced fuel costs and boosted passenger numbers. However, global demand dented the airline's cargo unit. The airline's improved financial performance comes despite global economic challenges.

site_title: Don't be fooled by commodity rally: Many producers still face debt cliff
summary: Commodity producers are struggling to contain debt despite a recent market rally. Many companies face a debt cliff, with leverage more than double year-earlier levels, and are forced to keep producing to stay afloat. A surprise rally in metals has helped some gold producers, but overall, the industry faces grim consequences unless commodity prices extend gains. Moody's Investors Service predicts a six-year high in corporate defaults, led by commodity companies, and the debt burden is growing for miners and drillers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SEMBCorp Marine raised its stake in Norway's Gravifloat AS by 44% to a 56% controlling interest for $38 million. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's CEO, Alvin Cheng, will step down in April. Pacific Healthcare Holdings was sued over a $1.78 million payment and a $500,000 loan. The US stock market edged down amid tariff threats, while NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Date set for 2nd S'pore hearing into tycoon's Canada land dispute
summary: A second hearing in Singapore has been set for April 15 in a land dispute case between tycoon Oei Hong Leong and Concord Pacific Acquisitions over a waterfront plot in Vancouver. The original hearing was adjourned due to the absence of counsel. This case, initiated in October, concerns a disputed plot of prime land in downtown Vancouver.

site_title: Aussie rates probe risks hobbling benchmark
summary: Australia's securities regulator, ASIC, is investigating ANZ and other banks for alleged interest rate manipulation, which may further reduce the benchmark bank bill swap rate (BBSW). The rate, used for trillions of dollars in financing, has seen a significant decline in participation, with Reserve Bank of Australia assistant governor Guy Debelle stating that reform is needed to maintain its robustness. ASIC's probe may also deter other banks from participating, threatening market efficiency. Changes to the Australian system are scheduled to be completed by the end of 2016, with proposed measures including expanding transaction types and widening the rate-set window.

site_title: Delhiites have to keep paying the cost of pollution over the next decade
summary: Delhi's population is expected to surge by 11 million over the next 16 years, making it a new megacity. The city's poor management and lack of infrastructure have led to severe environmental and social costs, including air pollution, which is now the worst in the world. Despite the Supreme Court's landmark judgment in 1998, the city's air quality has worsened due to exponential growth and inaction. Politicians and bureaucrats have failed to implement long-term solutions, leaving Delhites to pay the health and environmental costs for the next decade.

site_title: Strongest El Nino in 20 years may hike palm oil price to highest since 2012
summary: A strong El Nino event may drive palm oil prices to their highest level since 2012, with prices potentially reaching RM3,000 (S$1,005) a tonne in Kuala Lumpur. Global palm oil production is expected to shrink by 3 million tonnes due to dry weather, and inventories may fall to 1.7 million tonnes by June. This will lead to a supply-demand gap of 4.2 million tonnes, causing prices to surge and world stocks to be drawn down dramatically.

site_title: Prudential Singapore new sales, VNB premiums fall (Amended)
summary: Prudential Singapore's total new business sales (APE) fell 13.4% to £309 million (S$607.8 million) in 2015 due to the end of distribution relationships with Maybank and SingPost. New business profit increased 7% to £2.62 billion, driven by regular premium agency-sourced protection sales. Regular premium sales dropped 8.7% to £264 million, while single premiums fell 32.9% to £454 million. The insurer still leads the market for regular premium products with a 23% market share.

site_title: Electronic payments a big plus for emerging economies: study
summary: A Visa-commissioned study by Moody's Analytics found that emerging economies have more to gain from boosting electronic payments, as consumption growth in these markets is faster than in developed economies. Electronic payments contributed an additional $296 billion to global GDP between 2011 and 2015, with emerging markets experiencing a 0.11% increase in GDP, compared to 0.08% for developed countries. The study suggests that increasing electronic payments in emerging markets could further boost GDP growth, but notes that the positive impact may be conservative and potentially underestimated.

images.alt_text: Increased electronic payments led to almost the same percentage increase in GDP between 2011 and 2015 for emerging markets - at 0.11 per cent - as for developed countries at 0.08 per cent.

site_title: Public relations network expanding in Asia
summary: PROI, the world's third-largest PR agency network, plans to expand its Asia-Pacific presence despite a slowdown in Asian economies. The network, founded in Europe in 1970, grew 17.1% in 2015 and is looking to add more hubs in Asia, focusing on Malaysia, Indonesia, and Myanmar. Chairman Jean-Leopold Schuybroek believes Asia's growth rate is higher than Europe's and that it's the right time to enter the market, as companies that adapt to change are more likely to succeed.

site_title: Singapore investors resume buying on Wall Street in Q4
summary: Singapore investors resumed buying US stocks in the fourth quarter of 2015, netting a gain of $1.46 billion, reversing three consecutive quarters of selling. In contrast, US investors shifted to selling stocks on the Singapore Exchange, disposing of $1.24 billion worth of shares. Despite global investors being net sellers on Wall Street, US investors still picked up $8.22 billion in global stocks, contributing to a 5.5% global stock price increase.

site_title: Yen firms, euro retreats before ECB meeting
summary: Currency markets experienced a risk-averse tone on Wednesday, with the yen rising amid anxiety over a potential slowdown in China. The euro underperformed before the European Central Bank meeting, which is expected to lower rates and announce more asset purchases. The US dollar fell 0.2% against the yen, while the euro was 0.5% lower. Investors are cautious about placing significant bets against the euro due to past disappointment, and markets imply a small chance of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

site_title: Fortescue discussing debt refinancing: sources
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, the world's fourth-largest iron-ore exporter, is discussing debt refinancing with investors amid a price rebound that has taken iron ore above $60 a tonne for the first time since June. The company has $8.1 billion in debt and repaid $1.1 billion in the second half of last year. Fortescue's bonds have rallied, making debt refinancing more expensive, but the company aims to take advantage of market conditions to reduce debt. Talks with investors are ongoing, with no decision made yet.

site_title: Ambani foray into TV, telecom may rekindle rivalry with brother
summary: India's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, plans to spend US$2 billion over three years to capture the country's TV set market, expanding Reliance Industries' media and telecom presence. This move pits him against his younger brother, Anant Ambani, who controls Jio, a 4G telecom brand that has spent at least US$18 billion. The Ambani brothers' rivalry is set to shake up both industries, with Mukesh's Reliance Industries targeting consumers and Anant's Jio focusing on telecom. The move could lead to increased competition and potentially disrupt the Indian media and telecom sectors.

site_title: Woes in China, emerging Asia hit 2015 import growth: World Bank
summary: Global merchandise import growth slowed to 1.7% in 2015 due to China's slower growth path and difficulties in commodity-exporting countries. Emerging markets in Asia accounted for most of the reduction. If China's imports remained flat, the world's merchandise import volume growth would have been 2.1% in 2015. This slowdown contrasts with 3% growth in 2014.

images.alt_text: Global merchandise import growth slowed to 1.7 per cent in 2015 as China's slower growth path and difficulties in commodity exporting countries reduced trade volumes, a World Bank report showed on Wednesday.

site_title: MyRepublic puts out feelers on mobile plans
summary: MyRepublic, Singapore's fourth telco hopeful, unveiled proposed mobile plans, including a 2GB data plan for S$6 a month, ahead of winning the fourth telco licence in April 2017. The plans, which will be available to existing and new broadband customers, offer more value and features than existing telcos. MyRepublic's network will be cost-effective and future-proof, using a small-cell pre-5G network with the National Broadband Network as backhaul. The startup is close to its US$250 million funding goal and aims to provide insight into its approach and vision for the Singapore mobility landscape.

site_title: San Francisco tech community facing discontent
summary: San Francisco's tech community is facing increasing discontent due to the city's growing population, rising rents, and congested traffic. Despite the city's large budget, many residents struggle to afford housing and face eviction threats. The tech industry's influence is seen as exacerbating the problem, with some entrepreneurs and investors expressing concern that the city is becoming a "plutocracy." A recent survey found that 39% of Bay Area adults believe things are headed in the wrong direction, up from 29% a year earlier. Residents are calling for the tech industry to do more to address the city's affordability crisis.

site_title: Anchor Resources prices IPO at S$0.25 per share
summary: Anchor Resources, a Malaysian gold miner, has priced its S$7.2 million initial public offering (IPO) at 25 Singapore cents per share. The 28.8 million shares will begin trading on the Catalist board on March 18, 2016, valuing the company at S$69.9 million. The IPO will raise S$4.6 million, with proceeds to be used for expanding gold processing capacity, general working capital, and further exploring and developing mines and properties. The offering price is 4.3 times the post-completion net asset value per share.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages issue conflicting views on Cache Logistics Trust and Triyards Holdings. Cache Logistics Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) could be further eroded due to expiring master leases and weak demand, leading Phillip Securities Research to maintain a "reduce" rating. In contrast, OCBC Investment Research recommends buying Triyards Holdings, citing good utilisation levels at its Vietnam yards, low net gearing, and a strong net orderbook. Triyards' fair value estimate is set at S$0.61, based on an undemanding five-times price-earnings ratio.

site_title: Amazon to lease planes for delivery
summary: Amazon.com Inc has leased 20 Boeing 767 freighter aircraft from Air Transport Services Group Inc, a move to establish its own air delivery network. The leases, lasting five to seven years, come as Amazon aims to speed up deliveries and reduce costs. The deal also grants Amazon the right to buy up to 19.9% of ATSG's stock over five years at $9.73 per share, a 17.3% discount to the stock's Tuesday closing price.

site_title: Noble said to be planning biggest ever loan backed by inventories
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is planning its largest-ever loan backed by inventories, seeking $2.5 billion in a borrowing base facility guaranteed by oil. The company aims to increase the final size to $3.25 billion if commodity prices rise over the next year. This move comes as banks demand more security, forcing a dramatic overhaul in the way NOBLE Group borrows.

site_title: Saudi Arabia seeking up to US$8b bank loan
summary: Saudi Arabia is seeking a US$6-8 billion bank loan to help bridge a record budget deficit caused by low oil prices. The loan, which would be the first significant foreign borrowing by the kingdom's government in over a decade, would be used to extend a five-year US dollar loan. The government is currently drawing down its foreign assets and issuing domestic bonds to cover the deficit, but these measures are expected to run out soon. Analysts predict that sovereign borrowing by Gulf Arab oil exporters could reach US$20 billion or more in 2016.

site_title: Rout in global steel prices puts brakes on platinum recycling
summary: Global steel prices remain under pressure, forecast to stay low, limiting the recovery of platinum recycling rates. The drop in steel prices has led to slower car scrapping, resulting in a 20% decrease in platinum recycling volumes in 2015. Despite a 26% fall in platinum prices, analysts predict a 10% rebound in recycling this year, driven by higher platinum prices. However, continued weakness in steel prices may limit the scope of the recovery.

site_title: Zeti keeps rate at 3.25%, her last before retiring
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz kept the benchmark interest rate at 3.25% in her last scheduled decision before retiring in April. Despite turmoil surrounding her leadership, economists forecast no change to the rate. Zeti's leadership has been marked by her strict stance, particularly in her dealings with Prime Minister Najib Razak, who has yet to announce her replacement, sparking concerns about investor confidence. Malaysia's economy continues to grow at over 4%, but the uncertainty surrounding Zeti's succession is a concern for economists.

site_title: Thai Express owner plans 40b baht investment in hotels, fast food over 5 years
summary: Minor International plans to invest 40 billion baht (S$1.57 billion) over 5 years in hotel and fast-food expansions, aiming to reach 210 hotels and 3,100 outlets by 2020. The company will focus on internal cash and debt financing, with 14-15 billion baht set aside for acquisitions. Minor aims for 15-20% net profit growth per year from 2016-2020, up from 60% in 2015. Revenue from overseas operations is expected to rise to 50% by 2020, with Minor running Burger King, Sizzler, and other Asian restaurants.

site_title: BMW 2015 results beat as dividend proposal lags
summary: BMW reported a full-year operating profit of 9.59 billion euros, beating analyst estimates, driven by healthy sales of high-margin sports utility vehicles. However, the company proposed a lower-than-expected dividend of 3.20 euros per share, below the 3.38 euros per share forecast. BMW retained its title as the world's biggest luxury carmaker, with 1.91 million car sales in the year-earlier period.

site_title: Commodity rally won't last as fundamentals unchanged: analysts
summary: Oil prices remained stable at around $40 per barrel, despite hopes of a possible output freeze among major oil producers, with analysts warning that the commodity rally is not sustainable. A deal to freeze production levels could occur in the second half of this year or next, but production would likely remain high, and market fundamentals remain unchanged. Analysts predict that the rally in oil prices will run out of steam soon, driven by market sentiment and speculative positions.

site_title: Iron ore drops back after 'surprising blip' that notched record
summary: Iron ore prices dropped 8.8% to $58.02 a dry metric ton after a one-day record surge on Monday. The price decline follows concerns that global supply is outpacing demand, with the global market remaining grossly oversupplied. Analysts, including Morgan Ball and Lourenco Goncalves, predict that the recent gains won't last, citing slowing steel demand in China and rising mine supply. The price is expected to settle in the $45-$55 range.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine raises stake in Norway firm to 56%
summary: Sembcorp Marine has raised its stake in Norway-based Gravifloat AS to 56% with a US$38 million investment, increasing its controlling interest. The company aims to expand into offshore gas processing units and develop new state-of-the-art facilities for the LNG and LPG industries. Sembcorp Marine will eventually acquire the remaining 44% stake at the same price to gain 100% control. The deal reflects the company's strategy to broaden its proprietary designs and solutions.

site_title: EU regulators publish tougher rules for derivatives trades
summary: EU regulators have published tougher rules for derivatives trades, requiring banks and companies to set aside billions of euros as margin to back trades from September. The new rules, aimed at making the $550 trillion market safer, apply to privately traded derivatives like interest rate and credit default swaps. Initial and variation margins will be mandatory, with estimated initial margins rising from under $44 billion to $200 billion. The rules follow the 2008 Lehman Brothers crash and will apply to about 70% of the EU's derivatives market, with some trades already cleared or phased in.

site_title: Standard Chartered in talks on US$2b Iraq bond sale
summary: Standard Chartered is in talks with Iraq's Finance Ministry to participate in a $2 billion bond sale this year, amid the country's efforts to rebuild and modernize its banking sector. Iraq plans to sell Eurobonds in the second half of 2016 to finance its budget deficit, with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank providing about $6 billion in aid this year. The bond sale was previously halted due to investor demands for high yields.

site_title: STI rebounds after 2 days of losses
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded by 31.66 points to 2,810.43 on Wednesday, after two days of losses. Key contributors to the rise included Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Marine, and offshore-and-marine stocks, which rose amid concerns of a potential recovery in the rigbuilding industry. Hyflux also surged on news of a US$500 million contract in Egypt. Despite China's weaker-than-expected export numbers, analysts believe the government is taking steps to mitigate the impact on growth.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to uncloak investors with see-through system
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission plans to implement a "see-through" system to identify investors behind trades in real-time, with the goal of improving market surveillance and combating rogue traders. The system would assign an identity record to each investor, allowing the watchdog to monitor live trading and scrutinize markets more effectively. However, the proposal has drawn criticism from some brokers and investors, who raise concerns about privacy invasion and potential information leaks. The SFC will consult market participants before implementation and aims to minimize costs and volatility.

site_title: Thailand facing worst water shortage in two decades: government
summary: Thailand is facing its worst water shortage in two decades, with water levels at its biggest dams at their lowest since 1994. Water rationing has been imposed in some provinces and hotels have been asked to minimize laundry loads. The country is experiencing drought in 14 provinces and 31 others are at risk. The government has allocated 23 billion baht (US$651.56 million) to help farmers cope with the drought, and officials are warning citizens not to consume excessive water during the Songkran festival.

site_title: Japan central bank to hold off rate cut amid unstable bond market: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is set to hold off cutting interest rates at its next rate review, citing market jitters and concerns over bond market instability. Despite January's surprise decision to adopt negative interest rates, policymakers are reluctant to ease again unless external shocks impact global financial markets. The BOJ prefers to top up asset purchases rather than cut rates, and Governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled no immediate stimulus is forthcoming, citing the need to scrutinize the effect of negative rates on the economy.

site_title: Pacific Healthcare in legal spat over alleged loan, payment over failed sale
summary: Pacific Healthcare Holdings has been sued by Straitsworld Advisory over an alleged S$500,000 loan and S$1.78 million payment related to the termination of two sale agreements. The company and its nursing home subsidiary, Pacific Healthcare Nursing Home, are defending the claims. Pacific Healthcare had entered into the sale agreements in January 2015, but they were terminated in May 2015 due to unfulfilled conditions. The company is seeking legal advice and will vigorously defend both claims.

site_title: US: Wall St higher at open as oil prices rebound
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, driven by a rebound in oil prices as Brent crude held above $40 a barrel. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.65 points, the S&P 500 gained 6.81 points, and the Nasdaq composite added 17.96 points. The gains came as investors seemed to brush off US President Trump's latest tariff threats, with stocks extending their rally despite the uncertainty.

site_title: Saudi Arabia seeks US$6b-US$8b bank loan to shore up state coffers
summary: Saudi Arabia is seeking a US$6 billion to US$8 billion bank loan to help shore up its state coffers amid a record budget deficit caused by low oil prices. The loan, which would be the first significant foreign borrowing by the kingdom's government in over a decade, is being advised by Verus Partners and would be used to plug the deficit. Analysts expect sovereign borrowing by Gulf Arab oil exporters to reach US$20 billion or more in 2016, with Saudi Arabia's rating cut by two notches to A-minus last month.

site_title: Anchor Resources prices IPO at S$0.25 per share
summary: Malaysian gold miner Anchor Resources priced its IPO at S$0.25 per share, raising S$7.2 million. The shares will trade on the Catalist board starting March 18 and represent 10.3% of the company's post-IPO capital. The net proceeds will be used to expand gold processing capacity, working capital, mine exploration, and business expansion.

site_title: Europe steps back in time to revive Iran ties
summary: The European Union is reviving talks with Iran to increase economic ties, 14 years after initial talks collapsed due to Iran's nuclear ambitions. EU foreign ministers will discuss a potential agreement on trade, investment, and political dialogue, despite concerns over human rights and Iran's role in Middle East conflicts. A planned visit by EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini to Tehran in April could be the first step towards a cooperation accord, which could help Iran join the World Trade Organization and regain business lost to China during sanctions.

site_title: BoE's Bailey says big banks are not too complex to supervise
summary: Britain's Deputy Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, has dismissed the idea that big banks are too complex to be fully understood, and therefore should hold more capital. Bailey disagrees with critics, including John Vickers, who argue that lenders should hold at least 20% capital due to complexity. Instead, Bailey advocates for a mix of capital buffers, proper risk management, supervision, and tools for winding down a bank when in trouble.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MyRepublic unveils proposed mobile and broadband plans, surprising the market. PropNex Realty achieved record gross commissions of over S$200 million in 2015. COE premiums rose across categories, while rentals of private homes and HDB flats fell in February. Noble Group seeks a US$2.5 billion borrowing base facility. Sembcorp Marine raised its stake in Norway's Gravifloat AS to 56%. The Straits Times Index rebounded 31.66 points to 2,810.43, driven by a rise in Dow futures and China's economic rebound.

site_title: Qatar Air says Pratt & Whitney engines not adequately tested
summary: Qatar Airways CEO Akbar Al Baker has criticized Pratt & Whitney for allegedly inadequate testing of its engines for the airline's Airbus A320neo aircraft. Qatar Airways had initially planned to receive the revamped aircraft but has refused to take delivery due to engine glitches. The airline has threatened to switch to alternative engine supplier CFM International. Al Baker expressed concerns about the engines' performance in Qatar's hot temperatures, putting the airline's operations at risk.

site_title: Malaysia central bank holds benchmark rate, no change to reserve ratio
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3.25% and kept the reserve requirement ratio unchanged at 3.5% as expected. The decision was made in the last policy meeting for Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz, who is set to step down on April 30. The central bank cited infrastructure development and capital spending as key drivers for investment and economic growth, despite a modest improvement in the external sector. The decision comes as the ringgit has strengthened about 4% this year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 3.25 per cent on Wednesday as expected, and kept unchanged a reserve requirement ratio that it cut in January.

site_title: Paris trains dry up as France faces nationwide labour reform protests
summary: France began nationwide strikes and protests against labor reforms, with train services into Paris suspended as students and labor unions joined forces against the reforms. The reforms aim to reduce job security but favor companies taking on permanent workers. Authorities anticipate 144 marches and protests nationwide, with President Francois Hollande closely monitoring the situation to avoid a repeat of massive student protests 10 years ago. The government has postponed the presentation of the reforms to cabinet and is in talks with unions to convince moderate ones to approve the measures.

site_title: Football: Blatter 'very surprised' by search of French federation offices
summary: Swiss Attorney General announced that French authorities seized documents from the French Football Federation (FFF) headquarters in connection with a Swiss criminal investigation targeting former FIFA President Sepp Blatter. The documents linked to Blatter's 2.0-million Swiss franc payment to UEFA's Michel Platini were seized. Blatter expressed surprise at the raid, stating he was "very surprised" by the action. The search is part of the investigation into Blatter's financial dealings.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher, helped by rise in Dow futures, China's rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 31.66 points to 2,810.43 on Wednesday, rebounding from a two-day drop. The index was led by Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, which gained after a 50-point rise in Dow futures, indicating a Wall Street rebound. China's stocks rebounded, halving their earlier loss, amid state-backed buying. Maybank Kim Eng reiterated its "sell" on Keppel Corp, citing a potential delay in the rigbuilding industry's recovery.

site_title: Prudential posts 15.3% rise in full-year net profit, raises dividend (Amended)
summary: British-based insurer Prudential plc reported a 15.3% rise in full-year net profit to £2.6 billion, driven by growth in its long-term businesses in Asia, the US, and the UK. The company declared a full-year dividend of 38.78 pence a share and announced a special dividend of 10 pence a share. Group operating profit rose 21.8% to £4 billion, with new business profit climbing 20.3% to £2.6 billion. CEO Mike Wells stated the results demonstrate progress toward 2017 growth objectives.

site_title: China: Stocks see winning streak end on commodity tumble
summary: China's stocks ended a six-session winning streak, plummeting over 1% as commodity prices tumbled, prompting profit-taking amid concerns about the country's economic health. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.2% and 1.3%, respectively, with resource and energy sectors suffering the most. Investors dumped heavyweights like Baoshan Iron & Steel Co and Sinopec on lower raw material and oil prices, as February trade data revealed a worse-than-expected slowdown.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closing at 1,686.35, down 1.51 points. The index saw 1.83 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.9 billion, with 446 gains and 341 losses.

site_title: Google's AI wins first match against Korean board-game champion
summary: Google's AI system, AlphaGo, has won its first match against Korean board-game champion Lee Sedol in a televised match in South Korea, showcasing the company's software's super-human status in a 2,500-year-old strategy contest. AlphaGo, developed by Google's London-based AI subsidiary DeepMind, uses a neural network to learn from experience and develop long-term strategies. This victory confirms the power of DeepMind's system, which had already beaten a European professional Go player in a previous match. The win paves the way for future applications of the technology in areas such as healthcare and other complex problems.

site_title: Japan's Abe suggests higher chance of tax hike delay
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe suggested a higher chance of delaying the planned sales tax hike to 10% in April, citing global economic headwinds. Abe stated that a global economic contraction or a Lehman-style market shock could force a rethink, potentially delaying the tax increase. The government has already delayed the tax hike once, and Abe reiterated that it would only proceed if the economy is not severely impacted. The move comes as Japan's economy is facing slow wage growth and a potential recession.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dip as resources shares tumble
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.1% to 19,996.26 points, dragged down by a 4.3% drop in resources and energy shares, as investors took profits from a recent rally amid concerns over China's slowing economic growth. The China Enterprises Index lost 0.8% to 8,441.48. This decline follows a robust rebound in Asian markets over the past month, with most sectors experiencing losses, except for mining and healthcare.

site_title: COE premiums increase across all categories in latest bidding exercise
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rose across all categories in the latest bidding exercise, with Category A cars increasing from S$43,000 to S$45,000, Category B from S$46,970 to S$47,604, and the open category from S$45,009 to S$48,002. Goods vehicles and buses also saw a hike, while motorcycles saw a slight increase. The COE premium increases reflect the ongoing demand for vehicles in Singapore, with the government seeking to balance supply and demand in the market.

site_title: CEO of Lippo Malls Reit manager to step down at end-April
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's CEO, Alvin Cheng, will step down at the end of April 2016 to pursue personal and professional interests. Viven Sitiabudi, executive director, will assume Cheng's responsibilities until a new CEO is appointed. Cheng joined the manager in 2010 and oversaw the expansion of capital sources, including a Euro Medium Term Note issuance program and securing a Baa3 investment grade rating from Moody's in 2015. The board is currently searching for a replacement within the sponsor and related companies.

site_title: Court of Appeal upholds decision that Susan Lim must pay S$235,000 in fees to legal assessor
summary: The Singapore Court of Appeal upheld a High Court decision that surgeon Susan Lim must pay S$235,000 in fees to a legal assessor involved in a disciplinary inquiry over her 2012 overcharging case. The court dismissed Lim's appeal that the amount was "manifestly excessive." The case stems from Lim's overcharging of the sister of the Queen of Brunei, leading to her guilty verdict in 2012.

site_title: French soccer body's offices searched, documents seized in Blatter investigation
summary: Swiss authorities searched the offices of France's soccer federation and seized documents in support of an investigation into former Fifa President Sepp Blatter, who is suspected of criminal mismanagement and misappropriation of funds. The investigation centers around a 2 million Swiss franc payment, with Blatter denying any wrongdoing. This is part of a larger Swiss probe into corruption allegations against Blatter, who has dismissed the claims.

site_title: European stock markets nudge higher at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose slightly on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and Paris' CAC 40 gaining around 0.1%. This follows a decline in world indices on Tuesday and Asian markets on Wednesday due to concerns over the weak global economy. The International Monetary Fund warned of an "increasingly dangerous" view that policymakers are out of ideas, urging governments to take action to prevent another global recession.

site_title: MyRepublic surprises market by unveiling proposed mobile plans
summary: MyRepublic, a fourth telco hopeful in Singapore, unveiled proposed mobile plans despite not yet winning the fourth telco licence. The plans include two data options for mobile customers ($8/month for 2GB, $80/month for unlimited) and two options for broadband customers ($6/month for 2GB, $60/month for unlimited). The move was seen as "premature" and aimed to gauge interest and gather feedback, according to the company.

site_title: Chinese pilot project could bring electronic tracking to all cars
summary: China has launched a pilot project in Shenzhen, issuing electronic IDs to 200,000 vehicles, which could eventually enable real-time tracking of all cars. The project uses radio-frequency identification and aims to combat fake license plates and improve smart traffic applications. If successful, it could pave the way for autonomous driving and targeted transport policies, such as taxes and fees based on fuel economy and driving habits. The project, if expanded nationwide, could also raise concerns over government surveillance.

site_title: Sharp's banks considering additional aid as part of Foxconn deal: source
summary: Sharp Corp, a Japanese display maker, is considering additional aid from its two main banks as part of a planned takeover by Taiwan's Foxconn. The banks plan to lower interest rates on a combined 700 billion yen in loans and extend the deadline for repayment of 510 billion yen in syndicated loans. They may also establish an additional commitment line for Sharp to restructure under Foxconn. The plan has not been officially announced, and representatives for the banks declined to comment.

site_title: Australia: Shares resume rally, NZ hits record on bargain hunting
summary: Australian shares rose nearly 1% to reach a 2-month high, closing at 5,157.2, while New Zealand stocks hit a record at 6,457.3. Investors sought bargains despite weaker oil prices, snapping a six-day winning streak for Australian shares. New Zealand's record-breaking streak extended to a fifth day.

site_title: 'Fifth Beatle' George Martin dies at 90: Ringo Starr
summary: Legendary British music producer George Martin, known as the "Fifth Beatle," has died at 90. Martin signed the Beatles after hearing their 1962 demo and played a crucial role in their success. He produced their first single "Love Me Do" and composed scores for films "A Hard Day's Night" and "Yellow Submarine." Martin went on to work with other notable artists and recorded solo albums for Paul McCartney. Ringo Starr and John Lennon's son Sean paid tribute to Martin, describing him as "so essential to the band's success" and expressing his sadness at the loss.

site_title: China plans to unify corporate bill market
summary: China plans to unify its corporate bills market, aiming to reduce trading costs and risks through an electronic system, according to Vice Governor Pan Gongsheng.
