This move follows a reported 3.8 billion yuan loss by Agricultural Bank of China due to a bills of exchange scam. The central bank's work plan includes building a unified national bill market.

site_title: Hedge funds back off bets on China devaluation
summary: Hedge funds that bet on a sharp devaluation of China's yuan have largely retreated from their positions, leaving only ultra-bearish investors holding long-term bets. Following Beijing's aggressive intervention to prop up the currency, many US players made money betting against China, with some cutting exposure or walking away from the trade by the Lunar New Year holiday. Derivatives pricing for the yuan has fallen back to levels not seen since November, suggesting China may be holding the line on the currency.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to one-week low; stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won fell to a one-week low due to concerns over a slowing Chinese economy, but the Bank of Korea's upcoming policy meeting prevented aggressive dollar sales. The won dropped 0.8% to 1,216.2 per dollar, while South Korean shares rose 0.4% to 1,952.95 points. Investors are cautious amid US-EU trade tensions, but the Bank of Korea's policy meeting may provide some stability.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on global economy fears
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for the third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index declining 0.84% to 16,642.20, amid fears over global economic growth. Disappointing Chinese trade data and concerns about US-EU trade tensions contributed to the downturn. Automakers Toyota and Nissan also dropped into negative territory, with Toyota's index falling 0.73% and Nissan's down 1.25%.

site_title: M1 unveils remote elderly-care monitoring solution
summary: M1, a Singapore telecommunications operator, has launched its Smart Activity Monitoring Service (SAMS), a remote elderly-care monitoring solution. The service, available to M1 fibre customers, offers caregivers a one-stop solution with equipment installation, connectivity, and customer support. It provides real-time activity monitoring and data analytics tools to help caregivers identify trends and patterns, priced at S$14.66 per month. Additional motion sensors are available at S$103.80 each, with a one-time sign-up and installation fee of S$214.

site_title: Palm oil prices seen hitting 3,000 rgt as El Nino curbs output: analyst
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures are expected to rise nearly 20% to around 3,000 ringgit a tonne due to El Nino's impact on production in Indonesia and Malaysia. Global palm oil production is forecast to decline by almost 3 million tonnes in the year to Sept. 16, with Malaysian production expected to drop by 1.5 million tonnes. Analysts predict prices will continue to climb until they reach a level that stifles demand from price-sensitive importers like India.

site_title: Chinese hunt for property bargains from Dubai to Manchester
summary: Chinese property investors are expanding their reach beyond traditional hotspots, seeking bargains and higher returns in emerging markets like Dubai, Manchester, and other global cities. In 2015, Chinese buyers pumped in $463 million in Dubai, and their institutional investments in New York and Sydney reached $6 billion and $4 billion, respectively. Returns on investment in Dubai are as high as 7.2%, compared to 2.8% in Hong Kong. Chinese investors are also targeting student housing, particularly in cities like Manchester, where rental yields and capital growth are around 8% and 10%, respectively.

site_title: PropNex clocks in record commissions in 2015 down-market
summary: PropNex Realty achieved record gross commissions of over S$200 million in 2015, despite a down-market, with 40,000 transactions and a 22% increase in volumes from 2014. This success is attributed to its expanded project marketing team.

site_title: Oil prices rise as defaults expected to cut supplies
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose to nearly $40 per barrel on Wednesday, driven by expected defaults that could cut global production. Traders cited a 60,000 barrels-per-day drop in cumulative shut-in production and a projected 8.19 million barrels-per-day output in the US in 2017. Analysts warned that a global glut would take time to shrink, despite a 40% increase in oil prices over 2016 lows, as energy demand slows and concerns over China's economic slowdown cap price gains.

site_title: Gold falls with euro ahead of likely ECB easing
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,254.26 an ounce ahead of the European Central Bank's expected policy easing, with investors taking profits after its 13-month high last week. Despite this, analysts expect gold to rebound in the medium term, with potential prices reaching $1,300 or $1,400 by the second quarter. The ECB is expected to cut its deposit rate and expand its asset-buying program at its meeting on Thursday, supporting gold prices.

site_title: Bank of France cuts Q1 GDP growth forecast to 0.3%
summary: The Bank of France has revised its Q1 GDP growth forecast to 0.3% from 0.4%, marking a downward revision of 0.1 percentage points. This would be a slight increase from the 0.2% growth in the final quarter of last year. The revision was made in the Bank of France's monthly business sentiment survey, which showed a decline in industrial sector morale to 98 in February, the lowest since May 2011.

site_title: Trump sweeps Republican primaries in Mississippi, Michigan; Clinton loses out in Michigan
summary: Donald Trump won the Michigan and Mississippi Republican presidential primaries, solidifying his control of the party's nomination race. On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders upset Hillary Clinton in Michigan. Trump secured 37% of the vote in Michigan and 48% in Mississippi, while Clinton won Mississippi with the support of black voters. Trump's victories exposed Clinton's weaknesses and strengthened his front-runner status, while Sanders' win in Michigan exposed Clinton's political weaknesses. Trump emphasized unity among Republicans and vowed to bring manufacturing jobs back to Michigan, appealing to blue-collar voters.

site_title: Cathay Pacific 2015 net profit soars 90% on low oil prices
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a 90% increase in net profit for 2015, reaching HK$6 billion, thanks to huge savings on fuel due to low oil prices. Fuel costs plummeted 37.8% compared to the previous year. However, this was partially offset by a widened hedging loss of HK$8.47 billion. The airline attributed the surge to low fuel prices, with Chairman John Slosar stating that the business benefited from the fuel price drop.

site_title: Rents of Singapore private homes, HDB flats fall in February: SRX
summary: RENTALS of private homes and HDB flats in Singapore fell month-on-month in February 2016, according to SRX Property's flash estimates. The private segment dropped 0.7% and the overall rental index for non-landed private homes fell 5% year-on-year. HDB flat rents also declined, with a 0.9% drop in February and a 3.7% year-on-year decline. The volume of rental transactions for both private and HDB flats decreased, with 17.5% and 20.1% declines respectively.

site_title: Petronas says moving towards FID on Canada LNG project
summary: Malaysian oil and gas firm Petronas is moving forward with a final investment decision on its proposed liquefied natural gas project in Canada, despite a threat to walk away. Petronas will review the final environmental report to determine its impact on cost and schedule. The project's commerciality and market outlook will also be considered. The Canadian federal Environment Minister is set to release her final decision later this month. A draft environmental assessment found the project would not cause major ecological damage but would harm harbor porpoise populations and impact climate change.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on profit-taking, tracks overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.7% to 8,600.69, following declines in overseas markets and profit-taking after closing at a four-month high. The central bank warned of limited growth due to "downside" risks to global economic growth, while foreign investors continued to buy shares. The electronics and financials subindexes also fell, with the Taiwan dollar firming to T$32.904 per US dollar.

site_title: Saudi job creation dries up as oil price slump hits broader economy
summary: Saudi Arabia is facing a severe job market due to an oil price slump, with public spending being slashed and growth forecasts for the private sector being gloomy. The country's plans for economic reform, including replacing "jobs for life" in the state bureaucracy with new careers in the private sector, may be hindered by the current economic downturn. As a result, first-time job seekers face a tough market, with 400,000 graduates competing for jobs at "employment week" fairs. The economic slump is expected to continue into 2016, posing a significant challenge to the country's economic reform efforts.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's plans for economic reform foresee winding down 'jobs for life' in an inefficient state bureaucracy and replacing them with new careers in a dynamic private sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.570 points to 1681.310. Volume was 22.7 million lots worth RM10.3 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 85 to 67.

summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Tim Leissner, has been subpoenaed in a US probe into the Malaysia-based 1MDB fund. The probe, led by the FBI's New York office, is investigating whether funds were embezzled by politically connected individuals in Malaysia. Leissner, who championed a series of bond sales for 1MDB, is now cooperating with the Justice Department's efforts to gather information. His role in the fund and potential wrongdoing are unclear, and Goldman Sachs is reviewing its own involvement in the matter.

site_title: New Zealand warns dairy faces 'tough' outlook
summary: New Zealand's dairy industry faces a "serious or extreme" scenario due to falling prices, with the country's largest dairy exporter, Fonterra, slashing farmgate prices by NZ$4.75 per kilogram of milk solids. Finance Minister Bill English downplayed the impact on the broader economy, stating it would not have a significant effect. He ruled out a government-backed rescue package for dairy farmers, saying they can weather the storm on their own. The opposition Labour Party criticized the government's inaction, calling for help for struggling farmers.

site_title: Oil prices stable as falling US output countered by ongoing global glut
summary: Oil prices remained stable due to falling US production, but were capped by doubts over a global output freeze. US WTI crude futures rose to $36.51 per barrel, while International Brent crude futures traded at $39.62 per barrel. Despite China's economic slowdown and record crude imports, traders expect demand to continue falling, and a coordinated output freeze is unlikely. Analysts, including Goldman Sachs, believe it will take time for the market to rebalance, suggesting that higher oil prices may not be warranted.

site_title: Big US banks to take on tech rivals with instant payments
summary: US banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and US Bancorp, are launching an instant payment system called clearXchange, allowing customers to transfer funds in real-time using mobile phones. This move aims to compete with tech companies like PayPal and Facebook, which have already offered similar services. The system, which is controlled by the banks, can transfer funds instantly, whereas current systems typically take 1-3 days. The initiative is crucial for banks to cater to the younger generation and prevent them from switching to fintech startups.

images.alt_text: Depositors at some of the largest US banks are finally going to get the chance to do something quick and simple: send money to another person's account instantaneously by mobile phone.

site_title: Brazil's Marcelo Odebrecht gets 19 years in jail in Carwash

Odebrecht, CEO of Odebrecht SA, was found guilty of paying bribes totaling $39.8 million to Petrobras executives and politicians. The scandal has implicated dozens of businessmen and politicians, including former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who faces allegations of corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Disney announces US$75m loss on 'The Finest Hours'
summary: Disney reports a US$75 million loss on its film "The Finest Hours," which has grossed US$40.5 million worldwide since its January release. site_title: Singapore shares open lower amid concerns over China slowdown

site_title: Seoul: Stocks defensive, won falls on China concern
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.6% to 1,214.3 US dollars on Wednesday, amid concerns over China's slowing economy. site_title: Traders strike gold in champagne caps
summary: Traders in champagne caps have found a lucrative market, with some caps selling for up to 10,000 euros each. The caps, which date back to the 19th century, are highly sought after by collectors due to their rarity, artwork, and historical significance. Limited edition caps and those with unique designs can fetch high prices, with some rare caps selling for tens of thousands of euros. The market is driven by supply and demand, with some traders, like Pascal Dorme, organizing cap fairs to connect buyers and sellers.

summary: Asian markets retreated on Wednesday as China's weak exports data reignited fears about the global economy. site_title: HK, Shanghai: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.56% to 19,898.74, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index tumbled 2.14% to 2,839.41. The decline follows sharp losses in Europe and New York, driven by concerns over the global economy.

site_title: Real-time trackers aim to avoid repeat of MH370 mystery
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has adopted new requirements to prevent a repeat of the MH370 mystery. The new measures require aircraft to have tracking devices that can transmit location information at least once a minute when in trouble, providing real-time updates. This follows the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 two years ago, which vanished on March 8, 2014, with 239 passengers and crew onboard, leaving relatives still seeking answers. The new requirements aim to improve safety and provide more information in case of an emergency.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set for more declines amid oil drop, yen holds jump
summary: Stocks in Asia are expected to decline amid a drop in oil prices and a weakening yen. site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares edge higher, NZ stocks hits news record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.26% to 5,123.0, following a 0.68% drop the previous day, as traders shrugged off Wall Street pressure and weaker oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also hit a fresh all-time high of 6,456.44, despite some losers, including Skellerup and NZ Refinery.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to launch phone upgrade scheme in South Korea
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to launch a phone upgrade programme in South Korea, allowing customers to switch to a new premium handset every 12 months. The Galaxy S7s offer incremental upgrades, predicting weaker sales in the first year compared to last year's Galaxy S6s.

site_title: SilkAir offers seven direct Singapore-Okinawa flights in June
summary: SilkAir is launching seven direct charter flights from Singapore to Okinawa, Japan from June 1-25, 2016, reducing travel time to 5 hours and 15 minutes. summary: China can accept slightly lower GDP growth as long as employment remains stable and incomes continue to rise, said Deputy Director Huang Shouhong. This suggests China's leaders are prepared to tolerate some slowdown in growth to maintain stability.

site_title: UK health service faces 'looming crisis' over family doctors
summary: The UK's National Health Service faces a "looming crisis" due to a shortage of family doctors, with more experienced doctors leaving the profession and not enough new GPs being trained. site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on yen, Wall St losses

Toshiba's shares fell 3.7% to 200.7 yen after the report.

site_title: Report Queen Elizabeth 'backs Brexit' denied
summary: A British tabloid, The Sun, reported that Queen Elizabeth II is in favor of the UK leaving the European Union, citing an anonymous source. site_title: Italy, France want to create European industrial champions: Hollande

This cooperation aims to increase weight in the market and create significant companies in these areas.

site_title: North Korea's Kim says country has miniaturised nuclear warhead: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un claimed the country has successfully miniaturized nuclear warheads to be mounted on ballistic missiles, according to KCNA news agency. summary: European shares fell to a one-week low on Tuesday, driven by weak Chinese trade data that pressured industrial metals prices and the mining sector. summary: US bank Citigroup warned of a 15% drop in trading revenues in the first quarter, citing market troubles and global economic worries. Citigroup shares dropped 2.9% as the bank prepares to report first-quarter earnings on April 15.

Blue Origin is also working on rocket engines for major launch companies, demonstrating growing confidence in its business plans.

site_title: Michael Bloomberg aborts US presidential run
summary: Michael Bloomberg has decided not to run for president as an independent in the 2016 election, citing his concerns that a three-way race could lead to the election of Donald Trump, whom he believes would endanger the country. Bloomberg had been quietly preparing for a run, but ultimately abandoned his campaign due to the slim chances of success and the prospect of a deadlock in the Electoral College. His decision brings clarity to the presidential race, which has seen Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders gain momentum.

site_title: Oil prices drop on weak China data, high supplies
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling $1.40 to $36.50 a barrel, and Brent North Sea oil losing $1.19 to $39.65 a barrel. Weak Chinese trade data, including a 25.4% decline in exports and a 13.8% drop in imports, and skepticism about output limits from major producers, contributed to the decline. Analysts say the market needs proof of concrete action to push prices higher, citing a Goldman Sachs report that warned of a premature surge in commodity prices.

site_title: Volkswagen gets new US subpoena over pollution cheating
summary: US justice authorities have issued a new subpoena to Volkswagen over its emissions cheating, based on the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act. The government is seeking information on "clean car" tax breaks and rebates granted to customers who bought diesel cars with illegal pollution devices. Volkswagen is facing multiple investigations in the US and other countries, potentially leading to tens of billions of dollars in fines and owner compensation. The company's US arm declined to comment on the new subpoena, citing ongoing discussions with regulators.

images.alt_text: US justice authorities have issued a new subpoena to Volkswagen over its emissions cheating under laws governing bank fraud, a person close to the matter said on Tuesday.

site_title: Yen holds two-day gain as China slowdown signs spur haven bid
summary: The Japanese yen gained 2 days in a row against most major currencies due to investors seeking safe-haven assets amid China's economic slowdown signs. China's exports and imports declined more than forecast, with exports shrinking more than economists expected. This led to weaker US stock markets and lower bond yields, driving the yen higher. The currency is now trading in a range of 111 to 114.50 against the US dollar.

site_title: Maria Sharapova's business empire in doping turmoil
summary: Maria Sharapova's business empire is in turmoil after she admitted to failing a doping test, testing positive for Meldonium. Sponsors Nike, Porsche, and TAG Heuer have distanced themselves from her, risking a potential four-year ban that could collapse her marketing empire. Sharapova, who earns $30 million annually, has estimated a fortune of $200 million. Her attorney claims mitigating circumstances may result in a lesser penalty, but the Russian government has thrown its support behind her, with sports minister Vitaly Mutko calling for her return to the court.

site_title: Pharma crusader takes India's drug regulators to court
summary: Indian whistleblower Dinesh Thakur is taking the country's drug regulators to court, accusing them of failing to enforce rules on drug safety in India's $15 billion industry. Thakur, known for exposing dangerous practices in the generic drug industry in 2013, claims lax regulation led to potentially harmful medicines being sold without proper approvals. The case, filed as a Public Interest Litigation, aims to create a framework for drug recall and a commission to examine faulty approvals, with no penalties sought.

site_title: Singapore prime homes a good buy now: JLL
summary: A JLL report suggests that buying prime homes in Singapore is a good investment opportunity, given the significant correction in prices over the last four years. Prime residential prices have fallen 20% from their peak in 2011, making them 20% cheaper than other global cities like London and New York. Despite loan curbs and tax burdens, the cost of property ownership in Singapore is comparable to other global cities. The report predicts that prime residential rents will rise in 2016 as supply becomes increasingly limited, and developers may seek to sell 1,000 units in bulk in 2016-2018.

site_title: Ex-JPMorgan banker gets 5 years in prison for embezzlement
summary: A former JPMorgan Chase investment adviser, Michael Oppenheim, was sentenced to 5 years in prison for embezzling over $20 million from clients' funds. Oppenheim, 49, pleaded guilty to defrauding clients of $22 million over 7 years, misusing their funds to trade stocks and options. He must pay $20 million in restitution. Oppenheim, who worked at JPMorgan for 13 years, was fired in 2015 and argued that addiction to gambling drove his conduct.

site_title: Trump already a tainted name in Indonesia after Muslim ban remarks
summary: Indonesian villagers and lawmakers are outraged over Donald Trump's comments on Muslims, calling for a ban on his businesses in the country due to potential strained relations with the Muslim world. An online petition has garnered over 45,000 signatures, and some lawmakers have threatened to restrict US trade and investment if Trump becomes president. Trump's expansion efforts in Indonesia, including a six-star hotel in West Java, could be threatened by the growing hostility towards him, with some officials warning it could be a "black shadow" for his business.

site_title: Venturing overseas - what more can Singapore do on the tax front?
summary: Singapore businesses face challenges when expanding abroad, including navigating complex local tax and regulatory regimes, dealing with political instability, and understanding foreign taxes. To encourage internationalisation, the government has introduced the International Growth Scheme (IGS) with a 10% concessionary tax rate for five years on qualifying incremental income. The government may also consider extending time apportionment of employment income, granting special tax deductions for interest or related borrowing costs, and exempting foreign-sourced income from the Asean Economic Community. These tweaks aim to lessen the worries of businesses and help grow Singapore's external economy.

site_title: Forest City's slew of incentives seen as a big plus
summary: Singapore's Forest City, a joint venture project between China's Country Garden and Malaysia's Johor state government, has received multiple tax incentives, including a duty-free zone, making it more feasible in a depressed market. The incentives are seen as creating a "two-tier" market for developers and investors, with Chinese developers operating on a different level due to massive investments. The project is expected to attract investments of RM170-RM175 billion by 2035, with phase one of its residential segment set to launch in Singapore in the first quarter.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on lower oil, weak China data
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones shedding 109.85 points (0.64%) to 16,964.10, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes dropped 1.12% and 1.26%, respectively. The decline was attributed to lower oil prices and weak Chinese trade data, which saw exports sink 25.4% and imports drop 13.8%. Energy shares, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, fell, while Citigroup tumbled 3.7% after reporting declining trading revenues.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc advance on downbeat China data
summary: The yen and Swiss franc advanced against the US dollar due to downbeat Chinese trade data, which showed a 25.4% decline in February exports and a 13.8% drop in imports. The US dollar fell 0.4% to 112.95 yen, while the Swiss franc rose 0.15% against both the dollar and the euro. Investors are seeking safe-haven currencies amid economic uncertainty and volatility.

site_title: Fighting capital flows in the orbit of the ECB
summary: Three European non-eurozone central banks, Denmark, Sweden, and Switzerland, are adopting unorthodox monetary policies to combat capital flows and achieve price stability. Switzerland has the least room for manoeuvre due to large foreign reserves and political resistance, while Denmark and Sweden have shown more flexibility with negative policy rates and quantitative easing. Despite these efforts, the central banks face challenges in achieving their long-term goals, including the risk of hyperinflation and decreased bank profitability.

site_title: Iron ore giants Vale, Fortescue plan tie-up
summary: Vale SA, the world's No 1 iron ore miner, and Fortescue Metals Group, the No 4 iron ore miner, are in talks for a potential tie-up, with Vale considering a minority stake in Fortescue. The deal aims to create efficiency and supply chain consistency in China, where the two companies would blend their iron ore to match the quality of rival Rio Tinto. The proposal comes as iron ore prices stage a recovery to eight-month highs, with Fortescue's shares rising nearly 7% after the announcement.

site_title: Asia investor activism set to grow after BlackRock public campaign
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, voted against a deal by Hong Kong firm G-Resources Group to sell an Indonesian gold mine, citing lack of confidence in the company's use of proceeds in investors' best interests. This rare public campaign revs up investor activism in Asia, following a surge in 2015. As a result, BlackRock urged other shareholders to follow suit, signaling a growing trend of investor activism in the region.

site_title: Carney says it's better that UK stays in EU
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney has stated that the UK's financial sector and economy would perform better if the nation remained in the European Union. Despite claiming neutrality, Carney expressed support for Premier David Cameron's new EU deal, which aims to achieve financial stability and stable inflation. In the event of a Brexit vote, Carney warned that the City of London could lose business and that some firms might move out of the city.

site_title: Transocean again defers rig delivery from Keppel Fels
summary: Transocean has deferred the delivery of five jack-up rigs being built by Keppel Fels from 2018-2020 to 2020, with deliveries now set for two and three-month intervals starting early 2020. The move comes as Transocean faces a declining credit rating and reduced upstream capital spending. The rig building contract is worth $1.1 billion, with Keppel Fels to be compensated by the client for the deferment. This is the second deferment for the project, following the original staggered delivery dates of 2016-2017.

site_title: Prepare for rough weather ahead
summary: The offshore supply vessel (OSV) sector faces a depressed state due to low crude oil prices and oversupply of vessels. The industry has seen a 38% increase in OSV inventory from 2008 to 2015, while rig counts rose only 5%. Charter rates have dropped 50-60% and utilization is down by up to 40%. Experts forecast the OSV market to be oversupplied for several years, weighing on rates and utilization. To survive, OSV operators are focusing on cutting costs and improving efficiency, with those with strong balance sheets expected to thrive.

site_title: Staying optimistic despite challenges
summary: The Asia Pacific Maritime (APM) exhibition and conference, taking place next week, aims to provide a platform for industry players to network and learn from veteran shipowners who have survived downturns since the 1990s. Despite the current challenging market, Reed Exhibitions is optimistic, expecting 15,000 visitors from the region. One speaker, Khalid Hashim, managing director of Thai-based Precious Shipping Ltd, will share his experiences on surviving downturns, highlighting the cyclical nature of the business and the importance of resilience.

site_title: Weak demand causes China's Feb exports and imports to tumble
summary: China's exports plummeted by 25.4% in February, its largest monthly drop in nearly seven years, while imports fell by 13.8%. The decline adds to Beijing's economic woes as the country struggles to implement reforms and avoid a sharp slowdown. The weak demand is a significant concern for policymakers, raising pressure on them to address the issue.

site_title: Microsoft opens its corporate data software SQL to Linux
summary: Microsoft has made its corporate data software SQL available on Linux, a move aimed at expanding its market reach into the Linux-based computer market. CEO Satya Nadella sees this as an opportunity to increase Microsoft's presence in the industry. This decision marks a shift for Microsoft, which has previously built walls between its products and the rest of the industry. The move is expected to make Microsoft's database software more accessible to users running Linux operating systems.

site_title: KKR-backed clothing retailer SMCP files for IPO in France
summary: KKR-backed French clothing retailer SMCP has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) after doubling its sales over three years. Revenue surged 33% to 675 million euros, with same-store sales up 11%. The company plans to expand internationally, particularly in China, the US, and the UK, with ambitions to become a global leader in accessible luxury. SMCP may be valued at over 1 billion euros in the IPO, with Shandong Ruyi Group emerging as the preferred bidder.

site_title: OSIM offer sparks buzz over other possible candidates for delisting
summary: OSIM International's privatisation bid has sparked speculation about other companies potentially delisting due to gloomy market conditions and regulatory compliance costs. Analysts identify factors such as low valuations, high shareholder control, and substantial cash reserves as increasing the likelihood of a privatisation bid. Household names in the consumer sector, oil-and-gas sector, and property industry are being considered, including companies like Qian Hu, BreadTalk, and Banyan Tree. Experts warn that delisting can be a sign of healthy liquidity and M&A activity, potentially benefiting the market's vibrancy.

site_title: Xpress Holdings founder KK Fong to step down
summary: KK Fong, founder and COO of Xpress Holdings, is stepping down after 30 years to pursue new business interests. He will hand over the reins to a new management team led by chairman Ma Wei Dong on March 31. Fong plans to start a new venture in China and review his private investments. Xpress Holdings, which has evolved from a traditional printing company to one incorporating new media and digital technology, will continue to raise the quality of its print services and products under the new management team.

site_title: STI falls for second consecutive day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 44.74 points, or 1.6%, to 2,778.77, marking its second consecutive drop, amidst continued volatility in the local bourse. Weakness in Dow futures and sharp falls in Japan and Hong Kong are cited as contributing factors. Despite this, some stocks, such as OSIM International, saw gains, and analysts expect a rebound in the market, driven by Singapore's safe-haven status and potential monetary stimulus from the European Central Bank.

site_title: Singapore p2p online lending sector may see first loan default
summary: Singapore's peer-to-peer online lending sector may see its first loan default, with Capital Match reporting a troubled customer in the construction business. The company, which offers loans between $50,000 to $200,000, has registered a rise in "payment issues" during the Chinese New Year period. MoolahSense and Funding Societies claim their loans are at no risk of default, but Capital Match's director says a loan is likely to result in a default out of 50 loans. The p2p lending sector is largely unregulated and offers high-risk, double-digit interest rates.

site_title: Noble Group's bonds recover as commodity distress eases
summary: Noble Group's bonds have recovered to 60.1 cents on the dollar after commodity distress eased, boosting refinancing plans. The company's shares have surged 60% and bonds have rallied 44-43% as commodity prices rise 9% from a January low. Noble Group's CEO Yusuf Alireza is under pressure to refinance loans due next month, with discussions with banks on extending a revolving facility "well advanced." However, some analysts warn that credit fundamentals remain weak and caution on the company's creditworthiness.

site_title: Even retirees should leave market trading to the pros
summary: A 75-year-old retired engineer, Elmer Naples, initially managed his own retirement portfolio but switched to a fee-only financial planner after experiencing market volatility. Naples tried various investments, including stocks, mutual funds, and precious metals, but found it overwhelming. He now advises others to leave market trading to professionals, citing the potential for costly mistakes. Naples' experience highlights the importance of seeking expert guidance for managing retirement portfolios.

site_title: Trump phenomenon signifies shift to personality-based politics
summary: The rise of Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election signifies a shift towards personality-based politics, where candidates rely on their own skills and resources for electoral success rather than party backing. This change, which began with the expansion of primaries in the 20th century, has led to a decrease in party dominance and an increase in campaigning skills over governing skills. The shift has also resulted in a more self-absorbed climate, where party discipline suffers and bipartisan compromises become harder to craft.

site_title: Global powers are unprepared for the next emergency
summary: Global powers at the G-20 meeting in Shanghai failed to reach substantial decisions, highlighting deep divisions on fiscal and monetary policy. Concerns about the effectiveness of ultra-low interest rates and the need for more government spending exposed tensions among policymakers. Bank of England governor Mark Carney criticized his Bank of Japan counterpart, and Germany's finance minister dismissed the idea of debt-financed growth. The meeting's outcome suggests that the world's biggest countries are poorly prepared to deal with the next emergency, which could come sooner rather than later.

site_title: How China's rich are shaping national policymaking
summary: China's richest entrepreneurs, comprising 4% of the National People's Congress delegates, are increasingly influencing policymaking. They have successfully advocated for initiatives such as the "Internet Plus" strategy and Big Data promotion. The government has taken notice, with President Xi Jinping actively engaging with top entrepreneurs on international trips. For the first time, private entrepreneurs are actively involved in shaping the national five-year plan, reflecting the government's growing confidence in the private sector's role in driving growth. This development marks a significant shift in the balance of power between the Communist Party and private business leaders.

site_title: Ontario's small producers using old-school ways to beat oil rout
summary: Ontario's small oil producers, like Charlie Fairbank, are bucking the trend of declining oil prices by using century-old technology to extract oil from the ground. Despite a 14% increase in crude production this year, Ontario's total output remains low at 1,214 barrels a day. Low royalty rates and proximity to major fuel markets help keep costs low, making it possible for small producers to remain profitable. Experts predict that Ontario's oil output could reach 5,000 barrels a day, driven by the potential of the Utica shale and low oil prices.

site_title: Bulk ships are dying faster and younger this year
summary: Bulk ships are dying faster and younger this year, with 29 Capesize vessels scrapped so far, compared to 93 in 2015 and 25 in 2014. The Baltic Dry Index has plummeted to 290 points, its lowest level in 30 years, due to China's slowing demand for iron ore and coal. Prices for both commodities have dropped by more than 60% from their 2011 highs, prompting shipowners to park vessels in lay-up areas, with some paying up to $36,000 per month to keep them afloat.

site_title: Aero Express Logistics horizons widen with acquisition by MNX
summary: Aero Express Logistics, a Singapore-based third-party logistics provider, has been acquired by global player MNX Global Logistics. The deal, terms of which were not disclosed, aims to expand MNX's aviation services and provide AEL's customers with access to MNX's worldwide network and technology platforms. Founded in 2003, AEL specializes in the aviation and aerospace sector, with 80-90% of its business coming from the industry. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to drive global growth and is expected to expedite AEL's growth.

site_title: Italy's famed wine region threatened by wild game
summary: Italy's Chianti wine region is threatened by wild game, with reports of brutal and destructive attacks on vineyards. The region's prized vineyards could be affected for hundreds of thousands of years if the problem is not addressed. Local authorities are considering measures such as fencing to protect the vineyards, but the extent of the problem and the effectiveness of these measures remain unclear.

site_title: BAIC to raise 3b yuan for its electric-car business
summary: BAIC Group plans to raise 3 billion yuan (S$638.3 million) for its electric-car business by selling shares on Shanghai's exchange for emerging firms. Beijing Electric Vehicle Co, 60% controlled by BAIC, has attracted investments from tech companies like Le Holdings. The financing round aims to support the company's electric-car business and is seen as a strategic move to expand its presence in the market.

site_title: Shipyards likely to see more asset impairments: UOB-KH
summary: Shipyards in the Singapore offshore and marine (O&M) sector are likely to report further asset impairments due to increased risks, according to a UOB-KayHian sector update. This comes despite the sector making $2.2 billion in loss provisions in 2015. Shipyards are considered more vulnerable than asset operators, suggesting a worsening outlook for the industry.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker to 1MDB fund subpoenaed in US probe: sources
summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Tim Leissner, has been subpoenaed by US authorities in a probe into the Malaysian state investment fund 1MDB. Leissner championed a series of bond sales that raised $6.5 billion for the fund, generating above-average fees for Goldman. The investigation, led by the FBI's New York office, is looking into whether funds were embezzled from 1MDB by politically connected people in Malaysia. Leissner's attorney declined to comment, and it is unclear what information he might be able to provide to the US Justice Department's kleptocracy asset recovery unit.

images.alt_text: MAS said Mr Leissner was based in S'pore from 2002 to 2011, and moved to Hong Kong in November 2011.

site_title: DBS, OCBC preferred by women as employers
summary: Women in Singapore prefer working for DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, ranking them fourth and ninth among the top 10 ideal Asian financial services employers, respectively. The survey by eFinancialCareers found that DBS compares favorably in areas such as work-life balance and employee benefits, which appeal more to female finance professionals. In contrast, DBS lags behind in salary perception, which is more important to male finance professionals. The survey of over 6,500 finance professionals globally highlighted competitive salary as the top criterion for selecting an ideal employer in Asia.

site_title: Art scene in Bangkok blooms under junta rule
summary: Bangkok's art scene is thriving under junta rule, with artists using their work as a form of resistance against censorship and repression. Despite the military's efforts to silence critics, a wave of artistic expression has emerged, with galleries and exhibitions popping up across the city. Artists such as Jirawut Ueasungkomsate and Richard Mead are using their work to comment on the government's actions and the impunity enjoyed by state officials. The art scene is seen as a vital space for free expression and a means of promoting dissent, with many artists believing that it is essential for a functioning society.

site_title: China needs to step up economic restructuring, not just growth
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang projected an economic growth of 6.5-7% in 2016 and 6.5% for the next five years, which some economists find ambitious and potentially too high. This growth rate is lower than China's historical standards, suggesting that economic restructuring and reform, which the country needs, may receive less priority. China's economic restructuring is crucial, but the projection may indicate a shift in focus from growth to reform.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE-HT) announced a rights issue to raise S$238.6 million, primarily for Crowne Plaza Changi Airport extension. Raffles Medical Group (RMG) was upgraded to a "buy" rating with a target price of S$5.39, citing its positioning in the Chinese market and potential for growth. RMG's conservative approach to expansion and superior operational efficiency were highlighted as key strengths, with 23% target price upside potential.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings faces a claim from Daewoo Securities Co in South Korea over an alleged breach of an underwriting agreement from 2010, seeking 1 billion Korean won (S$1.15 million) in damages. The company plans to defend the claim and seek legal advice. Meanwhile, CATALIST-LISTED China Yongsheng, being taken private at S$0.032 a share, has appointed KGI Fraser Securities as its independent financial adviser.

site_title: Sharapova nailed in anti-doping test; Nike suspends deal
summary: Maria Sharapova, world's highest-paid female athlete, has tested positive for banned drug meldonium at the Australian Open. The tennis anti-doping programme confirmed the positive test, which occurred on January 26, and Sharapova will be suspended provisionally pending a ruling. Nike has suspended its deal with Sharapova, citing the investigation. Sharapova claims she took the drug for health reasons, including frequent illnesses and magnesium deficiency, and was unaware of its ban. She may face a minimal penalty, but her suspension is a major blow to the women's game, with her future playing career uncertain.

site_title: Chevron's mega Australia gas project starts production
summary: Chevron's $52 billion Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) project off Australia's north-west coast has started production, with the first cargo expected to ship next week. The project, a joint venture with Shell and ExxonMobil, is one of the world's largest natural gas plants and aims to drive long-term growth and create shareholder value. Chevron sees attractive long-term fundamentals for LNG, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, and aims to position itself as a major LNG supplier by 2020.

site_title: Canon, Fujifilm lead as Toshiba gets set to pick suitor for medical unit: sources
summary: Toshiba is set to choose a preferred bidder for its medical equipment unit, with Canon Inc and Fujifilm Holdings Corp considered front-runners. The two Japanese imaging firms have submitted bids of over 600 billion yen (S$7.3 billion), surpassing other potential bidders. Toshiba's executive meeting to select a suitor is scheduled for Wednesday. The sale of the medical unit is seen as a strategic move for Toshiba to divest underperforming assets and focus on core businesses.

site_title: India drops pension tax plan after backlash
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government dropped a plan to tax pension withdrawals after widespread backlash from salaried workers, who feared it would undermine the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party's prospects in upcoming state elections. The proposal, made by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, would have taxed lump-sum withdrawals exceeding 40% of a retirement pot unless the sum was reinvested in an annuity. The government's decision came after a strong outcry from workers, leading to a last-minute U-turn on the plan.

site_title: Global group targets 25% cut in deficient audits
summary: A global audit quality group, including Singapore, aims to reduce the number of deficient audits by at least 25% within the next four years. The International Forum of Independent Audit Regulators' (IFIAR) initiative follows a 2015 survey showing 43% of audits of listed public interest entities had inspection findings. The survey highlighted deficiencies in internal control testing, fair value measurement, and risk assessment. The global audit firms have agreed to the target, and Singapore's regulatory authority has pledged to support the initiative to raise audit quality and market assurance.

site_title: Rolls, Aston Martin ride brand cachet against downbeat mood
summary: Rolls-Royce and Aston Martin unveiled their latest models in Singapore, attracting a dozen or two interested buyers despite economic uncertainty. The strong brand and eye-catching models drew affluent buyers, showcasing their ability to command high prices. This trend highlights the enduring appeal of luxury brands, where a strong reputation and desirable design can override economic concerns.

site_title: Condo resale prices slip 0.3% in Feb: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore dipped 0.3% in February 2016, following a 0.8% increase in January, according to SRX Property data. This decline was attributed to a 0.8% price fall in suburban areas. Property consultants blame monthly fluctuations and reduced market activity, while citing the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) as a constraint on large property loans. Resale volume fell 10.8% in February, with prices down 7.4% from the 2014 peak, but ERA Realty expects a more active resale market this year.

site_title: Patching up Malaysia Airlines could be a long haul
summary: Malaysia Airlines is struggling to recover from two devastating plane crashes, with its fleet size, routes, and service quality dwindling. The airline's new CEO, Christoph Mueller, has implemented a turnaround plan that includes cutting 6,000 staff and ditching multiple routes. Despite a 10% increase in revenue per available seat kilometre, the airline's financial standing and reputation remain uncertain. Mueller expects the airline to return to profit by 2018, but experts question the sustainability of its recovery plan, citing the airline's bleak mid to long-term future and the impact of low oil prices on its cost base.

images.alt_text: With the mystery of the vanished MH370 unsolved, the recovery plan of CEO Christoph Mueller (above) has yet to lift the clouds hanging over Malaysia Airlines Bhd.
With the mystery of the vanished MH370 unsolved, the recovery plan of CEO Christoph Mueller has yet to lift the clouds hanging over Malaysia Airlines Bhd.

site_title: To feed sales, firms are reimagining the snack
summary: Mondelez International, the parent company of Oreo and Chips Ahoy, is introducing its first new product line in years, Good Thins, a line of thin, savory crackers made from alternative ingredients such as sweet potatoes and chickpeas. The move aims to capitalize on growing consumer interest in unconventional snack ingredients and healthier options. Despite higher prices, Mondelez's organic revenues grew 4.7% in the fourth quarter, while volume sales dropped 3.1%. The company is looking to shift its focus towards snack and biscuit businesses, which are more important due to declining chocolate sales.

site_title: Taking baby steps towards software that reasons like humans
summary: MetaMind, a Silicon Valley startup, has made progress in creating software capable of reasoning like humans. The company's researchers have developed a dynamic memory network that can process inputs from sound, sight, and text, and answer questions with a human-like understanding. This technology has the potential to revolutionize the field of artificial intelligence, enabling "conversational" agents that can interact with humans. MetaMind's advancements are a significant step towards solving the challenges of reasoning in AI software, but researchers still have far to go to match human capabilities.

site_title: HSBC going solo on China card issue a boost to group's expansion
summary: HSBC has secured approval to launch its own credit-card business in China's $1 trillion market, allowing the bank to expand into the nation's retail banking and wealth-management industries. This move gives HSBC flexibility in its Asian ambitions, despite setbacks from crashing commodity prices and a slowing Chinese economy. The bank will join Citigroup and Bank of East Asia as the only foreign credit-card issuers in China, with plans to add 4,000 jobs in the Pearl River Delta region.

site_title: Japan's economic outlook still iffy despite contraction that's smaller than expected
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 1.1% in the final quarter of last year, slightly less than initially feared, but private consumption fell faster than expected. The government is expected to inject fresh fiscal stimulus and delay a scheduled increase in the consumption tax to support growth. Analysts predict weak economic growth in the first quarter and a possible second consecutive contraction, which could put the world's third-largest economy back into technical recession.

site_title: BT illustration wins in global design awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) won a global design award from the US-based Society for News Design (SND) for its illustration "A Silent Vigil for Charlie Hebdo" published in 2016. The illustration, created by infographics editor Simon Ang, features pen nibs as candles to evoke the craft of slain cartoonists and the worldwide expression of grief. The award, part of the Best of News Design Creative Competition, recognizes outstanding entries for being daring and innovative. This marks the 37th edition of the prestigious annual competition, which received over 9,000 entries.

site_title: This South-east Asian economy is about ready for its opening bell
summary: Myanmar, a South-east Asian country, is poised for its economic opening, with a forecasted 8.4% increase in real gross domestic product in 2016. The country has a capitalist culture, natural resources, and a new stock exchange, but faces challenges such as a lack of credit rating and currency rates. The central bank aims to unify its four currency rates and has granted licenses to foreign lenders, with trading on the exchange expected to begin in March. The government estimates it needs $80 billion in power and technology projects to modernize its economy by 2030.

site_title: Oil dips in volatile trade on producer output freeze views
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday in volatile trading, with Brent crude futures at $40.24 a barrel and US WTI futures at $37.15 a barrel. Analysts at Goldman Sachs said the recent price rally was premature and unsustainable, citing a global supply glut and rising US shale oil rig numbers. Kuwait's oil minister stated that participation in an output freeze would require all major producers, including Iran, to be on board. OPEC members and other producers are set to meet on March 20 to discuss propping up prices.

site_title: OSIM hits 4-month high on privatisation news
summary: OSIM International's shares hit a four-month high after founder Ron Sim announced plans to take the company private with an offer of S$1.32 per share for the remaining 30.75% stake. The stock surged 12.24% to S$1.375, with 15.2 million shares changing hands. The offer price is pegged at a premium of 31.8% to the volume-weighted average traded price per share. Analysts say the offer is reasonable, but longer-term shareholders may not be keen to sell, given the company's weak sales outlook.

site_title: Profits take a hit as S'pore telcos race to reinvent themselves
summary: Singapore's three major telcos, Singtel, StarHub, and M1, have faced declining profits over the past few quarters due to the rise of cloud computing and over-the-top (OTT) services. The companies' legacy revenue streams from voice calls and SMS are being replaced by new revenue streams, with data and broadband services becoming key growth areas. Despite this, Singtel is best positioned to cope with the current market situation, while StarHub and M1 face challenges, particularly from OTT players like Netflix. To adapt, telcos will need to innovate and offer value-added services over broadband to develop new revenue streams, with IoT services also emerging as an opportunity.

site_title: EU membership strengthens economic 'dynamism': Bank of England
summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney stated that EU membership strengthens the UK economy's dynamism but leaves it more exposed to financial shocks. He noted that a more dynamic economy is more resilient to shocks, but increased openness also brings risks. The Bank of England has made extra cash available to banks ahead of the June referendum on EU membership, amid concerns of market turbulence and a potential credit crunch. Opinion polls show the "remain" campaign slightly ahead of the "leave" campaign.

site_title: Nikko Asset bullish on Japan equities
summary: Nikko Asset Management's chief investment officer, Hiroki Tsujimura, is bullish on Japan equities, citing fundamentals such as corporate earnings growth of 10% this fiscal year, which is expected to moderate to 8-9% in the next fiscal year. The firm believes that Japan equities are oversold and have attractive valuations, with the price to book multiple close to the bottom of 1. Tsujimura expects earnings per share growth to be the highest among peers, driven by the increasing adoption of the corporate governance code, which will raise total shareholder returns over time.

site_title: EU to force multinationals to make clearer tax disclosures
summary: The European Union has agreed to new rules requiring multinational companies to disclose tax information to EU countries, aiming to curb corporate tax avoidance. The rules, set to take effect in 2017, will require companies to report revenues, profits, and taxes to EU tax administrations, which will then exchange the data between member states. This move is expected to cost EU governments 70 billion euros annually. The EU deal goes beyond international guidelines, but some EU states have expressed concerns that the measures could deter foreign investors.

site_title: JPMorgan sees divergence in UK stocks with Brexit debate
summary: JPMorgan notes a divergence in UK stocks due to Brexit uncertainty, with the FTSE 100 index performing well while firms that would be most hurt by an EU exit trail behind. The JPMorgan EU Referendum index, tracking 11 companies including Barclays and Next, is down 12% this year. Firms like financial companies and those with high exposure to the domestic market are negatively impacted, while commodity companies benefit from a weaker pound. JPMorgan's James Illsley attributes the divergence to the "unveiled significant disparities within the market."

site_title: Africa's biggest rivals forge closer ties amid global slump
summary: South Africa and Nigeria, Africa's two largest economies, are strengthening ties amid a global economic slump. South Africa's economy is threatened by a weakening demand from China and plunging commodity prices, while Nigeria's economy has been hit by a collapse in oil revenue. The two countries aim to expand trade and investment ties, despite Nigeria's currency controls deterring investors. A high-level delegation from South Africa led by President Jacob Zuma will visit Nigeria to discuss closer economic ties, potentially rebuilding a strained relationship between the two nations.

site_title: Old-school companies get smart by gorging on tech deals: Gadfly
summary: Old-school companies are investing heavily in technology deals, with 48% of non-tech companies making over 1,600 tech-related acquisitions in 2015, a 48% increase from 2011. This trend is driven by companies seeking to incorporate technology into their existing products and businesses, rather than just pursuing scale and cost savings. Examples include industrial giant Honeywell's purchase of Movilizer, and General Electric's investments in digital companies, which have generated $5 billion in revenue.

site_title: Allianz to sue Volkswagen over Dieselgate share drop: source
summary: German insurer Allianz plans to sue Volkswagen in the coming weeks over the company's share price drop due to the "Dieselgate" emissions scandal. This represents the first major lawsuit by a German institution against Volkswagen, which is still reeling from the scandal. Allianz Global Investors (AGI) has not filed a lawsuit yet but is considering one, with the action expected to happen within the month.

site_title: State St starts gender diversity ETF
summary: State Street Global Advisors introduced its SPDR Gender Diversity Index ETF (SHE) on March 8, 2016, aiming to achieve market-rate returns by investing in US companies promoting women to senior ranks. The fund tracks companies with diverse boards and management. This 159th ETF is part of State Street's exchange-traded fund offerings, focusing on gender diversity in corporate leadership.

site_title: Carney follows bankers in warning 'Brexit' to cost finance jobs
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that a 'Brexit' would cost the UK finance industry jobs and money. Carney stated that financial firms will pull business out of the UK if voters choose to leave the European Union. Several major banks, including Goldman Sachs and HSBC, have already drawn up contingency plans for a British exit. If voters choose to depart, Carney said it's "without question" that jobs will be lost, but did not provide a specific number.

site_title: Global glut turns biggest LNG buyer into seller of fuel
summary: Japan's Shizuoka Gas Co will start shipping liquefied natural gas (LNG) abroad in April after completing a reloading facility on its Pacific coast. The move comes as a global LNG glut turns the country, the world's biggest buyer, into a seller. The facility will enable the company to reload LNG from tankers and sell it to other countries.

site_title: IMF ups call for action against global economic slide
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) strengthened its call for global economic action, warning of increasing risks of policy inertia and a potential economic slide. IMF Deputy Managing Director David Lipton urged leaders to expand fiscal and monetary stimulus and implement structural reforms to support growth. The Fund's growth projections may no longer be applicable due to a pullout of capital from emerging economies and a sharp contraction in global trade. Lipton warned against trade protectionist policies, calling them "zero sum economic policies" that will harm all countries in the long run.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after weak China data
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, March 8, 2016, following weak trade data from China that reignited concerns about a global economic slowdown. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.21 points, or 0.37%, to 17,010.74, while the S&P 500 lost 9.49 points, or 0.47%, to 1,992.27, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 33.35 points, or 0.71%, to 4,674.91. The decline was attributed to China's poor trade data, which fueled fears about a slowdown in global economic growth.

site_title: Ikea says will invest US$300m in northern India
summary: Ikea plans to invest nearly US$300 million in the Indian state of Haryana, signing a memorandum of understanding with the state. The investment includes 20 billion rupees (US$297 million), hiring 1,000 workers directly and indirectly employing 3,000 more in services. Ikea aims to open stores in the state, marking its entry into the giant Indian market next year.

site_title: China sends world markets sliding
summary: China's exports dived over a quarter in February, with imports falling almost 14% compared to forecasts. This led to a global market downturn, with Asian markets falling and European markets shedding 1.2-1.3%. Mining stocks were particularly affected, with Anglo American's share price tumbling 9.3%. The Chinese economy's slowdown is raising concerns, despite officials citing distortions from the Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: Tourists flock to Indonesia to see rare total solar eclipse
summary: Thousands of tourists are flocking to Indonesia to witness the country's first total solar eclipse in nearly 33 years. The rare event will be visible in parts of Australia and Southeast Asia, but only some areas of Indonesia will experience a total solar eclipse. The phenomenon has brought economic benefits, with hotels and events organized around it. Indonesia aims to double its 10 million tourist arrivals by 2019, despite struggling with poor connectivity and infrastructure.

site_title: Iron ore hits nine-month high on sustained rally
summary: Iron ore prices rose 1% to a nine-month high on Tuesday, reaching $63.30 per tonne, driven by expectations of a short-term boost in China's steel production. The rally, fueled by forecasts of a jump in Chinese steel making, has made iron ore the best-performing commodity for 2016, with a year-to-date gain of 46%. Despite some concerns about the sustainability of the rally, analysts expect a potential rise in steel production in China, supported by economic stimulus measures.

site_title: Bank of England warns of Brexit risks, provoking ire of eurosceptics
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that exiting the European Union could harm Britain's $2.9 trillion economy and prompt major financial institutions to abandon London, a global financial hub. Carney stated that uncertainty created by an exit could hurt the economy, and some banks are considering a move if the country votes to leave the EU.

site_title: Mencast Holdings to acquire Stone Marine Singapore
summary: Mencast Holdings, an offshore engineering provider, has agreed to acquire Stone Marine Singapore for around S$2.5 million, minus the total debt. The acquisition will grant Mencast exclusive territorial licenses to manufacture marine equipment in Asia-Pacific and the Middle East. The deal also involves a shared license for certain regions and a royalty fee. The partnership aims to expand Mencast's presence in the premium military and naval vessel market.

site_title: Gold nears 13-month peak after China data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to a 13-month high of $1,273.32 per ounce, driven by weaker dollar and lower European shares, amid concerns over global demand. China's February exports and imports slumped 25.4% and 13.8% respectively, fueling uncertainty about the global economy. The European Central Bank's policy review on Thursday and the US Federal Reserve's meeting on March 15-16 are expected to impact gold prices, with some analysts predicting a potential test of $1,300 per ounce if the Fed keeps interest rates on hold.

site_title: Mapletree buys student housing assets for £417m
summary: Mapletree Investments, a unit of Temasek Holdings, has acquired a portfolio of 25 student housing buildings in the UK for £417 million (S$819.2 million), with over 5,500 beds and a projected initial net yield of 6 per cent. The acquisition marks Mapletree's first foray into the UK student accommodation market, with plans to grow its portfolio aggressively. The move is part of a trend of institutional investors shifting from traditional asset classes to alternative ones, such as student accommodation, which offer higher yields.

site_title: Zika 'link' to paralysing myelitis: researchers
summary: French researchers have linked the Zika virus to paralysing myelitis, a neurological disorder, in a 15-year-old girl diagnosed with acute myelitis in Guadeloupe. High levels of Zika were detected in her cerebrospinal fluid, providing the first published "proof of a link" between the virus and the disease. This discovery suggests the Zika virus may be more than just a cause of brain damage in babies and neurological disorders in adults.

site_title: ViewQwest ups the ante in high-speed broadband
summary: ViewQwest has launched a 10Gbps fibre broadband plan for homes in Singapore, offering a custom-built PC for S$2,800. The plan includes a dedicated 24/7 customer support helpline and next-business-day on-site support for S$218 a month for 24 months. ViewQwest's 10Gbps service features symmetrical speeds, ultra-low latency of under 1ms, and is available for consumers who expect the best from high-end internet. This is the first end-to-end 10Gbps fibre broadband service in Singapore, with rival ISPs citing limitations in their GPon solutions.

site_title: VW's labour chief says big US fines will hit workers' jobs
summary: Volkswagen's top labor official, Bernd Osterloh, warns that big US fines from the Dieselgate scandal could lead to job cuts in the US and Europe. The US Justice Department is suing Volkswagen for up to $46 billion, and nearly 600,000 cars remain without a fix. Osterloh stated that the company's future viability could be endangered by a large financial penalty, which would have "dramatic social consequences." The extent of job cuts depends on the level of fines, and the company's management will assess the situation.

site_title: US Fed responsible for missing US$100m, Bangladesh says
summary: Bangladesh's Finance Minister Abul Maal Abdul Muhith blames the US Federal Reserve for the theft of at least $100 million from Bangladesh's account. The funds were allegedly stolen by hackers and traced to the Philippines. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York denies any involvement, stating there's no evidence of hacking or system compromise. Bangladesh plans to pursue a legal fight to retrieve the missing funds, which appear to span the globe from Bangladesh to the US and the Philippines.

site_title: China's Hebei province aims to shut 60% of steel mills by 2020
summary: China's Hebei province aims to shut 60% of its steel mills by 2020 to cut overcapacity, which has driven prices to their lowest in decades. The province will also limit steel production capacity to 200 million tonnes by 2020. The move is part of China's efforts to curb industrial capacity and address environmental pollution. The central government has promised to cut crude steel capacity by 100-150 million tonnes within the next five years and ban new steel projects.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic up 7.1% in January
summary: Global air passenger traffic increased 7.1% in January, driven by a decline in oil prices, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The passenger load factor rose 1.1% to a record level. IATA's director-general, Tony Tyler, attributed the growth to strong demand, airlines' efficient use of assets, and the oil price drop. The strong January performance suggests another year of passenger traffic growth, with the oil price decline likely providing additional stimulus.

site_title: China Yongsheng appoints KGI Fraser as IFA on privatisation
summary: China Yongsheng, a Catalist-listed concrete supplier, has appointed KGI Fraser Securities as the independent financial adviser (IFA) for its privatization deal valued at S$0.032 per share. The IFA advice and independent directors' recommendation will be disclosed within 14 days. The offer document is expected to be released in the next seven days.

site_title: Hilton exploring addition of 'hostel-like' brand, Nassetta says
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings, the world's largest hospitality company, is exploring the addition of a new "hostel-like" brand targeting young travelers seeking affordable, no-frills lodging. CEO Chris Nassetta stated that the brand would offer lower prices and less service, with an urban flair. The move aims to meet increasing demand from budget-conscious travelers, who are increasingly opting for alternatives to traditional hotels. Hilton prefers to develop new brands itself, rather than making acquisitions, and is also planning to break itself up into three entities to create separate companies focused on hotels, real estate, and time-share business.

site_title: Weaker US small business confidence bucks firming data
summary: US small business confidence declined to 92.9 in February, down 1.3 percentage points from January, as concerns about sales growth and profits hurt capital spending and hiring plans. Despite this, the economy appears to be picking up, with GDP growth estimates above a 2% rate for the first quarter. This contrasts with the NFIB's survey, which found labor market gauges softened slightly and reflected tepid economic growth in the fourth quarter. The sustained weakness in small business confidence is at odds with other economic data suggesting a pick-up in economic activity.

site_title: VW CEO says scandal will inflict substantial financial damage
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller warned that the emissions scandal will inflict "substantial and painful" financial damage on the company, taking years to fully assess. The carmaker has already set aside 6.7 billion euros to cover costs of recalls for 11 million affected diesel vehicles. Mueller stated that VW has made no attempts to conceal its wrongdoings, indicating a long-term impact on the company's finances.

site_title: Taiwan c.bank says difficult for economy to grow significantly this year
summary: Taiwan's central bank warned that significant economic growth this year will be challenging due to global economic downturn risks. The bank will maintain "appropriate" monetary policy to stimulate growth and stabilize prices. The central bank's governor, Perng Fai-nan, will face parliamentary questions on Thursday. The bank's next meeting is scheduled for March 24. This prediction comes amid concerns over global economic growth, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Football: Blatter vows to clear name in CAS appeal
summary: Disgraced former Fifa president Sepp Blatter has vowed to clear his name through a Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) appeal ahead of his 80th birthday. Blatter was suspended for six years over a two million dollar payment to Michel Platini, but hopes to have his ban overturned. He claims to have no new evidence to support his appeal and says he has been unfairly portrayed as corrupt. Despite potential revelations of his former salary, Blatter plans to remain out of football, citing his lifelong dedication to the sport.

site_title: Daewoo Securities files claim against China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric in South Korea
summary: Daewoo Securities Co. has filed a claim of 1 billion Korean Won (approximately S$1.15 million) against China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings in South Korea, alleging breach of an underwriting agreement from 2010. The claim centers on inaccurate financial statements and false descriptions of cash and assets submitted to Daewoo. China Gaoxian intends to defend the claims and will seek legal advice.

site_title: Update: Noble Group debt back above US$0.60 as commodity distress eases
summary: Noble Group's debt, which was previously at risk of default, has seen a significant increase to above US$0.60 as commodity prices recover and the company refines its loan facilities. The company is focused on generating cash and reducing its leverage, with discussions with banks about extending a revolving facility well advanced. Despite the improvement, credit analysts caution that Noble Group's credit fundamentals remain weak, and investors are being rewarded with a 44% return on its 2018 notes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall as investors become cautious
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng index at 20,011.58, amid investor caution ahead of policy meetings by the European Central Bank and US Federal Reserve. The market has bounced from 3-1/2 year lows in February, but investors are wary of near-term prospects, leading to declines in all main sectors, including services and energy.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell in opening deals on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.9% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dipping 0.9%. The decline followed losses in Asian markets, which were affected by a slump in China's exports and a retreat in Brent oil prices. The eurozone's CAC 40 index also fell 0.8%.

site_title: Private consumption, investment help drive Euro-area growth
summary: The euro-area experienced its 11th consecutive quarter of growth, driven by a 0.3% increase in GDP in the fourth quarter. Private consumption and investment contributed to the growth, with consumption rising 0.2% and gross fixed capital formation increasing 1.3%. However, net trade suffered due to a slowdown in China and other emerging markets. The European Central Bank is expected to announce additional stimulus measures to boost inflation, which remains below the 2% target. Despite this, risks to the growth outlook persist due to concerns over the UK's potential exit from the EU and the struggle for Spain's new government.

site_title: BofA Asia equity-trading head Droitcourt said to leave amid cuts
summary: Bank of America's head of Asia-Pacific equity trading, Arnaud Droitcourt, has left the company amid job cuts to trim expenses. Droitcourt, a Hong Kong-based managing director, joined Bank of America in 2013 after working at Morgan Stanley. The departure was not publicly announced, and a bank spokesman declined to comment. The move is part of Bank of America's efforts to reduce costs and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude: China's buying momentum slows
summary: China's buying momentum for crude oil in the Asia-Pacific market has slowed due to a US$10-per barrel increase in oil prices over the past three weeks. This rise in Brent oil prices to over US$40 per barrel may impact Chinese demand and shipments to the country in the second quarter, as Chinese crude inventories are high. China's imports have been supported by low oil prices and domestic refiners' buying, but high prices may lead to a drawdown of stocks.

site_title: Fabchem issues profit warning for 4QFY16
summary: Fabchem China issued a profit warning for 4QFY16, citing a net loss due to challenging market conditions in China and the temporary suspension of booster production activities following an unrelated explosion incident at a production plant in Shandong province. The company's revenue was also impacted by a slowdown in China's economic growth and increased scrutiny of industrial activities. As a result, Fabchem China's results will be released on or before May 30.

site_title: CMA CGM bonds tumble to near-record lows on earnings collapse
summary: CMA CGM SA bonds fell to near-record lows after the container-shipping line's quarterly profit plummeted 72% to $115.7 million due to lower freight rates. The company's 725 million-euro bonds due 2021 dropped to 74 cents, and its 300 million-euro notes due 2018 fell to 87 cents. The decline is attributed to a prolonged slump in shipping rates and the pending $3.38 billion acquisition of Neptune Orient Lines Ltd. Analysts expect a bleak outlook until summer, citing continued pressure on freight rates.

site_title: Xpress founder to step down
summary: KK Fong, founder and COO of Xpress Holdings, is stepping down March 31 to pursue new business interests. He will hand over the reins to a new management team led by chairman Ma Wei Dong. Fong started Xpress 30 years ago and transformed it from a traditional SME printing company to a technology-driven firm with a regional presence. He credits his entrepreneurial talent and relentless pursuit of printing excellence for the company's success, with Lim Huan Chiang praising Fong's deep passion for the business.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering nets S$18.3m contracts
summary: HIAP Seng Engineering Ltd has been awarded two contracts worth approximately S$18.3 million for mechanical works in Singapore. The contracts include a plant construction project worth S$13.7 million and a plant maintenance work worth S$4.6 million, both of which are expected to be completed by February 2017 and this July, respectively. The group expects a positive contribution to its earnings but does not anticipate a material impact on its financials for the current financial year.

site_title: Transocean says rigs from Keppel delayed until 2020
summary: Transocean Ltd announced an agreement with Keppel Offshore & Marine Ltd to defer the delivery of five high-specification jackup drilling rigs until 2020. The rigs, originally scheduled for delivery in 2016, will now be delivered in two and three-month intervals starting in the first quarter of 2020. The delay is due to the impact of a 70% decline in crude oil prices on exploration companies, forcing them to cut costs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 10.07 points to close at 1,687.86 on Tuesday, marking a lower trading day. The index saw 2.01 billion lots valued at RM2.06 billion traded, with 286 gains and 568 losses.

site_title: StanChart says China interbank bond quota scrapped for all investors
summary: China has scrapped the investment quota requirement for all eligible foreign asset managers to enter its interbank debt market, allowing registered financial institutions outside of China to buy bonds without individual quotas. The People's Bank of China will focus on aggregate inflows and outflows, potentially implementing macro-prudential measures if necessary. The move is expected to attract large inflows into Chinese bonds but foreign investors are likely to wait for more economic clarity.
