The situation has led to public protests and halted work among hundreds of unpaid foreign workers.

site_title: OUE H-Trust to raise nearly S$240m via rights issue
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) is carrying out an underwritten rights issue to raise approximately S$238.6 million, mainly to fund the purchase of the Crowne Plaza Changi Airport hotel extension. The issue price is S$0.54 per stapled security, offering a 29.4% discount to the closing price. The trust will use the funds to complete the hotel extension, which is currently under construction and expected to add 243 rooms. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the middle of the year.

site_title: Saudis face another test after battle with shale is won
summary: Saudi Arabia's efforts to balance the global oil market by reducing prices have led to a surplus of over 1 billion barrels, with inventories expected to remain high until 2021. Despite a decline in US shale production, the market will continue to accumulate stockpiles, weighing on prices. The International Energy Agency forecasts that it will take years to clear the glut, with prices potentially rebounding to $50 a barrel in June. Saudi Arabia has refused to speed up the re-balancing process by reducing its supply, instead opting to maintain its current output levels.

site_title: Indonesia could deplete coal reserves by 2033: PwC
summary: Indonesia's economically retrievable coal reserves could be depleted by 2033, according to a PwC study based on data from 25 coal mining companies representing 80% of the country's output. The study found a 30-40% drop in coal reserves due to reduced exploration and profitability, with reserves estimated between 7.3-8.3 billion tonnes. This could leave the country short of coal for its planned 35-gigawatt power stations. The Indonesian Coal Mining Association is urging the government to set coal prices based on miners' costs to stimulate investment and secure coal reserves.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.44 points to close at 1,697.93 on Monday, driven by a 2.44 billion lots worth RM2.45 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 317 to 594. The market ended higher despite a global focus on US-EU trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Dolphin Geophysical liquidation begins
summary: The liquidation of Singapore-based Dolphin Geophysical Pte Ltd has begun, with Moore Stephens liquidators appointed to oversee the process. The Singapore unit of the now bankrupt Norwegian seismic player, Dolphin Group ASA, is expected to face a shortfall of over S$200 million, with limited assets being disposed of. The largest creditor, a Norwegian bank, has filed a claim for secured and unsecured debts exceeding US$140 million. Dolphin Group ASA filed for bankruptcy in December 2015 due to debt accumulation and weak market fundamentals.

site_title: China's taste for craft beer draws even small-scale brewers from abroad
summary: China's growing demand for high-end craft beers is attracting small-scale brewers from abroad, with premium beers expected to make up over a third of the $80 billion Chinese market by the end of the decade. Global brewing giants, such as AB InBev, SABMiller, and Heineken, are shifting their strategy to focus on premium products, driven by China's 1.4 billion consumers seeking more tailored and individual products. This trend may help these companies unlock frothier profits in the world's largest beer market.

images.alt_text: The focus on premium products reflects a shift in China's 1.4 billion consumers, who now want more tailored and individual products from fast-food to travel.

site_title: Alibaba's Ant Financial could be valued at nearly US$50b: WSJ
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Ant Financial Services Group, is set to raise up to $3.07 billion in its current funding round, valuing it at nearly $50 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. The latest round of funding, expected to be completed by mid-April, will be raised from new and existing investors. Alibaba and Ant Financial were not immediately available for comment.

site_title: KLW to buy two units at Kallang Avenue for S$2.28m
summary: KLW Holdings has entered into an option to purchase two units at 2 Kallang Avenue for S$2.28 million from unrelated third parties, Ultra Group and Magnitude. The units, with a total floor area of 252 sq m, will be used as an office, showroom, and project operations base. A deposit of over S$227,850 has been paid, with the rest to be paid when the deal is completed around May 7, funded through internal resources.

site_title: 'Brexit' would boost UK bonds, JPMorgan asset management says
summary: Holders of UK government bonds are expected to benefit from a potential Brexit, as the Bank of England is likely to ease policy, cutting interest rates or implementing more quantitative easing, according to JPMorgan Asset Management. This could lead to increased returns for gilts, with yields currently at 1.47%. A UK exit from the EU is uncertain, with polls showing a narrow majority in favor of staying, but the pound has declined due to investor uneasiness, falling 0.6% to $1.4145.

site_title: Air freight demand solid in Jan, yields under pressure: IATA
summary: Air freight demand rose 2.7% in January, the fastest pace since April 2015, according to IATA. However, available capacity increased 7% faster than demand, leading to a 1.8 percentage point drop in load factors to 41.3%. Yields and revenues remain under pressure, despite the growth in volumes. IATA head Tony Tyler stated that volumes are a positive sign, but yields are still under significant pressure.

site_title: Malaysia investigates second piece of debris two years after MH370 disappeared
summary: Malaysia is investigating a second piece of debris found in Reunion Island, suspected to be from missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The plane vanished on March 8, 2014, with 239 passengers and crew. Only a wing flaperon was confirmed last year. Two new pieces of debris were discovered in Mozambique and Reunion Island, and officials are awaiting verification before sending them to Australia for examination. An interim report on the investigation will be released on the two-year anniversary of the disappearance.

site_title: UAE says oil price forcing producers to freeze output
summary: UAE Energy Minister Suhail bin Mohammed al-Mazrouei stated that current oil prices are forcing many producers to freeze output, citing that it doesn't make sense to increase production at the current prices. The minister expects a correction in prices to take time, but remains optimistic that a sustainable price correction will occur before the end of the year.

site_title: Eurogroup to send lenders' team back to Athens: EU's Moscovici
summary: Eurozone finance ministers agreed to send a team of lenders' representatives to Athens to complete a review of Greek reforms. The review, started in January, stalled over pension reform and IMF views on debt sustainability. The team will assess Greece's delivery of promised reforms in exchange for cheap loans. The development paves the way for new loans and debt relief talks.

site_title: Thailand plans US$1.98b loan programme for first-home buyers
summary: Thailand plans a US$1.98 billion soft loan programme to stimulate domestic spending, targeting lower-income first-time home buyers. The 70 billion baht (US$1.98 billion) programme will provide loans for homes not exceeding 1.5 million baht. The move aims to boost the economy, which has struggled since the army took over nearly two years ago.

site_title: Football: 2006 World Cup scandal inquiry to cost 3.5m euros
summary: The German Football Association's (DFB) inquiry into the 2006 World Cup scandal is expected to cost around 3.5 million euros. The inquiry was sparked by claims that the DFB used a slush fund to buy votes from FIFA executives in 2000 to secure the hosting rights. An official report has found that the bid may have been influenced by bribes, and the DFB is set to face further scrutiny. The scandal has raised questions about FIFA's integrity and the use of bribes in international sports.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after last week's rally
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, following a four-day winning streak for the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average last week. The Dow Jones fell 39.45 points, the S&P 500 lost 9.03 points, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 26.56 points. The losses occurred despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records last week.

site_title: Courts Asia to issue S$75 million of notes due 2019
summary: Courts Asia, a mainboard-listed retailer, plans to issue S$75 million of notes due 2019 at a fixed rate of 5.75% per year. The notes, payable semi-annually, have a three-year tenure and were initially set to be issued for S$50 million. The issue was upsized due to strong demand.

site_title: TTJ Holdings chalks up 40% rise in Q2 FY16 net profit to S$5.4m
summary: TTJ Holdings reported a 40% year-over-year increase in Q2 FY16 net profit to S$5.41 million, driven by higher revenue and reduced losses. Revenue rose 4% to S$28.56 million, primarily from its structural steel business. The company aims to capitalize on government-related projects and sustain demand from institutional and civil engineering projects. Net profit for the six-month period climbed 18% to S$9.53 million, with earnings per share rising to 1.55 Singapore cents.

site_title: Nine deals in investment grade as bankers turn bullish
summary: Nine investment-grade bond deals were announced Monday, following a week of strong supply in the primary market. The deals, from utilities and Yankee banks, saw over $48 billion priced last week. Toronto-Dominion Bank issued a five-year covered bond, while Danske Bank and Abbey National Treasury Services announced five and three-year senior bonds. The deals come despite weakness in equities and wider credit spreads.

site_title: BMW sees its future shift to the ultimate self-driving machine
summary: BMW is shifting its focus from luxury driving to automated driving as urbanization and changing attitudes toward cars redefine transportation. The company sees a future where "Sheer Driving Pleasure" is defined as liberating drivers through automation, with people still wanting to take over the wheel for thrill-seeking experiences. This shift comes as BMW faces competition in the luxury-car market and aims to revolutionize mobility with autonomous vehicles, which it believes will be a major opportunity.

site_title: Apple rejected by US high court in US$450m e-book case
summary: The US Supreme Court refused to review a federal appeals court ruling that Apple orchestrated a scheme to raise electronic book prices, forcing the company to pay $450 million to settle the antitrust suit. The ruling, made in 2014, calls for Apple to pay $400 million to e-book consumers, $20 million to states, and $30 million in legal fees. The decision leaves intact a settlement that was reached between Apple and over 30 states in 2014.

site_title: Eurozone Sentix index falls unexpectedly in March
summary: Eurozone sentiment declined in March for the third consecutive month, reaching its lowest level in over a year, according to the Sentix research group. The index fell to 5.5 from 6.0 in February, below expectations. Investors' assessment of current conditions in the eurozone dropped to 8.3, the lowest in 11 months, but expectations improved slightly. A decline in oil prices and concerns over global economic growth have contributed to the downturn.

site_title: China angered by planned US export restrictions on ZTE
summary: China expressed anger over the US Commerce Department's plans to place export restrictions on ZTE Corp, a Chinese telecoms equipment-maker, for allegedly violating US export controls on Iran. The restrictions, set to take effect Tuesday, apply to companies worldwide shipping American-made products to ZTE. China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei urged the US to stop the action, citing concerns over damaging Sino-US trade cooperation and bilateral relations. The US restrictions may complicate ZTE's ability to acquire US products and have been imposed following an investigation into alleged export-control violations.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally to a 2-month high, NZ touches record
summary: Australian shares surged to a two-month high, reaching 5,142.81, driven by a strong rally in banks and resource counters, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 1.04%. New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record 6,426.57 before ending nearly unchanged.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) chairman and CEO of OSIM International, Tan Sri Lee Sheng Wee, made a voluntary cash offer of S$1.32 per share to take the company private. SGX is also pursuing the acquisition of London's Baltic Exchange to boost freight derivatives. A survey by BlackRock found Singaporean women lack confidence in investing, while EY's survey identified big data as a challenge in corporate reporting. Singtel ranked first in 4G coverage and peak speeds in Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 13.49 points on Monday after six days of gains.

site_title: UK business chief quits, accuses PM Cameron of EU exit "hyperbole"
summary: British Chambers of Commerce director general John Longworth has quit his post after speaking in favor of Britain's EU exit, accusing Prime Minister David Cameron of "hyperbole" over the risks of Brexit. Longworth said the EU is incapable of meaningful reform and Britain could have a bright economic future outside the bloc. His resignation comes as the UK prepares for a June 23 referendum on EU membership, with the Conservative Party deeply split on the issue.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower; STI drops 13 points after six days of gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 13.49 points to 2,823.51, its seventh consecutive day of losses, after a six-day gain of 234 points. Offshore and marine stocks led the decline, with several counters experiencing significant percentage gains. Banks had a mixed performance, with DBS rising while OCBC and UOB fell. Analysts expect volatility in the banking sector in 2016, citing concerns over macroeconomic data points and asset quality.

site_title: VW says wrongfooted by US going public on emissions
summary: Volkswagen was caught off guard by US authorities going public with emissions-cheating allegations, contrary to its expectation of an amicable resolution. The German automaker had installed software in 11 million diesel engines worldwide, leading to a global scandal and massive fines. A company document reveals that VW's management was surprised by the public announcement, and the carmaker argues that it had no indication of a breach affecting the stock price until the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) made the allegations public on September 18, 2015.

site_title: China says to strictly implement law against illegal GMO planting
summary: China's agriculture minister Han Changfu stated that the country will strictly enforce laws prohibiting the planting of illegal genetically modified organisms (GMO) crops. The issue, mainly confined to some regions, poses no safety concerns. China will punish offenders severely, according to Han. This move aims to control the practice and maintain food safety.

site_title: Singtel tops in 4G coverage, peak speeds: IDA surveys
summary: Singtel ranked first in 4G coverage and peak speeds in Singapore, according to IDA surveys. The telco achieved 130.8 Mbps peak speeds, surpassing StarHub's 125.4 Mbps and M1's 75.7 Mbps. Singtel also topped 3G peak speeds with 31.2 Mbps, beating StarHub's 27.8 Mbps and M1's 14.5 Mbps.

site_title: Indonesia raises 31.5t rupiah from retail sukuk
summary: Indonesia raised 31.5 trillion rupiah (S$3.33 billion) in retail shariah bonds, the largest issuance since 2009. The 8.30% coupon is slightly higher than the 2015 issue. This is part of the government's efforts to lower dependence on foreign funds and deepen the local financial market. The retail sukuk can be traded in the secondary market after a one-month holding period, targeting individual investors.

site_title: Europe: Shares open lower led by EDF, Old Mutual surges
summary: European shares fell on Monday, led by a 6.4% drop in French utility EDF after its finance director's resignation. EDF's plan to build nuclear reactors in Britain was cited as a reason for the departure. In contrast, Old Mutual surged 11% after considering a 9 billion pound break-up. The FTSEurofirst 300 index fell 0.1% as investors await the European Central Bank policy meeting later this week. Despite recent gains, European stocks remain down around 7% since the start of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down on profit-taking, Shanghai rises
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.08% on Monday due to profit-taking, despite a strong US jobs report. In contrast, Chinese shares rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.81% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumping 2.03%. The US jobs report was seen as a positive factor, but investors opted to sell Hong Kong stocks instead, citing concerns over the city's economic outlook.

site_title: Brokers' take update: Ron Sim's offer to privatise OSIM is a good exit price
summary: OSIM International's founder and CEO Ron Sim made a voluntary unconditional cash offer of S$1.32 a share to take the lifestyle company private. The offer price is S$1.30 a share excluding final dividends, and Mr. Sim owns 68.31% of OSIM. Analysts say the offer is a good exit price for minority shareholders and represents a reasonable offer given the tough market environment. CIMB analysts believe the offer is a positive three-year view for Ron Sim, while OCBC Investment Research recommends shareholders to accept the offer, citing a 61% premium to their fair value estimate.

site_title: Oil rout over, Opec aims for US$50 anchor, says PIRA's Ross
summary: Major Opec producers are aiming for an oil price equilibrium of $50 a barrel, according to Gary Ross, a leading industry prognosticator. This target, if achieved, would signal the end of the oil market's prolonged rout and potentially curb the rise of rival producers. Opec's efforts to manage the market, which included a production freeze agreement with Russia, may have begun to curb oversupply and boost market sentiment. The $50 price anchor is seen as a new benchmark for global oil prices, potentially replacing the previous $100 a barrel figure.

site_title: SE Asia stocks: Malaysia at four-month high; energy shares rise with global oil
summary: Southeast Asian stocks rose on Monday, with Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur composite index reaching a four-month high as the ringgit hit a 7.5-month high. The Thai SET index also rose 1% and Vietnamese stocks extended gains for a fifth day. Energy shares were boosted by a rise in global oil prices, with Sapurakencana Petroleum and PTT Exploration and Production leading gains. Analysts attribute the rally to positive investment sentiment and surplus liquidity in the global financial system.

site_title: German factory orders fall less than expected in January
summary: German factory orders fell 0.1% in January, less than expected, driven by weaker domestic demand. Foreign orders rose 1.0%, mainly from the euro zone, which cushioned the decline. Domestic demand fell 1.6% while foreign orders rose 7.5%. The competitiveness of the German industrial sector was boosted by strong foreign demand, but industry expectations remain cautious, signaling a modest economic upswing.

site_title: JP Morgan cuts equities to "underweight" for first time since 2007
summary: JP Morgan Cazenove has cut its equities allocation to "underweight" for the first time since 2007, citing a recent market rebound that is expected to fade. The decision follows gains in equities since mid-February, and the firm advises clients to cut their exposure during any bounce caused by the European Central Bank. The euro zone is seen at an early stage of the cycle, and the UK remains a top regional pick despite Brexit risks. Utilities and telecoms sectors remain the top global "overweights."

site_title: Ringgit, rupiah climb as global growth concerns ebb
summary: The Malaysian ringgit reached a 7-1/2 month high and the Indonesian rupiah scaled a 10-month peak on Monday, driven by solid US jobs data easing global growth concerns. Asian currencies, including the rupiah and ringgit, have rallied in recent weeks amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike delay and a rebound in commodity prices. The improved risk sentiment is expected to continue benefiting emerging market currencies for a while, with analysts attributing the gains to firmer oil prices and a more optimistic outlook for the US economy.

site_title: Siege in Sydney ends with gunman found dead
summary: A gunman killed one person and injured two others in a six-hour police siege at an industrial estate in Sydney's Ingleburn suburb. The gunman, 33, was found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The victims were brothers involved in a domestic dispute. The incident occurred after a similar siege in December 2014, which left two hostages dead. Police confirmed the situation was not terrorism-related. Three people, including the gunman, were found dead, and two others received gunshot wounds.

site_title: South Korea not fretting over US forex manipulation rule
summary: South Korea's Vice Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok stated that the country is not worried about new US laws allowing Washington to bar countries from US trade deals and government procurement contracts if they keep currencies artificially low. The government will conduct closer bilateral communication with the US on macro-economic policies, including foreign exchange. This comes after a local media report citing an unnamed official said US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew expressed concerns over South Korea's forex policies. The South Korean government's basic stance on foreign exchange rates is to intervene via "market smoothing" measures in extreme price action.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall on profit-taking, stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Monday, dropping 0.61% as a stronger yen weighed on exporters and investors took profits following recent gains. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,911.32, while the Topix index lost 0.98%. This was the first decline in five sessions. The weaker yen, which has been trading near a 15-year high, negatively impacted exporters. The decline follows recent gains, with investors taking profits ahead of the US-EU trade talks and potential tariffs.

site_title: Japan's Kuroda signals central bank easing done for now, will study effects
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank will study the effects of negative interest rates, indicating no immediate expansion of stimulus. Kuroda maintained optimism on Japan's economic outlook, citing positive effects on asset prices despite criticism. The BOJ is ready to ease again if needed to hit its 2% price target, and Kuroda emphasized the potential for a "very powerful" stimulus effect on the economy.

site_title: China must focus on technology, cost cuts to boost rural incomes
summary: China's Agriculture Minister Han Changfu says the country must focus on technology and cost cuts to boost rural incomes, as grain prices are unlikely to rise in the next five years. China aims to achieve annual rural income growth of 6.5% between 2016 and 2020. The government will also crack down on food safety issues, including illegal additives and pesticide use. This approach is necessary due to falling prices, limited job opportunities in cities, and challenges in increasing farmer incomes in the coming years.

site_title: Singaporean women lack confidence in investing: survey
summary: A Global Investor Pulse Survey conducted by BlackRock found that Singaporean women lack confidence in investing, despite being financially savvy as men. 55% of women surveyed view investing as like gambling, and only 38% are willing to take on higher risks. Women tend to hold more conservative asset classes and seek advice from family and friends, with 47% consulting family and friends for long-term savings and investment decisions. In contrast, single Singaporeans are less aware of their financial needs and feel less comfortable making financial decisions.

site_title: No truth G-20 criticised negative rate policy: BOJ's Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda denied media reports that Japan faced criticism from G-20 nations for adopting a negative interest rate policy, which he claimed was aimed at achieving the BOJ's price target. Kuroda stated that he gained sufficient understanding from the G-20 members during a meeting in Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Monday there was no truth to media reports that Japan came under fire from some G-20 nations for triggering a competitive currency devaluation by adopting a negative interest rate policy.

site_title: China said to plan crackdown on loans for home down-payments
summary: China is planning to impose new rules to crack down on loans for home down-payments, stepping up financing risk in the property market. Regulators, including the central bank and the China Banking Regulatory Commission, will bar lenders from offering such loans and scrutinize mortgage applications to reject those with down-payment loans from other institutions. The measures come amid concerns about rising loan market risks and warnings from officials that top-tier cities' property markets have overheated. This is part of efforts to strengthen stress tests of property loans and control rising housing prices.

site_title: PwC names Robert E Moritz its global chairman
summary: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) has named Robert E. Moritz as its new global chairman, effective July 1, 2016. Moritz, who has been with the firm since 1985, will serve a four-year term. He succeeds Dennis Nally, who retires after a 42-year career. Moritz's background is in assurance, primarily serving financial services companies, and has held leadership roles, including head of US assurance practice and managing partner for the New York region. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to navigate the global economy and bring PwC's best ideas and solutions to clients.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises to 4-wk high, stocks inch up on US jobs data
summary: South Korea's won rose to a four-week high against the dollar, up 0.3% at 1,199.4 per dollar, following upbeat US jobs data and a bounce in oil prices. The won's strongest level since February 11 was reached, with analysts expecting it to stay above 1,200 won due to dollar-long positions being cut. South Korean shares also edged up, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index rising 0.3%, driven by demand for local equities following the jobs data.

site_title: Big data a challenge in Singapore's corporate reporting: EY survey
summary: Singapore's CFOs see big data as a key challenge in corporate reporting, with 58% citing it as a major issue, surpassing complexity of regulatory and compliance requirements. The survey found a decline in CFO confidence in corporate reporting aspects, with only 55% confident in compliance and 44% in key performance indicators. Despite this, 70% of Singapore respondents reported effective corporate reporting in securing the board's confidence.

site_title: China: Pledges on economy help shares rise a 5th straight day
summary: China's stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day, with the CSI300 index increasing 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.8%. The rally was driven by reassurances from top leaders that the economy will stay on a sound footing despite structural reforms. The technology-focused ChiNext board jumped 2.5% after Beijing outlined its vision to become a tech power. The opening of China's annual parliament meeting delivered few surprises, but officials sought to calm worries about the slowing economy and potential layoffs.

site_title: Oil prices extend gains in Asia
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday, extending gains for the third consecutive week, driven by strong US jobs growth and a cut in US drilling activities. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate jumped 66 cents to $36.57 a barrel and Brent crude rose 70 cents to $39.42 a barrel. A weaker US dollar and lower wage growth also contributed to the price increase. However, analysts note that an output cut agreement by the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is still needed for prices to continue rising.

images.alt_text: Oil prices extended gains in Asia on Monday boosted by strong US jobs growth data as a cut in US drilling activities sparked hopes of an easing in the global supply glut.

site_title: SGX to boost freight derivatives with pursuit of Baltic Exchange
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to acquire London's Baltic Exchange, aiming to boost its freight derivatives and enhance its derivatives credentials. The move is part of SGX's efforts to develop Asian pricing benchmarks for bulk commodities. Despite recent economic challenges, long-term demand for bulk materials is expected to remain strong, driven by infrastructure development in countries like India, Indonesia, and Central Asia. The acquisition would give SGX deeper coverage with large clients and enhance its pricing benchmarks in the shipping industry.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall, pare early gains ahead of trade data
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 8,638.39 ahead of releasing trade data for February, which is expected to show a 13th consecutive month of declining exports. The electronics subindex sank 0.6%, while shares in Hon Hai (Foxconn) fell over 1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.739 per US dollar. Talks for Foxconn to acquire a majority stake in Sharp Corp are reportedly "on the right track," despite previous deal suspension due to new material information.

site_title: Gold steady below 13-month high as upbeat US jobs support Fed hike
summary: Gold prices steadied below a 13-month high on Monday, as upbeat US jobs data suggested the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates this year, but not as soon as expected. US nonfarm payrolls rose 242,000 last month, beating forecasts, and gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,262.05 an ounce. Despite a recent rally, gold is still supported by expectations that the Fed may not raise rates next week, providing some relief to non-interest bearing gold.

site_title: China's CO2 emissions may have peaked in 2014: study
summary: China's carbon emissions may have peaked in 2014, according to a study, potentially undermining its existing climate pledges. The study found that emissions fell in 2015, and if growth continues, a peak would likely occur by 2025. However, Chinese carbon experts argue that the 2014 peak is unlikely. The government has promised to peak emissions by 2030, but international pressure may increase if China's targets appear too easy.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC says Ron Sim's offer to privatise OSIM is reasonable
summary: OCBC Investment Research recommends that OSIM International shareholders accept Ron Sim's voluntary unconditional cash offer to privatise the luxury massage chair maker at S$1.32 a share. Sim, who owns 68.31% of OSIM, is making the offer to take the company private. The offer price is S$1.30 a share excluding final dividends.

site_title: 12 dead in Chinese coal mine accident: report
summary: Twelve miners died in a coal mine accident in China's northeastern province of Jilin, according to state media. The accident occurred when coal gas flooded a colliery, and one miner was rescued. This incident highlights the dangers of China's coal mining industry, where industrial safety standards are often flouted. The country is the world's largest coal producer, and colliery accidents have claimed 931 lives in 2014, with some rights groups estimating higher figures due to under-reporting.

site_title: ZTE halted from trade after report of US export curbs
summary: ZTE Corp shares were halted from trade on the Hong Kong stock exchange after the US Department of Commerce was set to impose export restrictions on the Chinese company for allegedly violating sanctions on Iran. Suppliers would need to apply for licenses that are generally denied, making it difficult for ZTE to buy American-made equipment and parts. The company denied allegations of aiding espionage and is working to resolve concerns, but analysts predict significant supply problems and downward pressure on the stock.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.800 points to 1696.110 on Monday, driven by gains. The market saw 126 gainers versus 66 losers, with a trading volume of 65.01 million lots worth RM29.38 million.

site_title: United Continental chief back at helm
summary: United Continental's CEO Oscar Munoz will return to work on March 14 after a 5-month sick leave, following a heart transplant. Munoz took over as CEO in January 2016, replacing Jeffery Smisek. This marks a return to normalcy for the airline, which is the third-largest by traffic.

site_title: Asia: Stocks buoyant after US jobs, oil extends gains
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by a strong US jobs report and oil price gains. China's economic growth target was reaffirmed at 6.5-7.0% for the year, with Premier Li Keqiang pledging to loosen monetary policy and reform state-owned enterprises. US job creation added 242,000 jobs in February, easing concerns of a global recession. Energy firms, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, surged on the oil price recovery, which rose 1.8% in early trade.

site_title: Chinese MH370 relatives file suit in Beijing
summary: Relatives of 12 Chinese passengers on missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 filed suits against the company at a Beijing court on Monday, just one day before a legal deadline. The suits were filed in a small office at the Beijing Rail Transportation Court, with many relatives showing emotion as they deposited their documents. This move comes after a nearly five-year search for the plane, which disappeared on March 8, 2014.

site_title: Australia: Shares surge on commodities, bargain bounce; NZ holds strong
summary: Australian shares surged to a two-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 46.475 points to 5,136.5. The rally was driven by rebounding commodity prices, including iron ore above US$52 a tonne and copper to a four-month high. Resources stocks, including Fortescue Metals Group and BHP Billiton, led the gains. Energy stocks and banks also firmed, while New Zealand stocks held near-record levels.

site_title: China's forex reserves are stable, says central bank vice governor
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves are stable, according to Vice Governor Yi Gang, who stated they are "very stable" and the largest in the world. Reserves declined by $99.5 billion in January to $3.23 trillion, a record fall the previous month. Since mid-2014, reserves have shrunk by $762 billion, more than Switzerland's GDP.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OSIM, SingPost, IEV
summary: OSIM International's chairman and CEO, Ron Sim Chye Hock, has made a voluntary unconditional cash offer of S$1.32 per share to take the company private. Meanwhile, SingPost has completed its merger with US-based eCommerce logistics platform provider Jagged Peak. IEV Holdings' Vietnamese subsidiary has inaugurated a biomass plant in Vietnam, capable of producing 150 tonnes of rice husk briquettes per day.

site_title: Fight over sale of London Stock Exchange is about to get nasty
summary: A bidding war is expected for London Stock Exchange Group Plc as potential buyers, including CME Group Inc and Intercontinental Exchange Inc, may make unsolicited offers following LSE's merger talks with Deutsche Boerse AG. The deal could give one of the companies a commanding presence in Europe and create a company big enough to challenge CME's market-leading valuation. The stakes are high, with a potential combined market value of over $10 billion, and regulatory approval may be a roadblock to the deal.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday after Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 2.48 points to 2,839.48 on Monday, following a Wall Street rally on Friday. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial average closed at two-month highs, driven by a strong US jobs report and rising oil prices. Top gainers included Ezra Holdings, Noble, and Rex International. Trading volume was high, with 60.4 million shares changing hands worth S$84.6 million.

site_title: Two years on, MH370 families say search for missing jet must continue
summary: Families of MH370 passengers demand the two-year search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet continue beyond a June deadline, citing human error and incorrect initial drift models. New debris found off the African coast has rekindled hope, with relatives urging investigators to re-examine their approach. A meeting between Australia, Malaysia, and China will determine if the search will be extended, but families are pushing for the search to focus on the southeast African coast.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trading on Monday, driven by a strong US jobs report and investors' cautious optimism over China's economic growth outlook. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gained 0.64%, while Shanghai's benchmark Composite Index edged up 0.43%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.01%. The moves follow China's decision to lower its economic growth outlook for this year, which has investors weighing the implications for the region's markets.

site_title: SPH and StarHub to collaborate in ad sales, content creation, data analytics, marketing
summary: SPH and StarHub have signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on ad sales, content creation, data analytics, and marketing. The partnership aims to introduce new initiatives such as augmented mobile and television offerings and richer content across their media platforms. Several new initiatives will be announced in the coming months, with the companies citing strategic partnerships as a way to achieve innovation and reduce time to market.

images.alt_text: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and StarHub on Monday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to collaborate in areas of advertising sales, content creation, data analytics and marketing.

site_title: Former US President Carter says he no longer needs cancer treatments
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter, 91, says he no longer needs cancer treatments for melanoma that had spread to his liver and brain. He will continue to be observed by doctors but won't need immunotherapy treatment. If cancer returns, he will resume treatment at Emory University's Winship Cancer Institute. Carter shared his news at a Sunday school class in his hometown of Plains, Georgia.

site_title: Aeroports de Paris gets approval for stake buy in Vietnam airports firm
summary: Aeroports de Paris SA has received approval from Vietnam's transport ministry to buy a major stake in Airports Corporation of Vietnam (ACV), a state-run airport firm. The stake sale, valued at US$1.2 billion, will be completed in the third quarter of 2016. ACV operates all of Vietnam's major airports and initially offered a 20% stake to potential strategic partners after its initial public offering in December 2015. This move marks Aeroports de Paris SA as the sole strategic investor in ACV.

site_title: Ascott bags JTC lease for one-north serviced residence
summary: CapitaLand's The Ascott has secured a lease for a 50-unit serviced residence in Singapore's one-north business park. The property, currently operating as Citadines Fusionopolis Singapore, will be rebranded from April 1, 2016. Ascott's head of Singapore Cluster, Anthony Khoo, expects sustained demand from business executives seeking quality accommodation near one-north, which is expected to continue attracting top multinational corporations.

images.alt_text: Capitaland's serviced residence business unit, The Ascott, has snagged a lease award from JTC Corporation for a prime property in Singapore's one-north business park.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall on profit-taking in opening deals
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 0.35% and 0.53% for the benchmark Nikkei 225 and broader Topix index, respectively. Investors took profits after four days of gains, despite positive leads from Wall Street and rising oil prices. The Nikkei 225 lost 59.75 points to 16,955.03, while the Topix index fell 7.31 points to 1,368.04.

site_title: Hong Kong residential sales plunge 70% as slowdown intensifies
summary: Hong Kong residential home sales plummeted 70% in February, reaching a 25-year low, due to falling prices and economic uncertainty. Property prices have declined 10% since September highs, with uncertainty over the economy and interest-rate increases contributing to the slowdown. Analysts predict further price drops, with one forecasting a 30% decline this year. The Hong Kong government has ruled out relaxing property curbs, including extra stamp duties and mortgage caps, which have limited buying activity.

site_title: Former US first lady Nancy Reagan dies at 94
summary: Former US First Lady Nancy Reagan, the devoted wife of late President Ronald Reagan, died on March 6, 2016, at the age of 94 due to heart failure. She will be buried next to her husband at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California. Despite initial criticism for her influence and protectiveness, Reagan earned praise for her role in the "Just Say No" drug awareness campaign and her dedication to her husband, particularly in his final years with Alzheimer's disease. Tributes poured in from world leaders, including President Barack Obama and former President George H.W. Bush, praising her steadfast loyalty and guidance.

images.alt_text: Nancy Reagan, devoted wife and trusted confidante to late president Ronald Reagan who became the most ardent guardian of his legacy, died on Sunday, aged 94.

site_title: Najib vows 'we will continue' as Malaysia critics join forces
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has vowed that his government will continue to rule despite increased efforts to remove him from office. Najib, facing his biggest political crisis since coming to power seven years ago, attributed the government's focus on economic development to its mandate and majority in parliament. Critics, including former leader Mahathir Mohamad, have joined forces to call for Najib's removal, citing concerns over corruption and economic struggles. Najib has denied any wrongdoing, citing the closure of a graft probe and the return of $620 million in funds.

site_title: China's larger fiscal deficit ratio to prevent slide in growth
summary: China's Finance Minister Lou Jiwei announced that the country will run a 3% fiscal deficit ratio in 2016 to prevent a slide in economic growth and push forward with structural reform. The 2015 budget deficit was 2.4% of GDP, and reform of the tax system is progressing more slowly than expected. Lou also acknowledged that non-performing loans at banks are expected to rise "mildly" due to structural reform.

images.alt_text: A larger fiscal deficit ratio in 2016 will help China prevent a slide in economic growth and to push forward with structural reform, Finance Minister Lou Jiwei said on Monday.

site_title: Australia's watchdog appoints liquidator to wind up Sino Australia Oil & Gas
summary: Australia's markets watchdog appointed a liquidator to wind up Sino Australia Oil & Gas Ltd, a drilling services company, due to substantial and serious misconduct and mismanagement. A judge made this decision after proceedings against the company and its former chairman. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission will continue to oversee the liquidation process.

images.alt_text: Australia's markets watchdog on Monday said it has appointed a liquidator to wind up drilling services company Sino Australia Oil and Gas Ltd.

site_title: Indian farmers see Modi's budget as all promise, no delivery
summary: Indian farmers are disappointed with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's budget, which promises more aid to the countryside but fails to deliver. Despite doubling spending on agriculture and farmers' welfare to $5.3 billion, many farmers, like Ram Pal Singh, report receiving little to no relief from government assistance. Crop damage and low state purchase prices have worsened their plight, with some even considering selling their land. The budget's promises have failed to address the root issues of rural distress, and farmers are unlikely to support Modi's party in next year's election.

site_title: Sakae Hldgs to acquire majority stake in Chilean seafood trader
summary: Sakae Holdings, a Singapore-based food-and-beverage company, has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Chilean seafood trader Cocosa Export for US$3 million. The acquisition will give Sakae a 51% ownership stake and establish a direct presence in Chile and South America. The deal is expected to diversify Sakae's business and income base for future growth. The acquisition is part of Sakae's efforts to expand its overseas markets in food trading and distribution, as well as its raw materials supply chain.

site_title: Apple users targeted in first known Mac ransomware campaign
summary: Apple users are targeted in the first known Mac ransomware campaign, according to researchers at Palo Alto Networks. Hackers used a type of ransomware that encrypts data, then demands payment in digital currencies to retrieve it. This marks a departure from typical Windows-targeted ransomware attacks, which estimate to total hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The campaign highlights the growing threat of ransomware to Mac users, who are often overlooked in security efforts.

site_title: Alibaba, finance affiliate buy HK firm for China lotteries
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and its affiliate, Al Fortune Investment Holding Ltd, have agreed to spend HK$2.39 billion to buy control of Hong Kong-listed AGTech Holdings Ltd, boosting its lottery business in China. The acquisition, valued at S$424.3 million, will give Alibaba a 59.45% stake in the company, marking the e-commerce leader's return to China's lucrative lottery market after suspending operations due to government restrictions.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and its main financial affiliate will spend HK$2.39 billion (S$424.3 million) buying control of Hong Kong-listed AGTech Holdings Ltd to boost its lottery business in China.

site_title: Greece says EU migrant sharing is 'absolute emergency'
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has called for the urgent relocation of thousands of refugees to other EU countries due to a border blockade in Macedonia. The EU is set to push Turkey to agree on "large-scale" deportations of economic migrants from Greece. Greece is bracing for a fresh surge of migrant and refugee arrivals by the end of March, with over 33,000 refugees and migrants currently in the country, including 6,000 on the islands facing Turkey.

site_title: OSIM chief offers to buy out the company at S$1.32 per share
summary: OSIM International's chairman and CEO, Ron Sim Chye Hock, has made a voluntary unconditional cash offer to take the company private at S$1.32 per share, representing a 31.8% premium to the one-month volume-weighted average traded price. This comes after the company posted a 66% drop in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2015. Sim owns 68.31% of the company's shares and has enlisted Credit Suisse and Morgan Lewis Stamford as advisors to facilitate the privatization process.

site_title: Rising rents in Sydney matched by increase in homeless
summary: A recent "street count" in Sydney identified 486 homeless people, the highest figure since 2010, with a 25% increase from last year. Lord Mayor Clover Moore attributed the rise to a housing crisis, citing a 60% increase in mean rental prices and 48% growth in household incomes. 84% of low-income households in the area pay 30% of their income on housing. Mental illness and substance abuse are prevalent within the homeless community, with the city struggling to address the issue.

site_title: Oil rises as traders shut down short positions, US producers cut rig count
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as traders shut down short positions and US producers cut rig count for an 11th consecutive week, with front-month Brent crude futures up 36 cents to $39.08 per barrel. US shale producers reduced the rig count to 392, focusing on uncompleted wells amid low oil prices. The shift in sentiment, combined with a tightening supply outlook, is driving prices higher, although a slew of economic data releases in China may impact the rally.

images.alt_text: Oil prices opened strongly on Monday after rallying in the previous session, as tightening supplies supported the market and sentiment around a market recovery strengthened.

site_title: Email inventor Ray Tomlinson dies at 74
summary: Ray Tomlinson, the inventor of email, has died at 74. Tomlinson invented direct electronic messages between users on different machines in 1971, revolutionizing communication. Tributes poured in from the online world, with Google's Gmail team and Vint Cerf, a father of the Internet, lamenting his passing. Tomlinson's creation was first tested on ARPANET, the precursor to the modern Internet, and the first message was sent between two machines connected only through the network. The cause of death has not been confirmed.

images.alt_text: Ray Tomlinson, the American programmer widely credited with inventing email, has died. He was 74.

site_title: Head of business group resigns in Brexit row
summary: John Longworth, head of the British Chambers of Commerce, resigned after publicly backing Brexit, sparking a row over whether he was pressured to step down due to his pro-Brexit views. Despite the BCC's neutrality stance, Longworth's comments were seen as a betrayal by eurosceptic politicians, who accused Prime Minister David Cameron's office of exerting pressure. London Mayor Boris Johnson called the suspension "absolutely scandalous." The controversy has raised questions about the influence of politics on business groups and the implications for the UK's EU referendum.

site_title: EDF finance chief quits over British nuclear power plant plan: source
summary: French energy giant EDF's chief financial officer Thomas Piquemal has resigned over a disagreement on the company's plan to build Britain's first new nuclear power plant in decades at Hinkley Point. The dispute centered on the short-term feasibility of the £18-billion project, with Piquemal opposing rushing the plan amid union concerns and a high price tag. The project has been delayed, with EDF putting off a final investment decision, despite the British government's support for the project to ensure energy security.

site_title: Warren Buffett: Don't vote against America
summary: Warren Buffett urges Americans not to vote against the country, stating that the current generation of babies being born in America is the luckiest in history. With a GDP per capita of $56,000, they enjoy a significantly higher standard of living than previous generations. Buffett attributes this growth to increased efficiency and productivity, which will continue to drive economic growth. He notes that even those who may feel left behind by the market will still benefit from the increased output of goods and services. Buffett concludes that investing in America is a wise decision, citing the country's strong economic fundamentals and innovative spirit.

site_title: China's taste for beer to provide fizz for global brewing profits
summary: China's growing demand for high-end beers is expected to boost global brewing profits. The country accounts for half of the industry's global volume increase, but only 3% of brewers' profits. Small-scale brewers and global giants are tapping into the market, with Chinese consumers driving growth. This trend could help global brewing giants unlock frothier profits in the world's largest beer market, which is currently dominated by large-scale brewers.

site_title: UK factories pull out of slump, outlook still uncertain
summary: UK factories have ended a slump, with quarterly balances of new orders and output improving after a six-year low in late 2015. However, the sector still faces uncertainty due to the European Union referendum and expects a further pickup in the coming months. The EEF cut its growth forecasts for 2016 to 0.6% and overall economic growth to 1.9%, citing caution among factory managers due to the referendum. The Bank of England remains prepared to cut interest rates or expand its bond-buying programme if needed.

site_title: 2016's first EC launch outperforms recent projects
summary: Singapore's first EC launch, Wandervale, sold about 50% of its 534 units over the weekend, outperforming recent EC projects. The 99-year leasehold development in Choa Chu Kang attracted buyers with its average price of S$755 per square foot and proximity to the Choa Chu Kang MRT station. This success contrasts with recent EC launches, such as The Brownstone and Sol Acres, which saw lower sales figures. The strong performance may indicate that ECs can still attract buyers if priced and located correctly.

site_title: Iran billionaire sentenced to death for corruption
summary: Iranian billionaire Babak Zanjani has been sentenced to death for corruption, convicted of fraud and economic crimes after allegedly pocketing $2.8 billion. Zanjani, 41, was found guilty of working with the knowledge and backing of former President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's government. Two other defendants were also convicted and face the death penalty. Zanjani's trial was a rare public case in Iran, and he must repay money to the state and face the death penalty.

site_title: China will struggle to reach GDP targets till 2020: analysts
summary: China's GDP growth target for 2016-2020 is expected to be difficult to achieve unless the government trades reform for growth or polishes its data. Analysts say the country's economy is facing downward pressure, with record corporate debt and overcapacity. To reach its 6.5-7% growth target, China may need to loosen credit conditions and pile on debt, exacerbating imbalances and delaying reform. The government is reluctant to scrap the target, citing its legitimacy for one-party rule, but analysts recommend focusing on quality of life and solving social issues.

site_title: Business prospects: Boon or bane?
summary: Business prospects for 2016 are uncertain due to a global economic slowdown, but experts believe that investors can rebuild equity holdings in sectors with defensive characteristics, such as healthcare and IT. Digital transformation is expected to intensify, with businesses modernizing and automating to remain competitive. The Asean Economic Community will bring about growth opportunities, but retailers will face headwinds and must evolve to stay competitive. Despite the bleak outlook, industries such as human resources and talent management are expected to be resilient, and opportunities for growth will arise from the need for companies to adapt and innovate.

site_title: North Korea threatens pre-emptive nuclear strike on South, US
summary: North Korea threatened a "pre-emptive nuclear strike of justice" against South Korea and the US mainland if joint military drills proceed, following leader Kim Jong Un's order to place the nuclear arsenal on standby. The threat came after tough UN sanctions were imposed over North Korea's fourth nuclear test and long-range rocket launch.

site_title: Eviction economy stands in the way of decent housing in the US
summary: The US is plagued by a severe housing shortage, with three-quarters of low-income families unable to access government assistance. Instead, landlords like Tobin, a second-generation landlord, exploit poverty by charging high rents and offering low-quality housing. A universal housing voucher program would provide 30% of low-income families' income for rent, allowing them to break the cycle of poverty. This would lead to a significant decrease in evictions, family instability, and social problems. With an estimated $171 billion in homeowner tax benefits, implementing such a program would be feasible and would fundamentally change the face of poverty in the US.

site_title: Flash: Ron Sim makes unconditional cash offer of S$1.32 a share to privatise OSIM
summary: Ron Sim, CEO of OSIM, has made an unconditional cash offer of S$1.32 per share to privatize the company.

site_title: Short-term positive, but long-term negative?
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 7% rise last week, driven by a reserve ratio cut in China. The short-term positive trend may be offset by long-term concerns about the global economy, with Schroders trimming its global growth forecast to 2.4% for 2016. DBS's chief investment officer described the bounce as "technical" and noted that the negatives are structural, citing concerns about slowing economies and contracting corporate earnings. The US Federal Reserve's next meeting is scheduled for March 15-16, with market expectations suggesting a rate hike in April.

site_title: Volkswagen chairman, CEO knew of illicit software early, Bild reports
summary: Volkswagen chairman and CEO Martin Winterkorn was informed about the use of illicit emissions-control software in the US two weeks before the company's public disclosure on September 18, 2016. Winterkorn briefed the executive board on September 8, but the company's finance chief Hans Dieter Poetsch did not inform shareholders of the looming problem. Volkswagen's actions led to the resignation of Winterkorn and a significant loss of market value, with the company later defending its actions as a result of "interest in secrecy" and "no idea" of the expense until the US Environmental Protection Agency's statement.

site_title: Negative interest rates in Japan 'welcome': senior IMF official
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has introduced negative interest rates, a move welcomed by IMF Deputy Managing Director Mitsuhiro Furusawa as a step to achieve the BOJ's inflation target. The policy aims to counter deflation in Japan, which has been struggling with low inflation. Furusawa also expressed support for the G-20's commitment to use all policy tools to restore global growth and consult on exchange rate strategies. The move is seen as a significant step by the Japanese government to ensure the central bank's policies can be implemented smoothly.

site_title: Second possible MH370 plane part found in Reunion
summary: A resident in Reunion, French Indian Ocean, found a second possible piece from Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, a Boeing 777, measuring 40x20cm with a blue mark. The object has the same lightweight "honeycomb" construction as the previously found flaperon piece. The find was made while cleaning a beach and was handed over to police, who are now analyzing it. The discovery comes three days after a suspected MH370 debris was found in Mozambique, and an international team of investigators is set to issue a statement on the second anniversary of the plane's disappearance.

site_title: Overseas push critical for growth
summary: Singapore is seeking to expand its economy through mega trade pacts, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. To succeed, smaller firms must be competitive in the global market, with institutional and policy support crucial. The government can provide consulting expertise and improved infrastructure for trade finance, but ultimately, firms must take charge of their own destiny. By repositioning its economy to tap into its advantages, such as high technology and financial markets, Singapore aims to drive growth and stay competitive in the global economy.

site_title: Stock rally to hinge on oil prices and Fed meeting
summary: US stocks rose last week, driven by a strong February jobs report and a rebound in oil futures, reaching near the psychologically significant 2,000 level. The Federal Reserve's March 16 meeting is expected to be decisive, with some suspecting the rally could falter if pronouncements from oil-producing nations or the Fed fail to pay off. Despite a rate hike being highly unlikely, the strong data could lead to a more hawkish statement from the central bank, or firmer promises of rate hikes later this year.

site_title: Johor to be new economic powerhouse: Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that four mega projects in Johor will propel the southern state into a new economic powerhouse. The projects include Forest City, Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail, Gemas-Johor Baru double tracking, and Pengerang oil and gas hub. Najib said the projects will be catalysts for Johor and the country's growth, with special incentives for Forest City, including duty-free status and corporate tax breaks. He also highlighted Johor's strong investment growth, with RM200 billion in cumulative investment and RM27.96 billion in domestic investment last year.

site_title: Aussie rally takes a breather, US dollar nurses losses
summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.3% to US$0.7420 on Monday, trimming its 4.4% weekly gain, as investors took profits. The move followed data showing an unexpected acceleration in the Australian economy, reducing interest rate cut expectations. China's National People's Congress acknowledged a tough battle to maintain 6.5% growth over five years. The US dollar index fell 0.3% after a volatile reaction to payrolls data, while the euro rose to US$1.1000.

site_title: Copper hits highest in nearly four months as US$ falls
summary: Copper prices reached nearly four-month highs due to US data showing strong jobs growth with low wages, reducing the threat of early interest rate hikes. Average hourly earnings fell 3 cents in February despite a 242,000 job increase.

images.alt_text: Operations at the ENAMI's (National Mining Company) copper cathodes plant at Tierra Amarilla town, near Copiapo city, north of Santiago, Chile. Funds are actively buying copper.

site_title: Singaporean women desire international mobility at work: PwC survey
summary: A PwC survey of almost 4,000 professionals, including 104 from Singapore, found that Singaporean women desire international mobility opportunities at work but believe they have unequal access to these opportunities compared to men.

site_title: Intra-region trade links in Asean closer than in EU
summary: Asean's intra-regional trade intensity index reading of 3.54 surpasses the EU's 2.04, revealing a denser trade network within the bloc. Asean nations are 73.5% more intertwined than EU countries. This suggests that despite low total trade value, Asean member states have strong trade linkages with each other, making their regional trade more interconnected than initially thought.

site_title: Natixis in a sweet spot amid the oil market rout
summary: Natixis, a French bank, has benefited from the current oil market rout, particularly the contango trading opportunity, which has lifted its 2015 revenue. Global traders such as Glencore and Vitol have snapped up oil barrels at lower spot prices, storing them on tankers and selling them on forward contracts, resulting in hefty gains. This has placed Natixis in a "sweet spot" as it has a significant presence in global traders and has grown at a three-year average of 20% despite temporary setbacks in the oil market.

site_title: Trump stays ahead as Cruz raises pressure with split decision
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Ted Cruz secured split decisions in four states, with Trump maintaining his front-runner status. Hillary Clinton won a significant lead in the Democratic nomination, defeating Bernie Sanders in Louisiana. Trump's victory in the Louisiana primary and caucuses in Kentucky exposed unrest among party conservatives. Cruz's wins in Kansas and Maine show he may rally support from conservatives pushing back against Trump's rhetoric and changing positions.

site_title: FAA upgrade takes a toll on residents' sleep
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration's NextGen system, which modernizes air traffic control, has exacerbated airport noise complaints nationwide, particularly in Washington, DC, and surrounding areas. Since its rollout, noise complaints have jumped dramatically, with San Francisco International Airport experiencing a 10-fold increase and residents in Washington, DC, reporting a significant rise in noise pollution. FAA officials acknowledge the issue and are re-examining noise measurement standards, but progress has been slow, leaving residents frustrated and seeking relief through lawsuits and advocacy. A working group is trying to find a compromise, but doubts remain about the FAA's commitment.

images.alt_text: FAA administrator Michael Huerta said the agency is re-examining how it measures noise, noting that current standards date from the 1970s.

site_title: Bringing diversity to exclusive British schools
summary: Some of Britain's elite private schools are taking in more students from disadvantaged backgrounds to combat societal polarization. Patrick Derham, a former headmaster, initiated this change after being offered a free place at a private school at age 14. He aims to repay the faith in his potential by bringing more students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including young black teenagers, to these institutions, potentially changing the course of their lives.

site_title: Africa beckons, as Surbana Jurong eyes 40-60% of revenue from overseas in 3-5 years
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based property development company, aims to generate 40-60% of its revenue from overseas markets in the next 3-5 years. Following the securing of two major contracts in Africa, the company is expanding its international operations. Teo Eng Cheong, former CEO of International Enterprise Singapore, has taken on the role of chief executive of international operations at Surbana Jurong, driving the company's international expansion plans.

site_title: Banks in Latin America pin hopes on Argentina bond surge
summary: Argentina is set to issue up to $15 billion in bonds, the largest bond offering from an emerging markets borrower, after a historic deal with principal holdouts was reached last week. The deal paves the way for Argentina's first bond in 15 years, with a possible sale starting as early as April. This move is expected to boost Latin American debt capital markets and help bankers struggling to generate business in the region.

site_title: No-frills carrier Frontier Airlines said to hire Barclays, Deutsche Bank for IPO
summary: Frontier Airlines, a no-frills carrier, has hired Barclays, Deutsche Bank, and JPMorgan Chase as underwriters for an initial public offering (IPO). Citigroup will also be involved in the process. The IPO is a significant move for the private equity firm Indigo Partners, which owns Frontier. The exact details of the IPO are still private, but it is expected to be a major event for the airline industry.

site_title: Facebook may pay more UK tax in accounting change
summary: Facebook plans to alter its tax structure in the UK, reporting sales linked to British operations through its local subsidiary instead of its Irish unit. This change, effective early April, will likely result in the company paying significantly more British tax. In 2014, Facebook paid a mere $6,100 in British corporation tax, compared to an average British worker's income tax. The move follows changes in UK tax laws and comes as other US tech companies, such as Google and Amazon, face investigations over tax practices in Europe.

site_title: Asia's 'infrastructure wars' move into new theatre
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has signed a co-financing agreement with the Eurasian Development Bank (EDB) to invest in Central Asian projects, escalating the "infrastructure wars" in Asia. The move comes after the launch of the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) in January, which is expected to play a key role in providing infrastructure for the Eurasian continent. The agreement increases competition between the ADB and EDB, with both banks vying for influence in the region's infrastructure development.

site_title: Relationship app Peeple to launch on March 7
summary: The relationship app Peeple, initially met with criticism for allowing users to publicly rate acquaintances without their consent, will launch on March 7 with significant changes. The new app will require users to opt-in for reviews, and those being reviewed can hide negative comments. This iteration is compared to LinkedIn endorsements, but also carries PR baggage. The app's original plan to allow users to post public reviews without opting out sparked outrage and a petition to ban the app, but the updated version aims to mitigate concerns around abuse and stalking.

site_title: Determining interested persons & related parties
summary: Directors of companies face a specific type of conflict of interest when conducting transactions with related parties, including interested persons and related parties. These transactions can arise from business relationships and may be subject to laws, regulations, and corporate governance best practices to ensure fair play and transparency. The objective of Chapter 9 of the SGX-ST Listing Rules is to prevent interested persons from influencing transactions that may adversely affect the company's interests, while the Singapore Financial Reporting Standard 24 focuses on disclosure of related party transactions in financial statements. Effective management of these conflicts requires prompt and comprehensive disclosure, as well as robust processes for identification and approval.

site_title: Blackstone expects lower property returns as CMBS falters
summary: Blackstone expects lower US commercial property returns due to capital market volatility and muted economic growth. Global head of real estate Jon Gray said rates of return are coming down, with investment yields at "very low" levels. Blackstone, the largest private equity real estate investor, anticipates higher cap rates as it sells investments, while remaining bullish on US housing, particularly single-family rentals, which have seen rent gains of about 5% and occupancy at 97%.

site_title: Shanghai property market is 'overheated'
summary: Shanghai's property market has become "overheated" due to a surge in residential housing prices, according to the city's Communist Party chief, Han Zheng. Residential home prices in Shanghai jumped 2.2% in January, the largest increase since 2013. The city's government plans to strengthen housing regulations without providing details. In contrast, the governor of Guangdong province is drafting a plan to allow state-owned enterprises to purchase homes to reduce inventory. The property market in Shenzhen has seen the biggest boom, rising 52% in January from a year earlier.

site_title: Intel's Pentium bug fix proposed as solution for dark pools
summary: A London-based technology firm, Aesthetic Integration Ltd, has proposed a solution for dark pools in financial markets, suggesting that regulators use mathematical models and code to test trading systems, similar to Intel's method for detecting bugs in microchips. This approach, known as formal verification, could help identify discrepancies and improve transparency. The company has demonstrated its system using UBS Group AG's dark pool and claims it can find more discrepancies than existing methods, following recent fines imposed on several banks.

site_title: Hieronymus Bosch makes one hell of a homecoming
summary: Hieronymus Bosch's posthumous homecoming is marked by two blockbuster exhibitions in Hertogenbosch, Netherlands, drawing tens of thousands to admire his unique and often disturbing artwork. The exhibitions, which include 17 of his paintings and 19 drawings, were made possible through a massive research and conservation project. Bosch's works, created during a time of great tension in the late medieval period, depict a hellish world where evil is omnipresent and divine justice is unyielding. Despite debates over authorship, the exhibitions showcase the enduring influence of Bosch's imagery, which continues to captivate audiences and inspire artists today.

site_title: Obama administration split over encryption policy
summary: The US Justice Department's decision to take action against Apple over access to encrypted data on an iPhone used in the San Bernardino attacks has sparked a split within the Obama administration. Despite FBI Director James Comey's efforts to convince other departments to join the fight, officials from the Commerce, State, and White House Office of Science and Technology Policy oppose the idea of providing law enforcement with a "back door" into technology products. The National Security Agency and Department of Homeland Security have also opposed the move, citing concerns over heightening distrust of American products overseas and driving terrorists to seek foreign-made encryption.

site_title: Pilot shortage hits mid-sized, regional US airlines
summary: US mid-sized and regional airlines are facing a severe pilot shortage, threatening the broader aviation industry. The labour shortfall has led to cancelled flights, impacting smaller airports and affecting larger companies like United Airlines and Delta Air Lines. Regional carriers such as Mesa Airlines and Silver Airways have been hit hard, with some, like Republic Airways, filing for bankruptcy. Industry insiders cite longer working hours, poor compensation, and industry turnover as contributing factors. To address the issue, some carriers are boosting pilot compensation and offering bonuses for referrals.

site_title: Low oil prices put strains on Gulf Arab states' currency pegs
summary: Gulf Arab states' currency pegs against the dollar are under strain due to low oil prices, but analysts say they are unlikely to abandon the policy yet. GCC members, except Qatar, have raised interest rates to maintain the pegs, despite economic contractions. Maintaining the pegs is costly, depleting forex reserves, and the longer economic divergence continues, the more sense it makes to move to a flexible exchange rate regime, experts say. The policy brings financial stability and certainty, but also has a cost, such as higher inflation and falling living standards.

site_title: The rise and fall of a commodities giant
summary: Willem Kooyker's commodities giant, Blenheim Capital Management LLC, has seen its assets plummet nearly 85% from $9.1 billion in 2011 to $1.5 billion, largely due to an underestimated commodities collapse. Despite being the world's largest commodities-focused hedge fund at its peak, the firm has struggled with returns, with four out of the past five years experiencing losses. Kooyker, 73, underestimated the economic troubles in China and never thought prices would fall so far, so fast. Investors have pulled billions of dollars out, and other commodities specialists are also suffering, with the world's top 10 hedge funds managing $10 billion in assets, down from $20 billion in 2008.

site_title: Oil's squeeze spreads from Gulf states to banks
summary: Gulf states' economies are struggling due to low oil prices, forcing them to borrow and impacting regional banks. Oil prices have fallen from over $100 to below $30 a barrel in 18 months, causing Middle Eastern countries to borrow to prop up their economies. International investors are avoiding the Gulf region's debt, making it difficult for banks to raise capital. As a result, banks are struggling to meet local regulatory requirements, with some plans to raise capital on ice. Gulf banks are facing a dilemma between borrowing at higher costs or risking falling short of stricter requirements.

site_title: Nike under scrutiny over stolen payments for Kenya's runners
summary: Nike is under scrutiny over allegations of bribing Kenyan athletics officials to secure sponsorship deals. The company agreed to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in honorariums and a one-time $500,000 "commitment bonus" to support poor Kenyan athletes. However, an ex-employee of Kenya's athletics federation claims the money was used as a bribe to influence contract decisions. Nike denies wrongdoing, but Kenyan authorities have launched an investigation and suspended three officials accused of taking the money. The case raises questions about Nike's business practices and whether the US company intentionally made it easy for officials to pocket the money.

site_title: A Brexit could hurt currency, trigger credit downgrades
summary: A Brexit could lead to a weaker UK currency and trigger credit downgrades, as the country would lose leverage to negotiate trade deals and regulatory standards. The EU would also lose a major budget contributor and a key voice for free markets. The UK's services sector would be particularly affected, while the EU would face economic challenges from losing a leading financial center. Economists predict the UK would be economically worse off in the end.

images.alt_text: A leave vote also poses risks to the London property market as at least some corporate office demand is based on access to the EU's single market.

site_title: LSE to launch derivatives market despite merger talks with rival
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) plans to launch its derivatives market, CurveGlobal Ltd, despite merger talks with Deutsche Boerse AG and potential rival Intercontinental Exchange Inc. CurveGlobal is designed to compete with Deutsche Boerse and ICE, aiming to achieve cross-margining by bringing clearinghouses together. LSEG CEO Xavier Rolet confirmed the project's launch will proceed unaffected by merger plans, with the market expected to start trading later this year. The move aims to diversify LSEG's offerings and compete in the European derivatives market.

site_title: Omaha annual meeting to be webcast
summary: Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger will webcast their annual meeting on April 30, marking the duo's entry into the 21st century. The event will feature interviews with managers and shareholders, followed by Q&A sessions. The webcast aims to reduce attendance, which reached a record 40,000 last year, and also allows shareholders to monitor the duo's well-being and investment habits, including their diet. The meeting will be available at https://finance.yahoo.com/brklivestream at 9am Central Daylight Time.

site_title: Johor's Forest City now a duty-free zone
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has announced Forest City, a 1,386-hectare mixed-use development in Johor, as a duty-free zone. The move aims to attract investors and tourists, offering RM175 billion in foreign direct investment by 2035 and 220,000 job opportunities for Malaysians. The project, developed by Country Garden and Esplanade Danga 88, will also feature a duty-free shopping mall set to open by the end of 2016. Tax incentives for environment-conscious initiatives and companies in the tourism, health, and education sectors were also announced.
