A wing part and debris found off Madagascar are the only clues, but they offer little information on the plane's fate. The Malaysian government and airline argue they have no liability due to restructuring, but families fear they won't receive damages or compensation from Malaysia Airlines.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.29 points to close at 1,692.49 on Friday. The stock market saw 1.78 billion lots valued at RM2.16 billion traded, with 334 gains and 463 losses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore stocks rose 7% on Friday, driven by Noble Group's 10% gain despite being dropped from the Straits Times Index. Singapore Airlines will take full control of budget airline Tiger Airways after its share offer closes on Friday. Global private equity buyouts increased 5% in 2015, but competition awaits. The SPDR STI ETF was the most active ETF month-to-date, and Singapore Airlines' stock rose as the national carrier's share offer for Tiger Airways closes.

site_title: Messaging app Line plans up to US$3b dual IPO in NY and Tokyo
summary: Messaging app operator Line Corp plans an initial public offering of up to $3 billion in New York and Tokyo, with Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and Nomura working on the deal. The listing is expected to take place before the end of summer in the northern hemisphere. Line Corp is owned by Naver Corp, South Korea's largest web portal operator, which had previously put off the IPO until earnings and market conditions improved. The company's CFO had said last August that the IPO would be delayed until then.

site_title: Hong Kong home sales hit record lows in first two months of year
summary: Hong Kong home sales reached record lows in the first two months of 2016, with January and February sales volumes being the lowest on record since 1996. January sales of 2,045 units and February sales of 1,807 units were significantly lower than previous months. The total value of sales also decreased, with January sales totaling HK$15.8 billion and February sales totaling HK$11.8 billion, marking the lowest values since the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009, respectively. The sluggish sales are attributed to the slowing Hong Kong and Chinese economies.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates falls 10%: source
summary: Asia-Europe container freight rates fell 10.1% to US$231 per 20-foot container (TEU) in the week ended March 4, 2016, marking the second lowest rate since 2009. This was the eighth consecutive week of declines, with the average rate this year at US$529.43 per TEU, half the average of the same period last year.

site_title: Account wins help ad group WPP secure strong end to 2015
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, reported its best growth in 2015, driven by strong demand in North America, Britain, and western Europe. The company secured 5.6 billion pounds (S$11 billion) in new business, putting it at the top of the league table for new work for the fourth year in a row. Account wins from major clients such as Unilever, L'Oreal, and Tesco contributed to the growth, solidifying WPP's position as a leader in the advertising industry.

site_title: France did better on its deficit last year than planned, minister says
summary: France's public deficit in 2015 came in lower than expected at 70.5 billion euros, beating the government's target of 3.8% of economic output. The deficit was reduced due to economic growth of 1.1%, boosted by cheap oil prices and lower interest rates. The central government's expenditures fell by 1.5% last year, contributing to the lower deficit. Finance Minister Michel Sapin stated that the target was not only met but exceeded.

site_title: Air France jet in near-miss with drone: air investigation agency
summary: An Air France Airbus A320 narrowly avoided colliding with a drone while approaching Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport on February 19. The co-pilot noticed the drone on the left side and disconnected the automatic pilot, performing an avoidance manoeuvre. The drone passed under the left wing, about five meters below. The incident was described as "serious" by the French aviation investigation agency (BEA). This incident highlights the increasing threat of civilian drones to commercial aviation safety.

site_title: China: Stocks rise for 4th day, aided by banking heavyweights
summary: China stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, driven by a surge in banks amid speculation of government-backed investors stabilizing the market. The CSI300 index rose 1.2% to 3,093.89, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.5% to 2,874.15 points. This marked the largest weekly gain in over two months, as the Shenzhen start-up board ChiNext collapsed 5.3% due to concerns of a rival board launch. The banking sector's 4.3% jump offset the impact of the small-cap tumble.

site_title: Malaysia alliance demands removal of scandal-hit PM
summary: Leaders from Malaysia's political spectrum have joined forces to call for the removal of scandal-hit Prime Minister Najib Razak, amid a festering corruption crisis. A joint statement, endorsed by heavyweights from the ruling party, opposition, and civil society groups, urges Malaysians to unite against Najib's government. The move is seen as a dramatic escalation of the crisis, which has been ongoing for months. The statement does not specify how Najib should be removed, but emphasizes the need for collective action to save the country.

site_title: Japan PM Abe taps economist Sakurai to replace BOJ dissenter on board
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe nominated economist Makoto Sakurai to replace dissenter Sayuri Shirai on the Bank of Japan's board, amid controversy over the central bank's recently adopted negative-rate strategy. Sakurai, an international finance researcher, won parliamentary confirmation and is expected to follow the Kuroda line, with little known views on monetary policy. The move aims to shape the board ahead of the April policy meeting, where Sakurai could join.

site_title: SPDR STI ETF the most active ETF month-to-date
summary: The Singapore Exchange reported that the SPDR Straits Times Index (STI) ETF was the most active ETF for the month-to-date, reflecting a recovery in Singapore stocks. The STI gained almost 11% over the last four weeks, recouping nearly all its losses since the start of the year. Global equity markets are also rebounding, driven by improving US economic data and increased stimulus in China.

site_title: Japan to suspend construction for US base relocation in Okinawa
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has announced that the government will suspend construction work for the planned relocation of a US airbase in Okinawa, following a court-mediated settlement plan. The move comes after a long-standing dispute between the central government and local authorities over the base's relocation. The government aims to move the Futenma airbase to the Henoko area, while the Okinawa Governor wants the base off the island. Abe stated that the government's stance has not changed, but will engage in dialogue to reach an amicable solution.

site_title: SE Asia: Most markets higher, Singapore leads gains on the week
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets rose on Friday, with Singapore leading gains, as investors turned cautious after weak January exports data. The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 1.5% for its sixth straight day, poised for a nearly 7% weekly gain. Other markets, such as Kuala Lumpur and Vietnam, also posted gains, while Indonesia and the Philippines fell. The rally was attributed to continued gains in global markets and commodity prices, with investors expecting solid job gains in the US non-farm payrolls data, but not strong enough for rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia's Jan exports unexpectedly fall 2.8% y-o-y, oil shipments drop
summary: Malaysia's January exports fell 2.8% year-over-year, the first decline in eight months, due to weak global economic conditions and a drop in oil and gas shipments. This contradicts economists' expectations of a 2.5% growth. The decline in exports was also influenced by weak global commodity prices and a slowdown in China, Malaysia's largest trading partner.

site_title: Scandal-hit VW gives new dates for 2015 results, shareholders' meet
summary: Volkswagen has rescheduled its 2015 annual results and shareholder meeting due to the ongoing emissions-cheating scandal. The earnings news conference will now take place on April 28, and the annual shareholder meeting will be held on June 22 in Hanover, Germany. The company has postponed the original dates previously set for March 10.

site_title: Cathay Pacific seen posting wider hedging loss as oil drops
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd reported an unrealized fuel-hedging loss of HK$7.42 billion as of end-June, despite crude oil's plunge to its cheapest level in over a decade. The airline's hedging losses may balloon to HK$8.4 billion, affecting its profit forecasts. Cathay Pacific, like other airlines, hedged fuel at prices higher than the spot market, causing losses. The company's cost base is higher than its competitors, making it less profitable from the lower oil prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares notch up biggest weekly gain of 2016, NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares reached a two-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing 8.9 points higher, or 0.2%, at 5,090.0. The benchmark added 4.3% for the week, its best since October 2015. New Zealand stocks also hit a record peak, with the S&P/NZX 50 index rising 37.3 points, or 0.6%, to finish at 6,418.1, up 3.1% for the week. The gains were driven by commodity price increases and sector performance in mining and finance.

site_title: CAAS unveils tougher flight tracking rules for planes
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has introduced stricter flight-tracking rules for Singapore-registered aircraft, set to take effect in July 2016. The new rules require planes to establish tracking capabilities that provide location updates every 15 minutes, applicable to aircraft weighing over 27,000kg and carrying over 19 passengers. This measure aims to enhance air safety and security.

site_title: WongPartnership names another new deputy chairman
summary: WongPartnership has appointed Rachel Eng, former joint managing partner, as deputy chairman alongside current deputy chairman Tan Chee Meng. Eng handles IPOs, corporate advisory, and regulatory work, while Ng Wai King remains managing partner and Alvin Yeo continues as chairman.

images.alt_text: Singapore law firm WongPartnership's former joint managing partner, Rachel Eng, has become the deputy chairman at the practice, alongside current deputy chairman Tan Chee Meng.

site_title: Hot stocks: Keppel, SembMarine, DBS gain amid hopes of stable oil prices
summary: Shares of Keppel Corporation, Sembcorp Marine, and banks like DBS surged on Friday amid hopes for stable oil prices. Keppel gained 3.4% and SembMarine rose 3% as crude oil futures rose 0.35% to $34.69. Analysts expect oil prices to hit $50 by year-end, while US fund manager Franklin Resources became a substantial shareholder of SembMarine. Other banks, including OCBC and UOB, also rose on the day.

site_title: Foxconn said near finalising deal approved by Sharp's board
summary: Foxconn Technology Group is near finalizing a US$6 billion takeover deal for Sharp Corp, despite initial concerns over contingent liabilities. The deal, which would see Foxconn pay 500 billion yen for a majority stake in Sharp, appears to be less complicated than initially thought. Sharp's cash is dwindling, with 208.5 billion yen at the end of December, and the company faces the expiration of 510 billion yen in credit lines and loans on March 31. The deal may proceed as early as Monday if Foxconn and Sharp reach final terms next week.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge higher as dealers eye key US jobs report
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, closing 0.32% higher at 17,014.78, driven by anticipation of a key US jobs report and an annual policy meeting of China's leaders. The Nikkei 225 and Topix indices gained 54.62 and 6.30 points, respectively. Investors await the US jobs report, which could impact global markets, and are also watching US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australia: Shares make hefty weekly gains, NZ stocks hit record high
summary: Australian shares rose to a two-month peak, up 0.3% or 16.4 points to 5,098.1, driven by gains in commodity prices and resource stocks. New Zealand stocks also reached a record high, up 3.1% or 39.06 points. Gains were led by BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals, while banks and medical sectors were out of favor. The benchmark is up 4.5% for the week, with the next target being 5,183.63, a 76.4% retracement of January-February losses.

site_title: Olympics: Latest Tokyo stadium problem - where to put the cauldron?
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers face a new challenge as they struggle to determine the location of the Olympic cauldron due to concerns over a potential fire risk. The cauldron, a key element of the Games, was not factored into the new stadium design, which features wooden roof panels. Olympics minister Toshiaki Endo admitted that the issue was overlooked, and a solution must be found by April. The problem highlights the ongoing issues with the 2020 Olympic stadium project, which has been plagued by delays and cost overruns.

site_title: China defence spending to rise '7 to 8%' in 2016: official
summary: China's defence spending is expected to rise 7-8% in 2016, according to a top official. This marks a lower growth margin compared to previous years. The announcement comes as Beijing asserts its territorial claims in the South China Sea. The increase in military spending is part of China's efforts to assert its national interests.

site_title: Developed markets still not expensive: Rothschild
summary: Rothschild Wealth Management's global investment strategist Kevin Gardiner says developed-world stocks, excluding energy and mining, are not expensive. Profits are "looking OK" in the US, driven by higher incomes and a cautious consumer. He notes Asian economies are stabilizing and fears of another 1997 Asian financial crisis are premature. Gardiner is cautiously optimistic, particularly if the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates, and is adding energy-sector cyclicals to portfolios. He also recommends holding consumer stocks, including healthcare names, for the long term. Valuations in emerging markets have come down.

site_title: Swiss Franc coin that buys a bratwurst becomes target of crooks
summary: Swiss authorities face a surge in forgeries of the 5-franc coin, a valuable piece of metal money circulated daily. The counterfeiters aim to profit from the coin's high value, with the 1,000-franc bill also being linked to illicit activities. The rise in coin forgeries has caused a headache for Swissminth, the coinage department. The issue highlights the challenges faced by Swiss authorities in maintaining the security of their currency, with the 5-franc coin being particularly vulnerable to counterfeiting.

site_title: PBOC vice governor expects level of forex reserves to stabilise
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves, the world's largest, are expected to stabilize as expectations on the yuan become steady, according to Yi Gang, a vice governor of the central bank. Reserves declined by $99.5 billion in January to $3.23 trillion, a record fall the previous month. Since mid-2014, reserves have shrunk by $762 billion, more than the GDP of Switzerland. A Reuters poll suggests reserves likely fell for a fourth straight month in February, easing to $3.2 trillion. The stabilization of reserves is seen as a positive sign for the Chinese economy.

site_title: Australia search team still 'hopeful' as MH370 hunt nears end
summary: Australian authorities remain hopeful of finding the missing Malaysia Airlines plane MH370 as the search effort nears its end. Despite two years of searching over 85,000 square kilometers of the Indian Ocean, no wreckage has been found. A two-meter-long flaperon wing part was discovered last year, and suspected debris in Mozambique may be another breakthrough. The search is expected to conclude by June or July, but relatives of passengers are urging authorities to continue searching if "credible new information" emerges.

site_title: At 100, BMW sees radical new future in world of driverless cars
summary: BMW is shifting its focus towards driverless cars, aiming to revolutionize the automotive industry. The company plans to overhaul its research and development, with half of its R&D staff becoming computer programmers to develop self-driving car technology. BMW aims to be the "most intelligent car" and compete with Alphabet, the parent company of Google. This radical change marks a significant shift in the company's 100-year history, with the goal of creating a future where customers are mere passengers and the cars do the driving.

site_title: No plan to cut rates further now: BOJ's Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated he is not considering further rate cuts, despite negative interest rates adopted in January to achieve a 2% inflation target. The economy is "a living thing" that will be monitored for risks, and policy adjustments will be made as needed. Kuroda's comments follow Japan's efforts to reflate the economy and meet its inflation target.

site_title: Attacks escalate as Trump clashes with rivals
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump clashed with rivals at a Republican debate, unleashing fiery and off-color rhetoric. Despite the intense criticism, Trump's rivals acknowledged they would support the party's eventual nominee. The debate saw personal attacks, with Trump referencing his genitals and Rubio's hands. Other contenders, including Mitt Romney and Ted Cruz, criticized Trump's fitness for the presidency, with Romney calling him a "phony" and a "fraud." The debate marked a pivotal moment in the campaign, with Trump seemingly on a glide path to becoming the Republican standard-bearer.

site_title: ANZ bank taken to court by regulator over alleged rate rigging
summary: Australia's securities regulator has initiated civil penalty proceedings against ANZ Bank for allegedly manipulating the nation's benchmark interest rate. The regulator alleges ANZ Bank traded to create an artificial price for bank bills on 44 days from March 2010 to May 2012, seeking to maximize profits or minimize losses. ANZ Bank will "vigorously defend" the action, while the regulator seeks declarations, pecuniary penalties, and an order requiring the bank to implement a compliance program.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai mulls new quasi-sovereign fund to boost industries
summary: Taiwan's President-elect Tsai Ing-wen is considering establishing a new quasi-sovereign wealth fund to boost emerging industries. The fund, with the government as the largest shareholder, will focus on key sectors like biotechnology, smart machinery, and green energy. The plan aims to nurture growth in industries hit by a global trade slowdown, with the goal of keeping the central government deficit below 3% of GDP. The fund's investments will be made by local and foreign investors, with a focus on innovative financing mechanisms to utilize Taiwan's excess savings.

site_title: Oil prices rise on talk of Russia meeting
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Friday after Nigerian oil minister Emmanuel Ibe Kachikwu announced a meeting of key crude producers in Russia on March 20 to discuss a proposed output freeze. The meeting predicts a "dramatic price movement" and follows a week of gains for the battered commodity. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The meeting aims to address the global supply glut and slow down the global economy, which has been affecting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose in Asia Friday after Nigeria said key crude producers plan to meet in Russia later this month to discuss a proposed output freeze.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge down but headed for 3rd week of gains
summary: South Korean stocks edged down 0.3% to 1,952.05, despite being headed for their third consecutive week of gains. The decline followed a two-day rally, with foreign investors extending their net-buying spree. The stabilizing commodities prices boosted the appeal of risk assets, but a sharp decline in shipping firm Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd weighed on the market. Global commodities markets and central bank policy direction will dominate the mood next week, according to a strategist.

site_title: Snapchat raises US$175m from Fidelity in latest round of funding: WSJ
summary: Snapchat Inc has raised $175 million in fresh funding from Fidelity Investments, valuing the company at $16 billion, the same valuation as a year ago. Fidelity bought shares at $30.72 per share, the same price as when it bought shares last March. The funding follows a partnership between Snapchat and Viacom, which granted Viacom exclusive rights to sell advertising around Snapchat's content.

site_title: Global private equity buyouts up 5% in 2015, but more competition awaits: Bain
summary: Global private equity buyouts saw a 5% increase in 2015 to US$282 billion, with deal values between $5 billion and $10 billion rising. However, competition and deal-making pressure have intensified, leading to a 14% decline in deal count. The number of new buyout funds fell 11% to US$175 billion, but the percentage of funds meeting fundraising targets reached a pre-crisis high. Experts, including Suvir Varma, warn that PE firms must transform asset values to achieve attractive payoffs, citing the need for more aggressive deal-making and a shift towards concentrated investments.

site_title: Asia: Stocks swing before China leaders gather, US jobs data
summary: Asian stocks surged, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index up 4.7% for the week, ahead of a Chinese leaders' meeting and US jobs data. Energy shares in the US lifted declines, while oil prices reached an eight-week high. Futures on the Hang Seng Index rose 0.4%, and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.7% for its biggest three-day gain since November. Analysts expect China to unveil significant fiscal spending measures, boosting growth expectations.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA slips after CEO cautions over demand for premium seats
summary: Singapore Airlines shares dropped 0.78% to S$11.46 after CEO Goh Choon Phong expressed caution over demand for premium seats due to global economic headwinds. Despite this, the airline's Business Class demand remains stable. The carrier is set to take full control of budget airline Tiger Airways after its general offer closes on Friday. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research, remain cautious on the airline's hedging policy and yields on key routes to Europe.

site_title: China: Hong Kong stocks extend gains at open, Shanghai dips
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.55% in early trade, following a Wall Street rally, while Shanghai fell 0.39% after a three-day surge. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,052.10, and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.50%. The Shanghai composite index declined to 2,848.54. The decline in Shanghai follows a three-day surge, while Hong Kong's gains are attributed to the US jobs data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.720 points to 1686.480, amid a decrease in 30.8 million lots worth RM8.59 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 51.

site_title: Romney leads anti-Trump charge as conservatives stew
summary: Conservative Republicans are divided on whether to support Donald Trump's presidential bid, with some leaders, operatives, and voters fearing the party's future under his divisive leadership. Former nominee Mitt Romney and other party leaders have criticized Trump, calling him unfit to be president and a phony who lacks temperament and judgment. Trump has responded by assailing Romney and other critics, and the issue is set to be a major point of contention at the upcoming Republican debate.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on profit-taking; Taiwan dollar jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.2% on Friday, following a recent rally, as investors took profits. The TAIEX index closed at 8,592.85, its lowest level since November. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to its strongest level in three months, reaching TW$32.875 per US dollar. The decline in Taiwan's stock market was largely driven by regional market declines.

site_title: Samsonite to buy Tumi for about US$1.8b in biggest deal
summary: Samsonite International SA agreed to buy luxury baggage maker Tumi Holdings Inc for approximately US$1.8 billion, its largest acquisition since going public. Tumi investors will receive US$26.75 per share, representing a 33% premium over the company's closing price. The deal values Tumi at three times its trailing 12-month revenue and follows Samsonite's expansion strategy into distributing and selling other travel and non-travel bag brands.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher after continued Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore shares rose 5.56 points to 2,793.18 on Friday, following a three-day Wall Street gain streak. The CBOE Volatility Index reached its lowest this year, with 52.3 million shares worth S$64 million changing hands. Top gainers included DBS, Keppel Corporation, and Singapore Exchange. The rally marked a 5-day gain for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: SIA to take full control of Tiger; share offer closes on Friday
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will take full control of budget airline Tiger Airways after its share offer closes on Friday. SIA initially offered 41 cents per share but raised it to 45 cents after minority shareholders expressed dissatisfaction. With 95.6% ownership, SIA can acquire all outstanding shares, allowing for full integration and strengthening Tiger Airways' growth prospects. The deal, launched in November, aims to delist and privatize Tiger Airways.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower despite Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, despite gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.19% to 16,927.36, while the Topix index lost 0.17% to 1,366.73. A stronger yen weighed on exports, contributing to the decline. The positive lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, was not enough to offset the yen's impact.

site_title: Franklin raises SembMarine stake with S$1.82m share purchases by its funds
summary: US fund manager Franklin Resources has increased its stake in Sembcorp Marine (SembMarine) after buying 1.15 million shares for S$1.82 million, raising its total deemed interest to 5.03%. The purchase brings the average share price to S$1.58, with SembMarine shares closing at S$1.655, a 4.75% gain on March 3.

site_title: US downplays North Korea's ability to fire nukes: defence official
summary: US officials downplayed North Korea's nuclear threat, stating the country has not demonstrated the ability to miniaturize a nuclear weapon and launch it on an intercontinental ballistic missile. Despite this, the US has a robust ballistic missile defense system in place. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un warned of pre-emptive nuclear strikes, citing the country's need to shift its military strategy. The US and UN have imposed sanctions on North Korea following recent nuclear tests and rocket launches, urging the country to refrain from provocative actions and rhetoric.

site_title: Europe: Shares end winning streak as Evonik and health stocks fall
summary: European shares ended a five-day winning streak, falling 0.5% due to declines in Evonik and major healthcare stocks. The FTSEurofirst 300 index weakened 0.3% after Moody's cut its outlook on the global pharmaceuticals industry to "stable" from "positive". Despite recent rallies, European markets remain down 7% for the year, with analysts requiring more positive economic data to push markets higher.

site_title: Australians snap up cars and homes in fillip to economy
summary: Australians increased spending on household items, cars, and new homes in the first quarter of 2016, boosting the economy by 3% in the last quarter of 2015. Retail sales rose 0.3% in January, with annual growth at 10.5%, driven by the household sector, which accounts for 56% of Australia's economic output. This momentum supports the Reserve Bank of Australia's forecast of above-trend growth in consumer spending, leading to a decrease in bets on interest rate cuts.

site_title: Gold snaps back to bull market as prices surge on haven demand
summary: Gold prices surged to a 20% gain, marking a bull market for the first time since 2013, as investors sought a haven from global economic turmoil. The metal rallied to $1,264.25 an ounce, beating gauge gains in Treasuries, currencies, and equities. Weaker-than-expected US factory orders and slower service industry growth boosted demand for gold, prompting a 251.9 metric ton increase in gold-backed ETF holdings. The bullish sentiment is expected to continue, with open interest in Comex futures reaching its highest level since October.

site_title: Amazon, targeting smart homes, adds devices to 'Alexa' family
summary: Amazon unveiled two smart home devices, the $130 Amazon Tap and the $90 Echo Dot, as part of its "Alexa" voice-activated personal assistant family. The Tap is a portable speaker that can play music and order items, while the Dot can control connected devices like light switches and thermostats. The Dot will only be available to existing Amazon customers and can be ordered with voice command. This move aims to expand Amazon's presence in the smart home market, competing with other internet titans like Apple and Google.

site_title: North Korea leader orders nuclear arsenal on standby: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has stated that the country's nuclear arsenal must be ready for use "any time," following the UN Security Council's adoption of tough new sanctions on Pyongyang. This move is seen as an escalation of bellicose rhetoric. The sanctions were imposed in response to North Korea's nuclear tests and missile launches.

site_title: Goldman Sachs said to cut more than 5% of fixed-income jobs
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to cut more than 5% of its fixed-income traders and salespeople, affecting less than 10% of the workforce. The reductions, announced in February, will officially take place between May 9 and July 1, as the company balances market share and returns amid an industry-wide revenue slump. The move follows similar job cuts by other Wall Street banks, with Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein stating the firm remains committed to its fixed-income business despite the challenges.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Noble, SembMarine, Jardine Matheson, Hongkong Land
summary: Singapore Airlines' premium seat demand remains strong, but faces potential future decline due to global economic headwinds. Noble Group will be dropped from the Straits Times Index, while CapitaLand Commercial Trust will be added. Sembcorp Marine saw a significant investment from Franklin Resources. Jardine Matheson reported a 5% increase in net profit to US$1.8 billion. Hongkong Land's profit increased by 52% to US$2.01 billion, driven by property valuation gains.

site_title: Japan Jan real wages rise 0.4% y-o-y, first rise in 3 months
summary: Japan's real wages rose 0.4% in January for the first time in three months, according to labor ministry data. This increase is a positive sign for consumer spending, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has urged companies to lift worker compensation. The move aims to defeat deflation and boost demand. This is the first real wage rise in three months, indicating a slight improvement in Japan's labor market.

site_title: Bank of America said poised to cut 150 jobs in trading, investment banking
summary: Bank of America plans to cut 150 trading and investment-banking jobs, part of a periodic cull of low performers, according to sources. The dismissals are aimed at reducing expenses, with affected workers to be notified on March 8. The move is led by chief operating officer Thomas Montag.

site_title: Tech rivals join Apple's legal fight against FBI
summary: A broad coalition of tech firms, including Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Yahoo, has joined Apple in its fight against the FBI's demand to unlock an encrypted iPhone used by a San Bernardino attacker. The companies argue that the government's order would set a dangerous precedent, weakening the internet ecosystem and making users more vulnerable to hackers. The tech industry associations filed a joint brief warning of a potentially "broad and deep concern" among companies about the precedent, citing security and trust issues at stake.

images.alt_text: A broad array of technology firms joined Apple's legal fight over encryption on Thursday, warning of a dangerous precedent if the company is forced to help the government break into a locked iPhone.

site_title: UBS ordered to court in tax case over Singapore bank secrecy
summary: The US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has ordered UBS Group AG to turn over records on a Singapore bank account held by US citizen Ching-Ye Hsiaw, possibly sparking a confrontation with Singapore over bank-secrecy laws. The judge in Miami has set a March 31 court date for UBS to explain its refusal to provide the account records. This case could open a new front against offshore tax evasion beyond Switzerland, highlighting tensions between the US and Singapore over financial secrecy.

images.alt_text: The US sought to make UBS Group AG turn over records on an account in Singapore held by a US citizen, possibly forcing a showdown with the city-state over its bank-secrecy laws and opening a new front against offshore tax evasion beyond Switzerland.

site_title: US shale pioneer McClendon dies in car crash
summary: Aubrey McClendon, the billionaire wildcatter behind the US shale revolution, died in a car crash in Oklahoma City on Wednesday. He was 56 and had been charged with rigging bids for oil and natural gas leases just a day earlier. McClendon's rise and fall in the energy industry was rapid, with Chesapeake Energy Corp reaching a valuation of $37.5 billion in 2008 before plummeting in value. He was known for his charismatic leadership and was a key figure in the shale revolution, but his legacy is now tainted by allegations of corruption and a federal indictment.

site_title: Yahoo exploring sale of US$1b-3b in "non-core assets": CFO
summary: Yahoo is exploring the sale of US$1 billion to US$3 billion in non-core assets, including patents, property, and units, as part of a plan to spin off its core business. CFO Ken Goldman said the company has already sold or licensed over US$600 million in patents in the last three years. A committee created to explore alternatives is examining quick sales of these assets to generate funds. The move is part of Yahoo's efforts to restructure and reduce its debt.

site_title: Hongkong Land full-year profit up 52% on non-trading gains
summary: Hongkong Land Holding reported a 52% increase in full-year profit to US$2,012 million, driven by non-trading gains of US$1,107 million from property valuations. Underlying profit declined 3% to US$905 million, while revenue rose 3.5% to US$1,932.1 million. The company's commercial property segment saw improved demand in Hong Kong, while the retail portfolio remained fully occupied. A final dividend of 19.0 US cents per share was recommended, unchanged from the previous year. The company's residential contribution declined due to the absence of Serenade sales.

site_title: Anwar declares support for Mahathir
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has publicly supported his former rival Mahathir Mohamad in his efforts to pressure Prime Minister Najib Razak to resign. Anwar, currently serving a five-year jail term, urged Malaysians to set aside personal vendettas and work together to demand change. He called for reforms in key institutions, including free and fair elections, an independent judiciary, and economic policies focused on fresh growth. Anwar's support for Mahathir comes as the former premier proposed a core group to remove Najib from office.

site_title: US: Stocks rise ahead of February jobs report
summary: US stocks rose ahead of the February jobs report, with the Dow Jones advancing 44.58 points (0.26%) to 16,843.90. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also increased, with gains of 6.95 (0.35%) and 4.00 (0.09%), respectively. The market is awaiting the jobs report, expected to show 190,000 jobs added in February and a 4.9% unemployment rate, which could be considered mixed-to-positive. Initial jobless claims rose slightly last week but remained at a low level.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mandarin Oriental reported an 8% decline in full-year net profit to US$89.3 million due to softer demand in Hong Kong and Paris, with revenue falling 11% to US$607.3 million. The group attributed the decline to renovation disruptions in Kuala Lumpur and challenging conditions in Paris following terrorist attacks.

site_title: From hot to not: Perth chases Asian buyers as home prices drop
summary: Perth is attempting to attract Asian investors as its housing prices dropped 3.7% last year, the worst performance among Australia's capital cities. CBRE Group's Lloyd Jenkins is establishing a residential marketing division to capitalize on this trend, citing the city's affordability relative to record prices on the east coast. With the mining boom dissipating, Jenkins believes now is the right time for cashed-up Chinese investors to snap up deals in Perth.

site_title: VW says 2014 diesel test warnings did not get CEO's attention
summary: Volkswagen's former CEO, Martin Winterkorn, was alerted to US diesel emissions test issues in 2014, but the problem "did not initially receive particular attention at the management levels." A memo was sent to Winterkorn in May 2014 and another in November 2014, but it's unclear if he read them. The company admitted to software cheating in emissions tests last September, leading to billions in market value loss, Winterkorn's resignation, and investigations worldwide. VW faces US Justice Department and clean air regulator settlement talks and lawsuits over its handling of the scandal.

site_title: US dollar dips ahead of key US jobs report
summary: The US dollar declined to US$1.0957 per euro on Thursday ahead of the February jobs report, which is expected to show job growth of 190,000 net new payrolls and an unchanged unemployment rate of 4.9%. Analysts believe a strong payrolls report could boost confidence in the US economy and increase market expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The dollar had previously hit a one-month trade-weighted high due to positive US economic reports.

site_title: Indonesia plans to create startup IPO market to draw investors
summary: Indonesia plans to create a startup IPO market within its main stock exchange to attract investors and support the country's growing tech industry. The new trading market, dubbed the "technology board," aims to facilitate the initial public offerings of startups, potentially leading to the emergence of the country's first unicorns. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to capitalize on its rising mobile penetration and young population, which is driving an online boom. The initiative is seen as a key step in realizing the country's vision of becoming a regional hub for technology entrepreneurs.

site_title: Oil market pauses after three days of gains
summary: The oil market experienced a brief pause after three days of gains, with West Texas Intermediate falling 9 cents to $34.57 a barrel and Brent crude rising 14 cents to $37.07 a barrel. Despite hopeful signs of a tighter market, including falling US production and potential Opec meeting, analysts say the new price levels remain fragile due to mounting US crude stockpiles and the lack of concrete output cuts. Any meeting by Opec would likely only freeze production at current levels, with little impact on the market.

site_title: Boeing aims to spiff up in-flight bathroom experience
summary: Boeing is developing a "self-cleaning" toilet system for in-flight bathrooms, aiming to boost sanitation and reduce odors. The system uses ultraviolet lights to disinfect surfaces in just three seconds, killing 99.99% of germs. The prototype features hands-free door latches, faucets, and a toilet seat that opens and closes automatically. The concept has been filed for a patent and nominated for a Crystal Cabin Award. The system requires further study before commercial deployment, with Boeing aiming to alleviate anxiety caused by unsanitary bathroom conditions during flights.

site_title: Apple launches support page on Twitter, instantly gets 50k followers
summary: Apple launched a Twitter account dedicated to customer support, @applesupport, which gained 50,000 followers in less than a day. The account provides tips and tricks to users, and has already responded to customer inquiries and complaints. This move expands Apple's social media presence, following its creation of a similar support account, @AppleMusicHelp, last year. The new account is seen as a step towards providing more direct customer support through Twitter.

site_title: US bans use of e-cigarettes on flights to protect health
summary: The US Department of Transportation has banned the use of e-cigarettes on commercial flights to protect passengers from second-hand vapour, considering e-cigarettes equivalent to smoking. The rule, set to take effect in 30 days, applies to scheduled airlines, charter operators, and foreign carriers flying to or from the US. The regulation aims to eliminate confusion between tobacco cigarettes and e-cigarettes, citing health risks such as heavy metals, particles that may damage lungs, and cancer-causing chemicals.

site_title: China Resources eyes more brewers after Snow beer buy
summary: China Resources Beer, the country's top brewer, may acquire smaller competitors after buying out SABMiller's stake in Snow beer for $1.6 billion. The company plans to expand its presence in the Chinese beer market by targeting small regional breweries, including Beijing Yanjing Brewery Co. Analysts predict that large beermakers may need to merge to gain market share and improve product quality to meet Chinese customers' rising demands. China Resources aims to drive sales and profitability by growing higher-priced brands with better margins.

site_title: Emerging stocks extend their winning streak
summary: Emerging stocks rose for the fifth day in a row, their longest winning streak this year, driven by a rally on Western bourses and a cut in reserve requirements for Chinese banks. The MSCI's emerging equity index rose almost one percent, tracking a rally in Western markets, while South African shares jumped to three-month highs. Stronger metal prices also boosted emerging markets, with shares in miners like Lonmin and Standard Bank rising significantly. However, the rand weakened 0.8 percent, and Russian stocks rose only one percent.

site_title: Cairnhill Nine's units attract strong interest
summary: CapitaLand's condominium project, Cairnhill Nine, has seen strong interest with cheques received for a significant number of its 268 units. Indonesians make up a major portion of potential buyers, drawn by the project's direct connection to Paragon and lower pricing compared to nearby prime freehold properties. Units are averaging S$2,400 to S$2,500 per square foot, and the official launch is slated for mid-March.

site_title: Ex-Google CEO to head new Pentagon innovation board
summary: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt will lead the new Pentagon advisory board, bringing Silicon Valley innovation and best practices to the US military. The board, unveiled by Defense Secretary Ash Carter, aims to bridge the gap between the military and technology industry. Carter sees innovation as crucial to maintaining the US military's competitive edge, particularly against Russia and China. The board will focus on rapid prototyping, data analysis, and organizational innovation, with up to 12 members to be chosen from private and public organizations. A first meeting may take place as early as April.

site_title: Singapore PMI falls to 51.6 in Feb as private-sector conditions soften
summary: Singapore's private sector experienced slower growth in February, with the Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 51.6, a 0.9 drop from January. This marked the slowest pace of improvement since October 2013. Output expansion slowed to its weakest rate, while new work rose marginally. Payroll numbers and purchasing activity also improved at a softer pace. Despite softening growth, companies raised prices, driving inflation to its strongest in 20 months. Growth momentum is expected to weaken further unless demand picks up.

images.alt_text: Business conditions for Singapore's private sector improved at a slower rate in February, with indicators pointing towards softening growth.

site_title: Pan Sutong's Goldin Financial Holdings wins land site for HK$6.38b
summary: Billionaire Pan Sutong's Goldin Financial Holdings Ltd won a land site in Hong Kong's Ho Man Tin area for HK$6.38 billion, beating other bidders including Cheung Kong Property Holdings Ltd. The site, which can accommodate about 500 units, is the first foray into Hong Kong's residential market by a relatively unknown company. The purchase price was in line with expectations but exceeded estimates at some analysts.

site_title: LH Group plans to acquire Pacific Star Dev in S$140m RTO deal
summary: LH Group plans to acquire Pacific Star Development in a S$140 million reverse takeover (RTO) deal. Pacific Star has invested in prime properties and is negotiating land parcels for expansion. The acquisition will diversify LH Group's business into higher-margin property development, providing a regular revenue stream. The deal, partly in cash and new LH shares, will see Pacific Star's existing investors receive new LH shares. If successful, LH Group will transfer its listing to the Catalist board.

site_title: Buffett protege Cool turns to job cuts to revive Berkshire units
summary: Warren Buffett's protege, Tracy Britt Cool, is cutting jobs at four subsidiaries under her supervision at Berkshire Hathaway, including a 25% decline at Pampered Chef, a kitchenware retailer she began running in 2014. The job cuts are aimed at reviving the units, which saw declines in 2015. Cool's efforts are part of her efforts to turn around struggling Berkshire units.

images.alt_text: Berkshire said three of the four businesses that Ms Cool oversees had "significantly increased earnings in 2015, with two of them setting records".

site_title: Impairment steers Noble away from Iceberg
summary: NOBLE Group, the largest commodity trading group in Asia, reported its first annual loss in nearly two decades, totaling $1.67 billion, driven by a $1.9 billion one-time charge related to impairing the fair value of its long-term commodity contracts. The move was partly attributed to a writedown of $1.06 billion in coal contracts, which Noble claims was not manipulated by an anonymous group called Iceberg, but analysts note the company's mining and metals business continues to underperform. Noble has refocused on its core business and is working to refinance its revolving credit facility.

site_title: This biopic won't be breaking any records
summary: The biopic "Race" about Jesse Owens' life and his achievements at the 1936 Berlin Olympics is deemed uninspired, focusing only on Owens' athletic career and ignoring his post-Olympic struggles and complex legacy. The film sidesteps issues of racial segregation, Owens' humble roots, and his relationships with those around him. While it portrays Owens as a hero, it fails to provide a deeper exploration of his life and times, resulting in a limited and shallow portrayal of a complex figure.

site_title: Technology startups are the new gold for China's wealthy as economy slows
summary: Wealthy Chinese investors are shifting their focus to technology start-ups as the economy slows, seeking safer investments. Venture capital investments into China's tech start-ups more than doubled to $32.2 billion in 2015, with $4.7 billion so far this year. Private investors are backing companies like Didi Kuaidi, Lufax, and Meituan-Dianping, which have raised billions of dollars in recent months at higher valuations. This trend contrasts with the struggling Chinese stock market, where shares have plummeted 43% since June last year.

site_title: Samarco to pay 20b reais in damages for spill
summary: Brazil's mining company Samarco and its owners BHP Billiton and Vale SA agreed to pay 20 billion reais (S$7.2 billion) in damages over 15 years for a deadly dam spill in 2015 that killed 19 people and polluted a major river. Samarco will pay 4.4 billion reais till 2018, with payments increasing to 1.6 billion reais between 2019 and 2021. The remaining amount will be decided based on the work remaining to be done. The agreement does not cover private civil suits or criminal investigations.

site_title: CapitaLandCom to replace Noble in STI Index
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust will replace Noble Group in the Straits Times Index (STI) effective March 21, following the March quarterly review. The sole change is made due to Noble Group's removal from the index. The STI reserve list, comprising companies with the highest market capitalization, will replace any ineligible constituents. The next review takes place on June 2, 2016.

site_title: A comedy that is woefully short on laughs
summary: Ben Stiller's comedy film Zoolander 2, a sequel to the 2001 satirical take on the fashion world, has received mixed reviews. Despite generating buzz through cross-marketing efforts, the film is "woefully short on laughs" and lacks charm and visual appeal. The film's success in building a following on home viewing is not replicated on the big screen. Stiller and co-star Owen Wilson's efforts to revive the character may not have paid off, leaving the film a disappointing follow-up to the original.

site_title: Looking to past American presidents as role models
summary: US presidential candidates are adopting famous past presidents as role models, but often fail to live up to their ideals. Donald Trump compares himself to Franklin D. Roosevelt, despite FDR's internment of Japanese Americans, while also ignoring FDR's economic recovery efforts. Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio idolize Ronald Reagan, but inaccurately credit him with releasing US hostages in 1981. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders genuinely admire FDR and Nelson Mandela, respectively. The Republican candidates' self-serving foreign policies are likely to backfire, highlighting the disconnect between their role models and their own actions.

site_title: UK services growth at 3-year low as Brexit doubts grip boardrooms
summary: The UK services sector experienced its lowest growth in three years, with new orders rising at the weakest pace since 2013, prompting companies to cut hiring rates. The Markit/CIPS UK services purchasing managers' index fell to 52.7 from 55.6 in January, citing concerns over Brexit, financial market volatility, and weak economic growth. The UK's GDP now looks on track to expand by just 0.3% in the first quarter of 2016, a slowdown from 0.5% in the previous quarter.

site_title: ECB brainstorms as Draghi seeks stimulus that won't hurt banks
summary: European Central Bank officials are deliberating on potential measures to enhance monetary policy without harming banks, ahead of a stimulus decision on March 10. To mitigate the impact on banks, officials are considering variations on a tiered deposit rate and techniques to counter excess liquidity. The ECB may cut the deposit rate from -0.3% or increase bond purchases under QE to boost the currency bloc's recovery. The goal is to avoid squeezing banks' profitability and ensure a healthy banking sector, with some experts warning that negative interest rates could hinder lending to companies and households.

site_title: SIA expects shaky global economy to affect premium demand
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) expects a shaky global economy to affect premium demand, despite current strong demand for its Business Class seats. The airline plans to adjust the configuration of five incoming A380s by reducing the number of suites to better match demand. SIA's new A350-900, which landed at Changi Airport, will enable the airline to grow its long-haul network and attract premium passengers. The A350 is equipped with new cabin products and offers improved fuel efficiency and passenger comfort.

site_title: Temasek, UOB tap euro-bond market in maiden issues
summary: Singaporean investment company Temasek and UOB have tapped into the euro-denominated bond market, issuing 600 million euros and 500 million euros of six-year and 12-year euro-denominated bonds, respectively. The moves come as European investors diversify away from government bonds, seeking higher yields. The euro bond market offers flexible maturities and low borrowing costs, attracting institutional investors mainly from Europe. Temasek's issuance is seen as a strategic move to boost firepower for more investments in the region, while UOB's covered bonds are expected to be rated "AAA" by major rating agencies.

site_title: Changi prison life, as described by prisoners
summary: Theatrical practitioner Edith Podesta is reviving her award-winning play "Dark Room", a prison drama that explores the experiences of Singapore's "returning citizens" through word-for-word accounts from 10 male ex-offenders and a female inmate. The play, which debuted in 2014, will return to the stage at Esplanade's The Studios 2016 season with expanded material. The production aims to give voice to the prisoners' stories, shedding light on their personal journeys within the correctional facilities and the stigma they face upon release.

site_title: Media companies try to spend their way out of cable TV crunch
summary: Media companies such as Discovery Communications, Viacom, and Starz are increasing spending on programming to combat declining viewership and maintain supply of new content. However, this spending may become a permanent drag on profit, as investors worry about the long-term impact on profit margins. Analysts predict significant spending by Netflix, Hulu, and other competitors, with some warning of "margin compression for many years to come." The industry's poor performance in recent months is attributed to shrinking TV audiences and slumping advertising sales.

site_title: February was worst month for eurozone businesses in over a year
summary: Eurozone businesses experienced their worst month in over a year in February, with the Markit Composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 53 from 53.6, indicating a slowdown in growth. This, coupled with deflationary pressures, suggests the region's recovery is losing momentum. The European Central Bank is likely to act aggressively to avoid another downturn, with an almost certain additional cut to its deposit rate on March 10. Prices fell 0.2% last month, and firms discounted goods and services at the steepest rate for a year.

site_title: Indonesia's early-warning buoys out of action when big quake hit
summary: A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Indonesia, triggering widespread panic in the city of Padang, but no tsunami was detected due to malfunctioning early-warning buoys. The buoys, which cost $2.3 million a year to maintain, were inoperable, exposing gaps in Indonesia's disaster prevention systems. Authorities reported that shelters had a capacity to hold only 200,000 people, and there were concerns about evacuation routes. The earthquake did not cause any major damage or fatalities, but it highlighted the need for improvement in Indonesia's early warning systems.

site_title: US airlines compete for limited routes to Cuba
summary: US airlines, including American Airlines, JetBlue, and others, are seeking regulatory approval to fly specific routes to Cuba, following the restoration of commercial air service between the US and Cuba. Airlines have submitted proposals that exceed the daily cap of 20 round-trip flights to Havana and 10 to other Cuban airports. The US Transportation Department will aim to maximize public benefit in assigning the flights, amid strong demand from Cuban-Americans and leisure travelers.

site_title: Frequent change of passwords may not be a good idea
summary: A US Federal Trade Commission official, Lorrie Cranor, claims that forcing frequent password changes may not be effective in preventing cyber threats. This practice can lead to people creating weak passwords, as users may not want to remember multiple complex passwords. Cranor suggests that alternative security measures, such as multi-factor authentication and regular security audits, may be more effective in protecting against cyber attacks.

site_title: Bank-crisis losses can be avoided with higher capital buffers: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) suggests that regulators should encourage banks to raise new equity rather than pare assets to meet capital-to-asset ratios, potentially avoiding costly banking crises. The report finds that sufficient buffers of 15-23% of risk-weighted assets could have prevented recent banking crises in advanced economies. Emerging markets may need stronger buffers, and the IMF warns that stricter regulation could lead to regulatory arbitrage. The recommended buffer size is higher than the current Basel III rules, which require a 15.5% capital-to-risk-asset ratio.

site_title: Jardine Matheson 2015 profit up 5% to US$1.8 billion
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a 5% increase in net profit to US$1.8 billion for the year ended Dec 31, 2015, despite challenging circumstances in China and Indonesia. Revenue rose 4% to US$65.27 billion, driven by Dairy Farm and Astra's contributions. The company's performance was largely unaffected by the struggles in its two key markets.

site_title: Popularity of SUVs raises bar in emissions targets
summary: Carmakers including Audi, Maserati, and SEAT unveiled their latest SUVs at the Geneva Motor Show, amidst low petrol prices driving demand for larger cars. However, these sales come with a regulatory challenge, as carmakers must make the vehicles more efficient to meet emissions targets without sacrificing profit margins. The segment's growth poses a challenge to manufacturers, forcing them to balance profit with environmental regulations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust's share price has appreciated 11.9% year-to-date, making it the top-performing Singapore real estate investment trust. OCBC Investment Research downgrades the stock to "hold" due to compressed FY16 forecast distribution yield. Phillip Capital Research recommends accumulating the stock, targeting S$8.28. RHB Research upgrades China Everbright Water to "buy" due to two new wastewater treatment projects, justifying a 14 times FY16 forecast P/E ratio.

site_title: HDB resale flats up 0.2% in February: SRX Property
summary: HDB resale flats in Singapore saw a 0.2% increase in February, with both mature and non-mature estates experiencing the same rise. However, prices remain 0.6% lower than a year ago and 10.9% below the peak in April 2013. This marks a stabilization in resale prices after a 0.5% drop in January.

site_title: Crouching Tiger sequel is best kept hidden from fans
summary: A sequel to the 2000 film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" has been released, but it has been met with criticism for its lack of authenticity and cringe-worthy attempts at Orientalism. The Netflix-exclusive film, "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon 2: Sword of Destiny," features Michelle Yeoh reprising her role but lacks the poetic beauty of the original. The convoluted plot is dominated by action sequences, but the rest of the film is deemed uninspired, leading to a mediocre rating of C-. The sequel is best kept hidden from fans of the original.

site_title: What will we do if we have no oil?
summary: As the world relies heavily on oil for global trade, a dwindling supply poses significant concerns. With proven global oil reserves already dwindling and excess supply expected to fill storage containers soon, the need for alternative solutions becomes increasingly pressing. Creating an interconnected smart electricity grid could be a crucial initial step to mitigate the effects of oil scarcity, allowing for the efficient distribution and marketing of electrical power from various sources.

site_title: Own original artwork from Charlie Chan
summary: Singaporean graphic novelist Sonny Liew is selling original artwork from his best-selling novel "The Art of Charlie Chan Hock Chye" at Mulan Gallery. The artwork, priced between S$200 and S$950, features characters from the book, including Lee Kuan Yew and cartoonist Charlie Chan. Liew hopes to sell the pieces to fans of the book, as he had received several enquiries when the book was released, and to potentially increase their value if the book gains international recognition.

site_title: Greece resists IMF demands for more pension cuts
summary: Greece's finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, stated that the country cannot accept IMF demands for further pension cuts to achieve a primary surplus target of 3.5% of GDP by 2018. Greece has proposed pension system reforms, but the IMF is concerned that the plan will not yield enough savings. The IMF also seeks more generous debt relief from European lenders, which is delaying the review of Greece's first bailout and could hinder reforms. The delay has a political and economic cost, and the IMF and EU lenders are at odds over additional reforms.

site_title: India's love affair with gold tested as jewellers go on strike
summary: India's gold market is on strike as thousands of jewellers protest a one per cent excise duty on domestically produced and sold jewellery. The strike, which began on Wednesday, is a three-day halt to trading, with shops shuttered across the country. The move comes after Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced the excise duty in the budget, which jewellers claim will block a source of revenue and lead to irregular business practices. The strike may be extended if the government does not reverse the decision, causing frustration among consumers who are already facing weak demand and high prices.

site_title: Actors so good, they could sell any drug
summary: The Effect, a 2016 romance play, revolves around two volunteers who participate in a pharmaceutical trial and begin to question whether their feelings are genuine or the result of the administered drug. The play, elevated by the intelligence of its script, the direction of Tracie Pang, and outstanding performances from Linden Furnell, Nikki Muller, and Tan Kheng Hua, ultimately focuses on love rather than a critique of the pharmaceutical industry. Despite a flawed script, the actors' combined charms make the play a compelling and polished production.

site_title: UOB to invest US$10m in Israel-based OurCrowd
summary: UOB has partnered with OurCrowd, an Israel-based equity crowdfunding platform, to provide ECF services in Asia. UOB will invest US$10 million and partner with Sassoon Investment Corporation to support OurCrowd's expansion in the region. This partnership aims to bridge the S$180 million SME funding gap in South-east Asia, allowing SMEs and startups to access investments from accredited investors. OurCrowd's hybrid model of VC and ECF ensures a curated process, rejecting 98% of deals, and providing access to global investment opportunities for Asian investors.

site_title: Saudi aviation regulator in talks about airport free zones
summary: Saudi Arabia's General Authority of Civil Aviation (GACA) is in talks to establish free zones at Jeddah and Riyadh airports as part of a plan to diversify the kingdom's economy. The free zones will offer relaxed licenses, visa and taxation rules, and aim to attract foreign businesses. The move is part of a larger plan to privatize the country's airports by 2020 and boost the non-oil private sector. The GACA's chairman, Faisal al-Sugair, expects bids for Jeddah's King Abdulaziz International Airport by the end of April and completion of work on Riyadh's Terminal 5 in May.

site_title: UK housing market risks rising, but lower than in 2014
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe warned that UK housing market risks are rising, although smaller than in 2014. The rapidly growing "buy-to-let" sector poses a financial stability risk, prompting the Bank of England to request government approval to intervene. A public consultation will continue until March 11. Cunliffe noted that market growth is resuming, making those risks more prominent.

site_title: Ford unit joins foreign corporates issuing SGD bonds
summary: Ford Motor Credit Company, a US-based subsidiary of Ford Motor, has issued SGD 350 million 3.7% three-year bonds, priced lower than initial guidance, following strong SGD 750 million demand. This is the second foreign corporate bond issue in a week, joining Ausnet Services' SGD 200 million 5.5% bonds. The SGD market is seen as attractive to foreign issuers for funding diversification and competitive pricing, with DBS Bank and Deutsche Bank handling the issue.

site_title: You REALLY wanna read this column? Beware . . .
summary: Madonna's recent concert in Singapore sparked controversy after she simulated swearing and touched her private parts on stage. The singer's actions were deemed provocative and explicit, prompting concerns about the content being shared with the wrong audience. The writer of a column on the topic advises readers to be cautious about who reads their content, suggesting the use of disclaimers to warn readers about explicit material. The author is prepared for backlash from offended readers, stating they are not the intended audience.

site_title: China's top Internet dealmaker warns of 'lawless' markets
summary: China's top Internet dealmaker, Fan Bao, warns of "lawless" venture capital and startup markets due to the influx of retail investors. He cautions that individual investors are disrupting markets with inflated values, which can burst and result in significant losses. Fan Bao urges regulators to step in and curb irrational investment and asset bubbles, stating that primary markets are not suitable for retail investors and lack regulation.

site_title: Dance-meets-circus show iD is back
summary: Cirque Eloize's dance-meets-circus show "iD" is returning to Singapore with a new cast and tighter routine. Created in 2009, the show combines urban dance and circus arts, focusing on emotional evolution and self-expression. Co-founder Jeannot Painchaud, a former juggler and acrobat, aims to give new artists space to bring their identities to the show. The high-energy performance features acrobats, break dancers, contortionists, and a stunt biker, accompanied by a rock and electronica-inspired soundtrack. The show runs until March 6 at the Marina Bay Sands MasterCard Theatres.

site_title: US economy expands with wide range of wage growth
summary: The US economy expanded across most of the country, with seven regional districts describing growth as "moderately", "modest pace", or "slightly" according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. Wage growth varied widely, ranging from "flat to strong". This expansion comes as the US economy continues to grow despite inconsistent wage growth, with the central bank's survey published eight times a year. The report provides insight into the US economy's current state, highlighting its growth and wage trends.

site_title: Inflated import invoices behind bulk of China's capital outflows: economists
summary: China's capital outflows, totaling US$420 billion since August 2015, are largely attributed to inflated import invoices, according to a Deutsche Bank paper. The discrepancy between import invoices and Customs data is estimated to be US$328 billion, accounting for 78% of the decline in foreign exchange reserves. The Chinese authorities have been trying to tighten control over capital outflows, but outflows through the import channel remained high in January 2016. The economists warn that capital controls are not a panacea, as they may create new problems such as bigger property bubbles and constrain legitimate outward investment.

site_title: STI leaps 2.2%, bringing 5-day gain to 7%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 2.2% to 2,787.62 points on Thursday, with banks, Keppel Corp, and Singtel contributing 36% of the market's $1.8 billion turnover. The 5-day gain now stands at 7%. Other active index stocks included Noble Group, Thai Beverage, and Golden Agri Resources. Analysts attribute the surge to trading funds, but Macquarie Equities Research believes asset quality trends will drive bank share prices. The STI's rally is seen as a positive sign, but some experts caution that the market's momentum may be short-lived.

site_title: Tencent's Ma proposes lower entry barriers for China's internet
summary: Billionaire Ma Huateng of Tencent Holdings proposes lowering entry barriers for China's internet industry to spur innovation and encourage online healthcare reforms. Ma recommends allowing doctors to freelance, building online personal medical files, and relaxing digital content policies. China's internet users grew to 688 million, with 89% of enterprises relying on the web. The government plans to discuss policy roadmaps for 2016, including boosting investment in network infrastructure and improving GDP statistics. Ma's proposals come as the startup economy booms, with $37 billion invested in China startups last year.

site_title: City buzz
summary: No article content provided.

site_title: European and Asean business leaders suggest ways to move AEC agenda along
summary: European business leaders have presented a 24-page position paper to Asean economic ministers, urging the region to incorporate visions for the Asean Economic Community (AEC) into national legislatures and set up mechanisms to achieve the single market. The paper calls for ratification of key framework agreements, review of domestic legislations, and establishment of a clear implementation plan for commitments. The private sector is also emphasized, with recommendations to exempt micro and small and medium-sized enterprises from paperwork and duties, and to facilitate their participation in global value chains.

site_title: New tremors in high finance rattle foundation of post-crisis regulations
summary: Key regulators and economists are questioning the effectiveness of post-crisis banking regulations, citing recent market turmoil and the "too big to fail" problem. A Federal Reserve official, Neel Kashkari, stated that the crisis was not fully addressed, and some experts believe the largest banks may break up in the coming years. Despite the complexity of the current system, proponents argue that banks have become safer with higher capital requirements and reduced debt. However, market turbulence and growing skepticism may prompt politicians and regulators to consider more direct policies to reduce the size and complexity of large financial firms.

site_title: Deloitte South-east Asia names new chief
summary: Deloitte South-east Asia has appointed Philip Yuen as its new chief executive, replacing Chaly Mah who retired on June 1. This leadership change marks a new chapter for the company. Meanwhile, global market trends saw oil rise over 2% due to investors weighing market outlook and tariffs, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. Other news included NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warning of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls.

site_title: Capturing the changing photo market
summary: Eastman Kodak has launched Kodakit, a photography-focused app designed to connect photographers with customers and vice versa. The app aims to simplify the process of hiring photographers, including searching, portfolio viewing, and booking. It also provides a secure and private platform for clients to store and manage their photos, with copyright belonging to the customer. The app is free to register for photographers, and a rating system is planned to help clients make informed decisions. Over 220 photographers have already registered, with plans to expand to two other cities by the end of the year.

site_title: Dairy Farm full-year profit falls 17% to US$424.4m
summary: Dairy Farm International Holdings reported a 17% fall in full-year profit to US$424.4 million, citing a challenging retail environment. Sales rose 1% to US$11.137 billion, driven by home furnishings and restaurant units. The company's food business saw a 2% decline in sales, while its health and beauty division experienced a 15% operating profit decline. The board recommended a reduced final dividend of 13.5 US cents per share. Trading conditions are expected to remain challenging, particularly in South-east Asia.

site_title: Wines - nectars that force you to slow down and savour
summary: A 1995 dessert wine, Scharzhofberger Riesling Goldkapsel Auslese by Egon Muller-Scharzhof, is highlighted for its ability to slow down the consumer and encourage thoughtful enjoyment. This reflects a contrast to the fast-paced modern lifestyle, as quoted from William Henry Davies. The wine's richness and sweetness are said to demand patience and reflection, offering a unique reward in the world of wines.

site_title: US factory orders data points to easing in manufacturing slump
summary: US factory orders data showed a 1.6% increase in January, the largest gain in seven months, following a 2.9% drop in December. This rebounded economists' forecast of a 2.0% rise. The manufacturing sector, accounting for 12% of the economy, has been affected by a strong dollar, weak global demand, and inventory cuts. However, a survey suggests an improvement in sentiment among manufacturers, and industrial production gained in January. Inventories fell for the seventh straight month, but the inventories-to-shipments ratio decreased, indicating progress in reducing inventory glut.

site_title: US$ seen strengthening against major currencies
summary: The US dollar is expected to strengthen against major currencies in the coming months, according to a Reuters poll, but not enough to offset losses incurred since the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in December. Investors have shifted to safe havens like the euro and yen amid concerns over slowing inflation and economic growth. Despite expectations of two more interest rate hikes this year, markets are skeptical, and economists have trimmed their forecasts for the dollar's rise. The dollar will still strengthen, but at a slower pace.

site_title: Revenge classic retold in grey instead of black & white
summary: China's modernist playwright Cao Yu's "Savage Land" is reimagined in a contemporary production, blurring the lines between heroes and villains. The original play tells the story of Jiao Daxing, who seeks revenge against Chouhu after his father's actions lead to Chouhu's exile and family tragedy. The new production, directed by Chen Xinyi, challenges traditional portrayals of Jiao Daxing as a villain, instead exploring the complexities of his character. This reimagining offers a fresh perspective on the classic tale, inviting audiences to question their assumptions about good and evil.

site_title: Energy pioneer McClendon dies in fiery car crash, a day after indictment
summary: Former Chesapeake Energy CEO Aubrey McClendon, a key figure in the US energy industry's shale gas boom, died in a fiery car crash in Oklahoma City on Wednesday, just a day after being indicted for allegedly colluding to rig bids for oil and gas acreage. McClendon, 56, was traveling at "well above" the speed limit when his 2013 Chevy Tahoe crashed into an embankment, bursting into flames. He was not wearing a seatbelt. McClendon had denied the charges, which followed a nearly four-year federal antitrust probe.

site_title: Clarity in US presidential race a positive for markets - for now
summary: The US presidential election has become clearer after Super Tuesday, with Hillary Clinton leading in the Democratic primary and Donald Trump ahead in the Republican primary. Markets are reacting positively to the clarity, seeing it as a relief to financial markets. A Clinton presidency would likely bring stability, but her ties to Wall Street and email controversy could pose risks. Trump's nationalist policies and xenophobic campaign have garnered support among disillusioned voters, but his strongman appeal may not translate to a decisive victory. Markets are currently not worried about the election outcome, but a global economic slowdown and partisan gridlock could pose risks.

site_title: 'Frenemies' an apt term for prickly US-China relationship
summary: US-China relations remain complex, with "frenemies" aptly describing the relationship. Despite progress on joint UN action regarding North Korea, differences over the South China Sea persist. The US State Department condemned China on human rights after Foreign Minister Wang Yi's visit, highlighting the tension. The visit showcased the dual nature of US-China relations, where cooperation and disagreements coexist. The relationship continues to be characterized by contradictions and challenges.

site_title: BT journalists clinch two wins at SPH media awards
summary: The Business Times (BT) won two awards at the 2016 SPH media awards, including Commentary/Analysis of the Year for Joyce Hooi and Headline of the Year for Cai Haoxiang. ST's Wong Kim Hoh won Journalist of the Year, while TNP's Billy Ker took home Young Journalist of the Year. The awards ceremony highlighted the challenges facing newsrooms, with EMTM editor-in-chief Patrick Daniel citing a Boston Consulting Group report on the third wave of digital disruption in the media industry.

images.alt_text: The Business Times raised a riotous din with airhorns and whistles, celebrating its joint win with ST of the inaugural S$1,000 prize for Most Enthusiastic Newsroom. BT editor Alvin Tay (with hat) gamely took to riding a trishaw to up the ante.
Cai Haoxiang (above) took home the award for Headline of the Year with his tongue-in-cheek: "Stationery, but still Popular", for a story on Popular Holdings.

BT's Joyce Hooi (above) won Commentary/Analysis of the Year for her commentary: "By gum, the West is wrong about Singapore", written in the wake of the death of Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Airbus touts 400-seat 'A350-8000' jetliner
summary: Airbus is proposing a new 400-seat jetliner, provisionally dubbed the A350-8000, as competition with Boeing escalates for the world's largest two-engined jets. The A350-8000 aims to target airlines not requiring extreme Gulf conditions performance, unlike Boeing's 777-9. Airbus is seeking airline support and has begun a pre-marketing phase.
