The singer-songwriter, known for her powerful voice and emotional lyrics, performed a nearly two-hour set that included hits from her albums 21 and 25. Despite having previously headlined in an arena, Adele's anxiety and throat issues had kept her from touring in the past, but she has since found her footing and is now embracing the larger venue. The concert marked a triumphant return to the arena stage for Adele, who joked about getting used to the experience.

images.alt_text: When she sings, Adele is larger than life. At Monday's concert, Adele didn't bother with a costume change, although her one gown was properly sparkly. She is clearly aware that her voice, songs and presence are the real show.

site_title: US offshore wind companies now have critical mass and big backers
summary: US offshore wind companies have gained significant backing from major investors, including DE Shaw, Dong Energy, and Blackstone Group, marking a turning point for the emerging industry. Despite years of slow progress, the sector is expected to grow faster than predicted, with developers citing increased competition and innovative financing methods as key drivers. The industry's chief hurdle, the high cost of building at sea, is expected to decrease as more companies enter the market.

site_title: Australia's economy expands faster than expected
summary: Australia's economy expanded 3% in the year to December, beating market expectations of 2.5%, driven by consumer and government spending. The growth was supported by a 0.6% increase in the October to December quarter, with household spending and public infrastructure spending contributing to the expansion. The Australian dollar strengthened, while business spending weakened the quarterly growth reading. The better-than-expected figures raise hopes that the country is emerging from a recent slump, with the economy growing faster than the G-7 and OECD averages.

site_title: Keppel Land in Vietnam waterfront JV
summary: Keppel Land, a Singaporean property developer, has entered into a joint venture with Vietnamese companies to develop a 14.6-hectare waterfront site in Ho Chi Minh City's Thu Thiem New Urban Area. The $93.9 million investment will be used to develop premium residential apartments, office and retail properties, as well as an 86-storey integrated mixed-use tower complex. The project is part of Keppel Land's expansion in Vietnam, where its local staff strength has grown to around 480 since the early 1990s.

site_title: Ezra's Lee family puts Sentosa bungalow up for sale
summary: The Ezra Lee family, owners of EZRA Holdings, has listed their Sentosa Cove bungalow for sale at S$26 million, following the sale of a Good Class Bungalow in October for S$22 million. The property boasts a private berth and spans 12,400 sq ft of land area. This sale comes as the family has been divesting assets, including a recent sale of shares in Select Group and forced sale of Ezra shares due to a sharp decline in the counter. The sale is the latest in a string of transactions by the family amid a challenging oil and gas market.

site_title: Boeing exec says new mid-market jet is a 'tough business case'
summary: Boeing is considering a new mid-market jet, but faces a "tough business case" due to high production costs. Industry experts debate whether the market is ripe for a new aircraft, with some predicting demand for a small twin-aisle plane. Boeing is exploring options, including reviving the 757 with new engines or developing a new plane. However, experts warn that any new project could cannibalize other segments, and Boeing is prioritizing existing developments, including the 737, 787, and 777.

site_title: ECB plays down effects of negative interest rates on banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has downplayed the impact of negative interest rates on eurozone banks, with executive board member Benoit Coeure stating that banks' challenges are largely due to the current economic environment, not the ECB's monetary policy. Despite banks facing weak earnings and cost-cutting measures, Coeure argued that aggregate net interest income for euro area banks increased last year. The ECB is studying schemes to mitigate adverse consequences for the bank lending channel, but many banks have offset declining interest revenues with higher lending volumes and capital gains.

site_title: Japan and India hold promise: SocGen
summary: Societe Generale's Frank Benzimra sees Japan and India as promising investment opportunities. Japan's economy is recovering from deflation, and reforms are on track. India, meanwhile, has a large and growing market. Benzimra's comments suggest that these countries hold potential for investors.

site_title: Rolling Stones to play in historic free concert in Havana
summary: The Rolling Stones announced a historic free concert in Havana, Cuba, set to take place on March 25, four days after US President Barack Obama's historic visit. The concert, the first by the Stones in the Caribbean island nation, marks a significant event for both the band and Cuba, which had banned rock and roll in 1961. The Stones' lead singer Mick Jagger had previously visited Havana, fueling speculation about the gig. The concert will also feature the distribution of instruments to Cuban musicians.

site_title: Airbus remains upbeat on China market
summary: Airbus has inaugurated a delivery centre in Tianjin for wide-body aircraft, marking the European company's expansion into China's growing aviation market. The centre, which will receive its first A330 aircraft in 2017, is expected to produce two aircraft per month and meet demand for wide-body aircraft in China. Airbus estimates the Chinese aviation market will grow by 10% annually for the next five years, driven by outbound traffic, with the country forecast to have 1.7 billion air passengers by 2034, making it the largest civil aviation market in the world.

site_title: Cut in African stake signals latest strategy shift by new Barclays CEO
summary: Barclays, the British bank, announced a new strategy shift under its CEO James E Staley, cutting its stake in its African business, slashing its dividend, and focusing on two divisions: its British consumer bank and corporate and investment bank. The bank aims to sell down its 62.3% interest in Barclays Africa Group over the next two to three years due to regulatory and capital requirements. Barclays reported a net loss of £394 million in 2015, worse than expected, and plans to reduce its headcount further as it accelerates a wind-down of non-core operations.

site_title: Wandervale EC's average price set at S$755 psf
summary: Sim Lian Group has set an average price of S$755 per square foot for its Wandervale Executive Condominium (EC) in Choa Chu Kang, ahead of its launch on March 5. The 534-unit development, featuring 130 three-bedroom and 82 four-bedroom units, received 783 E-applications, with a subscription rate of 1.47 times. Prices start from S$655,000 for a three-bedroom unit, with the first batch of units available for booking at the showflat. The development is scheduled to receive its Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) by 2019.

site_title: Jurong Country Club to appeal for higher compensation
summary: Jurong Country Club in Singapore plans to appeal for higher compensation, seeking S$89.8 million, half of its initial claim of S$168 million, after the government acquired its site for the High-Speed Rail project. The club, with 2,700 members, believes its claim reflects the true value of its land, citing research by Knight Frank. Members purchased memberships at a higher price, with some selling for S$55,000 each, and the club aims to ensure fair compensation for their losses.

site_title: Go local on emerging debt: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley's asset management arm is bullish on local-currency debt of developing nations, expecting domestic sovereign bonds to outperform dollar-denominated bonds. The firm's portfolio manager, Jens Nystedt, attributes this to a likely bottoming out of oil prices, which boosts demand for higher-yielding assets. Indonesian and Indian notes offer high interest rates, making them attractive due to central banks' room to cut borrowing costs. The rupiah and ringgit have rebounded from 17-year lows, with benchmark 10-year local-currency bonds yielding 8.27% and 7.61%, respectively.

site_title: Hotel slump lures buyout firms
summary: Buyout firms anticipate a surge in hotel deals due to market volatility, which creates opportunities for value-oriented investors. Market volatility is expected to lure investors, as Tyler Henritze, co-head of US real estate acquisitions for Blackstone Group LP, stated. This could mark a potential pick-up in deals after a slow start to the year, driven by longer-term investors seeking bargains in the hotel sector.

site_title: RMB overtakes RM in Malaysia-China payments
summary: The Chinese yuan has overtaken the Malaysian ringgit as the second most used currency for payments between China and Malaysia, according to SWIFT data. The RMB's use in payments with China and Hong Kong increased by 68% over the last 12 months, and by 214% over the last three years. This growth is attributed to Malaysia's extensive trading relationships with China and its role in facilitating China's Asean trade relationships. The internationalisation of the RMB is expected to rise further due to China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative and regional infrastructure investments.

site_title: Daimler makes Singapore its commercial-vehicle regional centre
summary: Daimler Commercial Vehicles has established Singapore as its South-east Asian regional centre, managing 18 markets from the city-state. The move aims to decentralize decision-making and tap into Singapore's logistics and regulatory strengths. Staff strength will grow from 12 to 52, with the hub operations being transferred from Stuttgart, Germany. The company sees potential for growth in the region, despite current market challenges, and plans to manufacture locally to offer a range of products tailored to each market's needs.

site_title: France could seize on the chance of a British 'no'
summary: France is waiting for Britain to leave the European Union, with former French Prime Minister Michel Rocard saying it's time for the nation to "go". This stance is shared by many French politicians and commentators, who view Britain's decision as an opportunity for France to strengthen its position. Rocard's views echo those of former French President Charles de Gaulle, who famously rejected Britain's first attempts to join the Common Market in the 1960s. France's position reflects the country's long-standing skepticism towards Britain's readiness to be fully European.

site_title: What's on that iPhone? Fight goes to Congress
summary: The US Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) have asked Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino attackers. The case has sparked a debate about strong encryption and its implications for law enforcement efforts. Apple's general counsel, Bruce Sewell, said the company is not motivated by financial concerns and is taking a stand to protect customer security. FBI Director James Comey acknowledged that a favorable ruling could set a precedent for other cases, but also expressed concerns about the potential for encryption to hide conversations and personal documents from law enforcement.

site_title: Trumper Tuesday
summary: The 2016 Republican presidential primary saw establishment forces, including Senator Marco Rubio, attempt to stop Donald Trump's rise. Despite efforts to discredit Trump, he remained the front-runner, and Rubio and Senator Ted Cruz stayed in the race. The Republican leaders' campaign to stop Trump was unsuccessful, and he became the presumptive nominee for the general election against Hillary Clinton.

images.alt_text: Taken together, Mr Trump's wins have helped to transform him into the Republican presidential frontrunner, demonstrating that he could prevail in the south, the west, the north-east and the north-west.

site_title: Bloomberg waits in wings as Clinton, Trump savour wins
summary: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has emerged as the presumptive Democratic Party presidential candidate after a strong showing on Super Tuesday, winning a large majority of the Democratic races in 12 states and one US territory. She is likely to become the first woman to become a nominee for either of the major parties, a historic moment in US history. Meanwhile, billionaire businessman Donald Trump is becoming a strong favorite for the Republican crown, following his wins in multiple states.

site_title: Olympus to pay US$646 million to end kickback, bribe probes
summary: Olympus Corp has agreed to pay US$646 million to resolve US probes into kickbacks and bribes related to its medical business. The company's US unit will pay US$623.2 million in the kickback case, the largest such case in American history. Olympus will also pay US$22.8 million to its Latin American medical business to resolve a criminal case involving illicit payments to government healthcare providers. The company faces criminal charges that will be dropped if it complies with terms imposed.

images.alt_text: Olympus Corp has agreed to pay US$646 million to resolve US probes into kickbacks that it paid to doctors in the US and funnelled into bribes in Central and South America.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Q&M Dental Group is expected to accelerate its acquisitions in Singapore in 2016, with a healthy pipeline of Chinese deals. The company's market share in Singapore is low, providing room for mergers and acquisitions. Q&M's Chinese subsidiaries are expected to set higher internal targets to achieve a better track record for its upcoming IPO. Meanwhile, Wheelock Properties is in a solid financial position, despite challenging conditions in the domestic residential segment, and maintains its "buy" rating.

site_title: Intrepid Potash dives on Q4 loss and creditor talks
summary: Intrepid Potash Inc, a US fertilizer producer, posted a Q4 loss of $518.3 million, with shares plummeting 55% to 99 cents. The company attributed the loss to weaker commodity prices, including a decline in potash prices. Intrepid is in talks with creditors to avoid a loan covenant breach and has arranged a 30-day waiver. Despite this, the company's auditors have added "going concern" language to their audit opinion, which could be considered an event of default. CEO Bob Jornayvaz expressed confidence in the company's ability to survive and eventually prosper as a smaller, more profitable entity.

site_title: Minimum trading price rule pushes 41 firms into SGX watch-list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has added 41 Mainboard-listed companies to its watch-list for failing to meet the new minimum trading price requirement, bringing the total to 76 firms. The new requirement aims to improve market quality by reducing vulnerability to manipulation. Companies on the watch-list have three years to rectify their breaches, with some granted extensions to rectify profitability and market value requirements. About a third of watch-list companies eventually exit successfully, according to historical data.

site_title: US$ firms on economic data, A$ big gainer
summary: The US dollar traded at a one-month high against a basket of major currencies after strong US economic data, leading investors to bet on a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this year. The Australian dollar also surged, driven by a surprise economic growth report. Analysts predict further gains for the dollar, citing better US data and easing global financial conditions. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 98.473, with some predicting it could reach 100 in the near term.

site_title: Volvo boss says hybrid cars will compete on cost with diesel
summary: Volvo CEO Hakan Samuelsson says hybrid cars will become more cost-competitive with diesel cars in Europe due to stricter emissions rules, which will force carmakers to invest in exhaust emissions technology. Diesel cars, accounting for over 50% of new registrations in Europe, will become more expensive, making plug-in hybrids an attractive alternative. Volvo plans to introduce cleaner diesels faster due to the Volkswagen emissions scandal and is open to partnering with a third-party company for driverless car technology. Samuelsson predicts 10% of Volvos will be electric by 2020 as battery costs decrease.

site_title: SIA takes delivery of its first 'game-changing' A350-900 in Toulouse
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) took delivery of its first Airbus A350-900 in Toulouse, France, marking a significant milestone in its long-haul expansion plans. The airline has ordered 67 A350s, which will enhance its network and competitiveness. The delivery ceremony was attended by SIA, Airbus, Rolls-Royce, and international media, despite drizzly weather.

site_title: Moody's cuts outlook on China govt bonds with continued weak growth ahead
summary: Moody's cut its outlook on China's sovereign bonds from stable to negative, citing increasing government debt, further capital outflows, and concerns over Beijing's ability to implement economic reforms. The agency warned that weak growth would lead to mounting liabilities at policy banks, and a negative outlook indicates a higher likelihood of a rating change over the medium term. Despite this, Moody's maintained China's credit rating at Aa3, citing large buffers in the economy.

site_title: Unit trusts, ILPs under CPFIS gain 3 per cent in Q4
summary: Singapore's unit trusts and investment-linked insurance products (ILPs) included under the Central Provident Fund Investment Scheme (CPFIS) posted positive returns of 3.01% on average in Q4 2015, with equity and mixed-asset funds rising 3.87% and 2.37%, respectively. However, the full-year performance declined 0.19%, with unit trusts falling 0.08% and ILPs 0.26%. Experts predict a challenging 2016 due to global financial market volatility and low oil prices.

site_title: Volatility knocks 6,000 out of ultra-rich club
summary: A global economic downturn led to an 8% decline in the number of ultra-high net worth individuals (UHNWIs) in Singapore, bringing the total to 2,360. This represents a 3% drop in the UHNWI population worldwide, the first annual decline since the 2008 financial crisis. Asia continues to see significant growth in UHNWI populations, driven by China and India, and is expected to account for 41% of global growth by 2025. Singapore ranks third globally, behind New York and London, and Hong Kong remains the top Asian city with the most UHNWIs.

site_title: Uber spends millions on new HQ in Oakland
summary: Uber has invested $123.5 million in its new Oakland headquarters, a historic Sears building that will house about 5 times the number of employees as Lyft's headquarters. The facility, valued at $123.5 million, is about 4 times larger than Pandora Media's office nearby. Renovations, valued at $2 million, have been filed, according to BuildZoom.

site_title: Super Tuesday wins push Clinton, Trump closer to Nov 8
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump emerged as the favorites to secure their party's presidential nominations after winning seven states each on Super Tuesday, setting up a potential White House showdown. Clinton used her advantage among southern and black voters, while Trump tapped into the anger of blue-collar workers. Despite US senators standing in their way, both candidates seem increasingly prepared to fight for the nomination, with Clinton signaling a focus on the general election and Trump turning his attention towards November.

site_title: US crude stocks surge to fresh record on distillate, import rise: EIA
summary: US crude stocks surged to a fresh record high for the third consecutive week, rising 10.4 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. Distillate inventories increased unexpectedly, and imports grew by 502,000 barrels per day. Gasoline stocks fell by 1.5 million barrels, while refinery crude runs rose by 167,000 barrels per day. Refinery utilization rates also increased by 1 percentage point. The rise in crude stocks is attributed to higher distillate inventories and increased imports, contradicting market expectations.

site_title: High-value industries propelling China growth: KPMG
summary: China's economy is shifting from an investment and export-led growth model to one driven by consumption and innovation, driven by government initiatives to tackle overcapacity and promote productivity and entrepreneurship. Non-financial outbound investment reached a record $118.02 billion in 2015, and KPMG predicts 10% annual growth in overseas direct investment. Key sectors to watch include agriculture and food, infrastructure, high-end manufacturing, and real estate, with infocomm technology, healthcare, and transportation emerging as new areas of growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings made its largest share buyback, purchasing 16 million shares at S$0.42. The company has bought back 1.6 million shares in the past week. Meanwhile, Magnus Energy shareholders have requested an EGM to remove current directors and not issue new convertible notes. Genting Hong Kong plans to spend HK$1.99 billion to acquire its cruise shipbuilding yards from a German manufacturer.

site_title: Rice, pork and more to come from Jilin Food Zone
summary: The Sino-Singapore Jilin Food Zone (SSJFZ) has signed an agreement with Thai giant Charoen Pokphand to establish its first pig farm, with the potential to export pigs to Singapore within the next two years. The zone, which unveiled its first product, Fragrance 43°N japonica rice, has set its sights on more ambitious goals, including a joint venture for infant milk powder production. The pig farm, valued at S$1.07 billion, will rear up to one million pigs and is expected to increase pork supply for Singapore, addressing the country's reliance on external sources.

site_title: Feb manufacturing PMI a letdown, points to less room for growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the eighth straight month in February, with a PMI of 48.5, its lowest level in over three years. The sector's growth prospects are now bearish, with observers warning of less room for growth in the later half of the year. Economists attribute the downturn to weaker demand, lower employment, and increased inventories, with some citing the impact of the Chinese New Year as a contributing factor. The sector's performance is part of a broader trend of declining manufacturing PMIs in Asian economies, leading to concerns about regional and global economic growth.

site_title: Housing market risks rising, but smaller than in 2014: BoE's Cunliffe
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe stated that housing market risks are rising but remain smaller than in 2014. The rapidly growing "buy-to-let" rental sector poses a financial stability risk, prompting the Bank to ask the government for the power to intervene. A public consultation on the matter will continue until March 11. Cunliffe warned that the market is starting to move back, making some risks more prominent.

images.alt_text: The risks in the housing market are rising but remain smaller than in 2014, Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said on Wednesday.

site_title: STI up 1.7% on Wall Street, China rally
summary: Wall Street's Straits Times Index rose 1.7% to a five-day high, driven by a rally in Chinese stocks and comforting macro data. The benchmark index gained 44.57 points to 2,726.96, while major Asian bourses also advanced, with China's Shanghai Composite up 4% and Japan's Nikkei 225 climbing 4%. Despite concerns over China's slowing economy, Moody's cut its outlook for China's sovereign ratings to negative.

site_title: The milk you've never heard of rocking the dairy world
summary: A type of cows' milk from a2 Milk Co. is gaining international attention for its potential health benefits, particularly in alleviating digestive issues and potentially reducing the risk of diabetes. Developed in Sydney, the milk is made from the milk of cows that have been bred to produce A2 protein, rather than the more common A1 protein found in most commercial dairy products. Consumers like Gillian Fyvie, who experienced digestive discomfort from regular milk, have reported positive results after switching to a2 Milk Co. products. The company is seeing an international following for its innovative approach.

site_title: Possible debris from Malaysia flight MH370 found near Mozambique: NBC
summary: A piece of debris found along the eastern African coast between Mozambique and Madagascar may be from the tail section of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which disappeared in 2014. The US, Malaysian, and Australian investigators have examined photos of the possible debris, which resembles a horizontal stabilizer from a Boeing 777. Boeing engineers are examining the photos, and Australian authorities are arranging for an investigation. This discovery comes after a reported wing piece was found on the shore of Reunion island last year. The debris's origin remains unconfirmed.

site_title: Private consumption fuels Swiss growth
summary: The Swiss economy rebounded from a recession threat, with its GDP increasing 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2015, after contracting 0.1% in the prior quarter. This growth was unexpected by economists, who had forecast a 0.1% growth rate. The recovery is attributed to private consumption, which helped counteract the impact of a currency shock. The Swiss economy's return to growth suggests it is well-positioned to withstand economic challenges.

site_title: Germany to cooperate with US on IT standards to reboot industry
summary: Germany has agreed to collaborate with the US on IT standards to modernize its small and mid-sized businesses and safeguard its industrial competitiveness. The country's "Industrie 4.0" platform, launched in 2013, aims to promote digitalization in industry, while the US-based Industrial Internet Consortium (IIC) focuses on adopting industrial internet technologies across industries. The two organizations will set up regular technical exchanges and discuss common testing initiatives to facilitate smoother international cooperation and standardization.

site_title: Chinese overseas investment tops US$1 trillion
summary: Chinese investors have invested over $1 trillion in foreign property, stocks, and bonds between 2005 and mid-2015, according to Knight Frank's Wealth Report. This trend is driven by the threat of a domestic economic slowdown, prompting Chinese citizens and companies to funnel wealth abroad. This poses a challenge for authorities in Beijing as they struggle to manage the outflow of capital.

site_title: Some Magnus Energy shareholders want all current directors removed
summary: Magnus Energy Group shareholders have requested an extraordinary general meeting to remove all current directors and nominate replacements. They also asked the company not to issue new convertible notes. The company received the letter on March 1 and is seeking legal advice. This move comes after the shareholders expressed dissatisfaction with the current management, leading to a potential shake-up in the company's leadership.

site_title: Sugar-cane fuel wins in Brazil as cheap ethanol beats petrol
summary: Brazil's economic crisis is boosting the nation's ethanol producers. Cheap ethanol is drawing drivers away from petrol, with sales of hydrous ethanol rising 10% year-over-year and petrol sales shrinking 9.3%. Ethanol prices have remained high due to the price gap, which has fallen to 1 real (S$0.35) per liter. This trend is helping sugar and ethanol producers recover from years of poor results, with Biosev SA posting a net profit after eight consecutive quarterly losses.

site_title: US: Wall St lower at the open as oil prices slide
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Wednesday as oil prices slid, with the Dow Jones down 51.09 points (0.3%) to 16,813.99, the S&P 500 losing 4.73 points (0.24%) to 1,973.62, and the Nasdaq Composite index dropping 8.48 points (0.18%) to 4,681.11. The decline followed data showing US crude stockpiles reached record highs.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI falls to 48.5 in February, lowest in three years
summary: Singapore's manufacturing activity contracted in February, reaching its lowest level in three years, with a PMI of 48.5. This marks the eighth consecutive month of contraction, with a 0.5 drop from January's 49. The decline was attributed to fewer new orders, lower employment numbers, and a poor showing in the electronics sub-sector. The level of inventories and stocks rose, indicating possible slowing demand for manufacturing.

site_title: US private sector adds 214,000 jobs in February: ADP
summary: US private employers added 214,000 jobs in February, exceeding economists' expectations of 190,000. The ADP National Employment Report also revised private payroll gains for January to 193,000. The US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report on Friday will include both public and private-sector employment. Economists forecast US private payroll employment to grow by 185,000 jobs and total non-farm employment to increase by 190,000. The unemployment rate is expected to remain at 4.9%.

site_title: Olympics: 47% of tickets sold and Zika not a problem, Rio organisers
summary: Rio Olympics organisers reported 47% of tickets sold, exceeding 74% of the financial target, five months before the opening ceremony. The ticket sales amount to $194 million. Despite concerns over the Zika virus and infrastructure, organisers are confident, citing the World Health Organization's statement that there is no problem with Zika. The chairman assured that 90-95% of venues are ready, with the velodrome expected to be ready for a test event by the end of April.

site_title: HKEx plans for spot commodity markets in China would involve physical delivery
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) plans to create mainland, physically deliverable spot commodity markets in China, leveraging the London Metal Exchange's warehousing expertise. The move aims to support China's growing commodity trading needs. HKEx Chief Executive Charles Li stated that the plan is part of its 2016-2018 Strategic Plan, which includes exploring a warehousing and financing platform for spot commodity trading. The exact details of the plan remain unclear, but it is expected to benefit from the expertise of the London Metal Exchange.

site_title: Global watchdog says bond market liquidity a concern
summary: The International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) has identified bond market liquidity as a concern, citing limited data and potential for market stress. The watchdog notes that banks' tougher capital rules may reduce their ability to hold large bond inventories, leading to thinner liquidity in secondary bond markets. IOSCO is gathering more data and assessing the role of asset managers in addressing this issue, with a report on market liquidity expected in September. The concern is part of four top market risks for 2016, including cyber threats and misconduct in retail financial products.

site_title: Swiss economy grows, exports gain foothold in face of "franc shock"
summary: Switzerland's economy grew 0.9% in 2015, outperforming expectations despite a sharp rise in the franc, which soared over 25% against the euro. Exporters cut prices by 6% and sales abroad boosted pharmaceutical and chemical companies. While growth was weaker than peers and behind forecast, economists deemed the results "remarkably robust" and said fears of recession did not materialize. Growth is expected to pick up in 2016, with forecasts ranging from 1.2% to 1.4%.

site_title: As India expects rate cut, IMF warns Rajan to keep policy tight
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has advised Indian central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan to keep interest rates tight amid expectations of a rate cut. The IMF warned that inflation may accelerate to 5.3% by April 1, surpassing Rajan's target of 5% by March 2017. The IMF's report, released on January 27, stated that the authorities should be prepared to raise rates if inflationary pressures increase, as the nation's fastest economic growth rate is at risk. This contradicts forecasts from economists and government officials who expect a rate cut.

site_title: EU unveils huge migrant aid plan for Greece
summary: The European Union has unveiled a 700-million-euro emergency aid plan for Greece and other EU states affected by the migrant crisis. The plan, which must be approved by member states and the European Parliament, aims to provide humanitarian aid to those stuck at the Greece-Macedonia border. The funds will be allocated over three years, with 300 million euros in 2016, and 200 million euros in each of the following years. The EU is also working directly with the UN and other aid agencies in Europe, marking a departure from its usual external aid approach.

site_title: Indonesia hopes new hedging rules will attract sharia-compliant investors
summary: Indonesia's central bank has issued a regulation allowing Islamic and conventional banks to use Islamic foreign exchange hedging tools, such as deferred sales of foreign exchange under a muwa'adah scheme. The rules aim to mitigate market risks and increase sharia-compliant investors' confidence in the country's financial system. The new regulation, backed by the National Sharia Board, specifies that such transactions must have an underlying real need and cannot be used for speculation. The move is expected to attract sharia-compliant investors and expand Indonesia's Islamic finance industry.

site_title: Alibaba plans stake in China business magazine: reports
summary: Alibaba plans to take a stake in Caixin Media, a respected Chinese business magazine, as part of its expansion into the media industry. The move, led by Alibaba founder Jack Ma, aims to diversify the company's business beyond e-commerce. Caixin Media's editorial independence is expected to be respected by new investors, but concerns remain about the potential impact on press freedoms in China. The deal has sparked comparisons to Amazon founder Jeff Bezos' purchase of the Washington Post.

images.alt_text: The publisher of one of China's most respected business magazines, Caixin, said Wednesday it was seeking new investors following reports e-commerce giant Alibaba plans to take a stake in the company as it looks to expand its media empire.

site_title: China eyes 13% money supply growth to buffer economy in 2016: sources
summary: China plans to target a 13% broad-based money supply growth in 2016, aiming to keep liquidity flush and buffer the economy during restructuring efforts. This comes as the country seeks to tackle excess factory capacity and "zombie firms" through "supply-side structural reforms." The government aims for an inflation forecast of 3% and economic growth of 6.5-7%. The move is seen as a signal that further monetary policy easing is likely, with the central bank expected to pump out more cash via policy tools to meet the need for supply-side reforms.

site_title: Keppel Land in joint venture to develop waterfront site in Vietnam
summary: Keppel Land has entered into a conditional investment agreement to subscribe for 40% equity interest in Empire City, a US$93.9 million investment, for a 14.6-hectare waterfront site in Vietnam's Thu Thiem New Urban Area. The joint venture will develop premium residential apartments, office and retail properties, and an 86-storey integrated mixed-use tower complex. Keppel Land is partnering with Vietnamese companies Tien Phuoc Real Estate Joint Stock Company and Tran Thai Real Estate, as well as Hong Kong-based real estate private equity fund Gaw Capital Partners.

site_title: Indonesia, Australia issue tsunami warning after 7.9 magnitude quake off Sumatra
summary: A 7.9 magnitude earthquake struck off the west coast of Indonesia's Sumatra island, triggering a tsunami warning for West Sumatra, North Sumatra, and Aceh. The quake, 10 km deep, was followed by a tsunami watch for parts of Australia's western coast. No immediate damage or casualties were reported, but rescue efforts are hindered by early darkness in the tropical archipelago. Indonesia, particularly Aceh, was devastated by a 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami that killed 126,741 people.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 1.7%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.7% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,726.96. The key market saw 1.98 billion shares worth S$1.5 billion traded, with 285 counters increasing and 124 decreasing. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: German competition watchdog opens probe into Facebook
summary: Germany's Federal Cartel Office has launched an investigation into Facebook, alleging the company abused its dominant market position by infringing data protection rules. The investigation focuses on Facebook's terms of service on user data. The cartel office is examining whether Facebook's actions violated German data protection laws. The probe is ongoing, with no immediate conclusions or penalties announced.

site_title: China Everbright Water to operate treatment projects in Zhangqiu City
summary: China Everbright Water Limited partnered with the Zhangqiu municipal government to form a 95-5 joint venture to operate two wastewater treatment projects in Zhangqiu City, with a total investment of approximately 160 million yuan (S$34.29 million) over a 30-year concession term.

site_title: Hot Stock: Ezra most actively-traded counter on Wednesday
summary: EZRA Holdings was the most actively-traded counter on Wednesday with 235.76 million shares changing hands. As of 5:06 pm, the stock rose 7.25% to 7.4 Singapore cents per share, extending its climb over the last few days amid a rally in offshore marine stocks due to hopes that oil has reached a bottom.

site_title: Hong Kong residential plot sells for higher price than forecast
summary: A Hong Kong government land sale of a prime residential plot in Kowloon sold for HK$6.4 million (US$823,204), exceeding analysts' expectations of HK$5.86-5.9 billion. The sale follows a less-than-expected sale last month and cancelled tenders, easing concerns about a deeper downturn in the property market. This sale comes as developers report sharp profit declines and analysts predict a 10-15% drop in home prices in Hong Kong this year. The site, with a 50-year land grant, was awarded to Goldin Financial Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Football: Platini appeals against six year ban
summary: UEFA president Michel Platini has appealed his six-year ban from football at the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) over a $2 million payment made by FIFA to him. Platini and former FIFA leader Sepp Blatter were banned for six years each. The CAS will consider Platini's appeal before the European Championships in France, which would allow him to attend if he is successful.

site_title: Fewer ultra rich people in Singapore in 2015, but long term wealth growth intact
summary: The number of ultra-rich individuals in Singapore decreased by 8% to 2,360 in 2015, due to global economic slowdown, according to Knight Frank's Wealth Report. This marks a decline from 2014, but the report notes that long-term wealth growth remains intact. The survey polled around 400 private bankers, including 30 in Singapore.

site_title: Easy ECB policy "vital" for growth and banks' health
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) commitment to an easy monetary policy to boost inflation is deemed "vital" for the region's economy and bank health by ECB executive board member Benoit Coeure. The ECB acknowledges concerns about ultra-low rates impacting bank margins, but argues that restoring economic growth is crucial for the banking system. Coeure stated that the ECB's price stability mandate is essential in anchoring expectations of nominal growth, amid a highly sensitive banking sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares hit 7-week high on global, mainland China market strength
summary: Hong Kong shares hit a 7-week high, rising 3.1% to 20,003.49 points, driven by strength in global markets and a 4% jump in mainland China shares. The China Enterprises Index also rose 3.8%. Investors ignored Moody's downgrade of China's outlook to "negative" and focused on tentative signs of recovery in the property market, awaiting policy cues from China's annual meeting starting March 5.

site_title: BlackRock says 'Brexit' brings UK risks but few rewards
summary: BlackRock predicts the UK would experience less economic growth and increased unemployment and inflation if it leaves the European Union in the June referendum. Vice Chairman Philipp Hildebrand stated that "Brexit offers a lot of risk with little obvious reward." The report also warned of increased volatility in UK and European assets before the vote. Prime Minister David Cameron has scheduled the referendum for June 23.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.21 points to close at 1,691.03 on March 2, 2016. The index saw 1.66 billion lots valued at RM2.28 billion traded, with 478 gainers and 375 losers.

site_title: UK construction growth at 10-month low, housebuilding weak
summary: Britain's construction industry experienced a 10-month low in February, with the Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 54.2. This marks a decline from the previous month and below economists' forecasts. Housebuilding also slowed, with the pace of expansion the weakest since June 2013, and construction firms reduced staff hiring. The results indicate a slowdown in the economy, adding to concerns about growth.

site_title: Food Empire subsidiary enters joint venture with US$12.24m investment
summary: Food Empire's Future Investment Holdings has entered a joint venture agreement with Sweet Blossom Holdings for a US$12.24 million investment. The joint venture, Hallyu Ventures, aims to invest in food and beverage companies in Korea and the region. Future Investment and Sweet Blossom will hold 51% and 49% equity stakes, respectively, in Hallyu Ventures. This move is part of Food Empire's expansion plans into the region's food and beverage market.

site_title: Oxley buys back 16 million shares at S$0.42
summary: Oxley Holdings, a property developer, made its largest share buyback this year, purchasing 16 million shares at S$0.42 per share. The counter finished unchanged at S$0.425 after the buyback. This is part of Oxley's efforts to return value to shareholders, with the company having bought back shares in the past week.

site_title: Toyota promotes non-Japanese to help oversee structural overhaul
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is promoting non-Japanese executives, including Didier Leroy and Steve St Angelo, to oversee its structural overhaul. Leroy will become chief competitive officer, while St Angelo will be senior managing officer. The moves aim to make the world's largest automaker more nimble, following a series of changes in its business structure. Despite this, women remain absent from Toyota's executive ranks, with the company's first female managing officer, Julie Hamp, resigning last year after a brief detention on suspicion of violating Japan's drug laws.

site_title: SGX adds 41 firms to watch-list for failure to meet new minimum trading price
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has added 41 companies to its watch-list for failing to meet its new minimum trading price requirement of 20 Singapore cents. This brings the total number of companies on the watch-list to 76. The companies will have three years to rectify their breaches, or risk being delisted. The new requirement aims to improve market quality by reducing manipulation. The watch-list includes companies whose trading prices fell below the minimum, as well as those that failed profitability and market value tests.

site_title: Wandervale EC average price set at S$755 psf
summary: SIM Lian Group announced an average price of S$755 psf for Wandervale Executive Condominium, a 534-unit development near Choa Chu Kang MRT station. The prices range from S$655,000 for a three-bedroom unit to S$896,000 for a four-bedroom unit. The development saw a subscription rate of approximately 1.47 times during its e-application period, which ended on Feb 28. Wandervale is the first executive condominium launched in Singapore this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as miners gain on China stimulus
summary: European shares rose on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining stocks following China's new economic stimulus measures, which lifted copper prices. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index advanced 0.7%, while the euro zone's blue-chip Euro STOXX 50 index and Britain's FTSE 100 also climbed 0.6%. The recovery comes after sharp losses earlier in the year due to concerns over a slowdown in China, the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Poll shows value of pound a big factor in Brexit vote
summary: A poll of 1,002 Britons shows that 55% are worried about the impact of a Brexit on the pound, with 43% citing the value of sterling as a key factor in their vote. 61% of women are concerned, and 69% of Londoners. The poll suggests the value of the pound could influence the outcome of the referendum, with a negative impact on sterling potentially affecting travel, property, and remittances. Financial markets have already priced in concerns, with the pound falling 9% against the dollar since November.

site_title: China's real estate frenzy is back as Shenzhen prices surge 50%
summary: China's real estate market is experiencing a surge, with prices in Shenzhen rising 50% over the past year, the fastest pace since 2011. Leveraged speculators are buying homes in top-tier cities, fueled by monetary stimulus and a loosening of property curbs. Authorities are warning against "panic" buying and urging calm, but experts predict the government may act to cool demand in cities where prices have risen fastest. The boom is driven by abundant liquidity and investors seeking alternatives to low-yielding stocks and bonds, with some cities introducing measures to ease the market, such as zero down-payment mortgages.

site_title: Dubai launches 30b dirham wholesale 'city' to boost its trade economy
summary: Dubai is launching a 30 billion dirham (S$11.5 billion) wholesale "city" to become the world's largest wholesale hub, spanning over 550 million square feet. The development aims to raise the UAE's share of global wholesale trade, growing from $4.3 trillion to $4.9 trillion over the next five years. The project, which will include specialized trading parks and an international trade exhibition facility, is expected to be home to over 15,000 wholesale traders, solidifying Dubai's position as the region's largest non-oil trading centre.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has added 41 Mainboard-listed companies to its watch-list for failing to meet the new minimum trading price. Singapore may consider abandoning increases in foreign-worker levies due to the slowing economy. Ezra Holdings was the most actively-traded counter on Wednesday, with MyRepublic Ltd aiming to be profitable within three years of winning a mobile-phone license. Moody's downgraded China's government debt outlook to "negative" citing reform and fiscal risks. Singapore shares rose 1.7% on the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse net rises 54% to a record US$1b
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd reported a record net income of US$1 billion, a 54% increase from the previous year, driven by higher trading turnover. Revenue rose 36% to HK$13.38 billion. The exchange's fourth-quarter net income and revenue remained largely unchanged. Analysts expect the bourse to expand its trading links with China to generate additional revenue. Despite this, analysts do not see catalysts for the earnings drivers in the first half of 2016.

site_title: Singapore central bank seen on hold in April, but easing risks rise
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), may hold off on monetary easing in April unless China's slowdown worsens or job losses increase, according to a Reuters poll. The MAS cut its 2016 inflation forecast and faced challenges from weak exports, oil prices, and market volatility. Analysts see rising risks of easing, with four predicting a central bank move, but eight believe it's still unlikely.

site_title: Daimler Commercial Vehicles makes S'pore its regional centre
summary: Daimler Commercial Vehicles has established Singapore as its regional centre for managing 18 markets in South-east Asia, decentralizing from its Stuttgart, Germany headquarters. This move aims to get closer to its markets and realize their full potential. The company, which owns brands such as Mercedes-Benz Trucks and Freightliner, will oversee the region from its new Singapore base, replacing the existing Daimler South-east Asia office.

site_title: Spain's jobless inches higher in February
summary: Spain's unemployment rate increased by 0.05% in February, with 2,231 more people registering as jobless, bringing the total to 4.15 million. Most layoffs were in the agriculture sector, with a decrease in services, construction, and industry. Seasonally adjusted jobless numbers fell by 21,959 people.

site_title: US was Germany's biggest trading partner in 2015: data
summary: The US surpassed France as Germany's largest trading partner in 2015, with goods worth $188 billion exchanged between the two countries. This marked the first time since the mid-1970s that the US held this position. Germany's top trading partners were the US, France, and the Netherlands, with $173.2 billion, $170.1 billion, and $167.6 billion in goods exchanged, respectively.

site_title: Japan's three biggest banks declare yen's depreciation is over
summary: Japan's three largest banks, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, and Mizuho Bank, have revised up their 2016 forecasts, citing the yen's 6.7% gain in the first two months of the year. The yen is expected to end the year stronger than its starting point, with forecasts ranging from 105 to 118 per US dollar. This could hinder Haruhiko Kuroda's efforts to boost inflation and growth, as the yen's appreciation reduces the effectiveness of the Bank of Japan's easing policies.

site_title: Aberdeen sticks to trusted ways as dark skies loom
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management's Singapore-based managing director Hugh Young predicts a tough year for global investors in 2016 due to weak global growth and the failure of central bank stimulus. Despite clients pulling over $30 billion from the firm's funds, Young remains committed to his long-term investment strategy of finding undervalued companies. He has stuck to his approach for over three decades, weathering previous economic downturns such as the 1987 crash and global recession. Young's firm manages over $400 billion in assets, undeterred by current market conditions.

site_title: Asian currencies gain as US data lifts risky assets
summary: Asian currencies rose as US manufacturing sector data showed signs of recovery, easing global growth concerns. The Indonesian rupiah reached a 4-1/2-month high against the dollar, while the Philippine peso hit a seven-week high. China's central bank added monetary stimulus, reducing reserve requirements, and the G-20 meeting reaffirmed no country would devalue its currency to trigger a currency war. However, some analysts predict Asian currencies may underperform in the medium term due to a tepid global growth outlook.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won up on global economic recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks jumped 1.6% to their highest in two months, driven by China's monetary stimulus and positive US economic data, boosting global economic recovery hopes. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 1,947.42 points, while the won strengthened 0.7% against the US dollar. The gains followed a national holiday on Tuesday, when local markets were closed.

site_title: Petrobras to cut 5-year investment plan by one-fifth to US$80b
summary: Brazil's state-led oil company Petrobras will slash its 5-year investment plan by about one-fifth to $80 billion, averaging $16 billion a year, due to low oil prices, massive debt, and a corruption scandal. This is the smallest 5-year investment program for the company since 2006 and marks the latest downward revision. The new plan is roughly 20% smaller than the previous $98.4 billion plan and one-third of the original $235 billion plan.

site_title: Debts rise at China's big steel mills, consumption falls
summary: China's major steel mills increased debt by 1.6 percentage points to 70.1% in 2015, reaching 3.27 trillion yuan. Steel product consumption fell 5.4% to 664 million tonnes, the first drop in two decades. The industry aims to cut 100-150 million tonnes of crude steel capacity and eliminate "zombie" mills. Rising debt and slower demand will pressure the industry, with prices already at multi-year lows. The government will allocate 100 billion yuan to deal with job losses and tackle debt, affecting 1.8 million workers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks soar, extending global rally
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index surged 4.11% to 16,746.55, extending a global rally fueled by upbeat US data and hopes for China's economic boost. The Nikkei 225 index rose, while the broader Topix index of all first-section shares also jumped 3.75%. The rally comes amid hopes of central bank moves to support China's slowing economy.

site_title: China's yuan firms despite Moody's cutting China outlook to 'negative'
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the dollar on Wednesday, defying Moody's downgrade of the country's sovereign debt outlook to "negative". The People's Bank of China intervened to maintain the yuan's stability, guiding the midpoint rate to a one-month low. The offshore yuan converged with its onshore counterpart at 6.5517 per US dollar. Despite the downgrade, traders expressed confidence in the PBOC's ability to maintain yuan stability. The yuan softened against the euro but strengthened against the Japanese yen.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend global rally on US data, China stimulus
summary: Asian stocks surged on Wednesday, fueled by upbeat US economic data and China's fresh stimulus. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 4.04%, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul also saw significant gains. The move was driven by a weaker yen and improved US manufacturing sector reports, putting the chances of another Federal Reserve rate rise back into play. China's stimulus package aimed at encouraging lending and stimulating activity also boosted market sentiment.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise on good GDP growth, US economic data
summary: Australian shares rose 2% on Wednesday, driven by better-than-expected GDP growth in October-December, the fastest pace in almost two years. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 98.948 points to 5,021.200 points, building on a 0.85% gain on Tuesday. The positive sentiment was also boosted by upbeat US economic data.

site_title: Prices could fall on monthly basis in March, April: Bank Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Agus Martowardojo expects consumer prices to fall on a monthly basis in March and April, following a 0.09% decline in February. The February annual inflation rate of 4.42% is in line with the bank's target of 3-5% at end-2016. Bank Indonesia has cut its benchmark rate twice this year, currently at 7.00%. The bank will review its monetary policy on March 16-17.

site_title: Gold slides for second day as stocks rally on US economic data
summary: Gold prices dropped for a second day, retreating from an 11% gain in February, as global stocks advanced following better-than-expected US factory data. The Institute for Supply Management's February index showed a decline less than economists expected, with at least half of industries expanding for the first time since August. The rally in US stocks and Asian shares lifted investor sentiment, easing demand for haven assets like gold.

site_title: Airbus starts work on new China facility
summary: Airbus has begun construction on a new facility in Tianjin, China, to deliver wide-body planes, marking a significant milestone in its international presence. The facility, which will produce two A330 planes per month, is Airbus' first such facility outside Europe. CEO Fabrice Bregier described it as a "new milestone for Airbus' international footprint." The move aims to counter US rival Boeing's growing presence in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Japan's silver-haired seniors still punching the time clock
summary: Japan's elderly workforce remains active, with over 20% of those aged 65 and older still working, the highest proportion among developed economies. This is attributed to a desire to stay mentally and physically fit, as well as financial necessity. The government is gradually raising the official retirement age to 65 by 2025, and some companies, such as Honda, are also adopting this policy. The aging population is expected to account for nearly 40% of the population by 2060, putting pressure on Japan's social welfare system, with the labor force projected to lose over 27 million workers in the same time frame.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah in longest rally since 2010 as equities and bonds advance
summary: Indonesia's rupiah reached its highest level since October 2015, rising 0.6% to 13,278 against the US dollar, as it entered its 10th day of a winning streak. The Jakarta Composite Index also rose 1%, driven by speculation that the central bank won't cut interest rates aggressively. President Joko Widodo had called for lower borrowing costs to spur growth, but the recent rally suggests investors are awaiting further monetary policy changes. The rupiah's rally follows positive US manufacturing data and speculation that previous losses were overdone.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2016: Singapore may abandon raising foreign worker levies as economy slows: BOA
summary: Singapore's Budget 2016 may abandon raising foreign worker levies due to a slowing economy, according to a Bank of America Merrill Lynch report. The report suggests the government may fine-tune foreign worker policies instead of increasing levies. However, there are no expectations for the budget to have a significant impact on growth or markets. The focus is on Minister Heng Swee Keat's response to businesses' needs, with some hoping for more support after being neglected in favor of social goals. Property measures are unlikely to be relaxed.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump to 2-month high, won up on positive US data
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 2-month high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 1.4% to 1,943.56 points. The positive US economic data, including a beat in the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) index of factory activity, and China's cut in banks' reserve requirement ratio, boosted hopes for improved global growth. Heavyweights such as Posco, Samsung Electronics, and SK Hynix saw significant gains, with foreign investors net purchasing KOSPI shares worth 173.2 billion won. The South Korean won rose 0.2% against the US dollar.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up following regional bourses, near 4-month high
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.7% to 8,544.67, nearing a four-month high, driven by gains in regional bourses and broad-based buying. The electronics subindex led the gains, followed by the financials and plastics subindices. Shares in TSMC, a heavily-weighted component, also rose around 1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$33.113 per US dollar.

site_title: Hot stock: Ezion up amid active play among offshore marine stocks
summary: Ezion Holdings' stock rose 0.5 Singapore cents to S$0.515, driven by bets on offshore marine stocks and broad market gains. The stock was among the most actively traded plays, with 37.9 million shares changing hands. However, analysts warn that Ezion's financial position may be tested by late-payment customers and potential reduction in charter rates. Despite this, CIMB Research maintains a "buy" recommendation, citing positive free cash flow projections, while OCBC Investment Research advises a "hold" rating due to the company's high net gearing.

site_title: Oil prices fall on huge build in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday, with London Brent crude falling 8 cents to $36.73 a barrel, and US crude down 34 cents to $34.06 a barrel. The US saw a huge build in crude stockpiles, rising 9.9 million barrels last week, exceeding analyst expectations. Despite this, crude prices have trended higher over the past two weeks, with the bottom in the market now believed to be in place, according to ANZ bank.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally 1.5% on solid GDP, NZ nears 2-month top
summary: Australian shares rose 1.5% to an eight-day high, driven by better-than-expected GDP figures showing the domestic economy grew 0.6% in the last quarter. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 4,999.5 points, with financials stocks leading the gain. New Zealand's benchmark index also reached a near two-month peak. Analysts attribute the rally to upbeat US economic data and the boost to sentiment.

site_title: Australia's economy expands 0.6% in Q4, 3% year-on-year
summary: Australia's economy expanded 0.6% in Q4, beating expectations, to reach 3% year-on-year growth, driven by government and consumer spending. The stronger-than-expected growth was attributed to government and consumer spending, contrary to initial forecasts of 0.4% growth.

site_title: 'World's longest flight' lands in Auckland
summary: Emirates' Airbus A380 completed the world's longest non-stop scheduled commercial flight, landing in Auckland, New Zealand, with a 14,200km journey from Dubai, surpassing Qantas' 13,800km Sydney-Dallas route. The 17-hour 15-minute return leg will be operated by a Boeing 777. The record is expected to be short-lived as Emirates' upcoming Dubai-Panama City service will take 17 hours 35 minutes. The non-stop service cuts three hours off current travel times, improving New Zealand's connectivity to the world.

site_title: South Korea pension fund seeks higher dividends from local firms
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS) plans to ask domestic firms for higher dividends this year after their 2015 contributions to the pension fund's returns were the lowest. The NPS reported a 4.6% return on investments in 2015, with lower contributions from domestic stock holdings and overseas bond holdings. The pension fund aims to increase its overseas and alternative investment holdings to 35% of all assets by 2020 and is discussing dividend policies with local companies to encourage higher payouts.

site_title: Asian stocks surge, tracking US rally, as yen drops and energy shares climb
summary: Asian stocks surged 0.6% on March 2, tracking the US rally, with Japan's Topix index rising 1.9% after the yen dropped 1.2%. Energy shares led gains, while the MSCI Asia Pacific Index jumped 6.7% from its year-low on February 12. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index posted its largest increase since January, with US stocks continuing their upward trend despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Trump, Clinton capture key wins on US Super Tuesday
summary: US presidential front-runners Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton won key wins on Super Tuesday, capturing six states each. Trump won Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Massachusetts, Tennessee, and Virginia, while Clinton won the same states. Trump's rival Ted Cruz won his home state of Texas, bolstering his argument that he could stop Trump. Clinton's rival Bernie Sanders won Vermont and Oklahoma, vowing to continue his battle for the nomination. The victories set the stage for a potentially divisive Republican and Democratic convention in July.

site_title: Aussie dollar cheered by upbeat GDP data, NZ dollar subdued
summary: The Australian dollar surged after the country's GDP unexpectedly grew at a 3.0% annual pace in the December quarter, exceeding market expectations of 2.5%. This led to a 0.8% gain in the Aussie, reaching a one-month high of $0.7232. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates steady, with a 60% chance of a quarter-point cut by mid-year. The New Zealand dollar was subdued, remaining little changed at $0.6636, amid a negative US lead and a slight improvement in global dairy prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks soar 2.7% at open, extending global rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.7% at open on Wednesday, extending a global rally, driven by improved US economic data and hopes for Chinese economic growth. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 433.83 points to 16,519.34, while the Topix index climbed 34.78 points to 1,335.61. This follows a global rally and comes ahead of US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.810 points to 1674.650. Gainers outnumbered losers 139 to 40, with a total trading volume of 45.9 million lots worth RM20.9 million.

site_title: China reserve ratio cut not a signal of impending large-scale stimulus: Xinhua
summary: China's move to cut banks' reserve requirement ratio (RRR) by 50 basis points indicates a slight easing bias in monetary policy, but it is not a signal of impending large-scale stimulus. The cut frees up an estimated $100 billion in cash for new lending, supporting economic development, and is seen as a liquidity-neutral move to offset foreign currency reserve decline and accommodate open market operations. China's economy is growing at a reasonable rate, with no signs of chaos or crisis, making strong stimulus unnecessary, according to official news agency Xinhua.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday on US market rally
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 37.66 points to 2,720.05. The US markets surged overnight, leading to gains in stocks such as Jardine group, DBS, and Great Eastern. Trading volume was moderate, with 73.6 million shares worth S$132 million changing hands.

site_title: Ex-Chesapeake CEO McClendon indicted over lease bid rigging
summary: Aubrey McClendon, former CEO of Chesapeake Energy, has been indicted on charges of conspiring to rig bids for oil and natural gas leases in northwest Oklahoma. From 2007 to 2012, McClendon allegedly orchestrated a scheme between two companies, Company A and Company B, to not bid against each other, with the winning bidder allocating an interest in the leases to the other company. The US Justice Department's investigation is ongoing, and McClendon's lawyer has not commented on the charges.

site_title: Cheaper healthy food could save millions of lives: study
summary: Scientists at Harvard and Tufts Universities found that reducing the prices of fruits and vegetables and increasing the prices of sugary drinks could save millions of lives. A 10% drop in fruit prices could reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease by 1.2% within 5 years. Implementing such measures could prevent 515,000 deaths from cardiovascular disease and nearly 675,000 heart attacks and strokes. Several states and cities have attempted similar taxes on sugary drinks, with some exceptions, including the Navajo Nation's tax-free fruits and vegetables policy, which has been linked to education campaigns promoting healthy behavior.

site_title: Moody's cuts China outlook to 'negative', cites reform, fiscal risks
summary: Moody's downgraded China's government debt outlook to "negative" from "stable" due to uncertainty over economic reforms, rising government debt, and falling reserves. The downgrade cited a high debt burden that would slow GDP growth and increased fiscal risks. Moody's retained China's Aa3 rating, but warned it could further downgrade if reforms are not implemented. The downgrade is seen as a negative direction, but not a worrying sign, as China has a low government debt and a current account surplus that can fund its fiscal expansion.

site_title: China Resources Beer to buy 49% of SABMiller venture for US$1.6b
summary: China Resources Beer agreed to buy SABMiller's 49% stake in China Resources Snow Breweries Co, the maker of the world's best-selling beer, for US$1.6 billion. The state-backed company will acquire the remaining stake in their Chinese brewery joint venture. This deal marks China Resources Beer's expansion in the global beer market, further solidifying its position as a major player. The acquisition is part of China Resources Beer's efforts to strengthen its presence in the Asian market.

site_title: Clinton, Trump score first Super Tuesday wins
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump secured their first wins in the Super Tuesday contests, with Clinton projected to win in Georgia and Virginia, and Trump projected to win in Georgia. Trump's lead over Marco Rubio in Virginia was narrow, but he is still ahead nationwide, with polls showing him in a commanding lead. Clinton played down talk of a clean sweep, but Sanders was projected to win Vermont. The general election matchup between Clinton and Trump is becoming more likely, with a CNN/ORC poll showing both would easily defeat Trump if the election were held now.

site_title: Oil rises as Russia sees support for output freeze
summary: Oil prices rose 1.9% on Tuesday as Russia said domestic oil groups supported a proposal to freeze output to shore up the market. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 65 cents to $34.40 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude gained 24 cents to $36.81 a barrel. The market is driven by expectations of a tightening of supply and demand fundamentals, following a similar proposal by Saudi Arabia and Russia in February. The freeze agreement, if approved, aims to stabilize Russia's 2016 production level at 10.8 million barrels per day.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong to buy own shipyards in Germany
summary: Genting Hong Kong plans to spend HK$1.99 billion to acquire its own cruise shipbuilding yards in Germany from Nordic Yards. The acquisition aims to address the risk of not obtaining sufficient cruise ship building slots at acceptable prices. This move will allow Genting Hong Kong to build its cruise fleet, focusing on design, planning, and deployment. The company operates Star Cruises and plans a 10-year cruise ship fleet strategy for its three cruise brands.

site_title: Hyundai to develop mini electric car, electric scooter
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to develop a one-seater electric car and an electric scooter as part of its "smart mobility" project IONIQ. The move aims to expand into the growing industry of urban mobility solutions, driven by urbanization, pollution, and increased car usage. The project is part of Hyundai's future mobility strategy, following a similar announcement at the Geneva auto show.

site_title: Global funds bolt out as China opens door to yuan bond market
summary: China has opened its bond market to foreign investors, allowing them to invest without quotas, amid a record outflow of global funds. Global funds' holdings in Chinese bonds declined by 49.6 billion yuan in January, more than double the previous month's net sales. The yuan's weakness and lack of hedging tools discourage foreign buying, with central banks expected to dominate initial inflows. China's benchmark yield is 2.86%, higher than similar-maturity notes in the US and Japan, but lower than its peak of 3.70% last year.

site_title: South Korea Jan factory output shrinks more than expected
summary: South Korea's industrial output in January fell 1.8% from December, exceeding expectations and marking a decline in the country's manufacturing sector due to weak global demand. The result follows a revised 0.5% gain for December, and output in annual terms fell 1.9%. The service sector also saw a 0.9% decline in January. The data suggests ongoing challenges for South Korea's economy.

site_title: Australia new homes sales rise 3.1% in Jan
summary: Australia's new homes sales rose 3.1% in January, according to a Housing Industry Association survey, marking a second consecutive month of growth. Detached home sales increased 5.8%, while multi-unit sales fell by the same amount. The industry expects a healthy year for construction, with the sector expected to remain a mainstay of domestic economic activity in 2016.

site_title: China: Stocks flat despite stimulus measures, Hong Kong soars
summary: China's Shanghai shares opened flat on March 2, 2016, after a 1.68% jump the previous day on economic stimulus measures. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.60 points to 2,733.77. Hong Kong shares were sharply higher.

site_title: Glencore profit dives 69% as prices for metals, oil slide
summary: Glencore, a commodity trader and miner, reported a 69% slump in profit to $1.34 billion due to tumbling metal and oil prices. The company's mining unit swung to a loss, while its trading division generated $2.46 billion in adjusted earnings. Glencore aims to cut debt to $18 billion by selling assets and reducing costs. The company's shares have jumped 47% this year, despite a 55% drop in the past year, as investors gain confidence in its balance sheet.

site_title: US February auto sales hit best performance since 2000
summary: US auto sales reached their best performance since 2000 in February, with a 6.9% increase to 1.34 million vehicles, according to Autodata. Ford, Fiat Chrysler, Honda, and Nissan saw double-digit increases, driven by strong sales of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. Ford's SUV sales set a company record, while F-series pickup truck sales rose 10%, the best performance in a decade. Total annual sales are expected to reach 17.54 million vehicles, a 7% increase from last year.

site_title: Missing: US$15b lost somewhere in India's 1,500-page budget
summary: India's budget for 2016 remains shrouded in mystery, with a $21 billion wage hike for government employees still unaccounted for. Economists have scoured 1,500-page budget documents, with estimates ranging from $15 billion to over $70 billion. The missing funds could impact the government's credibility on reducing its budget deficit and sustaining its 7% growth rate. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has acknowledged the wage hike as "extremely challenging," but officials have provided conflicting information on the allocated amount, fueling concerns about the budget's transparency and sustainability.

site_title: Olympus to pay US$646m for bribing hospitals, doctors
summary: Olympus Corp of the Americas agreed to pay US$646 million to settle charges it gave hospitals and doctors kickbacks to buy its endoscopes, boosting sales and profits by over US$600 million between 2006 and 2011. The US Justice Department charged the company with violating anti-kickback laws and the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, but deferred prosecution after the company cooperated in the investigation and agreed to the fines and remedial actions. The company acknowledged responsibility for past conduct and committed to complying with laws and regulations.

site_title: Chinese overseas investment tops US$1t over a decade: report
summary: Chinese investors have invested over $1 trillion in foreign property, stocks, and bonds over the decade to mid-2015, according to Knight Frank's annual Wealth Report. This trend is driven by a desire to diversify portfolios amid a potential domestic economic slowdown in China. Despite restrictions on some Chinese nationals accessing foreign mortgage services, Chinese buyers remain a significant force in London's residential market. Experts predict continued investment from China in British and US property, but note that policy decisions in Beijing will influence the pace of investment.

site_title: Chongqing blazes economic trail as Bo scandal recedes
summary: Chongqing, China's metropolitan area, has continued to thrive despite the jailing of its charismatic former chief Bo Xilai four years ago. The city achieved a 11% growth rate in 2015, while the national economy slowed to 6.9%. Chongqing's success is attributed to its pragmatic approach, undertaking industrial upgrading and restructuring, as well as implementing policies to attract foreign investment and promote rural workers into the city. The city has become a leading center for automobile manufacturing and electronics, with many global brands operating in the region, and Mayor Huang Qifan is tipped for a national role, potentially as secretary-general of the cabinet.

site_title: US dollar rises vs euro, yen
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen on Tuesday, rising 1.1% to 113.94 yen and dipping the euro to US$1.0867. This comes as economic data showed the US manufacturing sector marginally contracting, but with many sectors reporting strong domestic demand. The ISM purchasing managers index for February came in above expectations, easing recession worries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Otto Marine, SingPost, SIA, Q&M Dental
summary: Otto Marine secured a $95.3 million contract for five years, while SingPost's lawyers notified the Securities Investors Association (SIA) about an anonymous letter deemed defamatory. SIA president David Gerald was asked if he shared the letter. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines will take delivery of 11 Airbus A350 aircraft this year, and Q&M Dental Group posted a 33% increase in net profit to $11.4 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: Singapore wireless wannabe MyRepublic eyes profit in three years
summary: MyRepublic Ltd, a Singapore wireless carrier, aims to become the country's fourth mobile-phone carrier and achieve profitability within three years. The company expects to start with a small subscriber base of 250,000 customers in the first year and reach 9% market share within five years. MyRepublic plans to offer unlimited data plans, leveraging its lower costs and existing infrastructure to build a 4G network nationwide. The company expects to raise S$250 million and will meet nationwide coverage by October 2018.

site_title: 'Brexit' brings UK big risks but few rewards: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock warns that a UK exit from the European Union in the June referendum would bring significant economic risks, including lower growth, higher unemployment, and inflation, with limited potential rewards. The company predicts volatility in UK and European assets, a potential shock to the global economy, and a decrease in the UK's clout in negotiating regulatory standards. Sterling would be vulnerable to Brexit fears, and UK equities would be harmed by a vote to leave.

site_title: China's green push gives clout to once "embarrassing" ministry
summary: China's Environment Ministry, once considered the country's "most embarrassing" department, has gained significant clout under the leadership of Prof Chen Jining. His efforts to crack down on polluting industries and factories have sparked a national debate and led to a collapse in commodity prices and a corruption crackdown. The ministry has summoned officials from 34 provinces and municipalities to account for environmental failures, and has overhauled its environmental impact assessment system.
