summary: Four Singapore-based designers form Outofstock, a design collective inspired by simplicity and poetry. The collective consists of four different designers. The SME Magazine article does not provide further information on the designers or their work.

site_title: India's RBI eases rules on what lenders can count as Basel III capital
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has eased rules on what lenders can count as Basel III capital, aiming to reduce fundraising pressures on the cash-constrained sector. The RBI now allows lenders to apply gains from revaluation of property and conversions of foreign currency in financial statements to core capital requirements under certain conditions. This move is expected to free up approximately $4.42-$5.16 billion for state-owned lenders and $737 million for private sector lenders, helping them meet their total funding requirements.

site_title: US: Oil gains push stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by a gain in oil prices and solid auto sales reports for February. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all increased, with the Dow up 83.07 points to 16,599.57, the S&P 500 adding 12.82 to 1,945.05, and the Nasdaq climbing 34.68 to 4,592.63. The gains follow a record high for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq on Monday.

site_title: Growing your wealth with insurance
summary: Insurance products can be a valuable addition to Singaporeans' retirement plans, helping to mitigate medical expenses and provide a steady income. A recent survey found that 66% of Singaporeans are concerned about having enough funds for retirement, while 88% do not expect to rely financially on their children. Experts like Tony Chow from China Life Insurance emphasize the importance of planning ahead due to Singapore's high cost of living and increasing life expectancy. Insurance can help supplement CPF and other investments, making it a key component of a diversified investment portfolio.

site_title: Will repeal of Section 153 harm board renewal?
summary: The Singapore Companies Act's Section 153 has been repealed, effective January 3, 2016, eliminating the age limit of 70 for directors. This change allows directors over 70 to be elected annually, rather than being re-elected every year. The repeal aims to align Singapore's legislation with other developed countries, and the lead author of a commentary previously advocated for the repeal.

site_title: Celebrating women who push boundaries
summary: Citibank is hosting an event to celebrate International Women's Day, "Pushing the Boundaries," featuring 90 guests, including women who have broken barriers, such as the first female team to scale Mount Everest. The bank has a high percentage of women in senior positions, with over 40% of Singaporean staff holding more senior roles as women. Globally, 30% of Citi's managing directors are women, and the bank has added more women to its board of directors, increasing the percentage of women leaders to over 30%.

site_title: Nobel Peace Prize nominations skyrocket
summary: A record 376 nominations have been submitted for the 2016 Nobel Peace Prize, surpassing the previous record of 278 in 2014. The nominations include 228 individuals and 148 organizations, with notable figures such as Donald Trump, Edward Snowden, and Pope Francis on the list. The names of the nominees will remain secret for at least 50 years, and the winner will be announced on October 7. This year's prize follows last year's award to four Tunisian groups that rescued the country's transition to democracy.

site_title: Billionaire L'Oreal family hires Lazard banker for wealth fund
summary: L'Oreal's billionaire Bettencourt-Meyers family has hired Lazard banker Alexandre Benais to invest some of the hundreds of millions of euros in dividends paid by the cosmetics maker. Benais will be deputy CFO at Tethys, the family's wealth management holding company, and CEO of Tethys Invest, a new fund for long-term investments. The new fund will be partly funded by L'Oreal dividends, which the family received $543 million in 2015 and will receive $624.4 million this year.

site_title: Top Global Q4 earnings drop despite revenue jump
summary: Top Global, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 42% drop in net profit to S$1.03 million for Q4 2015, despite a 145% year-over-year revenue jump to S$69.30 million. Administrative expenses and losses contributed to the decline, and earnings per share fell to 0.33 Singapore cents. The company expressed optimism about future growth opportunities in acquisitions and new businesses, aiming to deliver medium-term returns to shareholders.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: UK manufacturing in Feb the worst in almost 3 yrs
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced its weakest growth in almost three years in February, with a factory index of 50.8, down from 52.9 in the previous month. New orders barely rose, and employment shrank for a second month. The decline in manufacturing output is attributed to faltering export demand in mainland Europe and emerging markets, as well as uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU membership referendum. The Bank of England's Governor Mark Carney has expressed a dovish stance, indicating a potential hold on interest rate hikes until stronger economic growth is seen.

site_title: Thai True may not be profitable due to mobile costs
summary: Thai True Corp Pcl, Thailand's third largest mobile operator, may not make a profit this year due to high investments in expanding its mobile networks and rising costs. The company plans to invest $1.1 billion in 2016 and has secured a $2 billion loan guarantee. Analysts predict a loss over the next three to five years due to amortisation costs of 4G licences and network expansion. True aims to boost its mobile market share to 30% over the next three years.

site_title: Starland to be suspended after GRP offer hits 99.1%
summary: Trading in Starland Holdings will be suspended on March 2 after an offer by GRP Limited's indirect subsidiary took control of 99.1% of the company's issued shares, below the 10% threshold required by Catalist rules. The offeror, GRP Chongqing Land, has stated its intention to preserve Starland's listing status and does not intend to exercise compulsory acquisition rights. Starland has three months to restore its public float to at least 10% or longer if the SGX agrees.

site_title: Darco inks 3-year MOU to testbed industrial wastewater treatment system
summary: Darco Water Technologies has signed a 3-year memorandum of understanding with Aquaporin Asia to testbed an industrial wastewater treatment system. The project, funded by a S$2.5 million grant, aims to develop a zero liquid discharge system based on forward osmosis technology, which consumes less energy than conventional set-ups. The collaboration seeks to gain knowledge on zero liquid discharge operations and applications.

site_title: Uber's real estate footprint unmatched among SF Bay Area startups
summary: Uber has expanded its real estate footprint in the SF Bay Area, with a new Oakland headquarters costing $123.5 million and a planned San Francisco campus valued at $130 million. The Oakland building, set to house 2,000-3,000 employees, is four times larger than Pandora Media's office and five times larger than Lyft's headquarters. Uber's growth comes as the venture capital climate cools, with investors wary of valuations. The company's expansion underscores its dominance in the startup world, with a valuation of over $7.4 billion.

site_title: Iceberg's fourth report should be 'of no concern' to Noble shareholders: SIAS
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has stated that shareholders of commodities trader Noble Group do not need to be concerned about allegations raised in Iceberg Research's fourth report. Despite the report, Noble's share price rose 6% the day after the report and its announcement of FY2015 results, indicating a return in investor confidence. SIAS has determined that the allegations have "no discernible impact" on Noble's share price.

site_title: JD.com's revenue growth beats expectations
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce company, reported a 57% revenue increase to $8.34 billion in the fourth quarter of 2015, beating expectations. Despite China's economic slowdown, volume sales on its platforms jumped 69% to $22.19 billion. However, the company's net losses widened to $1.16 billion, mainly due to impairment charges on its Paipai.com business. Excluding one-off items, net losses were $100.10 million.

site_title: WP-run Aljunied-Hougang Town Council appoints KPMG as accountant
summary: The Workers' Party-run Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) in Singapore has appointed KPMG as its accountant after a court order. The move comes as the town council is expected to release its first monthly report by April 15. This decision follows the court's instruction to select accountants from among the Big Four firms, namely PwC, Deloitte, KPMG, and Ernst & Young.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom puts sale of T-Mobile US on hold
summary: Deutsche Telekom has put the sale of T-Mobile US on hold due to an upcoming auction of radio airwaves. The US Federal Communications Commission is set to start an auction at the end of this month, which could last for months, and participants are not allowed to engage in partnership or merger talks during the bidding process. This move gives potential suitors time to wait for a more favorable political environment towards telecoms mergers. T-Mobile US, 65.4%-owned by Deutsche Telekom, could spend up to $10 billion in the auction, similar to a record-breaking $44.9 billion raised by AWS-3 airwaves last year.

site_title: Microsoft to sell Windows security service to business customers
summary: Microsoft is launching Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection, a service for large businesses to detect and respond to security threats on their networks. The service, built on Microsoft's security data, uses in-house experts and algorithms to identify suspicious behavior and provides tools for IT directors to investigate and respond. The product is already being tested by a few customers and will be available in new versions of Windows 10. Pricing and a final release date have not been determined. The move aims to boost security in Windows amid growing demand for better protection from hackers and data breaches.

site_title: Shaw family said to acquire £270m London office from Malaysian pension fund
summary: A company controlled by the Shaw Foundation has agreed to acquire 88 Wood Street in London's financial district from Malaysia's KWAP pension fund for approximately £270 million. The deal is being advised by Knight Frank, but no comment has been provided by the parties involved. The acquisition is subject to completion, with the Shaw family and foundation declining to comment on the matter.

site_title: UK proposes earlier capacity power market auction in 2017
summary: The UK government proposes an earlier capacity power market auction in 2017 to ensure electricity supply in winter and enforce stricter penalties for non-compliant firms. The capacity market scheme pays power plant owners to provide electricity at short notice, aiming to invest in new plants or keep existing ones running. The government also aims to reduce the role of diesel generators in future auctions due to environmental concerns. This move comes amid concerns about electricity supply shortages in the coming winters, with coal plants closing and investors showing little incentive to build new power plants.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 16 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose 16.07 points to 1,670.820 on Tuesday, with 1.67 billion lots valued at RM1.64 billion traded. Gainers outpaced losers 476 to 405. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gained 16 points higher, closing the session.

site_title: Petronas may cut 1,000 jobs as oil slump prompts reorganisation
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil company, announced plans to cut 1,000 jobs as it reorganizes to trim operating costs amid the worst oil price slump in a generation. The company aims to lower capital and operating expenditures by 20 billion ringgit and reduce costs by 50 billion ringgit over four years. The job cuts are part of a new business structure, with affected employees to be redeployed or separated over the next six months. The move follows similar cost-cutting measures by global oil majors, including Royal Dutch Shell.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Tuesday, following overnight falls on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% to 6,084.51 points, while the DAX 30 index lost 0.1% to 9,482.66 points and the CAC 40 retreated 0.2% to 4,343.93 points. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Trump, Clinton poised for big wins on Super Tuesday
summary: Front-runner Donald Trump is poised for a big win on Super Tuesday, solidifying his control of the Republican presidential race. He leads in most states, with Texas being the lone exception, where Senator Ted Cruz is in desperate need of a victory. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton is expected to secure big victories in the Democratic primary, silencing concerns about her candidacy. Trump's lead in the Republican race has intensified concerns among party leaders about his hijacking of the party, while Clinton's wins could bolster her chances of securing the nomination.

site_title: Africa private equity fundraising to fall this year
summary: Africa private equity funds are expected to raise less cash for investment this year after a significant increase in 2015, with total fundraising expected to be lower due to a lag between fundraising and investment activity. In 2015, African private equity funds raised US$4.3 billion for investment, up from US$1.9 billion in 2014. While the value of private equity deals in Africa dropped to US$2.5 billion last year, the AVCA notes that there were more smaller deals, indicating a healthy economy at the small and medium enterprise level.

site_title: Euro zone factory PMI falls to one-year low
summary: The Euro zone's manufacturing activity expanded at its weakest pace for a year in February, with a PMI of 51.2, down from 52.3 in January. This weak growth reading is concerning for the European Central Bank ahead of its policy setting meeting, with worries of sluggish growth or even a downturn in 2016. Lacklustre domestic demand and a worsening global picture are contributing factors.

site_title: KS Energy unit bags US$6m contract to continue drilling in Egypt
summary: KS Energy's unit, KS Drilling, has secured a US$6 million contract with Egypt's Belayim Petroleum Company to continue drilling operations using its 300-feet jack-up rig, the "KS Medstar-1". The contract is expected to start in March 2016 and last for approximately four months, with no significant impact on KS Energy's financials.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher after gains in China, HK and Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.88 points to 2,682.39, driven by gains in China, Hong Kong, and Dow futures. The index closed in decent volume, with S$927 million in trading from index members. A cut in China's reserve ratio by 0.5 percentage point, aimed at maintaining loose monetary conditions, was seen as a positive move. However, experts note that China's economy relies on credit, and further reforms are needed to unlock productivity growth.

site_title: Asia credit close: credit lags equities after China cuts RRR again
summary: China's People's Bank of China cut the reserve ratio requirement by 50 basis points, resulting in decent gains across Asian equities but lacklustre credit markets. The Shanghai index rose 1.7%, while the Hang Seng gained 1.3%. Investment-grade bonds remained mostly unchanged, with the iTraxx Asia index quoted one point tighter. The RRR cut is expected to free up billions in cash for lending, and markets will now focus on the US presidential election primaries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.6% to 19,407.46 on Tuesday, tracking China's rally. The China Enterprises Index gained 1.9% to 8,068.29 points, with a total trading volume of 1.5 billion shares. The central bank's easing move contributed to the increase.

site_title: Japan big manufacturers' confidence weakens
summary: Japan's biggest manufacturers saw a decline in confidence, with a Tankan report showing a drop to plus six in March, down from 12 in the previous quarter. This marks a slowdown in the country's economy, with over 10,000 companies surveyed nationwide. The decrease in confidence suggests that Japan Inc is facing challenges, but no specific causes or forecasts for future economic performance are mentioned in the article.

site_title: Insurance broker JLT's FY underlying pretax profit falls 7%
summary: Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group Plc, an insurance broker, reported a 7% fall in full-year underlying pretax profit to £170.1 million, mainly due to investments in its US specialty business and challenges in its UK and Ireland employee benefits business. Total revenue rose 5% to £1.15 billion. The company's UK and Ireland Employee Benefits business saw a 9% decline in revenue, while its risk and insurance business grew 6%. JLT will pay a total cash dividend of 30.6p per share.

site_title: China launches two power trading exchanges
summary: China has launched two power trading exchanges in Beijing and Guangzhou, aiming to increase cross-regional trading and the use of clean power. The move is part of the government's efforts to free up electricity prices and eventually segregate the transmission and distribution businesses of state grid operators. This follows pilot reform programmes in seven provinces that allow generators to make sales deals directly with consumers, but some experts see the move as insufficient to reshape the sector.

site_title: SGX, chartered secretaries launch online tool to help spread out AGMs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Chartered Secretaries Institute of Singapore have launched an online calendar to reduce bunching in shareholder meeting schedules. The calendar allows companies to post tentative AGM dates, which can then be updated when finalised, and enables other companies to view these dates. The goal is to prevent clustered meetings, which may force investors to miss AGMs, particularly those with December fiscal year-ends. The move aims to promote active shareholder participation and aid investors and the market.

site_title: Taurus sees gold at US$1,400
summary: Gold prices are expected to surge to US$1,400 by the end of 2016, according to Taurus Wealth Advisors, citing central banks' limited firepower. The metal has already risen 17% this year, outperforming global equities and most corporate bonds. However, not everyone is bullish, with Goldman Sachs predicting a slump to US$1,000 due to expected US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Top execs urge boards to build strong risk culture
summary: Top executives in Singapore emphasized the need for boards to create a culture of risk awareness to protect their companies from unforeseen events. The 100 largest Singapore-listed companies improved their corporate governance standards, with SingTel and DBS Group Holdings ranking first in the region. Boards are urged to foster a proactive risk culture, moving beyond just compliance and considering a broader range of stakeholders. Companies should view risk as opportunities, rather than just avoiding it, to unlock its value creation potential.

site_title: French manufacturing activity stagnates in February
summary: French manufacturing activity stagnated in February, with a final Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 50.2, marginally lower than the previous month. Weak demand and budget restrictions at clients led to a decline in new orders, causing firms to cut production levels slightly. The downward pressure on inflation, as indicated by the survey's price indices, may not provide relief for the European Central Bank ahead of its Governing Council meeting next week.

site_title: Fitch further downgrades China Fishery ratings to 'restricted default'
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded China Fishery Group's issuer default rating to "restricted default" from "C" due to non-payment of a US$300 million senior note coupon, despite a 30-day grace period. The company is facing a cash crunch due to access to financing issues, but is in discussions with banks and creditors to obtain financing. A potential debt restructuring or sale of its Peruvian business could lead to a positive rating action, while a bankruptcy process could result in a further downgrade.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) has stated that shareholders of commodities trader Noble Group should not be concerned about allegations raised in Iceberg Research's latest report. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over US President Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for the MSCI's global equity index, and a Malaysian agency is set to seize about RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.1% in Q1: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices fell 0.1% in Q1 2016 compared to Q4 2015, according to flash estimates released by the Housing and Development Board. More detailed data will be released on April 22. The HDB plans to offer 4,000 build-to-order flats and 5,000 balance flats in May.

site_title: Smaller bonus takes UOB chief out of S$10m pay club
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong dropped out of the S$10-million pay club in 2015, with a 10% decrease in his bonus to S$9.22 million. His 2015 pay comprised of an unchanged salary of S$1.2 million and a lower variable bonus of S$8 million. This marks a contrast to his peers, DBS and OCBC, who received record bonuses in 2015.

site_title: US judge rejects Lehman workers' claims on stock awards
summary: US District Judge Richard Sullivan has rejected former Lehman Brothers employees' claims on $200 million or more in stock awards that became worthless after the company's 2008 bankruptcy. The judge ruled the awards should be classified as equity, subject to being wiped out, rather than as contract claims for cash payouts. The decision upholds a 2014 ruling by US Bankruptcy Judge Shelley Chapman, who oversees Lehman's Chapter 11 case.

site_title: Oil falls toward US$38 in New York after dollar's decline eases
summary: Oil prices fell to around $38 a barrel in New York after the dollar's decline eased, reducing crude's appeal as an investment. The US crude oil stockpile rose to its highest level since 1930, at 534.8 million barrels. The global benchmark crude, Brent, rose 12 cents to $39.26 a barrel. Oil prices had tumbled to a 12-year low earlier this year before rebounding on speculation of easing global surpluses as US output declines.

site_title: Singapore retail and office Reits expected to be resilient: Fitch
summary: Fitch expects Singapore retail and office Reits to remain resilient despite rising supply and weak demand. Key factors, such as low leverage and manageable debt, will help mitigate the impact. Retail Reits' earnings are likely to be limited due to rising vacancy rates, but lease renewals will be favorable. Office Reits face weaker demand and softer rents, but will see marginally positive rental reversions due to long-term revenue contracts and lower lease maturity rates.

site_title: America's not a poor country, Donald
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump claims the US is a "poor country" and should prioritize its own interests over overseas military commitments, including NATO support. This assertion is at odds with the country's actual wealth and economic power. The US is one of the world's wealthiest nations, with a strong economy and significant military presence. Trump's comments have sparked confusion in the markets and highlight the disconnect between his rhetoric and reality.

site_title: UOB offers card to woo millennials as StanChart courts affluent travellers
summary: Two Singaporean banks, UOB and Standard Chartered, have launched credit cards targeting millennials and affluent travellers, respectively. UOB aims to serve one in two millennials over the next three years, offering features such as priority access to bars and rebates on travel websites. Meanwhile, StanChart is targeting affluent travellers with a minimum annual income of S$150,000, offering 1.4 miles for every S$1 spent locally and 3 miles for every S$1 spent overseas. The banks' new offerings capitalize on data collected on their customers' spending habits.

site_title: Yahoo sets deadline for buyers to present preliminary bids: report
summary: Yahoo Inc has set a deadline of April 11 for prospective buyers to present preliminary bids for its assets, including its core web business or stakes in Alibaba or Yahoo Japan. The company, led by CEO Marissa Mayer, is seeking strategic alternatives after failing to show growth and struggling financially. Despite being one of the best-known internet names, Yahoo has fallen behind Google in internet searches and lost ground in online advertising. The company has narrowed its focus and reported a $4.43 billion loss in the final quarter of last year.

site_title: Fed's Williams sees 'huge impact' on US from China, Brazil
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated that China and Brazil's economies have a significant impact on US interest rates. The world's largest economy, China, is doing "quite well" with stable inflation and strong employment growth. The US economy grew at a faster pace than expected in the fourth quarter, increasing 1.4% compared to a prior estimate of 1%. This growth may influence US policy makers' decisions on interest rates, with China's slowing GDP growth and Brazil's economic impact also being closely watched.

site_title: From privileged life to bail on fraud charges
summary: Andrew Caspersen, a 39-year-old former Wall Street executive, was arrested and charged with securities and wire fraud for allegedly duping a hedge fund foundation of up to $95 million. Caspersen used a fraudulent investment vehicle and fake emails to deceive investors, including a foundation affiliated with a major New York hedge fund, into sinking $25 million into the scheme. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed parallel civil charges, and Park Hill Group, where Caspersen worked, fired him and cooperated with authorities. Caspersen's scheme highlights the issue of how much research and checking institutional investors do when making investments.

site_title: Kuroda backer Sakurai gets nod to join BOJ board
summary: The Japan's Lower House of Parliament approved Makoto Sakurai, a reflationist think-tank executive, to join the Bank of Japan's policy board, tipping the balance in favor of Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's stimulus push. Sakurai replaces Sayuri Shirai, who voted against the BOJ's negative interest rate decision. Sakurai's addition is seen as easing pressure on Kuroda, who secured a 6-4 vote in January to adopt the policy. The government nominee is likely to be approved by the Upper House, solidifying Kuroda's stance on monetary policy.

site_title: EXIM Bank's reawakening
summary: US Export-Import Bank (EXIM) chairman Fred P Hochberg successfully navigated the agency through a five-month lapse in funding in 2015, garnering support from the business community and lawmakers. EXIM, established in 1934, provides financing for US exports, filling gaps in the private sector, particularly for long-term projects and those exposed to political and regulatory risks. Despite criticism from free-market advocates, EXIM generated a surplus of $431.6 million in 2015 and has contributed $7 billion to government coffers over two decades. Hochberg argues that EXIM's role is to ensure a level playing field for US businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, and to support jobs at home. EXIM reauthorisation was passed in December 2015 through to 2019, but the bank's future remains uncertain with some Republican presidential candidates opposing the agency.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down on weaker oil prices
summary: Tokyo shares fell on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.13% and the Topix index dropping 0.30%, amid weaker oil prices. This follows losses on Wall Street. The decline is attributed to a dip in oil prices, which negatively impacted energy shares.

site_title: Eyeing future sales, luxury carmakers innovate to woo millennials
summary: British luxury carmaker Jaguar has developed a tool to attract millennials by creating a cinematic, 2-minute video of a prospective customer navigating a vehicle through challenging driving scenarios. The video is then emailed to the customer, allowing them to share it on social media. This innovative approach aims to win over younger customers who view traditional test drives as unexciting.

site_title: StarHub to take 9% stake in content producer mm2 Asia
summary: StarHub is acquiring a 9.05% stake in content producer mm2 Asia for S$18.04 million. This move is strategic for StarHub, allowing it to expand its pay TV offerings through original content creation. mm2 Asia, headquartered in Singapore, has a presence in Asia and has co-produced over 50 films. The partnership will also enable StarHub to tap into mm2's cineplex business and gain access to top-rated concerts and artistes. This collaboration is expected to enhance StarHub's content offerings and expand its reach in the region.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China Aviation Oil's target price is set at S$0.92, currently trading at S$0.79. Global aviation transportation remains solid, driven by 4.75% annual air traffic growth from 2015 to 2034. China's domestic civil aviation traffic is immune to the sluggish economy, growing at 10% per annum over the past two years.

site_title: Japan PM Abe: Will raise sales tax barring severe shock
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike to 10% in April 2027 unless the economy faces a severe shock. This decision comes despite weak consumption and exports threatening Japan's fragile economic recovery. Abe stated he is not considering dissolving parliament or calling a snap election, contradicting expectations of analysts who predict he may delay the tax hike.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Tuesday he will proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike next year unless the economy is hit by a shock on the scale of the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 or the massive earthquake that struck in 2011.

site_title: China's Xiaomi says has no plans to raise funds
summary: China's Xiaomi Inc, the world's fifth-largest smartphone vendor, has stated it is financially self-sufficient and has no plans to raise funds. According to global vice-president Hugo Barra, Xiaomi also does not intend to pursue an initial public offering. The company missed its global shipment target by 12% in the previous year, selling 70 million handsets despite local rivals achieving similar Internet-only sales.

site_title: ASX's Funke Kupper quits as exchange chief amid Tabcorp inquiry
summary: ASX Managing Director Elmer Funke Kupper resigned after 4 1/2 years, citing a need to focus on a potential probe into his former company Tabcorp Holdings Ltd. The investigation, launched by police, concerns Tabcorp's 2009 business opportunity in Cambodia. Chairman Rick Holliday-Smith will act as executive chairman until a replacement is found. Funke Kupper's departure comes amid Tabcorp's internal investigation, which may also impact the ASX.

site_title: Israeli firm helping FBI to open encrypted iPhone: report
summary: Israeli firm Cellebrite is helping the FBI unlock an encrypted iPhone used by a San Bernardino shooter, potentially ending the high-stakes legal battle with Apple. Cellebrite's mobile forensic software can retrieve data from devices, and its success could render Apple's assistance unnecessary. A federal judge had previously postponed a court hearing to allow a "third party" to present a possible method for opening the encrypted iPhone, which could bring an end to the data privacy debate.

site_title: Richmond Fed US factory index jumps to highest since 2010
summary: The Richmond Federal Reserve reported a significant increase in manufacturing activity in the lower US Atlantic region, with its composite factory index rising to +22 points in March, its highest level since 2010. This represents a recovery from its weakest level in six months, driven by improved activity in the District of Columbia, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, and parts of West Virginia. The rebound suggests a positive trend in the US manufacturing sector.

site_title: Football: Valls vows Euro 2016 will go ahead
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls vowed that the Euro 2016 football tournament will proceed as planned despite the Brussels terror bombings. He stated that not holding the event would be a "victory for terrorists." Valls pointed to the successful staging of the Cop 21 climate talks in Paris just days after a similar attack in Paris, where 130 people were killed.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Manuel Valls promised this summer's Euro 2016 football tournament would go ahead as planned in France despite the deadly terror bombings which rocked Brussels the previous day.

site_title: Oil trades near US$41 as US crude supplies seen rising amid glut
summary: Oil prices traded near $41 a barrel as US crude supplies rose amid a glut, with inventories likely increasing by 2.53 million barrels last week. This compares to industry data showing an 8.8 million barrel gain. Oil prices fell after a meeting between major oil exporters in Doha was canceled due to Libya's refusal to freeze output. Analysts say large US crude stockpiles will hinder price gains, but a potential output freeze could lead to a price rise. US crude stockpiles reached their highest level in over eight decades at 523.2 million barrels.

site_title: Paracetamol 'not effective' in treating osteoarthritis: study
summary: A study of 74 clinical trials covering nearly 60,000 patients found that paracetamol is not effective in treating osteoarthritis, a joint disorder affecting tens of millions of elderly people. Paracetamol was only marginally better than a dummy pill in alleviating pain or enhancing mobility. Diclofenac, a non-steroid anti-inflammatory drug, was found to be the most effective treatment for osteoarthritis. The study's results suggest that paracetamol is not a viable option for managing pain in osteoarthritis, contradicting its long-standing use as a pain reliever.

site_title: Rosberg beats Hamilton to win Australian GP
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Australian Grand Prix, his fourth straight victory, beating teammate Lewis Hamilton by 8 seconds. Sebastian Vettel finished third after a slow start and a tyre change. The incident-packed race saw Fernando Alonso walk away from a high-speed crash and Kimi Raikkonen's Ferrari catch fire in the pit lane. Rosberg's dominant strategy and Hamilton's slow start gave him the win, with Vettel's Ferrari struggling on the super-softs.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees risk from Bangladesh heist scandal
summary: The Philippine central bank warns of a risk to the local financial system due to the Bangladesh heist scandal, where $81 million was stolen from the central bank's US Federal Reserve account. Governor Amando Tetangco calls for lifting secrecy on bank deposits and strengthening anti-money laundering rules. Deputy Governor Nestor Espenilla expresses concern over domestic banks' ability to avoid criminal money. The incident has raised concerns about the potential for illicit funds to enter the Philippine financial system.

site_title: The academic perspective
summary: LSE director Craig Calhoun expresses concerns about capitalism's side effects, citing financial market risks, inequality, and climate change. He advocates for more regulation, transparency, and state engagement to address these issues. Calhoun also highlights the gap between the rich and poor, which has widened in recent decades, and the need for more scholarships and outreach programs to promote diversity. As an academic leader, he emphasizes the role of researchers in providing knowledge and analysis to improve debates and policy-making. Calhoun has established cross-disciplinary research institutes at LSE to study global issues, including inequality and climate change. He will soon become president of the Berggruen Institute think-tank, focusing on improving political governance and cross-cultural understanding.

site_title: Gloom deepens in VW's home town, six months after 'Dieselgate'
summary: Volkswagen's hometown of Wolfsburg, Germany, is facing a prolonged period of economic hardship six months after the "Dieselgate" scandal. The company's reputation and financial stability are at risk, with workers fearing job losses and a decline in municipal finances. Deliveries have rebounded, but the overall mood remains gloomy, with many attributing the situation to the lack of a clear plan to fix the emissions issue and the uncertainty surrounding US fines. The company's leadership, including former CEO Martin Winterkorn, is visibly dejected, and Moody's has downgraded its outlook for Volkswagen's future earnings and cash flows.

site_title: Mixed trends in luxury collectibles
summary: Luxury collectibles have experienced mixed trends, with some assets, such as vintage watches and luxury handbags, holding up well, while others, like diamonds and fine wine, are struggling. A major reason for this is the correlation with China, where a crackdown on conspicuous spending has impacted the market. Chinese collectors have driven prices up for art, luxury cars, and fine wine, but also contributed to the decline of other collectibles, such as diamonds and antique furniture. As China's economic influence continues to grow, investors may need to consider its impact on their portfolios.

site_title: China central bank queries banks on medium-term lending facility demand, cuts MLF rates: sources
summary: China's central bank queried banks on their demand for the medium-term lending facility, a tool to adjust liquidity in the banking system. The People's Bank of China cut rates by 25 basis points to 2.5% for 3-month loans, 2.6% for 6-month loans, and 2.75% for 1-year loans. The move aims to manage liquidity and support the banking system. The central bank did not provide an immediate comment.

site_title: China to look at free trade, rail deal with Nepal
summary: China agreed to consider building a railway into Nepal and start a feasibility study for a free trade agreement, aiming to lessen Nepal's dependence on India. Nepal's Prime Minister K.P. Oli discussed strengthening relations with China and proposed two rail lines connecting major cities. The two countries signed 10 agreements, including a rail plan, a free trade feasibility study, and a concessional loan for a new airport. China plans to extend its railway from Shigatse to Gyirong on the Nepal border, with a potential future connection between the two countries.

site_title: Nintendo's new social app Miitomo a hit in Japan
summary: Nintendo's social app Miitomo reached No. 1 among social-networking apps in Japan on its release, surpassing Line. The app, available only in Japan, allows users to create cartoon-like avatars and interact with friends, earning virtual coins and rewards. Miitomo is part of Nintendo's effort to bring back players who migrated to smartphones, with plans to release five mobile games by March 2017. The app's success has boosted Nintendo's share price 33% last year, with analysts praising the brand's relevancy in the smartphone age.

site_title: American Airlines plays hardball over Wi-Fi
summary: American Airlines is engaged in a dispute with Wi-Fi provider Gogo over the quality and pricing of in-flight internet services. The airline cited a clause in its contract that allows it to switch vendors if a competing offer is made. Gogo responded by announcing a competing proposal, which could lead to faster and cheaper connections for passengers. Industry experts believe this "arms race" will ultimately benefit travelers, with alternative providers offering more reliable and affordable services.

site_title: Oil prices rebound as producers agree to April meeting
summary: Oil prices surged as producers agreed to meet in April to limit output, overshadowing a US oil inventory build. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 5.8% to $38.46 a barrel, while Brent North Sea oil gained 4.1% to $40.33 a barrel. The meeting, backed by 15 countries accounting for 73% of global oil output, aims to stabilize the market and potentially freeze oil production at current levels. Iran has indicated its readiness to participate, and the market views the meeting as a crucial step towards production cuts later in the year.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday after Wall Street slips
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 4.54 points or 0.16% to 2,804.58, as US stocks slipped on Thursday due to mixed corporate reports and declining crude prices. Brent crude futures dropped to $40.05 per barrel, while US crude settled at $37.84 per barrel. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments on no further rate cuts also weighed on the market. Trading volume was moderate, with 69.3 million shares changing hands at 9:01 am on Friday.

site_title: Mariah Carey to turn life into reality television series
summary: Mariah Carey is set to star in an eight-part reality television series, Mariah's World, on E! network, which will follow her upcoming tour and marriage. The series will be a behind-the-scenes look at her personal and professional life. Carey's soaring five-octave range and global recognition make her a captivating figure, according to Jeff Olde, executive vice-president for programming and development at E!. The series is expected to premiere soon, although a specific release date has not been announced.

site_title: Import prices in February fall for 8th straight month
summary: US import prices fell 0.3% in February for the 8th straight month, with the decline slowing as the US dollar's rally fades and oil prices stabilize. The pace of decline is expected to end as the dollar's appreciation loses steam, potentially leading to rising import prices and propelling domestic inflation. This comes as the US dollar strengthened about 0.9% on a trade-weighted basis this year, while oil prices also show signs of stabilization.

site_title: Majority of S'poreans back Founders' Memorial
summary: A majority of Singaporeans (8 in 10) support building a founders' memorial to honor the country's founding leaders and ideals. The committee prefers Gardens by the Bay's Bay East Garden over Fort Canning Park for the memorial, citing its forward-looking narrative, open atmosphere, and accessibility. The memorial is expected to evoke pride, unity, and inspiration, while recognizing the values of multi-racialism, resilience, and determination. The committee hopes to see the memorial built within the next decade, pending government approval.

images.alt_text: Eight in 10 Singaporeans polled favour building a founders' memorial to mark the values and ideals that underpin Singapore's rise.

site_title: Volkswagen hit by new investor lawsuits in Germany, claims top 5b euros
summary: Volkswagen faces new lawsuits in Germany over its emissions-cheating scandal, with investors seeking over 5 billion euros in damages and interest. Two law firms have filed claims on behalf of shareholders, adding to the 3 billion euros already claimed by 278 plaintiffs. The company has repeatedly denied knowledge of the full extent of the scandal, but investors argue it should have informed stock owners earlier. The scandal has plunged the company into its deepest crisis, with shares plummeting 40% in the days following the scandal's revelation in September 2015.

site_title: Brexit could lead to higher air fares: study
summary: A study commissioned by the Association of British Travel Agents found that a Brexit could lead to increased air fares and uncertainties for travel businesses and the public. Deloitte's report warned that low-cost operators with smaller margins could be hardest hit, threatening budget flights to the EU. The study also noted that a Brexit could jeopardize trade and travel between Britain and mainland Europe, causing uncertainty and potential price hikes for foreign travel.

site_title: Tokyo: Equities fall as investors await Bank of Japan review
summary: Japanese stocks fell 0.2% to 1,377.31 ahead of a Bank of Japan review, with investors awaiting a potential policy decision. Most economists surveyed forecast the BOJ to keep policy unchanged, citing concerns over the Japanese economy's worsening state. The review coincides with the Federal Reserve's rate decision on Wednesday, as investors question the potency of central bank intervention.

site_title: China parents paying top dollar for properties that come with school rights
summary: In Beijing, China, wealthy parents are paying nearly $600,000 for a 13-square-meter room with no basic amenities, solely for the right to enroll their child in a top-rated local school. This trend is driven by the perceived value of access to quality education, with the room's owners willing to overlook the space's poor conditions. The phenomenon highlights the high demand for exclusive educational opportunities in China, where parental status and social standing are closely tied to the quality of their children's education.

site_title: Jang wins HSBC Women's Champions
summary: Ha Na Jang won the HSBC Women's Champions golf tournament, moving up to world No 5 on the Rolex Rankings. Jang, 23, finished at 19-under-par after a final round of 7-under-par 65, four shots ahead of Pornanong Phatlum. This is Jang's second win of the year, following her previous victory in the Coates Championship.

site_title: Demand isn't factor holding women back from joining boards
summary: Japan's efforts to increase women's participation in the workforce and corporate boards have shown modest progress, with the number of female directors rising 70% in the latest fiscal year to 2.7% of all company boards. Despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's initiatives, deeply rooted obstacles such as a narrow pipeline of female director candidates, limited management experience, and societal attitudes persist. Experts predict significant changes may take another 5-10 years, emphasizing the need for women to take an active role in driving change and overcoming these barriers.

images.alt_text: "It's not politically correct anymore to oppose putting women on corporate boards, even in Japan," says Ms Fukushima.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says inflation expectations fall shows need for low rates
summary: New Zealand's central bank stated that falling inflation expectations necessitate low interest rates. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) Assistant Governor John McDermott noted that a significant decline in inflation expectations poses a concern for monetary policy. The RBNZ recently cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 2.25% and signaled further rate cuts. If inflation expectations continue to decline, the bank may reassess interest rate outlook.

site_title: Empowering future leaders
summary: SAP CEO Bill McDermott aims to make SAP the most relevant business software company in the world, positioning it as the "Apple, Facebook, and Google" of its space. He plans to achieve this by expanding the company into new markets, particularly in Asia, where SAP's revenue is currently lower than in other regions. McDermott wants to create a multicultural and multilingual company, leveraging the entrepreneurial spirit and determination of local teams while maintaining a strong global presence. He also prioritizes empowering employees, including millennials, and building a successful succession plan to ensure the company's long-term growth.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares see winning streak end, NZ hits another record
summary: Australian shares ended a week-long winning streak, falling 34.8 points, or 0.7%, to 5,108.0, its first decline in seven sessions. New Zealand shares rose to a new record, with the S&P/NZX 50 index adding 27.8 points, or 0.4%, to 6,446.7, for the fourth consecutive day. The decline in Australia was attributed to investors taking profits on banks and miners, while New Zealand's benchmark index continued its upward trend.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic growth is unlikely to reach 3.3% until 2018, according to ICAEW's report, with domestic non-oil exports and manufacturing sectors expected to remain subdued. Office rents may decline by up to 25% in a prolonged slump, and Noble Group is seeking major funding without asset sales. Meanwhile, Maybank expects to grow its retail SME loan portfolio by 40% this year, and Alibaba's logistics arm has completed a fundraising round. Morgan Stanley forecasts a surge in US bond yields in 2016, and Singapore shares rose 0.6% today.

images.alt_text: DOMESTIC non-oil exports - and hence the manufacturing sector - are expected to remain subdued over the coming year, according to ICAEW's latest "Economic Insight: South East Asia" report.

site_title: Global group targets 25% cut in deficient audits
summary: A global audit quality group, led by the International Forum of Independent Audit Regulators, aims to reduce the number of deficient audits by at least 25% in four years. The initiative, agreed upon by six major audit firms, follows a 2015 survey that found 43% of listed public interest entity audits had inspection findings. Despite a 4-point drop, the group is unsatisfied with progress, citing deficiencies in internal control testing, fair value measurement, and risk assessment. The move is seen as a step towards improving audit quality and investor confidence.

site_title: China's growth addiction leaves deleveraging in back seat
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang has outlined plans for economic growth, focusing on a 6.5-7% growth rate for 2016, with a record high deficit and increased money supply expansion. The government aims to clean up the environment, boost innovation, and cut excess capacity, but debt growth is expected to rise to 258% of GDP, despite slower growth. The focus on supporting short-term growth has led to concerns that deleveraging efforts may be delayed, potentially exacerbating structural problems.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries' share price has risen 35% since its January report highlighting the undervaluation of its utilities segment, driven by investors seeking opportunities to buy beaten-down shares. The company's long-term prospects remain positive, despite a potential breather in the near term. Del Monte Pacific's share price has also been maintained at a "Hold" recommendation with a higher target price, despite a slower-than-expected earnings turnaround. The company's Asia-Pacific operations performed well, but US operations declined due to lost government and OEM contracts.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks up after US jobs data, profit-taking erases gains
summary: The South Korean won rose for a sixth consecutive session against the US dollar, reaching 1,201.4 to the dollar, driven by upbeat US jobs data seen as positive for the global economy. South Korean shares also gained 0.2% to 1,957.87 points, despite profit-taking, amid broad risk-on sentiment.

site_title: Hopeless and broke, some Afghan migrants return from Europe
summary: A small number of Afghan migrants, including 26-year-old Mohammed Asif, are returning to their war-torn country after being disillusioned with their experiences in Europe. Asif and others were forced to endure "nightmarish" refugee centers and faced hostility and economic struggles. A chartered plane brought 135 disillusioned Afghan refugees back from Germany, with more likely to follow. The crisis has left many with false hopes of a better life in Europe, and authorities are struggling to cope with the influx of asylum seekers.

site_title: Noble completes sale of Noble Agri
summary: NOBLE Group has completed the sale of its remaining stake in Noble Agri for US$750 million, with the proceeds to be used for debt repayment.

site_title: Europe: China fails to stimulate stocks
summary: European stocks ended the day with losses of less than half a percentage point, despite Chinese government stimulus aimed at boosting economic growth. The stimulus failed to address concerns over recent market gains and did little to ease doubts over new eurozone stimulus. The Bank of International Settlements warned of a "gathering storm" on global markets, dampening sentiment. Asian stocks, however, began the week in a buoyant mood, driven by strong US job creation and China's decision to lower its growth target.

site_title: Carrefour to step up spending on stores in Europe and China
summary: Carrefour, the world's second-largest retailer, plans to increase investments in Europe and China this year to renovate and open stores, aiming to turn around its business in Europe and revive weak sales in China. The company will invest 2.5-2.6 billion euros in store renovations and expansions, up from 2.4 billion last year. Operating profit rose 2.4% in Europe and 33.4% in Latin America, but declined 6.4% in France. Carrefour is also waiting for the right time to float its Carmila property unit, which analysts estimate to be worth at least 4 billion euros.

site_title: As Malaysia central bank chief exits, successor remains mystery
summary: Malaysia's central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz is set to leave her position after 16 years, with her last interest-rate decision looming on Wednesday. Despite turmoil surrounding her leadership, economists predict no change to the benchmark rate of 3.25%. The uncertainty over her replacement has raised concerns among investors, with some fearing a lack of central banking experience. The prime minister has given no indication of who will succeed her, leaving the succession process unclear.

site_title: Petronas threatens to walk away from Canada LNG project: report
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas threatens to abandon its proposed $37.43 billion Pacific NorthWest LNG project in Canada if the Canadian government doesn't approve it by March 31, 2016. The project, backed by major Asian energy companies, faces uncertainty due to the government's plans to increase environmental reviews for major energy projects. Petronas has already spent $12 billion on the project and won't accept additional hurdles from the federal Cabinet. The project's economic feasibility has been challenged by a favorable oil-linked LNG price environment.

site_title: SPDR STI most active ETF in the month-to-date
summary: The SPDR Straits Times Index (STI) ETF was the most active ETF in the month-to-date, reflecting the recovery in Singapore stocks, which have gained almost 11% over the last four weeks. The STI has recouped nearly all its losses since the start of the year, with global equity markets also rebounding. The MSCI All Country World Index has recovered more than half this year's losses, driven by improving US economic data and increased stimulus in China.

site_title: Flying high with Major Tom
summary: Airbus chief Thomas Enders remains optimistic about the future despite headwinds in the global economy. The company achieved a record 1,080 net orders for commercial planes last year, surpassing Boeing. Airbus plans to ramp up deliveries to over 650 jets this year, with revenue and net income projected to remain stable. Enders believes the company can survive with fewer than 1,000 orders per year. Airbus is focusing on growth in the Asia-Pacific region, where it expects to contribute 40% of its revenue in 10-20 years. The company is also investing in innovation, digitization, and talent acquisition from Asia to drive growth and remain competitive.

site_title: Get set for deflation, muted job growth, social unrest
summary: Global economies are facing a "deflationary spiral" with muted job growth and social unrest, according to a recent article. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 3% after the G-20 meeting, highlighting the challenges of containing deflation. The article draws parallels between Japan's "lost decades" and China's current economic situation, warning that policymakers must address the issue of deflation. A coordinated fiscal policy response is seen as crucial, but the article suggests that China's current strategy, similar to Japan's, may exacerbate the problem. Without action, the article concludes that the world may be prepared for deflation, stagnation, and social unrest.

site_title: Oil below US$37 as US inventory rise counters output freeze plan
summary: Oil prices fell below $37 a barrel on Wednesday as US crude inventories rose to a record 9.9 million barrels, contradicting efforts by producers to freeze output and address a supply glut. Global benchmark Brent crude was down 19 cents at $36.62 a barrel, while US crude fell 35 cents to $34.05. Despite Opec's plan to freeze production, analysts believe prices may not drop further, with some speculating that prices have bottomed.

site_title: Rig incident renews concerns over SembMarine's backlog
summary: A recent incident at SembCorp Marine's yard in Singapore damaged the Noble Lloyd Noble jack-up rig under construction, causing minor damage and potentially delaying its delivery in the second quarter of 2016. The incident has raised concerns over SembCorp Marine's backlog and rig-building track record, with analysts predicting the company may need to record provisions for worker compensation and damage repair. The rig's owner, Noble Corporation, has expressed confidence that the damage can be redressed ahead of the target delivery date, but the incident may impact market confidence and potentially lead to contract termination.

site_title: US oil & Gas liquidity stress at worst-ever level: Moody's
summary: US oil and gas companies face the worst-ever liquidity stress, with Moody's rating agency's "Oil & Gas Liquidity Stress Index" reaching a record high of 27.2% in February. This surpasses the previous high of 24.5% during the 2009 recession. The agency downgraded 19 energy companies' ratings, with 17 being exploration and production firms, and expects the default rate to rise as the year progresses. The high liquidity stress is driven by the prolonged weakness in energy sector credit conditions due to the steep fall in global crude prices.

site_title: Big pharma's China dream meets reality of price-cutting campaign
summary: China's government-run health insurance funds are capping payments to patients due to tight budgets, leading to a slowdown in sales growth for major pharmaceutical companies, including Pfizer. The move, part of a state-led campaign to slash drug prices, has resulted in lower reimbursements to patients and increased pressure on companies to negotiate lower prices with local authorities. This development poses a significant challenge for big pharma's "China dream" of expanding its market share in the country.

images.alt_text: The world's largest pharmaceutical companies are facing a roadblock in China as a state-led campaign to slash drug prices has triggered a slowdown in sales growth.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso secures contracts worth S$33m
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings secured S$33.3 million worth of contracts from January 1, 2016, for foundation and geoservices work, including projects at Changi Airport and HDB estates. The company's net order book stood at S$135.3 million as of December 31, 2015. CEO Ong Tiong Siew expressed optimism for more contracts in 2016, citing a healthy level of public and infrastructure projects.

site_title: A New Dawn
summary: Rolls-Royce has unveiled the Dawn, a super-luxurious open-top convertible in South-east Asia. The four-seater model features a 6.6-litre V12 engine producing 570 hp, with enhanced dynamic accelerator pedal mapping. The Dawn starts at S$1,468,888 and boasts features like a Rotary Controller with finger-writing capabilities. The vehicle's CO2 emissions stand at 330 g/km, and it has a top speed of 250 km/h. Deliveries are expected to begin in May, targeting high-end buyers in the region.

site_title: Beijing dreams of high-speed railway link with rivals in Taipei
summary: China is studying a proposal for a high-speed railway link between the mainland and Taiwan, with the Taiwanese capital, Taipei, as a potential rail destination by 2030. The project would face significant political challenges, given the long-standing separation between Taiwan and the mainland, and the potential for increased tensions. China's government has referred to the idea in its 2016-20 development plan, but has not provided further details. The proposal has sparked concerns about national security and public opinion, and would require cooperation from Taiwan's government, currently led by President-elect Tsai Ing-wen.

site_title: Buying by directors loses steam
summary: Singapore directors' buying activity fell for the first time in four weeks, with 18 companies making 30 purchases worth S$6.77 million, down from 28 firms and S$17.14 million in the previous week. The market's sharp rebound this month likely contributed to the decline. Despite this, several directors, including CEOs and joint chairmen, continued to buy shares at higher prices, with some increasing their holdings by up to 25.58% or 8.28%. The buying activity was driven by the rebound in the market, with companies such as Combine Will International, Avi-Tech Electronics, and Sunningdale Tech seeing significant price increases.

site_title: United faces shareholder revolt as CEO returns
summary: Two large shareholders, Altimeter Capital Management and PAR Capital Management, have accused United Continental's board of doing too little to improve performance, launching a proxy battle. They proposed a slate of six board candidates, including former Continental Airlines CEO Gordon Bethune, citing "long-term underperformance" at the airline. The shareholders criticized the board's efforts to engage with investors and accused the company of appointing three new directors without a stockholder vote. United Continental shares were down 1.2% at midday. CEO Oscar Munoz is set to return to work full-time on March 14 after a heart attack.

images.alt_text: A pair of large shareholders in United Continental accused the US airline's board on Tuesday of doing too little to improve performance and announced plans to launch a proxy battle.

site_title: Rebound in January factory orders points to easing in manufacturing slump
summary: US factory orders rose 1.6% in January, the largest increase in seven months, after a 2.9% drop in December. This follows two months of declines and suggests the manufacturing sector may be nearing an easing of its slump. Orders for transportation equipment jumped 11.4% and non-defence capital goods rose 3.4%. Inventories fell for a seventh straight month, but the improvement in sentiment among manufacturers and solid gains in industrial production in January indicate the worst of the factory slump may be over.
